description:
My friend and I needed to get of Sacramento for a day so we decided to drive out to the city and go to the zoo. When we first arrived at 12:30pm, we entered the pay parking lot and literally drove around for 30 minutes trying to get a spot. We weren't so lucky. However, we had other plans as well so we decided to do the other stuff first and return at a later time since they closed at 7pm today (this isn't normal, apparently. They close at 5pm).

We returned around 2:30pm and luckily there were plenty of spots! Yaya! We were able to find a spot close to the entrance. After we parked, we walked up to the ticket booth and there was no line. Double yaya! We were greeted by a friendly employee who helped us with getting tickets. For the two of us plus parking, we spent about $50; not bad. Then we walked up to the employee who took checked our tickets then we were off! 

This was our first time at the zoo and we honestly didn't know where we were going, luckily there was a big map bu the entrance. Now, my friend likes physical maps so she can check things off her list so we walked back up to the employee who took our tickets to see of they had any papers maps. The nice employee informed us that back in March of 2018, the zoo decided to get rid of the maps since they were a waste of paper and back for the environment. Great initiative, but bad for us. While there were not maps for us to gran, we noticed that on the side of the big map there was a sign that says "snap the map" or something like that. Pretty much advising us to take a picture of the map; great! 

Then we were off! There was a lot too see and I did not expect the zoo that big. It had a lot of exhibits and animals for us to check out. I have to say my favorite was the red panda! So cute. It took us about 2 and a half hours to get through everything, but we also stopped to grab a quick snack at one of the food places in the zoo. The food prices were expected; typical "amusement"park prices (that was an fyi; not a complaint. Just saying hehe). And, the gift shop had a lot of cute stuff so you'll definitely want to check it out before you leave. 

This is a great place for families with kids, and well pretty much anyone. It's right by the beach so when you're done visiting the zoo just walk across the street and enjoy the views. Great experience, clean zoo, cute animals = awesome experience. Highly recommend paying a visit. However, if the lot is full, there should be a sign or someone directing traffic as parking was a nightmare.
author: Misty T.

description:
This is a nice mid-sized zoo, and it is great for kids.  We found it clean and convenient, if a little bit cold.

There's a good variety of animals, and generally, the enclosures seemed adequate.  We did feel like some of the large cats and the wolves could have used more space, but presumably experts determined that this worked.

My son loved the train.  Great photo opportunities abound.  There's a huge play area also, but playgrounds are plentiful in San Francisco, so I wouldn't go to the zoo just for the playground.

Parking is $10 on weekdays, $12 on weekends.
author: michelle l.

description:
Good place for little kids and elders too.
Fun filled activities like the train ride, carousel for little ones and parents too.
Fun for whole family.
Clean and nice zoo.
Wonder placeto visit
author: Shefi A.

description:
Be ware of cafe playfiled. Food is a ripoff and they are not serving what they advertised. The Nacho Dog does not have a hotdog or bun. It is just a Nachos.
They should be ashamed of their behavior..
author: Alan K.

description:
We came here last Saturday to escape the Sacramento heat and smoky air. The kids haven't been to a zoo in a while, this one was near Sacramento, so not so far of a drive for us. Have good walking shoes on! Get ready to spend at least 3-4 hours here! 

The weather was beautiful! Nice, sunny, and cool. Not too hot and not too cold. We saw lots of animals. I was happy that we got to see majority of the animals out and about. Half of them were sleeping, but it was expected. 

The kids loved to see all the animals in their habitat! The habitats were nice, clean, and roomy. They did a great job keeping everything clean for the animals! They've got a train ride for $6 per person, kids under 2 were free. You get to ride around the park twice! The kids really enjoyed that!

I love it that we could bring in our own food and drinks! They are not sticklers on that. I like to bring in our own snacks and foods, just another healthier alternative to their everyday fast food items. There were plenty of benches and tables around the park! They even have a playground area for the kids! It was a nice ending after seeing all the animals. There were three areas for the kids to run around in. They even have a toddler area for little ones to play in. The parents could relax while the kids play. 

All in all, it was a great day! We will definitely be back.
author: Daisy T.

description:
Average Zoo (trending upwards), below average food. 

The zoo itself is old but they've done a great job refurbishing and building new exhibits. I've been going here since I was a kid and I can honestly say that it's never been better in terms of animal care and exhibits quality. It will only get better over time IMO.

Re: The food: I'm not sure I understand why all the food options at this zoo are so bad. I fully understand that many of the visitors come from all over the area and not just interested in urban foodie trends/hotspots. I get it, tastes vary. But to only have 3 main food items to choose from (pizza, hot dogs and burgers) in a city that prides itself on quality food choices just strikes me as really half assed. Would it kill them to add a deli with more of variety of food options (salads/sandos/etc.? I'm sure it would be profitable. Hell, just add a deli counter that makes made to order sandwiches (i.e. just like the new food court at the Oakland zoo). Instead, they force families to either eat outside the zoo or bring a huge picnic with them in order to avoid buying the expensive and low grade food they offer.
author: Darin E.

description: Amazing Zoo The Tigers put on a show for us it was a great day they were Absolutely Awesome. Also the giraffes looked so happy while they were eating breakfast.
author: Diana A.

description: My friends and I came here on our weekend trip to San Francisco, tired of doing touristy stuff in a city mired by protestors and eager to escape the cacophony of urban life, we decided to check out the zoo. We haven't been to a zoo in a while so this was quite a refreshing encounter with the animals. Though this zoo isn't as big as some of the other ones I've been to, the animals are in nice enclosures that seem spacious, comfortable and also provide a interactive environment for them. Unlike some other zoos where the animals seem to be languishing or hiding somewhere, the ones here seem to be quite active even though it was in the afternoon when I thought they'd be napping lol. When we were here we saw the hippo taking a bath, the tiger growled, the lion rouse from his place on the highest rock to regard us with his majesty before laying back down again. We also saw some baby snow leopards playing in their glass enclosures. Nothing beats coming to a zoo with interactive and inquisitive  animals because imho curiosity means they're healthy and doing well! Props to SF zoo, keep up the excellent job!
author: Natalie Y.

description: Love, love, loved the San Francisco Zoo! This was by far my best zoo experience. You are so close to the animals and there are tons more animals here than most zoos. They also have a train and the souviner shop was amazing!!!
author: Sunshine H.

description:
Great zoo which is often overlooked. This is smaller than Oakland but packs a punch and is in a great location by the ocean. The day I went...it was not too hot or too busy which worked out well. Saw the grizzly feeding which was awesome. Check out the coolest ever hammock in the park. The tarantula exhibit was just meh.

Nice to see a lot of local kids volunteering their time. You can plan to spend at least 4-5 hours here.
author: Sunil R.

description:
Hands down the most beautiful zoo I've ever visited.

I'm from L.A., & the zoo over here is just sad. Animals are cramped into such small enclosures, they hardly look alive.

So when my family & I took a trip to San Fran, we were curious to see what the zoo was like down by the bay.

It's beautiful! From the entrance, to the gift shop, down to the animal enclosures themselves. It's completely different in every way, shape, & form.

The animals here were active, they look, dare I say, HAPPY. Their enclosures are LARGE, & most of the animals were rescues. Take the rhino, for, example, as it was rescued and rehabilitated after poachers stole his horn.

Throughout our visit, the penguins were swimming, & literally leaping out of the water, the snow leopard was gnawing at a big hunk of meat right by the glass, & we witnessed a cub bear wrestling and playing with it's mother.

The caretakers seem as though they thoroughly enjoy working with these animals, they wore smiles from ear-to-ear & were very attentive.

It's different out here by the bay! They know what they're doing!

A BIG plus was the kids' play area. That alone was worth the price of admission. It's HUUUUGE. With a total of 4 different play stations, our kids burned themselves out running around pretending to be animals.

I loved this zoo. The price was right, it was CLEAN (a big + for this OCD Mom), it was fun, & most importantly, the kids loved it.

Oh! Just watch out for those apes. During our visit, one decided to poop in it's hands & flick it towards the crowd.
Yeah... I'll watch them behind the glass thank you very much! lol. 

Hope to be back again soon!
author: Leslie A.

description:
Great place to enjoy it with the family.
I let animals to see make you feel like you and Africa
author: Gonzalo T.

description:
Nice mid-sized zoo - we spent 5 hours and saw everything; catching several talks and feedings and having lunch.  Going on a weekday in July - light crowds.

If you plan it right, you can catch a good number of either animal feedings or keeper talks.  We saw penguin feeding at 10:30, then the wolverine was just around the corner for an 11:00 talk.  Later in the afternoon, we caught the mandrill feeding at 2:00 - then over to the lion keeper talk at 2:30.  

There are several distinct sections; some separated by enough trees that you wouldn't realize where things are in the rest of the zoo.  Sections are an African savanna, a primate area, a big cat area (with other African animals close by), a short South American section, a bear section, a small Australian section, a HUGE playground (kids could spend hours here), and a general explore with small animals where you can pet goats, get people talking about animals who were brought out, and have an insect area.

Nothing is a far walk.  There are about 4 food places; the lemur cafe in the center is the best.  

Some of the exhibits are top notch (lemur island is fantastic, the penguin pool is amazing).  Others look like they date back 30 years and could use an upgrade.  Yet, overall, there's nothing that is in bad shape; and most is well laid out with enough room for animals to roam.

Besides the animals, I mentioned the HUGE playground, there's a carousel, a small train that doesn't go far - but is great for small kids, a couple butterfly gardens, and a theater for shows.

We took public transportation from downtown SF: took about 40 minutes.  Right off the ocean; cool breezes.
author: Dave C.

description: I enjoy going to the San Francisco to see the animals who may behave better than some humans hanging at the Civic Center plaza. I enjoyed seeing the Koala awake which is rare since they are nocturnal creatures. I also enjoy the monkeys. This one of my favorite places in San Francisco.
author: Juan V.

description: This zoo is alright...all the major wildlife animals like lions and tigers are usually hiding, so it's kinda disappointing. It isn't too crowded, so that's a plus, but I thought it was kinda boring because the cool animals didn't make their appearance.
author: Jeff H.

description:
My boyfriend and I weren't even planning on coming to the SF Zoo during our trip, but I'm so glad we did! 

We saw signs for it at the Fisherman's Wharf and had a few extra hours before our anniversary dinner, so we thought, why not?

It's $20 per adult to get in and $10 to park. I think the parking fee was steep but that seems to be a theme in California so I guess I can't really deduce much on that. The ticket attendant was super nice and let us know to buy a zoo membership in our hometown because discount prices tend to cross over to other zoos across the country! We have a baby on the way so zoos seem like something we'll be at a lot in the future, so we're definitely going to take his advice.

The zoo itself was set up really nice. Maps were easy to follow and even when we weren't near an exhibit there was something to look at. They have several gardens located on the premises with gorgeous plants and flowers. 

All of the exhibits seem to be very well-kept and there's so many animals to see! It was a gorgeous day, so we got lucky with most of the animals being out and active.

P.S. They have peacocks roaming the grounds... Those birds SCARE ME (childhood trauma) but others seemed to really enjoy them walking around.

My favorite was definitely the otter and the hippo. The otter was so playful and RESPONSIVE to us, which was so weird to see! 

I'm so glad we got to check this zoo out. Was a great addition to our anniversary day!
author: Lauren P.

description:
My friends and I visited the San Francisco Zoo during our quick trip to the Bay Area, it was a fun venture, and it was very memorable. For context, the only other zoo I have ever visited was the Fresno Zoo in my hometown, and I have to say that the San Francisco Zoo proved to be much better and more enjoyable.

I'm not someone who's very passionate about learning  or looking at animals in general, so I'll be very honest when I say that I wasn't expecting much from this trip. However, man am I glad that I was wrong.

The group I came with were major animal enthusiasts, so they literally would just drag me around to all the exhibits they wanted to see. I could tell they were having a huge blast, seeing the wildlife that we don't have the opportunity of seeing back in the Fresno Zoo.  

My friends went crazy for the bug exhibit that offered a huge variety of insects to look at, we also loved the farm animal exhibit that even let us pet some of the animals there as well, such as the sheep and goats. My personal favorite exhibit  was the one where guests could see various animals up close, and be allowed to pet them, while a volunteer would tell us interesting facts about that animal as well. I thought it was something really interesting to see as the Fresno Zoo didn't have an exhibit like that.

The San Francisco zoo was so large that my friends and I didn't have the time to explore the entire place even if we wanted too! What I loved about this zoo in particular was the fact that it had a restaurant offering a large variety of food that we could eat, several themed playground areas where children could run around and play, several animal exhibits, as well as a pretty decently sized gift shop to grab some goodies. 

If there was one thing that this zoo would definitely need, however, and would largely benefit from, it would be specialized tours that would drive around the entire zoo. 

In the end, the San Francisco Zoo was an enjoyable place to visit, even for someone like me who isn't the most passionate about animals in general, will definitely visit again when we go back to the Bay Area.
author: Rhiamae L.

description:
This is the best zoo I've never been to, period. Everyone who works here is friendly and very helpful. The layout of the zoo promotes a healthy walking and learning environment. It's very clean and the animals appear very well taken care of. We also stopped to eat lunch- if you're used to lame, overpriced, icky food, you're in for a surprise! It's all very well prepared and tastes great. 
We come to the Bay Area every year for Thanksgiving week and will definitely be back for another experience.
author: Holly F.

description: Great zoo located across from the beach front!  Very spaced out ! Great kids play area! And lots of bathroom for my potty training toddler!
author: Adrianna N.

description:
I had a Great experience at the zoo today. 

My trip highlights were watching the langurs play non stop, tiger walking majestically, penguins swimming in a group as if they were choreographed, beautiful two horned bongo, black bears playing! 

I saw pink flamingos, hippo, one horn rhino, red panda(super cute), Komodo dragon to name a few first time.

Animal theater show was fun, learnt local animals and birds and after the show got to touch a ball python which was a good experience! 

Tropical forest was so real. 

The zoo also has a pretty huge play area for kids. 

Thank you SF zoo for a wonderful experience.
author: Dee S.

description:
One of my coworkers had her baby shower at The San Francisco Zoo. It started on Saturday, March 17th at 12pm. I was a little delicate from the night before, so didn't show up until around 12:45pm. Getting here was a little tricky as I was coming from the Outer Richmond. My uber went down Great Highway, so it had to turn back around in order to enter the zoo as there's only an entrance on the east side of the highway. He ended up dropping me off past the parking gates, so hopefully he didn't have to pay as the sign said no dropoffs or pickups. I didn't see this until I left the zoo. Parking is $12 on the weekends and $10 on the weekdays.

The baby shower was in the Great Hall. It was a good sized space. Definitely enough room for a buffet spread and all the dining tables. Each table had two SF Zoo stuffed elephants which I thought were cute. I ended up taking one home. There were also a beverage and a dessert station. For photo ops within the room, there is a cute fireplace to take pix in front of. The space was utilized well for a party of about 60 people? I'm not sure how many actually showed up, but we had plenty of room.

We were given wristbands to go to the zoo afterwards, so some coworkers and I decided to explore. Favorite animals were the giraffes, tigers, anteater, bears, lemurs, etc. They were the most active when we dropped by. Especially the lemurs since they had a huge habitat to play in. Some of the more disappointing animals were the lions, snow leopard, wallaby, koala, etc, as they just laid there and slept. I was saddened to see the komodo dragon as it's hind legs didn't work so it was dragging it's lower half as it walked. The hippo also looked so cramped in the tiny pool. I felt like he was just hiding in the corner as he seemed unhappy. The sea lions were cute, but we found out they were blind when we listened to the pre-recorded audio. Overall, I think we basically covered the whole zoo as we stayed until it closed at 5pm. We also saw the zebras, emus, mandrills, monkeys, llamas, a wolf, snakes, frogs, an iguana, meerkat, a red panda, etc.

I can't even remember the last time I went to the SF Zoo. It's fun to see the different animals, but this zoo can feel a little small and depressing. Glad I got to see the animals, but I think the zoo across the bridge is a much better one.
author: Elena N.

description:
After just visiting the Oakland Zoo, this was by leaps and bounds a better zoo. Mainly the food was better quality with more choices, there were more impressive animals, the layout wasn't as hilly and easier to navigate, and everything just seemed better quality in terms of the buildings and land.

My husband and I loved seeing the tigers and grizzly bears the best as you can get pretty close to them behind the glass. It can be a little chilly in SF so bring a jacket since you're right by the beach. This zoo can be done in about 3 hours including eating lunch there. If I had to recommend a Bay Area Zoo this woud be my first choice. The only thing I wish they had were more fun drink/dessert options like the San Diego Zoo has. We definitely would have shelled out for it!
author: Christine S.

description:
So we have some good news and bad news, first the good news, a few years ago this place was really run down, it was so bad I was never coming back, but they have fixed it up, it's really nice now, all the employees and volunteers were really nice.  Just park on the street, $12 for parking is too much, but if your rich then it's nothing to you.

The food is ok not too bad, the Coke was mixed pretty good, some places water it down either on purpose or they just don't know how to mix the drinks, but at the pizza food area it was mixed great.

The food area needs more tables, they are all full and people still in line buying food and no place to sit, so that's a problem, more tables should have been added when the remodeling was done.  Still more tables need to be added somewhere.

Also selling drinks before the drink machine is ready to put them out is not good, so they say sorry, take your cup and walk over to the next food area and get your drink, not a good thing.

Another not so good thing is no straws and no lids for the drink, taking away straws doesn't solve any problem, it's a littering problem, enforce the litter laws, otherwise you will just take away everything you use in your everyday life because a few people throw garbage on the ground.  I bet you find more condoms in the ocean than you do straws, so ban condoms.

One thing to watch out for if you have a stroller is the train tracks, it's a small train track but 1/2 way across it starts dinging, but it's only a couple of steps to finish but I barely got across before the arm drops, almost hit me, it really should lower slowly, I don't know how that would have felt if it hit me but for sure it would not be good if it hit a little old lady.

The train ride is fun but I think it goes a little too fast for those tiny tracks, I was a little worried that there was a possibility of it falling off the rails on the curves, it should slow down a little.
author: DT W.

description:
We come here every couple of months ... preferably on foggy gray days for better photo ops but none the less a very great place to take photos and bring the family and little ones.  Tons of animals .. exhibits and cardio.  Its along Ocean beach so the weather is always perfect ... dress in layers.  

Tons of animals...many exhibits have great views of animals... 

Downfall:: parking and to thoroughly enjoy the actual animals here you kind of need to get to them during feeding if not many are sleeping some place hidden. 

We always come when they open so we get the zoo lot... its $12 and you pay whrn you purchase your tickets
author: Cathy C.

description: Fabulous way to spend a day. It is huge so be prepared to do a lot of walking. Not only are the animals amazing to observe and learn about, the grounds are beautiful. If you go try to hit as many handler talks as possible. Really informative. How often can you go to a place where young, old and in between are all smiling?
author: Joe M.

description: It has been 3+ years since the last time we were at this zoo. We got there in the afternoon, there was plentiful parking on the street and lot of people going in the zoo but the line for admission was moved fast and we got in quickly!  The zoo is very clean and don't feel crowded at all and the weather was perfect, we stopped by all the exhibits and also rode the train.  My sons had a great time and we enjoyed it too.
author: Winnie T.

description: We decided to visit the SF zoo today. It's been about 12-15 years since our last visit. Boy has this place changed. The grounds are very nice and you can't beat the cool weather! what was very disappointing was the animals and how much the viewing structures have changed. Aside from the giraffes there really wasn't a whole lot there today and they no longer do the lion feedings like before. Many empty enclosures, ponds and space. Lots of cool old run down buildings not in use anymore and blocked off. Overall it was just ok. Nice day to get out and spend time with the family. But a little bit disappointing for me coming back after all these years.
author: Amarie S.

description:
Have you ever wanted to visit the zoo, looked at the price of an adult admission, and ended up not going because it was too darn expensive?! For me, that was all the time whenever I was back at home in SoCal with my high school friends. We'd always mention the San Diego Zoo as a fun activity, and even though some of my friends had discounts, I was always a "NOPE." $50+ for a ticket? COUNT ME OUT! That covers like a full tank of gas for me and then some.

If you're like me and are cash-strapped, the San Francisco Zoo is actually a very inexpensive opportunity to see a BUNCH of amazing animals (if you are in the area of course). Personally, I was very surprised when I came across their website and found that admission was only $20. And it's $19 when you go during the winter/spring season. The best part is, if you are a San Francisco resident, it's even CHEAPER (I believe like $17). Upon realizing that this zoo was pretty affordable, we decided to come by during our anniversary. 

The San Francisco Zoo is located in the far southwestern part of the city near the coast. I find this spot actually super convenient because 1. by car there shouldn't be traffic as it's far away from the city and 2. there's busses that come here. Plus, the zoo is near major streets/highways (Skyline/Highway 1), and so driving here should be pretty chill. Contrary to what you might think about the low price, there's plenty to see in the zoo. And therefore, I'd recommend setting aside at least 2+ hours of your time here. If you plan on parking inside the zoo, it's $12. But, many people have mentioned that you can probably find some street parking outside (at your own risk).

Based on mine and my girlfriend's first visit to the SF Zoo, we can wholeheartedly say that this place is definitely worth every penny. The San Francisco Zoo really does have almost 90% of the animals you would want to see at a zoo. For example, right when you walk in and even BEFORE you get through the gate, you are met with the CUTEST bunch of giraffes. And if you are lucky, you'll also see some ostriches roaming around. One thing I really enjoy about this zoo is that there are a lot of giant spaces for different species of animals to mingle about. I didn't find a single exhibit where animals were confined into a tight spot. 

Personally, my favorite things that I saw at the zoo included the anteater (you never see anteaters around!) and a brave little peacock that wandered out of its home. Even though we only spent 2 hours (we had a time crunch), there's SO MUCH to see that you can spend the whole day. Usually, they'll also have a special exhibit too. When we went, they were showing up species of tarantulas (yuck!). If you plan on staying a while, it's nice that the zoo has a detailed map for you (and signs too!), as well as plenty of rest (and food) areas if you get tired. 

All in all, I really, truly enjoyed my experience at the San Francisco Zoo. It was definitely better than I thought and definitely worth my ~$20 for admission. If you are looking for a solid zoo to visit in the Bay Area, the San Francisco Zoo is a viable option. I personally believe it's slightly more worthwhile than the Oakland Zoo, but luckily for people, they're both affordable. I give the SF Zoo an "omg, I'd travel 2 hours for this" rating. Come check out this zoo and I guarantee you won't want to leave.

Have fun and prosper!
author: Bryan W.

description: Ehh it's ok, I'm not really into zoos. Maybe aquariums... But it's ok if your a tourist into animals. Otherwise come thru for free days if you down for that.
author: Jray M.

description:
I was excited to visit the zoo with my 2 year old. We wanted to arrive early to view the grizzly bear feeding at 10:30am. We arrived and found the bears (in the very very back) to find out that the 'feeding' consisted of them throwing a bone and some lettuce out for the bears before releasing them from their night quarters. 
Like someone else stated, a lot of the exhibits were either empty, or had 1 animal who looked miserable, or sleeping. I was most excited for the chimps and the gorilla's. They chimps were all inside so we didn't get to see them and the gorillas habitat was so small. They looks sad and depressed. 
Needless to say, I was pretty disappointed in this zoo. Especially for the price you pay. We won't be back.
author: Kristeen D.

description: Wow, this is a really great zoo. The enclosures are big and lots of work went into making the environment nice for the animals. The zoo employees are friendly and knowledgeable. The zoo is well maintained, clean and nicely landscaped. It cast $10 to park and $20 to get in. It's worth it and I'll come back again.  Great way to spend the day.
author: Douglas F.

description:
Lion, tigers, and bears...oh my!  The San Francisco zoo is a place I always wanted to go to but never really carved out the time until now.  Finally.  So glad I visited.  

The sections of the zoo are broken up into different enclosures grouping animals by geographic and climate region. They give out complimentary maps, go ahead and take one or two. The place is large enough that I found that it came in handy. 

So many animals.  Plus they have resident peacocks that strut around freely.  My faves were the tigers, gorillas, monkeys, chimpanzee, and penguin colony.  I saw & heard firsthand that penguins do actually sing. No dancing though. There was one gorilla they cracked me up, he/she quickly gathered up all the celery sticks thrown into the enclosure by the keepers.  He hoarded them and snuck away from the pack to eat them all.  But always turned by around to see if the others see him.  One black& white monkey paused to stare at me while he was eating.  Apparently I was the entertainment during his meal. Loved all the personalities.  

Plus there were a lot of informational plaques describing the animals, climate types, locations, and conservation efforts.  Great! And beautiful gardens scattered around the grounds.  Pretty! 

The kids might like the mini steam train ride and Carousel. The pricing is extra though.
author: Lillian W.

description:
Oh sigh...The visit was underwhelming. Most areas either had like one animal present (e.g., rhino, eagle, hippo, bear) or none at all (were they hiding or not released)? We didn't get to see the snow leopard or the wolverine. I don't know if it was nap time for most of the animals, but like 75% of the stops had animals sleeping (e.g., lion, tiger, sloth). You can't really blame the animals, but when there's either no animals or one animal present, it is kind of strange...

The Africa Part of the zoo was probably the best, especially the spot for giraffes! They were so majestic and beautiful (*tear*).
I also thought that the location where the penguins were was nice. They had little holes in this large cave-like structure where they could hide/sleep. And this cave-like thing was surrounded by a circular stream where they could swim if they got bored. Ah but what bothered me was this little kid whom no one was reprimanding for going under the rope and attempting to step into the water...I get it. Kids know no better, but parents...did you not see the sign?
We need to respect the animals. I think it's already heartbreaking that these animals have to let humans point at them on top of being in these enclosed spaces...But when I see kids knocking on the glass (despite the signs not to) and ADULTS whistling and making bird noises or saying "come here" to animals... it's degrading. I feel for the animals. 
Animals (especially ones that have no choice but to live as a part of a zoo) deserve more respect and sensitivity. I was really turned off by the behavior of some people at the zoo.

In terms of parking: WHEW get here early. It's really limited. For weekend's, it's a flat rate of $12.
Thankfully, one of the employees came out and helped find additional parking for me and for some other cars.

The prices would have been decent ($19/adult) all-day (10am-4pm), but I wish there was more to see.
author: Christine H.

description:
I was a bit apprehensive after reading some of the negative reviews but we had a great visit to the SF zoo. Lots of animal sightings, well kept facilities and friendly and engaging staff and volunteers. My little nephews loved the playground! The animals  
seemed well cared for.
author: Britta A.

description: I haven't been to the San Francisco Zoo in years, but was pleasantly surprised by all the upgrades and improvements. Seeing the snow leopard cubs today was the highlight of our visit, it prompted us to get a family membership!
author: Bogee B.

description:
My two kids (7 and 11) and I just spent 4 hours at the San Francisco Zoo today and had a great time!  

We arrived about 15 minutes before they opened and found parking right in front.  (It's not a large lot, but when we were leaving around 2:30 pm, there were spots available here and there.  Don't forget to pay for your parking, $10, at the ticket counter either when you enter or when you're leaving.)  The line for tickets wasn't long, but then my son saw the "Skip the line" sign that said you could buy tickets online.  So I did.  I should've just gotten in line, it probably would've been faster.  First I had to sign up for an account.  Then I bought the tickets and had to wait for the confirmation e-mail to get my tickets to show the attendant.  It took about 20-25 minutes for the tickets to arrive in my email box!  In that amount of time, I could've just stood in line and already have entered!  I'll know next time to either purchase them the day before or just stand in line (especially since you have to pay for parking at sometime as well).

Once inside the zoo, we had fun!  (Note: There are no paper maps of the zoo. There are maps posted throughout the zoo and you are encouraged to snap a picture of the map to carry with you on your phone.  Kind of annoying to have to keep finding the picture on your phone, but I respect the fact that they are trying to save a tree by not having paper maps that are probably just thrown away after the trip is over.)

What I especially liked about this zoo trip was:
1) How close you feel to most of the animals, especially animals like the grizzly bear.
2) The fact that there are volunteers at many of the exhibits that will share interesting information about the animals with you.  All are extremely friendly and happy to answer your questions.
3) Because it's in San Francisco, the weather is perfect for a stroll around the zoo and it's all FLAT!

Our favorite animals--the red panda, the prairie dogs, the koalas, the penguins and the river otters.  We spent 4 hours here because my kids really enjoyed just hanging out in front of their favorite animals and observing them.  We were disappointed, though, that many of the animals seemed to be taking naps today (lions, tigers, kangaroos, koalas) and it wasn't even a hot day.
author: Amy K.

description:
I loved my visit!  SF Zoo is well maintained and pretty clean.  The staff are all very nice and pleasant. 
My favorite animal is prairie dog, they're the most cutest playful little guys. The monkeys and lemurs are very fun to watch!
Good mix of animals to make you say wow: Lions, Wolfs, Flamingos, Chimpanzee, Meerkats, Grizzly Bears, Giraffes, Guanaco, Anteater etc. 

The only down side to this is that the train in the zoo is only help you get around part of the area. It would be perfect if they it could see the whole zoo! The price is quite reasonable.

Great place for family, friends and fun.
author: Lin L.

description: I came for the Zoolights this year, and can't wait to come back to see the animals. The lights were very pretty, the staff were friendly, and informative. The reindeer and snow machine were excellent touches, and the children seemed to enjoy them a lot.
author: Stephanie K.

description: I really enjoyed spending my day at the Zoo! All of the animals seemed to have the space they needed, as well as clean living quarters. We were fascinated by all the different "kitties" and monkeys! All of the staff was very attentive and around to answer any questions. There was plenty of seating and food throughout the zoo for those who needed to rest or get a bite to eat! Parking was $12 and there was plenty to choose from. They also offer a military discount on day passes.
author: Kenzie C.

description: We took a little family trip here. It was well worth the one hour drive. We spent a total of 3 hours here. Parking on the weekends are $12 and $20 per adult. If you live in sf it's $16. We enjoyed looking at all the animals and even liked how they had volunteers in something g trail that had animals you can touch and learn a little about them. There are also an insect bulging and a indoor rainforest. They also have rides like the train and marry go round for $6 per person. We also loved the play area for the kids, they have 3 play areas all near each other and are perfect for the toddlers up to 12 year olds. We love seeing all the animals and they all looked well cared for.
author: Victoria A.

description:
This was the first time I have ever gone to the zoo! 
Parking is $12 and adult admission is $20, you're given a map of the grounds and there is quite a lot to cover. Unfortunately, we came later in the day...around 3pm and the zoo closes around 5, so a lot of the animals were already sleeping for the day. 

Although we were able to cover a lot of ground in just 2 hours, I would highly suggest preparing to be there for at least 3-4 hours to see everything. 

I would also suggest coming in walking shoes, or anything comfortable for your feet. I wore a pair of converse, and those usually get me through the day but my feet just couldn't make it at the end of the day. 

Great learning opportunity for children to get up close and personal with animals. (I definitely have never been that close before). And they have a lot of products in their gift shop to commemorate your trip!
author: Melanie B.

description:
Love this place. Better be prepared to spend the day here. So much to see.kids loved the big playground and carousel situated in the middle of the park. The train ride? Short, but fun. Goes around twice. 5 bucks a person. That train has some "giddy up". So fun. Kids loved it. Totally worth it. The line goes fast so do not be intimidated by the crowd. 
The giraffe, zebra exhibit is my personal favorite. However, the grizzly bears swimming around is so fun to watch. Never seen a rhino until today. Wow!!! What spectacular creatures. Hippo, penguins, lions and the roos. 
Tip! Bring your own wagon. You can rent them, but so much easier to have your own.
author: Danielle H.

description:
This zoo is easily accessible via Muni Rail service and if you're a resident of SF with valid proof, you get a discounted ticket price and that's one perk I do love about this place!

This place is more busy and frequently crowded during the warmer 'in season' period and that is the time when all the exhibits and experiences are open and available. During the colder and 'off-peak' hours the zoo is still frequented by many, but not as much during the season. Not all the attractions or animals are accessible to access or view during the 'off season' period and yet you'll have just as much fun and make memories.

The one exhibit from my childhood that isn't around anymore is the elephant enclosure, which was damaged so severely by an earthquake a long while back and the funding to replace and bring up to code would be so expensive to complete, they decided upon keeping the exhibit closed indefinitely and since has been repurposed.

I can and so often do spend as much time at the zoo every chance I can. There's this sense of calm and something special when sitting for hours in front of an enclosure, watching some amazing animals doing their thing out in their enclosures. Seeing as from day to day every animal can and does things differently, so from visit to visit I get a unique encounter with some of my favourite animals.

Don't forget to learn about animal conservation and the SSP (Species Survival Plan), and how the SF Zoo partakes in helping ensue endangered species have hope for reintroduction into their wild habitats!
author: J Austyn B.

description:
We have been visiting members of the zoo for about 30 years and this is the first review we felt we must leave.  The exhibits are slowly getting remodeled, which is a good sign.  The food concessions are atrocious to say the least.  This is a NOT a family friendly venue anymore unless you are part of the Silicon Valley elite.  An example being the zootoberfest food concession.
We purchased two pretzels, 1 soda, 2 icee and 2  brats.  The brats were smaller than the smallest hot dog and had a tough, flavorless taste.  The staff were under trained and were short on ingredients and cups.  In addition we paid $61 for this mess!   This is unacceptable.  In addition nearly every trip we make the small train costs go up $1.  When we ask the staff why they simply explain because of the "greedy management ".  This is the same scenario for the carousel.
I am sure with the extreme wealth in this area that the zoo can be made a better place and more affordable for families.  I urge the managing staff to look closely at what can be done to raise funds in the community through corporate sponsorship and such.   
Please make the effort to make and keep the zoo a world class conservation exhibit for our young ones to continue to affordably enjoy far into the future!
author: kelly c.

description:
Did you know?

The San Francisco Zoo leads the nation in providing a home to animals that otherwise would not survive in the wild?

Neither did I.

Case in point, I was heartbroken to hear that their sea lion was shot in the face by a fisherman in the bay resulting in blindness...but he was certainly still a happy looking fellow during his fish feeding.

So while this zoo doesn't boast super flashy exhibits or state or the art designs, its dedication to conservation is pretty special. I especially liked how many docents and keepers were actively working around the exhibits providing neat factoids/stories or opening Q&A.

Tips:
- Pay attention to feeding times and keeper talks, it makes your experience much more fun
- Bring food and drink. There's ample space for picnics...and its a lot cheaper
- Wear comfy shoes
- Be okay with the fact that this zoo is always under construction (less animals to see)
- Be patient. The animals are so much more charismatic when they are not being heckled. The signs are there for a reason.

Keep in Mind:
- Parking still applies on free days
- Every adult requires ID on free days...not bring a SF Res, get in free
author: Elaine Y.

description:
Ok, I am updating my San Francisco Zoo review to four stars. Yay zoo. Things are improving. My daughter and I went here today and I could tell the zoo had updated so many of their features.  This made things fun. 

So - I had written previously about prices. Everything seems the same except the train went up to a whopping $6 per person! I splurged on the train today. And, I swear, I think they are driving that train WAY faster than they used to. Even my five-year old daughter mentioned it. She said, wow, this train is going fast! Yeah, and it was. And it was actually fun! 

So on other updates: the sad polar bear is gone. I'm not sure where she went. But the exhibits that are there in that area are definitely upgraded and well maintained. You have the Sea Lions, the Alaskan baby bear cubs, the Mexican Gray Wolf, and the Grizzly Bear. Their habitats are all updated and full of great places for them to explore and sit. The wolves were truly amazing, and so were the baby bears. I thoroughly enjoyed it.

Be aware that the zoo closes at 4 now that it is "winter". I thought it closed at 5 and I screwed up my daughter. Oh well, mistakes were made. 

Overall, it seems like the exhibits at the zoo are improving. I am happy to see many of the animals seem content. In turn, this makes me content, and then that makes my daughter happy. 

So - four stars for the San Francisco Zoo. Way to go.
author: Liza W.

description: I love zoos.   We came here about a few weeks ago while traveling around Bay Area.   This zoo is very nice and clean.  The animals look very well taken care of and happy.   The gorillas are too funny.   They love to show off and put on a show when they have an audience.   They play with each other and make faces.  Too cute.   The gift shop is really nice.   Lots of good quality items to choose from.   Food is pretty good too.   I would come back here if I'm the area.   Would recommend a good 3 hours to take your time and see everything.   It wasn't too crowded during the week.
author: Shelby F.

description: Was terrible, there were no animals & way way to many weeds in the Wolves display. Bears..were all hidden, no elephants. Pricing was just..Way...Too Much..especially..to end a day with tired children not satisfied.
author: martha g.

description:
Review is for the zoo lights which was underwhelming to say the least.

Aside from the expensive hot cocoa, there weren't that many lights up for the kids to explore. There was no train ride this year unlike prior years. And the playground was just overall crowded and claustrophobic for my taste. 

For the price you pay including parking if you use the lot, I expected more from this experience. My kids still had a good time but when the most memorable moment for them is the cotton candy, that's surely not saying much.

I hear the Oakland Zoo Lights is a much better experience.
author: Lisa C.

description:
Clean park with cute animals but i wasnt too impressed after going to San Diego Zoo :p
Their food is nasty! Dont go to their cafeteria xD
Parking is $10 and you pay when you buy your admission tix.
General admission is $20
There are little playgrounds kids can play at and photo walls here and there :)
author: Yeonhwa S.

description: Beautiful zoo! My 3 year old really enjoyed himself. The park was very well-maintained. The playgrounds were beautiful. The carousel only cost $4. I have been to the Oakland zoo a few times. I have to say that I preferred the SF zoo over Oakland.
author: Liz G.

description:
Very nice, clean but small zoo. My son enjoyed it. I think they really need to reduce the fee. $20 for adult and $14 for less 4 pluses is expensive.

The park, on the other hand, needs to improve their maps. They have just over complicated the stuff
author: Qasim Z.

description:
Came here over the holidays and was quite happy that it was not too crowded. One of the zookeepers commented on how it was so much busier since all the kids were out of school though, so I guess the zoo isn't too busy on a normal day. 

While the park itself is not too big compared to some other zoos, there are so many different animals and zookeeper talks to keep you busy. I recommend going to the keeper talks (at least for your favorite animals) because it's so much more entertaining watching the zookeepers play with or feed the animals vs. watching sleepy animals. The lion keeper talk was probably the best one! You're about 5 feet away from the lion and only a layer of glass separates you from him. The penguins were a close second - they're just too cute to resist. 

Overall, I think this is a great place to spend time with your family with friends. The day I went was raining so most of the food stands and shops were closed. However, it seemed like there were a decent amount of them scattered throughout the park. You're also allowed to bring food into the park though, so picnic-ing is always a fun option!
author: Kris C.

description:
Generally I'm not too big of a fan of watching caged animals but I was here for a company outing, so what the heck.

I was surprised the zoo is actually not that big - you can easily walk around and see everything within 30mins (okay, I'm fast). I can see it's a lot of fun for families with kids - especially riding the choo choo train, for which you have to pay extra.

If you've seen enough of bears, flamingos, and spiders there is a food court with all sorts of unhealthy options to keep your cholesterol high. Fun for the whole family!
author: Sebastian F.

description: I enjoyed my time at the SF zoo on Memorial Day! The African animal exhibit and the penguins were my favorite. The weather was perfect and it made for a perfect afternoon outside. Wish there were more beer stands and places to sit that wasn't near a children's play area. We also got photobombed by my fave animal!
author: Tara A.

description:
I haven't been to a zoo in years. I dont really even remember loving them as a kid. I was a bit curious about what a zoo by the ocean would look like.

Parking was horrid! Plan to literally walk a mile TO the zoo...

The zoo itself was not as big as I imagined. The animals are pretty much the same zoo to zoo I guess. The penguin island was cool. The lion exhibit house was closed. My favorite was the gorillas.

Great place for kids and families.
author: Corabelle G.

description: Went here with the family and really enjoyed it. Saw all the animals and ate at the lemur cafe which was expensive. Still had a blast here and the best part was that we seen the lions here
author: Eric P.

description:
Nice large zoo with a train ride and carosel and a couple of play areas for the kids. The zoo is kept very clean and has a wide variety of animal exhibits. They have plenty of benches for resting along the paths.
Parking is $10 on weekdays and $12 on weekends. Admission is $20 for adults and $10 for kids over 3. The food is over priced--a simple bottle of water is $5. So, too pricey for most families to do very often.
author: Sue C.

description: If you lived in SF or anywhere in the Bay Area then you may have been to the SF zoo at least once. I am not a native of San Francisco but do love the benefits they give to San Francisco natives and anyone who works for Muni/city of San Francisco. If you come here frequently you may notice the zoo is not as big as the San Diego zoo. It's the perfect size and comes with animals that you don't see in regular smaller scale zoos. Once you enter I think you are greeting by a few howler monkeys or something like that because they make a lot of noise. However my review is not for the zoo in general but the eating areas during my lunch break. I loved the small cafe by the miniature railway and the rainforest house. The food they serve makes any work break I have a good one. Good taste and wonderful drinks.
author: Michael W.

description:
This review is for SF Zoo customer service and no-refund policy. 

SF residents! Remember to identify your place of residence when you purchase the admission tickets. If you forget to do so, you will be charged the higher non-resident rate by default. And, they will NOT refund you the difference after your tickets have been ripped. 

It happened to our family. We are SF residents. The receptionist would not correct the charges after we found out a couple of hours later. She stated that it was up to us to identify our place of residence. The admission supervisor has not responded to our voicemail and email.
author: Marrisa K.

description:
It's a good place to take little one. I've visited 2 of the top Zoos in the entire country so I guess I had my expectations set to high. It is a nice place don't get me wrong ,we loved the snow cats and the fishing cat. 
Everyone was nice and seemed to care about their job. 
Take your own food and drinks as a bottle of water is 5$.
author: Rica J.

description: I have been going here for almost 70 years niw. My dad used to take me and we would eat pink popcorn and watch Cuddles the hippo.  In 4th grade my class went here and the gorilla had a great time spitting on us. I have taken my son's here as kids and now they take their kids.here.
author: David D.

description:
This zoo is quite big and has many kinds of birds, animals and reptiles. My girlfriend and I are here on a fairly busy Saturday afternoon, having walked around almost all of the grounds. It is not the worst zoo I have visited, but I have some negative feelings about this place.

There are many empty enclosures today - the 'missing' animals include most of the bears, the wolverines, the anteaters and so on.

The boredom (and dare I say depression) visible in the behaviours of some animals was upsetting. The monkeys and chimpanzees were utterly disinterested in their surroundings (particularly the chimps - who also looked pathetically thin).

The zoo has a little train which runs around a (not very extensive) track near the Australian animals. Maybe the driver is bored too...or perhaps he is told to cram in as many trips as possible each day...but the train goes along  at a very fast speed (too fast to see anything properly or to take photos).

The layout of the zoo is not very logical or intuitive- the map handed out with the tickets helped, but we still lost our way a few times.

Many of the animals are behind Perspex screens. No doubt the plastic is clear and practical when it is new - however, the barriers are now usually scratched, stained and otherwise scuffed; making it harder to take decent photos. 

All in all, despite the above minuses, we had a reasonable return for our $40 (2x$20).
author: Jack W.

description: Just got back today. Unfortunately we wont be back again. 4 adults was $80 and for us 4 and 3 children to ride the train I got unlimited ride passes 19 each. The pricing is high but not bad. I was hopeful. The scenery was beautiful. However the animals looked so sad. Some cages were extreamly small. The rhino had a huge sore on his butt. It just makes you realize how awful it is to be caged in. So sad.
author: Jessica N.

description: This is probably one of the worst experiences at a zoo. I paid 10$ for parking 20$ for my entrance 14$ for my son- most of the enclosures were closed. The descriptions did not match the animals. The enclosures are tiny. It's far away from our home to drive for the experience we got-
author: Karla L.

description:
RE: ZOO LIGHTS 2017
Worst than last year. They closed off more of the park and decreased the lights by 2/3 compared to last year. 
They increased the prices of the tickets, too. I definitely DON'T RECOMMEND Zoo Lights for 2017.
author: Sugar C.

description:
My family of six came here on July 1, 2017 during their Red, White and Zoo event. It was a Saturday and we arrived promptly at 10:00am, the time they begin admission into the park. It's usually cold when the bay breeze rolls in so we bundled up and headed into the park. 

Admission was $20.00 an adult, $17.00 for a senior citizen (65+) and $10.00 per vehicle to park. I would highly suggest checking out the free parking along the outsides of the park like the other reviews suggest! For us with a senior, it was not plausible. Once inside, we rented a motorized scooter for my uncle, a little more on the expensive side $35.00. 

As we went though the park, it was obvious it had a few main jewels. Grizzly Gulch, the African Savannah, the Primate Discovery Center and maybe a few others. The other exhibits looked old and over-grown, matching a lot of their animals. The chimpanzee's were extremely old, the oldest being 59 years old. It looked like their entire exhibit was a old jungle-gym. You could definitely tell their age by their graying fur. Additionally, their elderly polar bear had passed away at the age of 36 years old. They no longer have elephants in their pachyderm exhibit due to the small quarters they were living, replaced with a tarantula display. Many of the animals just seem lethargic and unhappy. 

They do have a nice play area for smaller children to play in which is nice. Other than this, it would only be a one time visit for us as it is expensive and does not provide much.
author: Lacey B.

description: This is a review for 2017 ZOO LIGHT!! Such a disappointing experience! $8 entrance ticket and $10 parking, 5min walking through behind the gate?! The lighting tree wall is the ONLY thing worth for a photo! Majority area is closed, there's only few trees with light bulb. Not even great as a Xmas street light view. DONT WASTE YOUR MONEY ON THIS! :)
author: Ciel S.

description:
We came here on Father's Day, for a number of reasons: 1) Dad's got in free (woot, woot!), 2) My toddler got in free, and 3) it was an unusually hot weekend with 90 degree temps in the East Bay. However, at the San Francisco Zoo by the ocean? 64 degrees when we arrived, and 68 degrees upon our departure. A novel choice, indeed! 

The zoo itself is really a well kept zoo, and is a manageable size. Unfortunately, this also means that the animals have less room to roam. It's not nearly as nice as the Oakland Zoo (in my opinion,) but is still fun with plenty to see. 

My son's favorite exhibit was the gorillas (despite asking me "where" they were the entire time,) and he's talked about them multiple times since. This is one animal the Oakland Zoo doesn't have. The giraffes are always a favorite of mine.

The playground is large and unique, yet not shaded, and VERY crowded. It was a little chaotic, and too easy to lose a kid in the crowd, therefore we moved on quite quickly.

One more tip: Parking is $12, unless that's full (which it was,) and only valet parking is available for $20. We opted to park across the street along the beach. Not really the wisest choice, with no safe path except running across a busy highway. The zoo really should petition for a light to be installed in front, with a crosswalk in place. Long lines to get in, but they moved swiftly!
author: Amber L.

description:
I have to admit when I came here a few years ago I was not impressed. I was used to the LA zoo and the San Diego zoo so this zoo was kind of sad and small.

However, now that I have a toddler, it's my favorite thing to so on the weekend! We bought a membership because we needed a place for her to walk outside where she wouldn't be trampled. The zoo is never so crowded that we have to worry about that. 
The playground is awesome! I like that they have a small kids area with a super clean sand pit. The zoo itself is a good size for us to walk around. We usually do a lap around the zoo, hang out at the playground and go home. 
I recommend the membership for anyone with kids. It's the absolute best place for her to spend the weekend. 

Also, if you go before opening, you can easily find free parking on Sloat.
author: K S.

description:
I've been to SF Zoo many times growing up. But Sunday was the first time I took my son to SF Zoo. Due to crazy Bay Area traffic, we got to the Zoo at 3 pm. We paid $20 per adult and $12 for parking. The lady told us the park closes at 4pm, but the park doesn't close at 4pm and it actually closes after 5pm. Here is the reason why I am deducting a a star, we left the park at 5:30pm, and there was no one at the parking lot exit to hand our parking ticket to. The gate was already open, so technically we didn't even have to pay for the parking ticket. We wasted $12 and I don't think they should charge us for parking if it was an unattended lot. 

The Zoo itself is beautiful. Plenty of animals, animal and trainer shows, a train ride, 3 different playgrounds and the beauty of nature. I am not a big fan of theme parks/zoo food, so I actually brought my own snacks and drinks to avoid wasting money on mediocre food at the food court. Comparing the SF Zoo to SD Zoo, the SD Zoo is way nicer and larger but if I am not comparing the two, the SF Zoo is a great spot to spend the day and have an adventurous day with the family. Also, the Zoo is located a few feet away from the beach, so after a fun filled day at the Zoo you can over over to the beach to keep the family fun going.
author: Laila A.

description: Love the zoo we have a membership and go all the time. Some days are amazing with all the animals out and others the animals are hiding. The playground is amazing and the ice cream we get everytime! The glass could use a good cleaning however...you do see a lot of reflection off the glass making it harder to see the animals.
author: blaze c.

description:
Been coming here for years. Even back when I was a kid and the entrance was up towards 42nd Avenue. Over the years the zoo has changed, due to stupid people. Back in 2008, S.F. Zoo visitor saw 2 victims of tiger attack teasing lions, now the area is often closed and can only see them behind a 6" glass. 

SFPL Discover and Go once had pass families can get to avoid the overwhelming amount of people during their free days, but that is gone. They even had district free days that also disappeared. Now it only has the free 1st Wednesdays which has an overwhelming amount of people.  

The place is still fun for younger kids, but that's about it.
author: M C.

description: The zoo Had very few animals, it looked like it was closing. The food is very expensive I would suggest bringing your own food snacks and water for the kids. Very clean children friendly, but behind the times as far as zoo's go.
author: Premier Transport L.

description: I would give it 5 stars, but the last few times my family has gone an exhibit has always been closed and we've paid $12 for parking, yet the gate has been open for EVERYONE to leave, it's occurred during the weekend & on a weekday. They're stealing more money than they need. If that's the case, why have people pay for parking...absolutely ridiculous. Other than the parking issue, zoo is great and fun. My daughter enjoys observing everything and it's a fun family day trip for us. We bring our own food & picnic at the tables provided. We got a membership, hopefully the next time we go parking won't be an issue!
author: Kiki K.

description:
Decided to stay a few days in San Francisco on our way back from Hawaii and needed something to do for an afternoon as we recovered from time zone changes. Thought we would try the San Fran Zoo. 

We were pleasantly surprised with all the animal exhibits and things to see and do at the zoo. We took our 4yr old daughter and she had a wonderful time. We especially enjoyed the Tiger Feeding, the kangaroos, and the Giraffe Lodge. 

In the middle of the park there is a really fun place for the kids to play. Lots of slides, swings, and fun activities for the kids to climb and play on. Nearby there is also a carousel that my daughter loved to ride (she did it twice). The cost is $4 per turn and an adult can ride free with children under 42 inches. 

The only thing we didn't like were the bathrooms. They were DISTISGUSTING. We attempted to use 3 different bathrooms in different locations throughout the zoo and all were awful. Dirty, smelled horrible, with paper, trash, and anything else you could think of littering the stalls. It was the same for both Men's and Women's and the family restrooms. We tried them all. I felt really bad for my wife and daughter having to try to use the bathroom. 

Overall we had a great time and spent the entire afternoon (from 1pm to 5pm) and saw maybe half of the animals. Definitely enough to fill an entire day. Not sure we would visit again though if ever back in the area.
author: Steven A.

description: This is a pretty rotten zoo. Random stuff is always closed. Last time we went specifically to ride the carousel, my son really wanted to ride the carousel, and it was closed. No notice on the website or anything.
author: Meredith G.

description: I have not been there for about 20 plus years. It still seems to be the same although now being smaller.  Spend too much time looking for animals in their habitats without finding them.  I felt the maps along the way was hard to interpret and I got turned around several times.Still a great place to be and I can't wait to bring my grandkids for a visit.
author: Laurence C.

description: One of the best zoos to visit. The weather here is perfect to be comfortable walking around checking out all the animals. Kids love the little train ride and the carousel. It's one of the old original carousels with the creepy rabbit so it's way cool.
author: Christie C.

description: Very fun zoo. Animals were all out and about. Enjoyed the amount of different plants surrounding the zoo as well.
author: Natalie B.

description:
San Francisco zoo is small but fun. The animals seem really happy and are very well taken care of. The giraffes exhibit was our favorite. They seemed so playful and we loved that they came so close to get a drink. Great selfie opportunity!
I recommend bringing your lunch with you (Stop and get a California Special sandwich on dutch crunch from George's Zoo Liquor Deli).
author: Chris R.

description:
Finally had the chance to come here! It's bigger than we expected. I bought the tickets online so I wouldn't have to wait in line but we came when it opened and there wasn't much people in line. 

I think it's was a good idea coming first thing in the morning 'cause we got to see a lot of the animals that decided to hide after around 11am. There weren't too many people when it opened too so more freedom at the zoo! We also got to see a polar bear laying in ice, it was cute! 

Gave it 4 stars because when we came in, they didn't require us to get a parking ticket so we assumed we didn't need it. It was an inconvenience to go back to the front and pay for it. Parking was $10 or $12, forgot. 

Next time I'd visit is when I have a family of my own
author: Sheila C.

description: We found it a touch confusing to get around this zoo and were disappointed at how many of the exhibits were closed. I guess I'm a bit spoiled with the gigantic habitats at the zoo nearest to where I live (Binder Park Zoo in Battle Creek), so I would've expected a big city zoo like this one to blow our zoo out of the park. Charging $10 for parking, even for annual members, also seemed kind of chintzy to me but I'm a small town gal. We enjoyed seeing the red panda, penguins and a baby monkey having a delightful time exploring its jungle gym of a habitat. It is a great spot to enjoy a beautiful day, though. It only takes a couple hours to fully explore the zoo and the you can head across the street to enjoy a nice picnic on the beach.
author: Beth C.

description: Husband and I brought our daughter here.  A LOT of the animals were gone.  We walked all over and a lot of the animals were just not there.  We did see the Giraffes and a few other animals, but I was disappointed!  I wont be coming back.  I think the Fresno Zoo and San Jose are my new favorites.
author: Sarrinnah Marie C.

description: Had so much fun at this gem this afternoon! Deceptively large, there is a lot of walking but it was so worth it! Love the exhibits and that you can see the same exhibit from many different angles, the animals are awesome, they have almost everything you want to see at a zoo! Price point is really good too for a casual stroll on the weekend!
author: Courtnee N.

description:
I have mixed feelings about this place. The kids loved it. But the animals really seemed like they hate their lives. The animals just sat there. They were not doing anything. 

The zoo is not too big, and many of the animals were not available for some reason. I would have loved to like this place, because then I have another place to take my kids. But it was not fun.
author: Abu N.

description: My family and I love the SF Zoo, we have memberships and we definitely get our money out of them and then some! The exhibits are spacious and the zoo is spread out enough that you don't feel like you are in a crowd, even if the zoo is busy that day. They have a great kid's farm and petting zoo, where both my daughters love to brush the goats. They also have an amazing playground that has everything a kid could want and is accessible to all ages. There is also plenty of street parking so you don't have to pay to park. Another plus is that you can bring in your own food and drinks so you are not forced to purchase overpriced food there. I love the SF Zoo, it's my happy place!
author: Joanna L.

description: It's a cute place but I think it was a little sad. I feel like the animals were depressed. The food was better then expected.
author: Cynthia Y.

description:
I love going to the zoo! I usually reserve it for special occasions, but as we're getting acclimated to the Bay Area, we're trying to get out and about more. This place was definitely on my list of venues to explore. 

This zoo is right by the ocean, so we were a little chilly going in and coming out. It's a good idea to bring a jacket, especially since  it seems some parts are more exposed than others. Otherwise there's plenty of shade for people coming in the summer, and lots of little stores to stop into throughout to warm up a bit when it's cold out. 

The exhibits are unlike ones I've seen before. I kind of dig how they're set up to make use of the natural growth in many spots, like the red panda exhibit, but it does prevent some animals from being seen when they're cold. I really wanted to see the lemurs, but I have a feeling it was too chilly for them to be out by the end of the day, sadly. 

I will say that a lot of the enclosures are also more spacious and expansive than some I've seen in the past. They also seem more well-suited to the animals in them, such as the giraffe enclosure. Also, their enclosed aviaries that you can walk through are soooo cool. The birds are up close and personal!

It's day-trip worthy for sure. We made it all the way through in a single day, so I'm not sure when we'll be back, but it was worth a visit and we WILL be back someday!
author: Rachel N.

description: My family had a vacation in SF and it was really hard for me planning our free time. For us, we had a good experience here. A lot of animals. I've never seen pink flamingos !!! I like nature !!! Beautiful gardens with flowers ))) Friendly stuff. They can help you if you lost or have any questions !!! Next time I buy a membership.
author: Vicki G.

description:
This zoo seemed very old and outdated compared to other zoos on the west coast. 

It's a big poorly signed sprawl and you can barely find anyone who works there to point you in the right direction. The only animals you will see are peacocks and dinosaur displays since all the animals are either not there or are hiding. The few you can see look miserable and sick. 

Otherwise unless your into playing Pokémon Go which the zoo has tons of Poké stops and a variety of Pokémon to catch. 

I'd say avoid this place if your a tourist or a local... Kids and adults were both bored.
author: Vanessa S.

description:
Very nice zoo

My family really like it

Many things to do and the beach it's just across the street 

It is a beautiful view a really nice location 

Can't wait to go back again :)
author: Percy N.

description:
Oh my god. The animals here are ridiculously depressed.


The wolves need to be released, you could see the depression on their faces from the moon.


I'm ALL FOR animals and learning about them, but the cages and living spaces are too small. I won't be supporting SF zoo anymore.


Sorry, but I'm not sorry. Animal lover here, and this is unacceptable.


And no, I'm not a vegan, vegetarian, pescatarian, or liberal.


Edit* the care takers are amazing. I spoke with a woman who takes care of some of the monkeys and she was passionate and amazing. This review is not about them. They did not build those enclosures.
author: Rhiannon D.

description:
After visiting San Diego zoo it was hard for me accepting other zoos specially after a couple of very bad experiences with LA & OR zoo.

SF zoo was 16 mins away from my hotel & we were bored so we thought why not ... & to my very big surprise it was AWESOME!!
 
We saw a lot of animals & the place is very nice & family friendly. 

My daughter was so excited & we had a very nice time too :)

Give it a try & you won't regret it.
author: Rana M.

description:
What a cool place to come to and enjoy a fun filled day. We used to come here during the winter months show up early get a good parking spot, and enjoy all the animals. Over the years we have noticed that the zoo has made a lot of improvements, and continue to make improvements through the facilities.

The one thing you do have to be wary about is the parking availability. If you plan on coming in there's a good recommendation to get there at least 30 or more minutes before the gates open to the zoo this way you have time to get a good parking spot trust me you'll thank me when you do find that perfect parking spot.

The zoo personnel are friendly and actually happy to be working, the restrooms are clean but not perfect and the food is very limited what you could have and when you can get it. Overall it is a fun day for the whole family.
author: Michael N.

description:
For $20/adult, this zoo doesn't charge an arm and a leg, but what they have to offer doesn't quite justify even that admission price. There are a decent number of exhibits and habitat partitions. However, when I visited here with my boyfriend, they had countless exhibits closed for construction, which was a bummer. Many of their animals looked absolutely dreary and miserable, which totally killed my mood and made me question how well they take care of the animals. I've never seen such lifeless occupants at a zoo before. The sea lions had no water in their enclosure aside from a puny, sad stream of water dripping from a tap. Poor babies. Wish something could be done about this second-rate care. 

If you parked in the parking lot, remember to buy an "exit pass" for $10 to be able to leave the lot after your visit. Booooooo.
author: Christina T.

description:
Not sure why this zoo has so many bad reviews...Other than the fact that I've never seen so many crying children in one single area at any given time, I think this zoo was just fine. Sure, its not as big as the San Diego Zoo and maybe the place isn't super modern, but its cheap! As an SF resident, and taking the muni out there you get a nice discount and the entry is only $16, so for a few hours to walk around on a nice day and pretend you're a tourist in town, this is a good option.  

Tips: Take the muni/an uber, parking is $10 and it does look like a nightmare.  Get there early, the line gets pretty long mid afternoon.  Bring lunch/snacks, there are a lot of tables and places to eat (the food there looks gross and over priced) so bring your own (I suggest the little bodega outside George's Zoo - $6 huge sandwiches, chips, beverages, etc). Don't go expecting you're going to see all the animals, a lot of them are hiding in the back/sleeping and because this zoo is a bit small they only have one each of animals like tigers, polar bears, etc, so if they're not out - you're outta luck.
author: Kelsey B.

description: So it's not the San Diego zoo but what really is.  It's a great place and fun. We took the entire 6 hrs today to see everything.  So what .... the elephants and  polar bears died. They are making the zoo better and it's looking good. Kid friendly and clean. The food is horrible but really? It's a zoo.  $68 dollars got me 3 meals, two drinks and an apple.  I miss the doggy diner across the street.  Only thing that sucks is $10 to park.  Park on Sloat St if you can.
author: Tom S.

description:
This is still a solid staple for our Sunday routine with the kids. 

I usual route is the petting zoo, playground area, then the steam train. 

The petting zoo is definitely hot or miss. Somedays a lot of fiesty animals, some days very very quiet. 

The weekday toddler events are fun too! Very engaging!
author: Colin B.

description: Best, cleanest, and most well thought out zoo I have ever been to, not terribly expensive, but they do get you on parking.
author: Josh W.

description: There is limited parking , limited bathrooms . my best advice is to bring alot . There is a short train ride but there alot to see when you go.  The city is always cost a bit go but it most fun. You should bring snacks and water cause they cost alot zoo snack shack. The huge plus there huge play ground.
author: Joe C.

description: This zoo is a great size for anyone looking for a fun, half day activity. It doesn't take very long to get through all of the exhibits (about 4-5 hours) and the food is great. Just in case anyone is wondering, they don't have elephants or a reptile exhibit here (although the Rain forest exhibit does have some snakes). The animals were really cool and entertaining, and a lot of the zoo staff were out talking to people about the animals. Definitely fun for all ages and since it's only 100 acres, it's very doable for a family with kids. I'm only giving it four stars because it's not the most incredible zoo I've ever been to, however I would definitely come back because it was super fun.
author: Kendrah Y.

description:
It's not bad. The African exhibit is by far the best one they have. The animals are in a large space that you walk through. The insect exhibit is bad. There was no staff in the building and it's covered in spiderwebs inside and out. It is also very small and the tanks the bugs are in are hard to see into.

They have a great playground for kids and the petting zoo is nice. The Little Puffer Station is nice but it is a little expensive for such a short ride and you don't go by many animals. Mostly you just see the path and bushes so it's not really a big deal.
author: Chris S.

description:
Save your money and go to the oakland Zoo. This zoo is sad and pathetic and unkept. Half of the exhibits have over grown weeds plants and trees. The animals look filthy due to their habitats environments.  A lot of the exhibits do not have animals in them   So that was disappointing. 

We splurged and got the key to hear additional facts. Majority of the key boxes didn't work. So while only $3 it still is not worth it if you can't even use it.
author: Kimberley H.

description:
So disappointed SF zoo.
Some of Employees are very rude and  poor service, especially the gift shop next entrance.

And, there is a few animals, less than I expected. 
Some times many empty cages, so I was so sorry to my kids.

I even sent complain e-mail to the zoo, they'v never gave me any reply. Sooo disappointed there.
author: Jung Lan O.

description:
Visited the SF zoo for the first time. It is absolutely charming! Located a few blocks from the Pacific Ocean in a lush park-like area. The grounds were well cared for, nicely manicured with various greeneries and flowers. Some animals looked depressed, but that's probably because they're not out in the wild. Animals were all well cared for. 

There's a mini train that offers rides for $5/adult. Fun, pleasant experience. The train conductor and a peacock come by to collect tickets. The little peacock follows obediently. 

Would visit again!
author: Christine Q.

description: Wow!! I just love the zoo!! It was my first time in summer 2007 when I had a broken leg and I was with my dad and my cousin and my brother and sister. And I went there again in March 2016 with my brother and sister and her boyfriend. And I went there again one month ago with Camp Krem group.
