author: Rafferty K.

description: By far one very disappointing trip to the zoo. I came from out of town with my boyfriend for a fun weekend. We decided a trip to the zoo would be fun... wrong! The animals could've been considered DOA (Dead On Arrival). By all means I understand they're going to do what animals do when they want, but every exhibit we went to the animals were motionless. I would've had more enjoyment walking in a park seeing dogs run around.
author: Mariah C.

description: Michelle at the gift shop made our day! Phenomenal experience. As I work in the customer experience industry it was amazing to see someone go above and beyond. We love the SF Zoo & highly recommend visiting.
author: Matthew M.

description:
As members of the Oakland Zoo, we try to visit at least once a year since we get 50% off. During our recent staycation, my daughter and  I rode the Muni here; usually we drive and find street parking as the zoo charges $10 to park in their lot. For once, we got clear skies so we ended up spending most of the day here. Otherwise, bundle up as it gets quite cold when the fog rolls in. 
The zoo has been renovated in recent years, specifically their playground where my daughter played for an hour. Some of the animal exhibits bum me out like the lonely and bored polar bear. I still get the heebie-jeebies near the infamous tiger exhibit though plenty of signage indicates that the zoo won't tolerate any animal taunting or exhibit climbing. Still, if you have kids, this is a larger and more varied zoo than Oakland if a little dated.  
Prices would be steep without our discount.  The steam train is an extra $5/person. My daughter didn't want to go on the carousel as those tickets are sold separately too.  Food is meh for its high prices. I would recommend packing lunch, snacks, and drinks as pickings are slim at the Leaping Lemur Cafe.
author: Julie C.

description:
You'll find the most eclectic collection of species in the world here from mammals to insects to reptiles -very impressive !
I've been to other zoos in the bay area and around the US and the sheer variety of animals here impressed me
author: Praveer C.

description: It's beautiful place for a summer picnic. A lot of kid activity. Beautiful peacock I love the atmosphere here parking is bid expensive
author: J J.

description: This is a review of Zoo Lights 2017 specifically. My family has had a zoo membership for years & we have truly enjoyed Zoo Lights. Until this year :-( we went last night & the whole family was disappointed at how little of the zoo was actually open for Zoo Lights. In past years there were certain parts of the zoo closed off - but last night there was very little of the Zoo open! I am serious - it was all closed! The only open area was the playground, the carousel & the cafes - yes there were reindeer, yes they brought Santa in by the monkeys, but other than that - it was all closed! No giraffe barn, no train, nothing past the flamingos. I mean nearly nothing. This is mostly a message to the zoo - please bring back the Zoo to Zoo Lights!
author: P J.

description:
This review is for 3.5 stars. 

This place is no San Diego Zoo, but it's a great attraction here in San Francisco for people of all ages.

My boyfriend and I have been meaning to come visit for a while, and we finally made it up a couple months ago. The food is not great, but as with all family attractions, this was to be expected. This is a great place for kids to learn about habitats and animals and a fun place for a day date! I was only a little bit disappointed because it seemed as though the day we went, a lot of the exhibits were closed or were being moved, so lots of empty lots.
author: Sarah N.

description:
It was a fun place for the family to go to but it would have been nice to have more kid friendly areas in the zoo. 

The food is incredibly expensive for the quality and next time we are going to make sure to bring our own.
author: Omar K.

description: Last year we had a nice time, enough of the park was open to get our monies worth.  This year ... highly disappointing.  I basically paid $10 for my kids to play at a park.  There is only Santa, Reindeer, the snow and the park open.  Much more of it was open last year.  Had I known, I wouldnt have came.  Even without the animals, there was more of the park to walk and a lot more lights to enjoy last year.
author: Delylah K.

description:
First time here, I was disappointed 
Not too many animals here to see, yet the ticket was $20 


I had a pretty good ice cream, also good kids play ground but that's it.

Overrated
author: Mack A.

description: When I was little kid my mom and dad took me here weekly. When I came back to the city where I am from I went to San Francisco Zoo. This zoo is fantastic and easy assessable by muni aka public transportation. U can bring your own food in which is great . The staff are wonderful and there are plenty of animals to see. This zoo is a 5 star out of 5 !!
author: Peter C.

description: I seriously don't get people's reviews on here but I gotta give this place 5 stars.  Now I haven't been here in years but took my family here on 8/15/17 and we had a great time!  Yea it's old but it brings character.  Yea there's construction but that's a good sign.  Just check in advanced for any closed exhibits.  It may just be luck or the route we took but we saw all the animals live.  We loved the lions expecially seeing the 1.5 year old.  Oh and the new bear cubs! We were lucky to catch the feeding and they are so cute!!!  We did so the train ride at hefty $6 for a 5 min ride but seeing your baby's and kiddos faces are priceless.  It may not be as awesome as San Diego zoo but SF Zoo still has its character.  People stop hating on the little things.
author: Rob V.

description: Our favorite place to visit when we go to San Francisco. We got there when it opened and stayed until they closed. Best deal is to get the souvenir cups cause you get free refills. We had pizza and chicken strips and it was good. For photos its better to do the photo booth when you first walk in cause than you can share. The staff we talked to were awesome.
author: Amy J.

description: This review is not for the daytime zoo, but for Zoo Lights.  This year was a complete disappointment.   They closed off the majority of the park and I ended up paying $30 so that my daughter could play in the playground in the dark.   The only things available are a Santa (who took forever to get to) and things that you have to pay additional costs to do (carousel).   There wasn't even a train this year.  We were members for the past 2 years and had come from the central valley for this and were completely upset.  What a waste of time.  Many people we spoke to asked us "is this it?"  "Where are the animals?"  "Where are the lights?"  To me, the zoo just went really cheap this year and it is NOT worth the money.   What a rip off!
author: Edgar C.

description: This was probably the worst zoo experience ever. My 8 year old was bored. The animals looks lonely and sad. It didn't look really up to par. I've been to many zoos and this was by far on my list as the worst one
author: Christina L.

description:
Zoo is getting worse, just took my family there on 06/24/2017. So many cage and animals housing empty, animals all are so old like they were exhausted. No more polar bear, tiger, elephant, hippopotamus..v.v... and many more. Wasting money and times there, so disappointed. Not recommend anyone. 
Six flag or others animals amusement parks are way better than here. All you going to see only trees and views and more trees and empty spaces.... 1 star is very generous for this place. Not definitely going back.
author: Johnny T.

description:
I was fortunate during high school and college summers to work at the San Diego Zoo.  I picked trash, rode the back of the manure and trash trucks and would be a relief keeper on occasions.  I loved the variety of animals and the work around them that was key to maintaining the infrastructure of the zoo.

The San Francisco has been evolving over the years.  One such evolution is that there are not longer elephants, though the building is still labeled as Pachyderm House.  Sad, as elephants are among my favorite animals and were great fun to work with, hiding food for them to find, playing with them as I hosed the compound and putting lanolin around their eyes, giving them that teary look.

That said, the White Rhinoceros are behind the Pachyderm House so close to the crowds that you can see them and their prehensile lips very clearly.  They graze on the tender grass outside of the enclosure.  The Black Rhinos are across in another compound.

Most all of the mammals are readily visible.  The old lady of Polar Bears is now 35 years old and slowly works her way around her nice enclosure.  Penguins and sea loins are nearby.   One ape, the gorilla, has a silver back male and a harem of mates.  The chimpanzees are is a large central compound and regularly riot in the trees.  Monkeys are in other cages.

The layout is easy walking, covering a large area, so be prepared to walk a lot.  Unlike San Diego, the SF Zoo is pretty level, so strollers make taking little kids a lot easier.

During the week there is only one major eatery, the Lemur Cafe, in the center of the zoo is open with three options:  burgers & hot dogs, deli and pizza.  The lines for pizza and burgers runs out of the door but the deli has hot dishes without a line.  Weekends that are more eateries but far more people.  Visit during the weekdays if you can.

There are two large playgrounds so your elementary school level children can runoff energy while you sit watching and resting.  Then off to see more.

A great layout, lots of nice displays, roving docents with animal parts like skulls, paws and bones answer questions and let kids touch, there are some places where zoo workers hold animals, like iguanas, turtles and possums that you can gently pet and the signage is excellent.

Parking can be tough so come early.  Also, tell the ticket booth that you parked and you can pay the $12 parking fee for an exit ticket.  If you forget, you have to hoof it back to buy a ticket so you can leave the parking lot.

A very good place to spend a day.
author: Mitch K.

description: Didn't have anything to do and then I decided to come here after Yelping a bit. And didn't disappoint me. One of the nicest zoo I've been to. They've wide varieties of animals, birds, and insects. South Africans and Asian animals were the highlights. They've maintained it well and keeping very clean. The cafe serves a good variety of food in reasonable rate.
author: Maulik S.

description: Have not been here since I was in grade school! It's such a beautiful place! It's changed a lot since I was young. Took my two nieces on a sunny day. There was a long line to enter but it moved fast. Was not crowded, and had plenty of shading from the sun. Alright food snacks. My favorite new addition was the new playground! That thing was ginormous! That was definitely not there when I was a kid. Highly recommend. Take snacks if you go though.
author: Maggie G.

description: We loved the San Francisco Zoo.  It's reasonably priced and a decent size.  All of the exhibits are well maintained and you can tell that by how clean the water is in the exhibits.  They really keep this place looking nice.  We went on a day where a lot of things were closed and it didn't negatively impact our day at all.  Great day!
author: Allison C.

description:
This was a spur the moment trip I decided to take after I took a test in South SF early that morning. I arrived just  after 10am and the weather could not be more of a perfect foggy, misty, cold wet SF Fall DAY. Parked, paid $19 adult and $10 for parking I think. Had the option to pay as I left but just got it over with then.

As I walk in they are offering $10 tours. I decided to do it! Turns out no one else wanted to go so it was a personal tour. I had no cash so she took my CC info down on her CC form. I had 2 guides. It's a 60 min tour you walk very fast threw the park, one of the guides was in training. First stop lemurs, 2nd stop snow leopards(no show) they were putting snow out for her to play with, 3rd stop feeding time for Penguins! (Don't miss this time!!! 10:30am every day) best part of the tour, 4th back to the leopard (she was out) 5th stop back stage pass to see a secret animal ( no leg lizzard) very interesting! 
The guides were young but full of knowledge. Thank you I enjoyed !! 

After the tour I went back to the front of the park and with my map in hand visited every exhibit and was done by 3pm 

Next stop San Diego Zoo
author: Des T.

description:
If you do some advanced planning and accept that it is not the San Diego Zoo (or even the Oakland Zoo), it's pretty cool.

We got there first thing in the morning, paid for ourselves (SF resident discount!), parking, and the souvenir zoo key (which we probably could have done without because we barely even used it.) Most people started towards the right, so we ventured towards the middle, passing by many empty animal exhibits because they were apparently still sleeping. 

The polar bear that I remembered from way back is still here. Ol' gal is hanging in there.

The grizzly bear exhibit is by far the coolest. Hooray for the grizzlies!

It was about 11 when we made it to the train station area. Perfect timing for a ride on the little steam train. This is a must do. 

We prepacked lunch and ate at the tables in front of the station cafe. This cafe, I have to note, pours beer and wine in addition to regular drinks. BEER and WINE in a place filled with children. YES! These are brilliant zoo people.

My penguin homies were there. They seemed happy. Awake and happy penguins are cool.

Because of the many sleeping animals, we were able to see most of the exhibits within 3 hours and finished up in the playground. One of the structures (the one for the older kids) is like Home Tree from Avatar. The younger kids get some sort of glacier thing. Two sets of eyes are helpful to keep from losing your child as they get out of sight quickly. The play area for the super little ones is simpler and won't result in you losing your crawler. Oh, the snack area next to this does not serve wine and beer.

Highlights: 
SF resident discount
beer & wine!
mini steam train!!
an indoor sloth
cool playground 

Non-highlights:
the weather can change for the colder fairly quickly. Layer up!
sleeping animals
cold & sleeping animals
the anteater was missing
no elephant
author: Loli L.

description: Really enjoyed our day at the San Francisco Zoo.  The original architecture of many of the buildings and pens is very impressive.  Missing a star since many of the these beautiful features are sadly rundown and not maintained.  Many of the animal pens are full of invasive weeds.  The animals did look healthy, so that was nice to see.  I did feel sorry for animals that appeared to be "alone" in their pens.  I do support zoos as they care for many animals that could not flourish in the wild, but having a solitary animal with any companionship in a pen seems depressing.
author: Francie N.

description:
For the amount they charge at the gate, this place is in dire straits. As a kid this was my wife's favorite zoo, but now I can see why others prefer Oakland. Every exhibit is run down and overgrown. The protection glass in every animal section seems to be longing for some Windex. About half of a dozen electronic information boxes that appear to play a recording of some kind are missing the buttons to actually turn them on. 

However, the playground inside the zoo is pretty spectacular and our kids ended up playing here and claiming it as their favorite part of the zoo (even aside from the $6 train ride). 

All in all I hope they can dump some money into upkeep and bring this place back to its previously outstanding reputation.
author: Eric F.

description:
Great place to go if you're an animal lovers, a place to hang out your family and friends, or on a date. I went during the fall/winter so there might be a few animals that may not be out/available during this season compare to the spring/summer time. But you still get to see most of the usual animals.
Its always enjoyable walking around at each station looking at the animal no matter what age you are. I like that it wasn't overly pack even though it was a sunday. 

If you are sf resident, you get some kind of discount as long you have some kind CA ID or Driver license. Thats if you dont go on the 1st free day of the month. Theres parkings on the street and parking lot outside of the zoo if you dont want to pay at the zoo parking lot. But outside street parking can get fill up fast
author: Julie N.

description:
Last Sunday we headed out to the zoo with my family, including my 16 month old granddaughter.  Wow!  What a wonderful time we had.  Although we arrived a little late in the afternoon, we were able to see so many of the animals, starting with the giraffe, well actually giraffes....they have so many!.. I was impressed to see the rhino pushing around a huge object and to learn that they grind down their horns,
My little granddaughter loved the penguins.  The exhibit has water spraying and the penguins are so active...it certainly caught her attention.
We continued on to see the tigers...oh my how they roar.  I was surprised the hear that many years ago, the tiger leaped out of the enclosure and attacked to boys who were taunting it.  They have since raised the height of the enclosure.
My personal favorite was the hippopotamus.  He not only wallowed in the water, but came out of the water, pushed a big ball and jumped back into his pond...then opened his mouth to expose his big teeth and  let out a huge roar and open and she splashed through his pool.  What a show!

Unfortunately because we arrived so late, we were not able to see all of the exhibits.  Just before we left, we cruised by the koala displays.  The koalas looked like stuffed animals!  It was only when the zookeeper came to take them in did they move,
All in all a great day!
author: Lyn L.

description:
This Zoo will always have an incredibly special place in my heart, as I grew up in the Sunset District and slept each night only a stones throw away from all these beautiful animals. 

Visiting here never gets old to me, and I don't look at it as an entertainment day, as more a day to pay respect to those animals who day in and day out provide education to us, at the expense of their own loss of freedom. 

Come here to see amazing animals who otherwise we would never lay eyes on. Do not come here to be thrilled like you are at an amusement park. That is not the point of a zoo. 

One star off for too many exhibits being upgraded/not in use at one given time... and bathrooms could use some more frequent cleaning. Other than that, a spectacular, special place.
author: Kim D.

description: Most of exhibits were closed today and whole parts of the zoo were closed off, I counted at least 6 gates that blocked off half the zoo. They let SF residents in free today. I'm a member visiting with a guest today and had to pay for guest even though I told them I never received my guest pass or ride tickets. I may visit the zoo two times a year and never bring a guest and they couldn't let one guest in for free this time. I will not be renewing my membership with this treatment.
author: Nicole S.

description: My company sponsored a family day event at the San Francisco Zoo so I was able to visit for free. My 2 year old loved it. The train ride was the highlight of the trip. We ate lunch at the Lemur Cafe where the food tasted pretty good and was reasonably priced considering it was at the zoo. A huge slice of pizza was around $5 and a cheeseburger around $7. There are plenty of animals to see yet it is easy to navigate through. Compared to the Oakland Zoo, it isn't as hilly so I preferred the SF Zoo.
author: Sandy L.

description: I love this Zoo! And taking my son there for the first time was just wonderful! Everything was so nice and clean. Employees so kind and helpful thru out the park and the gift shop! My son loved the play area! I will definitely be coming back soon!
author: Veronica C.

description:
10.01.2016

It was a very Sunday Saturday and I took a stroll around the zoo around 12-2pm. It was very enjoyable since the last time I came was over two years ago. My favorite part was the African region where you can see giraffes and zebras. Definitely the first place to check out! Great price for a day pass and you can get a stamp if you would like to re-enter the park the same day. I also liked the fact that you could bring your own lunch and there are benches around the zoo where you can stop and eat. There was a bench in front of the giraffes where I was eating my lunch.
author: Kristy S.

description:
Extremely disappointed with this zoo,  we've been to about 10 zoo's across the county & this was the second most expensive and by far the worst.  
Parking is terrible, if you can find any.  The animals enclosure were very small & dirty, except for the giraffe's. There are signs up all over the city about the wolf exhibit & that was very disappointing as well.  The zoo's bathrooms are terribly disgusting  & parts of the zoo smell like trash. 
BRING FOOD!!  It's $12 for a hot dog & $9 for an icee!!  Which is outrageous.  

They do have many different animals which is nice.  Disappointing experience though & we definitely won't be going back,  use your money for something better.
author: Jason D.

description:
I'm not really a fan of the zoo except for that one time when I watched a gorilla wearing a dress tossing a banana peel at the crowd... would've been funnier if it actually hit someone.  I go for my nephew.  I can pretend to be excited for the hippopotamus swimming in the pool, the monkeys ooo ooo ahhing, or the flamingos (my favorite) one footed stance.  I can enjoy all that for you B just as long as it makes you happy.  

I will say this though, the chicken tenders and fries in the food court, Bueno.
author: Linda N.

description: Not what I expected. All the animals kids wanted to see were sleep (hidden), not in their display area, or have died. There was only one kid train ride and that was it. Most sections were closed off so you had to walk around, kinda in a circle. I thought it would have been a little more entertainment. For example, face painting, balloon animals, or save the wildlife mascot walking around to take pictures with.
author: Dominiqua S.

description:
I first visited the SF Zoo last year for my son's (7th) Birthday, and he had the time of his life! It did rain throughout most of our time there, but that only made the scenery much more exotic and had a real jungle-like feel to it. I loved every bit of it!

Fast forward almost a whole year, and although no rain this time, it was certainly a fantastic experience. Prime location, first and foremost. Located next to the Pacific Ocean is just perfect. We had little interaction with the staff, but when we did, they were always friendly and helpful.

The "Cat Kingdom" was my personal favorite, although the Tigers felt a bit shy that day. My son was exceptionally thrilled with the train ride (maybe he was a bit tired from all the walking, but nonetheless had a giant smile), and was super excited throughout the entire trip. 

Awesome location, awesome display, and overall awesome experience. We'll definitely be back soon!
author: Alex S.

description:
The weather was bad as it was cloudy, cool , with light rain that stopped after a couple of hours
The staff was very friendly and were very honest that a lot of exhibits were closed or the animals were allowed to go back and forth from their indoor enclosures to their outdoor enclosures.
We enjoyed our visit for the day
Beautiful landscaping mixed with enjoyable animal sighting and friendly staff
author: Al W.

description: I really like this zoo because being from Sacramento, our animals can be lethargic in the heat. Every time we come here the animals seem to be spunky and active. They have a great kids area where you can feed the goats and sheep. Hands on nature trail where you can pet and learn about different animals. They have redone the playground area and its fantastic. They have  lot of exhibits and quite a few eateries that are tasty. The only negative is they have a few enclosures that have been empty for some now and they just started construction in the primate area to make room for a new exhibit. They also don't have my favorite- orangutans. We usually spend a leisurely 5 hours here and see it all with stops for lunch and playground. Plus is it is literally right in the ocean so a quick stop at the beach after is always fun.
author: Francine B.

description:
This is a nice zoo.  No comparison to the San Diego zoo at all.

Pros:  The grounds are beautiful in most areas.  You can get really close to some of the animals, lots of things to do for kids.
Cons:  Some of the enclosures are very old and small.  The poor rhino, I felt so bad for him and his horn (ground off from pacing and rubbing on the walls).  :-(

Some of the enclosures are very cool, like the lemur exhibit, really cool.
Others are just small and obsolete.
I guess it all depends on donors and which animals they like.

For $19 it is a good deal. You can stroll through the whole place in about 2 hours.
Not much opportunity for any good food.  Most all was closed when we were there on Saturday.
author: Joe T.

description: Our first visit was on April and were hoping to be a cold day as the zoo is by the beach. However, the weather favored us and we had a great time. Our 2 year old niece loved every section of the zoo specially the penguins. Agree with everyone here- it is bigger and better than Oakland zoo. Also you can park on the streets but be careful while crossing the busy street.
author: Laxmi M.

description: I'm shocked this zoo is allowed is stay open, especially in a supposed enlightened area like San Francisco.  It was painful to even give this zoo 1 Star as it deserves to be shut down.  Again, one of the most DEPRESSING experiences you will ever have related to animals.
author: Bree B.

description: Coming to visit from Colorado, the Zoo was a bit less of what I expected. Gave it 2 stars primarily because of the expensive entrance tickets without Free parking. The place was small, we covered the entire zoo in about 2 hours. The animal variety was also lacking. The murals nor the exhibits appear not to be maintained either.
author: Ricardo G.

description:
Nice family place ...
I have a question for employees of this park, why all animals we saw in the middle of the day are sleeping???
We spend  3-4 hours inside and all animals are just hiding and sleeping????
author: Mary H.

description: I just had a pleasant first time visit a couple weeks ago. Due to my schedule, My visit was midweek and many of the areas we closed. All of the outdoor concession stands were closed as well. I still give a four star review because it was very informative, unbelievably clean, well maintained and the food in the main cafe area was actually quite good. I look forward to returning during the peak season.
author: Nick S.

description:
Me and my family visited the zoo in Jun 9th during our visit to San Francisco. We were greeted with a pleasant surprise when purchasing our tickets. Our tickets were EXTREMELY discounted for being members of the Cincinnati Zoo. All we had to do was show our membership card. 
 The zoo itself is set up very well and all the exhibits flow from one to another. Being a family that visits a lot of zoos we found this helpful in being able to see all the exhibits at the zoo. We will definitely go back on our next visit to San Francisco.
author: Carlos G.

description:
This is a fantastic zoo. It has one the best giraffe enclosure I have seen; although it may not be as huge as the San Diego Zoo, it's filled with these gorgeous trees and rolling grass. It has a very natural look and feel to it.  You get pretty close to the giraffes when they hang up their branches of food to eat right on the fence. During special hours you can go inside the giraffe house and the keepers give great talks. 

Another great spot is just down from the giraffes, where you can see a troop of Lowland Gorillas. I think they have at least 6, in a really nice and big enclosure full of grass, boulders, trees and toys. They have benches by the windows and it's peaceful to sit for as much time as you have watching them.

The other really great enclosure here is Grizzly Gulch. Two Grizzly Bear sisters have a thick grassy enclosure with a pond. They can often be seen sleeping right up by the windows, but are sometimes running around too. There are benches here too where you can sit and watch, which is really nice.

If you have kids, the play area is awesome. There is a giant "ice burg" playground you can climb on and walk through, and a really impressive artificial banyan tree playground of rope bridges, slides, and monkey bars. Make me wish I was a little kid so I could climb on it!

If you don't mind walking, I recommend parking on Sloat St. There is a lot of free public parking (a rarity in SF!) and it's right next to the zoo, so it's convenient enough to make paying $10/$12 for closer parking not really worth it unless you absolutely have to.
author: L U.

description: The zoo is nice in a very nice setting. Great place to spend time with family and to bring kids to learn.
author: Brigitte A.

description: I'm a bit of a zoo snob growing up in San Diego, but this zoo had a great selection of animals and enclosures built for maximum viewing potential. We also took a behind the scenes tour with giraffe feeding--well worth the price for 15+ minutes of feeding. Most zoos give you one lettuce leaf and you're done but not here. Loved it all except the terribly slow pizza service at terrace cafe. Avoid that place! Food was good but took 30 minutes because they poorly manage their supply chain. Also inadequate seating at this cafe. But overall amazing day, easy parking, and great atmosphere.
author: Jo M.

description: Good for baby,  interested in many species. Parking is ok. The entrance price is little high
author: Hakwan K.

description: Even on an overcast day it's always nice to come here even for only to visit the playground
author: Aspasia I.

description: Really enjoyed our day at the San Francisco Zoo. But most of the zoo is old. They really need a major makeover. The children's playground is very creative in the way it stays with theme. It's day-trip worthy for sure and we will be back someday.
author: Yanka M.

description:
being from sacramento I think its worth the drive to visit san francisco zoo! (ours is sooo tiny in comparison, its very sad). 

not only its looking at the animals, but many areas for kids in touch things and play areas as well. even a petting zoo.
author: Lisa V.

description:
Although it is a little pricey (hey, it's SF after all), it is a beautiful, well kept zoo with great views of the animals. The geeky zookeepers are happy to tell you minutiae about their favorite species. 

It's a little clunky to find your way around but not too bad. It doesn't have a ton of animals , but enough of the large ones to appeal to all of us. 

If you get bored, you can walk two blocks to the Pacific Ocean. Can many other zoos claim this? 

It's way on the other side of SF from the main downtown/Union Square but the Muni Metro takes you to one block from the zoo.
author: Patrick T.

description: I like that there are a lot of ways for the kids to be interactive & play. Playground, obstacle course, photo opps etc; I was kinda confused cus there were no elephants? Lol. I feel like animal wise Oakland zoo was better. But this zoo wasn't bad. Still had a good time! Might be time to spruce up the exhibits tho. Both for the animals sake & the zoo-goers.
author: Carmen A.

description:
We just visited SF zoo for the first time.  We are animal lovers and have been to San Diego zoo and Sacto zoo.  We are Sacramento zoo members, so we got 50% discount of entrance fee. 
 Adult entrance costs $20 with $10 lot parking on weekday and $12 parking on weekend.  We got to the parking about 11 am, and there was plenty of spots left, but we noticed the cars that arrived after 1pm had to pay for valet parking.  It's working it parking in the lot rather on the street, as it's dangerous to walk across the busy highway. 
It's difficult to compare the three zoos.  However, for SF zoo's size, it's very well kept and has a reasonable number of animals to check out.  We really like the open encounters for the animals, especially the large giraffe and zebra one-African savanna.  We love the tropical rain forest and aviary featuring different beautiful birds and exotic plants.  The grizzly bears are super adorable.  We enjoyed seeing the kangaroos hanging out with each other and snacking on their lettuce and carrots.  Our favorite spot at the zoo is the penguin island.  The penguins were so vocal; it's nice to see how they enjoy swimming and singing.  We stayed at the zoo for about four hours.   Definitely recommend it for family with kids.
author: Thdoe D.

description:
PROS:
- Huge zoo! 
- Lots of animals 
- Right near the water - so great views 
- Private parking lot - reasonable pricing as well 
- Plenty of animals to see 
- Huge cafe
- Food was quite good, offering healthy choices and all decently priced 
- Decently priced tickets 
- Cute train ride around the park 
- Clean park which is always appealing 
- Weekdays are less packed which is good
- Huge play structure 
- Adults: they serve wine here! #woo 

CONS: 
- Bring/rent a stroller for younger children. My 3 year old go tired of walking around because it was so big & we didn't bring a stroller 
- There was a lot of remolding causes lots of bathrooms to be closed off - not good for children 
- On the topic of bathrooms, there needs to be more of them within shorter distances, running around to find a bathroom with a toddler is no fun. 
- Snack shops should be available around the zoo as well 
- Some animals weren't even in their designated areas which was a shame to see. 
- May get windy and cold at times being close to the water
author: Anne R.

description: The parking is pretty small had to park at least a mile down. Which turned out to be fine after because the beach is across the street. Made it easier to just cross the street after the zoo. There was no zoo keepers around to give good information. The map really doesn't list everything so you have to find things out yourself. (Example) where the train ride was located and how much is costed. The train ride could of been better if it went around the whole zoo. Animals were all hiding out in sleeping so that was a bummer! The animals just seemed really hidden behind big walls!!! I will not be visiting again I will pick Oakland zoo anytime!!
author: Cindy L.

description: Love the SF zoo!  Beautiful setting, amazing animals, and so nice that you can walk across the street and go to the beach.
author: Megan H.

description:
Those who gave this zoo a 2-3 star rating must not have been to the Oakland Zoo. ;-)

Honestly, as a member of the Oakland Zoo - which happens to be 15mins away as opposed to the 45 minutes it takes to get to the SF Zoo - I do enjoy both zoos very much. However, the San Francisco Zoo has a larger and more well maintained space, not one but TWO elaborate and entertaining playgrounds, more animals, and better food. They also do a better job at ZooLights and have an area for Santa as well as reindeer in December. They also have mascots like the polar bear and giraffes for the kids (or you) to take pictures with. 

I also love that the San Francisco zoo is located right by the bay, which means you get to see the waves crashing against the shore as you arrive to or leave the zoo.

Parking is not included with your annual membership, unlike at the Oakland Zoo.
author: Asha S.

description:
My whole family came up here and spent the day at the zoo. We were happy with the amount of animals that we saw. I've been to the fuses and this zoo has a 20 foot separation between the glass and a lot of the animals. Unfortunately.  We would've liked to been able to get closer since were behind a protective glass. 
The layout of the zoo seemed good but there were two overgrown areas that I kind of wasn't sure what they were like something used to be there and it's no longer there. Probably won't be going back because I feel like I've seen everything but I liked what I saw.
author: Twy J.

description: Went to the zoo for the first time ever with my husband and it was awesome! They have so many interesting animals and I learned a ton reading all of the descriptions. Definitely recommend a visit if you haven't been yet.
author: Lindsay L.

description: i am used to the fresno zoo but this one was awesome. i especially loved the insect room and the playground area for the kids!
author: Brittny N.

description:
This place is so boring  a lot of the animals weren't out and the ones that were out looked so tired they barely moved around.
It's not worth the money but I give it two stars for being clean.
author: Noth I.

description:
I'm going to be honest here and tell you that I find the zoo incredibly depressing. It makes me so sad to all of the animals locked up, despite the fact that is serves an educational purpose. I felt even worse about the zoo when I heard that Kabibe, a baby Gorilla that I learned about in school, had died due to a tragic accident involving a hydraulic door. 

Like I said the zoo makes me sad, but I had to go to observe Primates for my Anthropology class. Tickets were rather pricy and they didn't offer a student rate.. bummer! At least it was a fairly sunny day and the Primates were out and about. I spent most of my time at the zoo making detailed observations about Langurs and Mandrills. I had the opportunity to see a new baby Francois' Langur named Chan. He was so tiny and cute, munching on kale with his mama! I spoke to a zoo keeper for a while about their group and he was very helpful and informative. The Mandrills were also very interesting to watch, but some of them seemed rather sad. I watched them for over an hour and little Lulu was picking the hair out of her arms and legs like it was nervous habit. Angie also spent the whole time alone :(

I also had the chance to see the Chimpanzees, Gorillas, and Giraffes. The Chimpanzee exhibit was the saddest of them all. It resembled an abandoned jungle jim and all of the chimps looked so incredibly depressed. After the Chimps, I went to the Gorillas and they had a nice memorial set up for Kabibe. There was one Gorilla who looked like she was in mourning. I could tell just from looking at her that she was the grandmother, Bawang (she acted as a surrogate mother to Kabibe). It made me want to cry! I read in the paper that they've had incidents with the hydraulic doors in the past and recently another Gorilla got her hand caught in it. I really hope that the zoo will be much more careful and take these problems very seriously in the future, Kabibe didn't have to die.
author: Rachel S.

description:
Visited San Francisco Zoo for the first time ever even I've lived in San Francisco for 4 years -- I took advantage of the San Francisco Residents Free Day on 2/29/2016! In order to get in, just show the proof of your residence of San Francisco, get a stamp, and FREE to go in!

I went in the afternoon and there were less people than I expected. I guess it was because the free day was on Monday. The snack spots & cafes were closed, only 2 cafes were opened -- I wish I knew so I could prepare myself better. Maybe there is a better way to tell us (the visitors) when we enter the zoo? I have no idea how the zoo run, so... oh well. Still surprised the snack spots were closed. 

The weather was amazing on Monday and it was actually hot after walking for a while in the Zoo. There was so many things to check out in the Zoo, however seeing the polar bear made me sad. I don't know what's going on with the polar bear but it was just so sad to see him/her sitting here. Maybe they can give the polar bear a shower? Again I have no idea. 

I wish there were more water stations or the snack spots were opened during the visit. Most animals didn't seem happy (or it was just the way they look?)... The staff were very friendly! I was so glad I saw tigers and lions,... they were so cute. The chimps were chilling and super zen. 

The parking was fairly easy! I didn't mind walk a couple blocks -- hey, it was free day! Can't complain anything when it's free.

2016024
author: Leslie C.

description: I think it's a pretty good zoo, but it definitely isn't the most amazing in the world! Cheaper for SF residents which is nice! They have lots of exhibits and the animals seem to be happy and have enough space, although I can't be sure. Not worth coming multiple times as it doesn't change much and you'll be quite bored.
author: Tom R.

description: SF Zoo Lights 2017 was a waste of time! Whoever made the decisions for this event should be written up. As zoo members it was such a let down. Over priced hot chocolate and churros, no night train, half the park closed, concession sales everywhere... its was bad. Not worth the trip for two reindeer and foam snow. My neighbor has more lights in his yard. Hope they read this and do something about it!
author: Larry E.

description:
What a lovely way to spend the day!

The San Francisco Zoo is extremely cute, clean, and well-maintained. I especially love that they have several areas for small children, including petting zoos and an awesome park with swings, slides, and other fun stuff. 

Also, they have a LOT of animals around here. I always get amazed watching the lions and tigers (and bears! Oh my!). The monkeys are super fun as well. Lemurs FTW!

They have lots of souvenir stores around the park and the selection of plush animals is adorable. I definitely recommend going to check it out. Another great thing about this zoo is that the restrooms are quite decent! 
 
On the down side, the food is not that good (even though it's expensive), and the coffee is terrible! And BTW, they make you buy their reusable cup when you buy coffee (which you can refill for $1.49), but you have to pay over $7.49 for a cup of coffee. SUPER EXPENSIVE! The only drink that doesn't come in their cup is the espresso. And it is bad as well.  
But, since you don't come to the zoo for a gastronomical experience, I believe that is quite alright because of Dippin' Dots (a must have!).
author: Andréia S.

description: Had a great time with my wife a while back checking out all the animals....the only sad thing was the seagull that swooped down off the roof behind me and snatched the klondike bar a was holding...my wife still laughs to this day about that.
author: Mark L.

description:
Took my 3 year old to the SF zoo today and I prefer this zoo hands down over the Oakland zoo. We visited this zoo on a sunny weekday - no crowds! We literally were able to walk right up to the enclosures without having to fight for space. We also found free parking on Sloat. 

The grounds are meticulously kept. The enclosures actually looked pretty pleasant for the animals. The hippo literally put on a show - yawning, snorting, and blowing water out of his blow hole. 

The key to the zoo is a nice touch for kids who can't read. The key activates different storyboxes throughout the zoo providing info on the different animals. It was definitely too much info for my 3 year old but it was fun for him to find the boxes and turn the key. 

The steam train was $5 for ages 2+. Pretty pricey but was a must do for my train loving kid. 

We went counter clockwise through the park saving the play area for last. Three really great themed play structures based on age. 

I definitely would come back but preferably on a sunny weekday. Definitely could see coming here on the weekend would be crowded.
author: Sophia K.

description: This is a wonderful zoo! The set up flows really well and it has a great steam train, carousel and playground. A few beer stands were definitely a plus for the parents :) the only reason I didn't do all five stars was the fact that a few areas seems a little empty. It may have to do with the fact that it was a hot day.  Either way our family had a wonderful time and would definitely go again!!
author: Nicolette T.

description: Too bad some folks are being cheapskates and complaining about the zoo.  I think it is wonderful.  When we entered I felt like we were in a different world.  My favorite exhibits were the girraffes/ostrich in the African setting and the hippo.  There are so many different species here I think some people don't know how to appreciate it.  Also, if you go, you have to ride the little train...super fun.
author: Debbie R.

description: Amazing experience!! Great food, great prices...and great people! So easy to navigate throughout the zoo, and the park inside of the zoo was awesome! My little one had a blast! Thanks so much, SF ZOO staff members!!
author: Eleni T.

description: This review is just for the train ride. It's a Saturday afternoon and busy for train ride. It's 2:40 to be exact. We ( husband , me and 1.4 months baby) stayed in line like any others. Paid 6 dollars time 2 adults. Hope to get legit receipts.But! I got a 10 AM receipts. The cashier ( African American with glasses , older dude) did not type anything but just open the cashier. Woo ... better watch out for this dude. He just chose the wrong customer . It'll be danger if I request to audit this .
author: tammy z.

description:
Had a great day, most animals where active. Just a little cold. 

My favorite was the red panda. The ant eatter. The line was a little long for the president day weekend but the zoo did not feel crowded. 

The train cost 5 dollars. Prices will rise in April.
author: Fran C.

description: Ehhhh it's okay, a lot of the animals weren't there, or they just looked bored. It's easy to get lost here and miss animals (if they are there in the first place) but it was fun seeing the animals that we did get to see, the giraffes in particular looked well taken care of and the bobcat was interesting.
author: Katie H.

description:
My 6 year old kid: "Mommy, why does that rhino have 5 legs?"
Me:  "uhhhhh, let's go buy a churro"

 .....now, fast forward about 8 years later

My Kid: "Mom, hahahaha, check out that rhino's boner ...I'm gonna take a pic of it"
Me: "uhhhh, let's go buy a churro"

.....kids, no matter what the age, I tell ya....its never a dull moment. 

This zoo isn't the best zoo out there, but its not terrible either. Its a good size and a great spot to bring your family.  There is a playground and petting zoo for the younger kids and exhibits for the older ones. My teenager was amazed with the Washed Ashore exhibit when we went. All the items were debris found in Pacific beaches and made into art - some art featured was a 10 foot long instrumental eel, a Styrofoam reef drum set and a four foot tall swaying anenome chime. 

Since the zoo is located across from Ocean Beach, it can get chilly so make sure you dress in layers.

Tip: Bring your own food in and save some $$$
author: Marissa P.

description: It's a quaint little zoo, but has a lot of animals to observe. It took about 2 hours to get around the whole zoo.
author: Sierra E.

description: I've taken my son here a few times in the last year... sadly, every time we visit most of the exhibits are closed. We went the day before Mother's Day and there was a lot of construction going on, not much to see but pictures showing which animals should be there. The train ride and playground were the only things that saved this trip for us. Maybe next time.
author: Vanessa W.

description:
This was probably one of the best zoos I've been to. It's huge! And it's very well kept, we walked around the entire zoo and the paths were clean, no litter, no suspicious mud puddles. Great dose of nature when you live in the heart if the city.

It seemed very well researched, I appreciate that the animals just weren't caged for show, but they have a good bit of land close enough to their natural habitats. As soon as you walk in you see the giraffes, zebras, ostriches, and other funky birds just living together like the circle of life, without their predators of course.

We came on an SF Resident free day, yet surprisingly it wasn't crowded. Very peaceful and quiet, families and children just enjoying and RESPECTING the animals and zoo ground rules.

Wouldn't even mind paying regular admission to come here again.
author: Jenny M.

description:
Silver bells, silver bells, silver bells, silver bells, silver bells, silver bells, silver bells....

The length of time you stay at the zoo lights event depends on how long you can stand listening to the same Christmas song on repeat.

The primary light display played the song "Silver Bells" over and over, and you could hear the song through most of the park, so it begins to drive you mad. Perhaps they only had the license to play that single song?  Let's get crazy and have two songs!

Also, so many exhibits were closed down, which is understandable because animals need rest, but please make it more clear with roped off lights leading you on a path instead of having to guess whether or not the dark cavernous areas are open. 

Need more staff: the success of zoo lights depends on having one "expert" in each habitat area to give a presentation or answer questions for the guests. There was a staff member at the Koala exhibit, and the giraffe exhibit, but the rest were empty. 

The whole event felt like a ghost town, and it was a Saturday night. The Portland, Oregon Zoo Lights is packed full of people every year. Perhaps advertise better?

The two best things about zoo lights were: the train ride and the playground with snow machine. Those were the two most busy spots, with lots of squealing happy children.  If you don't have kids, you might want to pass on this event.

Zoo lights desperately needs a sign in the front-- one that actually says "Zoo Lights" for branding. Then people can get pictures with the sign and promote the event on social media for free!
author: Clara M.

description:
This zoo gets an unnecessary bad reputation. People say its depressing and the animals are sad but I saw no indication of that. The animals all seemed healthy and happy. I noticed one reviewer said the bald eagles were clipped, there's a bulletin board right in front of their habitat that says they were injured in the wild and recovered, they are unable to fly because injuries they sustained. 

People like to be keyboard activists when there's really no problem. The park was very clean, as were the habitats. I will definitely be going back to this zoo for years to come. 

I mean I spent probably an hour watching a wolverine run in circles with a bone in its mouth, they're happy as can be lol.
author: Nick S.

description: GREATTT place to take a 2 year old! The weather was perfect, not too crowded for being a Sunday. Maybe it was due to this location being so spacious and big it didn't seem like many people were there! My son had a blast at the playground which btw it's uhhhhmaaazing!! Even I had fun running around that place! It's really a great place to take your child and let them burn some energy off!! It's not only for young kids but even the older ones will have a great time as well!
author: N Karina M.

description:
First time here and I enjoyed it alot. I decided to come here because Sacramento Zoo isn't big compared to SF Zoo. I really enjoyed many of the sceneries at this zoo, and the playgrounds were cool.

Wished they had elephants and orangutans tho.
But overall, awesome zoo! And located by beach!
author: Lia V.

description: I love coming to the zoo. The animals are well cared for and fed. The keepers will answers any questions you have, even when your children start asking questions like "do you want a different job?" Mid week there is no crowds so it's like you have the place to yourself.
author: Sabrina L.

description:
I absolutely adore the SF Zoo. I grew up going to zoos and this has always been a second favorite to the SD Zoo. 

Parking can be a bit of a hassle if you do not come early, SO COME EARLY. You'll just end up parking along Sloat street and walking probably 1/3 of mile to even enter the zoo, which if you don't have little kids no big deal. But if you do have little kids, then big deal. The zoo opens at 10, be there at 10! Otherwise you can do valet parking for 10 dollars which may be worth it if you don't want to walk. But we arrived around 1 to meet family and it was completely packed, albeit we did go on a Saturday afternoon so there is that too. 

The zoo has had some great additions over the years. We love walking through the big giraffe exhibit and seeing the big cats, although there are some exhibits that do look quite depressing. The polar bear we saw did not seem happy, just our opinion, who knows maybe he is a very happy bear, but he didn't seem like a bear who would thrive in the wild. We kind of joked about it, shame on us. 

The park is the perfect size for a family outing. They've got a great petting zoo area for kids to enter and pet different barn animals as well as a couple great playgrounds with different themes that my baby cousin adored. One of the only downsides is this zoo feels like it closes early. It might just be because it's a pretty big zoo and 5 just seems so bright and sunny, but it's understandable. If you're hoping to get photos with your little ones and fun barn yard animals keep in mind that children's zoo side does close earlier than the rest of the zoo!
author: Jay K.

description:
Oh this poor, poor zoo. 

Listen, I'm not into the jailing of animals so much in the first place. However, I do like a good zoo. I grew up going to the SF Zoo. This place holds a seriously special place in my heart which is why we've taken my son now. Twice. 

Where are all the friggin' animals?!?! No elephants, no pigmy hippo, half of the damn zoo is missing! That said, the petting zoo and kids area has been redone very nicely. The playgrounds are REALLY nice. And the learning discovery art area near it is pretty cool too. 

Will we be back? Sadly yes. Because for some reason I can't stop loving the zoo I see in my mind circa 1990.
author: Laila P.

description:
3.5 stars. Had a good time with our family here on a weekday.

No crowds, which was nice when you're wheeling around a 6 month old. Plenty of places to sit, no trouble what-so- ever viewing the exhibits, I was able to look at the hippopotamus for as long as I liked.

Some highlights would have to be the tropical aviary. Exotic birds flying over your head, lots of reptiles. The python was pretty scary looking, put "Snakes on a Plane," to shame... although I guess it doesn't take much to do that.

Liked the grizzly bears, those crazy guys were playing & wrestling with each other in the pond. You can step down and see them close up, half underwater.

Would recommend not going on such a hot day, I think it was like 80° in the city by the bay. It made a lot of the animals find their little shade spots & not be very active. Was looking forward to seeing the lions a little more than just a tail or a pair of ears.

The train was fun & the engineer was really interactive with the riders. Don't recommended riding it with a baby, because I think the train whistle alarmed the poor guy a little bit. Kids were free, adults $5.

Looked like there was some construction going on for future exhibits.

Adults cost $16.00 for admission and children under 2 are free. It did seem from the website that these prices do change depending on the season.

Bring the kiddos, we had a good day.
author: Nicholas T.

description: Over half of the exhibits were closed when we went today.  They really should post a sign at the ticket booth alerting patrons they will not be getting a full zoo experience before they hand over many $$ for a disappointing experience.
author: Barbara B.

description:
You can almost smell the fresh poop in the air.. ahhhh. 

San Francisco zoo is definitely a wonderful place to go regardless of the smell of poop, hahah. The zoo is near Ocean beach which is nice and on some days it can get foggy so you should check the weather report for the day.

Parking inside is also expensive so I would suggest parking outside of the zoo. There is a lot of spots along the side of the zoo and they're all day parking so you can save money that way. A day ticket for an adult is $17 each by the way~ 

The zoo itself is just amazing. It's pretty much a roundabout walk so you should be able to hit every animal enclosure they have available! They have a large variety of animals especially primates and it's simply amazing just watching the animals do their thang. And there's also a schedule of feeding times so you should check that out if you get a chance!

Also, don't skip out on the children's zoo! Even if you don't have little kids with you, you should definitely check it out. They have a petting zoo up there so you can see hogs, donkeys, chickens, ducks... and even feed goats and sheeps! Definitely not a moment you want to miss. And don't worry, they provide hand sanitizer and sinks and soaps to wash your hands afterward. 

Food here is pretty expensive just like their souvenirs so you should bring energy bars or something if you want to save money. 

Bathrooms are also pretty clean and didn't smell so that was a good surprise. 

Overall, I want to come back to the zoo already! It's a fun place to be and you get to see a wide variety of animals! :)
author: Venus L.

description: more than half of the animals were asleep or not in thier exibits total waste of money
author: Ramon J.

description:
We went in on a rainy winter day and it was a great day to visit the zoo. There were no crowds and the animals were all very active. The park seemed almost abandoned and without the patrons to warrant it, most of the services in the zoo were suspended. That being said, the park is designed almost like a blossom or hub-and-spoke with the entrance at the base the flower. We were able to snack, use the family restroom, and play around in a photo booth between regions without going much out of our way. The staff was a skeleton mix of youth and veterans of the zoo, without much interaction there's not much to be said. To those who feel zoos are principally a challenge to the decency of animals as they are captives, this zoo's specimens were mostly rehabilitation and rescue animals. There were some that appeared to have been bred and raised in captivity based on the health and numbers of the giraffes. 

The polar bear on exhibit did seem outwardly somber compared to his peers, we noted that his compatriot two enclosures over had recently passed away and considered the possibility of this affecting his demeanor. The gorillas were off exhibit, to our misfortune. The hippo, lion pride, and bald eagles were all favorites to behold. 

While the issue of examining animals in capitivity walks the line between positive and negative awareness of the wild, the San Francisco Zoo accomplishes the task of raising positive awareness for the exotic habitats. The prices were very reasonable for entry and I recommend this for families and couples - while it is obviously capable of bringing enjoyment to anyone.
author: Jeremy T.

description:
I absolutely love animals. The zoo is quite honestly one of my favorite places on the planet. What I do not like is showing up to said zoo and coming to the realization that a pretty serious portion of the attractions are not actually a thing. 

My wife and in-laws brought our families to the San Francisco Zoo this week and were somewhat disappointed with what we got. Entry price and parking are a little bit steep, but nothing too severe. There was plenty of stuff to do for the kids, but as I said before some of the exhibits were lacking, or not there at all. 

My personal favorite attraction at the SF Zoo for the past 10-15 years has always been the big cat house. You are feet away from some enormous cats, as their roars fill the room. This is amazing, unless the house is closed on the day you go there. If this is the case, you are just shit out of luck. Also absent were a few monkey exhibits as well as elephants. It's like they took some of the biggest attractions, and just removed them. 

Of the animals that were there, it was pretty cool. The bug house is still pretty amazing and hosts a bunch of neat bug displays. My favorite here was the giant tarantula they had. Thing was pretty enormous. 

For kids there is still the petting zoo, the little kids areas, the absolutely huge playgrounds, and the carousel. Little kids will have an absolute blast here, while adults will be somewhat disheartened with the animal selection. 

Overall a decent experience, nothing really to write home about.
author: Chris S.

description:
This is my second trip to the SF ZOO. This trip was not as enjoyable as the first due to the construction. We spent a total is 2 hours there and we did not get to see the entire park. Even with the construction there was still plenty of things to see.  The best part of the visit for my son were the Penguins.  They were so close that it felt like you could touch them. 

I wish this info was shared on the main web page for people planing to visit the zoo.
author: P G.

description:
I love this zoo - 2nd best zoo in California (next to San Diego). Animals are well kept and there's a lot to see.  I've been coming here since I was a little kid (and the doggie diner actually existed across the street).  The petting zoo is great and they had baby chicks you could pet inside one of the buildings. The exploring things they have at 2pm are great, where they bring out small animals you can pet and learn about. 

We were here again the other day and the big cats were mostly inside. Oddly, they don't seem to do the feeding any more which was one of the highlights of the zoo.  No elephants out either which sucked. 

The gorillas are awesome as are the bears - they came right up to the glass. The polar bear was rolling around on his hay, very entertaining. 

No pink popcorn anymore which sucked. You have a hotdog at the ballgame, popcorn at the movies and pink popcorn at the zoo and they stopped selling it which was the one downer while we were here.

I love this zoo and will continue to frequent it until I'm too old to walk.
author: Chimpy L.

description: Loved coming here. My daughter had such a great time along with her cousins. Good amount on animal variety. The snacks not so great but doable.
author: Ivon R.

description: My son and I loved the playground. The weather was cool but that was perfect for a long day of walking and strolling around. We will definitely return.
author: Norma P.

description: I went to there every week with my daughter. Safe and zoo employee always there and also get a a year pass is worthy of getting there often if you live that area of the city.
author: Wengfai C.

description:
A good place to take the kids. I never say so many kids so happy in one spot. 

Lots of animals and it's simply awesome to see them doing what they normally do. Almost saw a baby gorilla killed by another gorilla, but the mother saved the baby just in time. 

Parking is a bit steep. I'd drive around until you actually find parking somewhere else. Drop the kids off and go look for parking. 

No elephants. 

Overall, a nice place to spend one of your weekend days with the kids.
author: Benny H.

description:
Went for Holiday Lights at SF Zoo because I wanted to see some animals & Holiday Lights.

Don't go if you don't have kids it's too lame without kids.  For adults it's $7.50 a person.  Not really worth it either.

Not much Holiday Lights - they put some along the hand rails & around some trees, some lights in the shape of animals near the entrance.

Animals seen:
Reindeer - 3 or 4 of them.  They got tired really fast.
Koalas - 2 of them, they were awake & ate some Eucalyptus leaves.
Komodo Dragon - a giant lizard, meh.
Aye Aye Forest - these cat/squirrel looking things that you can't see very well cuz they are in the dark at night, no photos allowed.
Big Bugs - 3 different live tarantulas & the rest was just giant bug sculptures!  So lame.

New playground for the kids, some kid games were free to play, Santa took pictures with the kids, & some entertainment was ok.  Carousel ride was Extra $2 ea for kids.  That's not cool.
author: Ann L.

description:
I love this zoo, I really do. It's not the biggest zoo out there, but it's ideal for a morning or afternoon trip. The whole place feels very clean, green and organized. It is clear to me that all the animals and exhibits are well taken care off. You can see that they are really making an effort in creating beautiful open environments for their animals.

Even though they are a bit smaller, they do have a wide variety of animals including koala's. And everyone knows that's the most important animal, right? If you have some crazy little animals (read: kids) of your own, I would definitely recommend this place. They have very nice playgrounds, a nice children's zoo, a carousel and a train. 

Furthermore, this zoo does not get too crowded. Even during the weekends it is tolerable. I would recommend parking outside of the zoo though as their parking is quite pricey ($8 during the week, $10 on weekends). The admission price is also pretty steep, so if you plan on coming here often, I would recommend getting the family membership. 

On a side note, I noticed that many people are writing negative reviews for this zoo because they are against locking up animals. While I agree that wild animals should be able to stay in their own natural habitat where possible, I do want to emphasize that without the conservation efforts of zoos and animal organizations in general, a lot of these species would be extinct. It is important to raise awareness of the condition some of these animals (in the wild) are in and I think this zoo does just that. Furthermore, many animals in this zoo were born in captivity and/or would never survive out in the wild (e.g.bald eagles, blind sea lions).
author: Ellen H.

description: must see the lonely and extraordinarily beautiful snow leopard, why don't give it a partner?
author: Freya-Loki O.

description:
I think this was once a great zoo that has been sadly neglected. Needs tender loving care and some paint. Many of the exhibits ponds and water features were empty. Electrical conduit with missing cover just waiting for a child to stick his finger in.  Signs all faded and chipped...the place just looks worn. However...the animals look well cared for, at least they are spending their money on the most important thing.

The great city if SF needs to wake up!
author: Mark L.

description:
We came to the SF zoo this past weekend and had a nice time. Plenty of parking on the street, so if you're active and want to save a few bucks, that's what I'd suggest doing. 

The Zoo itself is very clean with nice habitats for the animals. There's plenty of places to hang out and watch the animals do their thing. Weather can be unpredictable so wear layers and sunscreen.
author: Stephanie G.

description:
This is my zoo, have loved it since childhood. A zoo is a hard business, walking the fine line between conservation and entertainment for sustainability. SF Zoo helps its cause with providing lots of education, including the childhood favorite of the Nature Walk, run by kids in the community who learn to be responsible and spread their love of animals.
There's always new exhibits every so often, keeping things fresh but also cherishing their classics like the rainforest building and now refurbishing their monkey exhibits.
I recently got to bring my young nephew here and re-start the cycle of zoo adventures for the next generation!
author: Tina K.

description:
This zoo is much smaller than I was expecting; for one thing, it probably only took me and my classmates about an hour to see the whole thing. We were mainly there for the primate exhibit (for anthropology class). The exhibits are exceptional! I was mainly excited for the lemurs.

The lemurs, speaking of, tend to be more active when it warms up. We came around 10am, and they weren't quite awake just yet. They also have a few other primates as well, and various other areas and exhibits. Australian, African, etc.

We also ended up eating at the Lemur cafe, which was okay as far as food goes. But pricey! If you're planning to eat here, expect Disneyland-like prices for it. Other than the outrageous food pricing, it was fun.

Kids will love it, since there is so much to see. Best day to go is on a weekday since there are less people there.
author: Molly M.

description: This review is long over due! I visited back in October for my birthday. We came on a Thursday and it was lovely. It's been years since I've been here (my 13th birthday to be exact) and it's just as wonderful as my last visit. The zoo is huge and there is so much to see. All of the animals look happy and healthy. It was clean and not busy, mind you we did visit on a weekday. I loved the African Safari with the giraffes and zebras. The monkey exhibit was also fun! They have so many different species and one of them had a 4 month old baby. It was adorable! Penguin island was amazing! You get up close and personal with them and it's not a typical display where they are behind glass. They really are on their own little island! We were here for 2-3 hours and had a great time. I highly recommend this zoo, it's well worth the visit.
author: Anna S.

description: I had a great time at this zoo.  This zoo is very well organized and split up into: Outback Trail, African region, Primate Discovery Center, Children's Zoo, Cat Kingdom, South America and Bear Country.  My favorite is the Cat Kingdom because of the tigers.  Sadly, the lion exhibit was closed because one of the lions just gave birth.  They have penguins and polar bears at this zoo as well.  That was a bit shocking as I thought they only live in super cold climates.  The animals have plenty of space to roam and there are good platforms with which to view the animals from.  Also, they have two big playgrounds that is great for kids.  There is an ice and forest playground.  It sort of looks like a mix of ice and fire.  I recommend car pooling here because parking is expensive.  The only downside is that a lot of schools and organizations do field trips here so your odds of seeing crying children are high.  Overall, I had a great experience and would definitely come back in the future.
author: Dang L.

description:
OVERALL: San Fransisco Zoo is pretty decent zoo, but it's nothing special when compared to other zoos. They have the "usual" attractions like lions and tigers and bears . There is a main food court/cafeteria along with the food stands that are scattered through out the park. They do have a parking lot.

PROS: The layout of the zoo is pretty fluid and un-confusing; especially when you also have a map in hand! The food court has a decent amount of options and pretty big servings too. They have a variety of animals with educational placards near each exhibit. They have a petting zoo with super cute baby animals!

CONS: The facilities aren't anything special. Some places are usually dirty. The food is expensive. Some animals don't seem all that happy in their environments.

NOTES: Parking was $8 for their lot but rates may change. Go see the adorable animals at the petting zoo! The beach is a block down the street and it's about a 20-30 minute drive to down town SF depending on traffic. If you go in the off season, you'll basically have to zoo to yourself!
author: Katie F.

description: We are members and love the place; coming here at least once a month with our 3 years old son. All is great here but what the hell have they done with the main restaurant!!! The menu use to be well designed with lots of healthy and diverse options...today to our disappointment, only burgers, wraps sandwiches and pizzas...this is extremely frustrating and will discourage us to renew the membership as the lunch was a part of our visit.
author: Jonathan M.

description:
My husband and I bring my son here a lot since we are members.   If you live in the city it's definitely worth it to become a member. We've visited over 10+ times in the past few months and our membership has definitely paid for itself with our visits. 

Since our little one is 4 years old, the children's zoo is one of our favorite places to visit because it's such a great learning opportunity for him.  It's wonderful when they have events and they have several throughout the year. I've been to Boo at the Zoo and Holiday lights and both are great. 

My sons favorite place in the zoo is the playground.  He LOVES that place and begs to go there every time we get there.   For the little ones, make sure to visit the little train they have which goes around a section of the park.  My son loves this train and waves every time it passes us by.  If you sign up to be a member, you receive several a couple free passes to ride the train with your little ones.  

if you want to save money on parking, you can park on Sloat blvd and walk over to the zoo.  If you're OK with paying for the sake of convenience, it's about $8 on weekdays and $10 on weekends to park in the zoo parking area.  I always feel bad for the animals because they're in cages and I honestly don't believe in keeping animals in captivity.  But I go to take my son so he can use this as a learning opportunity.  
Love their playground...
author: Christine P.

description: Was debating whether or not to go here or go to Oakland zoo for a date with my boyfriend and I'm glad we picked SF! The weather was chilly and windy but that was expected of SF! The zoo had a playground for kids and so many different exhibits! I was glad that I got the chance to see tigers, lions, gorillas, a hippo, a polar bear, and plenty of giraffes, and plenty of monkeys! They have peacock running wild here as well! I'm glad I was able to see some of these animals as I am aware many are in critical danger in the wild. Furthermore the polar bear, Ulu, is the only polar bear SF has after Pike passed away. Ulu is 33 years old and that is very old for a polar bear. So I was very happy to get the chance to see her as I hear that polar bears are also endangered.
author: Celine L.

description: Grew up going to this zoo and its great to see there grading and expanding enclosures and adding a more natural environment. For the complaints of skinny chimps they are one of the oldest troops in northern ca so tend to be a lil rough. Most the animals here are rescues wich is a plus. Some of the enclosure are empty but those are because there to small and they havent expanded them yet, good reason for them to be empty. Animals looked healthy and happy. Some like alot of the monkeys still need there cages changed over to a more natural style but all in all a nice zoo. The hippo could also use a enclousure makeover as still not alot of space or very deep water. For a very old zoo tho you can see there really trying to change to a more natural cage type. My fave is the gorrillas there so fun to watch. The playground is huge, train ride is fun and the merrygoround is beautifull. Plan to spend all day this place is huge.
author: Charlene L.

description:
A girlfriend and I decided to jam all four car seats into one truck and venture into the city to hit up the zoo.

The bad:

The parking is TERRIBLE. We drove around and around and ended up at a lot that is quite the trek, especially for small children.

The scanner they use to get the bar code from your purchased in advance tickets is bad. Took the gal several times with us zooming in and out on our phone. 

The layout of the zoo is not very user friendly and doesn't seem to make sense.

I do not feel like there were enough bathrooms and the ones they had were very spread out.

The good:

The entrance fee was reasonable. 

The gift shop was well stocked with all kinds of zoo animal related paraphernalia and was priced fairly reasonably. The gals at the shop were super nice and very helpful.

Stroller rentals are so worth it.

The ok:

The animals were often times hard to see and some of the enclosures seem a bit small.

All in all it was just ok.

I probably won't go back, because the Oakland Zoo is far better.
author: Melissa H.

description:
I took the little one to his first zoo visit since he's had an interest in animals lately. We came here on a monday and it was nice it wasn't overly busy. They have some animals here that they don't have at Oakland zoo but surprisingly, they don't have elephants. A lot of the animals seemed down and sad. The zoo is bigger than Oakland Zoo and I like that they have a lot of trees and greenery but it just looks like an old zoo under constant construction with sad animals. 

They do have a ridiculously cool playground for kids and toddlers which were full of kids playing happily. So there's that.
author: Rehana K.

description:
$20 entrance fee for a limited number of animals and exhibits. That's what you're paying for. 
I've been coming to the SF Zoo since I was a little kid and I've always wished they could do a better job showcasing the animals and having experienced/knowledgable people walking around engaging visitors. 
It's sad to walk all the way back to see the grizzly bears without seeing many exhibits or animals. Most of the zoo is old. They really need a major makeover. It was smart of them though to makeover the playground since it's their main feature. Sad. 
It would be nice to have a world class zoo.
author: Stormtrooper N.

description:
First of all, this is a great place to take kids. Besides the animals, there's also a petting zoo with goats and sheep, a large playground, and a train ride (usually--it wasn't running the day we were there). In other words, there's plenty to keep the kids busy for an entire day. 

Some people have complained about the animals' living conditions. Well, I've seen better, but I've also seen MUCH worse. I also think there's a fair amount of anthropomorphization at work in some reviewers' descriptions of the animals' emotional states. It does seem that some of the exhibits are a bit out of date (most Yelpers are probably too young to remember what zoos looked like thirty years ago), and are being upgraded one by one. Similarly, some exhibits have a lot of educational material attached, while others have the bare minimum. I paid extra for the "Zoo Key," which lets you unlock little audio clips near some exhibits, but I wouldn't recommend that--there weren't that many places to use it, and the extra content wasn't that interesting. 

All in all, we had a good time here, and would be happy to go again.
author: Nicholas D.

description:
We took our family to the zoo on a Thursday during spring break from 1:30-5 and it wasn't very crowded. It was our first time as a family and the kids loved it. The first thing you see is the giraffes, and it really gets the kids excited. This one giraffe was showing off a lot, which was funny. There are a lot of different viewing spots for the animals which is good because you can see pretty much everything.
