By the time we got to the lions and tigers they were resting, and not very active so next time we are going there first thing. The polar bear was cool but also very sleepy. 
The train ride was awesome! I definitely recommend that. There's not many views on the train but it goes fast which makes it exciting. 

A few reasons they are only getting three stars from me:
The cafe next to the train stopped serving food around 4 and we walked all the way there because we were hungry. 

Also, the carousel guy closed the ride early (even though the OPEN sign was still up) and my daughter was crying right in front of him and he didn't even care. She was really looking forward to going on and then he said it was the last ride of the day, sorry. Another family wanted to ride too. If I were him, I would have just ran it one more time since the zoo wasn't closed yet. He did not have good service or a good attitude. 

Otherwise, the service is all right. Seems like the animals are treated pretty good, and they have a lot of space to roam.
author: Amber H.

description: Zoo is cool but if u need a ride there and back make sure to get dropped off and picked up out side of the zoo parking lot. I had to pay an extra 12 dollars just so we could leave the parking lot from being picked up from the zoo. But like I said the zoo is cool the just that they dont let u know from the beginning.
author: Dalton O.

description: Navigating throughout the SF Zoo has many challenges for anybody in a self propelled wheelchair.  There are many uneven and steep inclines on the many paths/grounds at the SF zoo.  It adversely affects anyone who's in a wheelchair.  I thought I could independently handle myself in my wheelchair, but there were many areas of the zoo that I had to pass up due to steep sections of the ground.  Also, the former Children's zoo that they now have renamed the Exploration zone was also frustrating to handle the uneven pavements.  The sand in the Barn area made it almost impossible to maneuver my wheels, creating a lot of slippage and not enough adequate grip.  To be honest, I don't think I'll ever visit the SF zoo again (independently).  I would recommend to any wheelchair bound individual to have someone with you so that you can be pushed to safe guard yourself.  Of course there were sections of the zoo that were manageable, but when someone visits the zoo and pays their steep entrance fee, you want to be able to see all of the animals and not be limited.
author: Anuhe'a K.

description:
I've been to a couple of zoo and San Francisco's Zoo isn't bad at all. I was on the skeptical side, because of all the bad review, but it turns out every review was wrong. I got the chance to explore the whole zoo and it took a little over 3 hours. A lot of animals and we enjoyed every minute of it. Of course, like any other zoo the food/drinks inside are very expensive. Eat before you go. We ended up buying a bottle of water, because we got thirsty. 

We went in the morning and some animals were sleeping, but woke up later. 
Loved the bears and gorillas tho. Very active when we were there.
author: Chang R.

description:
I can't believe it took me over five years to make it to the zoo. I even had been given a discount card by my company and managed to loose it. It took me too long. 

They have a private parking lot and it's $8 to park there. It's probably a good option for families that have to carry a bunch of stuff. The Muni L line ends a block away from the Zoo and it's really a convenient way to get here. If you show a Muni Pass you get a dollar of admission. Also if you're an SF resident show your license for a discount. Everyone has to have your license of they won't give that person the discount (ask how I know).

I'll start with the good. It's a really nice outdoor setting that's a great place to walk around on a nice day. Bring your own food and drinks and have a picnic at one of the tables. It was pretty quiet when I was there so I could see these filling up quickly. 

There are a number of Peacocks roaming around the grounds and going in and out of the animal enclosures. Obviously they don't pay any attention to the signs saying to respect the animals. If you're here a few minutes and can't find a peacock, just wait a few minutes and you'll hear their loud, squawking call. Then it's really easy to find them. 

There's a decent assortment of animals to check out and most of the grounds are well kept. Some of the enclosures are creative. We rounded a corner and saw this Giraffe head peeking over this rock. He was licking something on top of this rock. It was very cute to watch him with his long black tongue trying to get at whatever. A lot of the enclosures have pretty good points for viewing the animals. 

Then the not so bad. If you're expecting something of the caliber of the San Diego Zoo or even the California Academy, you will be disappointed. There were a number of animals off display, parts of the zoo under repair, or in need of repair. Parts of it (and I'm not just talking the animal enclosures) could use some cleaning or upkeep. 

Then there's the ugly. Granted we were here on a weekday and the park was a little dead, but the animal talks we went to were really disappointing. We went to the 2:30 big cat talk and we got there early to get a spot. No one was there. We hunted a bit and found a sign. OK, 2:30 big cat talk here at 2:30. We checked it out a bit and a couple of other people showed up. We figured we had some time so we headed across the path to the rhino. We had fun watching this Peacock that was jumping between the enclosure and viewing wall. At a couple of minutes before 2:30 we walk back over. There's one of the same people that was there before and she kind of shrugged, nothing. We waited until about 2:45-2:50 before someone else started looking for someone that worked at the zoo. She reported she caught someone about to go out an exit. I guess this person called someone on the radio. Someone did show up about five minutes later. She thanked us for coming to the zoo and read mostly from the signs. She was also very hard to hear and a few of the dozen or so people who waited asked her to repeat things a couple of times. We got frustrated and left to go check out the rest of the zoo. How disappointing!

I think we can cross the SF Zoo off our list as been there, done that. I'm a member at the California Academy and find that more enjoyable. We also have been meaning to go check out the Oakland Zoo.
author: Scott L.

description:
I had such a great experience here! I've been to other zoos before (including the San Diego Zoo), and although this one isn't nearly as big, I honestly had a better experience here. Maybe I just came on a good day, but it wasn't too busy, the animals were extremely active so I got to see all my favorites in action, and I was able to see everything I wanted to see. I watched a tiger play with his ball for an hour and I was extremely close up! That probably made my entire trip. The problem with larger and more popular zoos is that they're overcrowded and impossible to complete in one day.

Lots and lots of cute little munchkins running around which made for an even better date for my bf and I. :)
author: Justine V.

description: My family loves this zoo.  It is my favorite zoo that I have ever been to.  The animals are more active here than at other places.  They have awesome educational programs, particularly aimed at kids (although I think I enjoy it more than my kids!), where you can pet or get closer to an animal and get information from volunteers. A lot of the animals are rescued.  I love the gorillas. Kids playground is amazing!
author: Christine H.

description:
Attn: this review only for kids playground!

Best playground i ve ever seen! Love the design.
My 2year all had great fun. We would be visiting this playground if there was a separate fee for that not including zoo.
Has designated area for any kind of ages. Figures of animals. And of course carousel.
author: Akylai A.

description: Lots of red zones were taken up by cars. Red zones are for emergency services and when we notified the staff of people parking there they said that it's ok because valet is there. People can still get tickets for that! But I guess if you're valet you can break the law.
author: HangryYelper ..

description: I've been a member for a while now but haven't been to the Zoo in a few months.  I took a friend.  It was around Noon on a Friday.  Even with a map, we had some trouble finding the animals we wanted to see and then there were no animals, basically, to see and the trails were confusing or closed.  The bird aviary was gone, or we couldn't find it.  We found 3 lions but no tigers, one monkey, a couple of giraffes, a sleeping rhino.  For the kids, I guess that was enough.  I was going to write and ask what was going on because once there was a wonderful little zoo here but I didn't see it on this outing.  The Terrace Cafe is now a pizza Parlor (Argh) and none of the snack carts, etc. were open.  We went to the Leaping Lemur Cafe and the food looked awful.  The visit was a disaster for us.  What is going on here?
author: Victoria S.

description: Great zoo! The staff was very friendly and let us pet the animals and the zoo is very clean and the food was good perfect price only downfall I would say is that some of the animals are not in the cages instead you have to walk around and see the other side of the exhibit but still a fun time!
author: Addison M.

description:
This is my first time at a zoo so I had done some research on this place before heading over. Based off their official website, I found free parking very close to the zoo (lots of room on a wednesday morning). Not only that, it was also a the day of the month where SF residents with ID could come into the zoo for free!

I also noticed that there were certain time intervals where events occurred: when a certain animal will come out, when they will be fed etc. I found that they stuck to this schedule 90% of the time. 

The zoo is pretty small if you just want to see the animals in its physical form, but if you actually sit down and actually enjoy their presence then this trip will definitely take at least 2 hours. If I had the time, I would've sat for hours on end at the red panda,  monkey, and the penguins exhibit! They are one of the few animals that actually move around a lot. 

Unlike most parks that have pigeons or crows walking around, this park has peacocks (both male and female) walking around the park like they own the place. #peacockselfie it's quite amusing too because they would sneak in during another animal's feeding time and eat along with them !

However what sucks is that they do not post on their official site which exhibits are closed or down for construction....bummer!!
author: Dixie L.

description:
I'm not sure why so many people are given the zoo such a bad rap. I may be a little biased since I've been coming to this zoo since I was five. I actually haven't visited The zoo in probably over 10 years and while a lot of it remain the same a lot of it changed for the better. Now to all the people that say that the animals don't look happy, it's a zoo there in an enclosure what what did you expect. This is an African savanna, it's a metropolitan zoo.  I have a toddler and he thinks it's great. 
The exhibits I really like are the giraffes and if you stick around until 3:45 you can go into the giraffe paddock where they sleep at night and talk to the zookeeper.  You can ask them any questions you want about giraffes and they will answer. Apparently the male giraffe is too good at mating so that's why he separated from the females.
The zoo also has a really cool playground for kids as well as a petting zoo. 
Other exhibits I highly recommend would be the lemur exhibit. There are tons of lemurs and depending on what time you go they will be jumping around all over the place.

If you have a kid live in the area who likes animals this is a great place to come and visit. Try to visit on a sunny day as the animal seem to be more active than when it is foggy.
author: Vincent W.

description:
This is a really nice zoo. This is the second time I have been here. The last time was in 2009. Things are nicer this time with more animals.  I can't believe we stayed there for at least 5 hours! The highlight of this trip was seeing the Flamingo chicks! So cute!  I really liked the Red Panda too.  
The cafe at the Leaping Lemur was surprising. They have Chicken Adobo!  It was very good just like home in Hawaii.
author: Kim O.

description: Loved this zoo and so did the kids we had 4 with us ages 3,4,8,10 they all had a blast . Love how all the animals were out. Except one wich was the kimoto dragon.the park area was lots of fun they all enjoyed the slides and swings. We have beento sacramento zoo oakland zoo fresno zoo and now sf zoo.this zoo was by far the best one we habe visited in these areas. Bigger than oakland and more to see tha. The rest. Affordable and the weather was perfect. We willbe visiting agai. In the future.
author: Sharai S.

description:
I came here for my twins' birthday and we all had fun. We got here around opening time when it was still cool, so many of the animals were still a little sleepy (I heard animals tend to be more active when it's a little warmer). We started to leave around 2pm and even then people were still coming in and the park was a lot more crowded by that point. So keep that in mind when you're planning your trip: morning = emptier but sleepy animals; noon/afternoon = crowded but active animals.

We all had fun walking around the park with my 4yos and looking for animals. They are big fans of the show Wild Kratts, so this was an opportunity for them to look for animals that they otherwise only get to see in cartoon form. The zoo isn't super large, which was actually a good thing for us. This way, we were able to ask them which animal they wanted to see next and then just go there instead of having to follow a set path for convenience' sake. Be warned, though, that there are no elephants here. My boys are big elephant/Dumbo fans, so they were a little sad about that.

Parking at the lot is I think $8 and very worth it for us. There's also parking across the highway on the roads for free, but it can get crowded there as well.
author: Maureen C.

description:
This is a rather infamous zoo. If you watched Jurassic World and thought, "those engineers couldn't possibly have been stupid enough to put such a large dinosaur in such an under-engineered enclosure," well, that actually happened at the San Francisco Zoo with the tiger exhibit. In 2007, a tiger leaped over a wall that was not tall enough and killed one visitor and injured two others. News reports blamed the victims for likely having taunted the tiger. Note that they were separated from the tiger by a 33 ft. wide moat and probably reasonably expected that the tiger would not be able to leap out of the enclosure.

In the aftermath of the attack, the zoo claimed the wall surrounding the moat was over 20 ft. tall. They later stated that it was actually only 12.5 ft. tall (the recommended safe height is apparently 16.5 ft.).

The zoo's also had trouble with animal maltreatment. It's banned by the city from having elephants because its enclosures were too small and the elephants were all dying. A gorilla was recently crushed to death by a sliding door.
author: Ryan L.

description:
My family and I visited SF Zoo for the Zoo Lights and were extremely disappointed. We come from San Leandro so it was quite a drive but the kids wanted to go this year for the train ride and the reindeers. We went in a group of 9, 7 adults and 2 kids. We got there around 6pm, played the games and rode the carousel and enjoyed the fake snow. We arrived at the train station at 7pm and to our surprise the train was not running anymore for the rest of the night. We went back to maybe cheer the kids up by going to see some live animals such as the reindeers and the giraffes but they were gone for the night as well. I don't understand why all the big attractions were closed for the night when there was still an hour of park time left and it is limited for 3 hours for zoo lights. I honestly feel cheated because we paid for the tickets, gas, and toll, and sat in traffic and didn't get to do anything we wanted to. If the attractions were closed I feel that we should've been notified at the front desk while purchasing our tickets.

I have came here on a regular operating day and was pretty satisfied with everything. All the animals were out and everybody was cheerful. The kids loved it. Food prices are expensive but that's expected. So maybe zoo lights is just a way to make extra money for the holidays for them? Because of this experience I'm not sure if I'll be returning.
author: Maureen P.

description: Please don't come here for the Halloween boo at the zoo. There's nothing fun for kids. We spent the whole day here and didn't get a piece of candy for trick or treating; there are some Trader Joe's stickers if you like. Otherwise, nothing booing at the zoo. We saw many kids carrying empty jack o lantern buckets for trick or treating while leaving with the same empty buckets. I can't tell you how disappointed my kids were. Don't get trick to come here for Halloween.
author: Woopie D.

description: Arrive early because the parking fills up fast and the line can be huge.  Once in the zoo the monkeys and lemurs are adorable, make sure you see the penguins and hippo as well as the African Savannah. The second floor ramp near the monkeys has a great view of the sea, it is a perfect place for pictures.
author: Ac C.

description: My kids always love going to the zoo and seeing all of the animals. They love playing in the playground and I appreciate the fact that they have 3 different play structure geared to 3 levels of age group. All though you can't stop the older kids from going into the younger kids play environment (it is the parents responsibility to keep an eye on their kids) they all somewhat seem to play well together. Lots of different exhibits of animal and a dedicated insect house. Oh and let's not forget the petting zoo.  All in all this is a great place to take the kids if they love animals.
author: Rebecca O.

description:
HAD A BLAST AT THE ZOO TODAY

Really enjoyed the grizzly feeding, the animal exhibits were great, even the overpriced hot dog wasn't bad.

I know zoos have a bad rep right now with a strong eyeballing from animal activists, but check this out: one of their sea lions was shot in the face and is blind. This zoo took him in, nursed him back to health, and because of his injury he is able to spend the rest of his life here being cared for.

All this nonsense about zoos being evil, etc., is just that: nonsense.

They provide a valuable educational need, and manage to help a few animals in the process too. And from what I can see, not a single animal is mistreated in any way.

I don't condone caging wild animals for the sole purpose of revenue generation. But I don't believe that is happening here, based on my limited exposure.
author: Randy S.

description: Coming here was one of my biggest regrets when I was in town a week ago. Not only is it run-down, a lot of the exhibits are empty, and the animals are some of the most unhappy I've seen. I'm no animal expert but when I saw the 2 river otters and the polar bear aggravatingly rattling the back door to leave their exhibit and back to their cages, I knew there must be something wrong. I'm kind of against zoos in the first place, so now I know better than to let myself be convinced to go to one if they're all as depressing as this.
author: Sam M.

description:
I love going to zoos and each time we've gone, it's been relatively peaceful and quiet. That's what we enjoy about this zoo in particular; it's a great way to spend the time learning and viewing various animals. It's got a great spread and the walkways throughout it are great. Not to mention that there will be a peacock in your path walking alongside or in the other direction. Actually that's one of our games; spot the peacock where it ought not be. In the last visit, there was totally two of them hanging out with the kangaroos. 

All around fun to be had at the zoo. :)
author: Shauna S.

description:
I loved this place. My son had so much fun. There was this older lady that worked that that was giving us cool facts about the animals. The white tiger (forgot the actual name) was absolutely gorgeous! Will definitely come back soon. 
Food is pretty expensive so be sure to bring some food with you or be full by the time your here.
author: Sicia O.

description: After living in the area all these years I decided it was time to hit the zoo. With an 18 month old in tow I set off to find it. I missed the turn the first time because the giant sign that says zoo is 1/4 mile after the branch that leads off to the right and is protected by a median strip. After doing a not so quick U-turn and another not so quick U-turn I was able to navigate my way into the parking lot and heading to the zoo. I really like how the entire zoo is set in the midst of a wooded area. It has a really nice sense of aesthetic to it. The staff is all super nice so I got my ticket and in I went. I arrived around noon and it seemed but a lot of animals were taking naps. So I made my way over to the playground area where my little one had a blast while waiting for some of the animal exhibits to perk up. All in all I think it's a really nice zoo. It has a lot of attractions are great for kids will and are really well-stocked souvenir shop as well.
author: Dave S.

description: This was our fist time here and we loved it. My boys had so much fun! So many animals to see. We love the farm animal area, where you are able to pet the animals. The playground is was nice and big for the kids to run around and play. The train was was nice as well.
author: Khiet E.

description:
Hands down the best exhibit is Tenzing the Red Panda!!

My partner and I traveled to San Francisco from San Jose just to see the zoo. To be honest, I found out that they had a red panda exhibit and I begged my partner until he said we could go there. However, this zoo definitely offers more than just a red panda.

The zoo has a pretty spacious parking lot although we did come on a weekend in September and most kids are in school by then. It was really empty so we parked close by and went to buy our tickets. Unfortunately we are not residents of SF so our ticket was 17$ per person. However, I thought this was quite a nice price considering that I've been to zoos where the price is over 25. You can pay for parking here as well and it costs 8$ per vehicle. We were given maps and then headed to enter into the park. The map comes in handy and shows you all the exhibits that you can go to. They are broken up by region/category. Here our some of our definite favorites.

Tenzing the red panda. I absolutely thought he was the most gorgeous animal out of the entire zoo. There is only one and he likes to take naps so it is rare to see him. We got lucky and saw him move up onto his tree house and lay down to take a nap. I was pleased.

Petting zoo. This is one of the best parts of the zoo. They have a mini farm with pigs, goats and mini donkeys. They have some goats out that you can brush and feed (50 cents for the food). The goats are quite friendly and they lick the food right off your hand! I was able to take quite a few pictures with the goats.

Flamingos. There is a huge flock and we saw about three baby flamingos. They are white and fluffy!! 

Otters. The two little otters we got to see were just angels. They were swimming around and twirling around each other over and over again.

Koalas. The one koala we saw was brought in by a zookeeper and put on the branch. It was the absolute perfect picture!

Insect zone. I'm not a huge fan of insects and I'm terribly terrified of spiders. However, they offer a lot of different insects to look at. There is a bee hive right inside (glass covered, don't worry!) and even an ant hill as well! This insect zone is bigger than most zoos offering cockroaches, beetles, spiders, ants, and many others. Not my favorite part, but if you like the creepy looking stuff, this is your place.

Giraffes. Just 3 weeks ago a baby giraffe was born! The baby was so adorable to look at and take pictures of.

Penguins. There isn't glass that is between you and the penguins. The exhibit is pretty open and you can get a real good look at them.

Peacocks. Some are in exhibits and some are just roaming around. They are friendly and you can take very close up photos of them.

Giant anteater. We were lucky and saw him come out and he is huge! It was really amazing.

Monkey exhibit. There are a ton of monkeys to look at and they even provide an upstairs for you to look at them at a different perspective! It was really clever.

Crowned crane. This bird by the far has the craziest hairdo. I love when it flaps it's wings around like crazy.

Furthermore, we also liked looking at the polar bear, rhinos, lovebirds, sea lions, snow leopard, hippo, and emu.

They have a cafe that you can eat it which is a little overpriced. They have plenty of penny machines for souvenir collectors and a cute little souvenir shop before you leave. We got a red panda plush to take home. :)

I really liked this zoo and thought it had a lot of animals to look at. Unfortunately there was still some renovating going on and a lot of the animals were sleeping as well. Great date spot and it took us about 3 hours to complete the whole thing.
author: Liz C.

description:
I saw a dik-dik in real life. That was enough to make my trip worth it! Then, I saw a super active sloth just going everywhere as fast as it could. Then it hung upside down from the tree to eat some dirt for minerals and get some belly rubs from the trainer. I spent maybe 15 minutes just watching the sloth do sloth things. The Hearst grizzly bear habitat is very nice too. 

I was there on a random weekday, so it wasn't even remotely crowded. It was easy to see everything. The only downside was that the komodo dragon exhibit and koala exhibit were both closed when I was there.
author: Ryan H.

description:
I always have had a blast here at the SF zoo! Though parking is $8 to park in the lot, you can park on the street for free and just walk one or two blocks. It's always great because they have a variety of animals and it's the biggest zoo among the 2 in the Bay Area. 
I would recommend bringing your own water and snacks. They have a building with different foods but they are pretty expensive. A slice of pizza is about $7, water bottles are $4 and dip n dots are also $5. 
It's nice to go on a weekday in the morning because it's not as busy as on a weekend!
author: Daniella D.

description: Very disappointed in this zoo. Only one nice exhibit that was the giraffe and zebra exhibit. Most other exhibits looked unkempt and care worn. Didn't see many animals out and about. A lot were in corners sleeping. Brookfield Zoo in Chicago is sooo much nicer. I would not have bought tickets if I had known how poorly it was kept. We wasted a whole day. Would not recommend it and won't be back.
author: Denise S.

description:
We had a fun day exploring this zoo last weekend. The zoo itself isn't too big (a good thing, since we didn't really want to spend the entire day at the zoo) but they manage to keep the grounds clean and it doesn't stink as bad as other zoos tend to.

The animals in their exhibit seem to be good shape, with the exception of the rhinos - they were so thin!  But for us, the best part of the zoo was the bear country!  We got to see the grizzly bears up close..munching their food...sooo cute!

Overall, I really enjoyed my trip to the SF zoo...Just had to take off one star for its parking (it gets full quickly) and their cafeteria food which was disappointing.
author: Veronica C.

description:
My family and I are huge zoo enthusiasts.
 In Every trip,vacation Or getaway we always try to insert a zoo visit  in our Itinerary. 
But I have to say, this Zoo is very Disappointing and needs major work.
The experience was mediocre and we're  very put off by most of the habitats, the way they are displayed and the evidente lack of stimulation they bring to the animals inhabiting   In it 
 The polar bear exhibit was by far the worst habitat we have  ever experienced in all the zoos we have ever been to,  the  bears were dirty and  laying on concrete and mortar enclosure  with no visible reference  to its natural  environment  which, from an educational stand point is a vastly lost Opportunity to Educate lil Ones about the different  types of weather and places.
 In my Honest opinion, a great Zoo, should have at least  two of this elements,a hint Of fantasy and a strong educational outlook.  After all most people visit a zoo to experience animals that they have only Heard about or seen in tv or Pictures.
 Please not this Review is base  on visit made almost a year ago But  it have made such bad lasting experience that every time  have that  desire to  make a trip to the zoo I automatically talk myself Out of it but I'm posting now cos I'm planing to visit the Oakland zoo and have my fingers crossed  hope it is a great  experience 
Wish me luck
author: Cátia T.

description:
Great great zoo, especially for a city. It's big, and the animal enclosures seem well-designed, even keeping different species together where appropriate. There are lots of zookeepers around to ask questions. There's also a huge diversity of animals at the zoo, providing places to explore for an entire day.

There were lots of baby animals when we were there, though we later learned that the baby gorilla had been killed by a shutting enclosure that couldn't be manually overridden. Hopefully the zoo will make appropriate changes in all of its enclosures, because it really is such an outstanding attraction in the city, tragedy aside.
author: Allison M.

description: I'd give 10 stars if I could - seriously the best deal in town; if you live in SF or Daly City then by all means support the zoo with a family membership. A hidden gem are the summer camps, classes for little ones and the fact so many dedicated people work and volunteer in many capacities. Both my kids are always out and about and fully engaged visiting animals or just having a blast in the BEST playground in town.
author: Papa Dadoo B.

description:
It's a zoo. It has animals.. Some.. There are no elephants and the animals they do have seem a bit tired and old. It's still a great place for children as it's the perfect size to walk around without getting extremely exhausted. The children's playground is also very creative in the way it stays with theme.

Parking is very difficult so prepare to walk a lot from where you park to the zoo!

There are plenty of restrooms and spots to buy drinks.

If you are deciding between this and the Oakland zoo for children I'd say go to Oakland.
author: Anitha C.

description: Waste of money all the animals are sleeping did not get to see as much as animals that I was wait to see the only thing  I like was the train station
author: Mary J.

description:
We LOVE the zoo! We recently became members of the zoo and are there at least twice a week. One time we came twice in a day!

The children's playground is top notch. They have specific areas of the playground for different age groups so you don't have to worry about a big 5 year old running over your 1 year old. 

They have different animal feedings scheduled throughout the day which is really fun to see and they have different art exhibits going throughout the year as well.

The only reason I give this place 4 stars is because of my natural love for animals and how sad it makes me to see them in such tiny cages. To see the huge, beautiful lion pacing back and fourth in a small cage in the lion house. To hear the monkeys making the same noise over and over up against the fence like they are trying to find a way out. It tugs at my heartstrings but for the sake of my daughter who loves animals and for the sake of her learning I will continue to come here twice a week.
author: Andy S.

description: Not the best zoo in the world, but still fun to go to. With the weather in San Francisco it's hard to find a nice day to go, but when you do get that day it's a great experience!
author: Mina S.

description:
I went with my husband, my 2 sisters and my niece. 

We had 4 adults and 1 child so the price was 80 dollars. I feel like it could be a bit cheaper bit we will get to that soon.

Parking- very good when you come early. We came 10 minutes before they opened and only 2 other cars were in the lot. Woohoo!

Arriving- so we made a day if it. We made sure to come early to spend the maximum time. If you do it right you can see some really awesome things. 
We got there early and since it's a bit of a car ride from Hayward and with a child and young adults, we all had to pee. The greeter let us in to use the bathrooms. The guy was also really nice. 
The bathrooms were also really clean.

Attractions- I really liked all the exhibits! Everyone says the animals looked depressed, but honestly, I believe they are just happy and lazy. They have toys and most are fed up to 3 times a day. Others have food in their habitats. The habitats do seem maybe a tad too small but if they were really big, we'd never see them. I mean, come on. It's a zoo. They are meant to be looked at and observed. If you don't like it, don't go. Right? I do know that quite a few animals there are actually rescued or were born in captivity from rescued parents. It would be hard to send and animal back into the wild when they know nothing of the wild. 

Feedings- I saw the penguin feeding and it was really informative and cute! They chart which penguin eats so none miss a meal :) 

I saw the bear feeding as well and the 2 bears bumped into each other while finding fish and they got SO mad. One bear roared and it was the scariest noise I've ever heard. It was blood chilling. All the children screamed lol.


I went to see the big cats but the sign said they didn't have a scheduled feeding so me and my family just lined up at 1:00 to get in. We stayed for about and hour and nothing. I looked online and they said the feeding is at 3:00 :( so I didn't wait long enough. I wish they would have posted the feeding there. Oh well. Next time :) 
I had to leave though because I guess I'm allergic to tigers lol. My husband too, we could breath after being in there. It's ok though :)  


Food- it's slightly expensive. I feel like some things are overpriced. Just don't eat at the leaping lemur cafe. That on is overpriced. The terrace cafe was a good price. We got 3 hot chocolates and a bag of popcorn. It came out to 10 bucks I believe. Not bad. One thing I do is pack snacks and water or iced tea with me if I'm planning on doing a family trip. I brought cliff bars and protein bars and water, some candies and stuff. My family was able to eat while walking and not have to stop the fun. They got energy because there is A LOT of walking lol.
Pack snacks! It will help a lot :) 

Cleanliness- it was ok. There are people who clean throughout the day but they need people to also clean the parking lot. The glass on a lot of the animals enclosures are scratched, dirty spiderwebby. They should clean more if the prices keep going up.  

Ok, now for the bad part. 

There are rules posted everywhere on how to behave near the animals. In different languages and in universal pictures. It was clearly stated to be quiet near the koalas but many people were yelling and screaming while they were trying to sleep. I did end up shushing some rude people because I got fed up with the disrespect. The animals are to be observed, not antagonized. They aren't entertainment, they are to be observed. 

But that's just my opinion.

In the big cat room, a security/ handler specifically told people NOT to yell and not to lean over the rails. As soon as we got in, a man started yelling and multiple people put their children over the bars. The tiger was getting upset and growling and almost tiger peed all over everyone. 

Overall I give it a 10/10 but I do wish more people would control and behave themselves and be a good example for their kids :)
author: Ariana L.

description:
It's hard to review a zoo because it doesn't necessarily have complete control over what it is able to offer. Not every zoo can afford pandas or up close and intimate exhibits, so I feel kind of bad for being a bit grouchy about the SF Zoo. 

As far as parks and places to be go it is absolutely beautiful (it's about 5-10 degrees cooler than downtown SF with wind chill) and well laid out. There is a lot of unused space (weird for San Francisco) and the animals are often distant and still, almost sullen. Now, I understand that they need their rest and don't necessarily always want to be around people, but it can be rather uninteresting to see a hippo pop up for air every five minutes. 

The animals avoid guests (except during scheduled feedings, make sure you make it to those) and sometimes it feels like a stuffed animal hall would be just as interesting. However, the smaller animals and the giraffes, kangaroos, and bears were very fun to watch and made up for an otherwise mediocre experience.
author: Daniel R.

description:
It had been a very long time since I had been to the SF Zoo.  In fact, I think my last visit was before I had obtained my driver's license.  I try and visit zoos on my travels to cities/countries around the world, but for whatever reason, the SF Zoo was not on my list of immediate places to visit.

I answered a call to serve through my former school's annual day of service.  I had always wanted to volunteer for one of their projects but either I was unavailable on that day or the maximum number of volunteers had been reached.

Approximately 35 of us showed up around 8:30 am on a cold but sunny Saturday morning.  We were provided with some instructions and background on the two projects we were to work on that day.  One was to lay sod and the other was to set up the outdoor area for the new red panda exhibit.  Most of us picked the panda exhibit option, where we would be performing landscaping tasks - moving and planting trees, digging a hole to create a pond, preparing the foundation for planting rocks, clearing out fallen leaves and garbage, moving soil, etc.

The landscaping team at the zoo was fantastic with providing instructions and guidance, sharing stories, and showing their gratitude for our assistance.  I would happily volunteer to help out there again next year.

Personally I never thought I would enjoy doing back breaking work so early on a Saturday morning but it was my first time time using a pick and shovel to break up soil, dig a big/deep hole, move the tree across the garden, lower the tree into the hole, pull out the tree from the hole (the hole was not deep enough!), dig the hole deeper and then plant the tree.  It's the tree to the left of the tree house, next to the pond.  It took three women to get this done and I am proud of having been able to contribute to the development of the red panda enclosure.  

After we completed our assignment, I decided to walk around for a bit to check things out.  It was nice to see that some things had changed for the better (open space for the savannah, primate area), others, sadly, stayed the same (Cat Kingdom, where the rhino appeared agitated and the hippo and tigers looked sad).  The good thing was that the animals looked healthy and the kids seemed to really love seeing them.  I know it takes a lot of money and time to make changes and I'm happy to see that there are improved safety measures for guests as well as more information on the animals.  

On the day of my visit the zoo was super crowded so I would say it's best to get there early in the morning or late in the afternoon.
author: Melissa L.

description:
Went there with my family on a nice summer Sunday. They had a great snow leopard documentary  in the movie room. The Gorillas were great and had a nice habitat, and the otters where playful. 

 Beyond that, a very sad day. The lions, and tiger cages were all out for cleaning. The Elephant home and bird sanctuary was closed, the Koalalas had been quarantined, the insect house was off limits, and the rhinos where out to lunch. 

If that where the end of the day, I would mark it off as a unlucky day for the zoo. But beyond that, the polar bears looked very skinny and hyperventilating, the lone snow leopard in captivity looked drugged and was wide eyed and drooling on the grass... and a bald eagle, a symbol of our country, was crying out in distress because he was trapped on a rock in the middle of small pond. He couldn't fly away because he was clipped. He also looked dirty like he had been struggling in the mud. 
I was horrified.
author: Mitchell R.

description:
So today the family wanted to get out of the house (going a little stir crazy with the excellent weather and all).

Hubby wanted to go to a park, I wanted to go to San Mateo and go to the Japanese Garden there, maybe some browsing around, stop somewhere for lunch and then maybe the NASA Space Museum after on the way home (now that wasn't a BAD idea, right?). Daughter wants to go to the zoo. I actually like the zoo, so I was like, "LET'S GO TO THE ZOO!" like I'm 5 years old again. Daughter starts in and hubby reluctantly grumps to the car and we go to the zoo.

So, my recommendations if you're looking for some cheap entertainment over the course of a year with the SF Zoo:

1) Get a family membership if you think you're coming back w/in the year. Two more visits pays for the entire membership and then the rest is smooth sailing. It's for two adults and up to five kids -the guest kids don't have to be related to you to get in BTW. You get discounts at the gift shop, the carts and at the food areas too, so keep that in mind. Also, you get discounts at admission at over 100 zoos and aquariums nationwide.

2) There is some alternate (we found free street ...it was a weekend FYI) parking on Sloat, where there's another entrance. The zoo is right by the ocean in that area -the ocean is beautiful, I can see a stroll on the beach afterwards sometime. It's a quick walk if parking there, so keep that in mind. You'll get two parking passes to use at the SF Zoo w/the membership and that will come in handy. Otherwise it's a $10 charge if the lot still has available parking spots.

3) Don't worry about the cost of food here. We found the cafe and the burgers and chips were around $8, which is totally reasonable. There are diners and such on Sloat but the cost was actually higher there and we didn't save any money by dining at the cafe we went to (I'm reviewing that later). The burgers looked really good. I wanted one, but we had already eaten. The coffee and a can of soda we got was pretty high (around $7.50 w/discount), so that was a bummer.

4) I can't advise enough for the weather. Make sure you have a jacket in the car for layering. It was warm and sunny where we were, but cloudy and cold enough to wear jackets there. Later it warmed up, but the jackets never came off until we got in the car to go home.

5) If you're an animal activist and you're going to get upset about unfair treatment it's probably not the place to have a standard visit for you. Nearly all of the animals (save for a pacing lion which is never fun to see) looked healthy and content enough to me. I appreciate the zoo as a place to teach us city folk about endangered species. Of course it's not fun to see animals in cages, ever, but it's just something that IS...it's something that is part of our- and other -cultures, and it just IS. I took some photos and the bars and the windows are sadly part of the pictures, but again, that's just how it is. It's easy for me to attach human feelings onto a rhino, for instance and think, 'he's lonely and needs a friend' without knowing the full story of why he's alone. And sure, I wish they weren't in captivity, but I can't see them being put back into the wild, especially if they're endangered. Anyway, just an opinion...

If you remember the Tatiana the former Siberian tiger, who killed a young man and mauled two others (allegedly as a result of their teasing), the tiger grotto area will give you goosebumps -at least it did for me.
author: Tamiko B.

description:
What a difference a few years can make. I was so excited to finally be able to bring my own son to this zoo. A place I went to, pretty much, once a month during my early years. I couldn't get enough of this place. 

I talked it up to my then two year old (he's three now) and gushed about the lion house, feeding the seals, the massive monkey hill, and that his favorite animal, the elephant, would be there. I also told him that we would go on the train, my boy's current obsession. 

Walking in to buy tickets, we're greeted by a sign In the window that the train is not running today.  Crap. Ok, fine. Distract the boy. He'll be fine. 

I have to say the giraffe compound is spectacular. It's the first thing you see when you get to the entrance of the zoo. Seems to go on forever and the giraffes just look so happy to roam freely in their habitat.  

So we walk around. Seems almost 10 minutes later and all we can still see are the giraffes.  ???  Oh wait, there's one Zebra, but it's behind a closed off door. We can see it through a crack. 

We walk more...  My fond memories of this amazing place and the hopes I had of sharing it with my own son... Dissolved with each exhibit we passed. The best thing was the giraffes. Everything else was in dire need of repair or a makeover. What happened???  

My beloved lion house, we saw two tigers. No kore rumbling roaring frenzy at feeding time. There is no more feeding time. They bring in a couple of animals just to give them nibbles and an educational talk about them.  The rest of the lion house holds a python display and a poorly filled plant area. 

Forget monkey island. They're now newly built cages and the best view is from the upstairs deck... No elevator for those of us with strollers. 

No more seals. No elephants. Old water fountains are filled with plants still in their plastic pots and random garbage. 

The old playground is now a pretty cool area of play structures for kids of various ages. A smaller toddler area is separated from the climbing structures for the older kids. Very well done. 

Overall, the whole experience was just so disappointing and very sad for me. Closest thing my son got to see that actually had an interested in, was a small sculpture of an elephant near where the old elephant displays were. And my goodness, I never realized how small it was. Poor elephants.  I that vicinity now are just a rhino and a very mangy polar bear. 

Sad. Very sad. Don't know if I'll ever want to go back.  Two stars only for the giraffes and the play area. The rest of the zoo needs a lot of work.
author: Denise M.

description:
This groupon loving girl scored a deal to sf zoo for $28 which includes admission for 2 adults and 2 kids. It was set to expire the end of january so we decided to take the girls for an outing before they start school again monday.

Parking was easy but $10 which is ok cause i already saved money on the tickets. 

We got there around 10:30 and promptly made our rounds. The attractions were good. The animals were easier to see then at Oakland zoo where some of the enclosers are more awkward for viewing. 

It took us 4 hrs to traverse the whole place which included a quick lunch and some potty breaks. The girls wanted to do the train which is a total ripoff at $4 a person. Some other kids were even complaining about it after!

Once we got done, my youngest promptly stated that the zoo was much too big and she was more interested in visiting the gift shop. I think they are about the age where seeing animals caged up is just more depressing. So i doubt we will be coming back.

The zoo is clean and the staff are nice. Good for smaller kids but older kids should pass if they are animal lovers. 

3 stars
author: Cynthia A.

description:
One star only cause it's an open place to drop a quick $100.

DO NOT GO!!!

Best walking paths outside of Golden Gate Park but hardly an animal in sight.

Talk about a waste of money, I couldn't wait to leave. The exhibits are horrible & the place has several areas in need of repair. It cost $20 per person to enter & $10 to park, if only there were a way to get a refund :/
I had more fun and saw way better exhibits at the Fresno Zoo & the Sacramento Zoo & it was half the cost.
Families of all types heed the warning: steer away from this place it's a money pit ...as in your money!!!
author: Dean S.

description:
I am really sad to say that when I was here, the animals looked so lonely and miserable. I love animals, but I love happy animals even more when they're thriving and active. The polar bear looked so sad and melancholy in his designated space, just waiting for life to pass him by. The rhino had his horn cut/shaven off and looked so confined and sad.  I mean how could you possibly explain these things to children? How the animals look and feel. I mean, the hippo kept trying to bite his cage bars. I'm not surprised at all that a tiger attacked an intrusive visitor a few years back. These animals are suppressed and definitely not happy - they're designed for the wild.

I might sound nit-picky, but whenever I dish out money for something, I endorse it. So until SF Zoo and Sea World start to change their approach with caring for the animals - even if it costs more to give them a much more thriving habitat (and honestly, I feel like they should use these facilities as conservation areas or rehabilitation and releasing the animals back into the wild), I won't be paying for tickets to visit anymore. 

Sorry SF Zoo, you won't be getting my business anymore anytime soon.
author: Sheena T.

description:
Kind of expensive ($42 for two resident adults and parking) but good selection of animals and not too crowded even on a weekend day. 

I recommend bringing a backpack with snacks and water because the food there is outrageously expensive and not very good. 

Also, the keeper talks aren't that interesting and very short. Don't plan your day around them. 

Animals are most active first thing in the morning and later in the afternoon.
author: Andrew S.

description:
Can't believe I've lived in the SF Bay Area for 3+ years and this Sunday was my first official visit to the Zoo! Though I've gotta say, coming from a city with a FREE zoo that rivals the SF offerings, I've sort of been avoiding the disappointment. 

This winter's unseasonably warm/sunny weather has been amazing. So much so, a trip to Ocean Beach doesn't require a puffy coat or thermal undies. This is reason enough to celebrate and go peek at some exotic animals, right? So off we went!

Admission is a bit steep, but hey, if it goes towards the fuzzy (and not so fuzzy) creatures, no way am I complaining. The habitats are kept clean and up-to-date from what I could tell and the animals didn't look sad or depressed... and the tigers didn't look the least bit interested in mauling humans, so I'll take it as a good sign.

The highlight was a quick glimpse of the new baby chimp, riding on it's mother's back. Seems like the family is pretty protective of him, keeping him at a good distance from the plexiglass. Also the orphan Grizzly bear sisters are fun to watch. Reading their story (and finding out that Grizzlies are now extinct in the "Bear Republic") was depressing, though.

If you're going to visit any zoo, the perfect time of day to do so is early in the morning. Not one to heed my own advice, we arrived right around noon. When the animals are taking a nap. Though it's cool to see them in a docile state, it doesn't make for the most exciting visit. Still not sure how half of them can sleep while there are screaming kids everywhere. Guess they're used to it by now?

Kudos to the Terrace Cafe for their ginormous portions of soft serve ice cream! It was probably the highlight of the trip. Seriously, the vanilla custard was about to topple over the cup. Three of us split the serving. And an overpriced/overcooked pretzel.

Around 2 pm, the fog started to roll in, in true SF fashion. That was our "alarm clock", saying it's time to travel back down to the Peninsula where the sun shines practically 365 days a year. 

Until next time, SF Zoo, I bid you aideu!
author: Abby S.

description:
Before I come to the zoo, I get animal books and introduce my children to different animals. When we get to the zoo, they get to see the animals first hand and tell me there names. This is a great learning opportunity. There is an insect room and my children just find it so fascinating.

My son and daughter love going on the train.
author: Dorothy B.

description:
This is an incredible piece of history in our big city! I love to see the care and positive employees as I walk around with my family. 

The cafe has great food! I even noticed a kids birthday party happening in the event space inside the cafe. A wonderful idea to celebrate at the zoo!

My favorite animals are the giraffes, hippos, big cats, bears and sifakas! I highly recommend this zoo! It's fantastic!
author: Gina S.

description:
I was very excited to go to this zoo because, as someone from Las Vegas, live zoo animals are hard to come by. 
However I was not as impressed as I hoped I would be. I was glad to see that a lot of the animals were in decent sized exhibits and had different things to play with and do. However the toys looked untouched and many animals seemed bored or unmotivated. None of them looked depraved or sick, which was good to see. The happiest animals seemed like the farm animals, probably because they were allowed to roam free and were part of the petting zoo.
The zoo was also very expensive. The ticket price, plus the parking and the cost of food was extremely high, especially for a family of five.
Also, they have a serious seagull problem. While I was eating, a bird came down and stole one of my chicken fingers. What's up with that?!
author: Katelyn R.

description:
For the record, I truly have mixed feelings about animals being held in captivity. On the other hand, I can't afford to travel around the world to see each and every one of these animals in their natural habitat. 

I was in total awe of everything I saw here today. The giraffe, the hippo, the cute baby gorilla!! All these beautiful creatures, so majestic!! 

The grounds are well taken care of, the playgrounds are huge and modern, tons of restrooms. I enjoyed the animal education highlights and petting area where we got to touch the goats and sheep. The little train ride was $5 and the highlight of my daughters visit. 

We had a wonderful day at the SF Zoo.
author: Marlene C.

description:
I haven't been to a zoo since I was a kid. And even though I don't think animals should be penned up, it was hard to keep this in mind because it was pretty awesome to get to see them. I think I appreciate being able to see the animals up close now in a way that I didn't as a kid. Most of the animals were out, even if asleep. I have a cat so I understand they're a sleepy bunch. 

I think I spent 2 hours there walking through all the exhibits. 

On a free day (first Wed of every month) SF residents get in for free. Be sure to bring ID with SF address and photo or some sort of utility bill to prove your residency. Also, there was a long line of families (who didn't really understand queuing too well) when we showed up just after noon. The line moves fast, maybe 15 minutes (?) to get in. If you want to avoid the line show up later. By 2:30-3 when we left it was gone. And despite the long lines the zoo isn't too crowded inside.
author: Jean K.

description:
a pretty decent sized zoo.  the only zoo that deserves 5 stars is the san diego zoo.  I'm a member so i can come in all the time and get free parking and train and carousel rides.  lots of animals and exhibits.  pretty fun to spend half a  day or even a full day.  right now they have the washed ashore exhibit where they take trash and make it into whale ribs and jelly fish and what not.  food is typical burgers and chicken strips for about 10 bucks.  id expect nothing less.  monkeys and polar bears and eagles and giraffes and the lion house.  they got plenty of animals here which is nice.  a huge new playground for kids.  my nephew didn't want to leave!  a safari theme and a antarctic theme. pretty cool.  decent size parking lot so you don't have to get here that early.  right across from ocean beach so you can visit the beach after the zoo or vice versa.  
in the end i enjoy taking photos of all the different animals.
author: Matthew G.

description: This was my first visit at the SF zoo and I left rather concerned for the animals. The majority of the animals seem sad, lonely, and seem to be suffering from caged animal syndrome. I've been to several zoo's, which leaves me shocked too see an out dated zoo in such a great city like SF. There's definitely a lack of funding or sort of problem there. It was a sad experience.
author: Daniela M.

description: Alot has changed since the last time I came here (over 10 yrs ago). Completely different from what I remember. It's so beautifully designed, simple, clean and all the animals were clearly well taken care of. The downsides were the expensive snacks, no lions in the Lion House, and we had to pay for the train ride, carousel in addition to the entrance fee. We ended up spending alot more than we had anticipated. Had a great time! Just be sure to bring cash because they don't accept credit /debit for the rides.
author: Paul L.

description: We really like this particular place! It's clean and beautiful garden. All animals looks so happy and calm. That was good experience for our weekend.
author: Yevgeniya O.

description: I know there are those that are opposed to zoos and I believe this is born from ignorance.  Zoo's do so much to house injured animals or animals that have been in captivity their entire lives.  This allows the public to see these animals and to educate them on the importance of each animal.  My 11 & 14 year olds and my husband and myself both loved being at the zoo.  Seeing how amazing nature and animals are, and gaining an even better appreciation of them.  Zoo's breeding programs for endangered species, the amazing PLANTS on displace that help be a place for migrating bees, butterflies and humming birds and everything else they do to help animals in our world is amazing and commendable.  Those who just think zoos are bad because they just keep wild animals in captivity, need to come and learn the truth!!!!!  Very commendable San Fran Zoo (and other similar zoos) for all your hard work, education and conservation efforts!
author: Angela M.

description: If you don't have a membership,  please get one. The zoo and the playground are amazing.  The playground has a new area with animal sculptures that my 4yo daughter loves.  She sleeps well after a day at the zoo and always wants to go back.  There are no elephants though.   And, you must be careful when playing at the playground,  you can lose your little one at another tunnel exit from where they entered.
author: juliet r.

description: There was not enough animals out, but I loved the ones that were out. My kids loved the playground and the gift shop.
author: Scott S.

description: Expensive ticket, small parking area, empty cages. No varieties of animals. I wasted my money and time.
author: Morteza R.

description:
Have been here twice now, once with small children and once with friends my own age.

Pros
Good fun for all ages
Variety of animals
Humane cages (either very tall or wide)
Lemur and Giraffe enclosures should set the standard for all zoos!
Dippin Dots! Pretzels! 
Penguins are easily visible
Huge
Train for children (which they absolutely adored!)
Nice to see the zookeepers cleaning out the enclosure's regularly 
Educational talks- very very interesting
Animals seem healthy and well-treated, the zookeepers seem to really care
Environmentally friendly
Awesome gift shop (gifts for all ages)

Cons
Food is (naturally) expensive
Not enough shade cover
Felt easy to get lost, but I'm a little directionally challenged
Awesome gift shop (quickly went over budget)
author: Kathryn A.

description:
I told my gf that I saw on the news that there was a new baby giraffe at the zoo.  That pretty much sealed it that we were going to have to make a trip.

I had never been to the SF Zoo, and not really been to a lot of zoos in general, so not a great deal to compare.  I will say for $17 for an adult, there is plenty to see here.  We probably spent 3.5-4 hours here looking at all the animals, never really spending too much time in one place.

The baby giraffe was cute, as were other baby animals that we saw, such as flamingos, ducks, etc.  And most of the animals were out and about doing things, as opposed to sitting around doing nothing, so that was nice.  There were also areas where you could pet some animals, like goats, chickens, ferrets, snakes, etc.

We came about midday and the zoo parking was supposedly full, so we moved on to the noted parking area on Sloat.  Even then we got one of the last obvious available spots.  So either come early or be prepared for a trek.

Overall, it was a fun trip with lots to see.  I wouldn't mind coming back.
author: Brent T.

description:
Love this place for my kids! So the only bad thing about our experience was that since the zoo is right off the coast and it being in San Francisco, it was very cold when we went in the beginning of August. Other than that, my two year old daughter had a blast! She got to see so many kinds of animals, her favorites were the gorillas and tigers. The lions didn't feel like cooperating that day, it was probably because of the weather (I think one gave out a middle finger); they just were not having it that day. The price was reasonably cheap, and don't forget to pay for parking as well. 
   They also have a beautiful playground, train ride, and carousel because we all know there comes that point where the kids (and us parents) get tired of walking around. My daughter was asleep as we walked out, which means that she had so much fun that it used up all her energy capacity.
author: Juan F.

description:
We took our 2 teenagers and our 5-year old to this zoo. I loved the location of this zoo since it is located right next to the beach and the weather was just right until we got back to our car and it was bombed with gritty bird poop on the passenger side. I had to use a napkin to open my door to get in. :)
My youngest was immediately excited upon seeing the giraffes and ostriches through the fence on the side while we were buying our admission tickets. We liked how open the giraffe area was and that they interacted with the ostriches. 
It was entertaining to watch when it was time for the zoo keeper to feed the penguins. There was a seagull trying to blend in with the Penguins thinking he can get some fish too. When he couldn't fool the zoo keeper, he ended up just stealing the fish from the Penguins. 
We were surprised to see the peacocks walking around throughout the zoo. Young kids were chasing them around. It was really beautiful and impressive to see their feathers standing up. 
The playground was cool. One side was glacier themed and another area was jungle themed. There were a lot of seating for parents to rest while watching their kids play. 
We ate at the Leaping Lemur Cafe. Food was ok. They had 3 different stations: pizza, burgers/sandwiches and Asian food (teriyaki bowls). We had the cheeseburger and the chicken club sandwiches. They use brioche buns and the sandwiches came with kettle chips...unsalted kettle chips. 
We rode the train, Little Puffer. This ride is not built in with your admission ticket, it cost $5.00 per ride (you go around twice).  
There was definitely one very interesting animal we saw on the day of our visit. My 5-year old kept asking me why the rhinoceros had 5 legs. I told her it wasn't a fifth leg, it was the same part that her dad and brother had. I took a picture and was going to post, but my teens and husband said not to post it. Lol...
Overall, it was a pretty good zoo with entertaining and one traumatizing animals.
author: Alma S.

description: What can I say...my kids love going here. We live about 5 minutes away from the zoo so we have the annual pass. Both my sons enjoying seeing the animals and also gets excited to play at their playground. Besides the wild animals...their lobster roll is actually pretty good...lol.
author: Phi N.

description:
I absolutely love San Francisco Zoo! The new playground is absolutely amazing. My almost 2 year old loves it! I wish they built playgrounds like that when I was a kid! It is just so beautiful and so spacious. 
The other thing that makes this zoo amazing is the people that work there - they are so friendly and helpful and so passionate about what they do - you can hear it in their voices and see it in their eyes when they give talks about the animals. 
Children's ZOO is a lot of fun too. I like the fact that goats and sheep are not behind the fence, you can just walk around and pet them and brush them as much as you'd like (Yes, you can pick up the brush and brush the goat!)
Zoo is not huge but the layout is smart. I feel like animals have a lot of space, the exhibits are well kept and clean. 

Tip: there is a lot of street parking on Sloat - no need to pay $8 for zoo parking.
author: Kasia G.

description: I love zoos. While the SF zoo is clean and then people are friendly they really need to upgrade the place. I'm sure they can get funding from Google , FB, or Ebay.  The animals seem relatively happy. Oakland Zoo is much better though.
author: Dylan B.

description:
I love this zoo. It's small enough to see everything in an afternoon without exhausting yourself or your little ones but still there's lots to enjoy. My favorite is the Africa area- zebras, ostriches, gorillas, and giraffes, oh my! Also the new playground is amaaaaaaazing. Great for toddlers and big kids alike. 
I always pack a snack/lunch and water. There are plenty of benches and tables to take a break.
author: Rocio G.

description: We had a really awesome time at this zoo. Definetly recommend if you would like to spend a day with your family. A lot of activities and fun for my kids. The kids really enjoyed the playground that they have. We went on a week day so there were no crowds but no shows either. It was nice not to be pushing around with our stroller. Looks like there is some construction going on by the grizzlies so that section was closed. Prices are reasonable, of course food is expensive as expected. Don't expect to pay less than $5 for anything, even ice cream. Make sure to bring sunglasses, I didn't so ended up paying $25. For a family of 4, 2 adults and 2 kids, 5 and 3. We spent $110 which included: parking, tickets, lunch, ice cream, and the train ride. We brought our own drinks. Can't say it's cheap, but it was worth it to spend time as a family and marvel at Gods creation.
author: Anthony S.

description: The zoo is an amazing place for young kids and family! This was the only place around town that is open for thanksgiving (open 365 days a year in fact) and I am ever so grateful. I mean, what are you going to do with a toddler for the whole day, where nothing else is open? The zoo is clean, staff are courteous, and is it much bigger than I thought with a large variety of animals and activities, including a playground. I am considering a membership for the future.
author: Lily T.

description:
Great Day. Went on a Saturday. Parking wasn't as easy as a week day, I recommend parking on one of the side streets. But you do risk having a vagrant bust your windows during a break in. In SF the homeless are allowed to do whatever they want and they exist in huge numbers. I have lived here all my life and have NEVER seen it this bad. The city council has tied the authorities hands together and doesn't want anything done about all the NASTYNESS. Zoo is pretty far from the usual nasty homeless guy hangouts, so it's a better local to take your kids. And it's near the Beach so take your beach stuff and watch the sunset after.

But back to the Zoo. 

The last time I was at the Zoo in 2010 it seemed like tougher times at the Zoo. This time I was pleasantly surprised to see some wonderful improvements around the grounds and animal enclosures. For being a busy beautiful Saturday the Zoo did not feel crowded. It was a very relaxing day. I arrived at about noon and stayed until 6 even though they close at 5. Nobody told be to get out everyone was very nice. 

The White snow leopard was amazing. Sat and watched him for an hour. He came or her came directly up to the glass. Amazing creature!!! The Tigers and lions looked great, Wished they had more space, but the enclosure was nice and clean with plants and grass. 

The insect building was great and it was fun interacting with the other patrons and their children. This feature was also a lot nicer then 5 years ago. 

Overall I was pleased to see the zoo looking so much better. In 2010 I was worried it may falter and close up because I was looking a bit shabby. But I didn't see that this time. 

I will be coming back soon.
author: Chris P.

description: Before I start this review, I just need to say one thing- WHAT HAPPENED HERE?! It is like totally abandoned and the horses at the petting zoo made me cry. Don't go here, just don't.
author: Myra B.

description: I've lived in the Bay Area for almost twenty years, but had never heard glowing reviews of the SF Zoo. I'm so disappointed I waited until now to check it out! I went there last week with five children, and we were all pleasantly surprised -- even a little astonished! There is a wide variety of animal life here, the zoo staff is extremely friendly, the grounds are enchanting, and -- most important -- the animals seem to be very well cared for and respected. We will now be making the SF Zoo a regular treat!
author: Liza P.

description: We drove all the way from Fremont to be there when it opens.  I wanted 4 1/2 hours to do everything so that I didn't have to be stuck in horrible traffic heading back home.  The Rainforest didn't open until 11:45, so we wasted a lot of time killing time in that area so that the kids didn't miss out on it.  It was closed down for restoration the last time we were here, so it was a big deal for the kids.  If your exhibit opens at 11:00, then 'maintenance repairs', as the operator explained that was happening is unexusable.  That should have been done before the time the time it should open.  So, we hit awful traffic by wasting nearly an hour before the exhibit opened.
author: Christy B.

description: I liked the zoo, what ruined my day was when i went to pay i paid for a parking voucher, which was unnecessary. I wish the cashier told me that would of saved me $12 that i could of put towards buying something for my 2 little nieces. I literally drive out the parking lot without even using the voucher. Nothing bad about the zoo, just wish the staff would of informed me that i didnt need to pay to leave later.
author: Danny S.

description:
The SF Zoo is a great zoo. No, it is not the San Diego Zoo or the Bronx Zoo or the Monterey Bay Aquarium, but it is a fabulous urban zoo. 
- The playgrounds are probably the most creative and magical playgrounds anywhere (though they can get very crowded)
- The children's zoo area - with the little farm - is a great way to get up close to many animals and is great for small children. The insect house is also a blast!
- They have a number of unique habitats and animals that you won't see at many zoos - such as the red panda, the lemurs, and the sloths. My personal favorite is the feeding of the grizzly bear sisters - something not to miss. The Africa savanna exhibit is so lovely.
- The grounds are gorgeous and spacious. When my son was in a stroller, I would walk for hours around the zoo. It was so nice to get outside and be in a lovely, green place. 
- The new sculpture garden is a lot of fun

There are too many wonderful things at the zoo to name... sure, there is room for improvement (ZooLights is very chaotic, needs more and better food options, some exhibits need updating) and there have been some tragic animal deaths, but overall it is an excellent zoo.

There are some wacky reviews here, including from some who want to see exhibits that have been changed or removed for the good of the animals. Many zoos are phasing out elephant exhibits due to the debate over whether elephants can be kept humanely in a small enclosure. I am personally thrilled that the SF Zoo has sided with the humane choice to no longer have an elephant exhibit. In addition, the cat house had large cats in small enclosures. Now, they are allowed to roam and relax in much bigger spaces. They have also successfully had cubs in recent years, which has required closures to allow mom and baby privacy. I hope more patrons become supportive of the zoo evolving its practices to best support the animals.
author: Jammy M.

description:
This zoo really aren't that terrible. I think it would be quite a bit of fun for the kids. As an adult I still enjoyed it. True. It is no comparison to world class zoo like the one in San Diego. It is smaller with less variety and the collection is not nearly as impressive. Most of the perspex glass display are in need of some loving care. 

If you have an afternoon with a few hours to kill, why not take a leisure strolling through the zoo? It is a fun and educational experience. I still learned quite a few things. My favorite animals in the zoo are the Gorilla. They are such beautiful creatures and so fascinating to watch.
author: Mona W.

description:
I'm a zoo person- I try to go to the zoo in each city I visit, and now that we live in Santa Clara, I finally made it by the SF Zoo this weekend! At first I put off going to avoid weekend and holiday crowds, but going at 10AM when they opened on Sunday was perfect. We didn't run into many people while we were there, and it was starting to pick up as we left at 1PM.

Three hours was a good amount of time to spend there, though we could have easily spent more and with kids I'm sure it would have taken longer.

Maybe it was the cold weather or the early hour, but the majority of the animals were out and about and active while we were visiting- especially the monkeys, who were super loud! 

My favorite animal was the snow leopard- seriously just looked like a giant house cat with a gorgeous coat. Kept walking up to the glass and rubbing against it as if he wanted to be pet! Tigers were dozing on a rock in the sun, much like my own cats at home. 

According to the map, there are two areas with anteaters but we only saw one- he was quite close to the edge of his enclosure though, so we got a great up-close view of him. Also the reindeer were on the map but their area was blocked off when we tried to find them- sad we didn't get to see them as the holidays are nearly upon us.

I didn't run into many zoo employees on my visit but there were a few stationed around with displays to go over with kids and they were happy to answer questions and keep up friendly and informative chit chat with adults.

Map and signage is easy to follow and paths are mostly smooth. Seems like they only have a few areas closed or under minor construction, adding improvements here and there.

Only criticisms are that the glass on some of the enclosures needs to be cleaned- not from handprints but from weathering or age, especially the lion enclosure which was quite fogged and scraped up making it difficult to see. Another few (the fishing cat and otter enclosures) have a really bad glare that make it difficult as well.
The petting zoo did not have food available as expected, which was a minor disappointment, as I love to feed the goats- but they were quite friendly and there were brushes to use on them, so it all works out.

Our experience was enjoyable, though I'd appreciate a lower ticket price- we are Bay area residents but have not gotten our new drivers licenses yet,but still had to pay the regular fee.
author: Stefany V.

description:
I think this zoo deserves a 3.5 stars. If you're a SF native, general admission is $14 and if you're from out of town, the ticket is $17. I was a little disappointed during my visit yesterday. It has been a few years since I last came by, but oddly, it felt as if the zoo was smaller than it was a few years back. Maybe it was because it was mid afternoon and most of the animals were taking a nap. So it was less interesting than it could have been for me.

I did like seeing the penguins, tigers, lions, rhinos, grizzly bear, polar bear, and the snow leopard. They also have a train ride that makes a small circle around the zoo. There was also a zipline set up for kids near the middle of the zoo. 

Overall, I thought it was an okay experience for me. I'll probably return in the future. I know that every few years, the displays are changed a little bit. I was actually really disappointed that they didn't have elephants, but I understand that they enclosures are too small for certain animals and that they need to do what's best for the animals. Still a little disappointing though.
author: Andrea G.

description: $34 for two adults. Parking is almost impossible, so you will need to either get there early or park at least four blocks away. Since it is a family place, expect strollers everywhere you go. Bring a camera with amazing zooming capabilities and be prepared to be disappointed when some animals are hiding or sleeping under a bush, out of sight. I didn't get to see the lions or the snow leopard in action when I went because they were sleeping. The polar bear was under water as well.
author: Samantha C.

description:
Was there for mother's day.  It has so many neat animals to see, even has a kids playground area.  The space for the animals is open and large, very few cages except for the birds.

My favorite was the insect area.  some very gross cockroaches.  ewww
author: Tony T.

description: We really enjoyed coming here. My kids loved the animals. We got there just in time when they were feeding the tiger and talking about them as well. I was kinda discouraged that they stop serving espresso drinks after 2pm?? That just doesn't make any sense. They have a petting zoo which kids can get to pet the animals. If you go on their website it will have the schedule of what they will do thru out the day. Self parking is $10 and $20 per adult to get in. Not too bad. I recommend to come early in the day to enjoy watching all sort of animals getting fed. It's really nice. I'll be back next year for sure.
author: Sammy G.

description: Never again! I am officially turned off from Zoo's. With a love and appreciation for animals, zoo's have always served their purpose... However, San Francisco Zoo does not seem to be taking care of their animals. As an uneducated guess, the animals seemed skinny and depressed. I've been twice in the past 5 years and had the same feeling, more disgusted the second time. I've been to my share of Zoo's and this is not one I'm recommending.
author: Ms. R.
