description: Who doesn't love the zoo.  This place is awesome.  The gorilla area is fantastic.  They have lot's of room to play and run around.  The African Safari area is really top notch  I'm glad to see them moving towards open pen areas.  It would be great if they made a more significant move towards that.  That said, the animals look pretty happy and content.  Definitely go see the grizzly bears.  They are very playful and like to show off for the public.  Four stars instead of five because the food choices are a bit limited, but we usually plan to just eat afterwards.  Get there early or parking can be challenging.
author: Greta R.

description: Fun place for the kids. Does get repetitive though. The new playground is amazing for the kids. The red panda is fucking awesome and I want one.
author: Brent B.

description: They played us. We went in the first we day of the month in August and they said they weren't doing free admission until September 7
author: Natalie C.

description:
Wow, I'm shocked that the SF Zoo only rated a 3 1/2 stars. My family and I travel from the valley all the time just to visit the animals. Some of the great things you'll find here that aren't at your local zoo:

- Medium size petting area: toddles and kids can run around, brush sheep... YES ACTUAL SHEEP... feed sheep and goats, pet horses, see baby chicken eggs as well as chicks recently born... Oh the list goes on and on.

- The Giraffes and Monkeys always see so happy. 

- Insect House that has everything from scorpions and snakes to Beatles and ant colonies... LIVE INSECTS. Also there a really cool bee hive where you can identify the Queen by a colored dot. The bees can go in and out of the hive through a small hole which provides access for bees to pollinate (and sting people j/k) and others to make honey. Really cool. 

- The zoo is located right across from the ocean. Bring a sweater or something warm because it gets chilly. 

There are so many things to do here. I wish it had more stars..

I give it 5 STARS!!!
author: Itsm E.

description: Went to the zoo on Sunday and i was very disappointed. We barely got to see any animals. Most of them were either not there and hiding or looking so depressed! Bathrooms were very dirty! Not worth the price we paid for! Oh and bring your own food cause food is not worth the price either!
author: Karen M.

description: I'm a fan because I'm a HUGE LOVER of the animals! It's a great place for people of all ages. The animals here seem happy and not aggressive towards humans so that means the zookeepers must be doing something right! I love the variety of animals they have here. From reptiles to huge mammals. My favorites are the snow leopards, the giraffes and the sea otters. SO CUTE. The zoo has been elephant-less since 2005 since elephants do not do well in the San Francisco weather. Admission is about 28 per adult, but I say it's well worth it. If anyone knows me, they know I LOVE animals so I could be bias. Having a surprise birthday trip to the zoo was really exciting for me! 14
author: Tiffany W.

description: Had a great time there today. Took the family to see some awesome animals and we were not disappointed. Apparently my 8 month old son wanted to do more people watching and flirting than looking at the animals, but Mom and Dad LOVE animals so everyone wins. The Petting Zoo was awesome and must son actually got to interact with some animals. Show stealer of the day was the Snow Leopard; such a magnificent big cat. All in all the Zoo is a great place to bring family members old, and young alike. My family will definitely be returning in the future.
author: Erik W.

description: On an overcast day,it's the best. Especially if the Lions are viewable in the building they house them in as the roar will shake your heart rate to a paltry anaerobic level! The Hippo's spraying urine 40 feet high like a rainbow is awesome!~ duck and take cover-they warn you about that! It's a pretty nice museum like exhibit Zoo but frequently they have exhibits that are not open and that is a bummer.If you have been to other major zoos this one is "OK" but not earth shattering,(except for those Lion roars when viewable!), The Oakland Zoo with the people mover up above you can go across each exhibit in is better in my opinion!
author: Brian D.

description:
I echo the sentiments expressed by Paul O.

I hadn't been to the SF Zoo for at least 7-8 years---back in the day when
the entrance was on Sloat. We decided to go the zoo to see Leanne's tiger cub.

We arrived shortly after they opened.

There were mobs of kids streaming into the zoo and we thought the zoo would be overrun by them and other large groups that were flocking in.

Once we went pass the admission gates, the crowds had dispersed and went
their separate ways.

We decided to see the tiger cub first (She was on "display" from 10-11)

Surprisingly there were no lines or crowds at the tiger exhibit.

Baby tiger was frolicking in the grass and playing with her mom's tail.
Leanne was very patient and tolerant of the cub's antics.  
In between the cub's swatting mom's tail she would give him gentle licks.

Nearby the tiger's enclosure there was a zoo worker "womaning"
 a cart with different big cat pelts, a lion's leg and a domestic  cat and lion's
skulls.  The\ skulls were identical except for size.  This explains our cats'
lionesque behavior.

The paw on the lion leg was HUGE!  One paw was larger than 4 domestic cat
paws put together.

We saw the other Big Cats who were napping or pacing in their cages.
The pacing behavior makes me feel so sad for them.

I know SF Zoo is doing their best to provide adequate spaces for the animals.

I hope there is a plan to provide the Big Cats with larger spaces to runnand roam.

I was impressed by the changes the zoo has made--spiffy new restrooms,
modern gift store  and many other improvements

Although there are many critics who think the animals should be released back into their native environment i do have some thoughts on that.....

Many if not most of these animals are offspring of animals who are
descendents of other animals raised in captivity,  They would not have the skills 
to live in their native environment.

When I lived in Kenya some of the people were not pro-animals.
Some animals were thought of as pests who ate their crops or wrecked
their land.

It is a sad dilemma that does not have easy solutions.

I trust the SF Zoo to build larger enclosures for their animal guests.
author: Rinky N.

description: I really like the zoo here. It seems like they take care of all the animals really well & all the animals was so active & happy looking when they were there.
author: Nikki O.

description:
$17 for adults
Children under 3 are free
I would have enjoyed it better if the animals actually looked happy. They didn't and it was sad :(

I don't think I can go back as it just made me too sad to see the sad animals.
author: Mel P.

description:
I feel compelled to write about this zoo. My god, this awful zoo...

First of all, I made the mistake of quick math that led me to believe that since I have a toddler and we live 10 minutes away and I have like 0 adult friends and therefore I have a lot of time on the weekends with my kid trying to do stuff, I should buy a year long pass for $115. So I did that. Before I saw then zoo. And then... we went in. 

Let's just clarify our terms here, because usually when I say "zoo," I mean a place that provides a home for animals that looks like their natural environment and serves as a place for kids to get balloons and watch gorilla's pick their noses and such. That's a zoo. Educational. Humane. Enjoyable. 

And then you have the SF Zoo, which I think is modeled after Alcatraz, and is basically a concrete jungle of tiny micro apartments where large animals are shoved.   A polar bear in a concrete ditch? Sea lions with so little water they can't submerge? Teeny monkeys in teeny cages. Ugh. It's like a hellish Kurt Vonnegut plot. 

I was so depressed by the time we got to the "African" section, which is A LOT smaller than Africa, mind you, and also why is it so small for all those animals? That's the theme.

And they don't have elephants because too many died, or at least that's what I was told (not by a zoo employee). So maybe that's true (seems believable) or many not, but whatever the case, I'm happy for elephant-kind. 

This place should be shut down. Today.
author: ash E.

description:
Love the San Francisco Zoo. While not particularly large, they have put a lot of thought into their exhibits. For example, their Africa exhibit lets you go through a tunnel and emerge surrounded by wildlife. The Rainforest House is essentially an open exhibit where you and the birds are in the same room. For this to work, there must be trust between the zoo and the patrons. What's unfortunate is they recently had to seal off the big cat exhibits with nets and glass, due to the incident several years ago. When the glass gets smudged (which is all the time) it is difficult to see the big cats. But what can you do? I have long commented about the anarchic behavior of San Francisco residents...

Will continue to go back. Very peaceful, especially on weekdays.
author: W. T.

description:
not exactly the best, but bigger than happy hallow. Sf residents get $3 off with id. Parking is $10, but bf and I had no idea where to park nearby for free. Pay for parking when you buy tickets and keep it with you until you leave the zoo. Saw lots of animals, but the big animals like the polar bears, lions and tigers were sleeping. Unlike Oakland zoo, you can see all animals without having to pay to get on a ride just to see certain animals. Food here can be expensive, duh, but it wouldn't hurt to spend a bit when you're having fun. You'll see carts selling snack around the park, but $3 for cotton candy???? Buying food from the cafes are better. 

As a lover of things with fur, tail and 4 legs, I have to  check out the petting zoo. So this one was kinda....idk. disappointing? Nothing, but goats. Some animals at the barn are only for looking. Can't feed donkey or sheep. 50 cents for pellets that you could hold with one hand. At happy hollow, it's only 25 cents with TWO hands needed to hold pellets and you can feed donkies, goats, pigs and ponies. There was a goat at the sf petting zoo name nutmeg and we weren't allowed to feed him because he was on a diet. Ok......idk why you let him roam around the barn with pellets. Why not keep him with the other do not feed animals?? Anyway, so between this zoo, Oakland and happy hallow, both sf and happy hallow are good, but both have their pros and cons. All I care most about are what animals there are and the petting zoo. Yeah, I love petting zoos.
author: Jessica T.

description: I was having a good time taking pictures until this girl holding the hippo bones told me no selfie stick...BS...it was on the map!..now my $20.00 not worth it...i will never come back to this place.
author: RB L.

description:
Zoos are generally kind of a sad place - it's like watching animals in prison. But if you get over that, the San Francisco Zoo is a pretty good place to take a nice long stroll while seeing animals. 

My favorite parts of the zoo are watching the animal feedings (penguins and bears), the African section of the zoo and the chimpanzees. Seeing all of the penguins lining up for fish was incredibly cute - and, since the fence is so low, you can see them quite well. The bear area is a little more inaccessible (not surprisingly so), but it's beautiful to watch those big bears lumbering about. They've done a nice job with the African section, I could watch the gorillas and giraffes for hours. The chimps - which are close to the entrance/exit - are a good stop on your way out because chimps will always leave you in a good mood. 

I've only ever been on weekdays which is a great way to beat the crowds. Even on weekdays, I was surprised by the number of people there so I can only imagine how crowded it is on weekends. 

If you plan on going more than a couple of times a year, the membership is worth it (plus you get coupons for free parking!).
author: Wendy L.

description:
It might have just been the particular day we went, but all the animals were out and about. $14 for San Francisco residents with ID, and it was an altogether awesome two hours of being astounded at how large most animals are.

We got there right on time for the grizzly feeding, and that was epic to watch a giant bear prowl through a lake for fish and lick honey off glass windows. The cluster of children on the other side of the glass might have given the bear blue balls though.

Pocket map gave just enough information and the Little Puffer train was adorable.

Don't miss the petting zoo, where for 50 cents, you get a handful of vittles for the goats.
author: Kevin L.

description: The animals run wild here..just kidding. The bears here cool. I also like the tigers. The rest of the animals are cool. The cost of attending has gone up but if you are a resident you can attend for free once a month. Definitely a landmark for the city. Just come and mix it up with the monkeys and chirp at the birds.
author: Robert F.

description:
My friend and her husband are members and recommended we go to the zoo while in town and it made for a memorable, fun experience. Seems like it is a fantastic place for kids, but our group of adults ranging from age 25 to 32 had a great time, too.

Not sure if we got lucky because we went on a weekday and it wasn't very crowded or if the zoo is so big it never FEELS busy as a result, but it seemed pretty empty while we were there.

The lemur enclosure was impressively large, but not much was happening, it seems we came by during nap time. We hoped to get a glimpse of the baby gorilla, but no luck there either. There were several freshly hatched flamingoes when we went, and we ended up standing to watch the flock of flamingoes for over half an hour without even realizing it. Who knew flamingoes were so interesting? The penguins were also pretty fun to watch. I wish we'd come earlier in the day because the animals weren't very active and we ended up missing some of the scheduled events we were interested in because we were wandering around on the opposite side of the zoo.

The highlight of our visit was definitely the hippos. There was a hippo lounging in the very shallow water in its enclosure and he walked to the other (empty) end of the pool, where we thought he would eat the lettuce sitting there... but instead he pooped the angriest poop I have ever seen! It seemed like he was trying to aim directly at a family standing at the fence, and you can bet they ran away as fast as possible. It was absolutely hilarious and definitely in the top five moments in our trip to San Francisco!

Some of the enclosures seemed criminally small (particularly the komodo dragon, poor guy) but most of the animals seemed to have very large living spaces.

It seems like a lot of the signage is in disrepair, there were several places where there clearly used to be informational signs about the animals you're looking at, but the signs had been taken down and not replaced. I was a little disappointed by this, the point of the zoo is not just to look at animals, but to LEARN about them, too!!

There was also almost no staff to be seen anywhere in the entire place. Every other zoo I've been to, I've accidentally stumbled upon zookeeper talks, animal caretakers happily explaining what they're doing as they go about their jobs, and other staff ready to talk to visitors about what they're seeing. I think I can honestly say other than gift shop and the ticket window, I probably saw less than 5 staff members the entire time I was there.

The overall emptiness and lack of information available about the exhibits and animals is why the zoo loses two stars.

The people working in the gift shop were very friendly and nice, I didn't feel like I was being pressured to make purchases, and the girl at the cash register seemed to legitimately enjoy her job. A very nice way to end a visit to the zoo. :)

Ample paid parking is available, but you can park for free a little farther away... just be prepared for the trek back to the car. After walking around the zoo (and there is a LOT of walking), you might wish you'd paid for parking.

Not sure I would have been happy with the ticket prices had my friend not had a free pass that had come with her zoo membership.
author: Linda H.

description:
I came here for my company picnic and was able to get access to the zoo. The event was free for me but I probably would not pay to come here. I have been to a few zoos including the San Diego Zoo and obviously this one does not compare. It is smaller and there arent many animals to see that are impressive. A few of the animals I was interested in seeing, like lion cubs, were not even present. Children would be amused and probably have a great time here but as an adult, I probably wouldnt come here again. It took an hour for me to go through the entire zoo.

**TIPS**
1) Great for kids, not so fun for adults.
2) There are free days for SF residents so I would research on that.
author: Amy H.

description: Well, we came here the day before we left back home.  My wife and I were visiting my parents and sister's family so figured to do a trip to the zoo.  My niece and nephew came along so that was fun.  I was able to use my Como zoo pass to get my wife and I discount.  The zoo itself has improved quite a bit according to my brother-in-law.  I was amazed that the giraffes and some other animals were all grazing together which looked right out of a scene from Africa.  The landscaping is absolutely amazing and kudos to the renovations.  We saw a lot of large mammals which my parents said were non-existent in the San Jose Happy Hollow zoo.  Parking was $8 on weekdays and $10 weekend.  I think they got us on a holiday rate so we paid full price.  Anyways, it was convenient and not as back as parking in downtown.  We spent close to 3 hours since the zoo is gigantic.  The restrooms are so far apart and there are at least a decent variety of food options in the café.  One of polar bear finally came out once the sun came out.  The train also had decent speed and didn't look like ones I seen in other zoos that go super slow.  Overall, we would come here again.  It would make sense to get a family pass if we plan on going several times.  I recalled Costco selling membership a few years ago so maybe check that out towards the holidays.
author: Phillip Y.

description:
Rawr ~ I took a trip to the San Francisco Zoo on a sunny Saturday recently. It's changed quite a bit since I was a kid, but that didn't stop me from feeling like one. Where is my Zoo Key?! They still work.

The Zoo admission is $15, unless you are local and it's $12. I felt like a kid, looking around for each animal - was it hiding, was it sleeping? What are they doing in there? :)

Oh look at the Penguins, they are pretty funny little birds diving in and out of their little pool. I had to laugh out loud when the toddlers freaked out at seeing a Peacock up close. Eeek! 

We arrived in time to see the Lions feeding in the Lion Den. The massive amounts of big hunks of meat reminded me of my visit to Espetus (Steakhouse) the night before. After their meal the Lion returned out to the Sunny Outdoor enclosure and the Female Lioness retreated to the cave.

My other favorite animals were the Bears, Polar and Grizzly. The Polar bear looked a little sad, but he was probably hungry as he paced back and forth along the wall we were standing near. The Grizzly Bears were minding their own business, really cute.

I had a great time walking around the Zoo and seeing the animals, but only got a chance to see about half of the place due to the time. Make sure to get there early!
author: Rebekah T.

description:
This is zoo wasnt as fun as oakland zoo 
Sf zoo was missing a few animals that oakland zoo does have like: elephants,  camels, cows,  reptiles. 
Oakland zoo has a reptile room which was awesome
Tickets for oakland zoo are cheaper and the park is better 

If I were to choose btwn both I wud go to oakland
author: Namal R.

description: Wasn't really happy with the visit like I was looking forward to. I really liked the decor of the play park for the kids n that there was always someone cleaning all the bathrooms. It was so sunny in the bay but when arriving here it was gloomy n gray. The directions in the park was very confusing n the map doesn't seem to match. We ended up in the same spot like 4 times. Some of the workers r friendly but some we're confused as well like when I asked for a certain spot the employee didn't even know what I was talking about...luckily a repeat visitor knew what I was talking about n explained where to go. Not many animals or to say big animals. My daughter luvs elephants which they don't hav.
author: Evelyn M.

description: We had a fantastic time at the SF zoo, we went on a Thursday morning and it was pretty quiet. The parking was easy and cheap ($9). This zoo is really well maintained, has a great gift shop with lots of interesting things for kids and adults and has an espresso bar! Bathrooms were exceptionally clean. All of the bigger attraction exhibits were pretty amazing if you have patience and hang out for a few minutes for the animals to appear. My son and I were enthralled with the grizzly bears and caught a feeding, they were very active and we're very interested in their audience as one grizzly came right up against the safety glass.  The hippopotamus exhibit was a lot of fun, we watched a feeding and we watched him for about 1/2 an hour! I notice a lot of people want instant gratification and only have enough patience to wait for half a second before they move on to the next exhibit, if you wait, sometimes you will see the animals doing amazing things! The patas monkeys were so fun to watch. We were there all day and didn't get to see everything since we spent so long at each exhibit, there is so much to see. We had a great time and I think this zoo beats Oakland zoo hands down! We left happy and satisfied with out visit.
author: Lillith G.

description:
"Pshhttt, Monkeys don't throw their poop in real life, that's just made up"
"No man I am telling you, i have seen it"

*5 minutes later*

"I can't believe you have monkey poop on your shirt right now"

Priceless.
author: Abe M.

description:
LOVE THE SF ZOO!!!

I've never been to the SF Zoo until I made an appointment to see the venue for my wedding. The staff members were so nice and very courteous, welcoming!

After walking around the zoo, it was perfect to have a ceremony and reception there. All of our money went back to the animals! It was well worth having your money go to a great cause instead of just renting a venue place for your wedding. We just had our wedding on April 6, 2013 and it was amazing! The staff members were very helpful and accommodating although they had a time constraint. But they worked around your schedule. 

Carol, event manager, was awesome! She put up with me in every detail, even recommended things that may have not been that good to me but ended out working better than planned. She and her staff did an amazing job in making my day feel special and stress free.

As for the zoo itself, I feel like it was my second home. I know the ins-and-outs of that place just visiting there more often. The animals were amazing and I've learned about animals I didn't know even existed. The great one horned rhino was amazing!! I felt like it took me back to the prehistoric ages!! Also, of course, it is right next to the coast so a little chilly at times but what do you expect? You're on the coast!!

Overall, I love this place and my family became official when my husband and I got married here so we'll definitely be an SF Zoo Family! We'll be back!!
author: Nina A.

description:
I like waltzing around zoos, even though it's pretty much you've seen one you've seen them all. It's a nice time to spend a day seeing all the creatures one usually only sees in pictures. This zoo is on the smaller side, we were able to see it all within a few hours, but it's still nice. They've got a bunch of different animals all divided in their respective continents around the zoo. The tiger and lion habitats made me sad though, they were tiny! They've even got a little "house" they're all together for the public's viewing please, rather than their habitats with all the greenery, which are even tinnier! The tiger I saw in there could only walk a few paces before he reached the end! 

The parking lot was jammed by the time we got there so we parked a few blocks away on the street for free, and as is the case with every zoo I've ever been to, the food is ridiculously expensive as well. 

*Random Thing That Annoyed Me* : They had smushed penny machines and I saw a cute red panda one you could make, but I couldn't find any sort of panda at this zoo!
author: Emily G.

description:
Great place to come with kids! Animals are actually very accessible for the viewing from few different angles. ( unlike in some other Zoos) My favorite corner is with Giraffes and Gorillas.
There is a wonderful playground on premises . Also Mary Go Around and Zip Line for kids ( for $3 charge)
I missed seeing lots of animals because we got stuck at the playground bit even than I enjoyed the visit. The admission charge  is reasonable.
I love that is one block away  from the Ocean. You can plan to  walk / play on the beach after the Zoo visit.
author: Dani O.

description: Don't waist your money parking is a mess if your not there by noon plan on parking out side and walking alot to get back to the zoo. Most of the animals were either sleeping or had a look of being depressed. The upkeep wasn't good. Most of the habitats smelled pretty bad. The areas where some animals were kept were rather small like the lion's and koalas. It gave you a sad feeling for the animals when you left. If you plan on going to a zoo in the Bay Area hands down the best zoo is Oakland many different attractions. The animals look happy and alert.
author: Monica D.

description:
"What's a pachyderm?" 
"Well son, it's an order of mammals, including but not limited to, Elephants, Rhinos and Hippos."
"What's an order?" 
"Drink your giant Dr. Pepper..."

Who doesn't love a day at the Zoo? I had just had the worst Eggs Benedict of all time (Hollandaise sauce is so easy SF, what gives?), and I declared we should go to the Zoo. My dining companion, who was also choking down some pretty brutal Hollandaise concoction, agreed. He then clapped very loudly.

The SF Zoo itself seems more humane than most Zoos because of SF's naturally temperate climate. All the usual suspects are there, tigers, lions, snakes, penguins, pachyderms... 

The SF Zoo also has a train that runs through it, which is a handy way to see things without walking around. I had managed to hurt my foot in SF (no one is surprised), and thought this would be a good way to get around. I was assured by my date that the train was just for children, so I hobbled about. As we were leaving the train passed us. All adults. 

PEPPER PROPS To all the snow leopards in the world. So cute! So bouncy!
author: Evelyn A.

description:
Extremely disappointed! $42 for 2 adults with parking & 2 yo son was free.  Grounds are unkept- weeds growing everywhere. The eating areas are filthy & this was at the beginning of a Monday, so obviously the weekend messes were still there. Many areas with spilled food & drinks, trash on the ground & filthy tables.  Also the food was horrible- burgers cold & hard- they make them ahead of time & let them sit.  Big pretzels stale. 
The walkways have many areas where the tiles have lifted & can cause a huge falling hazard. The train was broken. The buildings are faded & it looks so run down.
Lastly the animals were all lethargic, sleeping or not available.  This was between (11-3pm in April on a beautiful day. Their habitats are extremely run down, small and depressing. This is absolutely the worst zoo I've ever visited.  Monkeys didn't play, a polar bear in a captivity area which looks like a desert instead of snow, no elephants & they killed the baby gorilla with a hydraulic gate. Horrible experience. I felt so bad for those animals. 
Don't waste your time or money - find something else to do in SF.
The only good thing was that my 2 year old was clueless to how bad it was & his highlight was seeing one poor seal swimming in circles & grunting.
author: Jacqueline B.

description: The animals are extremely depressing to look at. Half of them looked fairly undernourished. My family wasted $20 for a very small and dingy zoo. Don't waste your time here!
author: Elyse E.

description:
It was my first  time at the SF Zoo and I truly enjoy animals. 

My experience here was an okay one. I mean I love the whole setup of the zoo, which is very beautiful to me and everything but the only thing that disappointed me the most was there were no elephants. 

It was refreshing seeing rhinos and a hippo though because I've always wanted to see one in real life and I got pretty excited seeing those. 

And the koalas were also something I was looking forward to. 

Oh and some of the cats exhibits looked dirty, I don't know it looked depressing to look into. 

It's a very active nicely laid out zoo. But I don't think I will be coming back here for awhile.  I am happy that I went though, because I love animals.
author: Jedrick A.

description:
I was extremely surprised that a zoo in SF would be as extensive as it was. I'm not sure why I had that pre-notion but I expected it to be rather small. It was surprisingly a nice and large place with a myriad of animals. The train is very cute as well.

The one thing that this place doesn't have is elephants. The other very disappointing aspect was the dinosaur exhibition if you can even call it one. It was basically a "maze" with pictures of dinosaurs. No bones, no models, no movies. Oh well.

Get parking early on in the street and not the paid parking lot if you can.

Overall - yes this is not a world class zoo like San Diego but for the city it does its thing.
author: Julia P.

description:
This was the best Zoo that I have visited in terms of animals being active and visible! 

All the animals were moving around and making to create an extremely enjoyable zoo experience. 

It took my girlfriend and I 2.5 hours to tour the whole place. I highly recommend visiting the SF Zoo.
author: David K.

description:
So damn depressing. This zoo is notorious for mishaps including the famous tiger attack and most recently the baby gorilla death. 

Looks very shabby and out-dated. They are in need for a new exhibit soon because the animals are just as bored as the ticket holders. 

This place is where hope goes to die.
author: Michelle A.

description:
Finally made my way over this zoo. I didn't expect it to be amazing, since Ive been to both the wild animal park, and zoo of San Diego multiple times. 
The zoo was larger then I assumed, and if your a resident it is only 12 bucks. I like the lay out of the zoo because you can essentially make a loop with out having to backtrack or miss anything major. The park itself was very clean, though some exhibits were old looking the majority have either been re vamped or in the process of being re modeled so id like to come back in a year. The animals looked clean healthy and reasonable sized conditions. Ive seen some zoo's that sadden me but for the most part they looked well kept. Grizzlies, tigers, gorillas, great stuff.
author: Benjamin B.

description:
I like this zoo.  It is very close to the beach so it can be cool here.  They charge for parking but if you do not mind a little walk, you can park for free on the street just north of the zoo entrance.  Their are some small local restaurants located along here.  They are an alternative to the zoo restaurants.

I was a little confused because you buy your ticket at the kiosk than walk in a little bit where they collect it at a little hut just pass one of the exhibits.  It looks bigger on the inside than I expected.  Some parts of the zoo definitely need a remodel.  It was interesting to see the older exhibits and compare them to the newer ones.

It is relatively flat so it is very easy to walk around.
author: Joe T.

description:
I love giraffes!  We came specifically to see Erin, the new baby giraffe (well, he wanted to see crocodiles, but there weren't any).  Erin is so cute!  And definitely my favorite part of the zoo.  And if you only want to see the giraffes, you can actually walk in and see them from a short distance in the courtyard area before they collect tickets.  So if you're in the area but don't have time for the entire zoo, stop in and peek at the giraffes for free!

My last visit here was nearly ten years ago, and a lot was actually still the same.  It took us about three hours to see everything.  We came on a Tuesday, so it wasn't crowded at all.  Parking was easy in their lot for $8.  It's right by the ocean, so it can be a bit chilly with the wind, but I survived fine in shorts.
author: Anna C.

description: The zoo is big and has a good variety of animals, however is very disappointing that they don't  have elephants. The price is reasonable and the zoo is clean.
author: Suzy R.

description:
This zoo is more like a 3.5, but I gave it a 4. I've been here a couple of times and I feel like it's always the same stuff. Although I love seeing the animals, after awhile it got a little bit boring. I love how the SF zoo has many events here and there, so that's something new. I love seeing the various animals and attending the feeding hours, because they are so cute!

Very children friendly and adult friendly if you want to feel your inner childhood. 

The bug area always gives me the chills, but it's so neat to see the different insects and what not.

If you don't want to pay for $10 parking, park outside the zoo. It's a small walk, but it saves you $10.

COME AND HAVE A GOOD TIME.
author: Martin N.

description:
The SF Zoo - Kill its own animals ! Boycott them, please.

A San Francisco Zoo worker was required to keep her hand on an emergency stop button controlling a hydraulic door that fatally crushed an endangered young gorilla, but investigators are looking into whether she failed to do so, The Chronicle has learned.

The 16-month-old Western lowland gorilla, Kabibe, was killed Friday after she darted under the electric door as it was slowly closing downward, an incident that has again raised questions about safety at a zoo that has seen a long history of injuries to animals, staffers and visitors.

A warning sign was in place near the gorilla door Friday, according to a photo obtained through a public records request. The sign states: "To prevent injuries to the gorillas during operation of the electric doors: Move only one door at a time. Keep your hand on the stop button at all times. Do not leave the electric panel until operation of the door is complete."
author: Charles B.

description:
We actually came here for the Christmas lights. They were, however, very unimpressive. A fancy hotel lobby has better Christmas lights. Do not waste your money!

We also got charged $10 for parking when it was not necessary. The ticket booth attendant didn't feel the need to let us know that it was not needed.
author: Gulzeb-Therilyn N.

description:
We took my niece here and she absolutely loved it. There is so much to see and on a nice day, it's well worth the trek. Luckily, for us, the weather was clear so it made this visit much more fun.

I really liked seeing the bears, penguins and koalas. We didn't pet any animals in the petting zoo. The peacocks are gorgeous.

Parking is $10 but it happened to be full so we parked at the beach for free and walked over. Get here early because it stays open until 5pm and the last time you will be admitted is 4pm. I recommend giving yourself a few hours at least to explore. I think we saw almost everything.

Also, it's pretty easy to get lost even with GPS. Don't say, I didn't warn you.
author: Amy J.

description:
Here's what I saw at the zoo yesterday:

1. Baby Tiger (her name is Jillian) playing with her mom
2. Baby Giraffe (already 6'6" at two weeks!) refusing to be herded back inside the barn
3. Aye Ayes!
4. Penguin feeding
5. Snow leopard with a big bushy tail
6. A monkey pooping
7. A grizzly bear pooping
8. A crazy hippo trying to bite through the steel cable enclosure. Yikes.

All-in-all, pretty awesome. It was a Sunday, but even with the crowds and kids, ti was totally doable--and I'm a crowd hater. 

Anyways, this was a good trip to the zoo. A lot of fun--I think the zoo's always a good trip because no matter who you are, it reminds you off the diversity of the planet, and I think this one is particularly diverse in their collection. They also really like reminding people that they are good at breeding the animals, so go SF. Plus, monkeys!
author: Allison S.

description: Very disappointing. I know it is not the San Diego zoo, but it was not what we expected. We have not visited the San Francisco zoo in years. It was very nice and a fun place to bring the kids. But that was 20 years ago. Our visit today was just a long walk and we could have  accomplished  that at  the park. The exhibits look unkept and the animals were moving very little. We rode  the train with the grandkids. It had technical difficulties. We waited for 30 minutes. It finally started and we were in our way. Well about half way through the ride parts of the wheels started falling off and rolling down the hills.  The train stopped and we had to disembark in the middle of bushes. The people in charge of this ride never even apologized or explained the situation. It was actually hilarious. What a joke. A lot of exhibits were closed. We basically saw giraffes and ostriches and bears. All in all I can say it was not fun. It is a waste of money.
author: Kim B.

description:
So I came here for a wedding. And it was awesome. People: everyone should get married on the African savannah here. Also, if it's an option, make sure you sign up for giraffe feeding, because it was tremendous. 

I loved that parking was easy -- $10 inside, free on the street outside, and that it was open early enough to see the animals before they get sick of tourists but not so early that all the creatures are still sleeping. They let you bring in your own food and drink but also have food for purchase if you're into that kind of thing. 

Some of the animals are kind of boring (is that their fault? I can't decide.), and WHAT is with that dinosaur exhibit? I thought zoos were for living creatures. Some of the exhibits could also use some sprucing up. 

That being said, it was a fun day, and not a bad way to spend a sunny Saturday.
author: Monica D.

description: The zoo itself was great but don't eat the food there! There was a guy selling lobster rolls from a cart that looked legit and tasted great. Fast forward a few hours and I was deathly ill from food poisoning. Had to pay $200 to stay in the hotel an extra day. This happened May 2015 and I probably will never go back because of that horrible experience.
author: Hella B.

description: It is a Zoo, what is not awesome about a zoo?  I loved all of the exhibits and the animal enclosures were pretty big and clean... Though I thought the bird enclosures were kind of small for the pour guys to be flying around in.  East to navigate, plenty of bathrooms & food stops, all in all it was a great experience.
author: Bryanna P.

description: Run down !!  The animals have to be stressed from the train  that carries patrons around the zoo.  The train was so loud and obnoxious it gave me anxiety.  The cages for the most part were clean but small and run down. There weren't to many animals which was the reasons we went to the zoo.  What kind of zoo doesn't have elephants? The elephant area had become a Lego play area.  The only that I can say is outstanding is the children's area.  I was so disappointed to see what this great San Francisco Zoo had become.
author: Lisa O.

description:
I had friends visiting from Arizona and prior to their visit, they purchased some SF City Passes that gave them entry to various places around the City. They planned most of their trip around my availability and on the day I was able to play tour guide, this was our first stop on the adventure.

In all the various years I have lived in the Bay Area, I had never been to the SF Zoo. In fact, I haven't been to a zoo of any kind in a number of years since the various summer camps my daughter was involved with inevitably took a field trip to one.

This zoo was nicer in some ways than most I remembered going to. The price for admission wasn't outrageous, the food offerings in the cafe were decent and reasonably priced and some of the animal exhibits were great. We really had a great time watching the gorillas and the giraffes and all felt sorry for the large cats. We liked the penguins even though they were stinky and were particularly fond of the polar bears although they seemed a little old and sad.

I am glad we came here and loved the location itself but don't feel the need to come back any time in the next bunch of years.
author: Tam F.

description:
So like, the SF zoo got a new baby giraffe!!!!  And it's soooo cute. :)

I love giraffes.  They're so incredibly big for being a baby (only 6 feet tall!), and they are funny animals to watch at the zoo.  This zoo was very informational, and I learned a lot about penguins at the penguin feeding!  They also have peacocks running around but the female peacock didn't follow me in leading her to a prospective husband.  Booooo.  

On another note, it can get really chilly here!  It's right next to the ocean so dress warmly and not like me in a summer dress and cardigan.  LOL.  It's FUHHHREEEZIN.  Overall, a really great place to be!  Hit the entire zoo minus the petting zoo in roughly 2.5 hours!  Though it might be an all day event if you have kids, it's a doable journey around the park in a small amount of time!
author: Jana L.

description:
I have to admit I've never been to the zoo prior to its expansion, so I don't have anything in mind to compare it to - hence the lacking star, but it was still a wonderful experience! My boyfriend and I headed over the other day (it was beautiful, hot, sunny weather!) and thought we would only spend and thought it would only take an hour or so. We ended up staying until closing! (Side note: there was a wedding reception happening there at closing, and it was gorgeous.)

They have a large collection of animals - much more variety than I had expected, and the habitats for the animals were beautiful layouts of rolling hills and flowers, large playgrounds and tree with elaborate tree structures, waterfalls and ponds, etc. It was a very hot day, and I'm assuming the animals were pretty exhausted from being watched by the crowds. Namely the large cats. But all of the other animals were pretty active, the bears, the rhinos, ostriches, penguins, otters.

The zoo itself is very clean, and the overall layout is easy to follow but also has wide and divergent paths that allow you to go wherever you wish and avoid crowds. The only thing that bothered me wasn't the zoo itself, it was the people - some parents were obnoxiously loud and setting bad examples for their kids or other children, yelling at animals to "move" or "wake up" despite the posted sign right beside them indicated a pair of lips with a finger over it, the universal sign for 'shut the hell up!'

On a lighter note, we stayed for the giraffe feeding, and got to see the newest addition to the family, a tiny giraffe taller than me with its mother. They were adorable!

We didn't purchase anything there - we knew better - and instead opted to go to a restaurant afterwards. All in all, it was a splendid date day, and I absolutely recommend heading to the zoo!
author: Di M.

description:
Stupid idiot humans yelling at the animals all day long. These animals were under a lot of stress. 

There is a train in the park that comes by every 5
minutes blaring its whistle right next to the polar bear and grizzly bear cages. 

And yes they are cages. Tiny cages of concrete rock for the Bears. Just so sad. 

There were loins in 10x10 cages. It was so sad.

I also observed them feeding the polar bear through a cage door. It was on its stomach on the ground trying to eat through a screen. It was being feed lettuce while some moron talked in a baby voice to it. 

Free these beautiful animals!!!!!
author: Chris H.

description: Very gorgeous , huge spacious area! Variety of animals I haven't seen at other zoos!! Very great place for family time! The food is rather expensive, but that was expected at outdoor places. Would have been nice if there was a petting zoo!
author: Mikayla T.

description: This zoo is wonderful. We are from SoCal so we visit the San Diego and LA zoos often. This zoo was more enjoyable than our two.  You can even view the giraffes and visit the gift shop without paying the reasonable admission. The zoo is just off the ocean south of Golden Gate Park. The paths are well laid out and let you view the animals from many viewpoints. The live steam train takes you on 2 loops. Food was excellent. The petting zoo and insect houses were very nice. Old merry-go-round was fun. Staff were all friendly and helpful. On a weekend I suggest getting there as soon as they open at 10AM. Plenty of benches. Lots of open space.
author: R S.

description:
We did NOT like SF Zoo. Very sad to see little koalas behind the glass in a little cubicle with its face down and covered with her arms! Noisy, busy place with miserable animals! People are like monkeys wistling and screaming at the animals trapped behind cages! Not coming back again!

We looked in their eyes as it was very painful! They sell their lives for stupid tickets and they are used like toys!
author: D G.

description: Today was my first time at the San Francisco Zoo and I have to say it is a memory that will stay with me for a lifetime. My boyfriend and I took part of the IfOnly Interactive Red Panda Experience in which we started off our experience with the lovely Katharine showing us around the zoo (which is incredibly substantial by the way) leading to the Red Panda enclosure. Antoinette led us in and Eric did a fantastic job of teaching us more about the red panda while still keeping the little guy engaged in our visit :) 5 out of 5 stars all around, I can't wait to come back!
author: Amber L.

description: Amazing place to be for animals but their services sucks. I dropped my GoPro Hero 4 Silver in the swan lake and they said they would get it in an hour... I waited till 7pm, which was 7 hrs, and nothing. No call, nothing. I'm thinking they didn't even check cause we called the next morning and they said "oh we will check the pond again, and call you back.." HOW LONG DOES IT TAKE FOR YOU TO GET IN THERE AND GET IT?? I would've jumped in to get it myself but I can't, I respect the animals home. Yeah it's my fault for dropping it but people make mistakes and them being lazy and saying that we will get it in an hour, is pathetic. It's been 24 hrs now. Customer service sucks. Other than that, the zoo animals are amazing.
author: Mariana G.

description:
The best thing about this zoo is that they actually have a main path for you to follow if you want to see everything and not miss a single thing. Signs are everywhere along with maps so you'll have a hard time missing exhibits. Exhibits themselves are pretty nice and spacious for animals and there's different vantage points that surround the exhibits if you want a different point of view. 

Petting zoo was lively and there was a worker there who gave out more feeding pellets to you if the machines didn't give enough.

Not surprisingly, the food here is overpriced.
author: Bryan Y.

description:
When the highlight of a Thursday afternoon at the Zoo is the sighting of an over-sized 4 year old in a stroller, in a Superman shirt, with a ten inch Slurpee™ in his hands & his mom says, "let me have that, you're going to throw it all up," and the realization that the best thing about the zoo is that it's a little slice of serenity, you begin to change your expectations about what a zoo is all about -- de-stressing. 

Sure, it's not baby birding shots of Fernet on 6th Street, but it's a mighty fine way to wind down someone's stay, or living, in SF. Pets lower stress, and add years to our lives. Animals in the wild have a trait we can learn from: while sleeping, they are able to release the stress "toxins" in their nervous system that are pent up throughout the day while in survival mode. This is how they're able to stay so calm (seemingly), and to live longer, and to not be overweight. When you notice animals paws and extremities twitching while sleeping, including cats & dogs, that's what's happening. We should take note (shameless plug for the Somatic Experience technique in the book, Waking The Tiger). 

Just being at a zoo, surrounded by animals -- tranquil, docile animals -- is relaxing. It can be frustrating when you want to see Chimpanzees swing from branch to branch & polar bears swimming, but that's not happening. 

The real thing to bet on while going to the SF Zoo is how likely would it be if "that Chimp could totally swing over here and rip that Slurpee Kid's face off," or, "that Gorilla could definitely walk over & leap the moat," or, "there's nothing between me & that hippo but a pissed off peacock & a bed of rocks, say... hippos kill, yeah?" 

I fancy myself -- and Zoos do too -- a Zoo expert. In a past life, I had the fine job of filming zoos. If you're comparing zoo-to-zoo, SF is feeble in the face of St. Louis, Denver & Indianapolis. Did we miss sting rays, jelly fish & shark petting? Did we miss the part where we can go below & see polar bears swimming? Elephants, anyone? What's a zoo without a solid elephant? Your bird exhibit is pretty mighty, though. You definitely Put A Bird On It -- Everywhere. And the kids you draw in are, like all other zoos, SOLID. The upshot of all this is that we bagged & tagged the zoo in 90 minutes, and since we're kidless, and your fine seaside location, we book ended our trip with pints & high fives at Costello's & the Park Chalet. And, we didn't throw up.
author: Jon A.

description: I have mixed feelings about zoos, but did enjoy a beautiful afternoon here with family. The food in the cafe was suprisingly tasty and well-priced! The highlight was a train trip on the mini train, so fun! The gift shops are kitchsy though--avoid if you have a child that will beg for cheap junk!!!
author: Maud R.

description:
I love zoos and I had really big expectations for the SF Zoo. I have been talking about going here for years. 

After coming back from the National Zoo in Washington, DC (which was free) I was very disappointed with SF Zoo. 

Yes, it's very large "99 acres of lush gardens and animal exhibits" and the "1,000 exotic, endangered, and rescued animals and majestic, peaceful gardens full of native and foreign plants" but there was not much for ME to see. I was looking for the "wow" factor and it wasn't at this zoo. 

The only section I really enjoyed was the African Region. It was lovely to see the giraffes roaming with the ostriches; animals that I didn't see at the National Zoo. 

Endless walking..with very little to see. Exhibits after exhibits of the same animal species (polar bears, lions, tigers) hoping I was going to see something else.. The massive lemur forest with the lemurs huddling by the doors. The 34 year old polar bear that looked sick and had me worried. The lonely bobcat, resting against the wall. 

The cute baby lowland gorilla chewing on a twig and attempting to climb the rocks. The sad Mandrill with its back turned towards me. The three Patas Monkey, grooming and sunbathing. The bored "senior chimps" sitting and behaving human like..just gazing mindlessly into the trees. The slightly pinkish flamingos feasting in white buckets..with the beautiful pink hues absent from their bodies. The angry hornbill using its bill to chase the native squirrel away. The Pachyderm building reeks of dung but filled with beautiful Lego art work (no more elephants).

I was in search for something entertaining and stumbled into the South American region. I looked up to see two beautiful red parrots (Rio!!!) resting upon the branch. "Hellooooo", I said. A few seconds later, I heard "herro". So cute, a bird speaking to me? 

Still, my heart wasn't content with what was in front of me..

As the sun started to fall, I sadly walked towards the exit gate, passing the African Region one last time to see off the giraffes as the glare of the sun brings tears to my eyes.
author: Karen S.

description:
Walked the entire Zoo; it is very clean won easy to follow paths.
Which means you're not going to miss any exhibits.  Only complaint not many animals were visible to the public..
Still enjoyable day with typical SF weather!!
author: Sandi G.

description: I haven't been here in ages but it's not the place I remember it to be. The playground got downgraded. There was no white alligator and the building it used to be in was closed. Also another exhibit with the jaguar was also closed.
author: Vincent G.

description:
Yes it is small and a bit dated, but what a gem.

It's all about getting up close to the animals, and on that score this place delivers.

My Goddaughter and I had a great time here, the animals were so interesting, the displays so well done. We really loved the penguins.

Come with a youngster or a youngish outlook.

Enjoy!
author: William M.

description: The zoo was great although it was a bit confusing. I started off buying the tickets & parking. Then had to give the ticket to the lady to get into the zoo. I didnt notice that I passed the stroller rentals since it was surrounded by gift shops. So I had to go all the way back to the entrance once I noticed they had them for rent. They had a double for $12 & a single for $10. It seems like the proper price for the single would be around $8. ( reason i deducted 2 stars) other than that it was organized , great animals & great scenery
author: Stevey W.

description:
I can't really say I was impressed at all. Went here with my 2 nieces, wife, and sister/brother in law over the weekend. 

Pro's: The food costs are very reasonable. Cheaper than a baseball game, which I didn't expect. There's a big Café in the middle of the zoo that features anything from tofu stir fry to chicken strips and burgers. Staff was very friendly, and lines went pretty quick. Lots of great things for the kids to do, such as statues to take photo's on, play structures in the park, and fun other photo op's that I thought were clever. The tiger exhibit was awesome. Never seen one so up close (by the Penguins). The layout is nice too, you can do one big loop and see everything.

Con's: No way around it.. the animals just weren't happy! The hawk we saw was on the ground with his peak through net like "get me out of here". The gorilla's clapped for US. The giraffe's walked in circles. The kangaroo's layed in the only patch of sun they could find, as did most of the other animals. Maybe it's because it was cold out and it's not their normal habitat?

Overall... I guess I was expecting a bunch of happy animals roaming around. Instead I paid to tire my feet out seeing a bunch of animals that looked super bored. Just my opinion...
author: Matt L.

description:
One of the best zoos I have been to.

We arrived about 45 minutes after opening and had no trouble finding a close parking spot, but the lot looked full when we left in the afternoon.We also went in April, even though it was a Saturday it was not summer, so I think it was less crowded.

The zoo has a wide selection of animals, including everything my kids wanted to see - zebras, giraffes and lions. The animal enclosures are large enough that the animals look comfortable and happy, but not so large that they can hide from you. Visitors are also able to get very close in. We got closer to the animals than at any zoo I've seen, we were able to see them really clearly and our photos are amazing. 

The exhibit with giraffes, zebras, ostriches and some other african plains animals was our favorite. You can walk under a tunnel and into a viewing area in the middle of the enclosure. This is where we got the best view.

As far as adults go, I really enjoyed the gorilla and lion exhibits. The animals were right in front of where we were standing, just hanging out. Since it wasn't crowded there were only a few people there looking, so we could take our time and take a bunch of photos. Both the gorilla and the lion looked right at my husband while he was taking their pictures. We got amazing photos, so it was a great trip for us, too. I uploaded 11 of our photos, starting here http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/san-francisco-zoo-san-francisco?select=ETvdmxZgOh6ZAJ81R8ntig#ETvdmxZgOh6ZAJ81R8ntig

We did ride the steam train. It was $4 per person. It was fun and my kids loved it, but the track is really short and the ride only goes around twice. It was a very short ride, kind of disappointing but my kids didn't seem to notice. 

We knew the food would be expensive, so we ate right before we came and didn't eat here. I did glance at some menus and noticed that food was pricey, but I don't remember the prices. I did see cotton candy, soft pretzels, kettle corn and burgers.

Overall, it was a great trip. I want to move to the area soon and I plan on getting a family membership to the zoo when I get there.
author: Brandi C.

description:
In response to Tina L.'s review, I see what she means by zoos being cruel, but they've changed since the original zoos that were about just caging animals for show. A lot of the animals that San Francisco Zoo has were about to die in the wild. For instance, one of their sea otters was found shot in the wild by hunters and blinded. SF Zoo took him in and now cares for him. Another example would be an eagle that was hit by a car and the accident resulted in its poor right wing because torn off. SF Zoo cares for it now and it lives to a ripe old age that many eagles in the wild don't get to see.

While I do agree that the original zoos were cruel when they were first established, now SF Zoo seeks to promote wildlife conservation and works providing a comfortable stay for the animals, often rescuing them from certain death in the wild.

---

I really enjoyed my trip to the San Francisco Zoo. It's a fairly large zoo, with many different exhibits separated into the different regions of the world as well as some animals. They have a great variety of things you can check out and there are little placards in front of each exhibit as well that gives you a little nugget of knowledge. The prices are reasonable as well so trust that you won't be needing to fork over loads of money just to have a great day.

Tips:
~ Be sure to check out their schedule on your map. That's when all the feeding shows are happening so if you want to see some action, keep your eye on the clock and the schedule.

~ Wear comfortable shoes - you're going to be doing a lot of walking and it would be silly to wear heels or even thin sandals that don't provide maximum comfort.

Room For Improvement:
~ When it comes to the feeding shows, I feel like the caretakers can make a bit of an effort to try and educate. For instance, explaining what they're feeding, answering questions, etc. I remember Academy of Sciences explains about the penguins and even answers questions while feeding. I don't see why the SF Zoo shouldn't do the same.

~ In the Nature Walk at the Children's Zoo, I understand that they get highschoolers to present the animals but they really need to teach them to present themselves a lot better. The girls who were doing the salamander were actually really annoying, occasionally shoving each other and giggling during the presentation. As someone who did a lot of community service in high school, I took all of my tasks seriously - it's not play time you're representing yourself and the zoo.

Overall, San Francisco Zoo is a great place for some wholesome family fun. I love seeing all the animals and we had a great time.
author: Clarissa Y.

description:
My Zoo Review

Hmmmmm where do I start....it's a zoo and I mean that as a positive and pejorative. 

I was very excited to take my 12 year old son to this zoo for the first time. It had been years since I had been, but I remembered it to be a generally positive experience. 

I will tell you right now it is something you only need to experience once and then you are done. I saw no compelling reason to return. 

First off ....animals suck it's no wonder we hunt them for food. Save for a few those un-evolved bast**rds remained hidden and asleep. What a waste! Do they not know I paid good money to be entertained? I want my monkeys to dance for me. I want them to smoke, wear little leather jackets and bring me small bottles of liquor like you get from airline attendants. Oh there were a few cool animals like the squirrel monkeys, the Black Rhino ( fat a**)  and of course the ever ginger Red Raccoon looking thing. What the hell was that animal any way?  Whatever it was it lives in a jungle and of course it needs saving. They all need saving ...animals are so needy! Any way the red raccoon thingy was fuzzy , cute and playful. OH YEAH it was a Red Panda which is counterintuitive because it looks NOTHING like a Panda, not the ones in China or the one that fat bast**rd that plays for the SF Giants. 

There were NO elephants ...nuff said

There was no reptile house...seriously what the f**k?!!

I got all giddy about the insect house, but most of them were dead or in jars and you had to go into a ungodly humid and hot little building with kids screaming like banshees to experience dead insects. Not exactly a Costa Rica eco tour. 

The highly reflective glass surrounding many of the animal displays made viewing the animals even harder, but it was the joyous spittle and sticky fingers of young crumb-crunchers all over that glass that made it a special biological collection of its own. 

I found many of the old buildings not open, and fountains and displays had been turned into kids playgrounds. Oh did I mention hordes of screaming children? The god**mn kids were louder than Howler monkeys. 
There was one playground that was supposed to be Antarctica, but I referred to it as "The worst version of Frozen ever!"

In all seriousness the zoo is dated and the setup made it hard to see the animals. I was honestly more impressed by the Sacramento zoo and considering the size of the two municipalities I wouldn't use that quote on your Chamber of Commerce fliers SF. 

The Zoo needs work... a lot of work. Oh and the Zoo needs more animals and by animals I mean live ones, and not dead or stuffed ones. FINALLY, will someone do something for god's sake about that poor Polar Bear  it was the saddest freakin thing I have ever seen and I am pretty sure they don't have green f**king fur in the wild.

If you have to choose go to The Science Academy at GG park....much much better experience over all
author: Kenneth F.

description:
I have gone here since I was a child.  I have many fond memories of the carousel, but it was not until later that I liked seeing the animals because their old enclosures were so nasty.

We had our honeymoon here...we packed tuna sandwiches, and bought cokes.  New Hubby drove a blue Dodge Dart.  We were starving students at the time.

DD brought us back a few years later, and she really enjoyed the many improvements to the habitats, and the Children's Zoo.  We saw so many great animals on display there.

Fast forward to today....DD, SIL and the DGD"s and their doting grandparents went for the girls first trip.  (they have been to Oakland many times)

Overall I think things have declined since we last took DD when she was in college.

The Children's Zoo:
Our first stop...and so many displays were empty.....no hedgehogs,or any animals to touch.  Just guinea pigs, a bunny, and some Meercats in cages. We did see and owl.  The farm area is about the same...goats, horses, baby chicks, two Alpacas, and two donkeys.  Sad. I loved the interactive parts where the young volunteers would describe the animal, and the kids could touch it.

The Primate Area:
MIA were the nocturnal animals....I was crestfallen!

The habitats have improved beyond the Gorilla enclosure....but so many cages were empty.

The African Animals, Bears, South American Animals:
Significant improvements in habitats, but again...sadly lacking in animals.

The penguin area, and the aviary were very sad in every way.

The best:
My favorite were the Koalas, Peccaries and the Carousel.

Allot of walking, but not nearly enough animals!

And yes, we brought a picnic :-)
author: Katherine F.

description:
Am I the only 29-year-old in Yelp history to visit and then write a review of the San Francisco Zoo entirely of my own accord, with no kids in tow? 

If not, phew! And if so, so be it; I'm still a kid at heart. 

A friend and I paid the zoo a visit on a Friday afternoon this summer and found it to be surprisingly well-maintained and not too crowded. The animals didn't look miserable as they often do at other zoos, for example, and even though we had expected to be overwhelmed with swarms of screaming--I mean, adorable--children, the zoo was spacious enough to prevent any cross-generational collisions. 

The vendors are pricy, as is the case with all zoos, but given the price of $14 for SF residents and the size of the zoo, the overall visit seemed like a great deal. The new wolverine exhibit also just came out, and I highly recommend checking that out as well, especially if you--like us--had previously believed that Wolverine was nothing but the name of one of the X-men.... Oops!
author: Ada W.

description:
Reciprocal with Oakland Zoo membership, what a savings right there of eleven dollar!  Very big zoo!  Yes they have shows!  Many animals but of course to see!

Nowadays unlike say thirty more years ago, the animals and the birds are in much more natural environments!  That includes here in San Francisco!  None those steel wire cages!  The animals do seem happier, hey that is as close you can see them if not want to go some far exotic country!  Better than thirty more years ago, many would just pace!  Now they so much happier, especially the times when they see the trainers (trainer for lack of better word) come with food!
author: Karyn C.

description: Went for the first time today.  I couldn't have asked for a better day.  The sun was shining and most the animals seemed to be pretty active.  My kids love the play areas and the rope walk. Me?  The hippo impressed me.
author: Kat G.

description: It's probably fine if you're into animals. But when you just want to get away, rent a jet. It smells better.
author: Loren G.

description: What better way to spend the feast of St. Francis of Assisi than communing with the animals. If you have your doubts about zoos, realize that the animals here are being well taken care of. The confined areas are large, and they have many hiding places if (like Ms. Garbo) they 'vant to be alone'. There are zoo staff that keep an eye out for anyone shouting at/bothering these beautiful creatures. Coming from NYC, I particularly wanted to see cats we don't have in the Bronx or Central Park Zoos: lions, the fishing cats, and bobcats. So preety! Don't miss the view of the Pacific Ocean from the beach a few blocks away, walk through the dunes and watch the surfers and the sunset...
author: Michele D.

description:
The zoo is huge consider its location (at SF).  The place is very clean for a zoo and I am please with the condition of the restroom.  I feel safe to let my son (3yrs old) walk around within my sight zone and no need to chase after him. 

The membership fees are very reasonable compare to other parks.  The only draw back is there is no drop off/pick up zone inside the parking lot.    The zoo is totally worth for a visit for a family day.
author: Liyi Angela Z.

description:
I've been here twice in the past year and have left with the same feelings both times. I really want to love this zoo and get the same magical feeling one might get at Disneyland or even the Monterey Bay Aquarium...but alas I do not.

Both times I have gone to the zoo the weather has been overcast and foggy (it is San Francisco to be fair) which didn't add to the experience. Both times I have gone multiple attractions have been closed, including food places. 

Of course I love looking at all the animals, but it's a small zoo and it doesn't take long to see all of them. Zoos also make me feel a bit sad for the animals. I hope they don't hate it in there.

I do like the little stories about each of the animals and how they got there, or what they like to do. I liked reading about the orphaned Grizzly bears and the eagles who couldn't fly. I also like the bronze statues scattered about which make for good photo opportunities. 

The zoo overall seems a bit run down and could use a good makeover. For the price spent (15 dollars) it isn't worth it to me to come more often. .
author: Issy D.

description:
Just visited this zoo this past weekend. I really enjoyed it.

The parking lot is a bit of nightmare. $12 to park and was already full when we got there and seems really small for such a popular zoo. We were really lucky and were able to find free parking across the street at the beach.

The zoo itself is really nice. I think it's spread out nicely. The zoo was busy but not packed. The animal exhibits looked ok, although a bit on the small side. I thought they had a good variety of animals. There was a baby giraffe there which was adorable.

I would definitely go again. It was $20 for an adult which I thought was really reasonable. I think the San Diego zoo is better of course, but I still think this is a fun zoo to go to for the day.
author: Sara K.

description: it is an amazing experience especially for the kids . The animals are amazing and always friendly woth people. I loved the giraffes the best they where so tall and i also loved feeding the goats that was an amazing experience to do. I will definetly be coming back to this zoo . #1 zoo in the world
author: Renity A.

description: Surprisingly It was not up to the expectations. Animals are also less while as per their Zoo map it looks like a huge Zoo. Children's zoo section was good (its more like a play area with dummy animals). We've already been to few other Zoos but this one looked just an average one. Zoo Parking is pay parking and usually full on weekend if you reach by noon but their are enough space for free road parking on Sloat blvd where we parked.
author: Anshul S.

description:
On Saturday afternoon I attended my friend's wedding ceremony at the San Francisco Zoo and it was fantastic. It took place at closing time around 5:00pm and it was a little chilly but not to bad for being next to Ocean Beach. Parking was free inside the zoo entrance, usually it costs $10.00 to park inside. We waited until everything was set up and the official wedding ceremony took place at the African Wildlife Area. The arrangement was done very well and the back drop was zebras and a giant wild bird. On the other side were some wild African hoofed animals. I  think the zoo bribed the zebras to come out during the ceremony with food and after they finished they ran back into their enclosures. The area seated about 70 people and was nicely decorated.
Afterwards, the festivities took us to the carousel, where they had an open bar and waiters/waitresses serving appetizers;tiny lamb chops, coconut shrimp, and bruchetta. All very delicious. The bartenders were all generous with their pours also.
All the guests got carousel rides also. 
After this, we went to the zoo reception center which was also set up very nicely.
The food service was buffet style and the food was excellent. The wait staff continued to provide food quickly when a selection ran out so the wait was not long,
The choices provided were sliced steak, chicken, red potatoes, grilled carrots and asparagus,
Caesar salad, and rolls. The food that was catered to this event was excellent and they provided sufficient amount for everyone and even offered second helpings.
I had no idea the San Francisco Zoo had this special event arrangement but it was well done and I was thoroughly impressed with this entire event.
author: jack d.

description:
This is a great zoo to take young ones to. We were lucky enough to get a family membership as a gift (very reasonably priced) and have been several times this past year. The zoo is well laid out and most in-park costs, such as rides and food, are reasonably priced and give a 10% discount to members. There is even a great playground for kids to work off some excess energy. For our 2 year old, this has been a great family spot. 
The staff have all been friendly and great to us. Not just zoo keepers, but even the concession workers. That really means a lot. 
I can't give it five stars, however, because most of the animals seem really sad and bored. Some have toys littering their pens that look like they haven't been touched in years. I'd love to see more zoo keeper interaction with the animals. One time we saw a hippo getting showered and a melon treat afterwards. It was the highlight of that trip. Please schedule more of these kinds of things.
author: Art B.

description:
The good: The themes are well put together with the grouped animals. The playground for kids is amazing. Theres a train that runs through the second half of the park. The bathrooms were surprisingly clean!!!

The bad: None of toddler attractions were up and running/open to the public. The food's gross, except for the snack carts. 

The ugly: The animals seem dehydrated & lethargic. Most of them were sleeping during the daytime. None of the recorded info boxes were working the day I went :(

So overall, nothing too below standards and nothing mindblowing great...
author: O.s. M.

description:
Let me start off by saying this park has a great design, but has poor execution.  The layout of the park is smart and concise, but this poses a realy problem when many of the attractions are closed or not in service.  The day I went, we were able to see a wide range of animals, but there were just as many animal attractions that were closed.  I don't know if we went during an off season, but there seemed to be an awful lot of maintenance going on.  I was very impressed by the courteous staff all around the park.

PROTIP:  Go to the kids section because they have a very interesting petting section.
author: David C.

description: This zoo is huge! Prepare to stand in line for a while on the weekends but once you're in it's worth it.
author: Keturah W.

description:
I haven't been to the San Francisco zoo in about 20 years, so going back for the first time since elementary school was a bit nostalgic.  I don't really remember much about what it was like then to compare, but I knew that no matter my age, I still enjoyed it.

There were plenty of animals out in their exhibits to see, so we saw every animal that we wanted to see (giraffe, zebras, lions, bears, tigers, flamingos, penguins, hippos, monkeys,...) It's just too bad that the koalas were sleeping.  My friend that I went with, who's a zoo member, said that she rarely ever sees the koalas awake.

I haven't been to any other zoo since I was a child, so I don't have much to compare to, but for what we have locally, SF Zoo does the job.  You're able to see all of the animals that you would expect to see in a zoo and more!

Parking Tip: If you go early enough in the day, there's plenty of metered parking on Sloat, and you just have a short walk in.
author: Audrey C.

description:
It's been a long time. I first went as a child and saw the beautiful black panther. The eyes, the eyes, the eyes.

The last time I was there, I saw the lions at feeding time. I had no idea of how huge they were until that day. I had no idea that the the roar of a male lion could vibrate your sternum. They all began roaring at sunset. The eyes, the eyes, the eyes. You see a different form of intelligence in their eyes. That's something that humans should experience.

On a funny note, I was at the Hippo exhibit with lots of people. Suddenly we all saw a gigantic bubble rising to the surface and when everyone figured out what it was we all ran like heck. A gigantic fart that smelled like rotting vegetables. I remember collapsing on a bench with other people because we were all laughing so hard we couldn't run anymore.

This is also where I saw a baby Rhinocerous about a month old (1990-92?). It was, as the French say, belle laide. It was stuck to its moms' side like glue until the keeper came. I guess that a gigantic bunch of carrots with the greens still on was a treat for Mom. But, the baby wouldn't go near that man.
author: Alexia G.

description:
I would have to say, this is probably the most impressive zoo I have been to.

I can't even recall the last time I went to the S.F. zoo, lets just say many many moons ago. My Babe Is a huge animal lover so, with always taking the opportunity to get over to san fran, we decided to take a trip to the zoo.

Parking can be difficult to find in the afternoon ( which is when we got there) however, we lucked out within several min finding a place. I also believe its $15.00 for parking that you pay at the admission desk.

There was quite a line to get in however, it moved quite quickly. 

Upon entering the animal kingdom, I immediately noticed how clean and well kept the grounds are.

I think the layout of the zoo flows really well. They have good majority of different animals to see that appeared to be well taken care of. My only concern was for one of the Polar Bears that was pretty skinny and the fact that it was so hott out for them but I am assuming they know what they are doing ( I hope)

We ate at a the Terrace Cafe which didn't appear as clean and well kept as the other cafes though still decent. They have a basic selection of food items to choose from such as burgers, hot dogs, ice cream cones and so forth that were not too expensive. I ordered a Hot dog and my babe and his folks got chicken strips. All items come with kettle chips. My hot dog was actually quite tasty ( I did not eat the bun) and descent in size. The kettle chips however, were horrible and so hard you could probably risk breaking a tooth. It was just bad ugh...

Overall, it was great seeing the animals, they looked happy for the most part ( except for some of the gorillas ) lol. They grounds were kept very well and the ground staff were all very friendly as well.

Can't say I am eager to come back anytime soon but it certainly was enjoyable.
author: Shannon H.

description:
'The San Francisco Climate is actually similar to their natural environment'.

Even with signs like that about the zoo, I couldn't help but feel that most of these animals are highly uncomfortable in this San Francisco weather.  With animals out in the open that are natively from South America, Australia, Africa & Asia, surely San Francisco isn't all that similar to every single one of those places is it?

In case it is, I'm extremely impressed with the versatility of San Francisco's Climate.
