Anyways, this zoo is fairly small, without much in the way of a 'unique attraction' for a zoo.  Nevertheless, zoos are always fun school trips for schools, so I'm glad San Francisco kids have this place to look forward to.

__________________________

Random Musings:
I'm not really sure what emotions and/or feelings looking at caged animals is s'posed to incite.  As for my experience here, it must have been nap time because every animal was snoozin'.  Seeing this, and knowing about the story of a tiger that escaped from his grotto at this zoo brought up feelings of dissatisfaction with life and a desire to (Row Row) 'Fight The Powah!'  

Break outta those cages! Get your freedom!

In reality, I'm far too lazy and complacent to actually act on those feelings.  But I really enjoyed that the zoo brought forth emotions within me.  That is quality entertainment in my opinion.  (At the expense of the animals.  Good thing I'm too selfish to care about the animals' dispositions, otherwise I might have experienced feelings of sadness instead)
author: Jason S.

description:
I really don't know why a lot of people are complaining on here about the zoo. Let me just get this straight across if you are turned-off by all the "$8 for parking is SO EXPENSIVE", there's no reason to. 

Why? Because it's $8 for the entire DAY. If you're there for 2 or 3 hours, the price is really REALLY good considering how you're in SF. 

It's been a LONG LONG time since I first went to the zoo (I think I was like 7 or something) and from what I could remember before a lot of the animals were asleep and not very interesting (maybe not interesting enough for my child-attention-span). I wasn't sure what to expect, especially after reading the reviews, but I'm really glad I went regardless.

My boyfriend and I went there on a Monday and there wasn't a huge crowd at all. We got there around 11, walked around all the enclosures, ate lunch and walked around some more. I think we probably spent around a good 3-4 hours there looking at all the animals. 

The tickets were $17 each per person for the adult price, which for the amount of hours we spent in there is totally justified. 

During the time we were there, a lot of the animals were up and awake. If one wasn't awake, we would walk around and before long they would be awake again. There's never really a dull moment. Plus there's feedings during specific times of the day (usually listed around the area where you buy your tickets) so it's always fun to go see that. 

The petting zoo was awesome. BRING QUARTERS if you want to feed the animals; it only takes quarters! And be careful, some goats have gotten smart enough to stand on their hind legs and eat the food while you get it. 

The bathrooms were ridiculously clean for a zoo and for a place that gets a lot of customers/people. Probably one of the cleanest bathrooms in a public area I've been to. 

My boyfriend brought our own food because we didn't really want to pay for the food due to the fact that it's a little pricey. If you want to splurge on a drink or a churro, sure, but otherwise I wouldn't eat a whole meal there cause it can get expensive very quickly. 

All in all though, a very good trip. Will definitely go back in the future.
author: Angela P.

description:
Never knew lions could live in San Francisco climate.  If the animals could talk, I wonder what they would feel about it.  "Trainer!  Turn up the heaters and bring a couple more filet mignons! Pronto!"    

Last time I went, it was late spring afternoon, and I took the day off on a Wednesday.  For San Francisco residents, the first Wednesday of each month is free.  It was possibly one of the windiest days of the year.  Maybe a higher power was telling me nothing is really free.  When not waltzing in for free, admission is around $15.  There's also a parking fee, so taking the metro line L and walking over could save a few bucks.      

The zoo is medium sized and has a diverse amount of animals.  You'll probably get through it within three and half to four hours at leisurely pace.  Many of the larger mammals are either sleeping or lounging around.  In their original habitats, they aren't juggling tennis balls or doing flips at the sight of a human being, so don't expect "performances".  If you're lucky you'll get to see a natural behavior like the dropping a few deuces or just animals monkeying around.  A small glimpse into nature is one of a kind.  

This isn't remotely close to the best zoo in the world, but the animals are always a joy to see.  Considering the cold weather at times, I'm glad there's even a zoo here in the first place.  Having this zoo in San Francisco is definitely a pleasurable privilege.
author: Arnold T.

description: SF zoo is pretty awesome. All the animals were pretty active. We saw peacocks just walking around the whole park. It was a slow day so maybe it was a little better than it would be on a busy day. The only thing that made me sad were the pilot bears. They just looked so sad. The children's playground was awesome. They had three different playgrounds for older kids and the younger kids.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
What can I say... animals! !!

Childhood memories...

Still an awesome place after all of these years.
author: Tiff C.

description:
Took our 2 year old nephew here since he's starting to get curious about all the animals at the zoo which he sees only in his books. The parking lot was full so we just decided to park outside (for free) and just had a good old walk to get in. The entrance fee is fairly affordable and if you're a San Francisco residence then you get some discount (which we're not though). It's our first time coming in to this zoo and of course we expect to see animals. The behind the scenes lion show is a big letdown because we waited a good 10-15 mins and no lion showed up, bummer! The polar bears were also MIA, so another bummer!. Although, we encountered a pretty peacock walking freely in the zoo and that made my nephew very excited and chased it around. The weather was nice so the walk and animal spectating wasn't such a huge complaint. The kids playground area hit the jackpot for us and the kids just let loose (and the adults keep chase). The primate are was what amused me, since I love anything and everything about them. Saw a silverback and some playful apes, It was such a delight watching them and I can watch them all day. 

It was a very productive day and the experience made our nephews day, tired souls the whole ride home. Will definitely come back again.
author: Joy P.

description:
My husband and I (25&23yrs old) went to this Zoo last Thursday. We are from Melbourne, Australia and we have a pretty decent zoo ourselves.

We love animals and the San Fran zoo is packed with them! We had never seen a Snow Leopard before and we spent a lot of time with her, she was so beautiful! We had never seen a rhino before either, I understand this Zoo rescued this Rhino and that is why he has no horn but I think they should have a sign somewhere saying it's a rescue... 

There was not much variety in the big cats and they are usually my favourites. We loved the giraffes being in the same enclosure as the zebra and ostriches!! 

We felt the $17 entry was fair, I like to support zoo's who are treating their animals right and not forcing them to be displayed all day etc.
author: Erin P.

description: Not the biggest or most spectacular zoo in the world. But for locals looking to share something with the family, this place is a great go-to. Annual membership is a great deal since they have kid-friendly events all year long.
author: Kate S.

description:
Our recent trip to the zoo was quite disappointing. Most of the animal enclosures were depressing. Most of the animals seemed lethargic and if they were not sleeping they were hiding.

The busiest and most exciting spot in the zoo was the kid's playground. This spot was lively ,happy and full of energy.  I wish the whole park was like this.

I was disappointed that each restroom we visited was dirty and in need of a a face lift. 

It would have been nice too see more employees educating the public or sweeping the zoo grounds. 

I live closer to Happy Hollow Zoo in San Jose and will most likely choose to stay closer to home.
author: Hilda C.

description:
San Francisco Zoo Valentine's Day Sex Tour - http://www.2camels.com/san-francisco-zoo-valentines-day-sex-tours.php

As amazing as it sounds!! Who knew that zoo animals were having so much fun!!! This tour is lead by zoo staffer & sexpert Jane Tollini, who does an awesome job of showing how kinky and freaky animals are. In addition, it was fun to watch many of the tour goers become uncomfortable with hearing about all the details of rhino sex and panda mating rituals - LOL! 

Truly a unique date.
author: Zander K.

description:
I'm from Vancouver and our Zoo is definitely not as cool as this one. 

Favourite exhibit was the gorillas. Saw a young one annoying the daddy gorilla by throwing sand at him then running across to try to steal a branch off another gorilla's back. Could have watched them for hours they were so amusing. 

They also have giraffes, hippos, penguins, monkeys, tigers, lions, polar bears, farm animals, insects, birds etc etc. 

We just parked across the hwy so it was free :) 

I definitely recommend coming here if you go to San Fran.
author: Teri L.

description:
It was our most awaited trip... We had read/ heard so much about SF Zoo before, It was worth visiting one time! 
We were 4 grown-up "kids".. Getting excited after seeing a lot of animals and at the same time discussing about their suffering in captivity. But, I think that's inevitable... 
We were there from 11:30 to around 4:30, I am not sure whether it was a nap-time for most of the animals, we couldn't see lions and tigers clearly as they were sleeping. 
Zoo management can certainly do something about glass panels, those were not clean and it destructed the view at times. If it is possible they can install anti-glare glasses. 
If you are vegetarian, carry your own food. Cafes inside do not have much of a veg options.. Leaping Lemur is better than others. 

P.s I might have cried a bit after seeing polar bear.
author: Tejaswini L.

description:
Our Cub Scout Pack just participated in the Wild Nights Camp out in the Zoo. The boys got a behind the scene evening tour of the park, when many animals were active. We saw and heard lions, tigers and the snow leopard. We camped out on a large lawn, near rest rooms and fell asleep to the sound of lions, peacock and the waves on ocean beach.  I pre-opening your followed and saw many other animals waking up. 

It was outstanding. Very well planned out and guided by Chris and Veronica, both students at Berkeley.  We got a pizza dinner, snack and continental breakfast. I highly recommend this for any youth growth.  A bargain at the price.  We will do this one again.
author: John F.

description:
I love the zoo. I know some people have a lot of things to say about the caged up animals, but I just really love the zoo. I came here on a not-particularly-fantastic day but it wasn't raining, so that meant it was great. The zoo was moderately sized--I grew up near Seattle and it felt a little smaller than our Woodland Park zoo, but I haven't been there for a few years, so I don't know.

It felt like there were a lot of animals that weren't out, but all the animals we saw seemed pretty happy and comfortable--except the polar bears, who looked a little sad, but apparently they migrate them around for varied terrain every now and then so maybe that's something to keep their life interesting. I was sad because the fishing cat wasn't out, but they have some really adorable monkeys here and the tigers were all pressed up against the glass and ahhhh so fluffy.

Side note: this place has dippin' dots! Which was pretty exciting for me and my boyfriend, even it wasn't anywhere near like going to an actual dippin' dots place, haha.

The hippo was pretty cool to watch come up for air, and the koala was adoooorable. There were a few baby giraffes that were too cute. I felt like you could see all the animals here really well--you could get pretty close, a lot of them were close to the edge of their exhibit, etc.

Despite being relatively small, we had a good time. If you're from out of town trying to get in all the sights to see in SF, the zoo should probably not be on any list of must-sees, but for a little day trip, we had a lot of fun!
author: Katie V.

description: Been a member for many years -- membership is the way to go, you don't feel guilty if you have to leave after a very short visit (think - toddler tantrum). I love the way they are always adding things and expanding their offerings. It is like visiting a park and I love it and I really love my penguins!
author: B K.

description:
We didn't know what to expect going to this zoo, but I must say we were more than pleased! First of all, how could you not love a zoo across the street from the ocean?  All of the exhibits were beautifully maintained, and compared to our home town zoo, large and lush. Our favorite was the giraffe and zebra enclosure, just beautiful. But the animal who stole our hearts was the cute little baby gorilla. We could have stood there all day and watched her play. We were looking forward to seeing the lion, but I guess the day we were there, he was not out, but we saw the lioness and a couple of beautiful tigers. 

This is a must see if you have kids and are in the area. It is expansive, beautiful coastal fog rolling overhead, lots of fun animals and a large playground area and merry-go-round. We are very excited for our next trip to the area, so that we can visit again!
author: Nicole M.

description:
A pretty solid zoo, but SF has nothing on San Diego in this case. 

Thanks to a volunteer opportunity which involved placing sod in the bunny/guinea pig enclosure, I was able to score free admission to the zoo which was legit. There are a bunch of interesting animals but I gravitated more towards the birds: hawks, bald eagles, macaws etc. They were really awesome and I got some great pictures! Most of the other animals were sleeping but oh well everyone needs their rest. 

I would recommend arriving early before the kids take over the park with their parents... it's gets pretty wild with all the toddlers and young children running around and it can ruin the atmosphere pretty quickly. Also beware of the main food area, it's craziness!
author: Sam F.

description:
The zoo has really improved since our last visit.  

The animals looked healthy.  The habitats were complete.  The landscaping was beautiful, and someone even cleaned our table for us outside the cafe.  

A lot of the animals were injured, and could not survive in the wild.  It's nice that the zoo gave them a safe place to live, while giving us strange life forms to admire.  It was a perfect place to chill out and cheer up.  

Admission was $15 per adult, and there was a $3 discount for showing our drivers' licenses with San Francisco addresses on them, so we actually paid $12 each.
author: David D.

description:
This is a great place to take the family.

First - it is in SF, so this is a great place to escape the "hot" summer days down south.

Second - kids loooove animals they read about in books.

Third - the zoo team is laid back and let people enjoy the zoo.

Overall, a really good time.  We purchased the membership for the family - a good deal.
author: Mike D.

description:
I love visiting zoos and seeing this one was at the top of my list. The location is show-stopping...right next to Ocean Beach on the famous Great Highway. We rolled into the parking lot and noticed some old buildings on the grounds which must have been part of the original zoo back in 1929.  It's boarded up and something is going to happen to the buildings. Not sure what.

We were charged for parking. I read from others they got free parking on the streets. Being a member of the Tucson Zoo, we got a bit of a discount for our visit.

The signage could be a littler clearer and informative.  I found it a bit confusing at times to navigate around using their markers. I first entered a part of the zoo that had very little traffic and again, found some very lonely and abandoned zoo enclosures. Nearby was the huge Pacayderm House. This zoo has no elephants and according to an official I spoke with, does not plan to get anymore after their elderly ones died. There is quite a variety of animals on display, including a rookery of Magallenic penguins. 

I felt several of the displays showed their age in wear and tear and also design. As always, I'd love to see the enclosures be more spacious. 

Everywhere were signs saying to respect the animals and report anyone harassing them....all this stemming no doubt from Tatiana, the Siberian Tiger, who was taunted by some tourists and escaped her grotto and killed one of them. They shot her dead as she was attacking another tourist in the group. Today I saw Sumatran and Siberian tigers as they were enjoying their raw meat treat. I must say everyone was being respectful and talking in quiet voices. 

I have mixed feelings about zoos but appreciate the ones who have missions and purposes for their existence. This one, while having lovely grounds, made me feel somewhat sad though I enjoyed my visit here.  I understand they, like so many other zoos, are having to deal with budget cuts in a time when they could so use a boost. I wish them, and all the animals they care for here,  the very best.
author: Peg P.

description: Our 11yo daughter summed it up best: "more like Zoo Ruins, than Zoo".  What a run down depressing place.  Although I am not a big fan of zoos in general, this one is pretty pathetic.  Nothing resembled a natural habitat.  A good number of the exhibits were closed.  If there was no animal visible outside, they were hard to see from inside any of the exhibit areas.   The capper was the poor gorilla who simply sat in a black plastic tub and picked at his/her hands.  The poor gorilla looked absolutely depressed.  In all honesty, I have only been to 3 other zoos (including the Philly Zoo, my hometown AND the oldest in the country) and the SF Zoo was hands down the worst.   Public facilities were partly available.  Restrooms were taped off.  A latte (we did not buy one) was $7.  A piss poor experience.
author: J C.

description:
Pros:  Easy and nice to walk around.  Has a big playground for kids. a Train ride (not free). 
Cons:  Lacking animals.  Everytime we come here...there are closures of animal habitat. 

At least lower the price if there are closures.
author: Hoover A.

description:
Parking costs $10. You gotta purchase it first at the ticket booth and save that ticket as your only means of exiting the place. I did read reviews about people parking on streets. Which if you drove around you'll be able to locate some public street parking. Since my boyfriend and I are not from San Francisco we didn't feel like getting lost. Plus you'll be doing plenty of walking as it is, so might as well save your energy. 

Tickets for nonresident was $15 per person. I tried to locate some form of coupon but they were not existent. Bathrooms were pretty clean. We were able to see many animals (graffiti, gorilla, peacock, flamingo, monkeys, polar bears, penguins, lions, wallaby, sea otters, etc.). 

My dislikes: there's a section where there's a lion house and when you walk in its all cages. It looked like a jail cell. It was a rather depressing imagine. I truly hope that they do not get abused. It made me think of the movie zoo keeper and how when there's a staff who doesn't care the gorilla gets abused. 

There's a small steam train that you can ride on to see the zoo but it'll cost you a few bucks. It's a fairly small zoo. It took the boyfriend and I only like 3 hours. And trust me we took our sweet time walking around. The LA zoo is a bit better. Although the area where the flamingos are didn't have a funky nasty smell like the LA zoo. 

What l liked was I was able to read stories of different animals being rescued and then placed in the zoos care. That was pretty touching and makes you appreciative of what you're seeing before you.

They also have a play zone for the really small kids which included swings! :) overall, we enjoyed ourselves. My boyfriend was advised to not come on a gloomy day. We weren't quite sure why. When we went it was mid afternoon, pretty gloomy but we were able to see a lot of the animals. We missed the feeding times due to coming here mid-afternoon. I would recommend coming if you've never been to this zoo.  

All in all its a-ok! Therefore 3 stars is appropriate.
author: Lisa D.

description:
What a great zoo. Far better than the Oakland Zoo in my opinion. This place is huge and it looks like there's much more room for the animals to roam around in. Come check out the giraffes, tigers, grizzly bears, hippo, the wandering peacocks, the petting zoo, insects, anaconda and penguins! Take the kids on a train ride that loops around twice for $4 per person. Children two-years-old and under are free. Get the kids a plastic key to insert in a box to hear additional information about each exhibit in English or in Spanish. Que bueno! Be sure to check out the schedule of feeding times for certain animals and pay for parking if you park in the lot. Otherwise you'll hold up the line on the way out. Not fun.

Get a family membership for $100 and get two adults and two kids access for the year. It's a great deal but they should incorporate parking into that too.

The playground under construction looks incredible. I'd def go play in there with or without my nephews. 

The cafe at the entrance makes yummy chocolate muffins and I couldn't believe they served wine and beer at the main cafe. I did try their steak and eggs. It was alright. But they had many other items to choose from. Great selection and with booze. Did I say that already? Great zoo. It's def a full day trip. Be sure to dress for cool weather unless you're chasing and carrying around 2-yr-olds.
author: Bernadette M.

description:
Parking - Lot is $8-$10 depending if you go on a weekday or a weekend

New signage and a lot of donors.

Variety of species - We were almost done within the span of an hour!

New kid play area as you enter.

Take advantage of SF resident day on 1st Wednesday of the month or a Costco Family membership.  Reciprocity applies for other zoos as well. Check online.
author: Jboogie L.

description:
I was so excited to visit this zoo since the last time I had been was when I was around 8 years old. 
I loved the way the zoo is laid out and how it is very easy to make sure that you don't miss anything. While I appreciated the wide variety of animals, I do think that their habitats need to be better maintained and more customized to what their habitat would be in the wild.
The tickets where pricier than I thought they should be and several of the exhibits were closed which was a bit of a letdown. They also had a huge variety of birds, which is great and all but I would really like to see more mammals or other "bigger" animals. 
The food was surprisingly good and inexpensive compared to normal "zoo food" but all the employees we encountered were not nice at all. 
Overall, it was better than our own local zoo in Sacramento, but not as great as I was hoping.
author: Katrina F.

description: 3 &1/2 stars, really.  It is a beautiful piece of land, and the grounds are very well maintained.  The entrance fees are affordable, and though it was raining and many of the exhibits were closed, there was plenty to see and we enjoyed ourselves.  I'm sure this is a gem if you live in the city and don't get to see enough nature.  It seems like the animals are well enough kept, not as depressing as other zoos, but certainly not the best.  I've only been to the San Diego Zoo & Wild Animal Park, which is ginormous, so everything seems small in comparison.  I understand these animals couldn't survive in the wild due to injury, or other reasons, but I felt sad for them.  None of the animals have much space, and most of them seemed lonely.  Overall, I had a good time and it is a nice Zoo, but I might not be the right audience.
author: Alexandra H.

description: I am not an anti-zoo person by any means. But I just read an article about your polar bears 35th birthday celebration.  You gave it snow, and ice. That's great but the poor thing has lived in Mediterranean like temperature.most of its life and loves to roll around in its own pool of urine. I have visited the zoo for 19 years since the age of 10 and I can't believe how blind I have been to the conditions these animals are kept in. I hope you are able to treat them better and if they are brought in under "rescue situations" to be able to release them back into the wild if possible. Like the marine mammal center just north of you.
author: Allan F.

description: I enjoyed the time we spent there. It's not somewhere I would go all the time, but I would go every few years sure. There are a good amount of animal exhibits and most of the time they are out playing. Other zoos I've been to the animals are completely hidden or put away most the day, but we saw every animal and they were easy to see!
author: Alyssa L.

description:
Today was my 1st time at the zoo and we hit the jackpot!  

The unusually warm and sunny day had just about all the animals out and about:  tigers, lions, snow leopard, gorillas (and even the mama gorilla came out holding a very little baby - possibly the one born in July 6 months ago?), hippo, rhino, etc.  

We got there around 10:30am, had lunch there (the $10 cooked-on-the-spot noodle dish was good) and finished around 1:30pm.  Saw everything except the Children's Zoo.

Though it was Saturday, the zoo wasn't crowded (the parking lot was pretty full,however.  Tip:  park at the beach and save $8/$10).  Could either be the warm winter day (Jan. 4th) or the $14/$17 entrance fee for adults...

4 stars given for nice layout (ample space to walk around, stroll, hang out, etc.), cleanliness and selection.  Pretty good for a small zoo.  1 star deducted for the price.
author: Roni K.

description:
I love the old growth trees in this zoo.  It's a pretty big park, but sometimes you don't get to see certain animals though.  We paid $4 per person (but free for toddlers & babies) and rode the train which took 5-10 minutes.  I don't know if it's worth the money, but it was enjoyable for our son. 

On the other hand, I was very disappointed in buying their cafe food. The Orange Glazed Chicken with Rice was horrible! I mean, parts of the rice was hard (which means, it could be old or they don't know how to cook it), and the chicken was hard to chew (which I am pretty sure it's defrosted from a frozen bag).  

My husband had gotten the Cheeseburger and fries and the burger was pretty bad too. We just couldn't believe we paid $26 for crappy cafeteria food. I really didn't want to visit my childhood memories of eating free lunch at school, but it did.  Never again, will I eat here and I suggest bringing your own food or eating before you come.
author: Moua L.

description:
Lack of funding has provided woes to this establishment from a general maintenance and staffing perspective, and it shows.

However, this place is actually great for animal lovers and kids alike.  There is a lot of potential considering how large the grounds are and quite a bit to explore if you're willing to walk the distance.

The animals typically look depressed and unhappy which leads me to believe the primary caretakers either are not doing a good job or these animals have just been in captivity for too long.  Sadly, I find this is the case in most of the zoos I've frequented across the country, with the only notable exception being the Wildlife Animal Park in San Diego.

My personal favorite part of this zoo is getting up close and personal with the giraffes which were housed in a small indoor ranch where you can actually get a chance to feed them.
author: Tony L.

description:
Someone told me it's all happening at the zoo...

Simon and Garfunkel anyone? I always think of their song...not sure why since that was WAY before my time...but I digress (I seem to do this often here!)...

I enjoy the Zoo - mostly seeing the giraffes in their beautiful open space (and their amazingly long tongues when they eat!), the hippo snoozing in his pond, and the penguins motoring about in their little kingdom.

They also have quite the petting zoo, if you're into that sort of thing! 

Food is pricey and doesn't offer much in the way of 'gourmet' - I would pack a lunch and sit out by the happy penguins, or otters for a nice picnic - they really are entertaining.

Great place for a family outing!
author: Christy L.

description:
My favorite part of this zoo is the grizzly bear area. The habitat is lovely and the bears seem to enjoy it and are often frolicking all over the place. I also love how they put food out at 11 AM for the bears and put some of it near the windows so you can see the bears up close. 

The rest of the zoo is also nice!
author: Lisa K.

description:
This is a review of the ZooLights, which cost $8 a person + $5 for parking.

Girlfriend and I arrived right at 5pm, a little before it got dark. Even then we noticed that there were MANY lights that were not turned on. We were hoping that all would be lit when it got dark, but NOPE! At least 50% of the lights were not on. I'm talking tree lights, decorations, and lights along the railings to help you see. There were entire stretches where we basically walked in darkness, not really knowing where to go (the signage was sparse as well). 

The only reason I didn't demand a refund was because we watched the tap dance and magic shows, as well as the giraffe feeding (which we almost missed because, surprise, it was very poorly lit and there were no signs). The events were passable, but the tent, sound system, and seating were cheap (rickety benches and lots of feedback/volume issues). The ONLY redeeming grace for the night were the giraffes, who were amazing up close, but guess what, we came to see the zoo LIGHTS! If we wanted to see giraffes, we would come during the day.

I understand that things get screwed up with the bad weather, but if half your lights are out, the reputable thing to do is to cancel the show and offer a refund, not sucker people in to see a half functioning show. A waste of time and money.
author: Tim L.

description: I have been a member of the Zoo for many years, and usually end up going at least 2-3 times a year, especially with friends who have kids (join at least at the family level if you anticipate bringing guests). The zoo is not in the same class as San Diego, but is still very nice, and the animals seem well cared for. Over the years, the zoo seems to have reduced the number of exhibits/animals, so that the remaining animals have better environments. The old-fashioned carousel is a delight, and does feature animals which go up and down.
author: Jethro B.

description: As a SF Bay Area Native (born/raised in the area for most my life) I visited this zoo a lot, especially for school field trips. It was always a nice zoo with a lot to see. The weather is also a perk because inland it can get hot but if you come to the zoo the nice bay breeze cools everything down so it is like being in a nice air conditioned building but outdoors! The city climate is neat and to see a zoo within a big city is a cool experience. Animals are sometimes out and the exhibits are in good shape. This zoo for a coastal zoo blows Seattle's out of the water.
author: Autumn L.

description:
PROS:
-FREE street parking as long as you are willing to walk about a block or so (saves you $8 on weekdays and $10 on weekends!)
-they are on the reciprocal list so you can get 50% off admission if you are members at any other zoo/aquarium
-many of the animal habits have been renovated so they aren't as sad (the last time I went was in 2010)
-they have a steam engine train and a carousel (also a con...see below)
-they allow you to bring in your own food 
-all flat (no steep hills)
-enjoyed the staff that I talked to today...everyone was courteous and friendly
-zoo is not super big so it's not overwhelming
-numerous animal feedings throughout the day

CONS:
-full price admission can be steep 
-steam engine and carousel costs extra ($4 per person for the train and $2 per person for the carousel)
-bathrooms are pretty funky
-across from Ocean Beach so it can get really cold (translation: wear/bring layers even if the sun is out)

They have Boo at the Zoo the last two weekends in October. They have candy tables throughout the zoo (around 5-6 stations) so the kids can get treats as they are seeing the animals. We went today and brought out three year old daughter in her costume. It was a lot of fun to see a variety of animals and go trick or treating!
author: Connie W.

description: South America and bear country are not too great. Not that many animals in those areas. Africa, cat kingdom are the best. Especially the lion house!! Cost is $17/adult. Not too bad but I understand the high cost of animal maintenance. The giraffes are awesome. Wilson the hippo was fed bok Choy. Lol.  Park on Sloat. Don't pay the $8 parking fee.
author: Ben L.

description:
Zoos are depressing because all you do is look at caged animals that have been taken out of their natural climates & habitats. However, this one was more depressing than others because it seemed all the animals are about to die. The polar bears had moss all over them, the ostriches are discoloured, the parrots' feathers are dried out, and the peacocks' feathers were falling out. 

My family and I came because we had free tickets. Parking is $10 per car, but there is plenty of free parking along Sloat Blvd. Park there and walk about 4 blocks.
author: Leslie P.

description:
I have to give 4 stars just for the animals. Although when I pass some animals I feel truly sad as they do not look happy at all (such as the polar bear, it is just too hot). 

But all in all it is beautiful zoo near the ocean. 

I am just deducting a star because even with the membership they charge you for parking which is 10$ and everything in the zoo is just way overpriced (drinks and food). I know it is a zoo but in comparison to Oakland zoo it is very expensive. 

I love that there are many volunteers stationed in most of the points and giving your fun facts and information about the animals. Really bless their heart!
author: Eri H.

description:
I heard that sometimes people get eaten here.  Don't know if it's true or not but kind of makes me question myself.  I mean, next time I'm feeding the tigers my leftovers I should be more careful about not leaning too far in.  Love the penguins though.

But hey, cafe: $6 for a short-ass cup of coffee is pretty lame.  You could at least throw in some cream and sugar or a free ride on the shuttle to the Polar Bear Express for that much.  WhoomP! There it be.
author: Matilda S.

description: Fantastic place for all. Lots of great exhibits, good places to sit for more seasoned members of the family. Sure there's places that need to be remodeled, but on the whole it's great! The newer exhibits are really innovative and place the animals in a more natural environment.  Slowly the zoo is replacing the older exhibits with newer ones, but that takes time and money. I've been coming here since I was a kid and now I bring my own children! Membership price is worth it if you visit 2-3 times a year.
author: Kelly R.

description:
Avoid going here on a windy, cold day. Being next to the ocean, it does get windy here, so windy you will have sand in your mouth!

Overall, this is not huge like Bronx zoo and they have selectively few animals. Went once and that's kind of enough for me.
author: Sunny E.

description: First time here today..had a lot of fun with my son..the place was a lot bigger then most zoo I've been too the only down fall was that they didn't have much animals..love the kids playground here..it's nice and big and perfect for ur lil ones to run around freely..will definitely come back again..
author: Linda L.

description:
I came here on a free day when there were lots of groups of kids on field trips but it still didn't feel crowded. The zoo is also very clean unless you're in a food service area. Even then, there was someone actively working to clean up. It's just hard to keep completely clean because it's so windy here so everything gets blown around. Also, people tend to be slobs and they don't clean up after themselves. 

Before my most recent visit, I hadn't come here in close to 5 years and it has really improved. The exhibits look much nicer now and the animals look healthy and well cared for. Many of the animals, for example the two sea otters, owls, and a few more that I can't remember, are actually permanently disabled. It's nice that the zoo provides them with a safe home and food when they would likely die in the wild. 

The exhibits are done in a way that makes it easy for you to spot the animals, while still giving the animals lots of space to roam around. It doesn't look like a sad animal prison. It's not too crowded at the exhibits even though I went on a free day. The zoo is pretty spacious and you'll be walking a lot. My body definitely felt tired after all the walking I did

I also liked looking for all the peacocks that roam around freely. They'd show up in the most random exhibits, like in the kangaroo area. Instead of Where's Waldo, play Where's the Peacock? 

TIPS:
-Eat beforehand because the food here is expensive and it is not worth the high price. 
-Wear comfortable shoes that you won't freak out over if they get a little dirty. 
-Dress in layers. It can get very cold here because you get the cold drafts coming off from the ocean. However, it got pretty toasty when I was walking around. 
-Wear gloves. They'll keep your hands warm and you won't have to worry about touching some invisible sticky thing that some kid left behind. Seriously, why are kids so sticky?! 
-Park on the street. Street parking is plentiful and you don't really need to pay for zoo parking. 
-Pack lightly so you don't have to lug around a heavy bag.
author: Nancy C.

description: It's an awesome zoo, exotic animals and cool spots throughout the zoo. They have zebras, Tigers, lions, rhinos, ant eaters, grizzly bears, polar bears, seals, monkeys, hippos, koalas, kangaroos, and much more oh and giraffes. Average price on tickets, good food to eat too, but pricy.
author: Juan C.

description: Came here for a work event the other day and it has definitely changed since I came in middle school. Structures are still the same, but they seem to have improved the children's structure (or so that I could remember). I was disappointed to not be able to feed the giraffes since I came to the event just so I can do so but it exceeded 100 people limit :/. We then managed to walk around for about 45 minutes before he zoo closed at 5pm. Discovered that the sea lions were gone :( I wonder what happened.. But my favorite part was being able to see that the peacocks still freely roam around the park. Probably won't be back unless it is a free event or for my kids one day haha. Definitely somewhere you should go for the day at least once in your life.
author: Amanda C.

description:
This was my first time at the San Francisco Zoo and I've lived in the bay area all my life. We are members of the Oakland Zoo, but wanted to try something different. Although I really like the Oakland Zoo, I really enjoyed this zoo, as well. The SF Zoo is larger and flatter with more of a variety of animals. It's also located near the ocean and is a lot colder (in the summer, at least) and foggier/cloudier (which is great for photography because there isn't all that harsh, midday sunlight).

The landscaping of the zoo was just beautiful. There was a nice garden there with lots of flowers and a large fountain. The exhibits were large (in my opinion) and well taken care of. There's definitely plenty to see and do there. There are also a number of peacocks and peahens roaming the zoo, which are beautiful, but quite noisy at times.

My favorite exhibits were the tiger and lions exhibit, the red panda exhibit (so cute!), the penguins, and the river otters. I really like their tiger and lions exhibit more than Oakland Zoo's. You can see the big cats a lot better and they seemed really active toward later in the day toward closing (they were all sleeping around noon when we got there, which is to be expected). The red panda was adorable and very playful. The penguins were also cute, as were the otters. I would have loved to have seen the snow leopard up close, but he was sleeping in the corner most of the day. The majority of the animals are active in the early morning and later in the day, so don't be surprised if most of them are sleeping around midday.

My main disappointments were that many of the smaller birds and mammals were difficult to see because of the fencing of the cages they were in. The bird area with the parrots and green jays was particularly disappointing because of the small wiring of the enclosures. It definitely is a hindrance to any sort of photography you want to do (no matter how nice your equipment), let alone just standing there and admiring them. It was also a bummer that their keel-billed toucan (one of my favorite birds) was behind really thick, kind of dirty glass in the Lion House and was very hard to see. I'm hoping they find a better location for him where he's more easily viewable (like the new South American Rainforest exhibit when it opens... it was sadly closed for renovations when we went). He seemed really out of place at the Lion House.

They did have some macaws on display out in the open (like the Oakland Zoo), but you couldn't really get a good look at them because of the small fence and train tracks that you aren't supposed to cross (there was a sign forbidding it). I thought it was a little weird having them only viewable if you took the train and that nobody else could really enjoy them like at the Oakland Zoo where they are up close and personal.

Despite those drawbacks, though, I'd definitely come back here.  You also get 50% off if you have a membership to a zoo that is in the zoo reciprocity program (like the Oakland Zoo). The big cat exhibit and red panda exhibit alone were worth it for me. I had an awesome day and would definitely make the trek back here later in the summer.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
It never seems to be too crowded here even when the parking lot is packed.  However, It can add up very quickly.~If you park in the front lot it's $10 and then another $15 for adult admission.
 I have to admit, I love the grounds surrounding the exhibits...maybe even more than the exhibits themselves. It must be the sea side air that make the plantings thrive the way they do.
author: Jill N.

description:
I like the Zoo. It always saddens me to see the obviously smart primates and big cats put into small concrete boxes, but I do enjoy the rest of the animals. It's a big enough place so that I haven't felt super crowded there. 
Food is expensive, eat first.
Tickets and parking is expensive, so plan to stay the whole day. If you are a huge Zoo fan, the Family membership pays for itself in about 2 visits, so that might be a good option for you.
author: Julie B.

description:
I absolutely loved this zoo. I went right at opening on a Saturday morning. It wasn't too busy so that was very nice. 

What I really liked was how integrated all the exhibits felt. Especially the lemur area, it felt like I was really in their habitat. All the exhibits were spacious and clean, and the animals looked perfectly content. 

The prices weren't too bad for a zoo, so I had no complaint there. Having to pay for parking was a little strange to me, since it's a private parking lot, but experiencing the zoo was worth it. Definitely recommended.
author: Aimee Y.

description:
This Zoo is an absolute blast! From the layout to the variety of animals to the beer and snacks (churros, woot!). I had a great time and was impressed at how big it was given the space.

Ok so I know a lot of people talk about how Zoos are terrible because they have animals trapped in cages.  While yes, that is literally the case - think about it like this: many of these animals are almost extinct and it is important to educate people so that they appreciate and have awareness of these disappearing species.  Also, a lot of these animals were either wounded or unable to survive on their own in the wild - they are getting a second chance at life while helping out their species by educating others.

The only downside is that it's always nice to go to the Zoo when it's nice out - but the large majority of these animals are only active when it's not that warm out.  My advice, get there early, grab a coffee, then a beer - then wander through the path - it makes a nice winding path from start to finish so you can see everything.

Total time it took me and my friend to walk through the entire Zoo and see everything? 4 and a half hours.  Be sure to check out the Emperor Tamarin - those little guys are amazing.
author: Lauren B.

description:
Having been to quite a few zoos, including the San Diego zoo, I didn't have extraordinarily high expectations for this one, especially based on the other Yelp reviews.  

But I was pleasantly surprised.  

I went with my toddler, who had no problem seeing and pointing out the animals.  Most were out and about, even playing around.  

It didn't seem depressing or rundown to me; in fact, the landscaping was nice and the animals seemed to have nice habitats.  

Listen, it's not the San Diego Zoo but, on the bright side, you also don't have to walk 11.5 miles to see all of the exhibits.  

It's perfectly sized to take your family for a nice afternoon of animal watching.
author: Monica C.

description: It's always nice to visit once and a while to see what's new here. If you grew up in the SFUSD then you've probably been here at least once. You might be able to see everything in half a day if you got in early enough.
author: Christopher S.

description:
A great family oriented site to see all kinds of animals and attractions. Although it's not as big and as popular as the San Diego zoo, it's still a local site worth visiting. Check out the lemurs, the rhinos and the giraffes exhibits. 

Located across from ocean beach the San Francisco zoo has been a landmark in San Francisco for dozens of years. Unfortunately, being so close to the water the weather is always hit or miss. Most of the time its chili and cloudy so you'll need to cuddle up for the cold weather. Admissions is pretty pricey but you learn that the majority of the funds are used to maintain and upkeep the zoo and it's animals.

The highlight of my visit was getting to see and interact with the baby giraffe. We were able to see him become acclimated to his new surroundings as well as understanding why his parents were so aggressive when people got around him. My wife and I were also able to feed the female giraffes as part of a special program where we were allowed to have a private visit at the giraffe barn. It was so cool and definitely a fun and worthwhile experience. 

The best time to visit the zoo is in the morning before the crazy rush of people start to show up in the afternoon. You're able to move freely through the park with ease and see all the animals before they get scared from the hoards of people staring at them. When you need something to eat I suggest you goby other Terrace cafe. They have huge portion sizes and really decent food, even for a zoo. I personally liked the dip & dot ice cream, it was so delicious and refreshing.

it was after that the fog started to roll in as our indicator to start heading out and go back home. Let me add that it's another reason to attend the zoo early. Because once the fog comes in, it's a cold and almost unenjoyable time. But don't let that scare you, I had tons of fun and so will you. It's not a huge site but it's big enough for a family to enjoy themselves. Figure out when special events are going on to increase you're overall satisfaction at the zoo. 

I enjoyed myself and I'm sure you will too. Until next time SF zoo!!
author: Donald W.

description:
I visited the SF zoo many years ago when I first moved to California.  I don't remember much, except that I was singularly unimpressed.  I came from Columbus, home of Jack Hanna... so we had a pretty good zoo as my only point of reference.

Fast forward 15 years, and we decide on a Saturday impromptu trip to the SF zoo.  My expectations were not high.

First clue that we might have fun: the prominent white board by the front gate which indicates the times for various feedings.  Penguin feedings!  Hooray.  Also, it indicated that the hippo exhibition would be closed early.  Really useful information for hippo lovers.  So we headed there first and avoided disappointment.  Information is good.  (Tip: Take a photo of the white board with your camera phone to reference it later)

We really enjoyed this zoo!  It was easy to get around.  The animals were easy to view, and they had all our favorites.  Giraffes, polar bears, penguins, hippos, rhinos.  The petting zoo was closed when we got there, but I'm sure we would have enjoyed it as well.  

I don't know if my memory is faulty, if I was crabby that day on my first visit, or if this zoo has improved greatly in the last 15 years.  But we loved it and will visit again.  The only reason I don't give it five stars is because the San Diego Zoo exists and has set a crazy high bar.  But I highly recommend a visit to the SF Zoo.  Especially if you haven't been in awhile.  

Bonus:  After the zoo closes at 4pm, you are within easy proximity to the beach, and to excellent creme brulee at The Bistro at Cliff House.  A lovely completion to your day.
author: Linda M.

description:
Today was my first visit to a zoo. I must say I had something different in mind. Perhaps I just had the bad luck of visiting on a day/time when most of the animals were feeling sluggish. Surprisingly though it wasn't the empty exhibits, neglected & dying vegetation, peacock running outside its display, or hordes of children that left me with a bad impression but rather the humans at the Terrace Cafe. 

My appetite got the better of me so I settled with the garlic fries and equally overpriced $5 half-ass-filled cup of soda. Indisputably, I would have preferred whatever the gorillas were being fed over the order that I got, which came in a completely dripping tray. A third of the fries, which looked like they were thrown into the tray with the vaguest efforts, had already made contact with the grossly wet surface... Seriously??!! I'm pretty sure a penguin could have done better without trying.
author: Elle N.

description: Such a great Zoo! I loved everything about it. Great for kids and even as an adult I had a ton of fun. Stop by the beautiful beach right after to top off your trip!
author: Sothary C.

description:
Price is $15 to get into the zoo.  Be sure to dress in layers, because it is located so close to the ocean.  This is a pretty large zoo for the Bay Area.  Probably the largest?  What sucks, is now they have the viewing areas even further away now, due to the tiger mauling.  But what I thought was super cool about this zoo was how old some of the animals were.  Grey seal, 41 years old; polar bear, 31 years old.  Super cool!  Also a lot of the animals taken in here, were injured and needed a place to live.  Luckily the SF zoo took them in.

I had a really good time here.  Just wish admission was cheaper and that you could get closer to the viewing area.  Other than that, it is a nice zoo.
author: Michelle M.

description:
This zoo is far inferior to the Oakland Zoo across the bay. I went today with my wife and kid and we seen mostly vegetation and a few animals. One café was open out of 2 or 3, most of the exhibits were closed to boot.. I went on a Tuesday so obviously they weren't fully staffed but it's a joke to charge people the prices they do with far less of an experience than you would get on a weekend. Just my 02.. I don't think I'll ever take him back there. I'd rather travel the hour to get to the Oakland Zoo.

On another note, One of the Polar Bears looked to be pretty old and sick. To the point where I noticed something is wrong with him, I don't see how they can have an animal in this condition on display and not getting the help it looks like it needed.
author: David S.

description: I'm so happy that I came to the SF ZOO! The weather sucked but I still had a blast! The best part about the zoo was the petting zoo where you get to pet the horses, goats, alpacas and donkeys!! The Lion House was fun and exciting too! We got to see the trainers feed the lions and tigers! They sound funny when they roar. As for the food, it was a bit pricey but I still liked it. I got garlic fries and dippin dots. I really love all the animals though! I would love to come back, or maybe I should go to the Oakland Zoo?
author: Tiffany T.

description: Great location and lovely selection of animals. My kid enjoyed it very much. It's small but big enough for a toddler. The petting zoo was also much better than the ones in Happy Hallow in San Jose.  The train ride is over priced but I guess it's standard for SF.
author: J G.

description: Even though I'm 22, I'm a little kid at heart and I love going to the zoo! $14 for sf resident tickets is not bad at all for a whole day of fun. This place is huge and there's so much to see. The huge lemurs exhibit in the beginning is amazing and there's so many different kinds, I never even knew. I like how the zoo is divided based on the geographical location of each animal so you see how they would look like together in the wild, well sort of haha. Just took off one star because both times I've been there, the big cats exhibit has been closed so I haven't been able to see the tigers or lions. Just hoping next time it'll be open.
author: Malika R.

description: It's good, but i imagined more.. i went in a rainy day, almost half of the animals didn't come up because of the weather, the place is nice but they have to put more different animals.
author: Gehad S.

description:
WARNING - We had our rental car broken into in the parking lot.  We learned to late that rental cars are targeted in this parking lot.  Thieves have easy access into and out of this parking lot.

Other than that the zoo was nice.
author: Peter J.

description: Went recently with my husband on our 6 year anniversary  (left kids at home) and had a blast! Got there right after they opened, no problem parking. Parking on weekends is $12. Not overly crowded like we expected, probably because it was early, seemed to get busier once we started leaving. All animals were out and active. Big zoo. Plenty of food and drink stations. We are now planning to go back with the kids.
author: Shannon S.

description:
This zoo is the best zoo by the Pacific Ocean. Ha.

Seriously though - I was impressed and liked how quiet and sorta empty it was on the day we went. (Saturday!) 

The foliage was nice and the animals seemed happy enough to me. Most of them are "rescued" so there is that to keep in mind... 

Overall well worth the price for all the active animals you get to see. We spent so much time by the lemurs - watching them jump around. Such a delight.

It was just me and my husband (no kids) and we had a great time. You can tell they put a lot of thought into utilizing the space as a way to speed awareness about certain environmental and animal issues... Which is good overall I think. It does get to be a bit of a downer if you read too many placards but hey that's the way it is some times.
author: Barbra I.

description:
Just for comparison-

SF Zoo animals not found at the Oakland Zoo; perhaps more monkeys including gorillas and mandrills. Also grizzly bear, polar bear and more of the large birds like; pelicans, eagles, peacocks, penguins, ostrich, toucan and cassowary. Also alpaca, horse, hippo, rhino, sea lion, anteater, koala, kudu, duiker, capybara, snow leopard, kangaroo, bobcat, red panda, bongo, komodo dragon and a larger insect zoo.

Oakland Zoo animals not found at the SF Zoo; elephants, baboons, Malaysian sun bear, camels, alligators, bats, giant tortoises, warthogs, hyenas, condor (camera only), giant vultures, (and maybe more of the smaller colorful birds like finches and warblers ect...), bison, large monitor lizard, three kinds of wild deer (seka deer and muntjacs) even domestic house cats. In 2015-2016 they will also be adding mountain lion, grizzly bear, black bear, beaver, eagle, grey wolf and jaguar.

Both Zoo's- then there are a whole bunch of animals they both feature, tigers, lions, chimps, flamingos, wallaby, lemur, giraffe, otter, large snakes and so on. 

Oakland has a sky flyer to get a good perspective of the whole zoo. It's sunnier and maybe more spacious for the animals. 

SF has better food. I will also say the security staff at the SF zoo are jerks. Once the SF zoo closes the guys riding bikes rudely tell you to get out. In Oakland, I've never received anything but nice treatment, they don't rush you out of there the very second the place closes as long as the customers are mostly leaving the staff is more than happy to let you stay a little longer. 

Prices are about the same.
author: Paul H.

description: We love taking our kids to the zoo it's a great way to spend the afternoon. The San Fran zoo has nice enclosures and the zoo isn't to big. Some zoo's like San Diego or LA are so big your exhausted by the time you get out of there.
author: Gretchen G.

description:
I wish the animals looked a lot happier and that the squirrels werent eating the monkey's food.

Though, its good place to kill some time!
author: Shel N.

description: I had a great time here besides the fact that some man tried to steal my purse and I couldn't find parking and had to walk 11 blocks with a little one just to get to the zoo. All in all good on price and selection of animals. Food is pretty expensive so I suggest bringing something and saving your money. It was amazing to see such different types of animals in one place. This zoo puts the Sacramento and Oakland zoo to shame. I would recommend stopping across the street to  see the ocean. The kids will love dipping their feeters in the ocean and playing in the sand. Might be lots cheaper than the zoo.
author: Jess C.

description: What is this, a county zoo? Nobody is working too hard at the San Francisco Zoo. We took our son to the zoo for the first time and it was also our first time so we were really looking forward to it. Sadly, we were very disappointed. Most of the exhibits were very poorly showcased. The glass to every single exhibit was so dirty that you could hardly see the animals. It looked like it hadn't been cleaned in months. Most of the animals looked malnourished and unhappy. It was an incredibly depressing experience. If I didn't know any better I would think the zoo had been abandoned for months with the poor animals left to fend for themselves. I think the $20 admission to this zoo is absolutely ridiculous for what you get to see. We are from Chicago and the Lincoln Park Zoo is free and miles above this place.
author: Amanda H.

description:
Facility is really good but undergoing some renovations. 

They had a new giraffe baby which was amazing to see, but there were a few disappointments. The ape area had closed viewing areas. All of this areas were through glass only (which had vandalism or really dirty). The Tigers and Lions were sleeping and docile so notice to see there. They were also prepping for an event on Friday, so most of their usual things were not available. Very little in terms of communications on this closure as well. 

Parking is an exit tax of $7.00. Add that to an adult admission of $17 made this a pretty expensive zoo. 

Overall happy with the experience.
author: Jason B.

description:
We went with my friend's children and I was impressed, but in the bad way..
I mean it wasn't at all what I was expecting from the zoo.
It would've been much better if we would've gone to San Diego Zoo. Meh. 

It can sound strange, but there are up and downsides all over, so your attitude towards that place wouldn't be clear enough.. 
You can see a crowd of flamingos - you'll enjoy it, penguins - oh yeah, monkeys, gorillas - for sure, but when a poor rhino will be in your sight - you'll start feverishly coming up with the reason WHY DID THEY CUT HIS HORN, MAMA? DID HE DO SMTH WRONG? I wanted to look into eyes of that ******* who did that. 

Most of the animals were sleeping or so disappointed with their life in cages, that you don't have any feelings except pity. 

Why do snow leopards fight? Why does tiger look at people that it seems that he wants to kill them right now, but there is damn cage? Why animals are soooo frustrated? And you have nothing to answer with..
author: Olga B.

description:
I must say that I LOVE the zoo! Even though it is a little depressing because some of the animals look so sad, I could spend  hours upon hours sitting and observing. We went on a Sunday and while there were a lot of people there, there was plenty of room to walk around and very little wait time if at all to get right up in front to see the animals. It was the first time to the zoo for my six-year-old and he had a blast. We even got to witness a bunch of seagulls steal a whole hotdog off of a person's tray which is not something you get to see everyday. 

The zoo is clean and there are ton's of places to sit if you get tired or just want to watch the animals. Food is pretty pricey though and not bad but nothing to brag about either. I paid for valet parking because the twenty bucks is totally worth being able to get out right at the entrance and not having to hunt for parking. We actually got there at 12 and stayed till closing but could have stayed even longer. This definitely won't be the last time I go, I only wished I lived closer so I could go more often!
author: Christina I.

description:
I honestly wouldn't believe I'd be criticizing a zoo, but in the case of the San Francisco Zoo, it sort of needs to be done. I went on a weekday with my boyfriend and a friend and despite the fact that we were a group of three, checking out the animals and taking pictures, our experience just felt really lackluster. I don't know of it's the dreary, cold, grey weather, but the animals themselves were either sleeping, lazing about, or the exhibits were empty. Many of the food carts were empty or closed as well, despite the fact that there were plenty of people in attendance. We went to the lion house and there were no lions to be found, and in general the place had this overwhelmingly lethargic feel. 

I did, however, think the penguin exhibit was awesome; it's open air, with the penguins swimming around in a big pool similar to a large, wide fountain, and you can get extremely close to them. Very impressive. I also liked how there were peacocks just roaming around the grounds, and how they often passed close enough to touch (though I wouldn't recommend trying it haha) and made their way into some of the other animals' exhibits.

After having been to the Oakland Zoo as well, my experience there made my trip to the San Francisco Zoo pale in comparison even more. There are more animals at the Oakland Zoo, the grounds are better maintained, the animals honestly seem happier, and it's just a much better experience for the money. Make sure you dress in layers here, because it gets cold, the fog is thick, and it often ends up misting during your excursion.
author: Angela M.

description:
Boo for the Zoo.
The setup is confusing and you will have to pass the same exihibits several times. They put this zoo in the coldest, foggist part of the city which is ridiculous.
Lots of empty areas where it looks like animals used to be and No Hippos, which are my favorite.
author: Adrienne G.

description: Love this spot! So cool being next to the beach. From the African area to the lions to indoor bug display -- this place rocks! Prices are good and kids love the train ride. Love the kids farm and the best is the new playground they put in! It's incredible!
author: Jay G.

description:
The zoo is nice but the price of ANY food is enough to make you choke on it. 
$5 per chocolate milk, $5 per slice of pizza. I have 4 boys & didnt wanna pay $20 for 4 slices of pizza so we decided to opt out of getting any food, so I got up to the register with my 2 chocolate milks for my boys & the cashier said, "$9.95." I stood & looked at him like there was a mistake. There wasn't. I then simply said, "sorry, I can't pay $10 for chocolate milk, I won't". 
Even if I was very wealthy or, say, had $50k in my bank account I wouldn't pay $10 for chocolate milk. It was insulting to be asked to. 
You go in expecting things will be higher, but that was grossly overpriced & in my opinion, highway robbery. 

That's my gripe, not family friendly.
author: Teralyn B.

description:
My wife and I have a family membership to the SF zoo. The zoo is a really good size and has a lot of diversity. There's a petting zoo, koala's, bears, a steam train, rhino's and more! 

Parking is pretty expensive though and they don't have elephants.
author: Yoni D.

description: We went during the week and early so it wasn't too packed. The best part was watching the grizzly bears feed. There was definitely a lot to see.  At $17 a ticket, it's well worth a trip to the City.
author: Jessica S.

description:
EVERY FIRST WEDNESDAY IS A FREE DAY. Only for SF residents with proof of residence -_-

There's not much animals if you go after noon. AND you should definitely go before the whale goes away. The whale only stays until September something.. See it while its still here but not on free days! They close that. -_- SUPER DISAPPOINTED WHEN I WENT YESTERDAY AND IT WAS CLOSED.

Overall the zoo was cool. The only downside was that there was barely any animals after 12.
author: Vernice T.

description: My family and I had a great time here. There are plenty of animals to see from giraffes, to gorillas, to lions, a hippopotamus, penguins and much much more. The animals all seemed to have nice, clean living conditions too for those of you who might be concerned. The park was clean and the staff was very friendly. They have a great miniature train inside the park for kids to ride on, along with adults. You can also bring in bottled waters along with some snacks for the kids to help save a few bucks. That was a good idea being that their food prices are about the same as your average amusement park. All in all we had a great time and will definitely be returning in the future.
author: Chris S.

description:
I haven't been here since elementary school and it is just like how I remembered it. Nothing much has changed.

The giraffes have a nice setting unlike the others animals which is sad. For instance, the polar bear's setting was all grass. I thought they would add some water and cement to the cage, but it was just grass. Even the polar bear's face was green! I like that this zoo has a lot of space to walk around. There are different cafes in the area and the bathrooms are clean, but some of the stalls in the bathroom that is right next to the giraffes were broken. I had to go through like 5 different stalls to get one that locks. There is a park inside the zoo for the little ones. Even though there weren't many animals out or even walking around, I still had a good time. I actually had a funner time here than Monterey Bay Aquarium. 

The day that I went, the weather was cold and cloudy so I think that made the animals do nothing and hide the whole time. I think it is best to go when there is sun and its warm. Parking is 10.00 if you park in their parking lot. Their other parking lot is free and it's on the other side of the zoo which means more walking to the ticket booth.
author: Jessica C.

description:
Didn't think I'd have a good time here because zoos usually make me feel sad but the animals here seem well cared for and happy. So much better than the Oakland zoo. 

Check out the penguins. So cute!   Then take a walk on Ocean Beach. Great way to spend the afternoon.
author: Victoria W.

description:
Went with our now adult children.  Went all the time when they were little.  There have been a lot of improvements at the zoo:  the African savannah, new playground and new/newly landscaped walkways to name a few.  Much of the zoo remains outdated:  the Zoo Terrace Cafe, the bear and sea lion grottos, and the lion enclosures.

Overall, it was a nice outing.  The sun was shining and it was actually quite warm.  The lions, rhinos and tiger were pretty active, which was fun.  

The zoo has a lot of potential.  Probably all of its "problems" could be fixed with more $$$.
author: mary f.

description: I was pretty disappointed with the zoo. They've been promoting a new exhibit with sloths (one of my favorite animals) so my fiance and i decided to check it out. They had closed one of the main walkways around the zoo so it was difficult to get from section to section. The sloth exhibit it turns out is only open a few hours a day so we went straight there. Looked for almost an hour and couldn't find anything until a zookeeper told us they put them in a different unlabeled enclosure and that they don't like people so we probably won't see them. BUMMER. They also had closed the sea lions and polar bear enclosures. Pretty upset no one told us this upon entry. There were some great exhibits with happy playful animals like the big cats, hippos, monkeys, but overall was a bit of a let down.
author: Kate L.

description:
Our kids are a big fan of animals, and this place wins them over in a heartbeat! The giraffes, the zebras, the monkeys, the flamingos, the petting zoo....big favorites with our kids. However, our kids are in love with the playground!! The playground is AMAZING!!! Best playground I've ever seen; it caters to all kids...from babies to toddlers to older kids. Such a huge playground for all kids!! They also have a cute train that you can ride to tour the entire zoo; you need to pay for it separately with cash at the train depot. The train is a hit with the kids.

One minus: The food is expensive. Bring your own food!
author: Anne M.

description: Came here a few months ago and loved this zoo! It was really big and very clean. We loved the giraffe and zebra area the most. Also the gorillas! The playground for the kids was amazing. My 2 year old had a blast playing there. I live closer to the Oakland Zoo but I much prefer the SF Zoo. And I am a huge supporter over the fact that they don't house elephants there. We will be back again soon!
author: Amber B.

description:
This zoo may be small, but it is gorgeous! It's heavily landscaped with different trees, plants, rocks and boulders. There are plenty of benches placed around the exhibits so you can just sit and watch the animals. The pathways are in great condition and all of them flow into each other so you don't have to do any doubling back to see an animal you might have missed. The zookeepers that I met were very nice and informative, one even showed me some baby ostriches that I might have missed. 

The exhibits are amazing, very lush with plant life and enrichment items. I like how they group some animals together like they would be in the wild. For example, the zebra, giraffes, duiker and black crowned cranes were all in the African exhibit. The only way it could have been more accurate is if the exhibit was dry and unbearably hot  like the African plains. 

I also like how much room the animals have. The two polar bears have 3 different connecting exhibits. All of the big cats also change exhibits every day, which is also an enrichment factor, because there will be different scents each day. Their electronic tour plug-in bays are solar powered which is cool. The only reason I didn't rate it 5 stars is because some exhibits had informative signs, and others didn't. 

Overall I would highly recommend this zoo to anyone visiting San Francisco. It's not as big as some other zoos out there, but I think that's part of it's charm. You can walk the entire zoo in about 3 hours and your feet won't be killing you by the end of the trip. It was great.
author: Larae H.

description: If you haven't been to the zoo in a while, then this would be a great time! In the recent months, the zoo welcomed 3 new members to the family: a baby giraffe, tiger and peccary. They are all so adorable, of course! When a couple of friends and I went it was a sunny and warm day. I suggest going on a cooler day or before mid- afternoon. The animals don't enjoy the heat as much, so by mid-afternoon they'll probably be taking refuge under a shade or inside their caves. Stop and talk to a docent. The two we spoke with were extremely helpful and informative. Also, if you're a San Francisco resident, don't forget to bring a valid ID to pay $3 cheaper than the regular admission.
author: Donna L.

description: This was my first trip to the SF Zoo, and it was fun, but I wasn't super impressed. The zoo was a good size, but there weren't any animals that were out of the ordinary except maybe the snow leopard. I liked that they had a schedule of animal feedings, but wish they were more frequent and had additional feedings. Unless you have kids or REALLY love animals, I wouldn't pay the entrance fee more than once ($17 for non SF residents, $14 for SF residents). Parking is free if you can find street parking (a couple to a few blocks away).
author: Amy D.

description:
I live in Sacramento but I travel to San Francisco Zoo because I know I wont be too disappointed. First off is the parking situation. Be prepared to spend a good 20 minutes looking for free parking. I skipped all of that hassle and paid $10 to park in the Zoo's lot. It fills up quickly but I found that the later you go the better chance you will have of getting a spot in the lot.

The line to buy tickets can be really long and if you have kids with you it can be a iffy situation being that the ticket counter is across from the enticing gift and toy shop (of course). So be prepared to have your blood pressure rise a bit as kids around you start to have a major meltdown. Go in a good mood and remember that patience is a virtue. 

I love the San Francisco Zoo for its pretty landscape and plenty of shady areas. They have a wide variety of animals and i always see something new whenever I go. The zoo seems to be kept up well and I feel less distressed over animals being caged because they have more of a natural habitat. 

I must say that I always have a good time visiting this Zoo and taking in the beautiful surrounding views of the San Francisco area after wards.
author: Cici F.

description:
What is there not to love about SF Zoo?!?! 

It is a great place to spend the afternoon with the family and children. My children enjoyed themselves looking at the different animals. We all had a blast and not to mention the nice play ground along with the train ride. 

We are annual pass holders and it will pay for itself if you visit multiple times (twice within the year to breakeven) during the year.
author: Tuan T.

description: Nice zoo. Customer service was lacking but all in all a great place to take your children or grand children.
author: Annett S.

description:
It's been a good 2 decades since my last visit to the zoo.  First thing I noticed... wow, it's cold!  How can African and South American animals adapt?  But if you moved a SF native into Africa, you'd adapt too!  

Overall, the enclosures seem a bit bleak and small.  I saw none animals active.  Have they forgotten how to run and frolic?  I guess if you don't have any predators after you and you're fed regularly, you don't have to move much.  And only the monkeys, flamingos, penguins and some of the birds actually had a good bunch to play with each other.  Most others were the only of its kind, but likely some of them are solitary animals to begin with.  But put them in an enclosed area, you cant help but think they are so alone.

We were fortunate to catch the feedings of the resident tiger and pride of lions.  I tell you, the moment the trainer opened up the gate, 3 intimidating lions made a grand entrance one after the other.  I gasped, yes I did.  They are everything you want a lion to be.  Huge mane, menacing paws, and adorable.  :)  The male lion was especially funny.  He did tricks w/o being told hoping to get his feed as fast as he could.  He'd open his mouth as if he wanted his throat checked... the trainer wasn't keen on that.  

We talked to a few trainers and over the years they have changed how the zoo is run.  Back in the day, they had as many as 32 big cats.  Imagine that!  Now they have 6.  Even being raised in captivity they still have territorial instincts, so the zoo has given them more space.  It's really best for the animals... and trainers.  Yes, there have been maulings in the zoo history.  Maintaining a large amount of big cats is daunting and imagine them when they are in heat.

Overall, I'd give the SF Zoo a 3 1/2 stars.  I can tell they care for the animals.  You'll find some older, sad looking animals, but then you read that they are here because they suffered from wing damage or were already raised in captivity.  The SF Zoo is there to rehab them and provide for them.  And honestly, these type of facilities may be the only resource to preserve a species.  I saw a black rhino.... quite rare and on the critically endangered list.  A few beatification attempts and more natural habitats may help.

Bonus: The original zoo key still fits the newer informational boxes!!!
author: Chris T.

description:
If you live in the city or take public transit then you can get a discount. There are also free days. Can't remember the exact amount or details but it's easy to find online.

This isn't the biggest or greatest zoo. It's a good zoo though.
It opened in 1929 and has about 700 species which is a good number. It wasn't that busy the day we visited which I prefer, you don't want to be beating hoards of people away to ruin the experience.

The enclosures for the most part are expansive and don't seem too cramped. Lots of kid's activities as well to keep them entertained.

Sometimes you have to feel bad for these animals in captivity but you are also in awe that such creatures exist....
author: Nick L.

description:
I wouldn't say this is the be-all, end-all of zoos, but I'll give it one thing:

It.  Has.  Lemurs. 

I'd never known myself to be a lemur lover before then, but since they're one of the first animals you walk by after the entrance, they're hard to miss.  Lemurs of every color and size, leaping from tree to tree, scaling rope ladders, snuggling adorably.  I kind of want one.

Other than that, this is a nicely done attraction with lots of different animals (though most in too-small cages, and why don't the polar bears have a decent-sized pool to swim in?)  I don't think it's an absolute must, especially if you've been to terrific zoos like the ones in San Diego or Singapore, but it's a fun place to spend an hour or two.
author: Joëlle M.
