description: Definitely one of the best zoos I have been to.  Not ginormous like the San Diego Zoo (although still the best) but just the right size for families!  Everything is clean and remodeled with cool habitats for the animals.  Definitely recommended!
author: Patrick R.

description:
I was surprised to see so many low reviews, but my wife and I absolutely loved the San Francisco Zoo. 

Pros:
1. Right when we got there, a security officer was walking the parking lot and gave us a free parking pass 'just because they were doing it that day'. 
2. The entry costs were only $24 which is fairly priced for other zoos I've gone to.
3. All exhibit and walking areas were clean and well kept. The gorilla area was a first for me and I was beyond impressed. Among some of my favorite exhibits are the lions, orangutans, and kangaroos. 
4. If you go to this zoo, you should definitely try to be there for the grizzly bear feeding! I've never seen anything like it and we thought it was amazing to watch the bears snatching fish out of the water.

Cons:
1. As one would expect, the food prices there are ridiculous. If you plan on purchasing lunch there, expect to spend $10-$15 per person.
2. The weather in that part of the bay area isn't always beautiful and cooperative. On bad weather days, I could imagine the miles of open walkways would be miserable.
author: Jeremy W.

description:
Hey everybody! ..and welcome to the San Francisco Zoo!...uh-one, uh-two, uh-three...
If we could talk to the animals, hey...just imagine it 
Chattin' to a chimp in chimpanzee (...swinging the microphone)
Imagine talkin' to a tiger, chattin' to a cheetah 
What a neat achievement that would be.
Hey, hey, hey.

...Actually a Vegas opening act could have helped pick up the spirits of the animals here. The spirits of the onslaught of multi-ethnic visitors needed no enlivening this morning...it was free...FREE...FREEE! 

Real estate comes at such a premium in SF that it is no wonder that a wild animal from the third world would be drawn to a seaside piece of property with free meals and accommodations. I'm sure they were shown the time-share video that promised the glory of a California lifestyle with the European-style charm of local amenities and service. Once they put their deposits down and said farewell to the fellow members of their species, I imagine there was no looking back for these brave creatures.

That's at least my explanation for the forlorn looks I saw on the faces of the animals who managed to make an appearance this morning. Today was not only the 4th of July but the traditional free first Wednesday of the month, a double whammy to the staff there, I'm sure. The stampede of irksome parents with their double strollers merely proves that Darwin was right...we are barely one step ahead of the primates we're looking at from the other side of the railing.

I have a confession to make - I was actually on the Board of Directors for about three years, more a corporate obligation than anything else - so I know how much effort it has taken to get the zoo even to this point. But I have to admit five years after my departure, I am still rather disconcerted that the cat cages still exist. Also frustrating are the dirty tinted windows that make glare inevitable on any photo you take and  the chain-link fence which makes any reasonable photo impossible. Signs were faded or plain gone.

The biggest frustrations were the missing animals. I was looking forward to having rainbow lorikeets land on my head at Binnowee Landing where they usually fly free under an expansive net. Closed. Oh OK, let's go see the koalas. Closed. Hmmm, how about the tigers? Sleeping in the back.

Granted this is the drawback of a zoo that pursues a natural habitat environment. But nothing epitomized the sadness of the zoo more than watching a young antelope pace back and forth scraping his broken-off antler against the chain-link fence for relief. At least I thought it was an antelope since there wasn't a sign.

There were some joys to be had nonetheless - the Magellanic penguins swimming in some awfully green water, the peacocks walking about, the grizzlies at play in their new exhibit, the lemurs coming out of the tree tops. I was thinking that the lemurs and giraffes are probably the only ones who have a shot at enjoying the ocean view here. By the way, I have to take some credit for the revitalized main entrance on the Great Highway side since I voted for the final design of that (I was pushing for the big gift shop you see there today...you can never have enough zoo snow globes).

No surprise that it was super-crowded today, but I'm sure it's more manageable when the $11 general admission is paid. I still feel the zoo feels isolated out there, and parking can get full quickly. There's only one transfer from the L-line to the 23 to get here by MUNI, and they give you a dollar off for your effort if you keep your transfer. Sure, it's not the San Diego Zoo, but whose is...other than San Diego, of course?

Hey, hey, hey....if we could talk to the animals, learn their languages 
Think of all the things we could discuss 
If we could walk with the animals...talk with the animals, 
Grunt and ...squeak and ..squawk with the animals, 
And they could squeak and squawk and speak and talk to us. (...straightening the toupee)
Hey, hey, hey! (...polite applause)
...Thank you, you've been a wonderful audience!
author: Ed U.

description: I love this place! I took my seven week old son and we had a blast!  As an animal welfare advocate, I had some concerns and hesitations about visiting the zoo but after my visit, I'm so glad I went!  Educating myself on the animals there and the ways they found themselves there was a great way to spend my Friday afternoon.
author: Vanessa L.

description: Hey, I don't know why this zoo isn't more liked. They had that tiger incident but that was a while ago ( I had an annual pass when it happened , frightening). But they have since improved the enclosures for safety and for the animals enrichment. Lots of walking but I love that me and my family are getting a workout while having fun.
author: Roo P.

description:
This is a nice big zoo with plenty of room for the kids to run and lots of animals to see.

The lions, bears, monkey's, giraffes and penguins were fun. Unfortunately, the elephants apparently died of pneumonia a few years back and have not been replaced.

There is also a nice big children's zoo with animals the kids can pet.

$8 for parking is kind of ridiculous and admission can be expensive, but if you have another zoo membership you can get a discount. We didn't have our Phoenix Zoo card with us and we have let our Sacramento Zoo membership expire, but we saved money by showing our AAA card.

I would give the zoo four stars, but the food at the restaurant was not only overpriced, but also quite bad. The chips were salted to the point where you couldn't even taste the potatoes, the chicken strips were undercooked and according to my brother-in-law, the hamburger was inedible. In the future, I'd recommend packing a picnic lunch.
author: Brad H.

description: Place is alright I guess for a zoo. $15 for general admission is fair, free for SF residents on the first Wednesday of every month is very generous. To me it says they care about spreading animal wellfare awareness, being able to give local residents access to animal knowledge for free, and providing a nice outing for people. The zoo can be hit and miss sometimes, some exhibits can be closed. I always enjoy seeing the lion, giraffe, and the monkeys! Food is a lil pricy, I got a pretzel that was ridiculously salty, bet they did that to get me to buy more drinks to wash the salt taste away. The penguins are always cute. If you're lucky you can spot the male peacock spreading all its beautiful feathers with all its lovely colors.
author: Stephen C.

description:
Baby Tiger! Baby Giraffe! Oh My!

We love the zoo. My daughter and I come here at least twice a month. We have memberships, so it's nice to stop in every so often for an hour or two....and not feel obligated to stay a long time.  Before our memberships I would stay all day to get my $30 dollars worth. But for $105 I get myself, a guest and up to 10 kids in for free!....for a year! What a deal!

The zoo seems to always have something under construction, which is nice that things are getting updated, but disappointing that you can't enjoy that enclosure or area at the time of your visit.

The food and souvenirs are all overpriced, but what zoo isn't? We try to pack a lunch and avoid the gift shops. 

All the animals look cared for and in clean, safe areas. The extra strength tiger enclosures ease a little fear. The children's zoo is adorable and fun for families. The natural trail is opening soon and we can't wait to see the hedgehog :)
author: JoBeth B.

description:
My review is based on the use of the Bernard Osher Great Hall for a wedding reception that I recently had there.

It was great.  Carol the SF Zoo's catering manager made planning the event easy.  She walked us through the entire process which made it convenient. Carol was available by phone or email on the weekends and weekdays and responded to all our questions quickly.

The Great Hall was beautifully decorated.  It has high ceilings, wooden beams, and a huge fireplace.

The SF Zoo is a great place for an event.
author: Randy M.

description: I hadn't been to this zoo in many, many years.  It used to be pathetic and I felt terrible for the animals.  This time I was pleasantly surprised by the improvements that have been made.  More natural large areas where different animals can roam,  landscaping matched to original habitats, well kept exhibits, friendly staff.  I was impressed.  We enjoyed the train ride (until it rained heavily), the warm pretzels (delicious) and generally walking around the zoo for hours (with young children).  Happy to have joined and will be back.
author: Karne N.

description:
This review is for the zoo events. Here is my breakdown of the wedding we had here: 

COST: We got great value for a wedding in the city. The only way we could beat the price of holding a wedding at the zoo was to get a permit to hold an outdoor wedding at a park/beach. This was hands down the least costly place to hold a wedding at a SF landmark with full-service catering. 

LOCATION: What you give up for not being central in city you make up for having free parking. Trying paying for an event downtown and the parking bill alone will easily out-price an open bar while giving your guests a headache. The zoo offered the easiest parking in the city. The only disadvantage is that this isn't a location where taxis will quickly arrive on a weekend.

CATERING MANAGER - Trust me, this will make or break you. She was amazing flexible and helped us every step of the way. She found ways to make our event cost effective whereas other event coordinators I've worked with find ways to make the events costlier. She worked with us the entire way to help make setting up and breaking down that much easier. Also, she was diligent about working with outside vendors. 

MEAL: The food was hands down amazing. We expected that the zoo would only offer chicken nuggets and fries but they have a great chef that makes surprisingly amazing dishes. During our tasting, we were amazed by the selection and options they gave us. 

LOCATION OPTIONS: Surprisingly, you have options where you can hold events at. We went with the traditional Safari/Carousel option but were looking at holding our event at other locations. Obviously, it makes a theme for an event simple 

STAFF: We found staff extremely friendly and well organized. There was enough staff for the event to ensure that our guests didn't get lost in the zoo. I've worked with other locations where they don't provide any direction or guest services. This will cost you in hiring more assistants or having guests wander in panic as they miss out on your ceremony. 

SUMMARY: I've worked on putting together large events in the past but this was hands down one of the easiest to plan and execute. The zoo was a great value for a wedding/event in the city and it's one of the best business decisions we've made. 

PS Thanks to all the yelpers that came!
author: Dan T.

description: A really great day. Highly recomended. We came close to the end of the day on a Saturday and that was great timing
author: Halvard B.

description: We always love coming here.  My girls always have fun.  My girls love playing in the park.  We can spend hours just playing.  My only complaint is the parking.  We sometimes have to park very far to get in but can't complain to much.  Fun place to go with the kids.
author: Tamara L.

description: The new playground is amazing !! Love that there's no wood chips the plus side is it has a soft compostable ground you know cork type !!  It's really nicely spaced out ! They have a play area for toddlers and older kids area ! Plus a Iceberg type playground really cool !! I believe there doing more to the Zoo which is alway a plus !!! I forgot to mention there's a little new snack shack located in that area !
author: Melissa M.

description: I really enjoyed my visit on a Thursday afternoon. Crowds were light, exhibits and park were clean, and animals seemed happy. As a zoo lover, I've been to some great zoos (San Diego) and some terrible zoos that should be shut down, but this one rates toward the top and their animals all seem pretty happy.
author: Craig C.

description:
My husband and I had our wedding at the SF Zoo in Dec 2012 and it was wonderful. Even with torrential downpours the venue was beautiful. The carousel was also a huge hit with all the guests, young and old!
I can't even begin to explain how grateful I am for the staff. They did a wonderful job making everything look great and run smoothly (even with lots of rain and other issues)!
And, almost all of our guests commented on how great the food was.
The Zoo was the perfect place for the wedding; from venue, to food, to overall atmosphere, the night was great!
author: Katie M.

description: Love the zoo, have been bringing kids here for the past 6 yrs. the latest DJ by playgrounds is awesome!love the nature trail and the carousel
author: Zaid A.

description:
This visit to the SF Zoo was considered a "staff retreat."  Not only did I not want to be there for this so-called "staff retreat"  but I just don't support zoos.  I really feel for these animals being caged up and most of them looked either depressed or bored.

Some of the exhibits looked pretty well maintained like the giraffes and gorillas.  Others looked really sad like the one for the seal.  We later discovered that the seal has cataracts and the staff decided not to build him a new cage for fear that he would be disoriented.  Still many cages or areas looked like they could desperately use an upgrade.  

Free parking available on Sloat.  Admission is $15.
author: Jen S.

description:
Not big on zoos even though I have a kid. This one's OK I guess. Huge animals in tiny cages? Awesome! Makes me proud to be human. 

Careful about the parking scam though. Lot was full, so we parked miles away, and then sent a scout (my wife) back to get the car.  Forty-five minutes later, she pulled in just to pick us up... WRONG!!! There's a sheet of printer paper taped to the gate that explains there are no pick-ups. Too late to back up with a line of cars behind you. Pay up sucker... AND walk to your car. No leniency.
author: Matt W.

description: Being from the East coast I had visited the DC National Zoo many times growing up and with my son since he was born in 2005. Highly recommend that Zoo if you're ever there!  We've been here twice, last July, and then just yesterday. I highly recommend coming here during the day on a weekday. We are lucky that we do a charter school that's part homeschool. We pretty much had the place to ourselves. He really enjoyed it. The first time we came was on a weekend in July. Still enjoyable but A LOT busier.
author: L. M. B.

description: I bring my three kids here for his birthday.  IT is amazing to see the the Zoo constantly adding new animals.  Make sure give yourself a lot of time if you want to see everything.  It is an enjoyable trip for me and my kids.  We will be back in the future.
author: Jen J.

description:
COming here as an adult and actually remembering it, I had a blast. My boyfriend and I decided to spend our five year anniversary here. We got here sort of late and I felt like at the end I was rushing us to make it to the back before everything closed. And luckily we did. 

The animals look very well treated, however, I do wish that they had attendants walking around each exhibit to monitor the noisy crowds. I was shocked to see so many people of all ages literally yelling in a "quiet zone". One kid was so obnoxious that I gave him "the look", ergo STFU. I mean how retarded are you?? Ok, I am done venting. 

The place was clean! There was always someone doing something, never just talking or looking bored or they hated the job, because really that ruins the atmosphere. During the penguin feeding the attendant was answering questions, so he knew his stuff. I was expecting short sentences but he would go on. My favorites are the giraffes of course and we saw two sibling baby koalas. I just about melted!! Definitely come to just say you have been to the bay area zoo and support these animals!
author: Crystal V.

description: San Francisco Zoo sucks.  The animal enclosures are the size of my bedroom and it's depressing to watch them pace around in those tiny areas.  Not sure how that is regulated.  The urban crowd that goes to this zoo is more focused on taking a selfie with every animal than actually seeing how unfortunate their living areas are.  I left this zoo sad for every animal in there.  Except for the guinea pigs which oddly have an unnecessarily huge habitat to roam in.  And why the hell are there guinea pigs at the zoo anyway?
author: Alaina L.

description:
I came here with the boyfriend because I missed the zoo.

Parking was easy because we came on a weekday and I received tickets, so I dragged the boyfriend with me. When I grabbed the map of the zoo, I looked at it and thought it was smaller than I remembered. We started to walk around and saw a couple of animals but for some reason I wasn't having that much fun. The only entertaining thing was the cute polar bear who was showing off his cool moves, but that was about it.

After an hour we felt like we've seen everything and left, I was pretty disappointed and so was the boyfriend. I guess I was so small and thought the zoo was huge, I probably wouldn't come back again. But, it was nice to see the animals I remember seeing when I was a child! 

The petting zoo area was the area that brought back the most vivid memory that I have of the zoo, because I remember when I was in 2nd or 3rd grade a goat came up to me and snatched my paper name tag right off my shirt. He started to chew my name tag up and I grabbed it and played tug-a-war with the goat until I gave up and then ran away crying. Good times, good times.
author: Heather C.

description:
As a native San Franciscan, I paid visits to the zoo quite a few times while I was a child. In recent years, I've taken visiting families and friends there and we always enjoy our time there. Given how expensive land is in San Francisco, I am very impressed with the size and layout of our zoo here. There are a good variety of animals exhibited. I particularly recommend checking out the aye-aye. There are not many places on earth you can see them and we got them here in SF Zoo. There only do a few shows a day so plan accordingly. 

The only reason I don't give it a 5 stars is that I prefer the larger Santa Babara zoo..... I still love SF zoo though!
author: Victor K.

description:
Its nice there! I just wish they had more animals and that we can feed the giraffes, zebras or ostridges etc.  and that we can take photos with the animals like tigers or penguins or sea lions. That is what we have in Thailand. 

So overall, I have been to much better zoos so this was just okay. But the animals are great! I love animals! :)
author: Peach K.

description: Very lovely zoo. This will be my go too zoo since i can't make it to san diego all the time. It was so beautiful here. The way everything was set up. I will definatly be back. Be aware of food though. Might as well bring snacks and eat out after the zoo. Too expensive because its in the city. Though the food is good there. Employees are extremely nice. Animals were very enjoyable.
author: Jackie B.

description:
This zoo is pretty fun and wont break the bank. The amount of animals on display is impressive with giraffe to seals and everything in between. The lions and tigers are pretty cool. At times you can observe them feasting.

The staff are friendly and helpful and genuinely care about the animals. I will return.
author: Justin C.

description: This is a pretty boring zoo for a city like this. It was fairly inexpensive; $15 for an adult and $8 for parking. It was a Tuesday afternoon, and it wasn't very busy. There was a lot of construction going on and not a large selection of animals. We walked around for about 30 minutes and decided to go to happy hour instead.
author: Ha D.

description: I'm sorry, but super disappointed. For a place that charges so Much to get in, and the drive more than an hour to get there it's so not worth it to go to a place that looks abandoned, not a lot of animals and display... So much hype for a place that is not worth all that trouble for....
author: Cesar A.

description: We had a really nice day at the zoo today, I had not been there in about 15 years.  Staff was very nice.  The zoo needs some help thought, donations etc.  Many of the enclosures have not been changed or improved in many many years.  The bathrooms were not that clean and need to be updated.  There was a line to get in, I was kind of shocked by that but it moved pretty quickly. I will buy tickets on line next time.  This is the good part of the review.  I was there with 5 children and they had a really wonderful time.  The rides are $5.00 each.  Lunch and a snack  is about $15.00 per person and admission is $20.00, parking is $10.00 or park on the street for free.  THE KIDS HAD A GREAT TIME.  When I got home I logged onto the website and made a small donation, it cost quite a bit to run a zoo and this zoo needs support.  Go with your kids, have fun and if you afford it, make a donation.  Wear sneakers and bring a sweat shirt, the neighborhood is notoriously cold but can warm up in the afternoon.
author: David C.

description:
First off, I like the zoo.  I am giving three stars because I think A-OK describes it.  Its a nice zoo, but its getting old.  I guess there are some plans in the works for significant revamp, especially of the "tropical forest" area and building.  

The one thing that gripes me, and maybe it can't be helped:  We arrive just after they open at 10AM, and no animals are out. We walk around for about an hour.  No animals.  Finally I run into a zoo keeper and ask. The reason?  All the animals are eating and dont come out until 11 or after.  Huh????  Then why, oh why, do you open at 10??? If you have ever been anywhere with little kids, you know they have ziltch for patience.  My two five year olds really were not happy no animals were out.  

Finally, after waitiing about an hour and a half, they started appearing.  My suggestion, either change their feeding time to a bit earlier, or open at 11.  Duhhh?
author: Rob B.

description:
We went there  for the "Boo at the zoo"
I wish they had better candies (mostly jawbreaker and nerds) 

 Clean and nice. Easy to follow the map to get to the places/ animals
We were lucky to see many of animals that day.
I'm considering of getting the membership for the zoo.... Can't wait for many more trips with my boy!!
author: Afshan L.

description: I love the SF zoo. I have been coming here since I was a kid (we are talking 30yrs+) and I always have such a blast. Last time was on Memorial Day. It was raining/misting and I was solo (reflecting on the loss of my father many years back, who was a Marine) but I found so much beauty there I just could not help but have an awesome time. I never saw any animals being fed (even when I was a zoo member) so for that, 4 stars, but it is a GREAT zoo and I have many photos and memories here . The food has gotten MUCH better over the years too so a big plus for that!
author: Bella B.

description: Yesterday i went on a fieldtrip with my son and his first grade class. I had never been to the sf zoo even though im bay raised. I have to say i was impressed. And probably more excited than the kids. I loved how close you can get to the animals. It was difficult  to make all feeding or the timed sessions but loved that it was a option. I thought we wouldnt be able to see everything in the lottle timing we had. But to my surprise we did and the kids still were able to play at the playground. I will for sure be back again. Another plus was that we went to ocean beach(across the street) to just walk on the beach. over all super happy with our first trip. Ready for more!
author: Ray G.

description: I am not a fan of zoos in general...but this zoo is pretty awful. the petting zoo may be the only nice thing about this place. their recent killing of a gorilla is deplorable...but the animals are in small enclosures and it just feels sad there.
author: Ari F.

description:
You know when you were a little child, everything, I mean everything appeared gargantuan in size!  The SF Zoo was such a huge place walking around and visiting all the animals as a child.

My daughter, Joy had to babysit three small boys, so I tagged along.  I noticed so many of the exhibits were unoccupied, except for a handful of animal living quarters where there were a few animals scattered here and there residing between each area.

The lions cage had beefed up its security-wise measures due to the lion mauling in December 2007. Other animals' living quarters were secured with very thick shatterproof glass high wall enclosures.

Security measures and the SF Zoo itself are so different now compared to when I visited SF Zoo as a child.
author: Shirley M. J.

description:
I enjoyed this zoo. The location is beautiful. I love that it overlooks the ocean while you are enjoying the different animals of the world. My favorite exhibit was the African one with the giraffes, ostriches, zebras, etc. Since that was at the very beginning (you can view it before even entering the Zoo), I felt a little letdown with the rest. Though watching the baby giraffe run around the pen and constantly slip and fall was pretty cute. 

My 4 year old loved seeing everything but was appalled they didn't have elephants (Her: "What zoo doesn't have elephants mama?" Me: "This one apparently.")

We were also bummed a bunch of exhibits were closed. And since someone told us to specifically go watch them feed the lions and tigers and they didn't, I was a little disappointed.

All in all it was a fun trip. Hardly anyone there at all on a Monday. Less than $40 for the day, including the parking. Cafe food was pretty good. 

This zoo has a lot of potential. Hopefully they continue to improve it.
author: Heather H.

description: My husband and I have never been here so we decided it would be a great family outing with our son. However, it wasn't that great for the price and being it's the Sf zoo. Animals were MIA and the zoo people were no where to be found. Also all their zoo talks are in the late afternoon. Nothing really when zoo opens. We were dissapointed and I wouldn't go back here .
author: Leah D.

description:
Haven't been here for about 5 years, I must say the Zoo is still very much enjoyable for me.

Just came here recently with my gf. Pricy entrance fees but it's not like I'll come here all the time.

The animals however do look sad and tired. But I haven't seen them behave lively for the past 26 or so years I've been living. It's a given that all the animals there are probably either tired or simply they just are not as fascinated about us as we are about them.

Wear good shoes if you hope to walk around for 2-3 hours like we did ;)

I love the insect/bugs area, always cool to look at. Smells funny in there though. Petting barn is awesome too. I very much enjoy watching the sheep and goats chasing little kids (because they purchased the food) and them being afraid, very, very, afraid.

Oh I also forgot to add, free parking on Sloat if you don't want to pay 8 bucks.
author: Jamie C.

description:
Traveling is  always a blessing to me. And, by tradition, I visit a local zoo in every city I visit, thus, I've been to many different zoos all over the world.
My favorite one is Moscow zoo, with its great variety of animals, awesome landscapes and friendly atmosphere.
SF zoo is a little bit small compared to what I expected, yet cosy and fun to visit.
There you can find animals from all over the world, - Australia, Africa, Russia, and spend some unforgettable time with your kids. 
You'll enjoy it, no doubt.
author: May A.

description: this was my first time here ...to tell you the truth i did not like it...and the smell in the closed room was awful......
author: Pritika M.

description: Nice place to spend the day.. It's not that big, compared to San Diego one for example, but it took us the whole day though to cover all of it.. A great variety of animals. Yet, there were no elephants for instance !! There are no shows throughout the day either. It's a fun place, where you can enjoy the good weather and have a nice day. Close to the beach, if you like to spend some time there too. If you can afford little walking, do not park in the zoo parking; Plenty of free parking slots can be found on Sloat Blvd north of it.
author: Amr E.

description: They charge $$ for parking. (I think it was 8-10 bucks) It looks a tad run down and very old and dirty exhibit wise... The playground and statue area was very nice... And, my son enjoyed playing there for a few minutes... My kids were starving so we bought a drink and pretzel. The pretzel was actually really good. Didn't ride the train cause the line was crazy long. They fed the bear while we were there and that was very cool to watch. But, besides the Bears and pretzel... And the playground...Ehhhhh ... I really felt disappointed. We are Zoo members in TX.. We have been to Zoo's all over the U.S...this definitely ranks as one of the ones that needs some major updating...which they might be doing soon?!? The animals...penguins...for sure need a better habitat. Just disappointing.... Animals deserve a better/updated areas. Overall not horrible...but, I've seen it once and won't be back.
author: Tiffany H.

description:
Four stars for families with kids or tourists. Worth it because it's a zoo.

Two stars for college kids and yuppies. Not their scene. Been there done that.

Some friends wanted to visit this zoo since it was free-first-Wednesdays of each month. However, you must have a SF-addressed ID or proof you live in SF. Otherwise, it's almost at full price, so beware if you think it's a good deal. 

This is worth a visit if you haven't been to the zoo for ages, but it is not all what you might expect. Little kids would enjoy it, not just the petting zoo area. I didn't as much as there's no elephants, leopards, cheetahs, etc. 

Some of the animals were asleep or hiding so it was not too exciting. Too many of the exhibits were "under construction" as well. The zoo is not really that big, but there's still enough walking so you have to be in decent shape, or be wearing comfortable shoes.

wth? (http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2009/08/07/BALE1950IA.DTL)
author: Peter L.

description: A very good, family friendly zoo. Pretty well kept, though the bathrooms were pretty bad. Nice animal exhibits. An awesome play are for the kids. The steam train is fun as is the merry go round.
author: Darryl H.

description:
**Free on Wednesdays for us locals with a valid ID***

I'm indifferent about this review. I don't want to give it only 3 stars because it's animals and as an animal lover I would do anything for them. But many of the animals stay secluded and the Lions only come out once an awhile for feedings. Food is of course over priced but its to be expected. 
I wish there was a better way to house all the glorious animals in an perfect environment outfitted with everything to make them happy but I suppose it's the best the city can do so I do appreciate that we have wild animals in our back yard in this awesome city.
author: Jessica M.

description:
Go for the animal feedings: that's when the animals come out of hiding.  Here are the best ones:

Penguin feeding: 10:30 and 3:30: http://www.yelp.ca/biz_photos/EnClsPfQ3j-9triBsg3YnQ?select=5K2hxFR5LTOo7GYSk4OFJA#NdkK4Mopy4FVgRkiGbFvUg
Grizzly feeding: 11:30: 
http://www.yelp.ca/biz_photos/EnClsPfQ3j-9triBsg3YnQ?select=5K2hxFR5LTOo7GYSk4OFJA#io0AewMJsmzzTzqkj0ZwqA
They throw fish into the grizzly pond for the main course: http://www.yelp.ca/biz_photos/EnClsPfQ3j-9triBsg3YnQ?select=kAkgCufOaRdUixZarkJmmA#kAkgCufOaRdUixZarkJmmA
Capybara feeding: 11:15: http://www.yelp.ca/biz_photos/EnClsPfQ3j-9triBsg3YnQ?select=5K2hxFR5LTOo7GYSk4OFJA#bbOJt1zP8KeV_yAVv6PxVA
Asian rhino feeding: 2:15: http://www.yelp.ca/biz_photos/EnClsPfQ3j-9triBsg3YnQ?select=5K2hxFR5LTOo7GYSk4OFJA#r2HjHJhHgcTqfVAN9SwYmg
Lion/tiger feeding: 3:00: http://www.yelp.ca/biz_photos/EnClsPfQ3j-9triBsg3YnQ?select=_GKROb0SCOZDqxMPzYojmA#_GKROb0SCOZDqxMPzYojmA
Hippo feeding: 3:30: http://www.yelp.ca/biz_photos/EnClsPfQ3j-9triBsg3YnQ?select=5K2hxFR5LTOo7GYSk4OFJA#gI-lEMdPXk4ycw_ZGe2bEg
Raptor feeding: 4:00: http://www.yelp.ca/biz_photos/EnClsPfQ3j-9triBsg3YnQ?select=5K2hxFR5LTOo7GYSk4OFJA#5K2hxFR5LTOo7GYSk4OFJA
Giraffe feeding: 4:30: http://www.yelp.ca/biz_photos/EnClsPfQ3j-9triBsg3YnQ?select=5K2hxFR5LTOo7GYSk4OFJA#rPUntQeJU6dbkat8QNWFxQ

The grizzly feeding was by far the best: show up a few minutes early to get a good position near the pool.  the hippo feeding was a close second.

Arrive before 11 AM.  Here's the monstrous ticket line you deal with if you arrive after noon: http://www.yelp.ca/biz_photos/EnClsPfQ3j-9triBsg3YnQ?select=5K2hxFR5LTOo7GYSk4OFJA#5D6y2b9cRkj-69adWKwCGg

Other highlights:
- Lemurs
- Snow leopard
- Spider monkeys
- Great Hornbill
- Kookaburra, when he's making his mating call
- There is often a raptor presentation at the wildlife theater just outside the children's zoo, at 11:30 and 2:30 (Thur-Sun only)
- River otter
author: Scott F.

description:
I hate zoos.  All of them.  The SF Zoo made me realize this.  I hadn't been there since I was a kid and maybe I missed how shabby and filthy it is, what poor condition the animals are in, the fact that the SF weather is too cold for many of them, the people that expect the animals to entertain them when they are just trying to get through another miserable day in this hellhole. 

Zoos were invented because there was no TV in the 1800's.  We don't need zoos anymore, we have NatGeo in HD.  Instead of zoos, we need sanctuaries to save animals that are being slaughtered in their native habitats, or who's native habitats are disappearing.  If you don't enjoy watching animals suffer, avoid this s***hole.
author: Tina L.

description:
Although this isn't the greatest zoo I've ever been to, I'm just a fan of zoos in general.  I love seeing the animals being taken care of, and watching kids being given the opportunity to learn about them.  It also help raise awareness for all the cruelty going on.

I've been to this zoo since I was in my single digits, and it is a SF landmark.  They are improving every year, and I hope to only see it get bigger and better.  If you haven't visited it yet, I suggest you do.

** I do want to say that I did get very upset with the whole tiger incident.  But I hope that all the idiots involved were taken care of, and that it never happens again.  I can't explain how disappointed I was with how it ended, and everything else.  None-the-less, the majority of the people that I see working there love the animals and the zoo ... and were just as angry, if not more, then everyone else. **
author: Pia V.

description: I really have no clue as to why it's rated poorly.   Took my 3-year old for a field trip and it was great!  There's ample space and sure enough I spent half the time running after my daughter. There was quite an array of animals and birds, including a snow leopard, lion, tiger, zebras, ostriches etc. Sure they weren't moving a whole lot, but that was OK with me. We saw a hippo bathing just 15 feet from us which was cool. I would definitely come here again. My only issue is that it opens at 10 which is kind of late. I showed up at 9:30 and had to wait for the ticket window to open.
author: Sarovar M.

description:
So fun!!!  I haven't been to a zoo since I was a kid and I always hear people complaining that they're depressing, but I didn't feel that way at all here.  Even before you enter the zoo the giraffes will make you smile.  They're so cute and awkward.  

Following the main path on the map is the best route, starting with the African Region.  Next is the Primate Discovery Center which was actually really impressive.  I'm not a monkey fan, but between the many species of lemurs, the baby gorilla, and the emperor tamarins (that were more fascinated by me that I was of them) I was stoked. 

The Cat Kingdom was kinda lame, cos most of the cats were sleeping.  But cats are kinda worthless like that, so I can't really complain.  The tapir and the anteater were oddly interesting.  They both kept sticking their tongues out at us.  

The (newly opened) Tropical Rainforest was rad.  There were dozens of butterflies floating about and loads of turtles and macaws.  It reminded me how much I need a vacation. 

Flamingos are always awesome, but the Children's Zoo was a surprisingly good time.  For some reason I thought it wouldn't be, but the meerkats and prairie dogs were pretty sweet and the birds of prey at Hawk Hill were super b.a.  The turkey vulture they had out is almost 40 years old and could still take me in a fight!  The Family Farm petting zoo was alright.  I mean, I love chillin with goats, but the animals there were really not impressed with me at all. 

The staff were all super helpful and knowledgeable.  I got to ask all kinds of ridiculous questions without the slightest eye roll and they would come up and show you something awesome.

They give you $3 off if you show proof of being a SF resident and another $1 off if you got there via muni.  I took the 23 bus and had no problems getting to the zoo.  After zooing it up, I walked across the Great Highway and hung out by the water for a bit.  What a great afternoon!
author: Denise K.

description:
My recent visit to the SF Zoo was a complimentary trip via company social event; my experience might be slightly different from the average zoo-goer. 

The drive is a bit complicated. However, the ocean view when you get to the parking area is great. 

When I got to the event during 11AM (when the event began), it was peak hours for parking. Since I didn't want to arrive late, we ended up having to pay an extra fee for valet because it was so difficult to find or even see a space. So even though I had a prepaid "general parking ticket", it was pretty much useless and a hassle.

Because of the first impression of the overly busy parking lot, I didn't expect much from the trip. However, the customer service of the event employees were good. They made sure to politely and subtly(!) check that we were admitted. The catering coordinators were also very good with maintaining a stocked food area.

In terms of the zoo visit, we were able to get all of the exhibits in 3 hours. Snack vendors are just enough and strategically placed. Boyfriend suckered me into buying some Dippin' Dots and cotton candy for us. Get in on that Little Puffin train ride + Carousel (yee!). Mad props to the very friendly train operator who made all the waiting kids happy by waving at passersby and to the waiting line before each departure. Also, mad props to the carousel ticket taker who didn't judge that I really wanted to ride the giant plastic cats. She even gave a pro-tip: the ones on the outside don't move up & down. 

The highlight was probably when there was a large crowd staring at the rhino exhibit and a bunch of kids were voicing how disappointed they were that the rhino wasn't being active. Upon hearing this, everyone saw the rhino sit up and start walking in circles. Then it proceeded to take a minute long, HUGE, pee. As in "Piss off, humans". Okay, well it was what I feel like the rhino was thinking... it was hilarious seeing the reaction in the crowd.  So mad props to the rhino.

The zoo is also a 10 min drive from Japantown too, so we were able to grab some yummy bites after, which is very important. Overall, the experience in the zoo is good. Just get there early and snag the cheaper self-parking :)
author: Ann S.

description: Sadly, the precious baby gorilla died by getting crushed under the hydraulic enclosure door. Gross negligence and human error.
author: Lisa W.

description:
My family enjoys going to this zoo, our last visit was in November of 2013. This visit was better than most, for some reason the animals were really active that day. Could have been the time of day maybe, we got there around 1pm. Another thing I noticed was the zoo seemed cleaner than normal, particularly the penguin area. They also made a lot of improvements since our last visit - they acquired a baby Komodo Dragon, they built a new play area, & it looks like they've improved some of the enclosures as well.

My family usually prefers the Oakland Zoo over the SF Zoo, but we still like the SF Zoo! With these recent changes it's going to be hard to pick which zoo to visit.
author: John M.

description: Very nice place . I went to SF zoo with my friends. Everything clean and very nice place. I like Red panda so much.
author: Hoai Thuong N.

description: Zoo was clean, but there needs to be more tenants considering the fact that there were several empty spaces.  The train should go around the whole zoo and not just a portion of it, while parking should be free!  The highlight, for the kids, was the petting zoo.
author: Ron D.

description:
This was my favorite place to go as a kid  and we finally got around to bringing the girls here.  I felt like a lot of the animals were missing.  There were a lot of unique animals that you can't see at the Oakland zoo (Koalas, gorillas etc.), but a lot of empty habitats as well. 

I missed all the nocturnal animals.  They do still have aye-ayes but they won't open that exhibit until summer.  

Overall, for us I think we'll stick with the Oakland Zoo since there is so much to do and see there with a lot less walking for the little ones.
author: Chris K.

description: Pleasantly surprised! Brought our 6 and 10 year old here on a drizzly, over cast day and had a blast. We came on a Friday so no crowds. Entry fee for adults is $19/person and kids were $13/child with $8/parking.  The animals were very active including the rare red pandas, hippo who was trying to escape, lively lions and gorgeous tigers. Peacocks were walking around and the Penguins were swimming about. Staff and volunteers were so helpful and inviting. Had a great time. Only reason for 4 star instead of 5 is because we've been to many other zoos with exotic animals but this one came close. Thanks for a great day!!
author: E M.

description: Today is the best day of my life... I was pretty much dancing, taking pictures, and hopping around like a little kid the whole time I was here! Admissions for adults was $20 per person + $8 parking. The first thing we did was hit the food courts. I ordered the chicken sub and it honestly is the best burger I ever ate that comes with just about everything and even kettle chips! Instead of having a burger with fries, they give you something crunchy to enjoy with ur burger... and I loveee what they did there! Although everything was pretty pricey, it's quite understandable because of the maintainence and services involved to keep a zoo going. The environment is extremely peaceful, and well kept by the friendly workers and staffs. Some of the things I didn't really like was that most of the buildings were closed when we went and the limited amount of zoo animals... many of the zoo animals are showcased at a distance.... Major disappointment! Other than that, I definitely recommend bringing your kids or even your friends/family/spouses here because it's a really great place for all ages!
author: Diane T.

description: First off, this is not my rating of the zoo, but of their membership office.  I renewed my membership with them online October 20, 2015 and basically, never received my cards. I've called and spoken with various people, but to no avail.  Each time everyone was so nice, said their apologies and promised to get the card made and into the mail, but I've received bills with no problem, but my membership card is nowhere to be found.  If you decide to go ahead and pay for a Zoo membership online, Good Luck!
author: KW S.

description:
This zoo seemed really small and not just the zoo itself but the in-closers too. Good verity of animals though. 
The staff in both cafés were the worst though, the unfriendliest  and rude people. We had just walked into the smaller of the 2 cafés, it was freezing out and wanted something hot to drink as well as I needed to nurse my baby. After sitting down and getting situated my husband goes to order and they say sorry we're closed.. Really cause the doors are open and people before us just ordered.  They couldn't even get us some hot drinks?! But even worse they asked us to leave so they could close. Really?! You can't start cleaning with me sitting quietly in the corner nursing my baby?!
author: Holly S.

description:
I Love SF Zoo and i'm happy that we have an attraction like this tucked into a little corner of SF.  The facility is extremely clean and has a beautiful and spacious layout.  They have their own parking lot for $10 the whole day, or you can park on the street for free.

I love how they have a Children's Zoo, packed with a bunch of hands on activities for the little ones.  Petting Zoo, insect room, a playground, and info on different type of pets and pals one can have.

They have all sorts of animals, and they seem happy enough.  Although, I wondered why some of the bigger animals had such smaller confinements.  I had fun and I think the per person price tag is totally worth it.

Tips: bring a sweater cause this part of SF can get chilly.  Purchase those little keys that you can enter into the "boxes" at most animal exhibits so that you can get more information on the animals.  You can pack your own lunch/snacks/drinks!  Thats a plus for those who don't want to spend money at their cafe.  There are ins/outs, just get stamped for reentry!  Bring your camera, and take lots of pictures =).  Read the fun facts for each animal.  Try and get there as early as you can so that you don't have to rush through the exhibits.   I got there at 12pm and stayed until closing at 5pm.  Have fun!
author: Reg E.

description:
My family and I came here on a family outing one Saturday afternoon and loved it!!  We really enjoyed all of the animals and the park is huge - you could spend a few hours here.

I especially enjoyed the giraffes :)  When we arrived, the parking lot was full, but we managed to find a free spot a couple of blocks away - not bad since we didn't have to pay $10 for parking.
author: Erin J.

description:
Lemur room Birthday Party package

I recently used the San Francisco Zoo's birthday party package to celebrate the adoption of my daughter and I couldn't have been happier with the entire party!!

Everyone loved the room and its close vicinity to the animals.  The food was a hit from the pizza to the add-ons.  The pictures on the website don't do the room justice because it is so much nicer in person.

But it was really the personal service that was outstanding!  We appreciated the personal greeting before the event. Gina was awesome throughout the party and afterwards-even storing the cake in the fridge for us while we wandered around the zoo.  And the face painter, whose name escapes me, was great-good w the kids and wonderful work.

Many of my guests remarked on the service and the venue and how great they both were!

Thank you for helping us celebrate in such a great way!!!
author: Kathy T.

description: The zoo was great!  My kids loved the animals.  The only disappointment was that on the day we went there they had a coupon and they wouldn't let us use it off of our smartphone.  They said that their coupon had to be printed!  What happened to being environmentally friendly?  They should really practice what they preach!!!
author: Neda A.

description:
I feel like I was here on an off day. Seemed like an odd number of animals were not on display. Most of the animals we did see were just sleeping. I realize they're not there to entertain me, but still... seeing them at a distance, asleep, made the trip to the zoo superfluous. I could have stayed home and watched Planet Earth on BBC or something.

Still, a somewhat charming and interesting place to wander around.
author: Stephen R.

description:
Defiantly one of the best zoos that I have been too in the states. San Fransicso Zoo in not one of the tourist filled areas that so much of downtown and the piers see all year round. It was a serene and beautiful area to observe the wonders of captive animals from around the world. The zoo is easily accessable by the muni.  After getting off at the last stop, you simply take a short walk tot the ocean, grab some pictures and walk a couple blocks to the zoo entrance.  There, you buy a cheap (I believe it was $14) ticket with $2 off for taking the muni and enter the zoo.  The zoo was very easy to navagate. So many zoos are like a maze which makes it difficult to see everything without back tracking a lot. Very little back tracking is required at the San Francisco Zoo.  I was really impressed with the animal habitats as the zoo made it difficult for the animals to hide from the public. I only remember not being able to see the snow lepord as it was hiding behind a bush eating. All the rest of the enclosures were accessable from different sides making it nearly impossible for the animals to hide.  You just never know what adventure you will find in the zoo.  I found a girl that I went to high school with in central Illinois over 10 years ago.  We just saw each other at the zoo and asked if we went to school together.  Ended up spending 2 hours together catching up.  So go to the zoo and have an adventure.

And as always, Have Fun!!!
author: Christian H.

description: We had a great time! Park is the right size not too big. Lots of things for our little one to do. Lots of animals to see. The only thing I didn't see was the elephants. No elephants?
author: Rebecca M.

description: A precious baby gorilla was needless killed.The SF Zoo needs to close permanently and the animals go to a safe sanctuary.
author: Victoria S.

description: This is a wonderful place for a great price of $17/adult! Parking is $10. This a great size zoo with plenty of animals to explore. I especially loved the tiger exhibits. They are so beautiful! The part that crept me out was the "insect exhibition." I do not like creepy crawlers and that room was filled  with them, which was really gross. The African section was pretty nice too where giraffes were roaming the grassy area. They also had lions, bears, a steam train($5) and a merry go round ($3), which was pretty cool. Oh, and the playground area for the kids was also sassy! It looks like a jungle/antarctica ice bergs themed. Overall, I had a great time here and one full day will get you to every part of the zoo and to check out every animal/insect there is here!
author: Lisa N.

description:
It is weird to go to a place I haven't been to since I was 8, seeing it now as an adult with my very own little boy.  Makes it really special.  I feel like i'm in a very clean, safe environment.  Friendly staff.  Playground nearby for when the kids need to jump around like monkeys.  And lots of coffee stands to recharge the parents.  
What I liked most is that people think of zoos mainly as animal prisons.  Most of the animals at the SF zoo are rescues and couldn't survive in the wild.  There are tags at each enclosure telling not only about the type of animal, but the specific animals story of how they got there.
I was happy to take my son to see animals he'd have to travel the world in order to see.
author: Dennis M.

description: If you live in or near San Francisco and have kids, the membership is totally worth it!  We have a 2 year old and love taking him there and every time we go we see some interesting behavior from some of the animals.  I like the layout of the zoo and that it isn't too big.  I also enjoy that several of the animals at the zoo were rescued and you can read about their stories.  The playground and petting zoo are always a favorite with my son and his cousins.  The food there is actually pretty good too.  We always go on weekdays and have the run of the place.
author: Tonya S.

description:
I've been to 4 other zoos, including the San Diego Zoo, and SF Zoo's design and layout are my favorite so far. Though the variety of exhibits cannot compare to that in San Diego, I prefer this zoo for it's smaller, more intimate habitats. You can get more up close and personal with the animals.

I'm a fan!
author: Michael W.

description: The lion feeding is AMAZING! The main reason why I love coming to this zoo.  Be warned!  Parking is almost impossible to find if you come on a weekend.  It is super packed.  The only downside is the Bears look really miserable,  especially the polar bears :( Dope experience overall.  Love the lion house!
author: Marissa M.

description: We had a field trip with ALL the 7th graders from Mill Valley Middle School today. After a slow start (we waited around to get going for a while), we had a great time. Each student had a clip board and wrote answers down as we checked out the animals. Favorites: Giraffes and Zebras; Gorillas eating broccoli; polar bears; grizzly bears and flamingos! Lunch was good too! My son loves pizza and had 3 slices! No complaints! The weekday experience was filled with school kids, but that's okay it was a nice day and after returning for a visit after several years, I was overall impressed with the habitats and grounds. Still lots of new construction coming our way. The SF Zoo is a hidden gem of the Bay Area!
author: Anne Z.

description:
It's pretty small. And a few of the exhibits and cages were empty.

I went to a wedding there back in September. The wedding was held in the Africa Savannah region. It was a nice service and the zoo staff were quite helpful. Afterwards (and between the ceremony and the reception), we all got to feed the giraffes.
author: Vivek B.

description:
Great place to go if you want to hang out and look at some pretty awesome animals. Went here for my 20th birthday with a friend and I had a blast. Yea the food may be a little pricey (including drinks) but it's ok. I had the clam chowder and it was good. It's clean, small and very family friend friendly. Animals are close up but they should work on the petting zoo, just goats. A lot of seagulls so beware of poop. 

Overall a good place to go and enjoy a day with friends or family.
author: Melissa G.

description:
Wow its been ages since I have been to the Zoo. Came to the Zoo on Sunday hoping to see the new penguin chicks that hatched. Too bad they were inside the whole time and didn't come out to play.

Had lunch at the lemur cafe - prices were reasonable and the chicken tenders and garlic fries was yummy.

The Lion house was a bust. Waited till 1pm for it to open to have a security guard scream out we will NOT be bringing in the lions today. =/ 

Hopped on the little puffer and felt like i was 5 again. 

Definitely a great place to spend a Sunny Sunday.
author: Linda L.

description: My daughter loves animals and I love bringing her and her friends here. Great way for kids to learn about animals they usually only see on TV. Feeding the lion is why I enjoy it. We usually park far from the park and walk over, not too bad if you are up for it.
author: Steve J.

description: Brought my 2 year old here and he loved it! There's been a lot of changes to this zoo since I was a kid but it's still enjoyable. I would recommend looking for street parking if you want to avoid paying $10 in the lot.
author: Sara L.

description: I love this zoo! Got to see koalas and kangaroos for the first time! Some reviews say that many of the animals didn't look happy - my understanding is that many of them are injured and rescued and live here because they're unable to survive in wild life. Even more so why my daughter and I love this place! It's also awesome that you can see many of these animals close-up.
author: Anna O.

description:
I'm fond of cats: big and small cats)) As I can enjoy big cats only at the Zoo, I go there alone or with my family from time to time. The SF Zoo is not the best one I've ever seen, but it's comfortable enough and it's a family place: my kid is keen on animals too. 
On the one hand it's sad to see such great animals trapped behind cages, but I can see them alive only at the zoo and I am happy there as a child. So I recommend you going there alone or with your family just to feel the atmosphere of childhood.
author: Lora P.

description: Parking was horrible, beyond belief. I had to find a spot off the highway which was also horrible because it was just as packed as the zoo parking lot. Then, to make it worse we arrived at about 2:50. They told us they stop selling tickets at 3, they start putting the animals away at 3, and that the park closes at 4pm. Yelp says the park is open until 5. So mad right now, didn't get to see the Zebras on Valentine's Day!!!
author: Danny L.

description: Although the zoo has its own paid parking lot, we had to spend 15 minutes cruising around the lot before a space opened up. Once inside the zoo, the kids were immediately drawn to the giraffes at the entrance.  The zoo is spacious with a plenty of animals to see.   The bathrooms were clean and the grounds were reasonably well kept.  The kids particularly liked the mini train ride and the play structures.   Aside from the parking, an overall good experience.
author: Jeff S.

description: Family pass pays for its self.. it's $115 for 2 adults and up to 5 kids per visit. We've been in 6 times since we purchased the passes a month ago and prefer to section off the zoo each time we visit making the trip less exhausting for the kids and leaving us a new section to explore the next visit. By the time we start over again it's like they've never seen the animals or have stories they wanna share from their last visit.  I just think it's great
author: Mimi W.

description: It was ok, I just wish the people handing out the tickets at the booth to go in were friendly, or maybe I just got one that was rude and dismissive. The animals were cute, but some were really skinny and looked starve and their water was super dirty. I also dont understand why the food stands are cash only. But other than that, it was alright and the petting zoo is a must!
author: Jacky H.

description:
My fiancé and I went there on a Friday morning, and it was pretty empty which was great. 

Beautiful and wide array of majestic creatures, although my favorite were the otters.  

Some parts of the zoo need renovation, but it was mostly good. It doesn't really compare to the San Diego Zoo, but the animals seemed happy and we'll cared for. 

Shoutout to the polar bear, which is very old and kind of grumpy looking, although he is pretty cute. 

Don't eat here though. It's so overpriced (expected) but the food just isn't good or even okay.
author: Yuri R.

description: Went here on vacation and had a wonderful time! I've been to a few different zoos, but I enjoyed how close you were able to get to the animals at this one. The baby monkey was absolutely adorable, we spent over an hour just watching him play.
author: Amanda V.

description:
I recently visited the San Francisco Zoo with the family and had an amazing time. My fiance decided to surprise us with tickets in celebration of my Mom's birthday. 

We got there early and made sure to visit every single exhibit. The staff was very friendly and knowledgeable. The Zoo was immaculate and the animals looked as if they were very well taken care of. 

I loved watching the giraffes being fed fresh greens. I also enjoyed seeing the beauty of the snow leopard. 

For lunch the family and I ate at Leaping Lemur Café. We enjoyed fresh burgers, pizza, and salad. And for a little pick me up we had hot coffee and tea.

I had an amazing experience and would love to revisit the Zoo again next year.
author: Angie R.

description:
I'm giving the SF Zoo a 4 star rating, even despite the fact that I hate going to any zoo in general (darn allergies!). 

I've gone on 3 field trips so far with my student group of about 120 kids, ages K-9th. All the kids have tons of fun.

I also must say that unlike other gift shops at other museums and attractions, the gift shop at SF Zoo is reasonably priced with a large variety and broad price range throughout the store. This is great for kids that bring just a few bucks for a field trip souvenir.

Also, my students love their huge playground at the zoo. Our school doesn't have swings, and SF Zoo's playground has I'd say around 10 total. It's also a great place to have lunch if you are with a student group---with playground, eating area, and bathrooms all in the same area it makes it much easier to supervise the children.
author: Valerie F.

description:
There are no elephants, fox, spotted deers, pandas, snakes (one anaconda was there though). There no exotic birds. The very common European starlings are displayed in 'African birds' display!!! . Polar  bears are plenty.

As a photographer, I can very well drop my camera in home and walk in. The reason being,  grill fence around displays are dirty with spider webs, glasses are scratched and hazy.

Food: In Terrace fast food near bear display is cheap in quality high in price. Plain ice cream swirl $ 8.00. I ordered French fries for $4.29 which was less both quality and quantity than $0.99 fries in your local store. Despite it was made after 15 minutes of delay, they kept it in the counter to cool down.  The young charming black boy in the counter was calling "next customer" for collecting orders i.e money. He was not interested in passing me the fry though. When I interrupted him and said "my fries are getting cold, could you please pass it to me?" he initially acted as if not hearing me but later when i insisted he said he will call police.
author: Jayakumar R.

description:
For a local spot for kids, its small, a bit of a gem but def out dated. 
Animals are animal and informational and exciting none the less for the littles. Gets cold easily but so close to the beach.
author: Ka'Neki M.

description:
I found this to be an okay zoo, not horrible but not amazingly great. There's plenty of animals to see - giraffes, gorillas, rhinos, tigers, kangaroos, koalas, etc. As with most zoos during the day, many of the animals will be hiding or inactive so it helps to take two trips around to see if any new animals are out. I missed the polar bear when I first passed by but he was out in the open when I passed by after lunch. 

Also, make sure to bring in some snacks and drinks (they don't check backpacks) because the food inside the zoo is very overpriced!!
author: JD R.

description:
No Elephants?? No Dolphins or Aquatic Animals?

=(

I know its no Sea World, or Marine World/Discovery Kingdom, but there was ALOT of empty vacant space. This place needed more Shows, and close encounters with animals besides the small petting farm zoo. 

The $4 train ride was a small rip. I thought the ride was around the entire park. But no...Not really.

Overall. Its okae. My 2.5 year old son had fun regardless.
author: Tiffany M.

description:
Unlike some people who have reviewed this zoo, I am not categorically opposed to the very existence of zoos. 

I think they can be extremely valuable in getting people interested in conservation and protecting endangered species. Not to mention the fact that these animals are very fascinating, and a joy to observe.

Having said that, the San Francisco Zoo is just depressing. Many animals languish in run-down enclosures that look like they're from the 1950s. 

I haven't visited the zoo in well over a year, but my last visit did not make me want to return. I saw a giraffe compulsively chewing on the metal fence of its enclosure. The polar bear did nothing but pace back and forth nervously, in a very tiny space. A hippo sat alone in a small concrete pool.

I'm no expert on animal behavior, but none of those things seem normal. 

When I go to a zoo, I don't want to spend the day looking at animals that are very obviously suffering. While it would be sad for the city to lose its zoo, I think the SF zoo needs to clean up its act, or shut down, with the animals being relocated to facilities that are better equipped to take care of them.
author: John R.

description: Good day, but...a lot was closed! No discount on entry price though! Wouldn't suggest buying lunch there either! Children's area was awesome!!
author: Linda S.

description: This zoo was nice cause you can get pretty close to the animals. Also, the zoo is flat, so it's easier for those with children or those who have a disability.
author: Eric R.

description:
Yay! Mentor field trip!

Honestly, I feel bad giving any zoo less than 4 stars. The programs and research they have are admirable. 

As for the animals on display...

We were able to get pretty close to a baby(?) giraffe. 

Polar bears!

I was really excited for the koala exhibit which turned out to be one sleeping in a small enclosure. Oh well, guess I'll have to go to Australia to see them up close!

the zoo is mainly outside so if it's cold, plan accordingly! also, you may end up walking a lot. 

They have deals for SF residents, military and groups :) Parking is $10 in their lot.
author: Sara P.

description:
I LOVE going to the zoo! I've been to the LA Zoo, San Diego Zoo, even a Zoo in China! Now I have been to the San Francisco Zoo. Definitely my favorite of all! My BF and I went on a sunny Saturday afternoon so I totally thought it was going to be packed. Any zoo can loose its awesomeness the more it gets packed with screaming kids and annoying teens. A quick bus ride and we were in the middle of a concrete jungle all by ourselves! Well, not completely alone but there definitely wasn't a crowd.

We got there about 2 hours before closing so a lot of the animals were just getting ready for dinner and a bath before bed. They all seemed lively, most likely because they were hungry and we looked like a good appetizer before dinner. We got into a staring match with the big Silverback Gorilla (I swear he was thinking about how to get over the barrier), saw a mommy and baby gorilla, got yelled at by a couple of chimps, watched the giraffe chow down, chilled with some flamingos, said goodnight to the koala, sunbathed with the kangaroos, got close to the polar and grizzly bears, followed the back and forth pacing of a hungry tiger, ran away quietly from the roaring lion, and watched the fighter jet penguins race around the pond.

The SF Zoo does these awesome BikeAbouts that I would love to do when they come back in season! I can't wait for our next SF Zoo visit! In fact, if anyone was wondering: I'm accepting any and all donations for an annual SF Zoo membership! You know, in case they run out of snuggies and you can't think of what else to get me for Christmas *wink*wink*nudge*nudge*

 Casi
see more pics at http://www.sanfrancisconoobs.com/11-24-2009/san-francisco-zoo-concrete-jungle/
author: Casi C.

description: The last time ,we were in SF Zoo was few years ago but was back on weekend for the Holiday Christmas and Night Zoo in SF. They offer free Night SF Zoo with Christmas on the weekend before Christmas. The only animal exhibit open for visitors are the rain-deer, penguins, Lions den and Lemur (Eye-eye). They also gave music performance and magic show. I am giving them 3.5 stars for making it free on the weekend but wish to see more animals for night zoo in the future.
author: Sam M.

description:
I was raised near DC so The National Zoo is my bar, not San Diego
I've visited SD once. It was fine. I've been to Oakland twice. I like it.

 I visited the SF Zoo today for the first time, for my own birthday as it were. Free parking on Sloat was a very worthwhile, and not a terrible schlep. The weather was cloudy and cool, perfect on my opinion. The visitors were plenty but not overwhelming. Myself, my six and two year old daughters, and my husband all enjoyed taking our time seeing the animals. So much so that we only saw half the zoo! Both times at Oakland we saw it all, at least what was open and which animals came out.

We did start in the African Region which allows for various perspectives of the area. The animals, zebra and giraffe were our favorites, were all walking about and easily seen. On the color-coded map we saw the Southern areas, orange, brown, and yellow. Most animals were out and out. The Pachyderm House was closed, and the lions were sleeping in plain sight, but we saw plenty otherwise. Two rhino species (one fed while a docent spoke), penguins, otters, leopard, tigers, monkeys, birds. 

After three hours, including sandwiches from home by the gorillas and a rest by the Rhino, I was ready to go and return another day. I hope it's just as cloudy and cool. 

I like zoos. Possibly more than my eldest who kept asking what there was to do at a zoo and while there, wanted to get to the playground. I realize they don't get the wide open spaces of the wild, and perhaps the facility isn't immaculate, but I had fun. I look forward to going back. No matter how incredible it is to watch Planet Earth, seeing so many varieties of animals in person is a treat.
author: Rebekah A.

description:
When my cousins from Hong Kong are visiting, I have absolutely no idea where to take them. Shopping, eating, drinking, EVERYTHING is just better in Hong Kong.

Except...we do have a better zoo. I haven't been to the zoo in ages, but I was excited to go since I know the zoo had some minor renovations, which includes a parking lot right next to the zoo and a nicer ticket area - which is about it.

A note:
I thought we had pandas here. I guess not.

My absolute favorite thing is and will always be the Petting Zoo. The sheep and goats follow you around until you feed them. The llamas here have never looked so pissed off. Where else can you see pissed off llamas? 

One more thing: we saw two Amish families, and my naive 15 year-old cousin from Hong Kong screamed, "Oh wow! Those people are like from the Sound of Music!"

"They're the Amish. And they aren't deaf," I had to tell her.

[Another thing - one of the Amish girls had a digital camera. She was snapping away at rhinos - I thought the Amish don't use technology? Anyway, instead of snapping away at rhinos, my younger cousin snapped away at the Amish..]

I love the zoo. The next time you need to entertain a group of tourists, bring them here. Whether it's the llamas or the Amish, they will be sure to bring their cameras and snap away.
author: Vanessa W.

description:
OK so yesterday I was at the children's zoo with friends and was getting some pellet feed from the dispenser on the left side of the family farm (where the sheep are normally kept inside the barn, but yesterday they were allowed to roam the grounds).

Let me tell ya, them sheep are like gangstaz. They make the billy and dwarf goats seem tame in comparison (even though some of them buck horns amongst themselves on occasion).

So I put in my two quarters and turn the knob. Cupped one hand and let the pellets slide in. Right when I turned around, suddenly 8 fairly big smelly wooly vegans (no patchouli oil or tie-die t-shirts luckily) on all fours got a little too close to comfort for me, hovering around crotch level with anticipation. One of them mofo's went as far kicking me (luckily not with force) as I tightly gripped my fiddy cent stash of veggie pellets, and another offender nuzzled my butt with its nose (and fairly hard at that) during round 2 of pellet procurement.

The fun begins when you put a pellet or two in a child's hand, and see them run like Forest Gump when the sheep start to smell food (or fear). But don't worry, as aggressive as they may be, I think they're cooler to the kids, because the wooly smelly vegans know the adult$ are the one$ who hold the moolah.

My advice, go in with no fear. Don't be intimidated by these hippy crotch sniffing wooly creatures. Get spooked, and you drop your stash and the sheep n' goats will gobble them like the stickiest of the icky.

Friends were still spooked from the Tatiana tiger mauling episode, and didn't want to visit the zoo, but they ended up coming and were cool with the new improvements made to make the exhibit a lot more secure. Although one of them wondered if the lions could scale the wall....

The Little Puffer steam engine train is working again, and as loud as ever.

The penguin exhibit still reeks of fishy sardines, but if you are a mondo raw fishy lover, this reekage might cause some brain cells to be stimulated in a sort of wrongful sinful and weird way that you don't want to tell anyone about.

The nature trail inside the children's zoo is always a fun stroll for the kids, as they can get up and close with petting small turtles, hedgehog. And there's an armadillo on certain days, plus a chinchilla (can't pet them). And parents, make sure you have them hit the disinfectant foam soap dispenser on their way out.

The dippin dots "ice cream" thing here is prepackaged (like Capri Sun drinks), unlike the scoop into various cup sizes to order like at Discovery 6 flags. The "rainbow" flavor mix contains a series of colored dyes, so stick with either cookies and cream, banana split or that one other flavor.

Zoo food and offerings are still as dismal as ever. Thankfully it doesn't take long to get right into the Sunset for all sorts of better A$N grub and drink.
author: Ken K.

description: I've been to a handful of zoos, and this is easily the most depressing one.  The "big cats" enclosure stunk horribly, and it was hard to be inside.  The polar bears' enclosure not only doesn't exactly mirror their natural environment, but was small.  Ever wonder if animals have mental health problems?  Look no further.  This polar bear had a dirty brown coat, bloodshot eyes, and an expression that said, "kill me now."  I've never been so depressed at a zoo before.
author: Maisie G.

description: I  love  the  zoo   Its   Cool   Place  to   Vist   Lots  of cool  animals   I  remember  the  zebra  train  it  was  fun  long time ago  you get  key    Turn  key talk about    Animals
author: eric g.

description: Decent zoo as far as zoos go.   Maybe 2-3 hours worth on animals to see.
author: Michael E.

description:
My second time back at the SF Zoo not as bad as I have imagined.
This time the polar bears were out covered in moss and giraffe's posing for those with cameras. The petting zoo was also informative and interesting, for those who like to see barnyard animals and stepping in Cocoa Puff poo.

Now I won't argue against anyone who says these animals look sad or depressing, half of the animals were asleep or laying down. I mean, when you take your kids out and check on the Rhino with its horn cut off what kind of answer will you give them when they ask why they did it? Or why the Gorilla family has two mommas that refuse to play with their baby. Or why the Tiger is pacing back and forth in its cage furiously.

But just plop yourself down buy a $5 dollar churro, enjoy the SF weather and enjoy walking around the zoo with your family. Sure this zoo may not be the best around, but learning about the animals in exhibits and seeing animals you would never think about seeing are as much as enjoyable as one could think.
author: Janet N.

description:
I love the zoo! We recently renewed our membership I let it lapse for a year and boy did we miss it. I have a 5 year old and he loves going to the zoo and we live so close too.

Another great thing about the zoo is even though it's in SF there is plenty of free parking all around or you can pay to park in the lot. 

Over the past few years they have been doing some great upgrades to improve the zoo and the grounds. Some of the animals habitats have been improved and they are currently renovating the children's playground.

The biggest drawback of our Zoo is we are missing an elephant. I would love to see one here again soon.

If you have children the children's zoo is a great place to visit with a petting zoo and the insect building that has a little indoor play area which is nice on the colder days. 

And now there is a little baby tiger cub. There's always some event or activity to do with your family here. 

I definitely recommend checking it out if you haven't or if its been awhile since you have been here.
author: Tiffany P.

description:
Fun for the family!!

It's usually cold so dress in layers.

Zoo's used to be more fun.....maybe it was more fun when I was 5.....
author: Jeff P.

description:
SF/Oakland Zoo comparison.  

Overall I've finally decided I like SF Zoo best overall, it's really just a feeling thing, I love the big expansiveness of the park itself.  Oakland Zoo is much smaller and hillier but nice in that way too.  

There are some different animals at each zoo, which depending on the kids' interests, may be a factor.  Oakland has the big fruit bats, giant tortoises, elephants, camels and a small reptile room.  SF has the gorillas, penguins, bears (except the tiny Sun Bear at Oakland), rhinos, hippo, great bug house and more big cats.  

SF's train ride is better while Oakland has the Skyway.  

The SF petting zoo is larger and more varied and you can feed the goats and sheep but that means the goats and sheep are more aggressive and will knock over small kids.  At Oakland there are only goats in the petting zoo and just brushing so the animals are much calmer and slightly disinterested.
author: Kelly B.

description:
People are too harsh on this place! It's a zoo!
And they take in a lot of animals that are handicapped as well such as that eagle! I love animals and I love that there's a place walking distance from my house where kids can go and learn about wildlife safely. 
There is plenty of free parking along Sloat if you don't mind a little stroll to the entrance. 
Overall, this is a nice zoo with a variety of animals and allows free days for SF residents :)
My only concern is that the peninsula is wayyy to cold for some of the poor animals that are meant for warmer climates...
author: Linda N.

description:
I have been meaning to go here!!! I finally went and took my son with me.

SF Zoo is bigger than it looks from the outside!!!  A nice range of animals and staff members that are friendly.
