$15 per person.. but another $8 to get out.. regardless, the park offers alot and I have to say it was nice to check out.
author: Roger A.

description: I was very excited to spend the afternoon at the zoo after so many years! It was overly crowded, we walked forever until we got to the entrance from where we parked. There were barely any animals. It was really sad to see the animals depressed that they were locked up in there. Totally not the impression I got as a kid. I would save your money and do something else.
author: Tia Marie M.

description: Horrible. A lot of the enclosures were filthy! The aviary REEKS of mold. And don't get me started on the bears' pool (it was disgusting, I couldn't believe my eyes when one drank from it). There were ducks in every single one of the open enclosures. The larger animals' habitats seemed far too small for them. I've seen hot tubs bigger than the hippo pool. I could see a few of the animals' ribs. I'm not an expert on Zoo standards nor do I know much about how the animals were obtained, but the living conditions were poor at best. A lot of the animals, especially the ones kept apart in separate enclosures, seemed extremely depressed.
author: Ashley B.

description:
I don't know what all the negative reviews of this zoo are all about, but I was here today for the first time in a couple years (and have been coming since I was REALLY young) with my partner, who had never been here before, and we both had a fantastic time that truly saved a trip to the city for us. The zoo was better than it was last time I visited. The African area is beautiful and well designed, as is the Lemur Island where my partner and I watched them play for a good half hour. The new grizzly bear exhibit is great, and the bears came right up to the glass! And for my partner, the petting zoo was one of the highlights of the trip.

Despite the clouds (and it was pretty cloudy), we still saw a ton of animals. The tarantula exhibit in the South American aviary. I know that every trip to the zoo doesn't always yield all the animals the zoo has (no zoo can offer because keeping them on display constantly that and giving two stars to a zoo because of it is ridiculous... go to sea world if you want your animals to jump through hoops and be on display all day) but I feel that even on a bad day you'll still see animals, especially with all the keeper talks, which you could follow and spend a a good 2-3 hours. Chances are you will probably see a lot of animals.  

I will say that with children, plan your trip well and don't expect to see all the zoo. It's huge. This being said, this is one of the most kid friendly zoos I have ever been to. They have a playground inside the zoo, and the kids area is a lot of fun (even for adults!). And for the adults, the raptors (the birds not the dinosaurs) in the kids area were all out despite the weather being cold, and truly neat to see. 

And to end our stay, the people in the gift shop were beyond friendly and helpful. They even grabbed us on the way out just to make sure we saw our photos with no pressure to buy them. 

It was a great day. Don't listen to the bad reviews, just do it. If you hate it, at least you are close to the beach, right?
author: Aaron S.

description: Came on a spectacular weather Sunday.  We took the L Taraval metro which drops you off half a block from the entrance. The zoo has a good variety of animals and is not so big that you can get lost in.  Definitely can spent 2-3 hours here. The animals look very healthy.  I didn't particularly like the tiger area. The tigers are kept in these small cages that are connected together by small doors.  I wish the tigers are kept in the open like the rest of the animals. The zoo is clean.  The choo-choo train ride is the bomb!
author: James W.

description:
PROS: The zoo is huge! The location is perfectly located right next to the beach along the outskirts of SF. The weather is cooler so if you're like me and have to lug around a 2-year-old and all her stuff it helps that the 90 degree weather that the rest of the bay is experiencing doesn't reach SF. The line was long and our family members forgot to buy our tickets and the employee at the beginning of the line let us go to the members area to get our tickets so we didn't have to wait. We really enjoyed the children's zoo since it was so interactive with the petting zoo. This was my first time as well as my daughter and we both enjoyed our experience. 

CONS: I do get a bit sad watching animals that should be running around locked up in a cage. I can't help it.
author: RoseMichelle M.

description: We came on the first Wednesday of the month for free day and was disappointed that we got turned away. There's no signs that say you must come by 4pm and get a stamp at the ticket booth. We walked right pass the ticket booth and went into the front of the zoo and were just waiting around for our party to arrive. We proceed to walk towards the zoo and a lady shot us down. She refuse to let us in for the last hour saying we miss the stamp cut off. We turned around and walked away. We had to explain to our 3 year old that he wouldn't be seeing animals today.
author: Mary M.

description:
I've been to several zoo's in the US and this has probably one of the bigger and nicer zoo I've been to. Only thing was that most of the animals looked rather sad and dead like with no facial emotion. 

Not only is this zoo HUGE but it is really nice and spacious. There are a lot of room for the animals and a lot of walking space for visitors. Since when we came up to visit in September it was really cold walking around and there where barely any visitors which was better for us since I hate going to crowded places. 

They have everything from a wide selection of places to eat at and a lot of different types of animals from all types of monkeys, polar bear, penguins, tiger, giraffe, ostriches, beautiful peacocks, bears, and a huge gorilla just to name a few. Everything was green and beautiful! They even have a train that goes around the zoo so if your ever get tired of walking. 

Not sure on the admission price but I'm sure it isn't to much considering there are so much things to see, take photos of. So if you have a few hours to spare then do come here...really nice!
author: Raych D.

description:
I really enjoy the SF Zoo. I bring my 3 year old daughter here every two weeks. This is NOT the San Diego Zoo...I am shocked that people give the SF Zoo such a low rating. This is a nice zoo...and it costs $12 for adult SF residents. The San Diego Zoo is better, yes...but it costs nearly $40 a person!!! 

I love the SF Zoo and I really recommend people plan out their visit. A lot of people on Yelp complained that the animals were sleeping! Well yes, animals do that. Check the feeding times for the Bears and Penguins. The Grizzly bear is fantastic fun!!! The petting zoo is great for the little ones. 

Yes, some of the pens date back to the 1940s. But others are new and fresh..check out Grizzly Gulch, the new seal exhibit, the Gorillas, and of course the new area with the Giraffes. 

The membership is a bargain at about $100 bucks a year. I come in with my daughter and don't feel like I have to see the whole place in a day. We'll come in see 5 things, do the petting zoo, and come back in a week or two. 

The zoo also participates in a variety of conservation studies and veterinary programs. Many of the animals have been rescued from unfortunate situations and many are helping with genetic research and worldwide conservation studies. 

The annual membership is tax deductible and can get you free admission at other zoos.

Anyway, bottom line is this....set your expectations it's $12-15 per adult (and children 3 and under are FREE) -- this is not Disneyland and it's not the San Diego Zoo.  It's affordable and nice, a fun and sometimes magical place for people to explore.
author: Alex P.

description:
What a wonderful experience at Tue SF zoo!

Even though it was a gloomy day in September, we had a great time.

I love that the zoo has a few cages as necessary and animals have a lot of space to move around. 

Really enjoyed the lion exhibit and the gorillas. 



Entrance fee is $15 for non sf residents and parking is $10 that you can pay at the box office and have ready when you exit
author: Yesi P.

description:
Great zoo!

Lots of animals to see and a fun/easy walk for everyone in the family. Just the right size place - not too big to see in a day, but definitely not too small - lots to see and do.

Not sure what those complaining about the facilities expect from a zoo, but I thought it was very nice. Decent food too!

Best part - the animal habitats were some of the biggest and most comfortable looking I've ever seen. Frankly the San Diego Zoo really bummed me out with tiny pens for their beautiful animals, but SF knows how to treat the wildlife!
author: Joe D.

description: I'm from New England where we don't have giant sprawling zoos and definitely do not have the range of animals because of our climate, so this to me was a fantastic adventure. The open areas and tons of space for all the animals wasn't something I was used to. I definitely enjoyed seeing numerous giraffes, the big cats very up close and my first time seeing a grizzly, live and in living color was scary even from behind the glass. The glass enclosures were great and I loved being so close to some animals like the penguins. Beyond the animals, it's very clean and I found lots of cool fountains and other bushes, trees etc, to play around with my camera, It's a great place for photogs and the closeness of the animals left me many great critter pictures.
author: Darren F.

description: Small but wonderfully set up for just a great day to chill out and enjoy a wide variety of rare animals.  Stop along the way and talk with knowledgeable and friendly staff, this makes the time  here a great experience. Love the Lemurs.
author: Bruce B.

description:
Went to the zoo with my granddaughter.  It is a small zoo and old and slightly rundown.  But still for my 6 year old GD it was a fun time.  She loved the giraffes the best. I like their area the best. It was open and you could walk through the middle and see all the African plain animals up close.

The zoo really needs to be updated-but with no money available I don't see that happening anytime soon.  

The food courts were terrible.  I went to one place where I waited in line for 7 minutes and did not move.  It looked like they only had one employee during Spring break week.  The other food court had three different areas, pizza, deli and the hamburger/hotdog area. The line for that section was very long so I jumped in the deli line which was the shortest.  Again they had staff but need to rework their service lines. Not fun waiting in line for a long time when you are hungry.

The staff was friendly and the park was clean, including the bathrooms.

So, if you are in SF and can't make it to San Diego go to this zoo with little ones. The bigger ones will find it boring and outdated.
author: Ralph T.

description:
Pros:
-Cheap and kid friendly 
-great playground for the kids
-lots of exhibits
-most of the animals are out all the time during the day
-lots of feeding times 

Cons:
-cold (but it is sf so what did you expect)
-no elephants


i LOVE the zoo. I am a huge fan! This zoo never disappoints. However if you go unprepared you might have a bad experience. Its SF so the zoo is going to be cold and windy, the animals need lots of space so you're going to have to walk around for a while to see all the animals and all the exhibits.. If you aren't up for walking just stay at home on your couch and watch tv like you normally do. This zoo is not too easy to navigate but with a map in hand you can figure it out. Make sure you stop by the children's zoo where you can see many more small animals closer up, very cool.
I would also suggest planning your visit around feeding times. It's always fun to see the animals being fed.
author: Laura F.

description: I hadn't been to the SF Zoo in a very long time until very recently. The giraffes, bears, zebras, and flamingos were some of the animals that really stood out. I think for the most part, the zoo staff seems to take very good care of them.
author: Paul N.

description: Guided tour here is awesome! As a penguin lover, I was very impressed with SFO zoo's largest collection of Magellenic penguins in the world-51! Even got to pet a penguin, which made my year. Also saw a Siberian and Sumatran tiger and, even though I couldn't really tell, have different type and color of stripes that work best for each ones' environment. The zookeepers are very knowledgeable, and you can tell they take pride in what they do.
author: Emily P.

description:
Pretty neat place to visit on Christmas Day. They decorated a lot of the enclosures for the holidays. The bears and fishing cats all got Christmas trees. On the day of when I went to visit, many of the animals were given wrapped presents to completely destroy, which was fun to watch especially the little monkeys digging through bags and stockings.

The downside to this place, they lack funds to completely upgrade so the infrastructure is rather sad looking and quite lacking.
author: Lily K.

description:
Beautiful Zoo in a setting that is truly respectful of animals.

Come on the weekdays if you want a little less crowd.

Park outside the park in the diagonals and save yourself eight bucks.
author: Kelly D.

description:
The funding for SF zoo is definitely coming along! I was extremely happy to see the new botanical garden, new rhino and hippo area. I was able to see the new beautiful tiger, sleeping peacefully in her new cage. The new tarantula exhibit was amazing with details and very personal, up-close experience to check out these eight legged creatures in all their glory. A confirmed arachnophobia, I kept my distance from these hairy guys and was able to peer at them at a safe "launching" distance. A lot of construction and planning is still occurring here. 

A lot of changes, clean-up, and larger areas for the animals. I always enjoy coming here. The staff are nice and their bathrooms are decently clean. Expect high prices for food and snacks, but it is what it is. And for quick anything ... well to be honest I'm not there for their train or carousel, pure educational and animal-to-animal appreciation.
author: Jamie L.

description:
I really like this zoo, but really I love any zoo...

Parking is $8, which can be hard to find if you come late in the morning, we got one of the last spots, then you would have to go to street parking.

Admission is $15 for adults, I feel it's a fair price.

The zoo is pretty outdated, but I know over the years they've tried to update enclosures and areas as well as they can.

The layout is a little odd, you'll end up backtracking a couple times, maybe there's a way to avoid that, but I like the extra walking.

My favorite friends are the giraffes, primates, penguins, anteater and large cats. They also have a few new rhinos getting acquainted to their new surroundings that were pretty neat.

We went on a Sunday and the cat house area was closed for a private birthday party.... oooookay? So we could only see the animals from the outside viewing areas. 

The thing I didn't like about this place is that the pathways are really uneven in some parts even though it looks like it had pretty recently been repaved. 

From what I saw the animals looked healthy and content and their homes were well kept.

I know there have been some issues with animals attacking people (obviously provoked), concerns over the well-being of the animals and such, but from what I saw today they seems to be doing a good job here of security and things like that.

I also spoke to a volunteer about the giraffes for a good 15 minutes and got to learn about the 7 or 8 they have right now, a few are quite young, I don't remember names but learned that they are a lot like horses and can suffer for digestive problems more than anything...
author: Karen S.

description:
My kid was begging me to go to SFZoo for a month and we did it!  They have upgraded their food options, selling wine and beer.  

PLEASE tell me when they will upgrade the ZOO options, cause I can go somewhere else to view random animals and they have a kiddie roller coaster.  This trip I felt I was being directed to ALL of the food venues.  Thanks my kids have enough crap food to eat.

What is up with the polar bear, he is pacing pacing pacing and he has green moss on his fur.  the new bear is all nice and fluffy and hasn't gone loco yet.
author: Christy Y.

description:
This was the place to be when you were a kid. 
Unfortunately, now it just seems..sad. Maybe it's just me, but there seems to be less animals than usual. And the animals that are there weren't as lively and happy as I remembered when I was a child. The exhibit where all the snakes, butterflies, and birds were seems to always be closed. 
I did however take my nephew there a few months ago, and he really enjoyed the train ride! 
It's as if everything is exciting when you first walk in and there is so much to do! And then you slowly make your way through the zoo to the other side and it gets bare, and empty. 
I'll still go with my family and what not. Hopefully things will improve!
author: Linnea H.

description:
Better than expected; a good couple-hour date.

Date highlights include Esther the ostrich, brown tiger with no stripes (inside joke), gigantic nut sack with eyes (hippo), blue-ass monkey, and the photo booth.
author: Inigo M.

description:
The baby gorilla is amazing and so are the other gorillas who are taking good care of him. Rejected by his mother and adopted by a new doting surrogate mother, we watched the little guy for hours during my last visit to the zoo. The exhibit is nothing like the incredible Gorilla exhibit at the Omaha Zoo but who the hell wants to go to Nebraska to see Gorillas? The gorillas at the SF zoo seem pretty happy with their home and have lots of personality. I can't wait to go back as the baby gets a little older and even cuter. 

As for the rest of the zoo, it was ok. I really hated how often we got lost and we wasted a lot of time getting out of the maze of unmarked paths. This was the first visit to the zoo in probably over 10 years and when we looked at the cat exhibit we could not figure out how it would be possible for Tatiana to jump or scale the moat but apparently according to physics experts its completely possible. I still think some dumbshit left the latch to her back cage open but who knows. I thought it was lame they have no memorial to her that I saw, but I guess as a zoo you don't need a big sign reminding you during your visit that one of the tigers ate some punk. 

The other exhibits were cool if you like zoos, which I generally don't, but honestly the Omaha Zoo ruined me for all other zoos. I will go back to SF Zoo but maybe when i return to see my favorite baby gorilla I will bring my GPS so I don't get as lost. 

http://arxivblog.com/?p=255&cpage=1

http://picasaweb.google.com/itsfzoo/BabyGorilla#
author: Lisa J.

description:
This Zoo is special. For the people, the history and of course the animals are all a part of making it feel like a community place to belong to and hang out at.

Also something uniquely inspiring happened the other day at the Zoo. The gentleman handling the Intern Reindeer position made a profound impression on us. He was knowledgeable, genuine and inviting like most folks there but he was passionately and gently empowering in a sharing conversation on the depth and breadth of zoo history, lore, animal information and vision for the future priorities and projects for the zoo. He made us have a personal connection that only a human conversation can do with a lovely context us taking a next step and a grounded inspired charming eloquence. This is the kind of person that turns members into Donors because he made me care.  We all look forward to seeing him our next visit.
author: Trella D.

description: Came here at 10:30am and stayed until 2pm and we walked around the zoo maybe twice (because we kept getting lost due to the lack of signs around) and we barely saw any animals! So disappointing when my two girls were looking forward to seeing all these animals and they didn't see any!
author: Hao H.

description:
For a world class city, we sure do have a 2nd rate zoo. 

The exhibits are poorly designed with little information displayed on what you are exactly looking at. Each time I visit here, I leave a little depressed. This is probably due to the conditions that animals have to exist in. 

I really have no issue with the admission price as it does take some serious $$ to maintain a facility. However where is all the money going? It certainly isn't going back into the zoo.
author: Rene C.

description: Went here with my family. Wow it's really changed, mind you I haven't been here in years. We parked for free on the street and avoided the parking fee by not parking in their lot. The entrance price per adult was $17.00. We got there right after they opened and I was excited to see the gorillas. We waited a few minutes and then they came out.  Most of the animals we saw were not active and just resting. Not as I remember as a child going there. I have to admit it was a bit depressing and sad knowing they can't roam free in their natural habitat. But I do understand the educational purpose of the zoo. Bring your own water and snacks. A bottled water at the zoo is 4 dollars. Wear comfortable shoes and bring a jacket it can get cold and windy. We walked all over and mostly had a good time exploring. We were there on a Saturday and it was baby stroller palooza, I was almost tripped by someone who was pushing a stroller and not looking where they were going. Anyways be careful and have fun! :)
author: Christine C.

description: This a great little zoo to spend several hours or an entire day. They have many diverse animals, from giraffes to rhinos, to big cats and insects. I went on a Monday and spent about three hours and still didn't see everything. The only con is the weather sometimes can be a little chilly...than again, it is SF.
author: John D.

description:
I went on a nice, sunny Sunday afternoon but was surprised when a lot of the animals weren't out or were laying out in the sun where visitors couldn't see them that well. Silly animals. 

Anyway, this place is large, and many 'exhibits' had plenty of room for the animals to move about. There were a handful of spots that were closed off or missing animals, but overall I liked the variety they had. The penguins were the highlight for me. Yay penguins! By the time we got to the children's zoo they were shutting down so we didn't get to see those animals :( 

I personally think the price is a little high, but then again I haven't been to a zoo in a loooong time. $15 for non-SF residents and $12 for residents. Parking is $10 in their lot, but we found street parking and walked. 

Bottom line: Good time for anyone, probably even moreso for kids. It's not Sea World or Busch Gardens, but then again no one really expects it to be.
author: Miffy Y.

description:
Okay, i give this zoo 3 stars instead of 2 purely because of nostalgia.

I used to come to this zoo every year as a child for field trips, and every month with my mom. It has so many great memories and i remember seeing all the amazing lively animals. I remember going to the old lion house where for a little period of time during the day they would FILL with all their big cats. You could hear the place roar and it was really a sight to see standing in this old victorian building.

Unfortunately, whether because of funding or the lack of interest this place has gone downhill. many of their amazing old animals have passed and not replaced, and many of the buildings lie unused. The animals seem a little sad and the place feels deserted at times. Its a shame because i think it's one of the better done zoos in the country. 

I hope this place sees a resurgence soon, and based on some of the more recent reviews it sounds like it has gotten a little better. keeping my fingers crossed!
author: James F.

description:
I had so much fun at the zoo today! It had been years since I had last gone to the zoo and my boyfriend and I just decided that it would be a great idea for a date if we went- and it was so much fun!

I'll admit that this zoo didn't have as much animals as I had thought but it was enough for us to spend 2 hours walking around and looking at everything. It's a fun experience for those who hadn't been to zoos for a while and don't really remember what to expect. 

I felt a little depressed about the animals at times but at the same time felt happy for those animals that had been injured in the wild and now have a place that they can safely inhabit and be well-taken care of. 

Anyways, overall, the zoo was clean and well-kept, the staff were friendly and we went on a weekday so there weren't that many people- I really enjoyed learning about the different animals and being able to come so close to certain animals (i.e bears, tigers, peacocks, etc)- it was a great experience.

P.S: It would have been much better if the staff would actually take care of the bathrooms once in a while...I mean, come on, I went on a Tuesday- there's hardly any people there yet the staff couldn't find time to take care of the bathroom?? The toilets don't even flush- and it smells REALLY bad.
author: Kelly Y.

description: We had a nice day at the zoo we are a military family so we're able to get in at the cost of San Francisco residents so that was a bonus. Although there werehypnos of animals there were also certain animals that we were looking for that we did not see there maybe we somehow overlooked the ELEPHANTS!!! All of that aside the zoo was really great! The prices of the gift shop items were too high just like every other gift shop in the world so that was no big shocker. But all in all it was a really nice experience.
author: Aszure G.

description:
There are animals, what's not to like! 
The only reason I give it three stars is because it really needs to be updated. Half of the zoo feels so old but they are making some renovations so that's good. 
Also, the layout is kind of weird.

If you are an SF resident and can prove it (i.e. Drivers License, Phone Bill, etc) than the first Wednesday of every month is free - that is worth 5 stars!!
author: Thea M.

description:
The SF zoo is a mixed bag:

Good
-------
 
  * Grisley Bear exhibit - Thank you hearst family.
  * Penguins - They get to swim around in what appears to be a large, converted fountain. But being rascally penguins they love it. Its spacious, open air, and a much nicer habitat then their cousins get at the academy of science. 
  * African Safari - another well designed exhibit which includes giraffes and zebras. Get there early for the feeding.
  * The steam train - Fun for kids.

Bad
-----
  * Many of the other exhibits where the animals are in concrete pens with poorly painted versions of their native habitat as a backdrop.
  * Parking - just park across the street for free.
  * The rhinoceros with his horn cut off. It's not his fault. But in the concrete ben with an old yoga ball it was just sad. 

Ugly
------
  * The rain forest exhibit - a half empty, humid room that looks like a military bunker from Star Wars.
  * The empty exhibits and abandoned buildings.
author: Matthew S.

description: Took my girlfriend to the zoo for her birthday as we're both huge animal lovers,  I loved the zoo, as did she. Will definitely be returning in the future to see what the animals are doing next! The aye-aye tour was awesome, it was cool to learn that there's only a couple dozen in captivity and that they were going to be sending theirs to London soon, felt very lucky to see such a creature before they are gone! Oh and if you decide to go to the petting zoo part and buy feed from the machine, watch out. A goat might push you out of the way and eat all the food as soon as the machine spits it out.
author: Jake H.

description: The membership fees are really good.  The size of the zoo is just right.  Just the bathrooms smell a little bad and I avoid them if I can.
author: Mitch M.

description:
NOTE, I apologize for turning this review into a semi-rant but this is what I took away from my experience:

Today I visited the SF Zoo for the first time in at least 10 years. It has changed considerably since I last visited as a kid. I tend to avoid zoos now that I've grown up. I find them pretty depressing when you consider these animals will never roam in their natural habitats again. But since I don't have the money yet to travel to distant countries to view them in the wild, the SF Zoo is the closest many of us ever get to see these animals. 

I have only recently begun to appreciate wildlife and I have quite an interest in big cats, so seeing them outside of a nature documentary was pretty exciting. I was able to view the Sumatran tigers, Leanne & Larry, as well as their new 8-week old cub. The cub was adorable, pestering her mother and attacking everything in sight. The glass barriers in some areas are pretty filthy & scratched-up so its a little hard to see clearly at times. 

While the enclosure for Leanne & her cub was quite a rich environment for the two to live in, the rest of the areas for the big cats were smaller and frankly pretty bleak. The Siberian tiger slowly paced around its enclosure while constantly bellowing(not roaring, it was more of a crying/wailing tone) as it was gawked at by dozens of loud kids and visitors. The snow leopard hid itself next to a log, its head wearily resting on its paws as if it was waiting to die. The bobcat also paced frantically back and forth in its small enclosure. I admit I'm no zoologist, but these did not seem like "happy" animals to me.

However I was glad to see that other animals like the gorillas, zebras and giraffes seemed to have nicer areas to live in. I cannot fault the SF Zoo for too much else besides the size of their enclosures. The staff seems to genuinely love their work and they are definitely providing better care than animal theme parks or circuses. Its a really beautiful place which has been carefully designed to incorporate elements of lands where some of these animals come from. While the SF Zoo is only 100-acres, its spread out in a way that gives you a long walk if you wish to see everything. Also wear layers since it tends to get cold out there. 

But I remain a critic(no I am not a supporter/member of PETA or the ALF)...
So why you ask, am I still critical of zoos?

1) Because their main purpose is exhibition, NOT conservation. Some zoos may donate some of their profits here and there to conservation efforts, but how much of that money is used and where it goes/how effective it is for conservation is debatable.
2) The zoo's goal to breed endangered animals for species survival is somewhat pointless when you consider many of these animals only know captivity and not their true environments. Few animals that spend any length of time in captivity can be released in the wild again.
3) It is cruel to restrict a wild animal's range of movement or their natural behavior, EVEN if loved and properly cared for. Large predators for instance, require large amounts of land to roam and were meant to hunt, not to be fed raw meat. Many animals go insane, sometimes banging their heads against walls or constantly pacing back & forth. I am a believer in open-range zoos, even though they cost more and are probably much harder to maintain. 
4) "A fat lion lying in a zoo enclosure waiting for chopped up cow meat once a day is not the same as that animal with amber shoulder blades pumping mechanically through the tall grass downwind of the buffalo, stopping, looking, snapping a look at eight other sets of black tipped ears ahead, in a silent signal adapted by evolution for the hunt. It's not the same as that animal that shoots out of the grass and grasps on to a buffalo in full flight, nearly a thousand pounds of muscle, and brings it to its knees with only its teeth and claws. One is a 3-D image. One is a real living, fighting, killing lion that influences the habitat it lives in, in Africa (and Asia.) There is no replacement for that." -Dereck Joubert

As I visited the SF Zoo, many questions were raised in my mind. If animals have no rights, then what gives us the right to exploit them and kill them? Are we justified in doing so just because "we can"? How soon will it be before the only wild animals left on Earth are the ones you see in zoos? Is it possible that many iconic animals like the tiger, lion, elephant and rhino will become extinct before our children grow up? Is the damage irreversible?
author: Paul E.

description:
I love zoos so I am giving this five stars.

Not as expansive as the San Diego Zoo perhaps, but if you come during the daytime there is hardly people there (meaning less people to compete to look at animals). The Giraffe exhibit is pretty cool, they share a space with a few other Safari animals so it is worth a visit. You can try feeding/petting the peacocks, they aren't scared of visitors and will even snatch food from the unsuspecting person.
author: Jean L.

description:
Ya know... I gave it another shot, although I had promised I wouldn't.

Here's the key... don't park in the lot.  I didn't this time, after having a horrible experience with the lot full and no way to get out on my previous visit.

Some of the empty exhibits were full now... there's a hippo and seals now where before there were just two empty exhibits... upgrade.

It was nice... there are still a few things I'd tweak... that poor (and beautiful) snow leopard could use some more space and those polar bears just always look so frigging sad.  But... it was much better this time than the last I went.

I may even go back at some point.  We'll see.
author: Bjorn S.

description: This place absolutely sucks. The employees are extremely rude. After 45 minutes there was nothing to do. A lot of the habitats were empty and the animals looked super miserable. Everything is ripped off at the zoo too and theres nothing to do.
author: Darian L.

description:
I'm a little kid at heart and I have an incredible soft spot for all animals and i must kind of brag but animals tend to love me too lol. I've been to many zoo's all over the world and i'd have to say that other then the zoo in Ireland this  is pretty up there! It's truly a feel good atmosphere and on sunny days this is just a truly perfect place to get away from the troubles that linger in our minds.. 

Not only great place for kids but its really enjoyable for everyone of all ages, as long as you like animals of course! I honestly recommend this to anyone, its easy going and laid back but also interesting and obviously everyday is a chance to learn something new! =)
author: Jessica M.

description:
I was set up to be disappointed by this Zoo but I have to say, I really enjoyed my visit here. My boyfriend and I came on a date, and we had a wonderful time. The SF Zoo is much bigger than it appears from the outside, so you can really spend a day walking around and enjoying the animals. 

Although a lot of the exhibits are small, they don't seem dirty. I do have to say though, that poor lone seal did look extremely depressed...

However, their gorilla enclosure is AMAZING. They have a little baby boy gorilla in there who is so playful, and they've set up extra barriers to that the baby is more comfortable. We could have stood there for hours, watching him run around and play.

Also, they give discounts to SF State students!
author: Rachel A.

description:
When the boyfriend and I vacationed to the city I knew that the zoo was one of the things I really wanted to see. Back home on the Big Island of Hawaii we don't have an impressive zoo; it's simple and small with a few exotic animals. 

I was blown away by how well kept the San Francisco zoo was and how many animals they had! My favorite spot was by the giraffe's housing; I have never seen one in person, and man was it awesome! They are such gorgeous animals :)

I wish we could've gone earlier, it was almost closing time when we got there, so most of the animals were mellowing out for the day. However, it was still an awesome experience, and the $22 we spent for admission was well worth it.
author: Regina G.

description:
new rules: only san franciscans can enter the zoo for free first wednesdays of the month. boooooooooo. Im a native, but my bf isnt..sigh.

they also have roaming skunks now.
author: kim w.

description:
So the SF Zoo website had a Gay Pride coupon where adults can get $2 off admission making it $13.  Not bad huh?  And you don't have to be gay.  The coupon is good for up to four people.

Things we saw (in no particular grouping):
-Zebra, Giraffe, Kudu, Ostrich, Gorilla, Oryx, Aviary
-Lemur Forest
-Mandrill, Patas Monkey, Chimpanzee
-Black Swan, flamingos, birds
-Lion, tiger
-Duiker, Blackbuck, Muntjac, Warthog, Anteater, Tapir, Capybara, Stork
-Grizzly Gulch, Eagle Island, Black Rhino, Bears (black and polar)
-Koala, Kangaroos
-Cassowary, Pelican Beach
-Prairie dog, Meerkat, Hawk Hill
-Insect Zoo, Family Farm
-Seal, Penguins
-Aye-aye (nocturnal animal.... so nuts!!)

I know the list may bring forth "oooh's" or "ahhh's" but let me forewarn you that most of the animals were either asleep or looked half dead, especially the seal and one of the kangaroos.  My favorites of the day were the Toucan-looking-bird, anteater (zot zot), and the aye-aye's (endangered nocturnal primate that you have to look at in the dark).  

Animals exhibits that were closed or empty:
-Asian Rhino
-Lion House (only one tiger and it was sleeping)
-South American Tropical Forest (closed for renovation 2009)

I wanted to ride the Little Puffer Steam Train but it was an extra $4 per person.  LAME.  Listen to everyone, park on the street, and save $8.  There's plenty of parking on Sloat Blvd., at least on weekdays!
author: Shannon L.

description: Just got outta here. Place is awesome. Wasnt windy today either. I think they should add snakes to the exhibit. And they shouldnt charge for parking. That is a lil ridiculous. The best part is they have beeeeeeerrrrrrr.
author: Augie K.

description:
Be sure to check the weather before you come to the zoo because it could get really chilly. I called the day before asking if we were able to bring our own food, and the guy told me no. Come to find out, you ARE able to bring your own food (which would have saved us tons of $$)- most items are overpriced. I saw people bringing in coolers and their own packed lunched. The people who check you in don't check what you're bringing so it would be wise to pack your own food and drinks.

We got there at 1030 AM and most of the animals were still sleeping. It seems that the park is doing a lot of remodeling. The park seems so big, but after walking around all the attractions...We ended up saying "that's it??"  What mattered most was that the kids had fun throughout the day. They do have a "childrens zoo" where the kids are able to pet and feed certain farm animals. The zoo separates the animals by their origins and  the map they give you is pretty basic and easy to follow, plus they have signs everywhere. It seemed like everything was in a circle so you'll probably end up at the same place more than once. 

Parking can get really crowded later in the afternoon so it's best to come early. Sometimes the lines can't get long too.  You can find the prices in the zoos website so be sure to check that out as well.
author: Sharon G.

description: I took my whole family's witch included  about 27 of us. I found it very sad to see that the zoo has changed so much and not  for the good. I totally understand that funds are tight.  But my funds are super tight too. For me to spend $405 dollars to get in and another $50 dollars for parking is ridiculous thats not even counting to gifts and food inside.  The park was clean! That was awesome! But it seemed to  not have a lot to do or a lot of exhibits opened. Many animals were just not available. There were no elephants.  That has always been one of our fav animals to see and even better to get the elephant rides! I think people would want to donate if there was something worth donating too! Maybe do some outside zoo events and ask for donations.
author: Dona V.

description:
As a kid, I would come here during the first Wednesday of the month in the summer. My aunt would take a day off and take my cousins, brother & I here. It was our tradition. When I'm old and a grandma, I think my cousins and I would take our grandkids here during the summer, just like my aunt did.

The last time I came here, it wasn't the same. I saw empty cages, where are the animals?! It sort of feels empty now.

I miss seeing the sea lions and etc between the bears and white building. They keep dying off, I think they're all gone now :[ I want them replaced, that was one of my fav attractions.

I prefer coming on a day it's free vs. a day you pay. More stores, kiosks & etc are open. I don't like coming here when it's empty, feels sad and gloomy.
author: Kylie L.

description:
I came down recently as a spur of the moment trip and birthday gift to my 2 year old when we spent a weekday together. 

It was a cold December Tuesday, and the park was practically empty! A few hundred kids maybe from private schools. But we saw everything without lines or annoying people hogging up the front. We spent a good amount of time in the children's farm and smelling the goats. We missed the bear feeding though, and I was bummed to find out there were no more elephants! Also the gorillas weren't out but I was excited to see giraffes, tigers, a lion, bears and the penguins... I'm not really an animal person at all, but I am a nature TV nerd and watch documentaries.. it's always nice to be able to see them in person, even if it's a zoo. 

There were some nice ladies who were either staff or volunteers walking around and making small talk with the few visitors, and that's how I found out about the elephants. 

I think my daughter enjoyed it (she just turned 2). She loved the penguins and flamingoes.  She was also stoked to see a Christmas reindeer!! That was fun. But she was mostly excited about the playground...we were there for a while.

$15 admission wasn't bad at all! We were there from opening until about 2 pm and saw the whole park in that span and didn't rush to get around at all. Even had time for a no-pressure lunch at the Lemur cafe -- which I must say had very decent prices for park food! (I enjoyed my clam chowder in a bread bowl very much and my daughter loved her mac n cheese). I even had a random conversation with a nearby diner about cameras ;-)

I love the zoo, and we will be back here with the whole family soon!

Lots of free street parking on these slow school days!! Totally worth taking a day off for to spend quality family time.
author: Anio D.

description:
My friend and I came to the San Francisco Zoo for the first time in over 5 years on a Monday morning.  The zoo was pretty deserted, which was nice in a way since we did not have to deal with parking issues or crowds.  One thing we really liked about the layout of the zoo was that the trees and greenery were seamlessly integrated with exhibits and the walkways.  Unfortunately, the penguin feeding takes place around 10:30 AM, so we missed that.  The zoo itself is not very large, so we were able to thoroughly visit all of the exhibits in 3 hours, with extra time in between to chit chat and get to know one another better:)

Do not skip out on the South American Tropical Rainforest building.  There is a new interactive Rainforest Adventure Maze that's pretty fun and surprisingly enlightening.  The maze leads you through a series of questions, right answers leading you through the maze, wrong answers leading to dead ends.  My friend and I are both pretty smart cats so we got them all right...except we got tricked on the last one =P  Also included in the maze are monkey bars, zip lines, long jump, and ropes for kids to have fun and simulate different parts of the rainforest.  In case you were wondering, I was slow on the bars while my friend was super quick and agile.

The bald eagle is unfortunately a loser as it cannot fly, so it just chills on a branch all day long; however, my friend loves this country and chanting, "USA!  USA!  USA!"  so anytime he gets to see a bald eagle it's always a treat.  He also really liked how peacocks walk around and mingle with park guests.  If you're lucky they might even show their feathers to you, but no such luck for us :(  It was also interesting to note the discrepancy between the exhibits - some of the animals, such as the lemurs, had pretty nice enclosures, whereas others, such as the bears and lions, did not.

In summary, The SF Zoo is definitely not world class, but they do have great animals and is a fun way to spend a few hours in the city.
author: Andrea W.

description: I was awed by this zoo, which is an all-day affair compared with the much smaller Sacramento zoo. The animals appeared to have ample room to roam, and many were rehabilitated. The tigers, bears, and monkeys with inflatable throat sacs were especially memorable. The food in the main cafe in the center of the zoo was actually not bad! Thank goodness.
author: Stacy G.

description: I have been to many zoos. This is far from the worst and over priced for what it is. There is no love or care put into this zoo. No personality. The exhibits are small and limit. I do feel sorry for these animals. Try Fresno.  So much better. To give a positive outlook right across of the zoo....wonderful beautiful site seeing beach. Walk along the beach for miles.
author: Tracy J.

description: The education center is comfortable, nice roaring fire in the back, great AV system.  Good place to have a conference.  Drawbacks are round tables so people have to turn chairs to see and no wifi.  Parking was free for conference attendees.  We didn't go into the zoo but we did see giraffes.  The lunch was just ok, make your own sandwich spread, boring and not much for vegetarians.
author: Rebecca H.

description: A fine place for little kids, but this isn't the San Diego Zoo. My opinion is it's in between a top notch zoo and a depressing place with trapped animals. Seems like the Zoo would benefit from a strong dose of funding.
author: Michael S.

description:
Loved this place when we first came here, and it was particularly a windy day a bit, it didn't stop us from coming. Came here with the little one and the bubz, to learn about the animals, plus this place is a great place to have a walk. Prepare to bring your workout/day shoes though, I walked around in sandals and did it hurt my feet.

Like many yelpers said, there are a very limited amount of animals here, and hopefully they can get more soon, because I would love to come back here for tor the long term.
author: Carol T.

description: Best Zoo ever by far! everyone loved it and had a great time!
author: Adeena B.

description: Just went today and it was amazing. The zoo is not as big as the San Diego zoo that i am used to going to but i still enjoyed it. Parking on the street is free and save you $8. Went at 10:00 when the park opens and all the animals were out and about. Got to see the tiger and its cub. Cant wait to go back.
author: Elizabeth A.

description:
If I were an animal (preferably a lemur) Id totally choose this zoo. Fine, it's not San Diego.... but it's near the beach, you get the best climate, you get to breath in the fresh Pacific, and actually enjoy a decent habitat. Ever been to the Sacramento Zoo? No? Then shut up. 

You know that scene in Jurassic Park, when they first see the brontosaurus? (or whatever)- that's what the giraffe area reminded me of... Gorgeous tall old cypress trees.... Lush, freshness everywhere. Cat house? Off the hook.Try visiting close to feeding time- I was able to walk a tiger to lunch. Check out the rad wondrous primate place as well.I'm also a sucker for petting zoos- (dont get dirty now!)  and this one is pretty neat- goats climb rocks like mountains, free roaming peacocks get cocky almost everywhere you try to walk, and kids really do learn a lot with hands on activities. The gift shop is surpringly cheaper than most- there are several neat things I wish I would have bought.  The espresso stand adds a nice touch-very good drinks, service with a smile. Hit this place up almost any time that's not too sunny- you're bound to see almost every if not all creatures.
author: Rosemary W.

description: This was the lamest zoo I have ever been to. If you want to pay to see peacocks wandering around, go for it! If not, don't wast your money and go to the Oakland zoo. That's right, Oakland.
author: Shannon R.

description: We love this zoo and the price is right ! the other thing we love is that the beach is across the street! perfection!
author: Maria Carmen D.

description: Great zoo for the family and kids. We really enjoyed walking around the exhibits. The African Savanah with the giraffes is a big highlight from a "wow" perspective. The petting zoo, though, is an amazing place for the kids. Feeding animals by hand is amazing. Don't miss this for sure. You have to put quarters in for the food, but there are plenty of change machines and the staff is really helpful. The train ride is really fun and pretty fast (in a good way). Also the food area is quite reasonable given the portions. My only issue is that many of the big animals seem very far away. We love going thinking we'll make a day of it, go see the beach across the street, and maybe even Golden Gate Park. But we always end up exhausted. Tip: it's a bit tough when it's warm.
author: LovinLife Z.

description:
We came here to beat the heat on the peninsula- it was definitely chilly and foggy. 

The zoo isn't as sad as the other reviewers suggest ( but the pacing tiger did make me sad). 

It's a nice retreat from the city. A good variety of animals and enough to spend the afternoon exploring.
author: Annie c.

description: Great Place to spend with you little ones ........ we like it we come here ones a month or so...... will see u soon again.
author: Boris M.

description: My family and I came here this past weekend and had a really great time. My son was turning 4 and I thought this would be a fun place to visit and it definitely did not disappoint us. The animals were fun to see especially the peacocks and baby gorilla. The food near the train ride was really good! Cheeseburger was very good and the garlic fries one of the best I've ever had. We bought the Icee souvenir cup and also was able to have free refills the entire day (huge plus). My son loved everything! He loved the train ride, playground and wolverine was there taking pictures and signing cards. Weather was perfect! We would definitely come here again. The only down fall was the parking lot was full when we got there at 11. We drove down one street and parked for free! Saved $10!!
author: Briana B.

description: The Zoo, the zoo my family loves going to the zoo. But they don't like this zoo. I was living up near Palo Alto and I went to this zoo in order to take my kids with the grandparents. This zoo was smaller than the zoo in Lows Angeles and if you can believe it was almost as outdated and dirty. None of the animals looked happy be too stuck there and it made a very sad experience. My children left unhappy because they were sad for the animals. Next time I go up north I will not be wasting my time with this zoo.
author: Gary M.

description: Our trip to the Sf zoo was very pleasant like usual. We were delighted to see the new exhibits and found the staff very helpful. The food was good. We were excited to see that there was an show today. The animal show was lackluster. Just a bunch of volunteers carrying animals around for the audience to see. The host Camden talked to everyone as of we were young children. Yes there are children but the show needs to be appealing for both children and adults. We almost walked out because my husband and I felt uncomfortable. The stage wasn't even used. Which is a shame because it would allowed the audience to see the animals better. I have been to a few animal shows and this probably was my least favorite.
author: Danie W.

description:
The zoo is an alright place. I'm sure this is great for kids. I definitely heard some kids totally freaking out when some of the animals were getting up and moving. Heheh. Does the heart good. Personally, I wasn't quite so excitable, but I did like getting to see a zoo worker feed a hippo - definitely the highlight of my trip. Hippos are big and cute. I want one as a pet. I'm sure that would work. 

There's a pseudo-train that runs through the entire zoo and is slightly obnoxious in its  efforts to get you to pay money to ride it, but that's probably the worst. The food isn't *too* overpriced like you might expect. 

So yeah, it's a zoo.
author: Grant M.

description: Cant throw rocks at the animals, too crowded, too noisy, too many crying kids can't even enjoy walking around cus there's always a loud ass kid. Got lost, had to get help. Going to the oakland zoo
author: Lola J.

description: The zoo itself is great but the staff is very unfriendly! I never seen one person smile even when asking them questions! The workers in the lemur cafe seemed happier when we walked away with our 21.00 sandwiches!!!!! They should have a seminar for their workers on how to enjoy your job!!!!
author: Tabitha M.

description:
*        ______________________________
         [________SAN FRANCISCO________]
         [     @@@@       @@@@      @@@@    ]
         [                 @       @        @      @        @    ]
         [              @          @        @      @        @    ]
         [           @             @        @      @        @    ]
         [      @@@@      @@@@      @@@@    ]
         [______________________________]    


During the Great Depression,  the San Francisco Fleishacker Zoo (65 acres)  was built along with the Fleishacker (sea salt water) Olympic sized pool.    A family our size (14 children) would  never be able travel throughout the world to see the various types of animals that they had on exhibit for the past 60 plus years.  It perked our appetite  to go to the library or buy books to learn more of the hundreds of mammals, snakes, birds, etc.

In the 1980s, (7 years), I was a volunteer for the Zoo doing various types of behind the scene work (i.e., feeding the small critters like monkeys, penguins, birds, goats, etc.).  Throughout the years, I would bring my sons, nieces or nephews to the Zoo and I must admit  that for the last year I have not visited the Zoo until today (January 3, 2008).

I felt a sadness for this place that I had found to be so full of surprises and joy, the playground, the train, the Merry-Go-Round, the petting zoo and all the beautiful inhabitants.  I wanted to learn what has changed, what can I do to make a difference.  So, I joined as a Guardian Keeper and will be signing up as a volunteer on January 17 for training.

What I have learned so far.  The Zoo has improved the compounds and have been on a tier program of improvements for all its inhabitants.   They have just completed the Hearst Grizzly Gulch, rescued animals like the elephant seal pups from the Marine Mammal Center spent the final part of their  rehabilitation, exchanging and learning from animal experts from all over the world to improve the care and returning rescued mammals to their original location.  Of course, the babies that were orphaned were hand raised and their chance for survival would be in the Zoo.  For example, once the two male giraffes were grown and strong enough to start their own herd, they were  moved to the Birmingham Zoo in Alabama and Niambi Zoo in Illinois, this year.  And, the new addition of two new males and four new red females added to the Australian Walkabout.

Lest, I  will never forget the beautiful and the short-lived life of Tatiana, the Siberian Tiger.  We all know the unfortunate story and hopefully, that the lesson learned and improvements for the protection of the existing inhabitants.

UPDATE: 

On January 17, I attended the Orientation for Volunteers and signed on for the Animal Resource Center (ARC) .  First, I have to go to the local Police Department (either Daly City, Colma or San Mateo Police) and have a background check and finger printed (how exciting!).  Then, I will be making arrangements with the ARC Coordinator for my schedule.  I wanted to work with the small critters that are brought to the School in the Bay Area.  I declined the reptiles and snakes (they have the big Boa!)   I told them anything that has teeth bigger than mine I do not want to feed it or it might eat me.
So, I will be handling chincillas, small monkeys, birds of all kinds, etc.  The shifts are 8 hours increments once a week or more if you choose.  Check with Liz Brager (Volunteer/Docent Manager) at 753-7122 for scheduling and more information. So, stay posted for my adventure at the SF Zoo!
author: Marian G.

description:
Kind of depressing place to go. haha No really though. The tickets were about $15 per person. When we got into the park, none of the animals were out, and if they were, they would be either laying down starring into nowhere, or sleeping. It was quite boring. 

However, the Lion's Den made up for most of the trip. The tigers, lions, and cheetahs were out all, and we saw them feeding, so that was pretty cool. Was able to catch some grizzly bears playing with each other too, but that was about it. The facts board located next to every animal exhibit was not as informative and fun as Monterey Bay Aquarium (Should've gone there instead). 

Thank goodness my boyfriend was with me to keep me entertained, I would've been so bored out of my mind!
author: Angela T.

description:
I have taken my children to this zoo 2 times and I have each time I think I have enjoyed it more than they have! 

Besides the run of the mill zoo animals, this zoo has a petting zoo and an area geared towards families and kids.  There is also a little train that will take you around the zoo, for an extra fee of course.  

The only negative thing I can say about this zoo is that I feel like some of the animal housing structures were kind of old and could use a face lift.  When you first come into the zoo, you walk into the section with the giraffes which is by far my favorite part.  The enclosures look new as well as the viewing platforms.  However, it seems the further you get into the zoo, the less newer it feels.  Don't get me wrong, I love how a lot of the structures still have the art deco feel. I can just imagine kids running around from animal to animal.  But a lot of it feels out of place in 2012.  By the time you get to the bears, it seems like they have all been but forgotten.  

Admission price is a little expensive, however what in San Francisco isn't?  If you are staying at a hotel, check the front desk.  I was able to get a flyer that had a free child's admission coupon on it.  Parking is $10 unless you can find free parking on the street.  But I don't even try and fight it, I just give in and pay to park.  

There are several cafes through out the zoo and lots of places to enjoy your lunch.  I would recommend bringing in your own food as the zoo food is pricey.  

Another thing I like about the zoo is the location.  It is not in the city so you don't even feel like you are in San Francisco.  It is in close proximity to the beach as well.  

Adults and children a like will enjoy this zoo and the animals!
author: Jenna T.

description:
I love the zoo, especially giraffes. 
The African Savannah part was absolutely awesome with amazing, picturesque views.
That's where the beautiful views, sadly end.
Because of that group of stupid boys who baited the tiger into escaping there are now huge, view-obstructing, plastic walls you have to strain to see through. They are always dirty and scratched and the tiger that's left is sadly pacing back and forth.
Not the awesome zoo of my past.
author: Kylee C.

description:
The first Wednesday of the month is. . . 

FREE ZOO DAY!

Yes my friends it is. But I have to warn you, get there early or finding parking will be as rare as finding me in a one piece swim suit. Also, beware of the over population of my bargain hunting and curry loving Indians that crowd the zoo on Free Zoo Day. Besides that, So much overwelming excitement upon entering the zoo, it'll have you shouting, "Oh shnitzzle they have GIRAFFE'S here!?"

Watch families rejoice. Watch men, women and Infants yell at the scene of incredible looking animals most of which rest on their behinds and stare. Watch the Men cheer while the polar bear moves an inch. Watch women jump orgasmically to the scene of the kangaroo hopping, as if the Girls Gone Wild cameras are on. Children astonished and jump from monkey to monkey. Exitement my friends! Look out for adorable Pengies! ferocious Cheetahs! (that look like your girlfriend) Lazy Lions! Colorful Peacocks! George W Chimps! Giraffe eye lashes! Sasquatch! What? It's possible. Anyway... Con, prices for food at the zoo resembles the Airport. Tip, bring lots of dollars and bring a camera too. (And no you can't bargain here, nor avoid my Curry loving species).
:D.

Open 10-5 daily.
Adults: $11
Youth: $8
Babies: $0
author: Sani S.

description:
For my science class i had to go either the San Francisco Zoo or/and Steinhart Aquarium (California of Science) for a self guided field trip. For my paper I have to observe animals. 

My boyfriend keep bragging that he hasn't gone to the Zoo in a long time and and I should bring him along. I haven't came here in years too. so, we went to the zoo during the weekday. So we picked a day when it was nice outside. 

Addmission are pretty pricey, $15. But if you take muni, show them your transfer and you get a $1 off. I would of payed the resident price, $12, cause I live near the zoo - living with my Uncle. But I dont have any proof I do. It has my parents address in my California ID card. 

We came to the zoo early morning when it opened up and looked around according to the Zoo map first. Having a glance at some animals and seeing if any of them was active at all and watching the scenery. Pretty relaxing walk looking at animals. Some where active, some wheren't there. 

We took the Steam puff Train Ride - $4 per person. Pretty pricey, but we havent came here in a long time. 

They were a lot of places weren't open cause it was probably for the summer - more active in the summer I assume. 

At the end of the day, I observed a squirrel monkey - it was the only one active.
author: Gen M.

description:
What a wonderful experience. I have never been to the SF Zoo, but I am so glad that I came here. I underestimated the size of the zoo, and I was impressed by the different areas. They make it a point to refrain from overly "caging" the animals. They provide an atmosphere that is fun for the visitors and safe for the animals as well. 

I would definitely go back!
author: Kare B.

description:
I can't say I saw the whole zoo but I can say these few things:

The food is expensive but it kicks the hell out of Oakland's zoo food.  

The kids zoo is way better than Oakland

The exhibits make it much easier to see the animals compared to Oakland.

Does the sun ever shine here, poor animals.  Cold, windy and always foggy
author: Daniel W.

description:
Other reviews noted noticing the lack of funds noticable through maintainence & staff...I didn't see it. It seemed very adequately staffed and it was clean, not in disrepair and looked like a zoo. Regearding depressed looking animals...what zoo have you been to where they didn't look that way? There were alot of animals to see and the all looked well-nourished. I went to a bathroom close to the front, late in the day & it was gross. There seemed to be alot of activities for children. I have no children and it was easy to avoid those activities.

The zoo is close to the coast and was quite cool. Bring a jacket! 

You can 'see' the whole zoo in 2-3 hours.

The giraffe feeding is very, very good. The giraffes are up-close.

I'm from DC where the zoo is free so $15/person seemed pricey to me.
author: Suzanne R.

description:
OMG!! I saw this shirt yesterday at True SF on Haight St.
Holy crap it's too hard to hold in the lulz! (I'm sorry!)

http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/dFVZdcbM8dZLJluzIB0ODQ/l
author: Jaye C.

description:
During my undergraduate days I supported myself by exchanging childcare for rent. Yes folks, I was a nanny. And anyone who's ever spent any time with small children knows that animals are a thing of love for them - what they talk about at night before bed, what they are still talking about in the morning at breakfast. LEMUR! BEAR! GIRAFFE! If they can tell you nothing else, they can tell you what animals they love (which is typically any animal they know the name of.)

I happen to hate zoos but if you find yourself with an energy-filled toddler on your hands, this is a great place to run him around in order to facilitate nap time. Also, if bribery is necessary, the old "If you go to sleep now we can go to the zoo tomorrow" works like a charm!
author: Miriam W.

description:
Although a smaller zoo, the SF zoo still has a lot of animals to admire. My favorite was the gorillas, although I was disappointed it wasn't possible to see the new baby. Other favorites were the black swan, the tigers, the bears, the giraffe babies, and watching the molting penguins be bed. The lions, unfortunately, were asleep. Although this is a smaller zoo by major city standards, it's pleasant and offers a lot of good animal viewing. 

The major downside to the zoo itself is that the roads are confusing, as they aren't labeled. I wasted a lot of time struggling to find certain exhibits due to the lack of labeling. I also was frustrated with the parking situation. Even with a handicap placard we still had to drive around for 15 minutes before finding some poor person leaving the zoo to stalk and wait for their space. There were also a lot of closed exhibits, which was disappointing. My overall verdict is that this is a good place to bring tourists and kids, and an average place for everyone else. make sure to bring a jacket, since this part of SF tends to always be chilly.
author: Denise B.

description:
I love the SF Zoo.  It has a special place in my heart.  However after doing extensive traveling and zoo visits in other states and countries, the SF is lacking.  Most of the other zoos I've visited have been larger and most of their animals are out and about ready to be gawked at.  Maybe I went on a off day but a lot of exhibits were closed =(.  The zoo is confusing to navigate and I there is only one turning machine to feed the goats... AND IT BROKE AS I WAS WAITING IN LINE TO GET TREATS!!!!

The SF Zoo definitely needs more funding.  I'm going to look for events and such I can participate in. =)

PS: Feeding the giraffes should not cost that much =(.  When I was in the Cheyenne Mountain Zoo in Colorado, it cost $2 to get a couple of crackers and you got to feed giraffes from a viewing deck... AWESOME!
author: Eleanor L.

description: One of the coolest places in San Francisco. Friendly staff, will not break the pocket book. Food is great and affordable. The animals rock.  I'm really impressed on how much cleaner it has become. PLUS THEY SERVE BEER AND WINE ON WEEKENDS!
author: Bryan F.

description:
I haven't been to the San Francisco Zoo since I was 7 years old. Now Im 23. Had the chance to go yesterday and spend it there with my girlfriend.

Admission prices are pretty pricey. It was $15 to get in. But if you take Muni they give you a $1 off. So we both paid $14 each. 

The zoo was ok. Somewhat boring, it was a nice day. It was a nice walk. We followed the zoo trail on the map and saw everything. A lot of the animals weren't there. Some of the habitats were empty (or maybe they were hiding, eating, or sleeping. Or Im just blind) 

We took the Steam Puffer Train ride. Cost $4 a person. Its like a 3 min ride in a circle around a part of the zoo. Not that great, but it was fun. They also got a Carousel which we didn't go on that charged $2 per seat.

I wished they upgraded this zoo. They should add more gift shop, Their were 2 g gift shops, and one was closed cause its "seasonal" same with the food stands. Their were like 3 big stands and all the small cart stands were closed. I wished they had more those. I didn't even bother to try the food. It was over priced and didn't even look that great. 

Now time to check to check out the Oakland Zoo! =)
author: Daniel S.

description: I hadn't been to SF Zoo in years. We went on July 5th. The weather is typical for July....foggy but nice weather for walking around for a couple of hours. It's rather easy to get around. The layout is good. A lot of the animals we could not see or they were sleeping. I guess what else can they do. It looks the same from the last time I went there. I've been to a few Zoo's around the world and this one is about medium. Some are better, some are worse. The only think I didn't like is the Koala bear exhibit. They are in a glass cage which seemed small for them. It was a nice time but I won't be back unless someone wishes to go. BTW...don't drive. We took Bart from the eastbay, then took Muni. Muni drops you off about a block from the entrance. It only took an hour to get there.
author: Douglas A.

description:
After talking about it for a few weeks, my boyfriend and I decided to check out the SF zoo.  We had driven by it one day when we went to explore the S. end of Ocean beach... and let me say, exploring and running together on the beach was way more fun than the zoo... unfortunately.

There were few animals in each exhibit, many abandon container areas, unnecessarily confusing paths that just took you back to different views of the same emptyish exhibits, and... well, the facilities are just worn down.  

I'll give 2 stars cause the white-faced Tamarins were so cute... too bad they were the only active thing in the zoo.  It really brought us down.  We had to go roller-blading in GG park to get our moods back up!

Will NOT be seeing you there.
author: Susan D.

description: Love love love this zoo! Staff is super knowledgeable and friendly. Very clean and well maintained zoo. Highly recommended!
author: Idiarys C.

description: we went on 6/27/15 and my daughter had such a good time it wasn't pricy either all day had a blast highly recommended for family fun
author: Rosalinda R.

description: Ugh.  We made the trip from santa rosa not far.... to take our 3 kids to rhe zoo.  The park was clean.  Foods super expensive but they allow out side food and drinks so that helps a bit.   The reason for the 2 star review is many of the animals were missing, and the large animals that were there seamed miserable.  The pore polar bear..... his pond to swim in didnt even look big enough for him to fit in, my opinion if you dont have the resources to ensure the animals are happy and taken care of dont have them there.  The zoo should be like home for them, concrete small lame amounts of vegitation not cool.  I am actually amazed its legal.  Pore animals we will not be going back to support this miss treatment of these beautiful animals.
author: Adrian G.

description:
I can't believe it's taken me THIS LONG to review what is one of my favorite places to go in the entire city of San Francisco!!!

But it has become imperative that I write a review after my visit last week.  Why, you may ask.  Well, to put things delicately, last week I had the pleasure of viewing two gorillas engaging in the act of mad monkey love!!!

It started off like any normal visit, showing my parents and their friends the African exhibit with the giraffes, emus, and other fabulous animals.  We meandered around the corner and eventually wound up circling the gorilla exhibit.  I've always been perplexed by this part of the zoo, because looking at the gorillas and seeing them stare back with such incredible intelligence in their eyes has made me feel a bit bittersweet about the notion that they are captives in a zoo.  Nonetheless, it is one of my favorite exhibits.

This day was a little different.  It was a Monday, so the zoo was mostly empty of tourists.  There was a group of zookeepers doing their rounds together, one of whom seemed to be lecturing the others on each exhibit.  She talked to her students about the gorillas by name and each of their personality quirks.  We all watched at some of the drama between the silverback (male head of the family) and one of the youngin's.  

Then, suddenly, the zookeeper motioned to the group to move on, mumbling something about the gorillas getting overstimulated by their presence.  I looked back into the exhibit, and at first my brain only registered that the silverback was standing with his back to myself and my parents.  I wondered if he was misbehaving by defecating in public or something along those lines.  Then I realized his hips were moving.  What we were witnessing was much more amorous in nature (literally...sorry about the pun, y'all!)!!!

We stared, unable to rip our eyes away.  It felt so wrong to keep watching, but we couldn't walk away, as with a trainwreck.  My mother and I kept exchanging embarrassed giggles, but we stayed for the whole show. 

It didn't last that long, and afterwards the silverback retired back into their enclosure, while his mate just walked off casually into another area of the exhibit.  We were left to ponder if perhaps their relationship has lost the flame of passion over the years, or maybe they are just friends with zoological benefits.  Who's to say?!

Afterwards, we enjoyed the lemurs and big cats and monkey exhibits, spent some meaningful time with the penguins, and so on.  But nothing will dull the memory of the gorilla passion to which we were all witness!
author: Amy L.

description:
San Francisco Zoo.  I have great memories of the San Francisco Zoo. 

I am so happy to see the remodel and new exhibits.

I like the layout of the zoo. The Children's Zoo with the exhibits and petting zoo was fun.   Kind of wish I had kids so I could return and watch their merriment. 

As part of a background and behind the scene view of the park I got to see a bald eagle up close. Thanks to Anthony @sfzoo for the great tour.
author: Infodiva B.

description: Good enough zoo but Yelp directions take you to the mailing address and it's about a mile walk from there to the entrance to the zoo parking lot.  And incidentally, there is a lot of free parking just outside the paid parking lot.  Don't make this mistake that we made.  Zoo is good for about 3 hours with 6-7 year olds after the mile walk to the entrance
author: Sue O.

description: We came here on a recent weekday afternoon, and absolutely loved this zoo. We recently went to the Santa Barbara zoo and this place blows them out of the water. First it is in a GREAT location, the beach and city can't be beat. They have great exhibits, cool animals, and just a great family place. Head this way and enjoy it!
author: Timothy C.

description:
I don't understand the hatred of the SF Zoo on Yelp.  I'm a little biased, in that I have a few fond childhood memories of visiting the zoo.  But, overall I enjoyed my recent visit here (on a Monday afternoon, which was a great way to beat the crowds).

The African section of the zoo is impressive -- several giraffe (including one baby), zebra, and kudu are all visible just a few yards from the fence.

I also enjoyed the stretch of bear and big cat enclosures.  They were a little on the "depressing zoo" side -- old and crappy exteriors, cramped interiors, but at least the animals looked happy.

I'm always a sucker for insect houses, and this one doesn't disappoint.  Beehives, lots of camouflaged insects, and a nice row of arachnids.  Woo!  

Unfortunately, you'll have to walk to the middle of the kiddy's section to get to the insect house.  The children's section was a bit of a disappointment.  There's simply not enough to get your hands on, with the exception of a very ho-hum petting zoo.  Zoo's just aren't fun until you can get your hands on something scaly and/or slimy.

The park's layout sucks.  Maybe it's great, but I can't tell;  there are far too few signs telling you where you've been, or where you should go next.  One member in our party had a map, fortunately.  I'd prefer to just walk around without having to resort to a map every twenty minutes.

Also, the price is really steep ($15/head, but you can get that reduced $3 if you procure proof of SF residency and a muni pass).

Still, though, I could see myself going back here to entertain out-of-town guests, especially animal lovers or kids.
author: Bill H.

description:
I love the SF Zoo... on sunny days. It sucks the other 360 days of the year. Who the hell decided to build a zoo next to Daly City? Same guy that decided to build Candle Stick I guess.

TIPS n TRICKS:
A. Bring your ID. It's cheaper for locals than for tourists. Also cheaper for students. Cheapest for elderly but they charge $30 for an electric scooter so beware.

B. For God's sake... don't buy any food there. That's crazy talk. Here's the drill. About 1/2 block up on Sloat is George's Zoo. Best f%#@ing sandwiches in the area. Cheap, too. Cost you 1/4 of what the zoo charges for horrible food.

C. Don't drink before going. You'll fall asleep for sure. Def an "upper" or hallucinogen kinda place. Trust me, the animals don't move a lot so you may as well imagine that they are.

D. Parking sucks arse. Try to go on a weekday to improve your chances. You can also try to get there about 2-3 hours before they close and a lot of the rock star spots will be open by then.

E. Bring a baby stroller. Who cares if you have a baby or not?! Everyone has one so just bring it!

F. Don't forget your camera. They actually try and charge people for photos at the gate. lol

G. Wear something you won't mind getting shat upon (is that a word?). There are lots of seagulls in the area and I've seen them bomb the customers with wet surprises from above.

H. Enjoy yourself. It's a great place to learn, people watch, and see a lot of happy children ( that does not include the employees who cry a lot ).

NOTE: A hear that the concession stands at the Zoo are great for employee theft. They have no real accounting there so the boss has no idea how much you sold or how much should be in the register. Woot!
author: Selino V.

description:
I'm really not sure how to write this review. As a father and a past contractor at the zoo, I'm torn between all the negatives and the positives. I'm trying to teach my son what Mommy Dearest taught me, 'don't say anything if you don't have anything nice to say." 

So, I'm not going to tell you how cold it was. 

I'm not going to tell you about the $21 I spent on admission and parking for my 5 yo and I. 

I'm not going to tell you about the crying kids who shoulda stayed home where it was warm. 

I'm not going to tell you how the City of SF and the Zoo screwed us on two very small contracts. 

I'm not going to tell you about the $17.50 I spent on lunch at the Terrace Cafe.

I'm not going to tell you about the seagulls who STOLE my soggy fries.
