I'm not going to tell you that almost all the animals were sleeping and that they aren't on the Discovery Channel, which I already pay for. 

I'm not going to tell you how I think that the zoo has a brilliant marketing ploy by having a few playgrounds because you get the kids tired and distracted so you HAVE to come back again to see the rest of the sleeping animals that you missed for another $21. 

I'm not going to tell you that I paid $3.50 for two AA batteries at the gift shop because I forgot that the batteries died in the camera. 

I'm not going to tell you it started raining just as we left. 


However, I will tell you this: 1) 5 year olds love to go to the zoo. 2) the staff was very friendly and helpful. 3) There were no code blue or code reds. (that means no hungry animals escaped and were about to eat you.) 4) No one said anything about me and my Bux coffee when we entered. 5) Walking around the zoo is good excercise! 6) I got some pretty good photos. Check it out!
author: Kevo M.

description:
the San Francisco zoo has definitely improve especially since its not own by the city of San Francisco anymore.

my favorite thing to do is walk around with a bag of kettle corn and watch the prairiedogs. they are soo cute!
author: Carol Y.

description:
One of the best Zoo's I have been too !  I was at San Diego Zoo last month and I am pleasantly surprised to tell you SF rocked it.  The weather was warm out, and all the animals were out. 

We were able to see the Lions eating and they put on a show!
author: Michele S.

description: Nice Large Zoo with many different kinds of Animals to see. The parking is usually horrendous on the weekends but they do offer a valet parking that makes the wait somewhat tolerable. Great place to bring kids and if you want something fun to do on a weekend I definetly recommend coming to the zoo.
author: Anthony G.

description:
The SF Zoo is definitely the best zoo in the bay area.  But then again, does it have any competition?  The Oakland Zoo is a joke compared to this place...

Highlights of my last trip:
The massive stone like rhino, the lazy but fascinating tigers and lions, the cute little penguins, the cool bald eagle, the funny oversized chimpanzees, the tiny little monkeys with white mustaches, the tall and flimsy giraffes, and the zebras... 

Disappointments:
The train ride was a joke.  We waited 45 minutes to get on a train ride that lasted under 2 minutes...  WTH?  My godson fell asleep while I was holding him in line and slept through the entire ride.  The petting zoo is great for toddlers and small children but that's about it.

Oh, and my age....  After  2-3 hours with my godchildren, I was tired and my feet freakin hurt!
author: Danny L.

description:
Ugh. This place is more depressing than an off-strip Vegas nightclub at closing time. 

This is not a good way to help people, espeically kids, make connections between the animals that fascinate and delight them and the things we can do to protect those animals in the wild (particularly compared to a zoo I do like, San Diego). This one is embarrassingly old school and doesn't even pretend to try and educate visitors. It's just like a big freak show.  The only people who seemed engaged in any kind of educational activity were some of the school-age volunteers to work at the children's zoo. Both stars for them. Cool kids. 

Despite the many signs asking visitors to be quiet or to not bang on the glass, or throw things, or feed the animals, most of the visitors seemed to be engaged in at least one of these activities at any given time. A sign that explains that loud noises are disturbing to the animals will be guaranteed to have at least one person standing there, making a great example for the kids, yelling at the animals:

"HEY!!!......It won't look over here....HEY!!! HEY!!! Why isn't it moving? Try throwing something at it....here, give me the baby's pacifier so I can throw it at that animal....it's still not moving....why are we supposed to want to protect these animals, they're boring....this sucks...do you think they have Coors here? I could really use a warm beer in a can."

I have any opposition to zoos, so long as the animals are treated humanely and I don't have to listen to your child's ear-piercing screams because they didn't get cotton candy. In fact, I came up with a very creative solution to California's prison overcrowding problem while we were at the zoo. It involves sex offenders and grizzlies. Charge an extra $20 for admission and donate the money to wildlife habitat protection. Now tell me I wouldn't make a great governor.
author: Pumpkin K.

description:
I do not approve of zoos. Especially after those two idiots were mocking the tiger and put innocent lives at risk.

WHY would you lock up animals? If you want to see animals so badly, go out into the wild. FAIR GAME. Do animals walk around and stare at you? Some people treat them like they don't have feelings -- and that they WANT to be in a cage or a glass box.

The animals at this particular zoo are never interesting. They don't do much. The most interesting thing that I've ever seen at this zoo was a giraffe drinking another giraffe's pee.

Oh, don't come here on those free days either. It's crowded, and they lock away most of the animals so you really barely get to see anything.

Positive note. They have cotton candy.
author: Erica A.

description:
This is one of my favorite zoos! We live in LA, and I might add, that the SF Zoo compares favorably to LA's and San Diego's zoo (minus the pandas). The price is very affordable and worth the intellectual investment. If you're not a zoo member but a member at another AZA zoo or aquarium, you can get half off the $15 general admission price. Just be sure to show your membership card and ID.

The habitats are well constructed and the animals are very active, especially during the opening hours. You have your big ticket animals as well, such as the big cats, rhinos, bears, etc. We were sad that the Tigers were lying so far away from the spectators. The glass enclosing the Tiger dens need to be cleaned. They were so opaque and stained at the time we visited. One of the main attractions has to be the penguins. They have their own little island. Very playful and close to you! 

My daughter loved the Little Puffer train. It's $4 per person but free for the under three-year-olds. The train is quite popular and a line will form. It'll go around its track a couple of times. The carousel is $2, and free for accompanying adults. 

If you're looking for free parking, you can park along Sloat Blvd. It's best to go right around opening time because by noon, parking will be impossible to find. When we left around 12:30 pm, the line to get in was insanely long. It's probably wise to purchase a membership to avoid such ridiculous lines.
author: Andy P.

description:
I'm currently spewing and spinning off animals right now, so what else better to start off with, than a beloved and now distant cousin of family outings from the past.

I remember my first several visits here still in pigtails and plaid pants, running around like any other 4th grader.  Watching in awe, as majestic giraffes move about slowly in their pens, or the tigers, walking to and fro, left and right.  Or the insect display, whose large beetles and various arachnids, prompted me to almost become an entymologist.

Now, as an adult, I actually shun zoos.  Although I do support the need and education for future children and youth to take active participation in ensuring Nature's existence, looking upon large cats and elephants passing everyday for everyone's viewing pleasure, in a pen, makes me sad.  Whatever happened to the days of just watching animals do what they do in their own environment.  Now, in order to appease the stupid public, they have certain animals doing tricks.

No, you dumbass, why don't you go stand on your hands and bark like a dog.

I support the need for making sure these magnificent animals do not slide into extinction, but please make their quality of life equivalent to that of what is natural for them.  Or at the very least, tell the public to shut the f*** up and just watch, listen, and learn.  I saw one parent lean over to make a branch move in order to engage a monkey who was napping on a log.  Motherf*****.  No wonder some of our future kids are going to grow up as the idiot representation of their forefathers.
author: Miika M.

description:
Wow, people are giving 1 star because they don't agree with zoos. To me it's like a vegetarian giving 1 star for a steakhouse because they don't eat meat ... 

Most of the animals in zoos are orphans or rescued or raised in captivity. They wouldn't make it in the wild. 

I went to the zoo this week end and i had a really good time. I saw many animals that I didn't remember they existed! Most of the exhibits were large and clean. Some needed improvements but overall it was ok and much more better than other zoos I've been to. The lanscape is really nice with mature trees, much like a park.

My only negative point: when animals are not in the enclosure, it would be nice to post it near the animal info.
author: Orphée M.

description:
I think for the most part there will always be debates about whether or not the SF zoo is worth visiting or even if its worth the price if you can find something better (i.e. Oakland zoo, SD zoo, etc.).

However, plainly speaking, the SF zoo is one of the only zoo establishments around the bay area, so if you want to see some animals this is still a great resource and a great place to visit. The zoo is plenty big so there is a lot to see if you want to see everything, but has detours to see a selective number of animals if you don't care for all of the amenities they have to offer. Despite it being somewhat cold and gloomy in SF, the zoo is still a great visit because you never know when the sun is going to come out for a visit :)
author: Lorrie M.

description:
Seriously, SF Zoo management needs a wake up call because other YELP users are now asking about my posting and indicating that they are also getting the same run around.

Do yourself a favor and just go to the Zoo and skip their catering & party services.
author: Patrick H.

description:
I've been a Yelper for almost a year now, and have refrained from diving into any dialog about the San Francisco Zoo.

I'm an Animal Keeper at the San Francisco Zoo, and am proud of it!  The people that work at the zoo, love the residents.  I started volunteering when I was twelve years old (yep, I've been at the zoo longer than I haven't).

If you've got a question send me a message, most of these yelpers that give our lovely zoo less than 3 stars, have no idea what their talking about, are completely misinformed, or misinterpreting something.

Learn something about the zoo and check out the podcast - somewhat shameless plug considering I make the podcasts :)
http://www.sfzoo.org/podcasts
author: Anthony B.

description:
I believe that the amount of zoos we have in this country is out of control.  It is not necessary for so many animals to be suffering in small, rundown zoos that various cities across the nation are unable to maintain, and the SF Zoo is a perfect example.  

Since banning zoos entirely would not fly, I think we should have a very small amount of zoos in this country - destination zoos, that people would travel to and center their vacations around (like Disney World).  Maybe one for each region of the country. Large, well-kept zoos where the animals have enough space and resources to be able to live their lives in a somewhat more comfortable situation.  There is no reason to justify every halfway decent sized city in America having a zoo.  Multiple cities are unable to properly maintain these zoos due to budget issues, and the animals are the ones suffering because of it.

I'm sure you are already thinking of the particular incident I am going to mention as an example of why - Tatiana at the San Francisco zoo.  That was a combination of multiple factors: a run down facility that was unable to keep the tiger in captivity, zoogoers that were taunting the animal, and an animal that acted out due to the poor living situation it was forced to live in.  When you actually go to that tiger exhibit at the SF Zoo it's easy to see why that incident happened, and shocking that there haven't been more incidents like that.  It is one of the most depressing, inhumane things to see as it is basically a small setup of various square concrete spaces that are obviously not adequate to house tigers or lions, with cloudy plexiglass windows to look at the motionless, depressed animals with.  The entire zoo is a pit of death and depression, in my opinion.

When you take a step back and look at it, it does seem a bit unbelievable just how many run-down zoos exist in this country, and how nobody seems to take issue with it.  Let's re-examine our morals and ethics behind animals in captivity.  Hopefully it will change for the better some day in the future.
author: Genevieve M.

description:
The zoo is near Ocean Beach. It is a great place to go during breaks from SFSU. Parking can be pack. They tend to close it off if it gets full. 

Only go here during sunny weather and early. Coming here in the afternoon can be boring.
author: Ronald N.

description:
www.sfzoo.org/furball

Come this weekend for the most fun event of the year at the
zoo~ its the sf Zoo 2 fur ball. we have in place a petting zoo, carousel rides, open bar, champagne toast while the lions and tiger es are fed, then a great post party with full appetizers, free drinks, dancing to pop rocks, silent auction, and a live auction with the prize being to name the two new Walla be babies. Come dance drink, bed, eat, indulge in nature, and kick off the last Friday before winter comes to town. CHEERS
saviors.
author: Samantha S.

description:
REGARDING: BIRTHDAY PARTY FOR YOUR CHILD - LEMUR ROOM
The party was fine although I did noticed the space seemed a little confining for the four year olds.  The per person fee is approximately $45 - $50 per person - no price breaks for children.  Be sure to read the fine print regarding their catering policy. 
You do not get to take any of the uneaten catered food home (except the cake).  For example, if you get seven pizzas and only eat three, they keep four (uncooked).  The zoo maintains it is for health policies.  My belief is it is a bottom line price break for the zoo.  My suggestion....take the money and throw a party somewhere else and book a caterer that allows you to take away the food you paid for
author: TC C.

description:
Lions and tigers and bears...and tapirs?  Oh man, so cute.  I went on a free day and it was worth the walk over.  I haven't been in years and watched as many of the animals were molting or shedding their summer coats.

I can't decide what I think of zoos as a whole because of them being in captivity.  On one hand, they are in an enclosed space.  On the other, these animals are from all over the world and it would be near impossible for me or any other average American to travel and see these animals in their natural setting.

My friend also made a good point that seeing them in person allows people to have a closer connection with them as well as raising awareness of their species, their natural habitat, and our consumption.  There are also a lot of babies around the zoo, too.  There were barriers for the barriers because they did not want tourists (or more likely stupid adults and dumb kids) dropping things over the rail so the baby gorilla could get to it and choke.  It made me happy to see the measures they took to protect the young one.

I guess it gets a minus one star because of my own moral dilemma.  Oh wait, and the peacocks running around the zoo.  They scare me a little.
author: Ashley I.

description: The San Francisco Zoo is perfect for my family.  We've had a membership this past year and it has been such a treat to see how our family's animal interests have developed over that time.  The SF Zoo has something for every interest level at any age.  There are plenty of hands on exhibits and the animal enclosures are designed in a way that really, there are no poor views.  The size of the property is manageable for even a half day outing.  Things are definitely ramped up in the  summer with extra docents sharing animal stories.  When I first came to SF my only previous zoo experience was the San Diego Zoo, (not exactly a fair comparison).  I have seen the SF make consistent upgrades to the property over the years - it's wonderful!  I'm looking forward to seeing the newest upgrade, the Koret-Taube South American Tropical Rainforest & Aviary!
author: Rachel G.

description:
Tips for a fun trip to the zoo:

-Check the weather before you go - zip code 94132. We were well-prepared for windy weather in the 50s, so walking around for a couple of hours was comfortable. I heard many visitors remark, "Wow, it's colder than I expected." Don't let it happen to you.
-Bring snacks. Would have had to shell out quite a chunk of change to feed my 22 month old on the snack offerings here. There is no bag inspection, so bring along plenty of finger foods.
-Visit the family farm/children's zoo first. If you bee-line it for the family farm/children's zoo at the start, you'll avoid the large children's groups that come during weekdays. Goats meander free within the children's zoo (and poop and pee everywhere too); kids are allowed to pet many animals, and there are sinks right outside for clean-up afterwards. 
-If you can, try to secure a SF family fun pass to the attraction for free admission for up to two adults and two children. Really an unbeatable deal. Available at SF libraries - check out sfkids.org for more information.
author: Wendy L.

description: Great place to bring kids with a wandering mind. Its cheaper much cheaper to be a member of the San Francisco Zoo you pay 105.00$ for a while year which includes admission for 2 adults and 5 kids. Not only that but they give you a list of places you can receive a discount off of admission. The train ride and the carousel only accepts cash! Plus side the kids had fun!
author: Charles P.

description:
It's Christmas day, and you're Jewish, Muslim, Hindu, Buddhist, or just don't give a hoot about Christmas and almost everything is closed.
Where do you go?  To the zoo!  Fab-u-lous.
author: dan s.

description:
You can get up close and personal with the animals here. Yesterday my nephew petted a Madagascar hissing cockroach, a 60-year-old desert tortoise, and a bunch of terrifyingly assertive horned goats (Tip: To find the goat-petting area, listen for the high-pitched shrieks of small children). 

Highlights:

- The African Savannah, where you can stand just a couple yards away from the giraffes, zebras, ostriches, and "dik-diks." The pretty landscape features a watering hole, hills, trees... The different species also interact (peacefully. they don't eat one another as far as I can tell). Yesterday I snapped four species with one camera shot.  This is so much cheaper than flying to Africa.

- The meerkats. When they rise on their hind legs, in unison, practically inches from your face, it's so exciting!  Not as soapy as Meerkat Manor, but still a joy to watch.

- The Gordon Biersch garlic fries in the cafeteria. Sadly, they've usually been sitting under a heat lamp a while.  But even when soggy, these garlicky fries are pungent and delicious.
author: angela n.

description: We visited this zoo during the summer, on a weekday and it wasn't crowded at all, which was nice! It's right off Great Highway next to the ocean and was easy to get to, easy to park. It's great for a few hours but no need to make a whole day of it. We found the walk around to be a bit confusing to follow, but loved the children's park! Not sure the highlight of a zoo should be a park but it was a fun area nonetheless. Eat at Lemur Cafe - not the children's park food area! The seagulls will swoop in and eat your hot dog before you can in the outdoor eating areas. My kids loved the Little Puffer Train ... but it's definitely a quick ride around the park. Twice.
author: Kristy S.

description:
I LOVE the Zoo and want to give 5 stars but I still believe there is room for improvement, which they are working on.

Let's start with the bad
1. Junk food galore. I hang out with a 2-year old all day and it would be really nice if they promoted healthy, organic snacks and meals.
2. They cut off a main artery from the bears back to the other side of the Zoo so my lazy self has to walk all the way around the anteater to get back to the penguins
3. They moved all the big cats in and took a few away :( This was due to the ADA noticing that it was not easy for handicapped patrons to make it all the way up the hill to where they used to be housed, so, whatever. 
4. When families park on Sloat to save on the $8 parking fee, there is so much speeding traffic! It is extremeley dangerous. I think there should be speed bumps. Really. I almost got run over by a Land Rover in the crosswalk before. 
5 They should have freshly popped Kettle Corn.

All the good stuff:
1. The Rainforest is open as of this weekend! YAY! 
2. Snow Leapord is gorgeous - get there 1st thing AM to see her eating
3. BABY GORILLA = so cute
4. Baby Flamingoes - they grow fast so get there now
5. The rehabilitation center in the Children's Zoo is amazing and they even have a baby alligator there right now
6. Zoo class with teacher Suzanne is an amazing place to meet animals up close and learn about different species. 
7. The Cassawary is such an interesting bird - looks like a dinosaur
8. Black Swans, oh my!
9. Giraffes and Zebras in a new space
10. The children's zoo and farm where you can pet Sheep

I love the zoo. I do.
author: Katherine B.

description:
Dude. I miss the zoo. 

I haven't been to another zoo before and I'd never been to a zoo at all until a couple years ago but I think this place fills my eyes with childlike wonder and I'm friggin 21 :D

I haven't taken a tour here but the 5 stars are for the range of animals they have, and the infrastructure of all the exhibits/food. Everything is easy to find and believe it or not, it could get much worse. I like the way everything is planted and my personal favorite are the penguins! I could watch those little guys swim and jump out of the water for HOURS. Don't believe me? Cover my ticket!

I really miss coming to this place and I wish I didn't live so out of the way to rekindle some childhood wonder =/

Thanks for making me feel 9 years old again!
Chris
author: Christopher T.

description:
The zoo is...okay. I know I shouldn't be criticizing a zoo, but it should be more lively than what I experienced!

I was there by 12pm. The zoo is well spaced and planned. You could possibly see every exhibit without a map! The problem is that the place felt deserted even though there were quite a lot of people there. Some enclosures were empty, some animals were sleeping, leaving a few lazy ones. All of the food carts were closed. This laziness infected me. I felt like sleeping with one of the koalas.

There should be docents informing people, "raising awareness". There should be more scheduled things to do for entertainment. It should feel more like an amusement park then a baby strolling park. They need new management.

If you're looking to be entertained or inspired, this is not the place.
author: Rahil P.

description:
I come here every few years. This visit was amazing. We found a great parking spot, they gave us a veterans discount, the weather was perfect! 

We loved the grizzly feeding. 

The trainer was hand feeding the rhino fruits and veggies as we passed, right at the fence! 

The new hippo enclosure was great, he was right there! 

They had a great bbq going and the food was tasty! 

All in all it was a great zoo day!
author: Jenna D.

description:
This zoo is not that great. If you really have nothing else to do, come to this zoo.

There are a lot better zoos like in San Diego. Yes, that's a lot farther away, but it's worth it. I'd rather go to Monterey Bay Aquarium than to this zoo.

First of all, it's far away (if you don't live in SF already). It can get cold. Many attractions seems to not be open. It's not that lively. There aren't that many people (that says something). The food is expensive inside and not even good.

The mood is just down, which doesn't make your mood go up.

Last time I was there, there weren't even any elephants. Their pen was empty and there wasn't even a sign to say what happened. This was disappointing.

I feel like if they made more money and more people came through, this place would be good. However, I wouldn't come back.

If you've never been, I would just try it out, but I don't foresee the best time.

I would say the only good thing about this place is that it is near ocean beach and in the city in general. There are a lot of other things you can do in the city.
author: Marlon T.

description: I'm an animal lover and this zoo definitely made me happy because seeing the animals lighten up my day.
author: Serena M.

description:
I have to tell you I did not like my first return trip to the Zoo in about 10 years.I missed the Bear feedings so when I got to the Bear Area All I saw was One Koala Bear.The signs are of no help in finding anything. I had to constantly ask zoo employees.  Maybe they are inside somewhere? The zoo  no longer has any elephants, which I was looking forward to seeing.

The installation of huge glass walls on top of the fence in the lion areas means you don't have a good experience viewing the lions and there are no more lion feedings.As another poster said, there are many vacant areas.

 When I asked about the elephants, a friendly zoo person told me to go look at the insect exhibit. I am not fond of insects and have no desire to go look at them.All the employees I talked to at the Zoo were very helpful and friendly.

I bought a waffle Ice cream cone for $4.50 and it was possibly the worst Ice cream(if thats what it was) that I have ever eaten. It tasted like chocolate flavored frozen water soft serve style. The wait to buy this on a Friday afternoon was 15 minutes as there was only one person at the register, taking orders and yelling to the cooks in the back for food orders.

The Gorilla exhibit was nice and I loved the Giraffe but overall, I would not return as the over all experience was very boring.
author: Mike M.

description:
I love zoos! I'm really just a giant ten year old, who isn't actually that giant. 
The San Francisco Zoo did not disappoint. We went on a weekday so it was pretty dead, which I liked because there was no competition for the animal sight seeing. 
I really appreciated how much the zoo worked on making nice exhibits for the animals. Lots of open outdoor spaces for the animals to play in. I really loved the lemur exhibit! They had an outdoor area with lots of tall trees for them to climb, plus an indoor area with climbing stuff for them. They seemed to be having a good time in it. I've never really seen a zoo with so much to offer for the animals. It's nice to know that they are trying to make their captive lives the best that they can. 
So yeahh I would say that the SF Zoo is definitely something you should check out if you are in the area. I have quite a large amount of zoo attending experience, some may even say I am a zoo expert and I have to say that I give it my stamp of approval. I know, it's a pretty big deal.
author: Ashley R.

description:
This was one depressing place...for visitors and animals alike!

Those poor animals. Big cats pacing in cages. A sad sea lion, all alone in a small concrete pool with waves painted on the side next to a sign that says he's a social animal who loves to hunt for his food. Grizzly bears looking bored stiff. A black bear with his back to viewers, staring into space, motionless. Koalas with a single tree to climb.

They really should close this place down it's so depressing and unnatural. It really made me sad.
author: David S.

description: Pretty nice zoo. It is clean and kept up well. The are a decent selection of animals. The food options are good and rental wagons for kids are nice. The food is quite pricy, but that's typical. It is in much better condition than the Oakland zoo, which is the other close option. Bring a coat here. It's right by the ocean so can get cold quickly.
author: L H.

description:
We checked out the zoo as a possible sit-down wedding reception site. We looked at the Great Hall and the Lemur Cafe.  The Great Hall is a beautiful space. It's a log cabin and has a very rustic look. It has plenty of space.  The staff there will help you setup the centerpieces if they are simple.  They have round tables and wooden chairs.

We really liked the Lemur Cafe. It has lots of windows. There is also a side room for kids to play. The floor is concrete, so it can be dangerous if toddlers fall. We will have lots of toddlers at our wedding, so that was a concern.  Also the place is only available at 6pm or after.  Since it's the cafe or restaurant for zoo patrons, they can convert the space right at 5pm, the closing time. There is also a cashier and soda fountain bar, so that would need to be covered. The catering staff at the zoo said they can easily put up some sort of divider to cover that up.  We liked the space, but it was a bit over our budget.

The strange thing is the catering staff never got back to us. We had a couple of questions which we emailed, but we didn't hear back.  We weren't completely set on having our reception there, but I thought it was rude and odd that she didn't get back to us.  I read good things about their food on chowhound.com and on craigslist.org.   The zoo is definitely worth checking out as a possible wedding or private venue despite the one non-communicative staff.
author: traveler Y.

description: Pretty neat! I'm going back in summer time.
author: Sandi S.

description: It was my first visit after probably 6 years. Now I know why I did not wanted to go back. I brought my 4 kids 12, 11, 4 and 3. We walked around tried to see animals but it seem they were all asleep the only thing open was the goats so I paid almost 100 to see goats and horses right!!!! My kids were crazy to get out of the zoo nothing exciting at all. Definitely not going back. Not worth your money!! The oakland zoo is much better and cheaper
author: Dee M.

description:
It is an OK zoo. I agree that the price of admission is very steep at $15 for adults. 

Pros: 
1)It has a large selection of animals. Meerkats, bears, koalas, giraffes, gorillas, kangaroos, and penguins. 
2)The children's zoo. It is very large as compared with the one at Happy Hollow. It was very cool to see the employees care for those animals that were rescued from places such as Louisiana and to know that they released them after it turns three years old. 
3)The Little Puffer Steam Train 
4)The Carousel 
5)A children's playground 
6)The food was surprisingly cheap and reasonable.  Normally, places such as the zoo would have outrageous prices.  Therefore, I don't understand why one person said it was outrageous and had brought food from home.

Cons: 
1)It seems to be run down. I was there for the first time back in the mid-90s and recall a zoo that was well kept and exciting. 
2)Hard to get to some areas. One of them was the lions exhibit. They definitely need a lot more directories throughout the zoo. 

Even though I was unimpressed with the zoo this time, it was still good to see my three year old nephew enjoy it.
author: Samson W.

description: Don't waste your money!!  It cost $62.00 to get through the gate for 2 adults, 1 child, and parking.  Then $5 apiece to ride the train and $3 for the carousel.  It was dirty, smelly, the animals are old and lethargic ~~ all in all the place looked old and run down.  Skip this and head to Oakland Zoo instead!!
author: Debbie N.

description: San Francisco Zoo is an awesome place to go to for fun or educational purposes. It is good for kids, adults, and groups. If you're the someone who is interested in studying animals for scientific studies, this is definitely the place especially for a course in zoology.
author: Bennett W.

description: This is my fiances second home always enjoy seeing her face light up when we go the staff is very nice and care very well for there animals we love you SF Zoo!
author: Cody M.

description:
Eh, Not much my cup of tea. For the first time being here at SF Zoo was not grrrreat. Boo. I'd realized after looking at a few big animals and birds, that this zoo only had one of each animal. What kind of zoo only has one animal of each, but hella birds. Haha. This is why I give it 3 stars. I've experienced better. 

Other than that, 4 stars for great food (cinnamon churros, the best of course) AND I'd say that the best area in the zoo was the Children's Zoo. It was exciting and very nice to feed the goats, even though they kept chasing you for more, it was scary and funny at the same time! I'd come back, but not for awhile.
author: Desiree L.

description:
Not a fabulous zoo. My toddler enjoyed it more than I did.
There are not enough signs anywhere, so you are forced to consult that damned map, which is a pain if you are child-wrangling.
Also there is a sort of depressing vibe -- the big cats' house was closed (recent tiger mauling of a zoo employee), and there is a giant weed-strewn lot where presumably the elephants used to be (the zoo has had a highly controversial relationship with elephants, and they are no longer to be found there, thanks to the efforts of PETA and other organizations).
The Oakland zoo is much better in my opinion!
author: Lisa T.

description:
First time at SF zoo. I swooped free parking on Sloat Blvd but you do have to cough up $8 to park within the zoo.

Admission was really pricey: $15 There is a deduction if you happen to live in San Francisco which is cool but alas! It did not apply to me.

Upon entry to the zoo my girlfriend and I received a map and we began our exploration according to the map's suggestion (which hit all of the exhibits in a certain order. Which was convenient).

We enjoyed every bit of our stay. The whole place was very clean, ample restroom areas, plenty of refreshment stations. The animals were just chilling in the shade (twas hot) and having a groovy time. Trainers were actually conversing with people and answering questions. I won't get into the whole morality question of 'zoo animals VS wild animals'. I'm here to review the zoo.

I would recommend bringing your own water bottles and some snacks because the goodies offered by the zoo are SUPER high priced. The Lemur Cafe has a bunch of lunch options too if you are starving. Great place for kids, a big gift shop.

The best part: all the monkeys/gorillas!
author: Matt B.

description:
When the highlight of our day trip here were the Guinea Pigs, you not it was not a great zoo. The park has a great lay out and the walk was nice. the baby Gorilla was very entertaining to watch. Dad kept a eye on him the whole time we were observing. baby gorillas are much like toddler children, they run and taught adults much the same. We spent lots of time at this location. They had extra barricades due to the young age of the baby. Still is was not crowded. 

My daughter bought every coin souvenir she found, another highlight, as she collects the 51 cent items everywhere. The feeding of the lions was very crowded, people are very rude, they see the animal, and forget that they are walking and stopping right in front of you, pushing to make room, while people were already there is very wrong. The big cats are great to watch, would not want to be the one having to feed them. If it were for the socially unaware idiots, it would have been better. 

Not much else to speak on, the train ride was a joke, two small little laps around a small section of land, which you can see not animals. A few farm animals to pet and feed. 

My daughter spent the most amount of time with the bunnys and piggies. She wanted to take one home, she thought it would make good company for the one we own. Watching the little animals run around and eat, shove one out of a tube just for it to walk away. Pure, simple enjoyment. 

I am not planning on coming back again. Customer service in the gift shop was horrible. I stood at the counter for 5 minutes, while someone said they would be right there, then another guest came up, and they were helped, I straight told the clerk, I was here first and she should be helping me, of course the man she helped "didn't see me"... Yea Yea.
author: Marie W.

description:
Just went to the zoo last weekend. What's with all the negative reviews? The place is a gem in a crowded, dense city, amazing they pulled it off. Huge compared to New York City's Central Park minizoo. I was expecting something dinky and was surprised by how nice some of the enclosures were. And there's a Siberian tiger!! That is amazing. I immediately bought a membership and plan to visit often. The setting is park-like, very green, beautifully landscaped. I thought the enclosures were quite large. The polar bear looked white to me. Plenty of tigers and the lion was there. Except for the Rainforest exhibit, it appears most of the renovations are done. A great petting zoo too, the place was very kid-friendly.

What's with all the negative reviews? Exhibits were closed for renovations, that doesn't make it a *bad* zoo, that's just what's necessary to make it a *better* zoo. I'm sorry, are zoos supposed to magically update without any construction? I do agree the zoo should post what exhibits are closed at the door.

Parking is free on Sloat. When I went last Saturday, plenty of parking on Sloat. Walk, people, burn that fat off.

I am flummoxed that people find $15 adult/$9 kid too expensive. Don't they realize how much it costs to take care of endangered large animals in a hugely expensive city? Or would you rather go out of town, spend money out of town, and pay $37 adult/$27 kids to get into the San Diego Zoo, which can then afford to pay the $1million necessary to rent pandas from China? Might as well fly to Minnesota to shop at the Mall of America and give money to Bloomie's.

Rating a zoo low because you don't like the idea of zoos? Well, most of the animals in zoos are there because they are injured and cannot survive in the wild. So should we release them in the wild and let them die? Or should we open a nice wide preserve for them? Okay, whose going to pay for that if you're already complaining about entry fees? I do think zoos may not be the best place for animals, but better that then dead.  And it's sad if the only contact we have with animals are on TV.  

Go to the zoo!
author: Jen K.

description: The biggest problem of this zoo is the location. It's always cold and ugly in San Francisco. Other than that this zoo has plenty of animals and great for kids of all ages. I take my daughter here every year for 7 years now. And I'm sure we will be back next year again.
author: Xenia K.

description: My son enjoyed watching the penguins and wants to come back soon. He asks about going to the zoo all the time! He also hung out at the petting zoo and was combing one of the goats, this was the first time he wasn't completely scared of going into the petting zoo. Other petting zoos have aggressive animals who are looking for food all the time. His eye caught the train and carousel but I managed to change his attention so I didn't have to pay for the extra fees, haha. I'm sure we'll ride that train soon enough as we'll be back.
author: Mochi L.

description:
Cousin comes to town with her family, including her ten month old daughter in tow.  Where to go?  The zoo, of course, to check out the new Grizzly Gulch.  Congrats to the PR department at the Zoo-you'd have to work hard to avoid the signs.

Without rehashing the elunds, as Miz Susan B details below, it's been a rough year for the zoo.  There was a tiger trainer mauled at the zoo in December '06 (google Lori Komejan) and OSHA ruled June 22 that it was the zoo's fault.   According to reports, the tigers were to be reopened a month later.  As of mid-August, that had not occurred, and there's big scary police tape in front of the building.

I like that the zoo offers a discount for SF residents.  It was a gorgeous day, and we had fun, although there were so many people feeding the penguins that it was hard to see.  My cousin ruled that the train jerked around too much to take the baby, so I can't review that either.  I will say my teriaki bowl was better than expected.  Yes, my expectations were extremely low, but I still thought that to be an accomplishment.

Not a bad place to spend the day with out of town relatives-just bring a sweater-it's COLD!
author: Beth V.

description: Went to the Zoo because it's free for SF residents today (the first Wednesday of the month). Went with a friend that just came from Hong Kong - she was amazed, but I wasn't. Came here maybe about 3 or 4 times ever, and this time wasn't any different. Since it's been super cold lately the animals aren't really out, but we got really lucky and saw the lions and bears up close. Whoot! I was excited to see those the most!
author: Linda K.

description:
Reading previous reviews, I'm glad I'm not alone in feeling this way about zoos. I came here the other day and honestly I was actually sad for the animals. Most of them LOOKED healthy enough and I'm sure they're provided the plenty of food/water they require. HOWEVER it was depressing to see the animals confined behind bars/cages thousands of miles away from their natural habitat. I'm sure their lions/tigers can't survive in the wild now if they were granted freedom but the whole situation is overall a negative for me. I loved visiting the zoo when I was younger but that's before I had any concept that animals have feelings too and I'm sure most (if not all) are depressed being behind a wall/fence. 

For example, when I got to the sea otters (I think they were sea otters) I looked around in their area for them but I didn't see them anywhere. My bf then pointed out "There he is" and I see it on its two feet standing looking out through the crack of the door that the employees go in and out of. It was heartbreaking to see that it wanted to break out but couldn't. Also the polar bears looked a lot smaller than the huge plump ones that you see in the pictures and they were panting and looked to be suffering. As gloomy/cold as the city can be, the weather here certainly doesn't compare to the arctics where they originate and were right next to the black bears which I'm sure were fine in this weather. 

Animal exhibits exists whether or not people want it to so I'm not gonna rate the place due to my own personal opinions about zoos.
I did have a good laugh at the monkeys though. One female came around offering itself over to an uninterested male. It literally came lifted its tail and put its red monkey behind in front of the face of the male for a few seconds. The male just kinda glanced at it and looked away. The female must have felt rejected and ran off.  It was hilarious!
I'm just happy that I didn't see any feces being thrown about.
author: Esther A.

description:
I really like going to the Zoo.  So many reviews talk about how sad and depressing the Zoo is but that has never been my experience.  There is a big debate about how ethical zoos are and I do agree that its optimal to see animals in their natural habitat.  I heard the zoo director interviewed once on KGO and he defended the zoos stating that people care more about animals if they are able to see them up close...yadda yadda yadda.  I don't know how the debate will end...but its incredibly magical to visit any zoo with children.  

It can be foggy but many days its not.  Family memberships are $75.00 and allow you to visit with your family every day of the year.  

Today we were treated to the sight of 4 young male elephant seals who were beached and unable to feed themselves.  The zoo and the Marine Mammal Center are babysitting them until they weigh enough to be returned to sea.  They also have 2 black bears that were "humanized" or so used to people they couldn't live in the wild anymore.  The baby giraffe is pretty cute too.  If you wish, you can watch its birth on a zoo podcast.  http://www.sfzoo.org/podcasts/

We try to see all the animals we can in the wild but it is nice to see animals we would otherwise never see.....
author: Tracie P.

description:
I've been going here since I was 5 years old.  

Since then, they've incorporated changes such as newer exhibits and newer animals.  However, there are still the familiar penguins, lion's den, zebras, and the primates area.  

This zoo isn't as big as San Diego's or the Bronx Zoo, but I'll always remember the zoo as being synonymous with my childhood, when I was free from worries and money and challenges that you confront as you get older.  Everytime I go here, it's like taking a timeout from life, when I get a chance to just reflect back on my childhood and how far I've come since then.  

P.S. For the peeps not from SF, don't get tricked into parking at the paid lots, but park at the parking on Sloat, on 47th avenue (where I'm from) or Ocean Beach if possible.  If it's the first Wednesday of the month, and esp. if that wednesday happens to fall on a holiday (such as July 4th this past year), plan on coming to park no later than 10:30 to avoid the parking fees.
author: Joe V.

description: My boyfriend and I had a really, really great time at the SF Zoo.  Some of the highlights included: the hippo (my personal favorite), the polar bear (his personal favorite), and a live penguin feeding.  The zoo had quite a spectrum of animals and exhibits, only about a 20 minute drive from the apartment.  I also really just enjoy the Ocean Beach part of town, too, so all in all -- a treat!
author: Mel G.

description:
The Zoo is okay. The staff is friendly and knowledgeable. However, maybe it's the SF fog, but the Zoo animals don't seem too happy. Only $12 for SF Residents and $15 for nonresidents - it's a good bargain for a day of fun. Kids under 3 are free - and parking is $8 - but if you park on the street in the back 42-44th street - it's free. 

My 1 year old loves the petting zoo. We spent most of our time there feeding the goats and chasing sheep. It's A-OK but could do some things to upgrade -- like larger enclosures for their animals and maybe a trim or two for some of those goat's horns.
author: Christina and Jaime F.

description:
This is my 100th review and I wanna make it a special one :)))

The date was August 4th, 2008. 3 days into our relationship jonathan and i decided to go to the zoo seeing that I had to go back to Oregon within the week to start working with Women's Soccer. This would be one of our official date locations that we hit up since both of us haven't been to the zoo in a very long time. 

We took the Muni to the zoo, and after we got arrived Jonathan kinda tripped on the sidewalk as we were walking in the wrong direction :P that was a good start to the day haha! ;) It kinda sucked that the weather wasn't all that... great. The classy grey skies making the city by the bay a gloomy place was the forecast for the day. Oh well, as long it doesn't rain on us right? 

Jonathan bought our tickets and off we went to our adventure! I don't really remember much about the zoo other than the primate structure but it was nice to see the animals here. I felt a little bad since some of them like the rhino seemed really lonely, and I imagined them like the movie Madagascar, they could all be a little cooky. Maybe even the penguins were plotting some sort of escape plan. 

My favorite exhibits were the tiger cubs and the kangaroos. We took pictures... actually Jonathan took great pictures of the tiger cubs playing and they were adorable!!! There is one picture he took where the two of them were pretty much nuzzled up against each other with their backs facing us. I thought it was a precious moment... and then they were wrestling with each other. Super cute. ^_^ That kangaroo exhibit was pretty cool, it was also pretty cute to see the joey's hanging out of their mom's pouches although one had its head sticking out while its legs were hanging out too. :) Cute stuff.

I can't forget the amazing time I had with Jonathan here. Oh... I should put this out there that he wanted me to take a picture of the kangaroo ears that was around the zoo along with the rest of the animal ears/antlers that were hung up around the zoo. That's his fav pic though. Why? i don't know... it's just cute :P

Sucks that the tigers aren't there (i blame the assholes that had it coming to them). Some of the exhibits are definitely showing age and lack of care, and it just didn't seem like the perfect home for some of these animals. I feel bad but it's better than nothing right? When/if i do have kids I hope the SFZoo will still be around so I can show them the great animals that live there, oh and get harassed by the petting zoo goats too. That'll be awesome haha.
author: Marie G.

description:
Well, I don't really know if this zoo is kind to animals or cruel to animals.  Looked like the rhino sure didn't have enough room to move around all by itself.  I am going to go with my gut instinct and assume these people do the animals more good than harm.  I really hope so.

The SF zoo is a good place to take the family (look kids, dying endangered animals kept like slaves, woohoo!).  Be prepared to do a lot of walking.  Go on a hot day, not a cold day.  We went on a cold day and all the animals were hiding in their 'caves'.

Bring a camera because this place is heaven for sissy wildlife photographers (your photo of that rare exotic animal could be the last one ever taken).  Don't forget to bring some sunblock or a sun umbrella, it gets mighty sunny out here in the outback.  

SF residents with I.D. get a discount.  I believe it is $9 for residents and $11 for non-residents.

Wait, what am I thinking.  These people keep the animals in jail cells, I was rationalizing the whole experience so I wouldn't cause any waves.  Three stars because I'm generous.
author: Cynthia B.

description: My company recently employed the SF Zoo for our annual holiday party.  This included a very fine gourmet dinner prepared by Chef Ricky, cocktails and animal encounters.  The staff was friendly and professional.  Carol who coordinated the event was especially helpful and there every step of the way to make sure our party came out perfectly.  I would recommend using the SF Zoo for your next party corporate event and will be looking for another reason/situation to use them again myself.  Be sure to add in the giraffe encounters - they were purely magical!
author: Allene R.

description:
We were a bit nervous about heading to this zoo after seeing the lackluster reviews on yelp.com but were pleasantly surprised.  

Yes, the price of admission is a bit steep (and we parked in off street parking to save the $8 fee which was just a little longer walk than the zoo's) but assuming your admission is going to pay for the upkeep of the zoo and animals...more than happy to impart with a little more than I hoped.

Our soon to be two year old upon seeing the nice African sahara type enclosure with its reallly close giraffes, zebras, and ostriches decided she had enough of the zoo since she was genuinely afraid.  Fortunately, there is a whole area of the zoo for little one's called the Children's Zoo.  It was wonderful to be able to expose her to farm animals (she pet a goat, saw the pigs and horses that are in her bedtime story books,  saw chicks, and a mouse), she enjoyed the insect house, and birds... This was a great start to get her comfortable with seeing animals up close and smaller in stature so not as intimidating before heading back to the bigger animal enclosures (ie. bears, chimpanzees)

We thoroughly enjoyed chatting with the student volunteers (and their knowledge on the different animal areas they were watching over) as well.  With perhaps our little one becoming one when she is older :).
author: Tani S.

description:
San Francisco, ever the iconoclast, once again breaks with convention at the SF Zoo.

SF pioneered wheat-free, gluten-free, egg-free, GMO-free ...

And now, the SF Zoo steps into the ring with 'animal-free.'

That's right, the San Francisco Zoo has virtually N=0 animals in it. On any given visit, you will find yourself first eagerly, then impatiently, stumbling down paths to nowhere, only to find ... nothing. Empty cages. Explanatory placards with no live subjects. 

The only evidence of wildlife is on the street signs, which have animal-themed names.

It used to upset me. We deserve real bears, not just the leather variety. Then, an animal-shaped lightbulb popped on: just STOP THINKING OF THE SF ZOO AS A ZOO. It's not a zoo -- it's a park! With animal-themed signage. A naked savannah. And mylar balloons.

As for substitute attractions, you might enjoy the Little Puffer - it's a teeny tiny train that put-puts around in a shaky circle, affording you birds-eye views of ... nothing. Little Puffer aside, you're gonna need a big fat toke to make believe this jungle of a zoo is little more than concrete.
author: Dan F.

description:
I feel that the animals here really have to be sad ones. This place overall is greatly needed for a new renovation because there are way too many dark and mysterous corners that are waiting for some child kidnapper to grab a innocent wondering youngling and snap him or her away. 
I happened to quest here on a free day where you need proof of SF residence and the cyborgs behind the counter did not understand the concept of being a student with only an ID card but luckily this creepy man on a wheel chair and his dog kindly said he was my son after I argued with the zoo staff for at least five minutes to let me into their run down zoo!
Free is the best time to go here, please don't go on a dead day, you won't love it at all.
author: Jon-o G.

description: San Francisco zoo is a old zoo that has been going a transformation in the last five years. It isn't huge but it has a good selection of animals which seem to be well cared for. Some of the highlights include the grizzly bears with their excellent enclosure. I also enjoy the big cats, even thought sometimes they are hard to see (feeding time is cool)  The gorilla  enclosure is getting old but the animals are fascinating. Over all the zoo feels cheerful and it is not overwhelming like some world class zoos can be. This zoo can be the center of a great spring/summer day in the city.
author: Sheva B.

description:
I haven't been to the zoo in 8? years and I only went recently because 1) the line for the Academy of Sciences was RIDICULOUSLY long (FAIL), and 2) the De Young Museum is closed on Mondays (FAIL).

The line for the zoo was unexpectedly longer than I thought too, but the nicer weather made it bearable. Unfortunately, there wasn't much more inside to make up for it. I think after going to Safari West and seeing the animals up close & personal, the zoo was a huge disappointment. Animals hiding, animals sleeping, animal displays closed for maintenance. I think it's a go-to place for the little ones, since they have the children's area as well, but if you're a grown up looking for a walk on the wild side, save your money and go elsewhere.

(Pictures added)
author: Miss H.

description: Horrible experience!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Worse ever I grew up going there & took our grandson there  Monday hardly any animals, grounds not kept. No gorillas or elephants. $ 15.00 to get in $ 8.00 for parking food was terrible & 7.00 for a hot dog on a stale bun. They are not giving anything back into the zoo. Really sad. It was $ 200.00 wasted for 5 hours of NOTHING. They should be ashamed of themselves & shut down - Do not go there. I want a refund was in tears when I left looking at the conditions of the animals. Maybe they are still paying the law suit for the kid that was killed there by a tiger - I guess I paid for the attorney yesterday. Please Zoo close & give these wonderful animals a chance  give them to Oakland. People work hard for their money & they even charge for a 6 Min train ride after admission. Again I was ripped off ......
author: Deborah F.

description: It used to be more exciting years ago when the entrance was in the middle.  Now it is off to the far right in the $10 parking lot.  I think this is a ploy to push people into parking closer to the entrance and making money- smart but inconvenient.  The novelty isn't that awesome anymore when the chimpanzees were in the middle of the park shortly after you entered through the center entrance.  It seems there are less animals also.  Where the heck are the elephants?  There are a lot less birds.  There are no more black bears or Kodiak bears.  Maybe, they are hurting after the lame kid who decided to taunt the tigers and won a Darwin Award for it.  Regardless, I still enjoyed myself here, but it isn't like it used to be.  It seems their constant fight to protect the exhibits in terms of safety against stupid people and their spawn has impacted the quality of the zoo.  That is too bad.  Regardless, I still love this zoo.  I've been coming here since I was a kid and still enjoy seeing these precious animals.  That's why I'm a fan.
author: Elizabeth S.

description: This zoo is nice. There are a lot of different animals to see and peacocks EVERYWHERE. The gorillas were probably my favorite since they had a baby one which was so playful. The Lemurs are pretty cute as well though. Personally, I enjoy the Oakland zoo better, but this one is nice if you do not want to venture outside the city.
author: Lindsey V.

description: We came here for my daughters birthday and she loved it! She's only one years old but loved seeing all the animals and exhibits. We had a nice time. They did have a few places closed down which was a disappointment but overall it was great.
author: Selina S.

description: Nice effort from an obviously underfunded facility. Very much stuck in the 80's kind of zoo. The animals seemed happy (no plucked feathers, few tattered fur coats) except the Snow Tiger which paced nervously in it's small pen. The food is terrible - eat BEFORE you go. The gift shop is sadly a cacophony of Made In China trinkets and junk, much of the cause of the extinction of the animals on display. Be sure to take the L line  transit - it's a cool subway-cum-streetcar that rumbles through some cottage classics.
author: Greg R.

description:
I came here a couple of weeks ago with a friend and her little ones, which is always fun in a sort of vicarious way.  

I always have mixed feelings about the SF Zoo.  On the one hand, I love the spot, right next to the breakers right at the southern point of Ocean Beach, nestled in an evergreen forest that somewhat shelters it from the wind.  This is a beautiful evocative location for a zoo.
Unfortunately, I am not so sure the location is the best one for the animals.  The cold foggy weather virtually year round doesn't seem to offer many of the African species that are used to warmer climates in Africa the kind of weather they need.  Some of the older sections made of asphalt are quaint but really got to go.   They are a relic from another period in time.

That said, some of the newer sections of the zoo such as the walk through aviaries are really brilliantly done.  They seem to be following the model of the San Diego Zoo, which is to try to let the animals live as normally as possible within the conditions allowed.  My favorite section of the zoo is probably the section around the train where the bears and bigger animals are (and where that kid got killed a few years back).  I really like watching those big animals when they play in the water.  

For the kids, the train ride is always a good treat and great pick-me up if their interest is starting to flag.  Best leave it for about mid-day or after.   There is a bit of line usually but it is usually worth it.
author: Nikki K.

description: The SF Zoo has most of the animals I admire. Polar bears, grizzlies, lions, monkeys, elephants and rhinos. What really made me give this Zoo 4 stars was definitely the ape exhibit. I had never seen apes with such unorthodox and hostile personalities. My friends and I were just standing by the observational glass when 1 of the apes suddenly bum rushed the glass, made a 4 foot high jump and straight smacked the glass right by my face incredibly hard. Then he just mean mugged us to death and began to bang on his chest like you see in King Kong. Pretty awesome and so memorable, I will never forget that.
author: Patrick O.

description:
We came for free Wednesday and had a great time!  I love how the peacocks just roam free..they're so beautiful!  
I also loved the giraffe exhibit and the petting zoo.   We took my daughter on the choo-choo train and carousel and had lunch there.  I did feel sorry for the monkeys in cages, but all in all it was an enjoyable day.
author: anne m.

description: Very happy with my overall experience. There are a lot of remodeled enclosures since I was here two years ago. I also love that this zoo is filled with rescued animals. All the staff was very friendly and willing to stop and give you extra info on the wildlife. The food was very delicious and reasonably priced. If I lived closer I would come here weekly. Keep up the great work! Can't wait to go back!!
author: Nicholas J.

description: I must say I generally enjoyed coming to this zoo except today "FREE DAY" we got there and were asked to pay for our admission because we were not residents of SF.  Never heard of such a thing.  The way I see it is if the SF ZOO wants to better their zoo, why not make a "FREE TO ALL" day instead of "FREE TO SF RESIDENTS" day.  The will make more money for the animals and the property ($ on parking-$8-$10 /car, $ on food, $ on the train, $ at the giftshops).   In all honesty the zoo is quite run down with many exhibits being "renovated"...which seems like its taking forever to create this kids play area by the polar bears, but anyways, I don't see myself or my 3 and 5 year old children coming back to this zoo anytime soon...even if we are less than a 7 minute drive away.
author: Annalisa T.

description:
Hmm...lots of negative reviews here but I don't see why. Is this zoo the best one ever? No. Is it the worst one ever? NO.

To those who complain about the animals being in captivity, they were pulled out of their natural habitats because they are endangered. By having a safe place to live they are doing quite well compared to others in their species that aren't around anymore.

The zoo was fairly clean. Keep in mind that children come here so yes, there will be a stray cup that didn't make it into the garbage can or some stray toilet paper in the bathroom. Nothing was unsightly or gross; it just looks like a place that children frequent.

The day I was there, the animals were out and about. I saw bears, lions, tigers, penguins, rhino. My only gripe is that the elephants weren't there because they were remodeling the exhibit.
author: Valerie B.

description:
I went to the zoo yesterday and.....

I saw a scrawny grizzly bear with alopecia and a bad rash, an Indian Rhino with OCD who can't stop himself from filing down his own horn, and a stunning peacock being chased by unruly kids who kept screaming, "step on the tail"  as they tried to..step on the tail... throughout the entire park.

Parents who allowed their kids to chase that poor peacock and didn't stop them when they tried to step on it's tail should be b*tch slapped. I was so upset that I almost lost my cup of dippin dots in the melee. Almost. Why does a stranger have to explain to your kids not to pester and scare an animal? Morons. 

Oh and since when did the natural habitat for grizzlies include cement? 
An entire enclosure made of cement with no grass, trees, etc. Unacceptable, SF ZOO.

This zoo lacks the proper funding it needs to provide a better environment for these animals. I kept telling myself that the zoo is a good thing because it raises awareness on issues such as endangered species and illegal hunting, etc...but in this modern era with the internet, movies, high-def tv...a massive collection of magazines and books..our kids can be fully educated without having to keep a grizzly bear in an f-in tiny cement enclosure to be gawked at for most of the day.

I can't bring myself to enjoy this place and feel happy for the animals.

I can't help but think that the ailments of the balding bear and obsessive rhino are more stress-related than anything else. They're frustrated. 

No more SF zoo for me.
author: Susie O.

description:
When I was in elementary school, we went here on a field trip and I tried to sit on one of the goats at the petting zoo.

I remember the bug room being like a train wreck. I was disgusted but I kept staring at how gross they are.

I think I got shat on by the birds in the bird room.

I remember thinking I was cool because I could jump off the swings...until I fell flat on my face.
author: emily g.

description: This place is pretty awesome! My fave part was the lion house!!! Only rated a 3 star because the SERVICE IS HORRIBLE!! From being so excited to coming here, we got to the ticket booth and the lady was so rude! No expression or "have a wonderful time" all we got was "I hate my job" from her negative energy! So that totally ruined our excitement! Then we asked a security guard who was just standing around on his phone to take a group pic of us said no... gee, thanks for trying to keep ur customers happen! if it want for this horrible experience with the service, I woulda rated it at a 5 star. But since customer service is important to me, I gave a 3 star.
author: Cassy T.

description:
15 dollar admission fee per person, plus 10 dollar parking...that was ridiculous paying 40 dollars before even stepping foot into the zoo. The prices are outrageous! I know they have to keep the zoo running but seriously?!!? Just on the price note...4 dollars for a small dip n dot--normal for about any amusement park you go to. 5 dollars for a plain burger. 

For a zoo it was okay. The place was rather small, and dreary. All the exhibits and habitats were so small, the animals seemed crammed in there. When we went into the Lion House, there were only 2 lions. There were...20 other empty cages. 

The highlight of the day for me wasn't even an animal that belonged to the zoo. It was a wild squirrel that people were feeding and gathering around. It got way more attention than any animal at the zoo itself!

I don't expect the animals to be dancing and performing for us...I'd actually be rather appalled if they were forced to do any of that! But the place was so dreary...I was there for 4 hours and aside with being with my wonderful boyfriend who took me there, I was extremely unhappy with the place and would not be coming back.

On the plus side...some of the workers seem to know their animals and history which was one of the rare plus sides to this place.
author: Charlene P.

description: The zoo really impressed me and surpassed my expectations! We found free parking on the street and admission prices were very reasonable.  I thoroughly enjoyed myself and would recommend it to others who are looking for something different!
author: Dominique Y.

description:
There is a love hate relationship here with me and the Zoo.  Don't get me wrong, I love to see the animals who seem happy here but there are some animals who look pretty sad /bored here too.  For example, the polar bears and koalas.  The polar bears have this one pathetic patch of water for them to jump down into and the rest of their cave is just hard concrete hardly the comparison to their natural habitat.  As for the shamefully small glass case for the koala bear well ask yourself ...which animal in their right mind would want to be on display like a Christmas display in the Macy's window?  That's just to name a few of just seem clearly out of their natural element.  Oh and the Tree Monkeys ..whose cage does not include one real tree...I mean come on, it's a TREE Monkey, give him a tree or two??

For the ones that do seem happy...I would say my favorite parts of the zoo include the Petting area where the Goats and sheeps roam freely around and get fed by the patrons.  I really want a pet goat now!  The Meercats were also very cute.  Bring your quarters and buy them pellets for feeding.  It's fun and they mob you like your the dry pellet goat feeding goddess.  

My parking suggestion would be to scout out free parking before paying $6.  The walk is not too bad and there seems to a lot of free parking on the out skirts of the zoo if you don't a short hike.  Or you can take the "L" train (MUNI) directly to the zoo.  

Food....you're better not eating but there is a cafe in the middle of the zoo that serves $3 juices, hamburgers, garlic fries, corn dogs, and pizza.  Food is not cheap here and it's not that healthy but I think I saw some salads too.

There's also free admission on the first WED of each month!
author: Mel S.

description:
I hate this place. Probably one of the hardest place to get to on Earth! My friend and I walked all around this Zoo, it is just messed up. DON'T EVER GO THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION. IT IS JUST HORRIBLE! You will spend about 2 hours getting lost and walking.

The zoo, we went there for a project for a class. Guess what? The animal wasn't even there? The park ranger even challenged me on the facts. First, I was looking for a specific primate. I already know what I am looking for and she was like " I can't tell you, you have to find it". DUDE, its a zoo, you should be guiding us to the RIGHT animal. 

The park rangers were either uninformative or try to challenge the customer. IF I can't even find what I came here for, why come here?
author: Jessica H.

description:
Fairly average zoo.  It's a little small compared to some other, nicer zoos I've been to (like Atlanta and San Diego).  They have some neat animals, but nothing too crazily exotic.  Just your run of the mill polar bear, penguins, lions, tigers, giraffes, etc.

Oh, the food sucks.

Overall, your average zoo.
author: Chad H.

description: I've been to a lot of zoos.  I would put this one as a pretty decent experience.  The animals don't feel "on display" and they have habitats that are close to what they experience in Nature.  There aren't a ton of animals and the zoo isn't nearly as large as something like San Diego but it was a nice afternoon.  My daughter L O V E D the train, which is additional $4 but I was fine with that since we parked on the street and saved ourselves the $12 parking fee.  In the same weekend I went down to Monterey Aquarium and spent WAY more money and did not feel like we had as good of an experience.
author: Lissa o.

description:
Giving the zoo one star just because it's a zoo isn't fair, they should be judged at how good of a zoo they are. So how do they stack up? Right now they are good but not great. 

A fundamental problem with the zoo is that it's older and the layout of the exhibits doesn't really work that well anymore. They have made great strides in developing large, open multi-animal exhibits such as the african savanna section but other sections (such as the polar bears and pachyderms) are poorly developed. Fortunately those in charge recognize this and are moving the zoo toward redeveloping those exhibits. But here in lies the zoos catch 22. 

They are constrained by space and money. They can't do much to increase the space they have which makes it even more important to efficiently use the space they have already (do they really need a huge exhibit for the cassowary, which while an interesting bird to look at isn't exactly an animal a lot of people care much about, or are paying to see). However, this costs money and as we all know the SF zoo isn't exactly awash in cash and charging only $15 for adults ($12 for SF residents) compared to $37 for the SD zoo and it gets harder for them to fill their coffers for the needed renovations. 

With that said, they do a lot of things well. The trainers really love their animals and all are given the best care possible. The lemur forest and  gorillas are fun to watch, especially the new baby Hasani. The children section is well done and after some time off the snow leopards are back on display. Even the food isn't outrageously priced, it's about $10 for a burger and fries which seems to be about par for any type of museum, aquarium or zoo and they offer very fresh vegetables for toppings. 

SF Zoo also takes in animals that might otherwise be killed. For example, the two grizzly bear sisters are wild from Montana and were going to be killed for entering neighborhoods and taking food. The zoo learned about it and was able to take the animals in and put them into a pretty nice enclosure. However, this doesn't always work so well. For example the seal which is old and maybe blind probably would have been killed years ago in the wild and I can't help but wonder if the poor thing wouldn't be better off.

The zoo also offers learning programs for children, bike about tours of the zoo, a teenage volunteer program to help young adults learn about  animals as well as volunteer options for adults. 

Possible improvements to make it better: Renovate the older exhibits and make more efficient use of the land available. It wold also be nice if they offered some sort of regular behind the scenes tours or help with the feedings of the tamer animals which the public could be a part of, similar to the Monterey bay aquarium behind the scene tours, which would also be a way to raise money.
author: Russ C.

description:
I haven't been here in years and realize it's probably worse than it was when I was a kid.

But I got to experience something here that most people never have and never will.

I was in Girl Scouts (unfortunately, it's a family thing..mother, grandma, yadda yadda) and we had the opportunity to SPEND THE NIGHT IN THE ZOO.

I'm talking tents, sleeping bags, BBQ, awesomeness. We slept on the grass right next to the giraffes, which was close to where the rhino was. The rhino was actually birthing that night and we woke up to see a baby rhino before any park visitors had the chance! We also got to feed the mama rhino the afternoon before.

We were allowed to take flashlights and were instructed to shine the light above the animals at night, so we were free to roam and see the Zoo nightlife.

It was an amazing experience. Peacocks roam the zoo freely, and they did so at night as well.

How many people get to say they woke up with a peacock crawling on them? That's sounds gross. ANYWAY...

I don't know which animals they no longer have, but that sounds like a bummer. I never had a bad experience here, so I have to give it 4 stars.
author: Kal C.

description: Had a great time with the family. Staff is awesome, I just took my kids to the updated playground set to open in a few weeks (absolute best playground I have been too!) thanks Zoo folks for making this a favorite stop for my family!
author: Erick T.

description:
I really like the SF Zoo, it has a nice landscape with clean housing for their animals. Recently, they bulit a new grizzly bear habitat with a glass wall so that you can be as close as an inch away from the bears. They have brown bears, polar bears, and grizzly bears.

The giraffe habitat is also quite fun to watch, at least three lively giraffes are present. They also have a fun lemur habitat where you can visit top of the trees via a stairwell to an open bridge area. 

There are such a fun variety of animals (anteaters, sloths, koala bears, birds, snakes, everything) and it is perfect to bring kids. They have a good sized petting zoo with farm animals and a duck pond and fountains where you can wash your hands after touching the animals.

The layout of the zoo allows even the busiest day of all-- Free Wednesdays (first Wednesday of the month) to be relatively pain-free to visit.  Also, there are a number of cafes inside the zoo that provide tasty food like hamburgers or burritos for a reasonable price.
author: Lorissa W.

description:
The last time I was at the zoo, I was 11 years old. I have been wanting to go back since they started doing the renovations and just didn't have a chance or the time to make it out there.

Over Labor Day weekend, I decided to go with my boyfriend. My mom is a member and added me onto the membership so I got in free and so did my boyfriend, with a free admission coupon. I think regularly, without a membership, its about $10? Not too bad. Anyways, you'd think on Labor Day it would be super busy and crazy, but it actually wasn't too bad.

We got there around 3 p.m. and honestly, a couple hours was enough to see everything (the zoo closes at 5 p.m.). I am really happy to see that a lot of the habitats are renovated or in the process of being renovated - everything as a whole just seems happier here, despite the whole situation with the tigers last year.

I'm really glad that we decided to go, it's really a great idea for a relaxing afternoon. Go towards the end of the day because that is when its least crowded and you can see a lot of the animals being fed :)
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Wanna see fluffy polars that have turned green? Peacocks in empty "currently under reconstruction" exhibits? Penguins in a habitat the size and shape of my bathtub? 

How about a 15 dollar hot dog that looks sweaty? Or a churro that tastes like sand?

No? Then fly down to San Diego and go to their zoo. I even prefer the one in Sacramento over this pit of sad animals.
author: Lorelle M.

description: Love taking my son to the zoo.  The SF zoo is big so theres a lot fo walking, but still fun.  The Oakland Zoo is great too and a little bit smaller.
author: Lyndsey S.

description:
I went to the SF Zoo on a date 8 years ago for the first time. Worst Date Ever.

We watched a rhino try to get around with an infection on his penis - it was gross more than sad. And not nearly as funny as it sounds now. 
Also, I watched a hippo in its little pool in its enclosure try, for what seemed like HOURS, to turn over or get water on its back - it couldn't. The pool was too small.... and I CRIED. 

Now I grew up going to the SD Zoo and Wild Animal Park, so I know my standards are high. I have since avoided the SF Zoo for the last 5.5. years that I have lived here. 

Welcome Nov 1, 2009 - I decide to be an awesome girlfriend (yet again) and go with my BF who needs to take notes on monkey observations for a class. 

Well, I was very pleased - the zoo looked great from when I was last there. The exhibit areas near the entrance all looked new-ish, the place was clean. It was worlds different than before. 

I was told their hippos died of old age and that's why they don't have them - in my head they died a horrible death of enclosures too small for their bodies. However, the giraffes, gorillas, rescue area (with many BABY turtles) and insect zoo are all new highlights for me. People do tend to let their kids scream a little too much near some of the sensitive animals - and that made me cringe. But if that is the worst of the events today. I am very pleased.

Tips to save:
Show SF residency and get $3 off your ticket
Save the $8 to park in their lot and park on Sloat near 47th.
