Bring your lunch and picnic over by the primate area or penguins.
author: Jessica L.

description: Beautiful displays of birds and mammals make this a worthy destination for animal lovers. The keepers are knowledgeable and helpful.
author: Carol S.

description:
On the first Wednesday of each month, San Francisco residents may enter the zoo without admission fees.  What a deal.

The zoo is currently being remodeled, so many exhibits are closed.  
Due to the Dhaliwal brothers incident, there are currently no tigers.    The animals look sleepy and unhappy.  I could not even see the Asian Indian Rhino, because the pachyderm building was shut down.  The last elephant packed her trunk and moved to the foothills of the Sierra  in 2005 and the last hippo died in 2008.  What is a zoo without elephants, hippos, and tigers.  The current habitat displays are much more natural than the depressing concrete structures from the '50s.

Must be a sign of the times, but after a little girl broke a glass bottle at the Leaping Lemur Cafe, the mother rounded up the kids and left the dangerous mess behind without telling anybody.  I had to tell one of the people behind the counter to help clean up the broken glass.   I believe the younger generation lack common decency and even a modicum of manners.  At least the polish dog was edible.  

Restrooms were clean.  Docents were helpful.

San Diego and London Zoos are superior.
author: Coyote B.

description:
Wow, this place is awesome. We loved it. We have been to the Oakland Zoo a bunch of times and recently we visited Sea World so we have some ammunition for comparisons.
This zoo is well organized, clean, well-maintained and has some stuff that is hard to find elsewhere.
Don't miss the nocturnal lemur enclosure. That was a highlight! 
The Nature Walk (in the Children's Zoo) was something even my older kids (11 and 12) loved. Each animal they met was accompanied & introduced by a (human) volunteer handler (age 12-15) who was really well-educated about each animal and was friendly, helpful and a great resource. We loved meeting the snakes, turtles and chinchillas. 
Any time we get to see the animals being fed and getting to ask questions of the handlers it's awesome. They were super friendly, knowledgeable and really helped open up the life of the animal.
It's not super big so it's not hard to make your rounds in half a day. 
Don't miss catching the train with your little ones. Super fun!
author: Christiaan V.

description:
I am definitely NOT a fan of zoos in general, but as a child I came here to the SF Zoo pretty happily until I began to grow up and realize that it just wasn't right to keep animals in captivity. (Man, did I love my Zoo Key!)  As an adult I very rarely came to this zoo, until my new hubby, who'd never been, wanted to bring our 4 year old.

The SF Zoo has really made the effort to move into a new era of zoos. Some zoos that I have been to in other places, put the animals into very large enclosures and this is a great improvement over the traditional zoo, of which SF was one, that had small concrete enclosures.  So apparently in the past few years, SF has tried to update, creating, for example, a nice open giraffe (with other animals) area in the front of the zoo with a great giraffe barn.  This was actually the highlight of our first visit, watching the giraffes eat in their barn at around 4pm. 

So, overall, I can totally understand the objections that many reviewers have stated about zoos in general, however, the SF Zoo has tried to update and does a pretty good job. In addition to the giraffe barn, we enjoyed the small monkeys, and insect hall.  Food fairly good, prices reasonable, kids get to appreciate and develop an interest in animals they never otherwise would have seen.
author: Hilary S.

description:
Best things in life are free why not give it a hi 5 :)

petting zoo pwns
author: Dylan C.

description:
Medium on the depressing scale. It's an older zoo so the animals don't have a lot of room to roam, especially the predatory ones. In one of the habitats there as a interactive map that lit up to show the natural ranges of various animals superimposed on the center of SF, and the range for a raccoon was already bigger than the entire zoo. This was in the grizzly area, I think, and the displayed range for the bear was the entire city or something like that. Ironic.

That said, the animals looked pretty well kept, no scraggly fur or anything. Animals were free to roam in the savanah exhibit and they do seem to be working on some more open range exhibits.
author: Jin Z.

description: I'll start off saying I'm a bit bias/spoiled because I've lived near the San Diego Zoo recently. The kids enjoyed it, especially the kids area. This zoo felt old & delapedated. Some areas felt like end of the world happened a decade ago, and you're seeing it for the first time since. Old deserted exhibits hardly covered up, just empty and overgrown. And all the areas for the animals felt small. I know this is SF and there's no way to really expand, but maybe take that new park area they're spending $ on and expand an exhibit. All in all we had a decent time... but the place needs some major updating.
author: Lindsay L.

description: Huge Zoo and a great experience. Way better that Oakland Zoo. There food court also has many options to choose from.
author: DJ F.

description:
I grew up with this zoo, and I love it here. My grandma has worked there for years. There are many nice employees, volunteers, and custodians that work there and care for the animals. There are a variety of animals from many parts of the world. It is cool when the white crocodile was there and when I saw baby tigers there. I miss the hippos there as well as some of the veterans of the zoo that are no longer with us. 

Parking can be a pain, but walking a little to go to the zoo is not that bad. I do hope that the animals at the zoo that are endangered can grow and regain strength in numbers. The zoo is great for families and children, and the food is good. I do wish that the zoo had more security to keep out trouble makers. It would be nice if the zoo had elephants, capybara's and hippos again. It would be nice to see pandas there.

The train is very fun to ride on. The merchandise is great for kids. I miss their night-time exhibit and the zoo-colored trams that used to be at the zoo. 


 I do not understand why police think it is ok to automatically kill animals if they are protecting themselves from mean people. I swear SFPD can be very hypocritical. All those three kids responsible for that tiger's death should have been killed or thrown into prison for life. The guy that kidnapped one of the monkeys at the zoo should also be killed or thrown into life in prison. 

If you don't like animals, then don't go to the zoo. Keep your ignorant thoughts and actions to yourself.
author: DJ Guan Yu M.

description: I usually like zoos but this one made me sad. It was very dirty and I saw garbage inside the animal enclosures. There wasn't much staff present and when I tried to tell someone about it they laughed. Don't support this zoo.
author: Nigel S.

description: Awesome! Don't miss the raptor feeding if you're there.  Great  zoo, we love this place.
author: Bob S.

description: This place ROCKS! I been here numbers of times from visting from the 1970's,1980's,1990's, some of 2000 and later living in Marin CA for past 7 years seeing this place had chang over the year and awesome place to bring your family here! The prices of food has change over the years but their is a McDonald not to far to go there!
author: EdwardF A.

description:
I was excited to see this zoo. I had a vision of it being a sanctuary for animals. It was and it wasn't. The outside habitats were pretty depressing, sparse, small, and not very engaging (for the animals). I giant rhino kind of looked like he wanted to die. I would hate to see the back enclosures. I would probably cry. 

The grizzly habitat was probably the best designed. The giraffe, zebra, and ostrich area had the most space and those animals seemed pretty happy. There were also multiples of them. I think some of the animals would probably be better if they had companions. I'm not a zoologist though, but it seems like pack animals should be with other animals of their kind.  

I think zoos offer a great learning experience, but I hope this zoo is able to redesign some of its habitats to be more animal friendly. If you can go, it's a great way to support a good cause.
author: K. C.

description: We went to see the new tiger cub of course! It was the cutest thing ever!! Would recommend it for sure! The 3 stars is because I noticed immediately the zoo smelled bad. Duh there are animals everywhere, but I've been to other zoos and the smell wasn't as bad as this one. Also, they should clean the glass walls more often so that we could see the cats better. It was still fun though :)
author: Debbie J.

description: This was my first trip to the SF Zoo in a number of years and my first since the extensive remodel of several years ago.  My question is, where the bleep are all the animals?  The new habitats are nice but there are simply too many empty display areas.  Maybe this is a new type of zoo where toy get to see an empty display area with a sign and not the actual animal.  SF Zoo used to be world class.  Now, second rate at best.
author: Douglas L.

description: such a great place to see animals. Great location and plenty of parking...Too bad they don't have good quality food or restaurants..but I would go again in a heart beat..
author: Jennifer L.

description:
I haven't been to the zoo in a few years.  I actually miss coming here.  I use to go to the zoo every year when my daugther's school use to have field trips here.

3.5 stars this time around because they raised the parking fee :-(  As i recall, when my daughter was in elementary school, the parking fee was only 5.00.

We came here yesterday to check out the new hippo, as we approach the area where the new hippo was suppose to be, guess what!!!  He wasn't there :-(  Again disappointed!!!  

I will be back, but hopefully the Hippo will be out and about when we visit again!  San Francisco Zoo, please don't disappoint me the next time I visit.
author: Shana W.

description: I recently visited this zoo and i was a little disappointed to discover that it was empty!  Everything was closed including the merry go round ride and train.  All the animals were either non-existent or sleeping.  I really wished they warned us about how everything in this zoo was non-functional before we paid the $10 to go in.
author: Carla M.

description: So when I lived in so cal. I went to the LA Zoo, and the San Diego Zoo Often. This place is some ways is way better then them. They exhibit layouts are AMAZING probably better then any other zoo, I got to watch a giraffe eating at eye level!!!, The animals mostly because its allot cooler is SF are out and about and are not hiding in there homes, The only thing is they are a smaller zoo so they don't have as many as LA or SD but it is still good, defiantly worth $15 admission, It took me a little over 4 hours to see everything and every animal I saw was amazing! The only downside is they only have like 3 areas to buy food and they are so far removed from the exhibits, you have to go out of your way to get food, but it is good i bought an $8 cup that gives free refills for the day and anytime I bring it back. I highly recommend checking this zoo out.
author: Julian Q.

description:
Zomg is that a tiger chasing me?!?!

jk

But seriously they had to shut down part of it because another animal tried to get out of the cage when we visited!
author: Robert P.

description:
It breaks my heart too see those animals living in the enclosed environment that is so unnatural to them.  Besides getting fed regularly and living supposedly safer than in the wild, I doubt those animals are living a happier life.  Some get companies, such as the tigers, lions, and grizzly bears;  there were 2 of each.  But most were sadly alone in their exhibit.

The petting zoo was cute.  Lots of goats and sheep to pet.  Put in 2 quarters and you can get a half handful of kibbles to feed them.  

Although it makes me sad to see those animals in cages and behind gates, but if paying that $15 admission is a way to help to pay for the care of those animals, it is then worth it.
author: Tadaa T.

description: So decided to go spend the day at the zoo. Never been to the one in SF an was excited for the day. Ok first issue. PARKING! Waste of time. After 20 minutes of searching an nothing. Come to find out it cost 10$ for parking. Total rip off. Finally parked an proceeded into the zoo. The main Exhibit my date an I we're looking forward to see witch was the lions!!! Was closed for the day. They should have posted on the website that the lions were out on vacation or something. We decided to go see the bears. Ok two bears. One was knocked out an sleeping. The other looked like he was to old to move or do anything. To top it all off they need some sort of a contractor in there to fix the uneven paths an upgrade their theme parks over all experience. All an all ladies an gents don't waste your time an hard earned money cause the lions are on vacation
author: JustinRocky S.

description:
I came here with my photographer BF to take some pics.  We lugged around some heavy duty camera equipment and went shooting.  We got some decent shots of some animals and some great ones too.  

Most of the habitats were "under renovation", which means what?  They ran out of money and it's just sitting there doing nothing?  I went to the zoo about 6 months prior to this last visit and the same exhibits were being put together.  Maybe I'll have to wait another 6 months to a year and check back again.

I was extremely saddened by some of the habitats the animals were kept in.  The tigers were just pathetic looking and one of the two was just skin and bones.  So sad....

I really don't like coming here but for kids I guess it's educational.  They also had a bald eagle out sitting on a guys arm.  We got some footage of that and the penguins.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NaisQl9HPPA&playnext_from=TL&videos=5b7pBQnnVvY&playnext=1
author: Rosalind S.

description: Nice zoo. Fun.
author: Denise C.

description:
I had heard mixed reviews about the zoo, but I found the actual zoo interior better than expected. I was envisioning a small town zoo that depresses you. The enclosures were well kept...some could use some updating with the glass not scratched from zillions of tourists to the point you can see the animal clearly...but overall not bad. However, there were 2 rectifiable issues:

1. Many of the pathways were closed due to construction, but they didn't tell you this until you walked 2-3 minutes down a blind dead end. With kids in tow, this sucks. It happened 3 times.

2. There was a major jam and arguments at the parking exit gate. There are literally no signs in the parking lot explaining the parking ticket system...so several cars didn't have one and got stuck first in line at the gate. Of course, the help intercom doesn't work.  Turns out the ticket scanner didn't work for my ticket either, but luckily the little Prius could just drive around the gate.
author: dan g.

description:
I feel bad for this zoo.  I've been in the area for years and this is the first time I've been here, and my daughter absolutely loved it.  Of course we tried to steer clear from the dangerous animal zones.   Just in case they aren't regulation height.   

But from what my daughter loved:

1) The penguins to watch. 
2) The Petting Zoo ... she absolutely loved the petting zoo. 
3) The large playground 
4) Carousel it made her dizzy though. :) 

I'd recommend it give the 4 above items.  I'm not even sure how much it costs because we we're there for a birthday party.   And I don't think any kid was dissappointed.    

Kids love animals.  We've been to Oakland zoo, and I like this better.  And the kid zones here we're pretty large.    So yes the tiger jokes, we're rampant, and it was a running joke, as well as a point to keep your wits about while walking around the bears, and tigers. 

But as long as the kids we're happy.  And the parents too in watching their kids see wild life animals in real life.    There is tv, and there is real life.  This is real life caged in but real.   

Let's try to make this place safer for everybody else.
author: Homer S.

description: We are from Phoenix visiting the Monterey Bay Aquarium with our grandson and decided to drive up to the zoo. It was a great decision. The zoo was easy to get around, the exhibits were well done and he loved the nature trail with the smaller rotating exhibits with kid volunteers. It wasn't so big that it was overwhelming and easily walkable.  Even the food was good!
author: Patricia D.

description:
The San Francisco zoo is a wonderful place to take your kids for the day.
I haven't been there since i was a child. It is much prettier than I remember .
The steam train was amazing, very fun. The animals were exciting and beautiful to see.
The only thing I didn't really appreciate was the price of parking around 10 dollars.
Also, it wasn't very easy to get out of the parking lot either. The system definitely needs to be updated. It could cause  some people not to come very often.
It is a wonderful place to go,i will definitely go again.
author: Monique G.

description: The San Francisco zoo so great the animals look so happy the flute is also awesome and plus being able to see the ocean right after we come on to the zoo was a very fun the kids loved it
author: Mo M.

description: Small place, and some exhibits were really nice, while others are just...sad. Especially the big cats. There's no other word to really describe this place.. over all, it's alright.  If you have someone visiting here, it's really not worth it at all.  However, it's only 15 bucks and you kill some time with that but really... not worth it.  However, if you got kids and you live in the bay.. it's the only zoo around because the oakland zoo is just a sad little place.
author: Meena N.

description:
Sad and depressing. We visited on a holiday weekend and you would think the zoo would perk up a bit when they expect more people. The place was filthy - trash and junk food scraps everywhere - including i nthe enclosures!!!  Garbage bins were overflowing and there was no evidence of maintenance anywhere.  

We walked every path in the zoo looking for something alive.  We dragged our children past endless chain link fences and abandoned exhibits. The gorillas looked healthy and the enclosure was clean. Apart from that and perhaps the Children's zoo there isn't really any reason to visit. Yes, lemurs and giraffes - but those are hardly enough reason to spend the $50 it takes for a family of 4 to enter.

Just sad, just plain sad.
author: Corinne C.

description:
This zoo is a little smaller than San Diego and some of the habitats are older but the staff is usually very friendly. Food isn't bad, prices are comparable to other major attractions. Lions, tigers, bears, oh my!

They have keepers and volunteers bring out owls, vultures and hawks in the children section so you can really see them up close. They just opened a fishing cat exhibit so you can see the cat catch a fish. Also saw it eat a rabbit. Mmmmm...the other white meat. 
Also, largest colony of Magellanic Penguins anywhere. Be sure to get there in time for the feeding. Found out their elephants and hippos were really old and are no longer so they are redoing their habitats. Black Asian Rhinos are sweet though (and rare)!

Carousel is from 1921 and it excellent condition. They have an actually steam train to ride on too.
It's a lot more zooey and a lot less ridey than Oakland.
author: Chris B.

description:
Gotta love their free admission every first Wednesday of the month.

Open 365 days a year! Wow! Moderate and expected admission prices with senior and child discounts. Members get to go as much as they want any days. 

I've been here about 3 times if I remember correctly. Field trip. Fun date. SF day with my friend. Large variety of animals and exhibits. Friendly staff who truly care about animals. Good place for family and kids. 

SEE PICS!
author: Mia N.

description:
Came here for the first time a couple of years ago and it was seemed like the saddest zoo ever!

I feel like this is the only zoo where Polar Bears are tanned and sit in their "caves" with their backs turned to the observers. There were peacocks roaming around minding their own business. Birds were chained at the foot for obvious reasons. Seals hanging out at the bottom of their pools not wanting to be bothered.

It was one of the weirdest experiences ever! You could literally get up close with the animals though I don't think you should.
author: Lola L.

description:
If possible, try to visit the zoo when they have the Halloween event. It's fun seeing kids in costumes, etc. 

As an animal lover, I am usually bummed when I see animals in such crampt environments, but I was quite pleased with the amount of space the larger animals had. 

The only animals that looked depressed were the Polar Bears. I would be sad too, if I didn't have ice islands and I was a Polar Bear. 

Animals not to miss are: 
1. Meerkats 
2. Prairie dogs 
3. Penguins 
4. Tapir 
5. Baby gorilla 
6. Zebra 
7. Giraffe 

There is a small tank exhibit for the penguins at the Cal Academy of Science, but the SF Zoo penguins are free to move around outdoors. They have an ice island and pool area to hang out in.  

Overall, I enjoyed visiting this zoo for the first time, as I don't remember going when I was younger.
author: Michael S.

description:
I should start by saying that my family and I are members of the SF Zoo, and we visit there at least once a month.  So obviously we don't hate it.   But there are things I've noticed over time that I think the zoo really needs to work on.  

First of all, as several other reviewers have noted, there is one polar bear who does nothing but pace back and forth all day in an agitated state.  This has been the case every time I've visited.  I've read that they got one of their bears from a Canadian town where the bear had been menacing residents, and that this bear was considered too aggressive to be with the other polar bears.  I think this is the same bear.  They have this bear caged very close to the pool where they have their new sea lion exhibit -- not sure that was the kindest planning, given that this bear is already in an agitated state and that polar bears have a very keen sense of smell.  Also not sure if it's kind to the sea lion, since it is a blind sea lion who might have an enhanced sense of smell himself.  Anyway, I wonder if they are feeding the bear enough, or if a bear who has "issues" with humans is a good candidate for a zoo exhibit.

There is also a small tiger who paces aggressively in a similar way.  Some of you may remember the reports from a couple years back, that the tiger who escaped and killed a zoo visitor had lost 50 lbs since arriving at SF Zoo.  I hope they are feeding their animals the right amount to keep them healthy and at least somewhat content.  

The grizzlies seem happy.  And the zoo does have a good policy -- which may be economically motivated -- of taking in animals that have been injured or maimed and cannot survive in the wild.  A lot of one-winged birds around.  That may add to the "depressing" vibe that others allude to, but at least the animals on display shouldn't be pitied too much for being in a zoo.  Also, the volunteers and docents are great.  

There's one woman who works in the membership office who's always super-cranky and unfriendly.  It feels strange to be willingly giving her money.  

My child's favorite exhibit is the Bug House.  I don't totally get the appeal, but she's happy there and it's warm and dry on cold days.  I notice that one of the Velvet Ants is always pacing aggressively, however....
author: Cynthia B.

description: Pathetic desperately in need of renovation.  Overpriced admission for what is offered.
author: J W.

description: Small zoo next to a cold foggy beach. Occasionally an animal will maul someone on or around a holiday. It happens.
author: Jordan P.

description: Went here with my daughter for her first bday.  Its a lot smaller than I remembered.  Still had a great time though.  Beer was only $5.  Gotta respect a zoo that won't rip you off on the brew.  Will definitely be back as often as possible.
author: Sam T.

description:
I like the zoo and the upgrades. It's a lovely park. Very different from the last time I was there. Enjoyed all the animals, but went mainly to see the grizzly bears for the first time--I love all bears. They are massive, beautiful, intelligent and sensitive animals. 

So why the absurd train running by the bear enclosures tooting the shrill whistle? 

The grizzly bears could use more space as could all the bears. The polar bear was pacing. San Diego did a great job with their polar bear exhibit--large, refrigerated, deep pool, bear toys to keep him interested--the bear looked content, anyway. Zoos are happy and sad places. If we are going to contain animals we should do our best to understand their needs and make them as comfortable as possible. I'd prefer to see fewer animals in better environments.
author: Kay B.

description: DO NOT EVEN BOTHER! I think they should just return all animals back to the wild instead of keeping them in cages. There's not much to see. ALL animals looked so bored and depressed! $17 its just not worth it. There's a train inside the zoo and you have to pay extra?! If you value your time and money dont go!
author: Kathy D.

description:
Lions and tigers and bears, oh my. 

Yea they got all that at the SF Zoo. I thought it was going to be larger, 1 star off for that. Checking my ID (so I get a residents discount) gratuitously and not letting the lady friend get it, 1 star off. 

Nice zoo, good bang for the buck. Well kept and easily accessible by public transport, L train. Go check it out, bring some alcohol with you.
author: Kenny H.

description:
I am giving 4 stars for respect to the animals in there.  $15.00 per person seems to be a little bit high to me considering the grounds and the animals looking neglected.  My review is based solely on my visit.  The lion, tigers, and polar bears were  all asleep and tired.  I mean these animals look sad and depressed to me ;(.  It just breaks my heart.  The train ride was great.  Customer service is great. The children's farm was AMAZING! ;) now those animals looked happy. ;)

Enjoy!
author: Nin P.

description:
LOVED the children's zoo....luckily we started there first.  The guinea pigs caught my attention.  So free and cute!!  Wish they had more info about them or had people talk to us about how they were fed, cared for, etc.  The petting farm was very nice too.  It helps to bring a kid along and see him taste their pellets and immediately have a disgusted expression.  PRICELESS!  The goats were pushy but rightfully so...they want and need their food dammit....

The other side of the zoo was "okay".  The animals were bored, sleepy (like I was), sleeping, eating, or not there.  Some of the animals were rescued.  It's nice to know that part, otherwise I would have thought some animal abuse was going on.  Well, even more so that being locked up against their will.  Catch 22.

Wish I would have ridden the $4 steam train but my cheapness got the best of me, BOO=(

Would I go back?  Definitely on first Wednesdays to take advantage of my SF residency, hyuk hyuk hyuk.
author: Aleka Y.

description: I hate seeing all these untrue and negative reviews about the SF Zoo. If you honestly think that the keepers don't care about the animals they are caring for you couldn't be more wrong. Ask any of the keepers about the animals they care for and they will tell you individually about each animal and their personalities. I honestly can't believe people think that someone also killed Kabibe on purpose?! They helped care for her before she was even born, don't you think they got attached to her like a family member too after seeing her grow into the beautiful goofy girl she was? Yes, there have been some accidents at this Zoo but when you're dealing with exotic animals you can't really predict everything can you? They do so much for the animals in their care and they love them!! And to all the people claiming that the animals look sad or aren't very active, animals have good days and bad days just like people, what you're expecting is unrealistic. If they aren't moving maybe the weathers got them down or maybe they're tired not everything means "look i'm so unhappy and sad" THEY'RE ANIMALS! You can't control what they do and how they feel. I would also like to mention that the staff really caters to what the animals would like to do they are never forced to do anything.
author: Lexi S.

description:
I like animals and nature and all that hippy bullcrap. So 5 stars.

I developed a love for mammals and birds here. I loved going to see the mammal freaks like the ant eaters and look at the tropical birds. Still more educational than Six Flags, minus all the lame teenagers.

But yeah, the animals are often sleeping and hidden. So go on a warm day. Poor animals are in the cold all the time.
author: Lana P.

description:
THIS PLACE WAS CRAP THE DAY I WENT!

About 4 years ago I went on the 4th of July and it was great! Lots to do, animals in every kennel, great atmosphere, great weather, just plain fun!

But umm, this year, 2010 on July 5th all I can say is MEH! I HAVE EXPERIENCED BETTER!

As we left the zoo the man behind us asked his kids, "Did you have fun?!" 
"Noooo..." The kids replied with disappointment in their little voices.

The love and I decided to take my munchkin brother and sister along with his sister to the zoo, i can't tell you how excited we were with it being their first time and us finally getting out of the house, yes we were excited alright..up until we got there!

IT WAS SO BORING!

Hardly any animals, the ones that were there looked so so so sad, i kind of wanted to risk my little life to set them free...EVERYONE looked bored..it was an ugly day (even though this has nothing to do with the zoo..however it does add to the horrible trip) and the pretzel were among THE WORST PRETZELS I HAVE EVER HAD IN MY LIFE!

The kids had grim looks on their faces all day, the most exciting part for them was seeing a lion close up in a cage..(who had his back turned to us the entire 15 minutes we watched) and the gift shop.

Other than these tiny factors i will never be back again..unless someone else is treating me..seriously.

2 stars for pretty inexpensive price ( $57 for 2 adults, 3 kids) and for the up close encounter with the giraffes! AMAZING...unfortunately the only thing that was AMAZING about this place.
author: Brittany D.

description:
I think there is one or two of each animal, except the peacocks that were walking around out in the open. Notable areas to check out are the lion house, tiger, kangaroos, eagle and owl exhibits, penguin feeding, grizzly bears getting frustrated with eating their frozen blocks of food, prairie dogs, and the insect zoo. I had time to walk around and take pictures of most of the animals in 90 minutes or so. I was too late to check out the gorilla, but I imagine it would have been cool, too. There are a lot of benches, so if you get tired, you can also rest with some popcorn or Dippin' Dots (quite a gyp, by the way). As you exit, there is even a recycle bin for your map.

My favorite part was the insect zoo in a separate building. The roaches were so gross. Oh god, domestic roaches and I have a bit of a history, so it was weird and satisfying to see the appallingly huge, meaty roaches all crowded in a glass box. I'd like to see them scattering out from a far distance. This mini-zoo even had non-insects such as spiders and millipedes. The container labeled "black widow" didn't seem to have anything inside, but I didn't get bitten or anything so

For $15 ($9 for S.F. residents and people 8?-14), $3 more than the L.A. Zoo, it seems more popular (hard to find parking around the zoo, find in residential streets) and a good deal even though I don't even like animals that much (I guess only the ones that are confined).
author: Brian H.

description: I miss all the old exhibits from my childhood, but so look forward to all the new exhibits the zoo has to promise.  My children loved coming here when they were younger and hopefully we will see new things in the future.
author: JJAMZ C.

description:
when I was 6, the chimpanzees threw their poo at my uncle (who was sleeping on a bench in front of their exhibit). true story.

so anywaaay, long story short, this place is like Disneyland if:
1) you're a kid or 2) you're a first-timer and you really love seeing animals or something
otherwise, it'll be a "nice day out"...

Top3 things to do:
1) Children's Family Farm - if you'e a kid or kid at heart, whatever, come here! you get to pet, feed, and brush goats and llamas. they even frolic freely here, lol.
2) Big Cats Show - see lions and lionesses being fed in the Big Cat house. 
3) Aye Aye monkey tour - see the nocturnal aye ayes in their special dark exhibit

when I was 6, this zoo was awesome. purely awesome because I got to see so many cool animals, aaand just amazing because of the chimpanzee incident. 
well I'm not 6 anymore, and hey, things change... and so did my take on this zoo.

but here's the thing, even if this place doesn't come close to that happy vibe you get at the Disneyland entrance, at least you had a relaxing day well-spent.
author: Surabhi I.

description:
I am still sticking to my 1 star but after receiving an email pointing out the fact that there are crummier zoos in the U.S. besides the one in S.F. (specifically Buffalo, NY - I haven't been it was just the example in the email I received) - I had to share my response to this email and some reasoning behind my 1 star rating:

"Thank you for your note.  I am sure the Buffalo Zoo is much worse than the SF Zoo.   It is a great reminder that there are always places with worse conditions, always someone else or someplace else who has it worse, always. This is true and I should keep it in perspective.  However, I am a native San Francisco girl (fourth generation) and for a city that strongly and loudly espouses "lead by example" and  "higher standards as a standard" for a variety of reasons - among them devotion to the welfare of animals - I have to judge this zoo with a harsher eye.  A city that has proposals to ban all pet sales within the city due to the "conditions" the animals must endure I think should be held to a higher standard with their own zoo.  A city full of diners that are wildly concerned with the living conditions of their food prior to slaughter....well, I'm holding that city to a higher standard on their zoo.  Look, I love the city - the good, the bad and the in between.  I am sure there are worse zoos in the U.S. and I've seen far worse outside of the U.S. (which would be an apples/oranges comparison), but I do feel this zoo deserves a 1 at best because of where it is located and the minimal expectations of a partially subsidized institute dedicated to the care and welfare of animals.  But, you are right, there are far worse places in the U.S."
author: Giovanni C.

description: This is probably my favorite zoo in California, and yes I have been to the San Diego Zoo, I even camped there. The reason I love the zoo here is bc I like that theres animal to see everywhere you go and the spaces arent too far apart, I also like that the weather is cool and that the zoo itself makes you want to walk. I love how they have peacocks running around everywhere and the two headed snack in the reptile section of the zoo is pretty neat. My favorite thing to look at in this zoo though are the penguins and koala bears
author: Ai T.

description:
needs money put into it,lots  of space but few animals.go in the morning as in afternoon animals are sleeping or sitting down,long walk around some nice plants but I would like more animals,kids will love it,zoo visitors are annoying the bother the animals by waving,shouting etc,needs cleaning a bit more on the paths,a few empty exhibit's,needs more money put in as some exibits need face lift,,small train $4
parking is a lot $8,
$5 would be enough
muni L and 18 bus goes there,
kids will love the zoo,
map they give you is hard to follow,they need more signs,took me about 3 hours to go around,i missed out a few things,family yearly pass $105
the grounds need work,lots of exibits were blocked off or empty,
they need fund raiser to put more money into it
author: cc c.

description:
I love this zoo. It brings back childhood memories, although it's nothing like it was when i was a kid.  Many of the original exhibits are gone. But that is a good thing because the newer exhibits seem to be more comfortable for the animals, no the cramped, concrete enclosures they once were.  

 My son and I visit the zoo about once a week and it's fantastic.  Some people complain about the animals not being out on "display" but they are wild animals and cannot be forced to be out entertaining the zoo visitors.  You have to go there not expecting to see every animal.  We are zoo members, so we aren't that disappointed if the animals are hiding or just sleeping.  We are able to go as often as we want.

I suggest getting there early and parking out on Sloat - where the parking is free.  Otherwise it is $8 to park in the parking lot on weekdays and $10 on weekends.

We just wish the Little Puffer's engineer would smile once in a while.  

Definitely bring a jacket.  The weather on the coast can be cold and damp, even if it's sunny a couple miles away.
author: Andrea T.

description:
Gotta give props to a place that is open on New Year's Day!  I usually hate NYD because there is nothing to do.  When I found out the zoo was open, my daughter and I hopped in the car and went right on over.

For some reason, this part of SF is much colder, windier and foggier than most other parts of the city.  I feel bad for the African animals.  They must be miserable here.

The staff were so nice on our visit, even the folks working at the cafe grill.  I was glad to see one staffer chastising a visitor who was feeding the monkeys.  I mean, what idiot doesn't know you can't feed the animals?  Save it for the petting zoo, biatch.

Even though I like it here, the zoo is pretty sad compared to those in other major (and even minor) cities.  The pachyderm compound is empty and decaying, save for one lonely tapir.  Poor thing.  You'll walk past many, many unused cages and exhibits.  It gets depressing pretty fast.

The children's/petting zoo is a lot of fun.  Watch out for those nasty goats, though!  One kicked my daughter -- not hard, we laughed about it.  Still, they are MEAN.  The prairie dogs and meerkats are a blast to watch.

On sunny days, this is a lovely place to hang out.  For the other 360 days of the year, you'll want to dress in layers.
author: Raina S.

description:
Who doesn't like going to the zoo? I LOVE IT! I know I haven't been here a lot & it's not the best zoo in the world but it's in San Francisco my home!

I remember coming here as a child with my aunts & uncles and having a blast. 

I DO HATE THE FACT THAT THEY CHANGED THE ENTRANCE TO THE SIDE.... BOOOOO TO THEM! but for the memories & the love of animals I give this place 4-stars.... & YAY! I'm a fan!
author: Dessa S.

description: Such a beautiful place to spend the afternoon. The trees and plants are gorgeous and the weather is perfect in the summer time with the breeze off the ocean and all of the shade. Lots of animals although I seem to miss the big cats every time I come. I love that there is so much room to get around so you don't end up tripping over strollers. My only gripes aside from the lack of cool reptiles and no elephants is the bathrooms. For such a clean and.beautiful zoo it amazes me that the bathrooms here are some of the worst I have ever seen. I mean I'd rather use a gas station bathroom. SF zoo, this is any easy fix and should really be addressed. It won't keep me from coming back but it will keep me from drinking anything while I'm there.
author: Nickie L.

description: Been there several times this year and i must say today was the worst trip ever. Staff was rude and animals were far and few to see.
author: Del B.

description:
I feel bad for the animals here....=O(  

This zoo is arrrrrrrrite..not the greatest.  i guess it's cuz i went to the san diego zoo which is 100x's better.  The place looks kinda run down and not well kept.  There also arent that many animals.  I guess that why student admission is only $7 (at least the time i went it was).  This place is good to go to when they have free days (first wednesday of every month) but i definelty dont think i'll be going back her anytime soon.  Unless i have 7 year old with me..i'd bring him to the zoo.
author: Kristen T.

description:
I took ny niece here today since she was aching to go seethe animals particularly lions, tigers and elephants.

Well, it cost $12 bucks for me to enter and thank God my niece was free since she's under 3 years old and it closes at 4pm. Isn't that kinda early to close?

I don't ever remember the zoo being so spread out as I must have walked for miles looking at the animals.  There was a carousel which was great but it cost an additional $2 to ride.  

My niece got scared by some of the animals and she insisted I carry here instead of pushing her in the stroller.  Food is pretty expensive in the park.  

Oh one more thing-no elephants in this zoo.  Can you believe it?
author: kenny l.

description:
A major embarrassment to our great city of SF.  This zoo has always sucked, and has been going downhill under hideous mismanagement for years.  The Chimps languish on a spartan cement platform while you build a spectacularly gorgeous new cafe to sell 8$ sodas?  I know a zoo has to support itself, but way to freaking prioritize.  This zoo seems to be run by people who hate animals, and the little joy the captives do manage to wring from life is due to happenstance or the kindness of their keepers.  Have I mentioned I hate this zoo?  Oh, I probably should.  I love zoos, I love SF, I live here, but the SF Zoo breaks my heart.  I will drive to Oakland, Sacramento, or Fresno, rather than pay to watch animals pace miserably.  Tiger mauling: not a shock.

All that said, I will grudgingly point out the zoo's good points.  You like lemurs?  You've got lemurs.  The lemur exhibit is great.  Meerkats and prairie dogs: great.  You give a rat's ass about ungulates?  The savannah exhibit may be for you.  The weird little cyclone fenced-in slum for big cat conservation?  Full of amazing felines, though it doesn't feel like part of the actual zoo (and god I hope those enclosures are temporary). Stay away from most of the monkeys and apes here (gorillas and patas monkeys being exceptions).

Shame on you, SF Zoo.  Can someone please hand over the reins to the Oakland Zoo directors before the animals start mauling themselves?
author: Evelyn G.

description:
All the animals were sleeping.  
The Zoo is like Nascar...
Pretty freaking boring unless theres crazy accidents going on.  
Someone please stick a leg into the tiger exhibit.  

Too soon?

Davids bottom line-  Oh well at least there was beer.
author: David L.

description:
I miss my old red elephant zoo key.  My kid took it to the zoo during a field trip with school years and years ago.  Because it was too old and no longer worked with the new boxes, he swapped it & another parent paid an extra $1 to get him a new key.  I about died when I found out. I had that key since childhood. The sentimental value alone was enough to cause an earthquake.  I still think about that key.  It was a hard plastic elephant with a long trunk which was inserted into the talking boxes, nothing like the flimsy stuff they have nowadays.  

So, today, I was a chaparone for my youngest's class to the zoo.  I've not been there in years, I mean, years.  They have grizzly bears from Montana!   I knew California's grizzlies are extinct and the last California grizzly (a male) is stuffed and propped standing on display at the new aquarium, so it was a complete surprised to see these 2 sister bears.
No more seals in the pool for you to feed, no more monkey island where you can watch those agile primates jumping up and down in comet speed. The lion house was closed & no tigers in sight.  The lions were sleeping as well as the koalas.  

The tiger exhibit is the same but now has a huge cement wall and windowed enclosure to protect the animas from humans who taunt.  
They have a nice gift shop where I bought a new zoo key (there were only a couple of talkie boxes around) for $3 with a bear cub standing on top of a log.  *sigh*.  I miss my red elephant zoo key.....
author: Ry T.

description: A lot of the exhibts looked too small for the animals it kept and most looked either bored or depressed. Now I do not agree with Zoos in the first place but if your going to do it please do it well. The lay out is well done just a shame about the animals. Me thinks the money could be spent on conservation and education rather than animal jail.
author: Samuel M.

description: Our first time visiting as a family - husband, almost 3 year old and almost one year old and I. It was in the 90s in San Jose and we thought this would be a cooler place to spend the day. The oceanside location gave us cool breezes and fresh air - it was my first visit to a zoo where I wasn't sweaty and cranky before we even got our tickets. We arrived at around 11am on a Saturday and there was plenty of parking In the smallish lot and no line for tickets (I'm used to the LA zoo where this is not the case!) The zoo was beautiful - well maintained, spotless, with happy animals in nice habitats that were spacious but still allowed for cozy viewings. The little petting zoo was perfect for little ones and we also enjoyed the giraffes and zebras. The zoo is large but walking it was a pleasure! Even the cafe (we went to he one near the carousel) was better than expected. I had a rice bowl with bone-in teriyaki chicken (yum crispy chicken skin!) and steamed veggies - a tasty kid friendly and healthy meal. All staff was friendly. Little surprises like animal sculptures, gardens and a kid friendly band playing on the lawn made the day fun. I loved all the open spaces to picnic or just play under a tree. Oh, and the playground was amazing! Probably even more fun for slightly older kids because it was quite exciting. If you plan to hit the playground with younger kids be sure to bring some sand toys as the sandy area is really nice. And there were plenty of shaded benches for parents to sit on. Also, at no point, even on a lovely Saturday in September, did it feel crowded. We were there for three hours and definitely didn't see everything - I hope we can go back soon! Just wanted to say well done to the zoo and staff. (And note, I really don't like most zoos for the typical reasons - depressing, smelly, hot, crowded - this zoo is clean and fresh with healthy animals, fun exhibits and play opportunities and not crowded!)
author: Honor R.

description:
The SF Zoo is a very poor excuse for a zoo.  It is a little better than it was the first time I went there about eight years ago, but not by much.  There are barely any animals there!  And the animals they do have there look pretty miserable.  The polar bears are rail thin and the chimpanzees look like they're about 80 years old.  Most of the enclosures are in desperate need of remodeling.

The only thing I was impressed with was grizzly bear habitat (very cool.  you're only separated by some glass, and the two sister bears seem happy there).  That's pretty much it.

It's an okay place to bring little ones because they won't know the difference between a great zoo and a pathetic zoo.  Except I think my 16 month old daughter was disappointed that there were no elephants (what zoo doesn't have elephants!?)
author: Eileen H.

description:
[note: zoo has been renovated so old Yelp reviews may be out of date]
a pleasant surprise - the SF Zoo is a quaint little place that actually felt nice to visit.  this is in comparison to my recent visit to the LA Zoo which was bigger but a bit dumpy (for lack of a better word).  the new African savanna set up is nice and roomy.  The Penguin pool where the penguins are able to swim in schools is pretty cool, as is the feeding time.  also have a gorgeous bald eagle (rescued bird that was a victim of a gunshot) that a handler brings out for viewing - so cool!  excellent place for kids and also has a petting zoo.  the free-roaming peacocks are a nice touch too.

Parking available on site for $8, or you can find street parking if you search around.  Food is at high tourist prices but definitely cheaper than the LA Zoo.  short walk to Ocean Beach.  AAA discount available (free kids admission).  you can also get membership if you plan on visiting more often and also gets your reciprocal discounts (or even free admission) at participating zoos in other cities.

if I were to give the San Diego Zoo (world class, $$$) and the Lincoln Park Zoo (smaller zoo with nice layout and FREE!) five stars, and LA Zoo barely three stars, then I'll give the San Francisco Zoo four stars.

on a side note:  what's with all these haters thread-crapping and dumping their animal activist anti-zoo rants here?  how does that add to the value of user reviews on Yelp?  if you don't use, don't rate! =P
author: JL G.

description:
My first time at this zoo and it really is worth it (more so if the animals are active)!  It's great for those who live in the area or are visiting and want to see some animals!  Plus, the price is decent, $15 per adult.  No student discount though.  Parking inside their lot is $10.  There are a number of free parking spaces walking distance to the zoo that you could snag on a less busy day, which is probably when the sun isn't out.  Surprisingly, the park wasn't crowded when I went Saturday and it was foggy.  Bring a sweater/jacket if you're there past 3pm because it gets chilly. 

You could easily spend 2-3+ hours here in awe watching the animals and walking.  The walking distance between to see the different animals isn't long, it gives a nice break and builds anticipation.  

PS. Even if you're not a child, I recommend stopping by the children's section!  The petting zoo is there!  It's nice of the park to provide wet wipes for before and after too!  They have free brushes to comb the goats with and you can buy food to feed them for 50cents, change only.  

PPS.  Why are there no elephants??  And why are the giraffes complimentary to see?? I love giraffes though so it definitely got me excited to see more of the zoo!  But, I'm just saying... ;P *Know you're worth! JK.
author: Pink L.

description: The gorillas looked super down, and the tiger looked.malnourished... it was depressing... I felt guilty returning after years of not coming. Saw a man get escorted out of the park for taunting the lions and throwing popcorn into their cage what an idiot... And a lot of the exhibits were empty so that was a little bit of a bummer. It was cute to see where my parents used to take us when we were children brought back memories... But I didn't like the way the gorillas looked bored and sad just wondering why they're there.. and the tiger was pacing back and forth like an inmate who was put in solitary confinement... it wasn't pleasant.
author: Clara H.

description: The zoo is laid out well here but the animals don't seem very happy.  I've never seen animals pace back and forth like they are mentally ill.  Its weird.  Even the Mandrill money was so fuckin bored it would just circle the enclosure wall looking for something to do.  Its kinda sad.  They should be left in the wild.
author: Fatty A.

description:
3 stars sounds about right..
For being a zoo in one of the nation's biggest/most popularity cities, there sure isn't enough parking to accommodate all of its visitors. We ended up parking on the street and walking to the entrance.

Like most zoos in the area, SF Zoo offers an annual membership, in which you get a "speedy" entrance and discounts/free admission to other zoos and public places of interest that are in partnership with the program. Not too bad a deal if you like to go to the zoo a lot.

A lot of amenities available for families; bathrooms, stroller rental, wagon rental, etc.
The layout is not too difficult to maneuver, and there is a food court in the middle of the zoo with different mini concessions spread throughout.
A petting zoo can be found as well as a barnyard for little ones to play in.

The Lion exhibit was closed when we went, sad face. But other than that, typical animal exhibits.
author: JASMIN O.

description:
I would almost give it the full rating, but there seems to be something lacking here. The restrooms are okay, the eateries are pricey; what else is new? Well, for one, the animal sightseeing is awesome, and for two, it's a great place to go to for virtually any type of group.

Spend some time here with your loved ones... and no, that doesn't mean you have to have an s.o. Just bring friends or relatives if you don't have one.
author: Carl Z.

description:
Went here close to 2pm on a saturday and boy was that a mistake- should have planned the whole day here for the price of admission!!!!!!! The price for admission for an adult is $15!!!! and if you are a SF resident it is $12...and I am not a SF resident....and good thing their parking was full beause it would have cost $8!!!! So, kinda bothered by the price of admission and the fact that it is only free to SF residents on Wed, I believe the first of each month...

I didn't get to stay that long, so didn't get to see half of the zoo, some of the events/feedings, missed the flamingos and the koala's, and lemurs :(((...but did get to see the penguins, the two grizzly sister's play fighting, gorillas, cnimps, polar bears, tigers, lions, giraffe, some wild birds, peacock (all cool)......

still deciding if I shall go back (since it was my first time) or just plan a whole day to go to the Oakland Zoo (haven't been there since i was working at a middle school and had to chaperone my students)- cost for an adult admission at Oakland Zoo is way cheaper, $10.50!!!!!....
author: cheryll t.

description: We had a great experience at the SF Zoo.  It was a chilly, foggy day, so we started our visit with a visit to the little cafe in the gift shop at the entrance-surprisingly delicious!  We were there in the afternoon, and all of the animals were out!  They have a great variety of animals, all of which looked healthy and happy.  We noticed the zoo seems to take in a lot of animals that would otherwise not have survived in the wild.  For example, the 2 sea lions who call the zoo home are blind and there is also a one-winged eagle.  Kudos to the zoo for taking these animals, who likely require additional medical care, attention, and funding.  One of the highlights of our visit was the lion room, where we got a front row seat to a lion and tiger feeding.  It was a nice way to end our afternoon!
author: Keely D.

description: Took my daughter here for her first zoo experience. Parking was a nightmare though. We literally had to stalk people to their cars and fight for a parking spot after driving in circles for an hour. Would have been nice if there was at least a sign stating if there was parking elsewhere. The zoo itself was ok. I wasnt overly impressed but wasnt let down either. My daughter loved the petting zoo!!! The food was so so. But the gift shop prices were outrageous! I bought a small stuffed animal and a childrens tshirt and spent over $45! Thats more than we paid to get into the zoo and park! Also it was really hard to find the zoo entrance...not many signs leading up to it. But besides all that we still had a great family outing!
author: Jessica N.

description:
My new job recently took me to the wilds of Africa.  By job, I mean the nannying gig.  And by wilds of Africa, I mean the San Francisco zoo.

Now... I love animals and I kinda hate children.  

The San Francisco Zoo is filled with sad, caged animals and loud, snotty, dirty children.

I may want to rethink my new career path.

Needless to say, having not been to the SF zoo is quite awhile, I was somewhat impressed.  It was clean and well laid out with lots to see.  The animals were plentiful and up close.  I really liked the lions and gorillas.  The Silverback reminded me of a guy I once dated, but I think this gorilla would have called me back after he got to second base.  

Gorillas, I'm sure, have manners.

I enjoyed riding the steam train and the carousel although I am sure that I got some little child's spit up on my boots and caught Rubella or Small Pox or some other dirty child disease.

And yes, I get paid for this.  

Besides the communicable disease it's not such a bad gig.

There isn't much in the way of food that isn't nuggets and cotton candy.  I was so hungry and annoyed that I almost went Tatiana the Tiger on some childrens, but at the last minute decided I could just get a Whole Foods salad on the way home.

Since becoming a nanny, baby just doesn't taste as good as it used to.
author: Rachel G.

description: Awesome Zoo. Animals are out to see but dont get there too early. Lunch, take one with you. Plenty of cool spots to sit, eat and check the animals. I like the fountain by the elephants
author: David S.

description: Throughout the years, the zoo seems to have less and less animals. I remember the first time I ever came here, they actually had elephants and hippos. There isn't any anymore. Everytime I've come here, I've always looked forward to seeing the turtles.. yes turtles.. not exciting but I never got to see them until the last time I visited. They do have free Wednesdays of every month, but is only for San Francisco residents! I moved to Sacramento two years ago, but I recently moved back.. and when I was still living in Sacramento, I never changed the address on my ID, so I still got in free, lol. They are strict though because back then, they never checked IDs, it was free for everyone.
author: Jessica R.

description:
I feel like we were at Jurassic Park opening weekend.

6 or 7 no shows.. No elephant.. No zebra.. No hippo... no bison.. Lion House.. Closed.. Pachyderm House.. Closed.. Tropical Forest house, being remodeled..   Seal area.. closed until the Marine Mammal Society would like to use the area to house sick animals..  Video of baby gorilla..  Did i pay to watch the discovery channel?  Because I could of watched a video from the comfort of my own home--paused while getting a slice of pizza, taking a whiz, and come back to watch it on HD.. Not on some cheeky monitor at the zoo

.. I saw more wild animals on the drive up.. 

It was insane.. I tried hard to not ask for my money back.. 

The insect zoo was a disgrace as it hasn't been remodeled or even updated in some 20 years. 

I believe I have had a better experience going to the Rain Forest Cafe and at least I am GUARANTEED  to see some animals that possibly may move.. 

The best part is the guide states that the park is available for Weddings, Corporate Functions, etc... Sure.. I'll be sure to pass this along to my corporate headquarters or my friends ready to get married so they can have an event in a barren park.. . . 

If I could give NO STARS.  I would..
author: Ray W.

description: The SF Zoo has some heartwarming rescue stories! It has a great layout, with the big cat and bear sections being my favorite. They have a great giraffe barn, Africa exhibit and a lemur island. And the burgers and garlic fries are delicious! Many people don't understand that animals are bred in captivity and is their only means of survival. Animals are not taken from their environment unless they are injured or unfit to survive in the wild. Sadly, some species don't even exist in the wild, and it's the only place people, especially children get to learn about and care about these animals and be outside with their families. Not everybody has the luxury to be able to travel to places afar to see them in the wild. Also, the zoo has the best playground I've ever seen for kids!
author: Erika C.

description:
The Zoo is always a fun place to take your kids. They have many different animals here and what my kids love is the kid's zoo area. It's your typical petting zoo and the kids get the chance to feed the animals. Be careful in here though as some of the sheep can be a little aggressive and will ram into you for food. 

I really wish that there were more animals for the kids to see. Maybe an elephant or two? 

They have carousal and a running train along with a large playground area for the kiddies. 

They have specific feeding times for some of the animals that are always fun. I wish that there were more staff members around to teach the kids more about the animals but maybe they do have this and we just missed them?

They have a private parking lot (where the old public pool used to be back in the day) and there is also parking found at the side entrance. 

Oh and bring your own food. The food there is a rip-off for what you get. If you have kids bring your own straws as they don't have them here anymore. They're trying to advertise their $7.99/$8.99 slurpy cup that holds practically nothing (it's one of those tall and slender plastic cups that you would buy at the fair) but it's re-fillable so you can always bring it back the next time you want to visit.
author: Just Meeh B.

description:
Do you have a place that really puts you in the perfect head space?  A nice walk through Golden Gate Park?  Maybe reading at your favorite coffee shop?  Personally if I'm ever in need of some quality Lauren time, to get in my "Zen" spot....I might go have a day where I go see a movie by myself, or people watch in the park, talking shit with a friend.  
Well, I have a friend.  My friend has a thing for goats.  An admiration if you will..maybe an obsession?  So on this lazy Sunday, we made a spur of the moment decision to go to the SF Zoo and play with goats, so he could get into his "Zen" spot.  Goats make him happy, so that was the plan, cuz if my friend is happy...so am I.

I'm going to give the Children's zoo here 5 stars.  They have a great area where you can just cruise around with the goats.  Become one if you choose...You can pet them, feed them, and even brush their lovely lil coats.  The conversations my friend was once having in his own head with goats were able to now come to the surface, and actually be heard.  Yes...he talks to goats.  He found his Zen, and we left the petting zoo in good spirits with smiles and stories.  Like the one story involving the one kid who gave the goat a lil nibble on his ear...or shall I say the goat took it without asking...and don't worry.  No damage was done.  Just a kid who will probably NEVER go to the petting zoo again.

As far as the rest of the zoo goes....I was a bit disappointed, but I think a lot of that had to do with the hour we were there, and the fact that I've been spoiled by the San Diego Zoo...We went 2 hours before closing, and all the good aminals were sleeping, hiding or who knows where.  Half of the habitats were empty with no sign, and most were just difficult to see.. No cuddly koalas, no efelants, the giraffes were staying in a cabin, and the chimps and apes were apparently monkeying around somewhere private.  We were still on the goat high though, so all this didn't really matter; it just gave us inspiration to come back and try again.

Goats = one billion stars, but I can only give 5
The rest = 3 disappointing stars
Average = 4.
author: Lauren F.

description:
Went here on a wednesdy.....for free!! Crazy, I know, however
the monkey's did not fling their poo. 
I was disappointed.
author: John-Michael C.

description:
3.5 stars actually.

First of all, for all the people complaining and giving negative reviews - the zoo, like everywhere else in CA has NO money. OK? It takes money and lots of it to renovate enclosures and landscaping, etc. So if you complain that the zoo looks run down and complain that the entrance fee is too high - well you need use your brain a bit more.

And yes, if seeing animals in cages makes you sad, uh, no zoo visits for you ok?

For the rest of you - this was my first visit in about 3 years and I found the zoo to be in much better shape and I found the food to be better. Yes, some areas are a bit depressing, but several area great: African Savanna, Grizzly Gulch, penguins, Tropical forest building, crazy Dr. Seuss looking birds. Also - good zoo keepers, feeding times, kid friendly. Yes it is foggy and cold, but bring extra layers.
author: Anon A.

description:
The largest outdoor exhibition of bad parenting in Northern California.

Highlights are the squirrels, much friendlier than elsewhere in town, probably emboldened by all those french fries they pilfer from the penguins and bears they were intended for.
author: Gil S.

description:
Poor SF Zoo. You're like that first cousin who has done too many drugs and may never be quite right again - I want to love you, but you just break my heart with all your stupid mistakes, poor decision making and self-defeating behavior. 

p.s. Please give the polar bears more space. I can't look anymore.
author: J F.

description:
My friend told me that every Wednesday of the month also free of charge.  When i arrived, only free for San Francisco residents with driver license.  My friends are living in daly city need to pay $12 each.  
And the zoo full with "shit" smell.....buy ticket to go.....STUPID!!!
author: jennifer s.

description:
It's time to start phasing out this type of zoo.  Many of the animals are basically kept in what amounts to an enlarged jail cell, for life.  Have these animals committed a crime?  No.  

Have the humans who have caught and caged these innocent animals committed a crime?  One wonders.
author: Jack H.

description:
I'm not sure why Jaye C. writes this sentence in her review below: 

'' Did you hear on the news about the Siberian tiger recently escaping and mauled down two people!? HAHAHAH! ''

WTF?  I found it completely inappropriate and quite shocking.

.

I pray for the Sousa family who lost their son in a horrible way as well as the 2 brothers who have many wounds to heal.

I also send my thoughts to the zoo's employees who have to deal with this tragedy.
author: Margie B.

description:
I haven't been to the SF Zoo in years but I have warm, fuzzy childhood memories of coming here on the regular with my gramps.

I AM SO GOING BACK NOW.  Have you all seen the baby gorilla they have?  This thing is extraordinarily, ridiculously cute. Please watch this video of it: http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/object/article?f=/c/a/2009/02/13/BAU415T0QV.DTL&o=1

He is 11 pounds and cuddles his human "surrogate mom", plays with rattles and his own feet, and is generally the cutest thing I've ever seen. He's definitely cuter than human babies - even CUTER THAN TEN PUPPIES IN A BASKET.
author: Sid D.

description:
I love the zoo. I hadn't been in ages, so I was really excited when we went two weeks ago.

The zoo is much smaller than I remember as a child (perhaps this is because they redesigned it, but I suspect it's just a perspective thing, as all things seem larger when you're a child). It took a lot less time to wander than I would have imagined, so it made for a non-stressful adventure.

I was sad that there weren't any elephants. I think a zoo worth its salt should have elephants. But it's not like you can just go and get elephants from anywhere.

The signage needs improvement, as others have noted. Definitely use the map they provide.

I didn't see any zoo keys for sale in the stores though...!! What's going on?
author: Tiffany L.

description:
So we had our company party... yes our company party at the Zoo.  WTF?  Seemed more like a company party for all the employees who have kids.  I know they had more fun than myself, though of course I made the most of it.  I tried to feed a little boy to the Giraffe... didn't work.  The Giraffe was more interested in the leaves he was holding up.  Did you know the male Giraffe has 5 female Giraffes all to himself?  In the wild they can have up to 12 females.... and Big Love on HBO thought they were tight with 3 wives.  I turned to a co-worker and said, "life is good as a Giraffe"  Funny.... the ladies were talking about the Giraffe's being prego... all the doods were thinking about was "damn, papa G is doing it and doing it and doing it well."  

If you haven't seen the new high tech Grizzly exhibit you are missing out.  They reminded me why Black folks don't camp.  As quick as we might be.... NO!  The Zoo keeper added a few samon to the pool/pond and let the Grizzlies hunt them down.  That shit was dope.  I felt 10 all over again.  I remember high fiving a little boy and say "cool" at the same time.

All I know is that it cost me $20 for a cab ride from the Western Addition to the zoo and that the Penguins STANK!  You need to get there real early or you are going to be parking 20 minutes away!
author: Jamal G.

description: I know this place isn't exactly animal PALOOZA! Many people complain about the lack of animals. People expect a lot! From a zoo. Like smiling animals walking around and interacting with one another n what not. But realistically, animals are not meant to be kept in zoos. The staff and docents are wonderful people who really know their stuff! Props to them. The volunteers have big hearts;) peace.
author: Lynn K.

description:
I love zoos, but the SF one left me with mixed feelings.  I love the small animal areas. We saw the penguins being fed, the flamingos looked pink and content, I got to pet animals I raised growing up (yeah, pygmy goats and sheep and potbelly pigs, etc), and the meerkats were hiding in their hole area, but cute.  

I was less impressed with the number of buildings that were closed, the tropical South America section, the feline conservation section, etc.  I read some of the signs for the bears and tigers saying they are rotated through multiple enclosures.  The spaces did not look large enough for those animals, maybe they need to tear down some walls and let them roam more. Still going to go back, but mostly because I love animals, not the management of this zoo.

On the upside, being an SF resident apparently got me a discount.  On the neutral side, the food was expensive for basic, but OK cafeteria food. I had the veggie burger and sweet potato fries.  I'm a sucker for the free refills souvenir cup so got the SF Zoo cup too.
author: Cara J.

description: Visited the zoo on a recent holiday weekend and found it much improved since my last visit.  I've been coming here since childhood and the place certainly has had its ups and downs.  I've noticed a tendency on the part of those who've reviewed the SF Zoo negatively in recent posts to anthropomorphize the behavior of the animals .  At risk of doing the same, I'll say that, on my recent visit, most of the residents seemed to be enjoying themselves (it was sunny) and were quite active.  The recent changes have been very positive and I'd be happy to recommend a visit to all.
author: Colin M.

description: It a zoo with animal, only love the special event they hold here, live 14 block away, kids will enjoy the animal, but it can get boring over time.
author: Calvin T.

description:
This is a review only for the ice skating rink, not for the zoo in general...

Just wanted to give a quick heads-up for people considering going ice skating out at the zoo - the "ice" is synthetic, not real.  That doesn't mean it won't be fun - my six year old boy had a good time sliding around on the synthetic surface in his ice skates (rented for $5).  But the synthetic surface really isn't anything like real ice, so if you're hoping for a real ice skating experience, you'll be disappointed.
author: Geoffrey B.

description: Even though it was much larger and diverse than the Sacramento Zoo, it was only a few dollars more (though parking is an additional $8). Being right next to the ocean gives a nice atmosphere and the large and open enclosures for the animals are also a nice touch. It also took longer to check everything out than I thought (definitely a good thing) and I managed to blow over 4 hours wandering around and grabbing lunch. My only complaint would be that the food and parking, like everywhere else in San Francisco is a bit on the pricey side.
author: Erin B.

description:
The San Francisco Zoo is great! My four-year old niece had so much fun here. 

The most memorable experiece of our day was when the hippo caretakers came out to "brush" the teeth of the hippos with the garden hose. The hippos loved it. And so did my niece.

* AAA Discount * used: My niece's admission was free because you get one kid's ticket free for each adult ticket you buy. Saved $9.
author: Kelly S.

description: If we lived in the city, I would certainly get a membership at this zoo. I was curious to find out for myself about the disappointing exhibits that other reviewers have mentioned. We went to the zoo on a monday afternoon and thus did not encounter crowds - thank goodness. I thought the grounds were well laid out and landscaped. The zoo is very big, especially for little ones to take all in. The new children's playground was very thoughtful and age-appropriate. Truly buckets of fun. Little Puffer train was a bit pricey at $5pp and super quick and done but that's ok. We did not use the cafe given that we brought our own picnic lunches and were free to eat wherever we chose. I thought it was amazing to see endangered animals. Sure some of the exhibits seem to be empty and the animals were sleeping. But geez - we are trying to visit animals in their un-natural habitat, trying to do their natural thing. They're not supposed to do acrobatic tricks because there are visitors lined up at their fences. I thought it was amazing to see gorillas, hippo, rhinos, polar bear, grizzly bear, peacocks (loose), anteater, ostriches, snow leopards, koala, sloth, scarlet ibis. These are animals I haven't ever seen before (except gorillas a long time ago). So I thought it was pretty cool. As for the stretches of empty land, animals need lots of open space to roam. It's ok that they are camouflaged and resting where they feel most comfortable, especially confined and in captivity. I will definitely come back with my kids real soon. We are members of another zoo and so were able to take advantage of 50% reciprocity discount. Yes I agree full price is steep but all zoos need to cover operating costs....
author: Emanuelle O.

description:
Male domestic partners Henry and Pepper setting up a household and raising a brood together. Just another day in the Castro you say? No, welcome to the penguin pen at the San Francisco Zoo!

Its not the best zoo around, but its come a long way since I've been there years ago. Despite the deserved bad publicity they've gotten recently, its not the remote wind swept set of cement bunkers I remember. 

They've really put allot of effort in the African Savannah exhibit. The landscaping is especially spectacular (especially this time of year?). The lions exhibit had the male like right in front of us: a perspective better than any other zoo I've been to. (In Oakland, they are up a steep hill and in Santa Barbara, they are far down below and often sleeping behind the big rock.) The penguins, lemurs and gorillas were all also very viewable.

Some areas are roped off for reconstruction so you have to do a bit off maneuvering and trekking back and forth with the map so you can avoid the dead areas. The worst part about that this was a stark reminder of recent events. This is a bit of a bummer but its understandable that they can't upgrade everything at once.

My son's class attended a workshop on habitats. They carted out various animals such as chinchillas, snakes, frogs and ferrets for the kids to pet. The instructor talked about how they found their way to the zoo, where they lived and there dispositions. They kids got allot out of it.

Others have mentioned the limited food selections. Its still limited, but it looks like they are making efforts to improve.

The train ride and the carousel is always a big hit with the little ones, sometimes even more than any of the exhibits. Go figure.
author: David P.

description:
I came here while babysitting a two-year-old. I enjoyed the experience because she was so excited about every exhibit, and it's hard not to enjoy yourself with a happy baby.

However, I think if I would have came here with another adult I would have been sorely disappointed. Despite the fact that many exhibits/houses were empty with "coming soon" signs (I can understand transition) the open exhibits were nothing stellar. Many of the cages, especially towards the front of the zoo, were very small. I felt especially bad for the penguins, who seemed to have a severely inadequate housing situation. In the petting zoo area, many of the stalls were filthy dirty and no fresh water seemed available. Both restrooms I visited inside the zoo were dirty and ill-kept.

Additionally, some of the staff seemed a bit cranky and/or uninterested. There were definitely friendly staff members we encountered as well, so i don't want to give the impression everyone was that way. There were also spacious enclosures for many of the animals, and the trees along the walk-ways were beautiful. The carousel was not running that day, but the "Little Puffer" train was a big hit with the two-year-old! 

All in all I'm glad I checked it out, but for as fantastic and socially/environmentally conscious as San Francisco is, I expected better.
author: Anne A.

description: I like the SF zoo.  I had a season pass two years ago and my kids loved it.  I feel that this zoo hasn't changed much in 20 years.  I wish more people would visit and make this a better zoo.
author: Ellie C.

description:
I was going to start ranting about how it's not very enlightened to keep critters trapped in small cages where they're subject to abuse by random and obnoxious visitors, but I kept drawing a comparison to my oppressive cubicled-dwelling work life.  Really, me and the zoo animals are one.  Stuffed like veals into these little pens with bad air, heckled by passers-by, held hostage by a purpose we don't subscribe to.  And then, at various times, parties and festive decorations are foisted upon us in a dubious attempt to boost morale.  OK, now I'm depressed.

All that being said, this is a good place to take the young-uns.  You'll be hard pressed to find a parking spot nearby, thus ensuring that the kids will get lots of exercise before they even get inside. They may or not notice the oppression of the animals.  Just go right to the prairie dogs or the penguins or the train, and it will be all right.
author: Andi T.

description:
No lions? Whaaaaat?!?? 

Anyways, I had a good time when we went and the kids loved the penguins. It was pretty cool watching them swim all together in the same direction at the same time back & forth, back & forth, back & forth.
