Just like any zoo or theme park the food is expensive, nothing too spectacular about this place but it is worth a visit to take your kids.
author: Ryan O.

description: huge zoo! beautiful. peacocks just walk around the place. it's a great escape in the city. near water front. gorgeous.
author: V B.

description:
I think how much you love your city's zoo is probably a reflection of how often you went as a kid.  

I went all the time as a girl, and I don't think I could like this zoo anymore even if it was built by Coleridge's Kubla Khan.  Yes, it's not the San Diego Zoo.  Get over it already -- This zoo is fantastic and perfect as is!

The remodel gave the Zoo a spiffy new entrance, and even though they charge for parking (Boo! just park on Sloat for free), it's easier for people with strollers or wheel chairs than the old, steep hill entrance.  

The new entryway also makes it easier to find the giraffes, so be sure to make it to the feedings that occur every day, and bring your camera!  You can feed the giraffes bananas by hand -- just watch out for their tongues!

The lion feeding is great for ROARs, but little kids might get spooked when they feed them little white bunnies (they're already dead, of course, but make sure you don't go right around Easter!).
author: Umilia M.

description:
Stop dissing on our zoo, peoples. San Diego Zoo it's not, but if you've been to a lot of zoos, you'll know that San Francisco Zoo is a good one. The Barcelona Zoo, which is famous for having an albino gorilla, has some siamangs in scratched up plexiglass enclosures that look like they need to take some antidepressants. The animals a the SF zoo, for the most part, look pretty contented or happy. The monkeys play. The great apes sit and ponder (occasionally deflecting the playful blows from some young upstart).  This zoo is a great place for a family outing and a wonderful way for Bay Area residents to teach our children about appreciating and respecting a diverse range of animals and their ever-threatened environments. 

It's so easy to get caught up in our own, small world. The zoo offers us the opportunity to remind us that we share this planet with some other extraordinary creatures. With all the glitzy materialism, fast paced media, and art and culinary culture, it's nice to decompress and think about the state of our planet and the wonder that it holds. 

My biggest complaint about the SF zoo is the trashy people who go to it and think it's cool to taunt the majestic big cats by running up and down along the cages or yelling at them. I wish the zoo had better security and free reign to use tranquilizer darts and big ol' ID tags that they could permanently staple to people's ears that say "I'm an A**hole who torments caged animals".
author: Pamela B.

description:
I grew up in love with the zoo -- it always was mysterious -- the cages were ugly, but you could really see all the animals without them hiding behind all the shrubs.  It was fun for us, but not for them.  

And it was free -- ah what joy to race down that hill to the entrance, make a run for those big round swings that always felt like they'd take off from their moorings and fling us into outer space.  The carousel.  The old Children's Zoo and Children's Fairytale Land... my memories of these are so vivid.  We used to have a blue Zoo Key, and it could be inserted into the talking storybooks that would then narrate a tidbit of info about the animals being viewed.  We'd invariably forget the zoo key at home, but there was one Talking Storybook that didn't require a key, and if you pushed the big red button, it would play this song:  

All the animals in the zoo
Are jumping up and down for you,
Hoping you will have fun today
And purchase your zoo key right away!

Over time the zoo changed, sometimes incrementally, sometimes dramatically.  Now, it doesn't even feel like the same place.  The old main entrance is no longer.  The swings are gone.  Natural animal habitats have replaced most of the cages.  And they charge -- a lot!  (Why I gave it only 4 stars).  Somehow when it was free, you could go for shorter visits and didn't feel compelled to see EVERY animal.

In some ways (like the restrooms and habitats), the changes are good.  But in other ways, the zoo has lost some of the mysteriousness, some of the intrigue.  I no longer imagine a lion escaping its cage and running amok amongst the zoo-goers.  But I can still buy the best, stale rectangle of Pink Popcorn!  

ZOO-GOING TIPS:  

-- If you can, grab a kid (one you know, not a stranger!) -- it makes your visit infinitely more fun!  

-- Despite the weather when you set out, bundle up and dress in layers -- due to ocean's proximity, it is guaranteed to be freezing once you set foot in the zoo grounds, and dang, your car is so far away!

-- Bring snacks or picnic goodies for the kids -- they do have snack bars, but they're pricey.  If you must, buy the pink popcorn and cotton candy, but then enjoy your own sammies and drinks. 

-- If it's your first visit, spend a moment looking at the map and charting your course, so you don't get worn out before you've seen the animals that are your priorities.  The distances are vast and kids get exhausted long before the day is over. (Unfortunately, they no longer offer the Zebra Train tours of the zoo -- I used to recommend these as a nice way to get the lay of the land.  Maybe with enough requests, they'll consider bringing it back?)   

-- Don't feed the animals (except the baby goats in the Children's Zoo).  But if you like to see the fat cats getting fed, be at the Lion House at 2 p.m., every day except Monday.  The roaring is tremendous!  

-- Be sure to ride the Carousel -- it is really the best!  

-- Consider joining -- with the admission prices so high, it pays for itself in two or so visits, plus is a great way to throw your weight behind something so deserving.  Plus, you get invites to special events, like Zoo Night (don't miss it!).  

-- If you don't want to use all your energy hiking to and from the free parking on Sloat Blvd., pay the $6 for the lot parking.  (Regardless of where you park, be sure you take your valuables -- leave nothing in your car, and be sure it is locked and secure -- this place is a target for car burglaries because they know you'll be gone and the coast is clear for a few hours.)  

- - - - - - - - - - - - - - -
Here are the prices (from the Zoo's website -- visit it for updates):  

NON-RESIDENTS OF SAN FRANCISCO
Adults 18-64 $11.00 
Youths 12-17 $8.00 
Seniors 65 and over $8.00 
Children 3-11 $5.00 
Children 2 and under Free 


SF RESIDENTS' DISCOUNT RATES (must show valid proof of residency)
Adults 18-64 $9.00 
Youths 12-17 $4.50 
Seniors 65 and over $4.50 
Children 3-11 $2.50 
Children 2 and under Free 


MEMBERSHIP
San Francisco Zoological Society Members receive free admission with annual Membership.

Family Membership: $75.00 (admits 2 named adults and their children or grandchildren under 18 years, with lots of free passes/ride tickets)

Individual: $60.00 (admits 1 named adult, comes with some passes)

Student/Senior:  $45.00 (admits up to 2 named seniors or 1 student)

Other memberships range from $85 to $500 (see website for details)

FREE DAYS
First Wednesday of every month, admission to the Zoo is free! Take public transportation because parking is limited.

TRANSPORT RENTALS
Wagons, Jeeps, wheelchairs, and electric scooters are available for daily rental at the Entry Village on a first come, first served basis.

Wagon/Jeep $9.00 
Wheelchair $10.00 
Electric Scooter $30.00 

DISABLED RATES:  General admission is 50% off basic general admission.  Disabled SF resident is 50% off basic resident rate
author: Bevy M.

description:
Picture this:

The rich as hell City and County of San Francisco purchases lots of land out near Livermore, and creates a massive wild animal park with huge open savannahs and a safari-style visitor experience.  Annex the property as part of San Francisco County and call it the San Francisco Wild Animal Park (at Livermore, or some bullshit to make everyone feel nice).  Then extend BART through Livermore (which is already planned) and out to the new park, near Altamont Pass, or perhaps even in up Mines Road, past Del Valle.

Then, the animals could be transfered away from the cold, foggy coast of San Francisco, which is NOTHING LIKE their natural habitat, and placed in a much larger, more comfortable environment.  Then redevolop the old zoo grounds into a giant skatepark and amusement park for the youth of San Francisco.

The zoo has an abysmal location for these animals.  It is too cold.  I can close my eyes and see it again as I did when I was six, and it was glorious and huge to me then.  But now, ugh.  And this recent event....man, what WORSE thing could happen in a place charged with the care of the animals and the safety of the guests?

Let's hear it for the SAN FRANCISCO WILD ANIMAL PARK (at Livermore, or some bullshit)!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

UPDATE:  Okay, okay....I'll settle for "Northern California Wild Animal Park" to rally the necessary folks, for the wellbeing of the animals.  Let's hear it for the NORTHERN CALIFORNIA WILD ANIMAL PARK (at Livermore, or whatever)!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: Randy F.

description:
Before today, the last time that I was at the SF Zoo was about eight years ago.  Funny how one never has the time...kinda like those native New Yorkers who have never been to the Statue of Liberty.  As I read some of the other reviews on Yelp, I had to wonder if these people had ever been here a decade or two or even three ago.  I have pictures of me as a baby here being carried around in a basket.  

Plenty of fond memories of running around with red and blue zoo keys and Pink Popcorn bars (back when they were still sweet and delicious, not anymore).  Walking around on an absolutely gorgeous, picture perfect day today (yes, I know it's often foggy here), looking at the animals, I was really impressed with how far this zoo has come.

The new Africa area had a really nice layout with paths winding around the giraffes, gazelles, gorillas, and etc.  Next to the animal areas, I discovered a lot of recently created new paths and discovery areas throughout the entire zoo.  The two sister grizzlys (grizzlies?) were fantastic and were thoroughly enjoying their new environment, happily coming from the far end, right up to glass of the pool to the delight of people and toddlers alike.

The prairie dogs were really cute and a total hit, as were the meer kats in their new environment.  There are a variety of tall cones in the meer kat area and one of the meer kats kept standing on one, loving the attention and looking like a hood ornament.  Also loved the penguins looking like the movie Surf's Up!  

The Children's Zoo and petting area was fun and with all the goats walking around and in the stable, I joked with my friend that it had noticed the pentagram she was wearing.  Thought of the pagan rituals in the comedy movie Dragnet. :)  

The insect room was interesting as well and one of the zoo workers who we had met in the wild bird area was now in the room enthusiastically telling everyone about the wolf spider with 200 babies on it's back.  It's hard to be a mother!  It was fun to watch all the kids running around and screaming excitedly upon discovery of a scorpion, tarantula, or black widow spider.

The lion house and pachyderm house were closed, but it looked like they were in the process of renovating.  The only real disappointment was that the tropical bird house which we were looking forward to was closed due to construction.  I was also hoping to see those two huge old trains in the main area that used to be there to climb on when I was growing up, but sadly, they were gone.  As a plus though, all of the grounds are far more lush and have been nicely landscaped with a lot more plant life everywhere. 

Granted, from a food standpoint, the food is far from gourmet, but it has really come a long way from what it used to be.  As a child growing up, the food here was barely edible and you had a choice of a low grade hamburger, cheeseburger, or hot dog sitting under a heat lamp.
  
Although I didn't eat at any of them today, I noticed that there is an asian food cafe, a Mexican food cafe (Terrace Cafe), and a variety of foods like fish and chips, onion rings, and garlic fries at the others.  In addition, there are plenty of new bathrooms and also a lot of new snack bar type Gilligan Island type stands scattered throughout the park selling bottled water, soda, caramel popcorn, cotton candy, fruit juices.

Another thing I noticed was the enthusiasm of all the workers I came in contact with there.  Even the guy running the little train around the park was just as happy and enthused as his passengers who were waving at everybody as they went by.

Being an animal lover, I ordinarily don't like to see animals chained up or in cages, but the modern layouts and environments are far more humane than they have ever been.  Despite it's shortcomings, the zoo gives people, both young and old, an opportunity to see animals up close that they otherwise might not have a chance to see and as such makes them more environmentally conscious and that's a good thing.
  
Another Yelper suggested closing this zoo and making it into a wildlife sanctuary closed to the public.  Noble as that sounds, if that ever happens, it would be a sad day indeed.  How can you expect tomorrow's youth to care about animals and the environment when the only time they're ever even seen one is on the internet or the Discovery Channel?  The zoo serves a very real purpose and does wonders for awareness. 

As a native San Franciscan that was born here, I can honestly say that this place has come a long way.  Hoping they continue to improve so that many more people can enjoy this for generations to come.

On top of it all, the first Wed of each month is free to SF residents.  Free!  Ya gotta love free.  Parking was $8.00, but there's no need to use it as there's tons of free parking in the area as long as you don't park in their lot.

Afterwards, it was a short walk to the beach.  Can't ask for much more than that.
author: Roy N.

description:
Its a fun Zoo to bring the kids...It has a big playground in the middle for the kids to enjoy..
I have many good childhood memories here...
Ever since the tiger attacks this place has gotten negative reviews....Why? Those idiots were instigating the tigers...so they got what they deserved..

We never pay for their parking..we always park outside..there are plenty of parking and its free..
If your in frisco....come and check this place out...or the oakland zoo...but I dont cross that bridge to often...for the fear of my life..lol..
Stay in frisco...you will be safer.
author: Jessica M.

description:
- I predict you will be delightfully surprised by the molting yet active penguins and find them as one of your favorites. Try to catch them in the afternoon during a feeding.
- I predict you will be most disappointed when you get to the koala and he is nowhere to be seen.
- I predict you will climb through some bushes at one point, hunting for the capybara.
author: Adam W.

description: We live in the East Bay and usually go to the Oakland Zoo. Today, we decided to try the SF Zoo and we were disappointed. Many exhibits and even roads were closed. It was sunny and warm but not many people were around at all. They didn't even have an elephant or camels, etc. Some of the cafes were closed too. Most animals were asleep. The sea lions were fun, and the grizzly bears and gorillas were alert. Most of the bathrooms were pretty dirty. Out of a line of a dozens stalls we could find one or two that were usable. There were not enough road signs in the zoo to tell us where we were so we kept getting lost. Better signage would have been better. The playground was big, but not worth spending 17 bucks to play on when I could just go to a public park. The only ride was a carousel compared to Oakland which has a whole ride park next to its zoo. The goats in SF were mean and aggressive and almost hit my toddler in the face with its horns while trying to wrestle food out of her hand. I had to pry the goat away!
author: J B.

description:
In the world of Zoos, the SF Zoo is showing its age -- 10 years ago they were getting rid of the old style exhibits (lots of concrete and bars) in favor of more modern, natural ones.  They're still updating them, and the buildings that look like they date back to the world's fair badly need renovation.

The new exhibits (such as the giraffes in the savana area, or the monkey and ape areas) are quite nice, and clearly modernized.  The animals look better in their natural environments, and the whole experience is better knowing the animals are treated well.  It's clear the zoo has tried to enhance the big cat and bear exhibits by reducing the number of animals so the ones there can wander from area to area; still, too much concrete in there really hurts the feel of the area.

Enjoyed the nice collection of birds scattered throughout, and the ever-present peacocks are always entertaining.  Friendly staff van be found throughout the park.

I had a wonderful afternoon walking through the zoo; it looked like quite a few of the exhibits were closed/coming soon, but it was still enjoyable.  No one is going to confuse the SF zoo with the Vancouver or SD Zoo.  It is a good zoo, however, to visit once in a while; but it's not the sort of place you get lost in for a day.
author: Aaron L.

description: The Zoo isn't super big. There are some great highlights: the Grizzly Bear sisters feeding is so fun,  I really like the African safari area & the spider monkeys are so cute & always active (even when it's kind of cold out).  Def renewing my membership!
author: Sunset S.

description:
Normally the zoo is full of young children screaming their heads off because an animal lifted its head, but when I went to the zoo there was definitely a role reversal. Last week at the SF Zoo the lions were having sex like mad and the adults in the crowd were going crazy and laughing like hyenas. I have never been so amused in my life. Now we've all seen animals doing it on the Discovery Channel, but there is nothing as awkward as seeing it in real life. I really felt like we should give them some privacy, but I think the male lion liked that we were watching, and the lionness was like "not this again!" 

Anyways, I had a great time. I got to see the penguins get fed, and the giraffes were so pretty. There were peacocks everywhere and the flamingos are awesome. I can't believe that the goats in the petting zoo aren't fatter because they get fed all freaking day long. AND...I got to eat kettle corn and pretend I was a kid. All in all a great day out.
author: Laura D.

description:
Ok, who's bright idea was it to build a zoo literally across the street from a beach?!?!?!  And not a nice beach, an always freezing COLD beach?  In a part of town that is always covered by overcast.

These poor animals.  It must have taken them AGES to acclimate to the weather.  I'm still not sure how they do it... maybe its all those indoor heated rooms they build for the animals.

I went here today for an extra credit assignment for school.  My main objective was the primates, so I really didn't look around much.

The animals did seem well taken care of.  Their environments were clean and well kept.

Today, LUCKILY the sun was out and there wasn't a cloud in the sky.  Personally, just because it was 62 degrees in the city, I was still freezing, but the animals may have enjoyed the sun for a change.

The Leaping Lemur cafe was serving Gordon Biersch food which looked and smelled great.

Only one out of 5 gorillas was out in the open.  Who knows where the others were.

There was however a 7 month old new baby monkey of some sort.  It was the cutest thing I have ever seen.  Apparently, its mother rejected it at birth and they are trying to get the monkeys here to accept him.  Poor little guy, I hope they do.

Overall, it was a nice weather day to go.  I wasn't entirely disappointed.

Three stars because I don't think the animals should be living beach-side in a city known for the fog and coldness.
author: Karlita C.

description:
There were some cool animals here but I felt like I was in Gotham City from a Batman Movie...

random peacocks everywhere....

everything is over grown....

closed down buildings...

depressed animals...

i was so upset when I left I went to Happy Hour ;-)
author: Jared B.

description:
Ive been a few times and i think that the animals look depressed. True it's a zoo, but still. The elephants and seals look like they want to smash their fucking face into a wall. The monkeys are consistantly pissed and are quick to fling the waste. Highlights - baby lions are a blast to watch play. Lowlights - Doesnt seem big enough for the animals to ram around in. Im giving it 3 stars for the sheer fact that the animals still clock in everyday.

Not to mention...greatest collection of goats EVAR....i am soul linked to goats in ways you dont even know, and i had the best conversations with Chad, Allison, Doug and THEEEE Professor Cheevers.

I found my Zen, and it looks, feels and smells like goat.
author: Mick F.

description:
It's been years since I've been to the SF Zoo, and I must say that it's so much nicer than I remembered.  

The first animals you'll see as you enter the zoo are the giraffes.  Have you ever seen a giraffe canter?  I'd never seen it until this past trip, and it's an amusing sight.  What was going through his head must have been something like this: "Now what did I need over here?  Darn, I forgot again.  Shoot.  Well, if I run back to where I was, I'll remember. Oh yes, it was those tender green leaves, ... or was it?  Oh, I forgot again."  At any rate, that giraffe was quite gawky and awkward, but he was having such fun that we were, too, just watching him.  

We also saw the penguins, were stalked by a peacock (who didn't have his tail feathers -- what's up with that?  do tourists attack peacocks and pull out their tail feathers or do they just grow them during mating season only), watched the indolent big cats laze in the sun (actually, the fog), looked at the bears play with their pumpkins, and interacted with the really fat prairie dogs and the really skinny meer cats (that struck me as really funny that one is called a "dog" and the other a "cat").  

Perhaps our very favorite was near the end, the Insect Zoo!  My kids love bugs, but I have to say that it's pretty gross to watch those cockroaches, hissing beetles, the tarantulas (who knew that there are ones w/ red knees and ones w/ white knees), ants, and even water beetles.

My least favorite part?  Buying a Zoo Key for $3 and only finding three working zoo key stations.  But it's pretty nostalgic to own a zoo key again.
author: Patty W.

description: If your looking for a fun and inexpensive day with friends and family and you don't mind a little bit of walking, then the San Francisco Zoo is the place for you! As soon as you enter you immediately see Acacia Plaza to your right which is a part of the African Region home to the Zebras, the Kudu and most of all the beautiful and breath taking Giraffes! All i can say is WOW! We went to the 430 feeding of the giraffe's and I could of stayed there for hours just watching the gentle giants! The big cat feeding is also something to see! And right outside you can also watch the Penguins get fed and absorb a lot of information. Over all its a real fun time at the Zoo! With lots and lots to see and do but it is also a pretty educational experience at the same time.
author: Debra M.

description:
Okay, 

SO I really like this zoo--not going to lie.  It is old school--anti habitation and pro animals in cement cages.  The cages are usually surprising close to "observation decks".  I almost was able to spank a penguin on its head.  Almost. So close. 

After you watch the lions pace back and forth for a while, I recommend exiting the zoo and you'll be right at the beach! 

 A pure treat for any visitor.

 =)
author: Bill B.

description: Although we had a really great time spending the day in SF Zoo with friends and family last week. I must say coming from a third world country, even our mini zoo was a whole lot better. But from a different perspective, if you just want your kids to experience seeing giraffe and monkeys, especially the very colorful peacock, then this is the place to be. We also had so much fun riding the train, there is a $4 fee per head, then again it's worth it especially when you're with family and having fun. Entrance fee is $15 for adult and free for 4 and under, I forgot for kids I think  around $9. There is an $8 parking fee aswell.
author: Jonah B.

description: We had a great time at free day at the zoo on mother's day. It wasn't overly crowded and, having been awhile since I'd been there, had some great new exhibits, my favorite being the grizzly bear siblings.  we also really liked the chimpanzee who carried around a red blanket and every time he stopped to sit he'd drape the blanket over his head.
author: Henry Y.

description: I've never really enjoyed zoos, but I recently visited the SF Zoo and I totally enjoyed my visit.  My daughter liked it so much she kept asking to go back.  So the next weekend we went again.  The zoo's pretty big, so we got to see things we missed last time.  The baby tiger was very cute!  We saw him playing with the mommy tiger.  The Children's zoo has a nature trail that was pretty neat.  My daughter got to see little animals up close and even pet some of the little animals (e.g. guinea pig, bunny, turtles).  She had a great time exploring the nature trail.  The zoo is well maintained, bathrooms are clean, cafes lunch.  There's lots of space for the animals and a good variety of them.  We saw a koala bear, polar bear, penguins, and giraffes.  It's also nice when it's triple digits whether in the east bay and you go there, it's 30 degrees cooler.  Will definitely return.
author: Little one C.

description:
When I was here last, I remember wild turkeys--pretending to be peacocks--were running amok and the gorillas looking pissed.  

Sadly, this zoo has gone downhill since I remember it as a little boy.  Sure you get the full aromatic animal experience, but you could get that at a circus AND be entertained.  The variety of animals in their manufactured "natural" habitats seems to have diminished as well.

I'd recommend the Oakland Zoo above and beyond the SF zoo if you're looking for a true animal outing, not to mention animals that seem to be well cared for by their keepers.  

And if you're looking for a donkey show, you'll need to go south of the border.
author: Jeff H.

description: Pretty decent for ticket prices and annual member fees, you can also find free parking AROUND the zoo, but the food there is nasty and it cost an arm an a leg, also I feel like it closes a little to early.
author: Xuan C.

description: I'm a fan... Not only is this zoo HUGE but it is really nice and spacious. There are a lot of room for the animals and a lot of walking space for visitors.
author: Graylain A.

description:
PROS:
-Wide variety of Wildlife, Birds ,Insects, Amphibians,Mammals, No elephants or panda bears from all over the planet- at least on 1/15/2011
-Very clean kept except for the dining areas and the nearby, i.e . seagulls flying around people who litter their food (on purpose or not) I rather eat lunch inside because of the smell
-Parking lot Close to Entrance...Discount for AAA& other check website Last wednesday of month is Free admission
-Kids enjoy the place!
-You can see the whole place if you get their late in about 4 hours.
CONS:
My GPS got to 1 Zoo Rd and it took me to the NE Side of the Deliveries Area/Adminstration Bldg. : Saw numerous people looking Lost and got asked several times do you know where the Main entrance to the ZOO is? They really NEED better signage in that spot if this many people are making the same mistake...
-Lots of areas were vacant like 3 grottos in row in the Bear Country and a promenade & the LION House was completely empty.
-FOOD overpriced and tasteless, as usual in these type of places, need better signage where the utensils are, all of their ketchup pump containers were completely out. (LEAPING LEMUR CAFE) 
-Closing time early on Sat. =4 pm??
-I expected to see the kangaroos hopping around, not sleeping on a steep hill on their backs next  some peacocks lol
-The Giraffes and Zebras were kinda off to the side when entering and when leaving.
-The scanner for your parking ticket stub is most annoying confusing system ever. Its a barcode which scans a red criss crossing circles where you don't know whether to stick it in or leave it on the bottom.
Bottom Line: Its in a peaceful area of the city, beats the oakland zoo! You go to the Beach afterwards to relax! My favorite things were the Insects, Bears, Lions, Tigers, Monkeys and Rhinos, oh yeah lastly...The  20 ft Anaconda in the Tropical Rainforest building!
author: Ambar G.

description:
Hard for me to review the Zoo when I worked here during the year of 2005. I still give them 4 stars. Loved comming here since Free Wednesday, yes I am Asian. I read some of the reviews about other Zoos being so much better than SF ZOO. What people don't know is that our SF ZOO is a non-profit organization. We don't get alot of funding from the city. 90% of the money is from donations, admission tickets and from Zoo members. 

I use to work at the membership Dept. and its hard. Yea, I would like to see the Zoo upgraded, but with what money? I've seen people write $10,000 checks and even little kids donate $5. So for the people to complain about the Zoo looking like crap and not comparing to the San Diego Zoo, don't judge what the Zoo looks like, but see how hard people work to protect/ save the animals each and every day.

Everyday I would stroll around the zoo during lunch and enjoy watching the animals lounge around and chilling. Saddens me sometimes when I see how small the enclosure is, but you can't release them back in the wild, they won't survive. There are many hidden spots at the zoo like the snow leopard area and areas not meant for visitors.

I like feeding the polar bears and going to night tours.
author: David L.

description: The SF Zoo is a great standby outing for families.  The new African Safari habitat was nicely done, the polar bears always seem to be playing and the steam train is a hit with most little kids.  That said, it is a zoo (hint: those reviewers who don't like zoos may want to give it a pass) and it has a number of empty habitats now that give the appearance of abandoned lots.  You can find much better zoos in other cities... but it's a pretty good option for those who live here.
author: Geoff D.

description:
wow, i came out more depressed knowing that the tiger will probably have to pace back and forth for the rest of it's life..alone.. :( 

the exhibits were sad.. birds are meant to fly, so why are they in cages where they can't even spread their wings?
author: Sylvia G.

description:
Aside from the disappointing (yet highly touted) reindeer exhibit, I thoroughly enjoyed my visit last week to the SFZoo.  The beautiful location and ample room afforded me a unique experience: I had something on my mind that I just couldn't communicate.  I just could not figure out how to express myself... which for a jabber-jaw like me is an unusual condition to find myself in.

I often times see myself living out scenes from movies, substituting myself for certain characters as they experience situations that are similar to mine.  At the zoo I felt like the "other car" in Planes, Trains, and Automobiles.  Perhaps it was the holiday that made me think of it...  Can you imagine how the couple in the car felt as they tried to convince a fatigued John Candy that he was traveling in the wrong direction on the highway?  They could clearly see that John was doing something wrong, behaving in a way that could bring him to harm, yet these poor motorists couldn't convince him.  Candy's character dismissed these people as drunks, ignoring the signals they were trying to send.  What happened to those people after their scene ended?  Did they lose sleep, wondering why John Candy wouldn't listen to them?  Were they offended that he was dismissive of their efforts?  Did they feel dejected or blame themselves for not being able to get their message across?

I love animals because they are different than we are- they never worry about other animals' feelings.  In every other capacity the animal kingdom shares traits with man, excepting this: there is no empathy outside of humanity.  Is this a blessing or a curse?  Perhaps only "Screaming Driver," and "Screaming Driver's Wife," (played by John Moio and Veronica Vanderkloot) will ever know...
author: Drew P.

description:
I like this zoo. 

It zoo has a nice layout. Be prepared to walk a lot and bring your own snacks and water because purchasing them there can really add up.  

We go on 'free' day for San Francisco residents so it's usually pretty busy. I can't speak to parking since we ride the Muni but the crowds of people walking around really aren't too bad, especially if you get there early. I really enjoyed the petting zoo section in the children's area. Watching kids and animals interact is really fun.  

Definitely give this zoo a chance. It is not huge and amazing and sunny like San Diego, but I've been coming to this zoo since I was a small child and it really does have it's charms.
author: Holly S.

description:
This should be more of a 2.5 star review. The layout of the zoo is nice as far as general flow and ease of navigation. Parking lot filled up quick, but wasn't too hard to find a spot around the corner on Sloat. Also, the outdoor bbq serving fresh grilled sandwiches and beer/wine was a nice change from usual carnival-style, hot dog vendor-type meals that you normally encounter at zoos and amusement parks.   
As far as the animals go, the gorilla area was cool-large and their were several of them you could observe from different vantage points. However, I have to agree with several other reviewers-many of the enclosures were just sad and outdated. And it reflects on the inhabitants. A world-class destination city like S.F. should have a zoo that's top notch.
author: Brad B.

description:
Free day at the Zoo - on the weekend?! - I'm there!! 

What ultimately happened though was that I went, got excited about the cool animals, saw some jack-ass torturing a peacock, got depressed, left, and walked around Lake Merced instead. 

Seriously, what adult rolls up a map, squawks at a free roaming peacock, pokes it with a stick and yells at his kids to check out the crazy bird. I hope the peacock bit your kid's face. 

Compared to many of the Zoos that I've been to, the San Francisco Zoo has by far been the most depressing. The lack of space and drab look of the animal exhibits nearly rivals Six Flags Discovery Kingdom.
author: Laura R.

description:
When I was 18 a friend of mine and I thought it would be a great idea if we took acid and went to the zoo. So we took acid and went to the zoo.

At first it was cool. Mostly sitting on every bench we encountered. Somehow we gravitated to the primate exhibit where we sat and I contemplated the absurdity of sitting there surrounded by wild animals. That, and the fact that if you say bananas over and over again it ceases to make any sense. Bananas, bananas, bananas. See? Weird, right?

The zoo can be kind of overwhelming when on acid so we left with me mumbling, "Man. I really need to see something normal." We thought that going to the beach would put us at ease and show us the simple beauty of the sea. That's pretty normal, right? Well I made the mistake of going to the public bathroom down there and opening a stall only to find a completely naked octogenarian standing there. 

He could only muster a weak "Uuunghh." 

I stood there for longer than I probably should have but I just could... not... look... away. I finally said, "Oh, sorry," and closed the door. I didn't even use the bathroom. I just left. The sight was so traumatizing I simply didn't have to go anymore.

The moral of the story is that sometimes the absurdity of being surrounded by wild animals is more normal than real life.
author: Josua P.

description:
Yesterday was my first visit to the zoo since the remodel.  San Francisco residents with MUNI Fast Passes get in for $7.  The zoo was just great.  My boyfriend and I took my 7-year-old nephew.  WE HAD A DELIGHTFUL DAY.  This certainly isn't the San Diego Zoo but it's lovely, down home, lots of fun, and honestly, very well done.  Every staff member from the snack bar vendors, to the train conductors, to the zoo keepers were wonderfully accomodating and friendly.

After losing $2 in broken lockers,  I was told to go to Membership Services but the line was much longer than I wanted to deal with.  I returned to the lockers to tell Steve that we should just carry our stuff.  A passing staff member over-heard this, got the money refunded, and even comped us two free train rides!  AWESOME service!

We had such a fun outing at the zoo with my nephew that I can't figure out why we don't visit more often!  I just couldn't believe how inexpensive admission was.  Since I only live about 2 miles away, I'm seriously considering buying memberships.

Five stars for a top quality, reasonably priced "attraction".  THANK YOU SF ZOO!
author: Amy A.

description: OMG I LOVE THE GIRAFFE. Lots of the animals looked very sleepy. Many animals.
author: Anders S.

description: If you are planning a special event and want to do something noteworthy and a bit unusual, the Zoo is a great venue. We wanted to have a pre-wedding event--not a traditional rehearsal dinner but a cocktail hour event to bring everyone together. We visited the zoo and got a tour of the possible venues we could use--they were all great. We learned we could arrange to have animals come visit the party, too, which sounded pretty cool. In the end we selected the Carousel, which was a HUGE hit. Having that 100-year-old carousel running for the entire two-hour event, so that everyone, from the 4-year-old to the 80-year-old, could ride as much as they liked, was fabulous. It brought the party together, added an element of fun and group play that made it as memorable as the wedding. Food was excellent; drinks professionally served and very reasonably priced. We looked at several different kinds of venues, and the prices and unique nature of this venue made it a clear winner. There is free parking after 5 p.m., another great feature in the city. Zoo events staff is great to work with; loved every part of this experience.
author: Cindy C.

description:
I love the zoo. But I feel that SF Zoo is getting shittier and shittier each year I go. Last year I only paid like $7 for being a minor and a student. This year, I paid $15. WTF!

A lot of the exhibits were closed. Which is so disappointing for $15. I was looking forward to the reptile house with the anaconda? Guess what, it's been closed for THREE years, claiming it was under construction. Bullshit.

I guess it's a good way to spend some time with friends in San Francisco. Oh, there's a beach very close by, so that's a plus. haha

I only 3 starred it because I love zoos. But this is getting too ridiculous.
author: Kim T. N.

description:
I live about 5 minutes from the zoo and I also bought a family membership here which, for the price, was not that bad. However this place is just plain boring. How often can you come here and see something new? Once....and that is all the use I got out of my membership.

The food and gift shop inside are expensive, the parking sucks, and it's almost as if no one works there. Zoos are not what I remember they used to be.

I guess if you are really into watching animals languish away in small areas you will love this place, other than that you should save your cash and go to the Exploratorium.
author: Josh J.

description:
HOLY COYOTE! If I was an avid animal lover, I would totally have my wedding here. I went to an amazing Rockabilly themed wedding here and enjoyed every moment of it because it truly reflected what the couple is like and broke the mold of your standard wedding.

Not only was I treated to a delicious tomato/mozarella skewer and hot artichoke dip appetizers, zoo volunteers also brought out a white possum, baby crocodile, armadillo and about 2 other small animals for us to PET/TOUCH during the cocktail hour!

The main seating area had a ski lodge type feel with a fire place and beautiful wooden rafters with little wooden animal statues around the walls.

The food was pretty good too - yummy mashed potatoes, great steak and veggies. For me, the stuffing inside the stuffed chicken breast tasty a little off, but the actual chicken breast itself was very good.

So if you are an animal lover, this is the wedding venue for you.
author: Jenny B.

description: Just came back from the zoo and overall, nothing special but my kid enjoyed it. However, I want to warn everyone NOT to take the train ride; it is a major ripoff. On the map, it looks like the train would circle the whole zoo. In reality, it just circle a very small portion twice. The whole ride took about 3 minutes, coming to about $1.67 per minute. Even my 8-old son agrees it is a major ripoff.
author: Alex Z.

description:
I've been to the SF Zoo only ONCE and it was enough for me. The one time I went there was a protest going on. The protesters were passing out flyers on the mistreatment of the elephants and how one died because of an infection it got from standing on the cement. 

The habitats were lacking compared to Oakland Zoo but some of the animals were cute.
author: Anna K.

description:
sunny day + spring break + free Wednesday = chaos at the zoo

Breeders everywhere - and I'm talking about the visitors.  More families than you would ever want to be surrounded while at the zoo.  Do all these people with tons of kids not have jobs?  What are they doing out and about?

As a former student of zoology, I appreciate being able to see wildlife in person that I could only watch on TV or read about in books.  Of course, I don't like seeing animals held captive -- not even domesticated animals.  So if you have pets and get high and mighty about captive animals in the zoo, then I think it's just hypocrisy.  Do you really think your dog/cat/etc wants to live with you?  Seriously.  If they had a choice, wouldn't they rather be free?  

OK, off soapbox A.  On to soapbox B.  

My ambivalence about captive animals aside, if you are going to have zoos, aquariums, pets, etc., then the conditions should be decent.  Sadly, I saw some terrible exhibition spaces that were not very nice for the animals, I imagine.  For example, hippos with barely any water to swim in and having only a small pool.  Hello, they're mostly aquatic.  Ditto for the polar bears.  

Looks like they're doing lots of construction and things might get better, but I'll believe it when I see it.

I give it 2 stars because people wouldn't care about saving elephants or other exotic wildlife if they never saw them.   Second, they do captive breeding programs for animals that are endangered and might go extinct otherwise.  That alone justifies zoos in my opinion.

Soapbox C (last one, promise)-

Here's the deal -- you don't want to see animals in captivity?  Stop buying so much crap that you don't need, which ultimately leads to habitat destruction and these animals becoming rare, threatened, or endangered.  We're all to blame.  Do more, buy less.  The less you buy, the less demand there is to destroy the environment.  Seriously, do you need a table from rain forest wood?  Don't drive so much/use too much electricity/etc... polar bears are drowning because of greenhouse gases.

Oh, and have fewer kids.  Please.

PS - I typically like good zoos, I have a pet (see pictures), and belong to the breeders, too.
author: Surf R.

description: I worked for a few days as a temp here in the development department and got to go in and see all the exhibits for free. I love zoos, aquariums, and practically anything that involves animals. I am by no means an expert but I think this zoo really tries to make the animals happy and comfortable as best they can. Zoos are always kind of depressing because you feel for the caged animals. But it makes me feel better when I know the zoo tries hard to be good to their animals and the SF zoo definitely does this. The animals were great and they all seem to have their own personalities which is funny to watch. I think this is a great place to take your kids and I would support the zoo if I had any money to give.
author: Jenny C.

description:
How terribly sad. I am a zoo enthusiast and the day I visited the SF my heart died a little. Put off by the 15 dollar price tag for admission, I waited for "Free Zoo Day", the first wednesday of every month, to venture out. Luckily I took advantage of San Francisco's handy public transportation, otherwise I would have to pay another 5 dollars for parking. Entering the park was hopeful, with the first enclosure containing a family of giraffes and zebras or something else as well as a large monkey jungle gym on the opposite side. As my friend and i continued on things quickly went downhill.
       Half the exhibits were closed off and the ones that weren't really should have been. Rhinos, tigers, grizzlies were all kept in concrete cubicles that wouldn't satisfy a homeless person. The animals looked completely miserable. In addition, the window barriers were filthy, making all views of the animals blurry.
        Everything was overpriced, the bathrooms were filthy and the placed seemed desolate. There were no zoo keepers in sight or docents to share information about the zoo. Groundskeeping was minimal. You're better off saving yourself $15 a person and just ride the bart. That's enough of a zoo.
author: Sweet P.

description:
Came here with my boyfriends 2 year old cousin and had a blast. Its a laidback zoo with gorgeous trees everywhere.

The bears were great and so were the gorrilas.

It is the perfect size. 

Be careful of seagulls if you eat there ( which I never would).

There were things that cost extra in the park which was lame.

And yes its sad that these animals have to be in cages, and yes when you return as an adult you realize how depressing it is....but as far as this feeling goes at this zooo it was very low.

Maybe its because we were with a 2 year old.

I reccomend this zoo for a nice sunday stroll if you haven't been.
author: Sari G.

description:
Uncrowded on a random, cold Tuesday...especially enjoyed watching the penguins being fed, Sumatran tiger cubs wrestling each other and getting licked on the head by their mom, and the prairie dogs intermittently playing imaginary lazertag with each other while standing guard for imaginary predators! 

A gratuitous pocket zoo map promises much more than the zoo actually delivered since many exhibits are either  "closed", "future", and "opening soon" exhibits. For example, the map has an area marked "future hippo" which does not contain a hippo that was sent here from the future to destroy the human race. The lion house was closed.  

The animal enclosures generally allowed for full access to viewing...most of the descriptive signs accompanying the exhibits  resembled trivial pursuit answers (if there existed an "Animal Planet" edition)...along with multiple instances of recycled facts just worded slightly differently...as an alternative, my friend found the relevant wikipedia articles on her iphone as a guide...noted this little bit of possibly unintentional humor on the sign at the grizzly bear exhibit at the end of the list for the grizzly diet: "...mammals (small and large)." 

The miniature train-ride looks like it would be a big hit with Harry Potter fans...the petting zoo included lamas!...everything is priced for the tourist...$6 to park near the entrance...a plain vanilla zoo.
author: Matthew L.

description:
The lemurs seem to have the nicest pad. What's up with that? What about the poor chimps or gorillas? Don't you think they are more aware that they live in a prison?

Anyway, the San Francisco zoo was a bit of a disappointment.  It's pretty small and some of the animal habitats are depressing. And, there are a ton of crazy peacocks lurking about -- one followed me into the bathroom (pervert!). However, when I need a fix of cute animals, it'll do in a pinch.
author: Rebecca H.

description: I love the zoo. It is gorgeous and has a great education program. AND my husband and I got married here in July. The staff was perfect. Highly professional and they took care of everything. The food was great, the setup and take down was great. Lisa, Stephanie, and Adam handled everything and all I did was show up. I am so grateful I had a gorgeous wedding and it was well worth the money. Also, the money goes to the conservation of the zoo and the animal's welfare. How fabulous is that! Highly recommend a day trip or having an event here. It's just friendly and lovely.
author: Bunny N.

description:
Now, I used to work at this zoo taking photos for tourists that have money to burn so I was there practically everyday for a good six months or so. (My god, was it that long?!)

When I started working there, I had never been to the SF Zoo. Now that I've stopped working there, I've never been back. Why?

Since the zoo is located right next to the coast, it's usually foggy and cold and grey out there, even if it's sunny and warm in the Mission District.

With the cold weather, you can't help but feel really bad for the animals. I think the giraffes and zebras are pissed. They probably wake up in the morning, look out their barn window and think, "Another cold ass day? I did NOT sign up for this shit." Don't believe me? 9 times out of 10 on a grey day, you'll see all the lemurs huddled underneath their heat lamp.

The other parts of the zoo are kinda odd. The facilities don't seem right. A little too 1950s "let's put a koala behind glass like a store front window display." 

If you're there, be sure to check out the depressing blind geriatric seal next to the lonely tapir. The tapir spends its day alone, sitting in his pool of water or on a pile of hay. The seal spends its day blindly swimming around and around and around in its tiny pool of water. (But it's not the zoo's fault, because the seal is so old and has cataracts in its eyes, moving the seal to a better facility would be too stressful for it.)

Fun things to do at the zoo? Watching seagulls steal hot dogs right from under patron's noses. Those seagulls are CRAZY. You can also chase the various peacocks that wander around the zoo (or let them chase you... it happened to me. Kinda disconcerting.) And you can (though you're not supposed to) feed the squirrels that hang around the Little Puffer train. And you can laugh at the outdated sign for the old elephant habitat that says "PACHYDERMS."

Hmm, I guess wild animals behind cages doesn't really thrill me. Maybe I'm too old and the magic is gone? I'm sure plenty of little ones would still get a kick out of the SF Zoo. They don't know any better. It's like when I went to Disneyland after college and just ended up thinking "How many of these character actors are just out of work actors who can't strike it big in Hollywood?"

But the staff is super nice. Since I worked there, if you know the right people, you can eat loads of fattening foods for free, I mean discounted prices.

I miss the dippin' dots, churros and cotton candy. One star for each junk food item!
author: Viv C.

description:
This is becoming a world-class zoo. Anyone who doesn't think so, try visiting the outdated LA Zoo: http://www.yelp.com/biz/hybp3zlDXTxjwZBFTCQbdg

The new Africa Savannah exhibit is great. I love the meerkats and the penguin island. The Children's zoo is excellent and the petting zoo/farm is one of the best I have been too. One of the benefits of it's location at the ocean is the sea birds, mostly gulls flying overhead and squawking. That and the tall Cypress add a nice effect.

This zoo is built for children, children playing and children getting close to and viewing animals. They have a great playground and lawn a carousel and a train ride. All fun stuff in addition to the animals.
author: Scott M.

description:
Pulling up to the SF Zoo for the first time and driving around the parking lot you suddenly realize that the parking lot is pretty darn small.  A short drive up Sloat to find a free parking spot wasn't too bad. 

Walking to the entrance you suddenly realize that this is a pretty big zoo, by Sacramento standards.  Koalas, kangaroos, rhinoceroses, giraffes, gorillas, monkeys, lions, tigers (still alive), and bears.  We had a great time walking around looking at the exhibits.  The penguin island was neat as you could see the penguins swim by.  You can feed the giraffes here too.  Really neat.  We are planning on going back to look at the rest of the park.
author: D J.

description:
For SF family appreciation day- My family and I enjoyed a day here. We walked all around viewing the various animals. The insect zoo is such a treat for me since I dig oversized cockroaches and furry tarantulas crawling around a thin glass cage. (Yeeech!)

 The surprisingly entertaining creatures were the prarie dogs! I had no idea they are soooo social and malicious to each other. hee-hee!
author: linda l.

description:
I LOVE SF ZOO!!! Hands down THE BEST zoo I have ever been to, considering the only other zoo I've gone to is Oakland Zoo...and Manila Zoo...does that count?

We brought the lovies here today on this glorious Sunday. And what a perfect day it was! The weather was neither hot nor cold, the crowd was average, and the mood delightful! We paid a discounted price of $17 for the four of us since we're zoo members so SCORE!

They have a plethora of animals that Oakland zoo does not have such as the kangaroo, ostrich, koala bear, panda bear, grizzly bear, brown bear, polar bear, rhinoceros, hippopotamus, peacock, anaconda, different types of owls, hawks, gorilla, antelopes, lemurs, prairie dogs, etc. Of course they have the usual lions, tigers, elephants, zebras, giraffes, flamingos, monkeys, chimpanzees, meerkats. They have other animals that I just cannot recall at this time for the life of me.

The playground is okay in size, but the slide slides better than the itty bitty one that they have at Oakland. They a wider selection of eateries as well; more expensive, but better. They have snack huts at every turn where you can pig out on cotton candy, pretzels, churros, dippin' dots, popcorn, soda...hmmm...cavity central waiting to happen! They even have photographers at the entrance who will take your pics 'for fun" but you are not obliged to buy.

Unlike Oakland zoo, you do have to pay to ride the Carousel and train and the lines are longer. Not ideal for us since we have a 20-month and 7-month old lovebugs in tow.

What I don't understand is how on earth that tiger jumped over the fence. AND why would anybody tease and taunt a caged animal that is known to be ferocious?! There are "shh" signs in certain areas like the gorilla section so please follow the rules, peoples!!! Respect the animals please!

I also don't understand why people bitch about the prices at an attraction such as this one. This isn't a factory outlet or the flea market so don't expect things to be cheap here. Or don't come here at all. I suggest you just watch the Animal Planet from your own home. Stop complaining! Enjoy the park! On a side note, some of these animals have either been captured as a young then donated to the zoo because they are unable to survive in the wild or injured so that is why they are here. Some were born here.

The staff and volunteers are very informative and are more than willing to answer any and all of your questions. 

We will be coming back here soon. I cannot wait!

One more plus, Ocean Beach is across the way. Great place to kick back and lounge after trekking the zoo!
author: Candy C.

description: I had a really great time bringing my twins here for their second birthday- the girls loved it! The animals were cool and the weather was really nice. We went on a weekday and at the end of March- so it was not packed with screaming kids running all over the place. It was really mellow and not busy at all.  Admission fees were not too bad either.
author: LaVon S.

description:
Why so many bad reviews of the zoo?  It's not that bad. Actually quite pleasant. My personal favorites are the goats, flamingos, peacocks, giraffes, and ostriches. I wish they had more exhibits though and I also wish it was a little easier to figure out. But it is great looking at all the animals, which is what most people go to a zoo for. San Francisco residents get free admission on the first Wednesday of every month. 
The only thing I don't like is if you get a drink at the cafe there and want to walk around the zoo, you'll have to do it without a lid on your cup...not so easy to do on a windy day in San Francisco, which is almost any day of the year. I also wish they would stay open later! 
But all in all, a great experience!!!
author: Christene M.

description: Long time not visit zoo and time to bring back kids for yesterday. Fun and good for kids like before. Now have free kid ticket for paid adult till end of this year. Only cafe is too small and less choice for crowded weekend.
author: Kyle T.

description:
I was raised in San Diego with the world-famous San Diego Zoo.  My family always had season passes and I even attended Zoo School there when I was younger.  The SF Zoo can't begin to compare to the SD Zoo in terms of size, variety, beauty, or sheer awe of the exhibits.  But then, I didn't expect it to.  I actually like the SF Zoo just as much as SD, only in a different way.  SD (and other world-class zoos) can seem sterile, with the animals sequestered so far from visitors, across concrete moats and behind thick plexiglass.  At SF you can get face to face with almost all the animals.  The exhibits are intimate and there aren't nearly as many crowds.  There are even peacocks just wandering around free which blew my mind the first time I went.

You MUST go to the petting zoo located in the children's zoo area.  Seriously, it makes the day.  Unless you grew up on a farm, petting, brushing, and feeding the various animals there is a total trip.  Just watch out when you purchase your food pellets from the machine.  Once, when I was about to collect my food from the machine, I was pushed aside by this enormously fat goat on his hind legs who proceeded to eat all my pellets straight from the chute.  I didn't want to shove him out of the way and get kicked out of the zoo for animal abuse, so I just stood there and took it.  Boyfriend said I had a look on my face like I'd been raped.  Of course it wasn't quite that extreme, but I certainly felt violated.

The zoo closes at 5.  Depending on the time of year, that's just in time to go across the street and watch the sun set over the water.  Perfect day.
author: Lauren C.

description: Just went last weekend and have to say that it wasn't as magical as I remember when going as a kid for field trips in elementary school.  I remember the Lion house being filled with people that watched as the big cats poured into all the cages to be fed, however the room now looks depressing with a sign reading "no scheduled feedings" throughout my time in the park I kept thinking of the Jurassic Park line "now there will be dinosaurs on this dinosaur tour right?" The SF zoo needs more animals! Highlights were the grizzly bears, sea lions, giraffes....disappointments were no elephants, and most of the cages were empty :(
author: John H.

description: My husband is originally from the east bay so we decided to bring our 2 little guys to check it out. Both of us had been here years before. This visit was actually quite disappointing, especially for the price paid to get in and for parking. Thankfully I had packed snacks so we weren't forced to pay for overpriced food too. We planned our visit around wanting to see the "big cat feeding", which on their website stated 3:00pm. We made our way through the park before that, and agree with other reviews that the set up left much to be desired. You must double-back and/or pass the same area multiple times, and in most cases their are no animals in between. Seemed quite run down. The carousel was closed, and guess what? They don't do big cat feelings. We were finally told that food is "used for training" so they no longer do it. Ummm...huh? Don't they get to eat like normal animals?? No wonder they all look depressed and angry. The kids enjoyed it, but if you're in the area I would highly recommend the Oakland Zoo over this!
author: K T.

description:
So I generally don't like zoos.  Actually, the little kid in me just wants to spend all his time looking at animals, but the adult in me knows that a bunch of zoos treat their animals poorly and that really the only wild animals that belong in captivity are those that are endangered and those that are no longer able to survive in the wild.

I came here with my mom and nephew last week.  I wasn't expecting much, and my expectation was just about met.  Actually, the scale of the place is really nice, especially when you're carting around a two-year-old who's more interested in water faucets than exotic animals.

So if this weren't a zoo, I might give it three stars for its layout and friendliness alone.  But it is a zoo, and a lot of the exhibits are depressing.  I love watching polar bears, but they just don't look happy in enclosures overgrown with weeds.  I also don't like the fact that it took the passage of a city law to force the zoo to get rid of its elephants after it had mistreated them.

The little train is cool; the grizzly-bear exhibit is super cute, especially when the bears are sleeping.  And the children's part of the zoo is really really really cool.  In fact, if this were the extent of the zoo, I would give it four stars.

So the real reason for one star is that because of the zoo's negligence, a man and a tiger are dead.  I know that a bunch of people think it's the taunters' fault that the tiger attacked them and that they "deserved" it--which is a ridiculous statement on its face; being mauled to death seems an extreme punishment for teasing and throwing things at a tiger--but it's ultimately the zoo's fault that the tiger was able to escape its enclosure.  The zoo had not built the tiger enclosure up to specifications, and the zoo's immediate response to the tragedy was to get a PR company to smear the victims' names in the papers.  You can say whatever you want about these guys, but the zoo is ultimately responsible for keeping the public safe.  Period.  They've since fixed the big cats' enclosures, so they're safe now.

One cool thing about this zoo is that you can see part of the African exhibit without even paying admission.  Just go up to the ticket office and watch the baby giraffes and gazelles through the fence.
author: John S.

description: Remember that episode of The Simpsons where the dolphins were tired of living in the sea so they went to land and kicked out all the humans back to the sea? If you're going to run a zoo, at least keep the living conditions in decent conditions. The last time I went here was last year ago, but I think back when I went here a couple of times when I was a kid and the zoo's condition was a lot better back then.
author: Gerard Y.

description:
I've been to a few zoos - The Philly Zoo, The Washington DC Zoo, the North Carolina Zoo - so i was excited to visit the zoo in San Francisco.  I figured it would be a magical place where the animals were well respected and humanely treated.  I never saw abuse at the other zoos, but this is San Francisco.  People love animals here.

How wrong I was.  This felt like some two-bit zoo in the middle of Podunk, Alabama.  

The Large Cat exhibit was atrocious.  There were hardly any signs to direct you to this tucked back display and I understand why.  The cages were overgrown with vines and trees.  The few cats that we did see were sacked out in their little boxes and looked no more special than your average SPCA cat.  the snow leopard was out and sleeping on a pedestal, but his cage was tiny as well.  The exhibit was poorly maintained, overgrown, uncomfortably small, and generally forgotten about.

And don't get me started on the poor koala who was housed in a teeny glass box as if he were a necklace at Tiffany's.

My favorite animal, the river otter, was in a similarly small pen all by himself.  Just doing short laps back and forth.

About half of the exhibits were closed.  And this was on a Saturday, I'd hate to see it on a Wednesday.  South American Tropical Forest - Closed.  Bald Eagle - Closed.  Little Puffer - Closed.  Lemurs - Locked up.  Black Swan - Gone.  Grey Seal - Gone.  Most Primate cages - Empty.

There was no shortage of peacocks, though.  It was as if all those missing animals had been transformed by the peacock fairy into these dumb birds that wandered all over the grounds of the zoo.

I've heard that they're doing a lot to bring the SF Zoo back into prominence, so that's encouraging, but it was an overall disappointment.  Next time I'm checking out Oakland's zoo.
author: Lindsay D.

description:
I enjoyed the time I spent here on a day the week before Christmas--the week before the Tatiana tragedy.

I'll agree with others here, that there are some exhibits that are pretty depressing--the Hippo was one.  But I thought the big cat 'cages' were ample enough.  Anyone who thinks these animals have it bad should watch one of the several thousand documentaries on lions / tigers in the wild.  It's a brutal fucking world in the jungle, FYI.  The cats here will never starve to death, never have their young eaten, never get picked apart by hyenas....they may, on occasion, be taunted to the point where they attack and then end up shot by police, though.
author: Nobody M.

description:
In need of some living contact, four friends and I visited the zoo on a sunny Thursday afternoon. The place was nearly empty, but surprisingly peaceful.

About two years ago, I visited the Philadelphia Zoo. The deplorable conditions---small concrete cubes with very large, sad looking animals---made me want to join an anti-zoo organization of some sort. Well, being somewhat lazy and a non-joiner I never addd my voice to the fight against zoos, though I remained morally opposed.

However, I'm also easily susceptible to peer pressure and when a group of friends suggested we trek all the way across town for a field trip to the zoo, I joined in. I was pleasantly surprised that the fee for SF Residents (with written proof, so bring a piece of mail if your license isn't up to date) is only $9...less than a movie!

My group wandered through the zoo for nearly 3 hours and I was thoroughly impressed with the exhibits. I don't pretend to know much about zoos or animals, but the environments looked very pleasant, including grassy areas, trees and toys, and none of the animals looked sad. There was also a lot of information about the animals posted, so it was truly an educational experience.

The only part I found a little disturbing was the lion and tiger feedings. The large animals are shut into small metal cages and are fed large lumps of meet while the audience oohs and ahhhs. Before they were fed, the lions and tigers were pacing and looked quite agitated. I can't really blame them, I wouldn't be too happy if 100 people watched me eat every day either.
author: Lara L.

description: We loved the zoo! The overall exhibits were large and beautiful. In some places a bit too large when the animals were on the furthest side it was hard to see. But we loved the steam train and the penguins! Check out pictures from our last trip there on our blog ! http://peekabootravel.com/blog/?p=551
author: Kara M.

description:
I don't why everyone is so negative about this place. 

If kids from 14 months to 10 years old were yelping they would give it 5 Stars. 

I took my niece there (16 months old) with her mom and she had a blast. The highlights were definetly the rhino and the lions! The lions were just amazing. And that cute little train ride was a bonus for her - she did not was to get off the train, I believe they call it "puffer". 

It's pretty awesome to have a Zoo in San Francisco. Overall the niece was happy and I was pretty impressed as well. 

Only negative is I can't believe they are charging $8 for parking...that seems unnecessary.  I think they would attract more visitors if they lowered the parking fee. It's out in the sunset, not downtown SF.
author: Kristina A.

description: Nice zoo, smaller than we expected for a major city.  Place kinda spread out a little much.  Thought the cost was a little much for their size and offerings and more so when we learned at the gate they charge for parking too so thank goodness we parked outside their lot and on the main street.  Staff not especially friendly when you do try to interact with them.
author: John F.

description:
It has been so so way way to long since I have been to the Zoo.  I took my grand-kids there over the holiday weekend.  They have done such a good job of cleaning up the zoo and they continue to work on it to make it better... Yes I have issues with wild animals being caged, but I also look at the flip side that helps educate us about the animals in the wild...  

I have my Zoo key from the 60's when I was a kid and I bought my grandson a Zoo key... I am not sure why they still sell Zoo keys since we only found one box that actually worked... but alas it is a memory for him.
author: Robin G.

description:
Its a little sad to come to the zoo.  If you think about it, it's just a large animal shelter with no chances of these creatures to ever be adopted.  You walk through and observe the monkeys, the cats, the penguins...  I guess it's fine for people to come here.  After all, the money they spend to get in goes to the care of these animals.  It's not like they're abandoned or without food or shelter.  It just feels lonely knowing that they've been removed from what was their habitat...or are not able to ever return to their natural habitat.

I give it a 4 stars because at the very least they're cared for.

The End
author: Duckie A.

description:
Half the zoo was under construction the last time we were here. However this is definitely one of my all time favorite zoos for one reason:

HUGE PETTING ZOO AREA. Oh god. It was awesome.

Plus the penguin area was pretty large and had lots of little penguins swimming around which was super cute.
author: Mindy W.

description:
This zoo is really quite pathetic. The poor animals are actually caged- yes, while you might have thought sf zoo would have improved standard of living for zoo animals, it hasn't. Polar bears had the same surroundings as grizzly bears. Does that seem right? Monkeys were literally in cages with FAKE branches. Come on! If it takes charging more $ for entrance fee, the zoo should do it, because this is just sad.

The petting zoo was fun- but the animals were all so overfed from kids who walk around giving them food pellets all day long. Adorable Alpaca though!
author: Emily A.

description:
BABY COMFORT LEVEL:  Fantastic!  I pined over bringing the jogging stroller for rough terrain, but the universal car seat stroller was just fine.  Wide sidewalks and plenty of nooks and crannies to park when looking at the animals made it a cinch while carry the baby in the Bjorn and pushing the daiper bag in the stroller.  Also, you can find lots of benches to take breaks.

Through the eyes of a nine-month-old, the San Francisco Zoo is a magical, amazing, happy place!  Especially relevant is the Children's Zoo where she LOVED tugging on the goats horns, petting the sheep, watching the ducks, and squeeling out loud at the gophers.  Watching her excitement and wonder makes our visit there a snapshot of a "bonus" mom moment.  She was soooooooo happy and the layout makes the animals quite easy to see up close.

Other areas of great enthusiasm were the penguins (lots of them loud and up front), the hawks (large), and the monkeys (she remembers them from the Baby Einstein "Animals of the World" DVD.)

FOOD
The Leaping Lemur Cafe offered a comfortable indoor place to eat and rest after carrying 20lbs. on my chest for 1.5 hours.   There was a man at the table next to us who had nine-month-old twins and a four-year-old.  The twins were screaming for their food as he poured through bottles and jars in preperation and then had to go back and forth feeding their opens mouths like little birds.  Every now and then he would talk to his four-year-old, while taking very quick bites of his sandwich.   I asked him if he was alone with the three kids and he was, but was remarkably calm and seemed to even enjoy it!  When I see parents like this I just can't complain about, well...anything really.

The food at the Lemur Cafe is not stellar, but there was a nice bun for the baby to chew on.  The hamburger meat was not great.  Around the corner is an outdoor cafe that serves Asian food, but the cafe offers a place to be out of the wind and relax a bit.
author: Janty S.

description: Had an excellent time at the zoo, the animals were great, there were a lot of people but it didn't seem crowded, and the service was all around good. My only complaint is the conductor for the train is the grumpiest man I have ever met! And he is suppose to be around kids all day? We are trying to teach a two year old manners and so we wanted him to say thank you to the conductor and the conductor looks at us and says "I don't have time for you, get out of my way, I have things I have to do." Are you kidding me?! All we were going to say was thank you. If you are going to be around kids all day get then learn to put a smile on your face, your job is suppose to be fun. Other than that experience the zoo was very pleasant.
author: Emily L.

description:
I am hard pressed to even give this place a star.  This has to be one of the saddest zoos I have ever been too.  

Walking into the zoo I passed a man and his two kids and overheard him say "all that walking for 10 animals!"  I should have turned around at that very moment.  He wasn't kidding. 

There was one gorilla, and he was sitting in his little doorway looking bored as ever.  The cimpanzee cage was closed as were so many others.  They appeard to be doing some construction but common can't you do it gradually rather than closing down so many exhibits at one time.  

At the very least the zoo should have posted all the exhibits that were closed that day.  If they did post it I know I most certainly didn't see it. 

I give this zoo two thumbs down.  I really hope the kids get some enjoyment out of it.  Personally I think they should close the place and put up condos.  Let those poor animals go to the San Diego zoo where they will have a better life.

Not bitter just stating how I felt about the place and if you asked my 8 companions that day they would all agree. 

I think I will stick to the animals in the Castro, at least they are not caged, although some of them should be.
author: Scott P.

description: This is definitely not the best zoo in the world, but why it has an average of 3 stars on Yelp boggles my mind! I came here this past May and hadn't been since I was very young so I basically forgot and it was just as if I had never been before [: Lucky me! My only childhood memory of this place were the blue keys you could purchase to stick into the parking meter type things to hear about the animals, haha. But anyway, my favorite thing about this zoo is that it is RIGHT next to the beach [: I literally got sand in my toes just walking to the entrance!! *You have to wear sandals to achieve this experience* :P I don't recall how much admission was but I know you get a discount if you live in the city.. This zoo was a decent size, meaning enough to tire me out after walking the entire place, and has a nice big cafeteria to serve everyone's needs! My favorite part of this zoo was the insect room where they had every creepy crawly you could ever want to (or not) see! It was really impressive and I recall screaming a few times when I turned around and there was a gigantic spider behind me ]: Good thing it was in an exhibit! I would definitely return here again someday.
author: Alysia W.

description:
Preface: I am a member of this zoo.

That said, the zoo is really showing its age and needs some fixing-up badly. Some of the animal exhibits are extremely depressing. I just don't get a happy feeling here. Perhaps less would be more. Maybe the zoo should get rid of some of the exhibits and concentrate on the best ones?
author: Jennifer P.

description:
The zoo is nice and has improved over the years.
BUT--the people who take tickets can suck it.  I took a friend's 3! kids there with her family pass and because my name didn't match the card she made me go back and purchase a ticket for myself.  The 3 kids and I waited in a line for about 15 minutes and when we got back to the ticket taker she was still rude and the oldest kid called her a mean bitch (I swear I didn't coach him).  She clearly doesn't have children because she told him to shut up instead of laughing it off.
Aside from that we loved the lions and the lemurs and the baby giraffe.  I also like that the zoo got rid of it's elephants because they were sick because they had no space to walk around.  They live upstate now in a sanctuary.  The zoo did this even though the National Zoo Assn dropped them for it.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
I always wondered what the SF Zoo animals thought of living in the fog. Sure, we as humans can get sick of it at times, but at least we can escape it during a monthly pilgrimage to the peninsula. But what about the animals? How do they like it that the coldest winters they've ever spent would be a summer in San Francisco? (Thanks, Mark Twain!)

Regardless, I've been coming to the zoo since I was a wee one. And while before, everything used to be awesome and cool, some things seem to have degraded to a point of much-need restoration.

Some highlights include the penguins (and their feeding), the roaming peacock (he will get close to you, watch out) the new-ish Grizzly Bear habitat, and most of th the areas in the critter county (i.e. meerkats). We got to feed the giraffes but perhaps that was more of luck than anything else.  I was also pleased to see that they still enlist young volunteers who have small animals such as chinchillas or turtles and then share information to anyone willing to listen.

Lowlights would include the empty pachyderm section, a gorilla pen with one gorilla, the absent cats (and a closed big cat feeding area) and napping marsupials. The barricades around the gorilla and cat pens are a reminder of what happened last Christmas, but honestly, isn't there something else that can be done?

SF Residents and those with MUNI passes can get discounts, just bring proof. Free admission on the first Wednesday of the month.
author: Bryan B.

description:
My experience with this zoo has been a bit up and down.
