I've been visiting here since I was a small child so I remember the Fairy Tale-themed areas of the place and recall when an elephant --- actually a couple of them--- lived there.  While my kids have enjoyed going there too  even they at seven and four years old are starting to notice that this place has too many empty habitats in it. 

We've also had some rather odd experiences here, like the lion feeding session just a couple of days after Easter when eyebrows were raised over the sight of dead white bunnies thrown in the feeding cages. Yeah, Happy Easter kids!

Our most recent visit took us to the Reindeer Romp, an attraction we heard about last year but never made it to after the Christmas Day tiger escape temporarily shut down the zoo. I don't know what I was expecting from three of Santa's reindeer rejects (Belle, Peppermint and I don't  recall the third name) but, this was far from a romp.  If you could even see these poor creatures through the fencing you were in for a reindeer snooze fest.  The trio looked as if its was slipping into a food coma after Thanksgiving dinner.  One even looked like some child had scribbled on one its horns with a green crayon!  Santa, do  these three a favor and take them back to the North Pole!

The carousel is beautiful and it looks as though some wonderful improvements are on their way to the Childrens Zoo thanks to Fisher Price.  They are sponsoring new programs including a Learner's Cabin.  Props to FP for your continued wonderful work in educating children!  The walk around the zoo is lovely and the Puffer Train is charming but, there are a lot of attractions and facilities in this place not being utilized.  Despite it being a holiday week with lots of visitors milling about not all of the food venues were open.  One employee told me I was lucky I hadn't come the day before as the line at the Lemur Cafe was out the door.  The bathrooms were disgusting.   If you look around though the improvements are coming.  They are working on this place and can only continue to do so if we keep patronizing it.
author: Kristine D.

description: I got the membership for $100. Got my moneys worth in a month. Daughter loves it here and its cheap! Foods edible, and the carousel is loads of fun.
author: Keyser S.

description: Expensive and boring. Can they just make one huge cage and put all the animals in one? Would make it more interesting and prob save money.
author: Steve M.

description: Ahhh, SF Zoo. We have always gone at opening and have never been disappointed. The animals are always out. Our favorite exhibit is the Africana exhibit. I mean, just the lay out is super cool. I know a lot of people call this Zoo a bit depressing... but there is something "tried and true" about this place. Yes, it is old. Yes, it is in desperate need of some new exhibits and freshening up. Yes, the primate exhibit is probably the most depressing place ever. However, the fact that the peacocks pretty much just wander around the whole zoo is pretty dang cool. We really like the bear exhibits and the Lion's Den. I enjoy the walk around and the overall layout of the zoo. The food isn't great, so bring your own food and drinks. It will be a most of the day trip if you have kids. Bring some extra money for the little train ride also, that is if you have kids. Definitely worth the visit, but be sure to go early and with a plan so you can see all the feedings and active animals!
author: Christina T.

description: It's so wonderful that they are able to have a zoo in such a densely packed city like San Francisco. It was smaller than many of the zoos I had been to, but they managed to cover a wide variety of animals. The most unusual part was the hamster/rabbit exhibit in the children's zoo. It was funny to see hamsters running around in a zoo exhibit. Due to the fact that the zoo is right on the bay, the air was very chilly. It was even cold in the sun. I can see that parking might be an issue on crowded days, but we didn't have a problem with it. We had a great time.
author: Kari G.

description:
The zoo is lacking.
Most stuff in Sf is exceptional when it comes to parks and rec, but this place is tiered. 

Still not bad. Go down south to San Diego to see how its done.
author: Walter M.

description:
Shame, shame, shame on you SF and Zoo Society!!  How can you call that three-quarters-empty park a zoo?   The few animals that are there look depressed and unhealthy.  It's been years since I was there - but I don't remember the park being in such a run down state.  I made it a point to visit being there is a new baby gorilla.  My son and I got there around 11:30 to find out the baby gorilla is only out from 10:00 to 12:00!!  Why?  The weather was OK - typical SF weather - not raining, not windy -- so why the short hours?  Got to the enclosure just in time to see the back of the mom walking into the night enclosure area and that was that.

Sad that I can actually remember the animals I saw because there were so FEW!!  Three baby giraffes, one adult giraffe, two lions, two tigers, eight sleeping kangaroos, quiet a few smelly penguins, one dazed polar bear, three sleeping koalas, a few birds, a few tiny monkeys whose glass enclosure was practically covered by bamboo trees in front of it, three mandrills (one of which had obvious recent head surgery), two of the saddest chimps I have ever seen (should call the chimp eden guy about this) and of course the back of the gorilla mom.   Oh, almost forgot - two lemurs in an enclosure big enough for a heard of buffalo - why?

The tiger enclosure looked like it could hold a tyrannosaurus rex - metal bolts, electric wire, two inch plate glass -- slight overkill I think.  

Back to the review -  $15 to get in.  $8 to park (there is street parking off the side of the entrance).  $3.50 for a churro.  $3.00 for water.  Handful of pathetically depressed looking animals -- Simply put, a total rip off.
author: Mrs N N.

description:
I Love the San Francisco zoo!  For fun, I like to strap raw meat to my ankles and dangle them over the big cat inclosure's while I yell, "here kitty kitty".  Boy...that never gets old.


Update:
Apparently one of the cats got angry,  escaped, and killed someone, so I wouldn't recommend this.
author: Benita S.

description: I came here on a windy cold day and imagined it would have been a lot nicer of an experience if the weather was better.  We came on one of the free days for SF residents not as crowded as I imagined it would have been. My favorites were the Bears and Kangaroos.  There were peacocks that were walking around everywhere, pointless to have them behind gates cause they would fly over them :) Not a very big zoo, but descent.  Lots of parking available and near the Beach.
author: Charla M.

description:
In the SF Zoo the animals have 2-3 times the space they have in most normal zoos across the US & Canada. They also have areas that are open range safari style reminiscent of game reserves in South Africa that mimic the normal environment the animals live in. 

Frankly I don't see the "crampness" others are talking about because if you have been to their actual environs (like I have) they do not have that much more space than they do at the SF Zoo. Granted it could be bigger (like San Diego) but frankly San Francisco doesn't have the square footage other major cities have so comparatively it is the right size.

They also have overnight events and environmental education for children which are very important.

Also animals are expensive to feed especially those with special diets so if you're wondering where the money goes there you go.
author: Valerie F.

description:
Really? 11 dollars to get into this place? Seriously?

Apparently so.  Also disappointing is that in exchange for the beautiful new front entryway, we no longer may use our cheapo plastic elephant zoo keys for the interpretive boxes. 

Most disappointing is the very few renovations that have been made to this zoo since I was a small child.  Even at a young age I knew it wasn't right to keep wild animals in cement enclosures with no stimulation or natural habitat.  But the 21st century and technological inventions did not catch up with this place.  We can carry phones anywhere in the world and talk to anyone, and yet we are still so barbaric as to treat other creatures this way.

This is not to say I don't enjoy zoos or the concept of zoos.  This one in particular has a particularly atrocious track record of how they treat their animals.  

While i happily report that sections of the zoo are under construction (hippos, specifically, which happen to be my favorite) it is unfortunately not enough to redeem this place.  20 seconds infront of the Polar Bears and you too will realize how demoralizing this zoo can be.
author: Monica B.

description: Clean, well maintained, and a whole day's of entertainment. Animals seem happy and well taken care of. A lot of variety and definitely worth the price.
author: M K.

description:
Talk about being understaffed and underfunded. I appreciate the goals of the zoo but there needs to be some improvements.

I like:
1. Variety of exhibits.
2. Friendly staff members.

No good:
1. The place is being worn down.
2. It's not kept clean and I would think for a place like the zoo, this would be a priority.

Final Call:
I go once/twice a year just so I can support the zoo. It's great to enjoy nature's diversity but DANG, they've got to upgrade that place!
author: Chuck N.

description:
I have not visited the zoo yet for the normal entertainment values, but I do want to mention that we went to a wedding here the other day and it was fantastic. The Savannah was the background for the ceremony with plenty of animal activity - ostriches, a zebra, antelope, and some other exotic creatures. They had bars and snax in many places and zoo interns walking around with animals at a pettable range: a baby alligator, a gorgeous snake, a giant owl, ferret,  a hedgehog. 

The sit down dinner (their own caterer) was a very respectable salad, and bread, steak or polenta, and creme brulee. (Wedding DJs need to be spanked, though, why do they always insist on playing Me and Mrs Jones?) I digress..

If you have never fed a giraffe, it's worth the trip for that alone. None of the animals seemed depressed to me, actually they seemed pampered. Should wild animals be caged for viewing purposes? I believe the zoo's mission of bringing awareness to the public is a very good one.
author: Amy J.

description:
I had fun here seeing all the animals when I attended yesterday. The Zoo is set up fairly convenient and easily readable. Wish they had more animals but overall everything was cool. Only thing that bothered me were the food prices and annoying people (not the Zoo's fault). However they did have $1 hot dogs, it's just the long line turned me off.

I think it's cool how SF residents get to go for free on the first Wednesday of every new month, makes living in SF somewhat cheaper, haha.

Note, Children's Zoo is pretty annoying as well as the kids are freaking crazy, some scared, some mean, some just blah. Very family friendly and a great way to spend the morning in the city, 4 stars.
author: James D.

description: Ah, San Francisco Zoo, you are not the zoo you used to be.  Fortunately, my kids are too young to know that, and they are won over by the attractions/exhibits you DO still have left, like the train, the petting zoo, the carousel, and the wild cats.  I hope you can get your stuff together soon and win back my love.  Perhaps start by making the penguin area less stinky?  Then, maybe you could try to make the animals look a little less like they're wishing for death.  Just a thought....
author: Rebecca M.

description:
I don't enjoy zoos.  I don't know why I go.  I guess for birds, insects, reptiles, fish, whatever...it's okay to be in a tiny cage.  But I absolutely hate seeing some of the most beautiful and stunning creatures on this earth, trapped in a tiny little cement world.  It's disturbing.

I think the only happy animals we saw we're the river otters.  Hehe, they were so happy swimming and running around!!  I heart you!  Everything else made me depressed basically.  

Especially the Orkney Seal....OMG.  Someone should just  shoot him and put him out of his misery.  I wanted to cry when I saw the state of his enclosure.  It's a disgusting paintpeeling green pond, that he's basically the same size of.  He swims in circles and looks absolutely suicidal.  The outside area is about the size of my bedroom and nothing fancy about it.  Just looks like an old rundown shack.  (I hope they do some kind of show with him during morning hours when schools are around, at least maybe he has something to look forward too?  I however didn't see it.)

So here's the thing, obviously this zoo is in dire need of some funding.  It's in a horrible state.  So I can either say this...If you feel empathy for even the smallest creatures don't go to this zoo.  It'll only make you cry and hate being human.  But then I'd feel guilty about deterring anyone from visiting, because they obviously could use the support.

So in conclusion:
For kids I'm sure this zoo is amazing.  For any adults thinking about going...well, the choice is yours.  I'm not going to recommend or not recommend.  (But you've been warned.)
author: Mary R.

description: We have a family membership at the Oakland zoo that allows us to get 50% off of other zoos around the country, including the SF zoo. However, the lady at the ticket window insisted that we present membership cards for each person in our family in order to get the discount. We explained that it was a FAMILY membership (stated clearly on the card!) and that our children (4 and 18 mos.) were not issued cards, but she still refused to give us the discount. She also accused us of lying about our 18 month-old's age so we could get him in for free. We could not believe her rudeness and lack of customer service! We even explained what happened to the manager and he asked, "so... what is your problem?" !! really??! He didn't offer us any compensation or anything! The whole experience ruined the day for me. I don't think our family will ever go back.
author: Kathryn C.

description: Came here for their free admission for sf residents on the first Wednesday of each month. The zoo was surprisingly empty except maybe at the goat petting area. Most of the animals were asleep and there were random peacocks roaming the area throughout the zoo. The most eventful thing of the day was watching a hippo first take a deuce then turned around to consume some of it (o.O). Overall, I would not go out of my way to come here but yay for free admission. The exploratorium also has free admission on the first Wednesdays of each month so I will probably go there next time I have a chance.
author: Robert Y.

description:
All right, so the front of the Zoo is glorious. Rolling green hills full of animals that (play together), fake rock that's straight out of an amusement park, and gloriously free first Wednesdays.

But underneath that golden gilding lies a rotton core. If you wander deeper in, you see some pretty ugly things.

Tied for patheticism: a dirty, overly plucked peacock, dragging two broken feathers, running in between rhino and other African animal pens ...and.... the elephants, trapped alone and outside in tiny, cement pens with giant dropoff cliffs (without any "toys" or shrubbery), subject to tons of construction noise as well as the squeals of (the most stupid train ever) that circles an area of like 200 feet... and also tied with... penguin island, which is opaque with feces.

I may be a biologist, but I hate the zoo. Free is asking too much to see a bunch of unhappy animals. If you want to see some animals be happy, visit a goddamn park, or save up to visit Costa Rica or Africa. The only reason I didn't give this place one star is that it's slowly been improving over  the "ol' public". Maybe someday, *all* of the animals will play together (I'd personally like to see the tigers pimpin' about).

***1/2/2008 EDIT*** It seems that I got my wish, but the tiger pimped around just a bit too much. Maybe I'm an evil psychic or something...
author: T.Z. R.

description:
One of the saddest places on earth! 

Partner and I ventured over with a six year old nephew thinking that, in spite of our better judgment, this would entertain him. Lions and tigers and bears ... But my oh my. What a sorry, dirty, rundown, sad place the SF Zoo is. It's sadness wasn't lost on the six year old who found it weird and a little depressing. Believe me, he isn't the left coast offspring of an aging moon child. He's a meat eating red state-living Hulk fan who couldn't wait to see the gorillas. What he saw was a small group of very depressed looking apes, a few sleepy and obviously bored monkeys, a closed Rain Forest exhibit, an empty bear exhibit, a playground that is not only dated and small but dangerously out of repair and - ready for this - empty! 

My only caveat to the depression rant has to be the baby tigers. But who the hell wouldn't love to sit and watch three hilarious little cats romp around all day? You'd have to be a little dead inside not to smile at them. They're oblivious to the size of their miniature enclosure - for now.

What the SF Zoo does have is plenty of concessions, a very modern and well merchandised retail store (no surprise) and some terribly friendly (and I'm sure genuinely caring) staff. They get the star.
author: Steve J.

description:
The San Francisco Zoo is not what it used to be. Storybook Land, the petting zoo, the merry-go-round, the elephant keys to listen to a narration of each habitat and exhibit and the miniature steam train. All this and more was part of the experience of going to the SF Zoo. 

Families can barely afford to attend places like the SF Zoo, the cost is so expensive. And, there really is not a lot there for the fee. The zoo is not as clean as it used to be, etc.

Over 10 years ago there was a change in the zoo as it moved from being a city owned and operated facility to a privately funded and managed entity. Not sure if that was such a good idea. 

But perhaps it is the way the world is today...so much has changed. It is not the happy place it used to be. In fact, much of San Francisco is not the place it used to be. 

Play Land the amusement park at Ocean Beach is gone! Much of what developers did to Ocean Beach to fill in the loss of Play Land is not attractive. It looks so worn out and run down. Sad really!

The Cliff House is bland...not the grand attraction it used to be. And, again another place that is too expensive for average people to visit. 

Why the ruins at what used to be Sutro's are not restored to a natural habitat? I don't understand. Those stagnate pools have been there for decades. They look messy!

I often wonder what tourists think when they see that mess and so few really nice places to visit that are reasonably priced.
author: Jonathan F.

description:
We had been to the SF zoo many years ago, and we were really impressed with this trip compared to our last one.

We went this weekend.  The weather was great.. mid-60, and sunny.
All the animals were out.   
We got to see multiple feedings (cat's, giraffe, penguins, etc).

We have season passes to happy hallow and were also able to use those for a ticket discount here.
author: Andrew D.

description:
It's been soooo hot in San Jose and I have literally cooked at night.  I figured that for this labor day weekend, while I was not working, I would enjoy a cooler day while being outside.  San Francisco was the perfect choice.  i had never been to the zoo, and I did not feel like going to a movie.  Like Margaret said, "why does it cost more to see a movie then to go the zoo."  I agree!  I spent the most fantabulous, did I mention COOL, 5 hours at the zoo.  Strolling around slowly, taking in the beautiful scenery, I truly had a wonderful day.   Not sure, but I felt like I was walking in a dream.  When you first walk in...you see my favorite part-the African Safari area.  Tall giraffes walking slowly next to zebra's and ostriches.  How amazing and odd to see such a magnificent  sight in the city.    Other mentionable highlights were the sleeping lions, tigers, and a particular rhino-he knows who he is, who was particularly excited in an x-rated fashion.   I know it's nature, but it does not make it any less shocking.   

My second favorite part was the children's petting zoo.  I admit I wanted to stay away, however, it was the highlight of the afternoon.  It was funny to walk among goats roaming around.  I couldn't get over how fat they were. They have food machines scattered around the petting zoo, and you can pay to feed them.  I was a little scared, because some of the goats were ramming people for food.   One even came after my bag, but I pushed him away.  It was funny.  I loved the little donkeys, alpaca's, and steed.  Moreover, I liked the nature walk where I saw bunnies, turtles, and even a chinchilla-wow, fur was soft and it takes 150 of them to make a coat...how SAD!  Only downfall was that there were many "coming attractions," but I guess that makes me want to go back.


Parking was $6, and entry fee was $11.  They also have garlic fries, if you fancy.   Very worth the price, and ocean beach was right across the way. Tragically, I did not want to leave, but had to.  Yes, it maybe foggy and gloomy, but it just makes the ambiance of the zoo that much more comparable to a dream.
author: Flor D.

description:
I was really impressed with this zoo!

Keep in mind I come from a small crap hole town in FL that had 1 wildlife park that had goats and flamingos, oh and 1 Hippo that was most known for the way he blew his crap all over the crowd. 

I had been given passes to come here from my work to check it out since we are thinking of doing promotions for them in the future. I was stoked that my tickets were free, but would have been ok with paying the only $11 entrance fee!  You really can't beat that price!

I was really impressed with the new Grizzly Gulch and the fact that the Big Cat feeding's were back.  Make sure and mark the 2pm feeding on your things to do, cause it is worth seeing. 

Be patient with the parking it can be a challenge.
author: Alicia K.

description:
They treat the animals better than members. 

We will cancel our membership for a few reasons, but last night they had a "Night Tour 2006 Presented by Fidelity Investments" and it sucked so bad I was embarrassed to be there. My neighbor had encouraged us to become members four years ago as a place to go and walk around with the kiddie. He also said the member nights are great and you get to see night feedings. 

Well, we could have done other things on a Saturday night. Standing in lines all night for food, train, and tours was not my idea of "fun" at all. The train rides could have been one trip around instead of two to speed the line so people did not have to wait an hour for the train - and have kids breakdown in fits way past their bedtime. The worse part about the event was the bear feeding line got cut off right in front of me. She picked me because I was holding the line for the wife and kid and she eventually let me go ahead but the line never moved and I gave up. She was rude, the staff and volunteers were not happy to be there it was obvious. 

Everything was bottle-necked and the staff/volunteers did nothing to hurry the lines and all the members I was talking to were all complaining when their kids were out of earshot. Nobody wants to sound like the party-pooper but it was a joke. 

The lights they had strung through dark walkways never went on and kids were crying as they tripped on short fences. The workers just honked as they went by on their Cushman's and never bothered to help or get the generators going. 

The dancefloor was a great idea but with thousands of people and only enough room for twenty people on the dancefloor it was a horribly designed event. 

Outback was the food sponsor and - phttttt - the salad was soggy, the chicken was dry and way too peppered for kids, the meat was tender but with plastic cutlery it was impossible to cut. We joked around and pretended like we had to eat like the lions! They did not have anything for kids to eat unless they like rice and bread. Ooooh, and free water but no gift like promised:

http://secure.sfzoo.org/Registration/CalendarDetail.asp?ActivityKey=177531&OrgKey=1431

The members only up-charge dinner and tour package was a joke and the lines were too long. All we could say is that I hope it was worth it to them to frustrate members for one successful evening. 

Fidelity sponsored this and I would be concerned as a sponsor to have an event so poorly planned for the amount of people that reserved tickets and passes over a month ago. 

Plus, the polar bear always looks so sad and tells me he wants to go home. Seriously, the zoo is in poor shape compared to other big city zoos around the world we have visited. We are all for fundraisers and donate a lot locally to various museums and non-profits but when members get treated like this it makes you wonder why you became members in the first place... free passes, two $5 parking vouchers, a few train tickets, and members night? We just want to be valued as members at events or just one event, the vouchers and stuff does not matter.
author: James T.

description:
LAME! I spent $15 to get into the zoo. Many of the cages were empty, the ones that did have animals they were sleeping. I always feel bad for animals at the zoo tho. I enjoy seeing them but how would you feel if it was the other way around? You locked up in a cage and all the animals coming to see you. I know weird way to think of it. 

We did get to see the baby gorilla ...that was cute. 

I still think they should military in for free. San Diego zoo lets us in free. Its definitely not worth $15. 

I know the San Diego zoo is very nice and we shouldn't compare the SF zoo to it. I have been to the St. Louis zoo and it is one of the top zoo's along with SD and its free to everyone. I've also been to the zoo in Roswell, NM. Its small but still a very nice zoo...and its more open for the animals to roam.
author: John K.

description:
I went with the family and some friends to the zoo this weekend.  For young children, it's a great place for them to run around and see all the animals that are in their books.  We especially liked the Little Puffer train and the African savannah (probably because it was the newest part of the zoo). The carousel is also high on the list for my 3 yr old daughter.

We bought a family membership.  It's a good deal if you go 2-4 times a year.  They also give you two free parking passes, some ride passes for the train and a couple guest passes.  My only small complaint is that we thought it was a little stingy to even limit the number of parking passes and ride passes. It would seem to me that for a membership, they should be included as much as you go to the zoo.
author: Ed C.

description: for $15 there are so many to see :) the baby tiger is so cute! animals here seems happy! my baby loves it, will defiantly come back
author: Babybabe S.

description:
I just moved here from San Diego about 4 months ago.  I have been spoiled by having the SD Zoo and Wild Animal Park so close, so I do admit, my opinion is not unbiased.  If you have ever been to the SD Zoo, you will find that the SF Zoo doesn't even come close. 
Still, I had a nice time.  The park was clean, staff friendly and very helpful to a girl with a broken ankle.  I rented a motorized scooter for $25.00 which worked out great and gave me freedom to check out what I wanted.  It was a GREAT price, I would even be willing to pay $15.00 admission if I thought the extra money would go strictly to the animals.  Plenty of handicap parking which does cost $6.00.  
Overall, a nice outing for the day and I would return because the admission price is so cheap $11.00 and I like Giraffes.
author: Shauna C.

description:
I begged to visit this zoo to my friends & they all turned me down, because they all thought zoos are boring besides one friend of mine that I rather like going with.

transportation:
we could've drive, but we decided that its so much more less to just go by public transportation. If yall are in the bay area, I think it is fine to just take the nearby public transportation (if live by any) to get to the zoo, unless yall need to get to elsewhere afterwards far. 
I prefer public transportation, because it's just like an adventure, because there are just random things to see. (haha) for example, i've never rode on the muni/metro/electronic bus, or however you'd like to call it. (haha). & i found the little electronic bus kinda cute. the ride wasn't toooo long, depends on the bart station you get on the ride. i got on from embarcadero bart station. SO once you got off the bus at the last stop, it really only takes the walk of crossing the street to get to the zoo. & i prefer public transportation for those who would like to save some $ from parking at the zoo.

weather! : preparation!:
the day we went was pretty cold, around 65 degrees & its by the beach. I think the weather really influence the way of fun comes from the zoo. it was kinda crappy weather, and we were really hungry thru the whole trip (we went early), so EAT & PICK A GOOD WEATHER before going!
 
price:
the entrance price is 15 for normal admin. 
once we got in, there were employees who took pictures of us. so prepare !

environment:
we started our adventure in the zoo, hoping for a blast of excitement, but we both agreed that this zoo was pretty ghetto. (lol)
we didn't mind the animal smell too much because we were in the zoo..., just covered our noses with our clothes. (really stinky!)
really, don't expect too much. we all noticed that the animals were not very active (maybe because it was cold), & they were mostly single housed, we thought it was pretty lonely...for them.
animal types weren't too many. the overall environment should've be better if they take the time to trim prettier plans into a nicer pathway like a park. & the plants / housing for the animals were not too pretty.
there were little animals for petting, if you go at the right time for the "show".
foods were expensive....haha, but yall already expect that already. 
so overall, i feel that it is not the best zoo. don't need to visit again after one time. i did take lots of pictures of the animals that were available.
author: withgrapefruit y.

description: Went on a weekday with the boyfriend. Not crowded but the animals look depressed here. They need more animals and at least some shows.
author: Yvette N.

description: My first visit to the San Francisco Zoo. We had such a great time. My son who is 4 just loved the train ride. It was the best 4 dollar ride that I've spent in awhile. The train took us around the park 2 times at full steam ahead. I was amazed at how close you could get to the animals. We will be visiting the zoo again soon. That place is so big and so much to see.
author: Jessica S.

description: This is an cute place for an outing. Parking can be tricky, fortunately my friend and I  found a place on one of the side streets. BUT after coming back from Kenya and going to their Zoo/ Baby animal rescue center in Nairobi-- this place is just average. Where is the place for them to play? Wide open spaces? I mean, there is a jungle-- but it is a concrete one.  It was super pricey for watching animals in a crawl space....
author: Vicky T.

description:
I agree. This zoo IS depressing. All the animals look miserable in their confined spaces and I once again get that urge to break them out of their cages and yell at the top of my lungs, "BE FREEEEEEEEEE!"

Compared to the San Diego Zoo http://www.yelp.com/biz/san-diego-zoo-san-diego#hrid:ywFKqC0QvL9fKPhQLd7ziw, this zoo blows.
author: Pearl V.

description:
I grew up going to Como Zoo, where you didn't have to pay to get it, you just donated money at the end to go to the animals, and it had been a long time since I'd been to the SF zoon (as a child) when I headed over here a while back.

I loved the goat farm, and the cute little buggers who would practically knock you down to get the treats that they gave you to feed them.  I could have spent the entire day in the goat farm, and next time I go, I'll be brining more quarters for more snack for them.

The bird exhibit was interesting.  I really like the old architecture of the zoo, and appreciate them not changing much of it  over time.  The penquins are adorable - and I am looking forward to going back to see the buffalo and another exhibit which were being re-modeled.

It wasn't very busy the day I went, and I think people have to remember, that you get what you put into the zoo's near you, as they are non profits.  If you think it's so sad, then become a friend of the zoo - or try to help out instead of just complaining about it.  

The new giraffe habitate is amazing.
author: Samanta V.

description:
Recently went there with my grandma and sis..
I've got to say.. We don't end up seeing too many animals because my sister is 5 years old and she has an obsession with going on the carousel and Little Puffer about 30000000000 times.. hahah.. It is still a blast for the whole family because my grandma and I definitely enjoy going on Little Puffer too.. It is a little train that goes on tracks around a couple of areas where you can see bears, you go over a little bridge, pass by caribous, and chill.. It is great and really fun.. You get giddy like a little kid.. We always end up walking by all the bears, then the anteater (whom i must say is very cute), then the penguins, elephants, otters, rhinos, and lions,  then the giraffes, and back to the carousel. I have got to say, I am super impressed with the monkey area of the zoo.. They have A LOT of my favorite animal which definitely makes me happy.. I get excited when I see the tiiiiiny little monkeys in the walkway on the way to the gorillas.. They are sooo cute.

Definitely an awesome place to go, once in a while.. :)
author: Anna B.

description:
People judge by comparison, it's the only way to differentiate the good from the bad (and sometimes ugly)-that's why the SF Zoo gets such a bad rap. This is not the San Diego Zoo we're talking about here. This is an older zoo with left-overs from the 70's peeking out in spots near the newish other exhibits. The contrast, I think, makes the still vacant and yet to be landscape a bit of a disappointment. 

Notwithstanding, I still love the Lion House (ooh a trainer was mauled there recently, if you read the news-ouch) and the Giraffe area and a lot of the other little coves with critters that remind me of field trips there as a wee lass and visits with the fam on other occasions. 

The primates are a stand-out part of this zoo in need of a face-lift and they make for great entertainment as they people watch throughout the day. The petting zoo is also good fun as the goats all headbutt for more feeding pellets and the donkey kinda just stands there. 

It needs a bit of re-vamping but it's still a good zoo.This is a great place to visit and take the kids in the city.
author: Jessica D.

description:
The Zoo is a way good time.

Don't miss the tigers (Sumatran and Siverian varities), giraffes (tall variety) and meercats.  The newly landscaped exhibits are very attractive (haaay good lookin') and offer some up-close-and-personal views of exotic species.

There's still a lot of work to be done here, though.  Walking past some buildings from the 1940 construction (the "Pachyderm" house, anyone?) brings back some memories from way before I was born.  

Volunteer opportunites are so hot right now.  You can come to "Renew the Zoo" the second Saturday morning of every month... get dirty, see the zoo before it opens, get inside the exhibits.  Worth a try for sure.

The g/f also took pics of all the animal's butts.
author: Rob W.

description:
For my 100th review, I give you the S.F. Zoo!

Not my first time and hopefully won't be my last.  Wanted to take the kids here today before my membership expires this month.  Took LOTS of pictures and videos.  We had a great time for the most part (the exhibit housing the alligators was closed and my son was bummed.  The train ride line was too long and my daughter was bummed.)

Here are some helpful hints the next time you go:

1.  Don't buy the membership if you don't go often.  They have "free Wednesdays" the first Wednesday on each month.  However, I saw a sign stating that they are changing the policy.  Stay tuned.

2.  Get the carousel ride and train ride out of the way, if possible.  The train ride especially has a ridiculously long line, but worth the wait if you brave it in the afternoon.  Bonus tip for the carousel - tell them you will be standing and they won't charge you two bucks.  C'mon, don't be lazy.  The rides are for the kids people!

3.  BRING YOUR OWN FOOD!  That should be a given, but I thought I would say it anyway.  Men - suck it up and bring a backpack.  Some favorite snacks for you and the kids, your favorite drinks, napkins, wipes and an extra change of clothes for the kids are not that heavy.  Don't be a wuss!

4.  Family bathrooms - love them, especially when everyone has to go!  I only know about the one near the men's room by the playground area, but there has to be a few others in the zoo.

5.  Parking fee - what a scam!  Don't pay it when you get to the Guest Services office or ticket window.  Go to the parking lot before you leave to see if "security" is monitoring and if the exit bar is up or down.  If it's up, they aren't checking for the bar code ticket.  Happened today.  Saw security, but he walked off and the bar was up.  I could have saved $8.00!

6.  Check the website for events.  Fisher Price was there letting kids try out new toys and ride motorized vehicles (my son drove an Escalade and my daughter drove a Barbie Mustang).  That was a nice one hour distraction

Weather was foggy, but what were you expecting in S.F.?  The sun?  LOL!

Will be back again (when I'm free on the first Wednesday of every month)!
author: Mario P.

description:
I think the depressing part of a zoo is that their habitats are bigger than my apartment.  I know I'm supposed to feel badly for the animals, but my needs are a bit more immediate.  Not a sustainable attitude you say?  You're probably right, so could you get your SUV (Yes, I'm sure you got a great deal on it during GM's employee discount days) out my half of the parking spot?  

Did I mention that I'm a divorced father and I like to spend my kiddy days dragging my daughter around the zoo looking for divorcee moms.  I like to use her like my favorite spinning lure.  Sure she gets a little dizzy, but by the end of the day she's in a sugar coma with all the starchy foods at the Lemur Cafe and an extra round of dipping dots anyway.

Only the zoo can make for such fond memories.
author: Keith R.

description:
I had a great trip today.

Super cheap prices...less than 10 bucks. (i went in free w/group)

Petting zoo was fun! (i went with kids)
Prairie dogs were about and running.
Ducks were everywhere.
Lemurs and monkeys were active.
Penguins were about.
Ducks were everywhere
Giraffes were very active
Rhino was moving...
Duck were everywhere
Ostrich was right in front of us
Lions were zzzzzzzzzing...
Tigers, didn't eat me...yet one of them roared and paced back and forth.
Ducks were everywhere
The bears were there...and one of them was peeing....
peeing for a very long time...about 1 minute my whole group watched in amazement of its peeing ability and how big its bladder is!

I had a great day at the zoo.

Who cares if its small, what do you expect in a 7x7 mile city?
author: Steven C.

description:
I'd always found the zoo rather depressing, the monkeys always wholesome family fun, but depressing and dreary to say the least...
until there was some interesting revolutions....
apparently, as many of us know, a tiger escaped from its area, and attacked some people...
Quickly, the tigers actions were defended, because the tiger was being antagonized by certain people...
I say, good for the tiger...
However, according to police reports, when they FINALLY arrived, they entered the facility, and upon seeing the tiger, they gave the animal a direct order to "STOP".
Unfortunately, the tiger was not from here, so it did not understand english too well, so they shot it.
Why do i always miss the good stuff?
author: jonathan b.

description: Even though we went on a hot day, but it was still windy and overcast at the zoo because it's right next to the ocean! I don't know if it's just because it was chilly, or the animals were just lazy, but a lot of them seemed so lethargic and bored. But it was still very fun to walk around and look at everything. I feel like this zoo has better and newer facilities than the Oakland zoo, but still definitely not the best or the biggest zoo I've been to. If you like zoos like me, then definitely check it out!
author: Lulu S.

description: With not much else to do on a Saturday afternoon we ended up here. It's certainly a big zoo but where the hell were the elephants? I think I liked the children's zoo the best where I got to pet some things like a ferret, legless lizard and a hedge hog. Actually, the penguins were really cute and the exhibit was nice but the rest of the zoo was just okay.  The place just seems a little neglected in some areas.
author: Christina H.

description: Who doesn't like going to the zoo? I came here for my biology class field trip. The animals seemed sleepy during the times we visited. They must have stayed up all night partying. I still had fun at the zoo even though we had to complete our worksheet. My favorite part was seeing the penguins and giraffes. They are too cool. The food and drinks here can be pricey, but is expected for a park. Overall this place is fun for both kids and adults.
author: Tim N.

description: Love their little train!  All the animals seem really well cared for... rumoured to have a new playground there too - we are so lucky to live in San Francisco!
author: Dawn N.

description: Just a warning for those with small children.  Do not get hurt at SF Zoo. We had an accident today and the way they handle things  is a disgrace. Their First Sid Office is a joke. They brought us into a dirty, cluttered office. My grandson had a bad fall in one of the exhibits and they did not react at all.  We went into the Dinesour Maze thinking this was safe and fun and wham, came out with a bloody mouth missing a few teeth.  Yes, that is correct, ends up they had a zip line in there that was just oiled and he fell flat on his face. I am so upset, no manager, supervisor etc.   just watch out. I was told oh gee accidents happen here at the zoo everyday.  Oh really!  Great!  Not very settling to me.
author: Denise D.

description: Nice place to visit, lots of things to see, is not yet comparable to the great zoos, but has lots of fun things to do.
author: Silvia W.

description: Raped by orangutans. I fell into the enclosure. No one believes me. I still have nightmares about it...
author: Tom And Mary G.

description: Its really great to go to the San Francisco Zoo when you know that you dont have to pay for the admission fee on the first wednesday of the month... I used to remember coming here on my  field trips during my kindergarden school days, After for so many years that the San Francisco Zoo has been around... I still like to come here on my free time and to take a look at all the animals that they have at the San Francisco Zoo, the animals that. I enjoyed to look at the most is the Polar Bears because of the white fur that they have on there are other animals that I like to look at but my favorite would be the Polar Bears of course!!! Not only that this is a really a great place to bring your kids which I see all the time when coming to the San Francisco Zoo!!!
author: William B.

description:
Great place to take the fam to see the animals, just dont piss em off is all.
Respect the animals. Pretty big place, you might wanna take 2 trips to really see everything or hunker down and pack a lunch for an excursion to see it in one day. Pretty close to the beach so you can venture to there right after if you still have some energy. Nice place and a nice collection of animals on exhibit. I would renew my membership but I dont go there as often  since I dont live in the city anymore but Id say its worth getting a membership if you like the animalz.
author: Storm S.

description:
Just read through some of the reviews about the SF Zoo and am left wondering why people who don't want to see animals in cages go to the zoo?  

This has always been one of my favorite day trips with my kids.  We are fortunate to have 3 zoos so close to home, but this is the one we enjoy most.  There have been considerable improvements and upgrades over the last nine years that we have been regular visitors and noticed more construction under way on our visit this week.  My 2-year-old had a fantastic time on his most recent trip.  He loved the children's zoo, although he was a little nervous about animals out of their cages when we got to the petting zoo area and he was certain that the animals I was calling guinea pigs were in fact sheep, but other than that I would say this area was the highlight of his trip.  He also enjoyed watching the hippo come up out of the water to lay in the sun - what a sight!  His only disappointment was that he couldn't see dinosaurs at the zoo.

We took advantage of the first Wednesday of the month free admission day, were lucky enough to find street parking and packed our lunches ( a good idea on free day because the lines at the concession stands can be long), so the only money we spent was our $2 donation and a $2 carousel ride.  Pretty good value for a day trip in the Bay Area.
author: Maryanne R.

description:
Sad to admit that this place is only a 3-star.  Not that I've been to a 5-star zoo before, but there's only so much you can do at a zoo.  If 5 and 6 year olds were to Yelp this zoo, I'm sure they'd give this a much higher rating than the average rating it has now.

I have to say for one thing, this zoo is confusing to locate through.  Map or no map, once you get far enough into the zoo, it's going to be hard to find your way out.  It's a definitely maze.  The signs that are supposed to guide you around are either too broad or not in the right place.  Some of them contradict themselves.

Like any zoo, the animals are always a treat to see, especially if one enjoyed it as a kid and went to one after many years.  I know I've been to this zoo as a kid, but I don't remember any of it so I can't say for sure if it's been remodeled or not.  

It's no longer free for everyone the first Wednesday of every month.  It's for SF residents only.  However when my friends and I went yesterday, one of the guide gave us free tickets.  He was really nice, we even took a picture with him so we can remember him.
author: Anne N.

description: I really wanted to like it here. I tried to make the good outweigh the bad, but it just wasn't working. There were a few exhibits that were interesting, like the kangaroos and a few monkeys, but the majority of the animals looked like they had seen better days. Most of them were sleeping, or looked bored and/or sad. The gorillas, for instance, seemed like they were frowning and looked lonely. The polar bears had barely any space and just stared wearily upon the gawking crowd while the freaking loud ass train roared through. One of the otters kept swimming in frantic cricles crying out in miserable wails. Some of the enclosures just seriously looked too small. I hope the employees of the park pay more attention to the creatures and stimulate them. It breaks my heart to see them look miserable. We pay money because we expect them looking happy and healthy, running and playing. I really hope things get better there. I don't think I will be returning. This experience left a metaphorical bad taste in my mouth and made me wonder.. Are zoos bs?
author: Madi L.

description:
I've been to several zoos over the years and I'm sorry to say this one is by far the worst that I've seen. I can't believe as we arrived I was actually considering joining this zoo as I figured we might make it back a time or two before moving away in a couple months. We won't be back.

I don't know when the busy season is for a zoo but I figured the middle of July should find most if not all of the zoo open and the grounds well manicured and clean. I'd guess nearly half of the zoo was closed and the entire place seemed dirty.

Several exhibits appear to have been originally designed to have water between the guests and the animals but you can tell it's been many years since there was any water in there. And then there are the multitude of exhibits without any animals. Last time I checked the point of a zoo was to showcase animals. Where the hell are they?

The only cool things at this zoo are the carousel and the steam train. Both were better than expected. Other than that... meh. Even the churros were sub-par and the vendor didn't hesitate to tell us that they used to be better.
author: Gary T.

description:
I'm not opposed to zoos (at least the ones with conservation efforts). And I just went yesterday, so this isn't a review of a zoo from a year ago. 
All in all, the animals looked bored. How bout some animal enrichment zookeepers? 
Also, it's a small zoo-it might take maybe a half day to go through all the species-but that being said, I do enjoy the species they have there. 
Like I said,  a lot of the animals (hippos, tigers, etc) seemed bored. I would love to see the zoo expand some, but I'm sure there isn't really anywhere it could expand. 
It's a nice zoo, for a day trip. Or a half a day trip.
Also,I wish I could take away the screaming kids who run up and go under the railings and tap on the glass and are generally really bothersome to the animals. 
I did get to the see the Penguins being fed (which was awesome) and the polar bear (although taking a nap when I saw her) had three spaces! I thought that was pretty interesting. And I really liked their Outback section (first time seeing a kangaroo in my life!)

Overview: Small, but nice zoo. The smaller animals are enjoying it more than the larger ones, and it does need some upgrade, but it's not a bad zoo. Parking is expensive at 10 bucks.
author: Vince D.

description:
Lots of animals to see.I wonder what they are thinking when all these people are looking at them.

No poo was thrown at us.
author: Dani D.

description: I love the zoo =D I love animals and to see them in action is pretty cool.  Other than this place, I've only been to the Honolulu Zoo, Underwater World in Guam, and the San Francisco Bay Aquarium.  My favorite part of this zoo was the area where you get to hang out with the goats and sheep and be able to feed them.  The penguins were really fun to watch them swim and play too.  I actually enjoyed seeing all the animals here! Also makes me want a capybara!  I saw a lot of animals that I did not even know about, but they were really cool!  But my main concern was the polar bears.  The weather was getting warmer and towards the afternoon, the sun was shining down and the wind was gone and there was this one polar bear that kept walking back and forth while panting..... I felt so bad because it looked like it was loosing its mind =/ But it ended up going down to the pool and cooling off a little bit.  Anyway, I enjoyed it, the only thing that sucks was that when we got back to our car, someone door-dinged and wouldn't admit it; even though we parked all the way in the back corner giving whoever happens to park on the only parking beside us EXTRA EXTRA room. NICE JOB IN MESSING UP A SHOW CAR.
author: Kayla A.

description:
9/30/15 UPDATE - The zoo keeps getting better.  The rainforest exhibit is now open and a fun new addition.  

1/18/14 UPDATE - The zoo is GREATLY improved.  The new playground opened last November.  There are three separate areas, based on age group, and all the structures are made to look "natural".  There are more animals - a Rhino, hippopotamus, some sea lions and the Rain Forest building is now open.  The polar bear no longer had a "green" tinge to it's fur, and it might have been my imagination, but it seemed more content.  The former pachyderm building houses special exhibits.  There is still room for updates, but they have come a long way since my first review.  Our last visit had me feeling like it was a day well spent.  

*************

2/20/10 UPDATE - Just went to the zoo last weekend and it appears there is some progress on the "Renew the Zoo" campaign.  The back part was closed off and there was actual signs of construction on the South American Rain Forest building.  Hopefully I can raise my rating in the near future.  Of course Happy Hallow opens in a month, so who knows when we will be back.  

*************
Our beloved Happy Hallow is closed for renovation, so we decided to make the trek to San Francisco. It amazes me that a great city like San Francisco has such a mediocre zoo. Given the city and state budget crises, I doubt it will change any time soon. 

The Good - African exhibit, Australian walk about, Children's zoo, Grizzly Gulch.  The Carousel and Little Puffer train are a hit with kids. 

Just OK - the big cat and bear habitats seem to be lacking. The playground - yes, they have one, but the equipment looks like it is from the '70's. There is so much space it could be great. 

The bad - Lots of closed exhibits, empty, dilapidated enclosures, including the building that once housed the elephants. Depressing. Nonexistent signs and meandering trails. We went on the last Sunday of Christmas break, and the restroom off the the Leaping Lemur Cafe was closed, and the restroom in the front of the zoo was disastrous. Seems like poor planning. 

Bottom line - if you have children it is an OK afternoon.  If you don't have children, it is hardly  worth it.
author: Heather H.

description:
The highlight of our visit was the pair of grizzly bears who were quite active in finishing their mid-day meal.  We also enjoyed watching the penguins and monkeys.

Several exhibits were empty and others, such as the cage area for the big cats, a bit depressing.

Overall, this is an o.k. option if in the area, but we like the Oakland Zoo a bit better.
author: Richard A.

description:
This is an embarrassment to San Francisco. The website makes this look as good as San Diego or London or Taronga zoos - but its more like something you would find in the midwest.

+ves
+ free on the first Wednesday of every month if you are an SF resident
+ the koalas were very cute, and close enough you could see them
+ lions, tigers, gorillas and bears were in nice enclosures

-ves
- the Australian WalkAbout was disappointing - a few roos that was it
- half the sections were closed, the reptile village was closed, and it seemed every other animal was not there
- a very confusing layout, you had to track back to a lot of things just to see everything
- takes about 90 minutes to see the entire park, not a world class zoo which SF deserves
author: Joseph T.

description: I can tell you that the zoo is better than it was before. I like it before too but saw improvements. Good food and fun to go to with your kids.
author: C G.

description:
Fun diversion.  Went on a free day (1st Wed, SF residents only).  Saw some awesome grizzly interactions, but most animals were asleep  The Siamese tiger pen is depressing, esp as there is only one tiger left.  I think the savanna pen is neat (with giraffe).

I was really hungry but all the cafeteria food looked disgusting, so ended up not eating.

Highlights
+ Penguin
+ Tiger/lion cages
+ Bears
+ Giraffes
+ African aviary (very visceral experience- the birds can be very close and look slightly menacing)
+ Flamingo pond
+ Generally helpful information on animals, their diet and conservation trends.

Draw backs
- Food
- Lemurs (where were they!)
- Bald eagle marooned in the distance
- Aussie outback (everyone was sleeping)
- Multiple housing units were closed indefinitely for no reason.

Overall: If you're lukewarm on zoos, try to make a free day as opposed for paying the $12/$15 adult admission (cheaper for SF residents).  Ideal for parents with kids, school trips and zoo enthusiasts.
author: Jeff A.

description:
I only come here on free days (first Wednesdays of the month!), though I haven't visited for almost four years now. So sad about the tigers... 

One year, orangutans threw poo on my friend's shoes because he was being WAY too loud at their area. We heard a loud "pat pat pat" and "whooooom" ending with "SPLAT". It was quite funny actually... well... not so much for him.
author: Teresa Y.

description:
The usual animals, but It's better than expected.  

the zoo parking is too small, and when it's full they should put up  a sign...
they also need more sign around the zoon to point to different animals

Note:  starting 9/1 they are increasing the admission price
author: Coco L.

description: Nice place to go with kids....The Zoo always have different things....my son love going there ...
author: Delmy O.

description: SF zoo is a blast. Kids loved it. The gorillas were a riot, they were putting on a great show. Weather was cold, but that is classic SF.
author: Cat B.

description:
Went to the SF Zoo for my boyfriend's birthday this year. Neither of us had been since we were little, and it sounded like fun. It was on a Tuesday, and we had a GREAT time.

There were a few parents running around with very young children, but other than that, it sort of felt like we were the only ones there. In a good way.

I wish it were in a little better shape right now, a lot of exhibits are currently closed, but I'm still giving it a 5 because I had a wonderful time. Overpriced food (duh), but they also had a pretty good selection of decent beers available.

I'd recommend a weekday, but I loved my day there.
author: Jessica K.

description:
DEPRESSING. about a year ago they had the "grizzly experience" or something like that. it was supposed to be all about bears. there were probably four bears there and they were seperated. i hate it when animals are forced to be alone. they need friends too!! same goes for all of the other animals. give them buddies, geez!! 

the only reason why it gets two stars is for nostalgia. i used to LOVE the zoo. animals. pink popcorn. the playground. the children's zoo. petting animals. the elephant shaped zoo keys. lion feedings. the carousel. the giant fountain.
author: Regina C.

description:
Not bad, not bad.

I've always loved this place from the time I was a kid and up 'til now. I went here on Wednesday with a friend since it was free. I was able to get in easily but my friend - not so much. He had a Colma ID and forgot to renew it to change it to his SF address so he was turned away from the gate. BOOOO! So he did what he could.

He snuck in.

How? I have no idea. But when he told me he'd find a way to get into the zoo, I wondered how - until about twenty minutes later, he called me from inside the zoo. Apparently, he went James Bond on the gates and shimmied himself inside without anyone seeing him. That was awesome.

There were far too many places that were renovating their areas, so animals were missing. A lot of them looked sad and my heart went out to a lot of them inside their cages and such. I did come face to face with a lioness who stared at me unblinkingly as I took pictures. And then the bear who walked right up to the window where I was in and stared at me.

That was amazing.

But other than that, it was alright. I wish the animals didn't look as though they were suffering from depression. It doesn't make me feel too good walking around and seeing their sad little looks. :[
author: Thea G.

description:
We need a zoo but not this (never thought I'd see the Chronicle fold before our zoo).

I want lions chasing game the old fashioned way, not gnawing at bits of this-n-that behind plexiglass.  I want giraffes parading across golden Savannah skylines.  I want primates screeching in clucks and wheelings whenst I approach.  I want hippos bellowing out their territorial marks.

But here all I get are catcalls for churros and neon-green stuffy-play things.  If I wanted those I would go to Pier 39 and Rain Forest Cafe, respectively.

Here most of the animals (save the neurotic birds) just do what people do every Sunday.. just layabout waiting to be fed and all that jazz.  

But zoos are an important educational and cultural institution in the American rubric.  Please, support your local zoo with a nice matching donation from work, and for the cool stuff just go to youtube.
author: Jim W.

description:
I went to this zoo about a month ago, I'm not sure if they are doing construction work or something.. but this place looked as bad as landfill.
Not to mention this place had almost NO animals, and most of the exhibits were closed.. very disappointing
If you want to see a real zoo, go to the one in San Diego.
author: Eric C.

description: Adventure for the kids. My favorite part of this zoo is not only the exotic animals but the wonderful space provided. I've never had to fight for a glimpse of a bear or giraffe. Peacocks freely strut around uncaged. The grounds are vast, clean, and clearly mapped so I don't get too lost in the wild. Food is pricey and not worth half your wallet. So be sure to have lunch first or a large breakfast.
author: Charlene K.

description:
Before I had children, I could have happily lived my life without visiting another zoo.  As a child growing up in Southern California, spent many an obligatory weekend doing the whole San Diego Zoo/Sea World surf & turf animal show thing with out of town guests.  Watching animals pace around concrete cages never really wowed me.   But my kids love it and I can't deny them trips on the Little Puffer train though I do require them to be doused in Purell after we visit the farm animal petting zoo, which is actually really well done.

Being a Ferry Building regular, I am, however, spoiled by the huge variety of great, fresh and largely organic food available to those of us who live in the Bay Area.  So, the food options at the Zoo are horribly disappointing.  Eating at Leaping Lemur cafe isn't all that different from eating at a middle school cafeteria somewhere in the middle of America -- except no lids on drinks or straws (to protect animals).   Bring your own lunch and save the $25 you'd otherwise spend on cold fries and scary looking hot dogs and burgers.
author: Grace W.

description:
Took my daughter there this morning, and it ruined the rest of my day. Half the cages are empty, which I guess I could live with, but one literally had two feet of garbage piled in the corner. I'm sure at least one person working there is responsible for cleaning the place ... and that person should be fired.

The animals that weren't dead looked depressed. Tropical bird house was closed. Elephant house was boarded up like a crack house. If they aren't going to attempt to acquire another elephant, the least they could do is knock the building down and put up an overpriced food stand.

I'll now sum up this review in the most scientific terms possible: The place sucked ass. 

One star, but only because I tried no stars and it wouldn't let me.
author: L S.

description: I love zoos, but the SF zoo is so spread out that we were unable to see all the animals in one day. The animals are well taken care of and depending on what time you go, it is pretty neat to see the feedings.
author: S. A.

description:
Ah, the zoo.  One of those places that you want to explore but need a good excuse...like having a 4-year-old with you.  This weekend I finally got to take my niece here, and she loved it.  I had no idea what to expect here, size or quality-wise, but I was pretty impressed by both.  The african section in particular obviously had a lot of money poured into it.  I also wasn't really expecting the little one to last through the whole zoo, but amazingly she never got tired.  Her favorite part?  Probably the train ride.  It's nice how the train goes by the bears but otherwise it's kind of useless.  Why not have a train that loops around a big portion of the zoo, taking you to sweet vantage points you can't get to on foot?  Just an idea.

As for zoo politics, yeah, I'm not thrilled by these places either.  Especially because watching the animals on Planet Earth is about 10,000 times cooler, TV vs. real-life notwithstanding.  The captive breeding programs they have for endangered species are nice, but they don't really need a public zoo for that....or do they?  Maybe the admisison prices help fund it.  I don't know.

So unless you take the gravest possible exception to the existence of the zoo, definitely a cant-lose proposition for entertaining the kids.
author: Wes M.

description:
okay...  so Jess P. loves her some BEAH's!!!  So she organized a little sojourn to the lovely little zoo to see her MySpace friends in their new home.  I even gave up Bingo to go along.  Bingo!

First the trip out there was like traveling to another dimension.  Usually my trips to the parallel dimension require only a six pack and a closet size bathroom with all the lights off (don't ask).  This one only needed a long ass ride on the 5 and a transfer to the sketchy 18 (there was a mysterious substance on the windows and the driver liked her brakes a little bit too much - it was closely followed by one of Muni's new hybrid buses though so we totally got gipped on the cushy ride to the zoo) the driver knew we were looking for the zoo though and totally stopped in traffic to let us off since we missed our stop.  

It's a nice zoo, but it made me sad.  Seeing all the empty ghetto 1940's WPA era enclosures, with one forlorn looking polar bear who posed for a very opportune bear ass shot.  

Penguin Island was cute, but those birds have some foul breath making such a ruckus before they got fed, everytime they cocked their heads back and started cawwing an overwhelming stench would blanket the island and I got so nauseous.  Birds are foul (fowl) with their backwards legs and beaks and feathers.  It ain't right.  

I loved the monkeys and their riotous screams, swinging away... sitting down for a few minutes to pose for photos... no...  to poop.  Followed by a $9.75 snack of fries and chicken fingers at the Leaping Lemur.  Nothing like poop, fingers, and fries to get a girl in the mood eh?

Well that and the Little Puffer train was stalking us all afternoon.  Careful when you cross those tracks sister.
author: Ryan G.

description:
When I was little my dad use to take us to the zoo every other Saturday (my mom worked on Sat and the zoo kept us all from crying for her). 

I too have many fond memories (still have my zoo key). Yes the zoo needs improvement, especially since the latest tragedy. But it is still an important place to take your children to learn about the wildlife that is slowly disappearing. 

My heart goes out to the family of the young man who lost his life, but equally to Tatiana as her presence will be very much missed.
author: umeboshi l.

description: The zoo is great on free day.  it is nice that they have a petting zoo section so you can interact with some different animals.  Not sure I would pay full admission, or if I would go as a tourist, but it is a nice local trip.
author: Jonathan U.

description: One of the best zoos I've been to. Quite a few peacocks, however I like peacocks...soes it was alright.
author: Jennifer P.

description: This is a great urban zoo. Unlike the zoo on the other side of the Bay in Oakland, the animals seem to have a fair amount of room to move around here. There's a great range of exhibits and a several spots to stop and eat lunch. We've been member for 1.5 years and it's a great value for a family membership. My soon-to-be 3-year-old loves it here, and so do I!
author: Brian T.

description:
On the plus side, we liked the giraffe and penguin exhibits. The  animals seemed content, and had what seemed a reasonable habitat.

We found the conditions and appearance of the gorillas, the lions and tigers, the bears, and especially the polar bear and the anteater,  extremely depressing, and our baby daughter seemed to react badly to them as well. This model of displaying large animals is out of date now as it is recognized that keeping the animals in such constrained conditions is bad for them and not a hit with visitors. These  1940s-era habitats are inhumane, and the animals seem visibly miserable as a consequence. The anteater in particular was pacing neurotically in its tiny enclosure to such an extent it had worn a path in the grass. Does the zoo have any sort of animal welfare program? No obvious evidence for it, though you would certainly hope so. I noticed many of the older enclosures were closed off; is this a sign that they are trying to upgrade the animals' conditions? What is the rationale for having a waterfall in the lion's enclosure? So many questions, but no information on display and no staff around to ask.

In spite of the signs asking that visitors not disturb the animals, many visitors were doing just that, by shouting, tapping on glass etc, as the design of many of the displays allows them to do this. Considering  the high admission charge (the $8 parking fee in particular caused raised eyebrows), could they maybe think about hiring some staff to enforce this rule?

I am sure that they have good intentions and have the welfare of their animals at heart, so why do they keep their animals this way?

We also found the food selection unhealthy and expensive. We are vegetarians and the selection was limited. The kids' mac and cheese seemed to be missing the cheese.

Sorry to be so negative as I am sure these guys are trying their best, but it's been a very long time since I visited a zoo which left me so depressed and I wanted to share the feeling. I'd love to think I could come back in a year or two with my family and see happy animals and have a better experience. Alternatively they could donate the animals to a facility that will look after them properly and build some sort of theme park on the site instead. It couldn't be any worse than what we saw last weekend.

Oh, and they don't reply to emails either.
author: John M.

description:
Today, we went on yet another visit to the zoo. Our kids love going. I must say that every time we go the animals are very active . Today the Rhino was amazing watching how fast they run. He was playing with a ball in his area and it was just wonderful to watch.... 

The best part of today was watching the hippo play. The hippo kept getting out of the water running around and then jumping back in the water. It had all of the patrons amazed. 

We truly love the zoo, and have yet to have a disappointing visit.
author: Denisse P.

description:
For years I had heard how bad the SF zoo was. So I didn't go.
I discovered it with my mummy girlfriends and it rocks.
I have been so many times in the past few months that I can't even count them.
Every time we spend hours and we only see part of it.
The favorites of my one-year old are:
- The goats in the petting zoo
- The flamingos
- The grizzly bears
- The prairie dogs
- The playground
The annual membership is a great deal.
author: Elsa T.

description:
Way too many reviews here, but had to throw my two cents in...

This is a very sub-par zoo IMO.  I come from OK, home of the TULSA ZOO.  Which basically ROCKS!  Lot's of nice cool buildings/ exhibits to wonder through and learning along the way.  TONS of animals and lots of nature-y stuff. 

SF Zoo?  Not so much.  We went on Mother's Day Sunday about an hour and a half before they closed.  All the animals were sleeping!  No elephants!  How can a zoo be a zoo without ELEPHANTS!??! 

Also, the lay out of this zoo is NUTS!  It's a huge zoo, but with so few animals (and no elephants), it's just a glorified natural trail!

I doubt I'll be back here.  I just was not impressed.  My kid had a great time running helter-skelter throught the "streets" with his little buddy--so this place got 2 stars for making the munchkin happy.

Also, the employees at the front gate (who take your money), were like SO not into being there.  Can you say RUDE?!  Geez!  Where is your freakin' smile!  You work at a zoo!  If you hate your job, go work at the morgue!  Ugh.  I really cannot stand bad attitudes at  "kid places".  No one forced you to work here!  *sighs*  Okay, I feel better now.

I think we may try Oakland zoo next, but to be honest, I do not have high hopes.
author: Amber G.

description:
**This review is strictly for the Kettle Corn**

It is AMAZING. The BEST I have had except for this one vendor at a Farmer's Market in Seattle. The popcorn is freshly popped and then coated with a salt and sugar mixture to create that perfectly glazed crispy, crunchy shell. I come to get it when the Zoo has free admission (the first Weds of every month) and I get the Large bag....about $6? Well worth it and makes me happy for at least 3 hours..
author: Jessica h.

description:
I enjoyed the zoo when I went, but I think it was more because of the company I was in than the zoo itself. It was pricey for a zoo trip, but I did like that they offered a $2 discount to SF residents. Once of the few discounts we get living in this land of inflated cost of living! 

The animals are cool but the displays truly suck. There are very few signs saying what you're seeing or giving any kind of info on the animals.  

Also the place is difficult to navigate and the map they give you only makes it worse. They need way more signs and each sign should tell you what direction the exit is in. Most of the time we had no idea where we were. 

But the baby giraffe is worth all the hassle, she's sooooo cute!!! The gorillas are so human-acting its creepy. And we got to see an entire howler monkey grooming session, which was worth the price of admission.
author: Nissa A.

description:
WILD NIGHTS AT THE ZOO.  Yes, I slept  at the zoo. Me and about 30 others experienced feeding the giraffes (so cool) and being awakened by the roar of lions and saw the polar bears first thing in the morning. It was pretty fantastic. Would've been better if there were less kids and more adults so we could've gone off the beaten track a bit more. Although I understand that is you get a group of 30 of your own peeps, you can experience even more.  The tamarind (sp?) monkeys are my favorite! so cute - like a cross b/w a cat and a monkey.

update: JAN 6, 2008.... Feeling pretty lucky we weren't there on "harassed tiger night" -- definitely a sad damper to the experience. DON"T TAUNT THE TIGER!!!
author: Victoria Z.

description:
I came here on a free first weds of the month!! GYEAH!

Came here for a biology project, had to draw the animals and write their kingdom and stuff.

When I went, we watched the small monkeys.  I thought they were cute.  Not until one bent over, another came behind it, and rammed them in the butt. =O
author: Michelle N.

description:
We live about 7 blocks away, so we end up here about twice a month with our toddler.
Some favorite attractions include the new addition, Henry the hippo, the flamingos, the anteaters with accompanying baby, and the leaping lemurs.  
Try to get there early, as the crowds usually arrive around noon, but from 10 AM to 12 Noon things are generally pretty relaxed.
author: Leo S.

description:
This review only gets a second star because I'm from the bay area, and I feel the need to show some loyalty, but yes, this zoo has never been stellar.
 
 I hadn't been here for over 10 years, and decided to go yesterday with my boyfriend, but we were both very disappointed by the lack of open exhibits and enclosures ("This exhibit is closed for maintenance. Sorry for the inconvenience" was a common sight to see), and some of the enclosures were very run down looking, and yes, the animals seemed to be in suspended sedentary mode and most were lying around looking depressed and lifeless. 
 
 I was thinking how embarrassing it is for San Francisco to have such a bad zoo.

 San Francisco, you really need to get your act together, and do something about the zoo--are you reading this?

 P.S. We hope the wounded prairie dog we saw received some attention, and that the salamander-loving docent told someone about it.
author: Inga G.

description:
This is probably one of the top 5 things to see if you have someone from a foreign country visiting you.

-Gorillas walking around
-Lions and tigers eating
-A Bald Eagle
-Kangaroos

Slightly illegal story:
My company has a an office in Bombay and we often have 1-2 of the team from that office in San Francisco for team building, etc. I took them to the ZOO (I love that place and will take any excuse to go see Lions chewing on a 15lb steak) and we saw all the exhibits Lions, Monkeys, etc. and we make out way to the Rhino exhibit...the gate to the Rhinos wast unlocked! Long story short we ended up patting one Rhino and getting charged by another.
author: Isaac N.

description:
OK, no Elephants. Baby Elephants are cute.

So I am going to sound like a total grouch but Zoos should be tranquil. 

But it is FULL of LOUD children. Now I understand it is one of the places to take kids but it gave me an idea of having an evening at the zoo for grown folks!
author: Marcus R.

description:
I've been to quite a few zoos and I think the San Francisco Zoo meets expectations. It unfortunately does not beat expectations.

For the most part it is clean and the upgrades keep on coming. My favorite exhibit has got to be the meerkats just cause they are so cute. The African Safari upfront is great at letting you get in the middle of all the animals' business.

The gift shop is very very nice (though a bit pricey)
author: Allen B.

description:
My family visited SF Zoo free on Family Appreciation Day.  This was the first time I visit the zoo so did my kids.  My husband returned after 40 years.  Therefore, we were so excited for this family trip.

First of all, the management was a little bit messy.  The workers (including the volunteers) did not really organized before the zoo opened.  Some procedures were not well-communicated; some asked for the visitors' ID to make sure that they are living in SF to meet the requirement of free admission on Family Appreciation Day; some workers just handed out the bands; some asked us to wait in line and some really wanted to let us go; someone gave us a map and another worker wanted to take it back....

My husband really wanted to get an annual pass for the family but I asked him to hold it after the visit to make sure that we would plan to come back again in the year...and this was a right decision...

First of all, the admission fee is $15 per person, $12 if you are living in SF, children under 3 years old free.  For a family of 2 adults and 2 kids under 3, each visit costs $24.  If we join the basic membership of $80, we would need to visit the zoo at least 3.3 times to make it worth.

Secondly, some of the exhibits were missing or the cages were under construction.  It's really disappointed that we could not find the hipo which is the favorite of my 2 little one.

Thirdly, a ride on the train for $4 and horse seat for $2 each person is really not cheap in the current economic situation.
