Fourthly, insufficiency of signages and maps really made it so frustrated to walk fro and back to find where our targeted animals were.

Last but not least, many of the attractions or shows such as the animal farms were either not opened or closed when we were there.

Finally, I told my husband that our official visit to SF Zoo would possibly the Family Appreciation Day in 2010.  Our kids are just too small to feel excited to see the animals.  They just want to go home and take a nap after a trip of 2 hours.
author: Roserrele W.

description: This place is better than its reputation would indicate.  If you're coming from San Diego or DC, of course it will seem like a pale shade.  I grew up in a small sized city, and I'm totally impressed with what they've done.  My kids (2 and 5) absolutely LOVE this place.  Every time we go we've discovered something new, and we've been members for almost 3 years!
author: Alexander S.

description:
Umm, 3.5 stars.

So far the last summer of my life (I'm not dying, I just have to get me a 9 to 5 job real-real soon, same thing though right?) has consisted of many voluntary days of taking my pre-teen/teen cousins to various youth-friendly places all around NorCal. I'm telling you I should charge their parents and run my own summer day-camp.

After packing two cars full of kids we took them here and honestly... they were most excited when one giraffe tried to mount another. I could barely get them out of the African savana area. 

Imagine 7 kids plus your 24 year-old-fiance giggling to the sight of 16 foot tall animals trying to get it on.

THAT WAS MY DAY AT THE SF ZOO.

P.S. Don't eat here, the food is terrrrrrrrrrrrible!
author: kate r.

description:
I'm not going to lie, as far as zoos go, this is pretty lacking. For one, all the animals look like they're just lying around drugged. Secondly, the zoo is very run down, and a fifth of the exhibits seem to be under construction. My friend and I couldn't go to several places because they were closed due to construction.

Next, there were a lot of empty cages/pool areas. The place looked very run down.

Highlights of the place include the cute koalas, lions, tigers and penguins. The kangaroo pen smelled awful (I know, wildlife poop). Beware also of the random poop scattered along the trails/pathways you walk on. 

I think as a child I would find this place more magical but as an adult, it's hard to look past the lack of animal variety, the closed exhibits, and the general rundown feel.
author: Katherine P.

description:
If I had known that the parking was $6 and exiting the premises (automatic parking stop bar?) without having to payI would've saved money. But whatever. (one star knocked off)


 My family, my boyfriend, my boyfriend's sister and I waited in line for 15-20 minutes to pay $11 for admission feehere are the results of the zoo.


 Overall, the animals looked unhappy. I felt bad for some of those animals. A majority of the animals didn't have someone to play, eat, sleep with, etc. Where are the zookeepers and staff to make sure that the animals are being fed and their spaces were kept clean?! Shame on you.


 A lot of kids running around and the parents weren't keeping an eye on them, but taking plenty of pictures of animals. Sadparents, what's wrong with you?! But I don't blame the zoo itselfit's the parents. Tsk tsk


 Food pricespretty hefty if I say so myself. For a burrito it costs $8!! Portion wasn't even that huge. Burgers were small and good enough to eat for a kid but for adultsyou might want to order another. Good thing we ended up bringing little snacks to munch on. So we saved money on our part.


 Overallwe still enjoyed ourselves. Got the chance to see penguins, lions, tigers, bears.but I didn't see a panda. That was suppose to be the highlight, but they didn't have any. =(
author: Fraulein C.

description:
Visited yesterday after around two decades and NOT IMPRESSED. This place opened in 1929 and it looks like nothing has changed much since that year. The grounds are very un-kept, dead grass and weeds everywhere. The exhibits/enclosures are prehistoric and ugly for the viewer as well as the animals. It's all too spread out also. 

Most of the animals don't look very happy, and they are missing a lot of key animals like pandas, tigers, elephants... I mean they had an okay amount of different animals but it could have been more. 

It really looks like a bomb hit this place, I can see this place closing it's doors for good in the near future. If they want to avoid that they need to do an immediate full-renovation of everything. I really don't think San Francisco is an ideal place for a zoo anyway, especially in this part of the city- too cold.
author: E. R.

description:
I held my wedding at the zoo a few weeks ago and couldn't have had a more perfect, fun experience.  Carol with catering and Laney with events bookings were amazing through the whole process.  The ceremony outdoors at the African Savanna was memorable for everyone and the reception in the Great Hall was beautiful.  The catering staff were super professional and went above and beyond in making us and our guests feel welcomed.

I highly recommend to anyone looking to have a unique, special wedding without totally breaking the bank.
author: Lauren P.

description:
Going to the zoo on Thanksgiving is curious.  It's mostly filled, on this day, with people who aren't worried about eating turkey.  Or my family, and my two nephews who love it here, with our turkey waiting at home.

The meerkats are always satisfying, sitting up like little statues or sunning their tummies.  Prairie dogs are also great.  I like the raptors - hawks and eagles. Nephews like the rain forest, and especially the insect house, filled with tarantulas and beetles.  The new grizzly bear exhibit is great; the bears have room, grass, and their own pond, and seem far happier than their polar neighbors.

There's also a small steam train that does a loop.  Several cafes with adequate food.  At the holidays, four reindeer in a pen, and a skating rink.  It's not an amazing zoo, but a clean and manageable one, and very reasonably priced at $6.
author: Amy L.

description:
Maybe it was the weather or the fact that I am pmsing, but this place made me deeply sad.  It looks terribly depressing.  Many of the cages look too small for the animals, little to none landscaping, lots of empty/under construction areas.  
The best part of the day? Little Puffer - the bonsai train ride.
author: Mrs. G.

description:
A zoo is what it is.  Caged animals.  People looking at caged animals, and people having to pay to watch caged animals in an environment that no matter how hard they try to make it like their natural habitats, are not.

eh.

It's fun to take my nephew because I want him to see animals, but then what am I teaching him exactly?  Hm...
author: jen a.

description:
On my 4-day first independent trip to San Francisco, my friends and I decided to go to the zoo. We were really excited, especially because we had a coupon. Seriously, coupons make EVERYTHING more exciting. Our bus ride there was LONG, we missed our stop and it was a foggy day. 

The zoo itself was nice when you first stepped in. The giraffes, zebras and bird-that-looked-like-an-old-man were the first animals you see when you get in. They were playing on pretty green grass and everything looked so nice and happy. But as you made your way to the bears, tigers and rhinos..it just got sad and depressing. 

I would give it a 2, but I don't remember my 2nd grade field trip to the LA Zoo, so I can't say I've had a better experience. On the brightside, they serve beer and almost everything in the gift shop is cheap!

PS. how did that boy get attacked by the tiger? Seriously, that's a pretty wide ditch for the tiger to jump.
author: Chynna Y.

description:
My husband and I got married this past May in the San Francisco Zoo, and we were thrilled we chose it as our venue.  The zoo was beautiful, cooperative, and well-organized throughout the process.
 From the start, the zoo was helpful, working with us to schedule our big day appropriately.  Originally we had looked at an April wedding, but despite having openings that month, they advised us to wait until May for better weather.  As planning continued, the zoo made things easy on us. For example, they took care of the catering, tables, linens, and open bar.  This made them almost a one-stop-shop and made our lives that much easier.  They offered us a wide menu of food options, and worked with us to set up a buffet for our guests (per our request) after inviting us to taste some of their entrees.  About a month prior to the wedding, the zoo coordinator worked with us to get our photographers, florist, and day-of planners into the zoo so they could look over the reception hall, venue, and even much of the zoo for photography planning purposes.  The zoo coordinated with us as we made our own tickets for our guests (the zoo allows free access to wedding party members), but with our vouchers guests were also allowed to enter into the zoo early for a reduced price if they wanted to see some animals.  Overall, despite it being a wedding, the zoo made the process as smooth and easy as you can imagine.
 Since the wedding was to occur after the zoo closed, our coordinator worked with us to take pictures prior to the ceremony.  Thus, we and the wedding party were able to take photos in front of our favorite animals including lemurs, pelicans, and bears.  The zoo also cooperated with us to get photographs on the carousel and their little train.  They ultimately let us take as many pictures as possible before the ceremony, giving us only the problem of sorting through them all! 
 The wedding venue itself was the area situated in the African Savannah exhibit.  Guests must transit through one of two tunnels to get there, allowing for the bride to stay concealed until the start of the ceremony, but also surrounding our guests with a variety of animals including giraffes, zebras, ostriches, and Marabou storks among others.  For animal lovers like us, this gave the wedding a great exotic/wild feeling to it, and also made for some excellent photo opportunities.  For planning purposes, the savannah seating area fits around one-hundred guests.  While this was our desired wedding size, it could limit you if you are looking to have more guests.
 Following the wedding, we treated our guests to a giraffe feeding and five animal encounters.  The giraffe feeding brings the wedding party, and subsequently guests, into the giraffe house to pet and then feed them bananas and leaves.  None of us had ever pet or fed a giraffe before, so it made for a fun and memorable experience. 
Meanwhile, since only about twenty-five guests can fit in the giraffe house at once, the rest of our guests enjoyed cocktail hour with drinks, hors d oeuvres, and the five encounters.  For the encounters, the zoo has animal trainers bring out five animals (the zoo gave us a list of about twelve animals that were typically available, but realize that sometimes trainers are not on hand or animals could be sick so there may be last minute changes) for our guests to pet, examine, and learn about.  We chose the golden eagle, a hedgehog, an alligator, an opossum, and an owl.  As with the giraffe feeding, it made for a memorable and fun experience for both ourselves and our guests, and it also allowed us to have unfettered time to take photographs after the ceremony. 
Finally, the Great Hall made for an excellent location for our reception.  With its large fireplace and high ceilings, it made for a grand but homey setting for our celebration.  The buffet was well organized in the back, and we had plenty of room for 100 guests, our sweetheart table, food, cakes, and our DJ, with plenty of room to dance as well.  Also, despite the high ceiling, the sound quality in the room was excellent.  Outside of the hall was a lobby area where the open bar was located along with our photo booth, which provided enough room for our guests during cocktail hour.  Just past the lobby was the dressing room for the bride, allowing everything to be centralized but still appropriately separated.  
If you are animal lovers looking for a memorable wedding, the San Francisco Zoo is for you.  It offers great views and memorable experiences while accommodating your wedding's logistics.  As an added bonus, you can be happy that the proceeds from your ceremony will go to help the zoo's animals.
author: Kate S.

description: How funny that people give bad ratings to a zoo for the animals appearing bored or not being entertaining enough. Huh? Very strange. Animals are not necessarily going to perform just because you're looking at them. My husband and I took a trip to the zoo recently. We love zoos. We were probably one of the few adult, childless couples there that day, but who cares. Zoos aren't just for kids. I had never been to the SF zoo either so I was pumped. We ended up having a really good time. The admission price is very reasonable, the zoo is laid out well, and there is a lot to see. My favorite exhibits were the meerkats/prarie dogs in the little kid area and the grizzly bears. All of the animals were cute and seemed well cared for. My only small issue and why I bumped down a star is because some of the signage and displays were a little confusing or difficult to read. I think if they put a fresh coat of paint on the place it would really shine. Even so, I think it's a very nice zoo and I will definitely be back. I suggest a visit if you're in the area!
author: Hylary L.

description:
Ah my day at the zoo with three rambunctious kids all under the age of ten..the zoo is the not my number one choice to take kids but they all wanted to go.somehow my niece and nephews enjoyed the whole day running around and looking at the animals. They especially enjoyed the petting zoo. Lots of goats, horses and sheep running around and you can buy the food for a mere quarter...That the cheapest thing you'll get here at the zoo cuz everything else is way overpriced.. How could three sodas and two churros cost fifteen bucks? Highway robbery..

Some of the animals look really sad. The seal especially looks real bad.  The area is too small and just depressing.. Maybe they should just release the Seal into the ocean...  The poor hippos looked cramped. that pool ain't big enough for one not alone two... 

For the animals sake, the zoo just needs to improve....
author: Trish P.

description: I normally love going to the zoo but today it was just not the same. maybe it's just the off season, but a lot of the animals seem to be missing? where did the hippos go? what about the lorikeets? I loved feeding the lorikeets. also I think I've been spoiled now that I've seen the san diego zoo. san francisco is so progressive in a lot of other ways, but the zoo still seems to be in the early 20th century. get some bigger enclosures for your animals, guys!
author: M.E. W.

description:
I went last December with my boyfriend to see the Reindeer Romp exhibit. Other than that visit, I haven't been since I was a kid. I have to say, the zoo was just okay. I don't know what it was, maybe it was because it was cold, but all the animals seemed...sad. The best part were the lions that were still in their cages and we got pretty close to them. Still, they were sad...just pacing back and forth again and again. The giraffe and zebra exhibit is the biggest and we were able to sit and watch them for a little bit. The bird exhibit was closed, but I didn't mind since I'm not a bird fan. The food...was horrible. The best part was the coffee since it was so cold.

Alright - for the Reindeer Romp, the whole reason we really went. It wasn't anything more than what looked like a large petting zoo. It was a temporary enclosure with a few reindeer and hay. That's it.

I'd like to go again when it's warmer - hopefully that's when animals perk up and are more active. I don't know if there are bears now, but there weren't any when I was there. I didn't feel like there were many animals at all actually. We saw the whole zoo in maybe 2 hours.

If you can go on a free Wednesday and on a warmer day, that's the day I suggest you go. Even on a regular day, I think it's only like $11/person, which isn't bad at all, but there really isn't much to see or do.
author: Caroline I.

description:
The San Francisco Zoo is perfect in terms of size.  It takes a good couple of hours to walk the whole thing, and you feel like you've gotten your money's worth when you're done.  It's not too small, and it's not too big.  Just as I started feeling tired, I had seen everything there was to see.

Ethical objections aside, the animals are cute and fun to watch, especially the penguins.  I also enjoyed petting grumpy goats at the petting zoo.

There isn't much of a selection as far as food is concerned.  You better eat before you come or plan to spend a ridiculous amount of money on greasy food that is terrible for you.  Also, apparently straws and lids are a hazard for animals, so if you get an Icee be prepared to eat it with a spoon.  I found this method to be surprisingly enjoyable though!  And hey, why not for the sake of the adorable animals?  It's nice that the staff at least cares about them not choking on plastic while they're in small quarters away from their natural habitats.
author: Laura W.

description: Who knew that an event at the San Francisco Zoo could be host to a fantastic party!  We had a school function in the Lemur Cafe over the past weekend.  We had 47 adults in the Lemur Cafe for an amazing experience.  We overlooked the primate area where we watched the monkey read the newspaper!  The staff was very accommodating.  The beverages and snacks were presented well and very tasty.  We ended our event with an animal encounter where two zookkeepers brought in a baby alligator and hedgehog.  The zookkeepers were so knowledgeable about their animals.  We all left feeling quite impressed with the San Francisco Zoo.  If you want to host a unique experience, I highly recommend this venue for your next event!  Don't forget to visit the little puffer train.  The conductor is a blast to talk to!
author: Karen G.

description: I am 48 Years old and my wife is 46, we were born an raised in San Francisco, we have three children of the years 26, 15 and 6. We took my younger daughter to the Zoo on 6/27/10 and were disappointed.  My wife took the children there last year and she noticed much has changed.  We first noticed that the admission fare has increased, secondly it seems that there are no more kiosk for food and everything has been centralized to the 3 or 4 Cafes, which are over-priced.  I always thought of the Zoo as an affordable outing, now it seems to be operated with a Corporate attitude, so sad.
author: James Boris P.

description:
This is the worst zoo I have ever been too! First be sure and ask to pay for parking when you buy your tickets. You need a special $8 parking ticket to get out the parking lot and they dont tell you this. They also refused to take my AAA card which they advertised as getting in a child free. She said she couldnt tell if it was an old card or not. Its not and the guy who towed my car a few months ago and hotels take the same card all the time. 

Half the exhibits are empty and over grown. Half the trails and walkways are closed. What few cats they had, were in an awful area that my kids deemed "Zoo Jail". 

They had a nice Lemur area the kids liked. But the info cards all over the zoo were all about Bushmeat and the awful places the animals were from instead of giving us facts about the animal. It was good information, but did my 5yr old need to seem a truck full of dead monkeys displayed at his height at the monkey house? Ummm, no.

Other than what appeared to be an armed guard in the cat house/Zoo Jail, I only saw one other employee at the zoo after were inside. The zoo closed at 4pm, the kids area at 3:30. We will not be back. It was awful.

Two good things: The giraffe exhibit was neat, you go thru a tunnel and end up kind of in the middle. And the Grizzly Bear sisters area was very nice. The bears were very active and happy.
author: amber a.

description:
One of San Francisco's bigger tourist and local attractions, the SF Zoo has a lot of exhibits missing for their consistent price of $12 per adult.  It isn't the cleanest zoo, but it is one of the most complete in Northern California.

Aside from aggressive seagulls that may aim for your delicious churro, the zoo is very secure and safe for your children.  So far, only the peacocks run loose and roam freely, but they are perfectly harmless.

I visited the zoo just last March of 2006.  As I recall, there should have been elephants and camels, but I saw none.  The exhibit location where they used to be was entirely empty.

The African exhibit is always naturally exciting simply because we don't see those animals anywhere else in the world.  That's where they put the giraffes, kudu, ostrich, and waterbuck.  Of course, for anyone that has gone on an actual safari, this exhibit is small potatoes.  It would be nice if they had warthogs to insipre the kids who so always love Pumba from The Lion King.

This zoo also features a primate house and diverse aviary.  There's also an insect and probably reptile house (none are of my taste, so I didn't bother to confirm a reptile exhibit).  For those who love the Australian Outback, there is a small walk and field of kangaroos and wallaby's that will definitely contribute to capturing a cute romantic moment.

One of the very interesting exhibits is the Meerkat burrows.  You can peer into the rocky walls through the built in windows and observe the meerkats that are sleeping or working indoors.  However, there is one healthy precaution to note:  people  (kids especially) spread germs easily and to look through these windows, you have to get up close to almost touching the window with your eyes so close to it.  Spare yourself the pink eye and bring a travel pack of sanitary wipes to clean the surface before peeking.

Going at 1-2pm is probably not the best time since most animals were sleeping.  Only the black bears were active that day among the mammals.  Either they all just eaten, or many were also just being fed and thus difficult to see.  To find the best time, call in to check on feeding times and exhibit activity schedules.

Kids can also purchase keys, for a price, in which they can put into machines to listen to exhibit information.

Eat before you go.  It is best to not have to purchase expensive lunches with aggressive seagulls circling like vultures over your french fries.
author: Gregory F.

description:
If I do not like the SF Zoo maybe the zoo is just not my thing. Here is what I didn't like.

1. Entrance Fee $11 (adults)
2. Parking Fee $6
3. Cheeseburger, 2 chicken strips, fries, & a soda $15
4. Miniature Train Ride $3 (adults)
5. Except for the grizzly and polar bears, the large animals being kept against their will were refusing to perform the standard song and dance. And they are getting better health care them most of us.
6. Trying to find our way to the exit for an hour. This place does not have enough "YOU ARE HERE!" signs. F the little free map, I needed a GPS today, it was like a labyrinth fulled with animals.

The only time I'm coming back here is when my son is old enough to ask me because he wants to see the animals.
author: Bebe L.

description:
I'm on the fence when it comes to Zoos in general, but I thought I would comment on our SF Zoo...

gone are the days of the Zebra tram and the plastic elephant Zoo Keys.  Gone are the days of happy animals-or so I thought when I was a little girl.  These animals are always so tired and depressed looking and their exhibits are far too small.  They have polar bears, who are used to sub zero temps, sweating bullets  in their sad, sad exhibit, and lions and tigers freezing in the sunset fog.   The Oakland Zoo is a little better, though, with large exhibits and expansive foliage for the animals.
author: Michelle R.

description:
how to put this:
It's like Disneyland, on the off season, times eight... And much much sadder...

see, Either everything's closed, broken, being worked on, or 'coming soon'...

I haven't been to this zoo in almost over a decade, and the last time I ever been to the zoo was the one in Honolulu, which was pretty nice.
Walking into the SF Zoo, it looks like you're walking into something good. Nice clean building, the gift shop looks nice and new with lots of stuff to buy, and overall, you set your expectations on a high bar.
Right?

Wrong.
After a brief walk around on the right side of the park, we walked around the other parts of the zoo, and it went downhill from there.

to be honest, The rest of the zoo looked like those run-down rip-off theme parks in Japan or something where everything is fading.
That, plus many construction walls.

also, The pre-fabricated food (in some locations) is sub-par (but pricier) than high school meals...

All this talk, and I didn't even mention the animals.
honestly: What animals?
There's several areas where it's empty, despite that it could very well hold an animal or two. Then there's the areas that does have an animal or two, and that's all. Only a handful had a lot of animals to see.
Probably the only good thing from the place was the petting zoo, full of many farm animals roaming the lot. (just watch where you step)

I could go on and on, like the only reason my visit was enjoyable is because I had some buddies joking around when I was there, but I'll mention why 2 stars:
This zoo needs as much help as it could get.
Go ahead and arrange to bring the whole family to go one day. Eat inside the zoo, ride the train or carousel, or both, or twice! Go ahead and buy a souvenir or two...
Donate!

With all the construction going on now and more dollars going in, I'm sure your future visit will be even better.
But if your family does go for a visit any time of the year, especially with children, I'm sure you'll have fun anyways...

(nymo's top tip: take the muni to the zoo! at the ticket counter, just show your receipt/transfer or monthly pass, and you'll get $1 off your ticket price! save $9 since parking is $8! now with that extra cash, you can spend that in the zoo and probably donate it! uh, you will do that, right?)
author: Nicolo T.

description: If you want to spend a day walking around looking at sad animals put in cages way too small for them, probably step in a large pile of poop AND be disgusted by the conditions... then the S.F. zoo is your place!! Living in such a wonderful, forward thinking city I expected a lot more. I will never return.
author: Dyanna C.

description: If you are a sf resident and are available on a wed., you get in for free. I love the perks that sf has to offer.
author: James S.

description: Love the zoo!! Miss the lion feedings and the elephants hope they bring them back as soon as they can!
author: Nina P.

description:
They are finally making improvements to the place better known as the last stop for animals before heading off to their resting place.

Before, it used to be completely tragic, but now there is a little light at the end of this animal cage.  The safari makes up for almost all the other areas of this amusement-less place.  

Empty pens, or signs reading "Bobo has moved away", or "Ginger was not well, and will never return"... something crazy like that... but, how depressing.  

Now, the San Diego Zoo is impressive.  The keepers of this place should take note, or take notes on how to develop a living environment for keeping animals happy.

Aren't you supposed to leave the zoo feeling good, not upset as another one went to the Animal Farm in the sky??
author: Benjamin B.

description:
I hadn't been to the SF zoo since I was a kid and I had remembered it being a pretty sad/miserable-feeling zoo.  But the other week when it was one of those hot, hot days we decided to take our little tot to the zoo and give it another chance.  
In short, there are still parts of the zoo which are sad and miserable-feeling and there are other parts which are much improved and quite nice.  If you go with low expectations (as I did) you may be pleasantly surprised.  
It probably isn't the best place to take out-of-towners, but it seems worthwhile to support a place where locals can find a little animal exposure.  (I wish they had the resources to make it better all around!)
author: Vicki L.

description:
My husband & I decided to go to the zoo yesterday (Labor Day, what were we thinking)....luckily we had free tickets so we didn't have to stand in the mile-long line.  This is the second time we've been there in recent years, and I was reminded why it's not my favorite zoo....

Pros:
-The African area with the giraffes & other animals is nice.  They seem to be well taken are of in this area.
-The new grizzly bear area is nice!  When we were there, both bears were in the water & came right up to the viewing window.  
-The children's farm/petting zoo is always fun (guess I'm a kid at heart), although most of the goats seem lethargic from all the food they've been fed.

Cons:
-The area with the grey seal made me want to cry.  It was so run-down and the seal looked depressed.
-The area with the polar bears needs to be upgraded.  It was quite warm when we were there yesterday and the bears were panting from the heat.  They kept trying to go in the door to the back area but it was closed.  They looked unhappy.
-A lot of the areas need a facelift.  
-The need to do something with the "Pachyderm" building.  It's completely boarded up and run-down.  Depressing...

I don't think we will be going back to the SF Zoo anytime soon.  :-(
author: Ann W.

description: Not a bad day out but I will probably never be able to get over the slightly depressing feeling of this zoo. For some reason their schedule for lion feedings is secret and I always seem to miss it. Exhibit quality ranges from very substandard to pretty great with many strangely empty exhibits.
author: Mike L.

description:
The best zoo I've ever been to! Couldn't believe how cheap the entrance fee was either! We took a taxi from our hotel because we couldn't figure out how to get there, but there's a tram stop just outside and over the road. The surrounding area looks a bit dodgy but once we got on the tram it was fine.


 There is a good selection of eateries in the the zoo and prices are good. The animals all look happy and well cared for and a lot of the keepers were on hand to tell you about the animals and answer question.
author: PandaPants

description: It had been at least 20 years since I'd been to the zoo, and I met my son there with my 3 grandsons. It is so pristine compared with how it used to be. We only stayed an hour, mainly viewing only a few animal areas. I was impressed with the quality of life the animals seem to have, and with what good condition they appeared to be in. They all looked like they'd just come from the animal spa. The railings in front of the exhibits are the perfect height and shape for you to hold a toddler on so they can sort of sit and see the animals. I am looking forward to going back soon and want to see all of the animals.
author: Barbara S.

description:
Yesterday was free and I have not been to the S.F. Zoo in literally years. *Cue nostalgia of childhood days* Anyway, I went a bit later in the afternoon at around 2 and not many people were present. This was striking to me given that 99% of the time I come to the zoo, loads of people crowd the walkway to the entrance at any given time in the afternoon.

It was quite "dead" and quiet. Getting in was a breeze, but the massive 'SFRES' hand stamp, really now? Enough with that, but I was scouring to find the maps which is the first thing I always do at attractions/theme parks/museums. It was in an unmarked cardboard box on a table in the middle of the path. Just looking at it dictated the rest of my time spent. The unflattering 1pg half-fold was so bland that I just threw it in my Ruehl bag I was holding and just started walking to whatever trail was first, and lo and behold it was the lemurs. I never actually got to see them ever since the last major remodel since the children and students would be crowding the lookout points. The lack of bustle yesterday was to my advantage, thank goodness. 

Fast forward because I don't want to tell a story, I had trouble navigating since I was not familiar with the new layout. Tip: get two maps from the start (and don't forget to recycle them afterward)! I was disappointed for the most part since the new zoo is a big step downward from my younger days. I mean, c'mon...no elephants, no bears, no aviary/tropical forest, you get the point. I don't recall seeing hippos either. The experience is completely lackluster and anything but fun. Pretty much the only thing fun you will find, is that good for nothing steam train. I don't see how the animals can stand that racket on a daily basis, let alone the zoo keepers and employees. My favorite koalas were not out today. Major downer! Now, what the Zoo needs is funding to renovate the ancient exhibits. The poor tapir gets no attention whatsoever, and he's not the only animal that's basically nonexistent. 

I spent the most time probably at the Insect Zoo in the Children's Zoo. Lots of fine specimens, but could be much better. The petting zoo was thriving, which was a much needed change in the attitude of the day. The prairie dogs right next door have gotten much fatter since the last time I visited them. And where are the meerkats? 

My my, what a way to start the new decade. I must preserve the memories of the days when there were transit tours and construction wouldn't shut down practically half the exhibits. Hopefully, I will return at its 100th anniversary to see a fully transformed Zoo for the better.
author: Dominic T.

description:
I've been a member of the zoo for a long time.  It's a small zoo, but I it makes it easy to see the exhibits.  When I first started going, I would have given it two stars but they are making lots of improvements, and they removed the elephant exhibits which was necessary as they had such a small, depressing space. 

Do they need to do MORE?  Heck, yeah.  The cat exhibits need a lot of improvement but the African Animals exhibit is quite nice, the gorilla area is decent as is the Lemur area. 

Zoos can be depressing for sure, but they are one of the ways breeding programs happen and zoos help inform the public on the importance of maintaining and improving the protection of animals in the wild.

I'm not sure what the one star reviewer was talking about in regards to some of the animals.  The grizzly bears are usually very playful (perhaps he went on a off day) and I often see them swimming and playing together.  The cats are not in in the original tiny cages for the most part (unless they are being moved to different areas, or during feeding).

The sea lion area DOES suck, not  sure why he is in such a crappy area.

The zoo is always upgrading and I hope that they continue to create new and larger areas for their animals even if it means having even fewer animals.  I'm sure it's been difficult what with those teenagers abusing the tiger and now trying to sue the zoo for everything.  

I'm giving 4 stars for effort.
author: Bianca G.

description:
Another adventure for the little guy and I, a afternoon at the zoo.  
We are so lucky to have such a well maintained zoo close by.  Parking is easy, weather is good, staff is super friendly.
The girl at the ticket window was nice enough to inform us that the train would be closing at 3pm, so we dashed over and took two rides around the zoo (kid loves it)  then we slowly wondered back towards the entrance which usually takes about an hour or so. . 
A must stop is penguin island, the tigers (so beautiful) and sadly, so caged. . . the tiger cups were absolutely adorable. bears are, well bears. . giraffe enclosure at the entrance was so spacious - nice to see that their  roaming area has been enlarged.  
Zoo carousel is a must 3 ride event for us.
author: Kea C.

description: If you have been to the San Diego Zoo, you may be slightly disappointed with what you find here. Some parts of the zoo are not very well kept, but right now is a great time to go because there are baby animals everywhere. I don't know if it was a good idea to keep these animals in the coldest part of the city, but they supposedly have heaters. The gorillas looked bored and there was a giraffe that kept moving his jaws like he had peanut butter stuck to the roof of his mouth. Both exhibits were my favorites. I wish someone would give this zoo some more money because it has the potential to be really great.
author: Tin-Tin E.

description: Okay, so I grew up in the area and visited the San Francisco zoo regularly as a kid. When I first came back after an adult, I found the zoo a little sad looking...there are some empty exhibits and against the often gray, cloudy sky the zoo can be a little down. But now that I have a toddler I can appreciate this zoo for what it brings to the local community. There are a lot of programs for local children groups, and since joining with a family membership I've become a frequent visitor for an hour or two whenever it's a sunny day. My son loves the gorillas, zebras, and giraffes the best. The children's petting zoo has primarily goats, but it's still a nice little space for the little kids to run around and get close to some animals in a safe environment. Yes, there are nicer zoos out there like San Diego, Washington DC, and even the Oakland Zoo...but being only ten minutes away from my home, this zoo is a fun place for my little guy to run around, learn about animals, and experience a little more than a regular park. We try to visit certain exhibits during the zookeeper hours, so we've been able to watch the giraffes and grizzly bears feeding up close, which I never got to see as a kid. My tip is to try going on a sunny day...it seems to make the zoo ten times nicer looking!
author: Kristy C.

description: This zoo is old and outdated.  There is only one of each animal and most of the exhibits are closed.
author: Michele A.

description: I'm not really a zoo fan, but I really enjoy the SF Zoo and find it far better than its counterparts, especially the overrated SD Zoo.  It's not a huge place, but it's laid out pretty well and very easy to navigate.  The animals have decent to large habitats and we were able to see all of them on the day we went.  Yeah, some exhibits could be larger; the African exhibit is quite impressive, but the bear and lion ones could be larger. The grounds are just beautiful and the location is perfect, right on Highway 1 across from Ocean Beach.  And we lucked out and went in August when kids got in free!
author: Liz I.

description:
i love the petting zooo !! ! ! ! ! makes me laugh. 
gorillas too. the zoo is pretty big, i alaways get tired of walking, but it's in a good day's fun. a lot of it seems to be renovation though.
author: Veranna N.

description:
This is the worst zoo I have ever been to. There are tons of empty cages. There are miscellaneous pieces of equipment and "housing" just left lying around. It just looks junky like someone hasn't taken the time to clean up their back yard. 

The cages are not built in a way that makes it most attractive for the zoo patrons, or more importantly, comfortable for the animals themselves. It all seems sort of haphazard and thrown together, with items built in the way. And, it seemed like everywhere we turned there was a sign that said "Employees Only."

You walk around the zoo and feel much more like you are in a botanical garden than you are in a zoo looking at animals. It has a very eerie abandoned feel. Perhaps this is due to all the walking that you do in between the animal exhibits. When you actually do get to see the very few animals that are there, it is a joy, but that seems so few and far between.
author: Dawn L.

description: Came out here for Momma's day with the family and the weather was perfect so what else can you ask for? well the anaswer to that would be more animals. Upon my surprise the Northern part of the zoo is pretty barren these days and they don't lack space ,but rather lack of animals. They were working on the rain forest but what's up with the othr exhibits? I will be back again soon...
author: Richard G.

description: Great zoo. I have been coming here since I was a little kid and this place still fun to go to.
author: Joshua L.

description: Just left the San Francisco Zoo and I am a San Francisco native so as a child we went for field trips and with my family. It appears that alot of the animals have passed on since then. I didn't realize they keep the same animals for 30 plus years or until they die. You would think they would have tried to mate them or bought sum younger animals. There were several animal cages empty and some saying how the animal had recently passed. I will say the animals looked ok as far as health and well being. That is honestly my main concern. The grizzly bears are nice cuz we got their and they had just put the food out to feed them. They came barreling around the corner ready to eat. I was upset that they didn't have any elephants. I remember them having them as kids but I guess they died too which is surprising because I thought elephants could live like 50 years but what do I know. All in all the kids really enjoyed themselves and it was free to get in because it was the first wedsday of the month.
author: Jenn G.

description:
We recently held our wedding and reception at the SF Zoo and were extremely happy with the entire process and the event itself.

Everyone we worked with at the zoo was polite, professional, and competent throughout.  Special thanks to Carol, Laney, and the head waiter who's name I've forgotten.

The only thing lacking was that we had hoped there would be more animals than a couple storks in the background of the african savannah where our ceremony took place.  It was still a beautiful site, and we enjoyed the animal encounter at the reception very much.  They brought an owl, armadillo, baby alligator, and ferret. 

Highly recommended.
author: Kyle C.

description:
A beeee-yoooo-teeee-ful sunny day, after a dim-sum lunch, we made to the San Francisco Zoo and took a walk.

Some animals were not out... it was getting towards closing time, but I found that the zoo was a wholesome and sweet experience.  Walking around brought back memories of my five-year-old self on the kindergarten trip to the zoo.  Yes, they made us eat sitting around that big fountain, where we could face the penguins.  I remember the hippo, and was saddened to read of her death just months ago after an extremely long life.

I know it is politically correct to hate zoos and cages for animals.  However, I do know that this is not a one-sided issue.  For example, these caged animals get the best medical care and food available and often live twice as long as their wild brethren.  I also can see that the zoo is trying hard to give these animals as stressfree life as possible.  A screen of thicket around a monkey enclosure to give privacy when raising youngsters is an example.

I wonder what _we_ as patrons are doing to further the cause.  One thing that distressed me was that while observing a monkey with a small baby clinging to her back... people were repeated  using their flash, even though they probably only got flash reflected by glass.  It was annoying.  Another thing was small children wandering behind the barricades at the monkey enclosure.  Kiddos will be kiddos, but I hated (HATED) that the mom SCREAMED at them to get back... :::sigh:::  I guess I think that kiddos should be scooped up and brought back a little more quietly... rather than subject _everyone_ to the scream.  Personally, it used to scare me a little more when my mom was quiet and deadly... but hey... here is the childless professional who has learned not to have an opinion on how other people are raising their children.. just please don't scream in my ear, I am well behind the barricades.

What was the most impressive?  The HUGE paws of the polar bear?  The frentic playfulness of the otters?  The iridescent plumage of the peacock?  The frightening roars from the lion enclosure?  The playful head rub of the tiger as she passed her enclosure-mate (the same gesture I have see my cat make a million times)?  The stare of the huge heron behind the screen?  These and a hundred more were my favorites in our hour-and-a-half walk.

We will be back.  We turned in our admissions toward a family pass.  It was such a nice walk, we will do it again!
author: Kelly B.

description: Just went to the zoo on 9/25...what happened???  I was really looking forward to returning after 6 years but very disenchanted with the horrific and dirty conditions of the zoo.  I feel so sad for a majority of the animals living in such cramped quarters with filthy water..  Don't even bother with the bear exhibit, what a joke.  There isn't anything to see except a very sad and lonely polar bear, flamingo exhibit too small and most of the viewing areas were disgusting.    The only good areas were at the beginning with the gorillas and giraffes - otherwise, you're in for a surprise!  Who is handling the funds to improve the quality of such a tourist trap!
author: teri g.

description: I love going to the zoo, and living in a city that's got one less than two blocks from the ocean. While it's kick-ass to watch the giraffes eat from that up-close-and-personal vantage deck in the faux safari area, my absolute favorite pit-stop is the petting zoo. I bust out my quarters and feed every ugly goat in sight and my friends, the ducks. If that was all the zoo had, I'd still go, because the third grade boy in me still gets a thrill from touching critters. Oh, make sure you mention it if you're a City resident for two bucks off your admission, because they certainly won't ask or remind you when you buy your tix.
author: Gregor G.

description: We came here pretty close to closing. The animals at that point didn't seem like they wanted to be out, and many of them weren't at that time. I wanted to see the koalas, but they were already put away. A lot of the animals were pretty easy to see. I have to say I got a kick out of the bug displays. I was pretty happy with the zoo. The restaurants and booths were pretty much closed then, too. Admission was pretty reasonable... $11. Parking actually wasn't too bad, either.
author: Sara W.

description: the zoo is very zoo-like and has lemurs, which can often be seen fornicating in the open.  I like this corner pocket of the city placement and the people who are here are always pretty happy. the pictures they takeof you when you come in are NOT b/c you're rad. they'd like you to purchase them.  If not they will be deleted
author: e c.

description: The San Francisco Zoo is awesome. I love lemurs and they have the LARGEST lemur habitat in the United States. My husband likes the penguins. They zoom through the water like a torpedo and they come pretty close to you. I love the tigers and lions. Their Emperor Tamrins are adorable!
author: Lauren M.

description:
Great place to come and stare at hopeless caged animals in their man -made habitats.  Honestly!  I love this zoo and all they have to offer. This location is large, affordable and open 7 days a week .  I came here as a kid and once again as a man, and can say Im the only animal who stinks at this place.  
Every animal you or your child loves lives right here in our zoo, so why not spend the day out and make some new friends?

Come first wednesday of the month - its free! 
Show proof of SF residency, huge discount!
author: Ray M.

description:
i havent been to the san diego zoo, but i have gone to the bronx zoo, and fresnos (pathetic) zoo.
 
SF zoo: right across from ocean beach. good for kids. and the lion house is awesome!. i went once with my brother and sister and wow! i cant believe how close i was to the lions. it was really cool to be able to be so close to something like that. i think i like this zoo so much because they have all the feedings going on. If you go, you're bound to see something. the wonderin peacock is always amusing.
if you have kids, you have the different play grounds inside for them, the petting zoo. i just want to know wha happened to the HUGE gift shop, last time i went it was closed or something. anyways they have many different types of animal houses, so you can see a whole bunch of things.

we'll have to see if my review changes after going to the San Diego zoo.
author: Anna U.

description:
Ode to the San Francisco Zoo

It was such a perfect day for the zoo- a cloudless blue day with the sun's rays bouncing off  the fountains and sparkling across the vast open lake. 
I heard the birds chirping and the lazy chimpanzees basking under the sun, while the lions napped- enjoying the same warm breezy air.
On the Serengeti plain- I saw the giant giraffes, grazing on the the highest limbs of the trees, the gregarious gazelles grazed nearby enjoying the sweet new buds of grass...
The Gorillas were spying nearby, donning the same quizzical expression , wondering in amazement how peculiar i am to them...
Ah yes the carousel- the music of Saint-Saens, "The Carnival of Animals" ringing in my head, yes these dear friends have animated me...the pictures of the black neck swans-  snacking on the eucalyptus leaves, and the penguins who inspired me  that black and white do go together.  
This is the only time that I really didnt mind the screaming children running around with  the inexhausatible fuel of cotton candy, sweet drinks and caramel corn! 
For I too was gawking at the pink flamingoes, laughing with the bears and certainly shouted with the macao birds in the aviary.
It was a great visit,  seeing familiar faces again- that someday- I wish to see them in their real homes.

PS. Support your zoos- lets learn from each other, respect each other and share this beautiful home we call Earth.
author: Arissa C.

description: My daughter loved the zoo it was her first time and she enjoyed every bit of especially the kids zoo she played with the goats and ducks ran around with a big smile on her face made my day. I cant wait to take her again nothing like the real thing and keeping her away from the TV works for me.
author: Alex H.

description: Hmmm. I hate to say it but this zoo is pretty lame. This place looked depressing and barren. A lot of the animal habitats were empty, not because the animals were sleeping but just plain empty and taped off. I also noticed they don't have anymore elephants, leopards and cheetahs.  Don't get me wrong, the animals that were there were great but its hard to observe animals that look pretty bummed. The amazement is definitely not the same from when I was younger. Looking at animals in captivity is depressing.
author: Jordan A.

description:
Three stars! One for goats and One for meerkats and One for penguins. In case you didn't know, pygmy goats are my all time favorite animals. EVER. I would have a pack of them in my backyard if I had a backyard and not just a crummy fire escape. I would love those goats and make them knock eachother up so I could have bunches of baby goats everywhere. 
I probably won't have a backyard or goats for some time, so it sure is lucky that the SF zoo has a children's petting zoo, where I can go love a goat any time I choose. The petting zoo rocks! 
The meerkats and the penguins are also enough to melt the cold dark place where my heart once was time and again...
Things that suck are disgusting food options (think school cafeteria free-lunch program at Gary Danko prices), the polar bears (they look so sad), the daily public feeding of white bunnies to the lions (um...ew!), and the eternal construction in different areas of the zoo.
Oooh! I love the Little Puffer steam train and the merry-go-round, too.
I know it's a bit of a switch from my usual m.o. of stiletto heels, vodka, and boy-craziness, but I like to switch it up every now and then...
author: Autumn K.

description: I hadn't been to the zoo in a really, really long time, so I have absolutely nothing to compare this to.  Many of the animals were asleep/ pretty idle when we were there, which made it a lot less exciting.  There was a penguin feeding while we were there but otherwise no real events or activities going on that guaranteed the animals would be up and about. Overall I enjoyed myself and I think the layout of the zoo is nice, to walk around in/ etc.  Would probably help to go on a warmer day too!
author: Richa A.

description:
It's got to be 10-15 years since I've last been at the San Francisco Zoo. Today I went along with my group to perform at the zoo's Chinese New Year celebration. I'm glad I didn't pay.

I remember the zoo to be a lively place. There used to be bustling crowds with happy children in awe of the wildlife. The animals were vibrant and energetic. You could always count on the primates to cause a ruckus with their constant yelping (no, not a pun) and mischievous behavior.

Maybe my memory serves me wrong? Maybe as a kid you're oblivious to the fact that this place just isn't that happy? Maybe this place has just deteriorated over the years?

What I observed today on a typical cold, foggy San Francisco day was an unkept, old zoo filled with seemingly sedated animals. Maybe they were just bored and tired from being confined to these cells? What became more and more apparent was that I was walking around a prison with animals that aren't "living," but just existing. "Hey look, that polar bear looks like it's posing to be a rug," said one patron while I was walking by the exhibit. I bet that guy thought it was sort of cool, but most "wild animals" don't play like they're log cabin rugs. The only redeeming quality to this place is the African exhibit with giraffes, zebras, etc. This was the only exhibit that was vibrant and roomy with animals that didn't look like prisoners. And yet this exhibit sits under the dull, cold, and foggy San Francisco weather. It's even worse that it's by the ocean. Has anyone ever thought this might not be the appropriate habitat for most of these animals? Is there freakin' fog in Africa??? I'm no animal activist, but in my opinion this place needs to be shut down.
author: Al L.

description: Unless you have a tiger-proof suit I wouldn't recommend going here.
author: Matthew R.

description: I feel so bad for the animals that are trapped behind cages and living in man-made environments . I really think they should be freed and let into their natural habits where they are free to do whatever they want . I much rather watch the behavior of animals in their natural habitat than animals in a man-made habitat . I think that's why I never really liked the zoo as a little kid .. it was just so boring watching the animals miserable and bored in their cages / man-made habitats . It's good for kids though .. just to get recognized with how the animals look like . It kills their curiousity . As for the zoo itself , it's not that great .. not much animals and the food they sell here isn't that great either . But hey admission is cheap ( I think ) and it's free every Wednesday of each month .
author: Eileen L.

description: Miserable little zoo. I guess the only benefit is the low cost of entry.
author: G J J.

description:
I love SF Zoo! I've been going there since I was 12 years old. I've taken my kids there, and now I take my grand-daughter there. I've got a zoo pass so we can go whenever we like. 
Every time we go, since she's only 2 right now, each time is a new experience for her. She's fascinated by something different each time. A lot of the exhibits have changed, just over the last few years. They have closed down the Tropical Forest building,and this last time there was finally a fence around it & a sign saying it was being refurbished. We shall see. 
They have since revamped the gorilla & giraffe area. That I would have to say was a change for the better. She loves looking at the animals. 
We went there last August to see the baby gorilla. She was standing next to the viewing glass not more than 2 feet from it. They were so similar in size. Everyone was in awe......except my grand-daughter! She was more fascinated by the lone ant marching its way along the cement border of the glass! LOL! Go figure!
We pay willingly for the overpriced food, knowing it's making it's way into their coffers to help maintain the zoo. It's not bad tasting, as good as most of the fast food places.
There have been so many changes in the past 33 years that I have been going. Some good, some not so good. But it's still an experience not to be missed by children.
author: Debi S.

description:
It's often difficult to weigh the role of simple nostalgia with some of the things you love.  I love the San Francisco Zoo.  I was born in San Francisco, and some of my earliest pleasant memories are of playing in the zoo playground, riding on the carousel and my combination of horror and delight when Puddles the Hippo would flick his tail back and forth, showering the crowds with his....um...hippo manure.  Of course back in those days there was also Monkey Island, which fell way short of a PG rating for oh so many reasons.  The roars in the Lion House still evoke almost cellular memories of awe  that I'm pretty sure go back even further than my childhood.

Now I know the SFZoo, or Fleishaker Zoological Gardens, as we knew it then, can be a bit lackluster, especially in contrast to more modern and animal-friendly spaces such as the San Diego Wild Animal Park, but when the fog comes seeping in between the Monterey Cypress and there's a little salt water mist in your hair, the beach is a stone's throw, and the Doggie head is smiling, everything is all right in the world.

The downsides? OK, a tiger "went tiger" [Chris Rock] there, ostensibly because the zoo was cutting a few corners.  Big Deal.  I have to confess that I believe anyone teasing a tiger pretty much deserves whatever they get, and hurrah for animals being animals and not some domesticated super-sized housecat.  And the bears always look a bit morose, don't they.  The otters and seals deserve more as well - a few toys maybe?  Some water jets for those hard-to-reach place, hm?...hmmmn?
But overall, when you've walked the SF Zoo, you feel like you've actually WALKED (unlike the Oakland Zoo), and seen some things.

 I also have to mention here that the single sexiest thing I've ever seen in my life...and I've seen a few...was at this zoo.  Oh Sure, you say, in front of the children and all?  Yes, siree.  It was the Spring of 80-something, before they moved the smaller cats out to the gulag.  The Snow Leopards were...well, making more Snow Leopards.  The male was clearly completely shagged out by the time I got there, lying glazed-eyed and breathing hard.  The female pulls herself up by the forelegs, and in a languid motion that would put the best pole dancer to complete shame, nudges the male's face with her head, then proceeds to drag her entire body across the front of his face, lingering particularly with her hind quarters and her gorgeous full tail, which caressed his head like a hand.  There was no space between the final inches of her tail and the motion with which he exhaustedly raised himself as though she and he were magnetized. He circled her, did what they do, and resumed his fatigued recovery.  This went on several times as I watched, fascinated, and taking notes.....

ah, but I digress.  Where was I?  Oh yeah, people say the food isn't great - what do you expect, it's the frikking ZOO!  Pack a lunch if you've got kids, or bite the bullet - hell, they've got some edible Asian food there, and that's more than most zoos can say.  Take the day, drive out early, when it's still foggy, linger with the gorillas and the African Savannah, delight in the goofy little lemurs, then go to the beach for sunset.  Insider's tip: there is hardly anyone there on weekdays, and it can be very romantic.  3 stars for zoo.  5 stars for atmosphere.  It averages out.
author: Kimberly V.

description: What are the right days to go to the Zoo? Every time I go to the Zoo, it is COLD, so the animals are clearly not loving it, moving little, if they are there to begin with. A lot of variety keeps it from becoming stale, I just wish there was more action and a more hospitable climate for these animals. If we are to cage them, they should enjoy as much as we do, right?
author: Haz O.

description:
If there were a no-star option I would give it to the decrepit SF zoo. For such a pioneering city in all things liberal, the zoo lies on the outskirts like a leper island. Dirty, stinky, sad, depressing. I literally went home and cried... This was over 3 years ago and I still can't shake it from my mind. After this review I'm gonna contact PETA. 

Please BOYCOTT THE ZOO!! Contact city officials and urge them to donate the animals to Oakland or San Diego. There needs to be an official investigation to see how a $15 fee for adults times however many visitors per month doesn't equal humane conditions for the wildlife.
 Tiger was behind thick dirty, tag-etched bulletproof plastic and chain-link fence. Habitat? Really? 
 I went on a muggy day and didn't see how emaciated Polar Bear was supposed to escape the heat...don't they live on glaciers!!!??? Does anyone do their research there? 
Staff was WEIRD and unfriendly, like they were in on some sick animal abuse conspiracy. This zoo sucks.
author: Chelsea C.

description: I only came here once.  It was two days before the tiger attack.  The zoo as a whole was pretty nice.  Some of the exhibits were closed, and they didn't seem to have too many animals in some sections, but still a decent selection.  The exhibits could be a little more updated.  When I was looking at the tigers with my friend I was with I actually turned to him and said "huh, you think they could get out of there if they really wanted to."  Oops.
author: Robin L.

description: Totally disappointing! I found many displays void of animals. Very difficult for toddlers to see animals in alot of natural settings. Poor directional signing makes it difficult to find your way around. I hadn't been to the zoo in many years. It's amazing how it has deteriorated.
author: Mick R.

description: I'm not into bestiality nor am I by any means a pervert, but I have to say there are some damn fine lookin' animals here.
author: Bangkok C.

description: not as good as it used to be lot of animals were m.i.a but the hippo and gorillas were a plus! but next time ill be going to sacramento zoo (not as crowded has fairytale land across the street for the kids) traffic was bad too!
author: James J.

description: I'm puzzled by all the negative reviews.  I've been to many zoos, and this one is no worse then any other I've seen.  In fact the Gorilla area is really cool.  When we were there, the gorilla's got into a massive fight which was a little scary.  The sound of one gorilla slapping each other showed the power of these animals.  The big cats were sleeping which was a shame, and there are no elephants.  The kettle corn was pretty good too...I ended up getting a stomach ache from being unable to stop putting them in my mouth.  The only negative was the lack of signs at every turn.
author: Iftikhar K.

description: we've gone to the zoo twice this month. it was alot cooler when i was younger. there aren't that many animals and everything seems to be closed. or the animals are hiding. the place is clean and looks great from all the remodeling they've done. the food is sooooo expensive and not good. also we went to the petting zoo today and i was rammed in the ass twice and kicked by a goat who wanted food.
author: Angelina M.

description:
I went through considerable trouble convincing Pumpkin K that zoos are cool.  I explained how attending the zoo should be an educational experience, and though the animals there are in captivity; they are happy, well fed, and protected.  They are better off here than in the wild, because they represent the beauty of their species, and bring humans closer to caring about the precious life on this world.  I made her read the first 5 chapters of Life Of Pi for gods sake -and if you haven't read the book then maybe you should- but don't expect to come away from the SF Zoo feeling enlightened, educated, or optimistic about animals, their habitat (natural or re-created), and animal captivity in general.
Can a zoo feel tired?  This zoo felt like it was tired.  Thus the animals: tired.  The river otter, rhino, and polar bear were all standing and moving around, but we think it was because they've lost their minds.  No, really.  
The river otter was alone in his enclosure, but swears he's being followed.  He chased his tail until he finally caught it, fell down, and went to sleep with his tail down his throat.
The rhino cannot face towards the crowd, so all you get to see is his ass.  And if he needs to walk to the other side of his pen to eat, he does so with his ass right in your face.  Remarkable how you can see the same show at the food court.
The polar bear could've been a statue for all I know.  He was standing and looked angry.  A frozen, angry grimace over a tiny pool of water not suitable for a freakin otter.  I shit you not, the otter had twice the water of the polar bear!  I'm not an expert, but I've watched enough Discovery Channel to know that these beasts do enjoy a good swim once and a while.  What the fuck does a polar bear need a reflecting pool for??
Okay, enough blog.  Time for something useful.

The first Wednesday of every month is free admission.  Cool.

Wear jeans and bring a jacket, even if you start the day in shorts.  This area of town is seemingly shrouded in mist, wind, and clouds more often than other areas.

E. Bring a baby stroller. Who cares if you have a baby or not?! Everyone has one so just bring it! (from Selino V.'s review - priceless)

I like their coffee from the concession stand inside the gift shop by the front gate.  One problem though, no lids.  No lids?  I imagined the Korean girl that served me giggling as I walked away, spilling hot liquid on my hand.  "I told him we don't have lids! hee hee!"

Steal a quick look at the meerkats in the kids area, and then if you don't have kids, make a break for the exit as fast as you can.

Pretend like you're taking pictures of the exhibits, but really take them of the backs of the people standing in front of you.  Snap off a good 20 or 30 shots of anyone there.  Get prints develops at Walgreens in 5x7, then take them to the gym with you and tape one up on the eliptical machine in front of you.  One for everyday of the month.  Hot damn, instant motivation.

See the grizzly bears.  Not a bad exhibit, looks pretty new.  Lots of playing when we were there.


Take the survey at the end of the day.  There are volunteers with clipboards standing at the exit on your way out.  My gal is the one who agreed to take the survey (on behalf of us both), and I'm glad she did.  I would never have thought to give my feedback, and that's exactly what these people are there for.  If you're going to complain, I guess it's good to have the balls to tell them at the end.  Plus, he gave us a free ticket for the trouble!  Don't save it unless you know someone that can use it.  Just hand it to a random person headed in.  They'll be super psyched, and you can ride out the rest of your day on that sweet karma.
author: Jeremy P.

description: The most depressing place on the entire planet. The poor animals in those terribly artificial habitats. I'm sorry, I don't care about seeing the (admittedly adorable) penguins if it means sticking some beatiful large cats in a cage. I don't like the cages. Not one little bit.
author: Jordan M.

description: I used to come here when I was a kid.  I really like this zoo, it's big and has a large playground for the kiddos.  The cons are the parking, never enough and it's always cold becuase they're right across from the beach.  They should have an in-door dinning room because I am tired of having segals stealing my hot dog.
author: Chris R.

description:
I've been here a few times and its been OK nothing spectacular. The lion feeding was always my favorite but they don't do that anymore. In fact they don't do a lot of anything anymore. We went on Wednesday with my 4 year old brother and it was $8 for parking, $15 for each adult, and I forgot how much I paid for my brother but it was ridiculous how much that place cost for the crap experience. There are no elephants, no hippos, no tiger/lion feeding, the baby gorilla was nowhere in site, the lions were on the floor in the cage and you could barely see them, only one gorilla was out and really visible, all the bears were asleep and in the back of the exhibits except the grizzlies. The rhinos were in the back of their exhibit, the kangaroos are always asleep. Overall everything was either asleep or not in its cage, except the african exhibit at the front with the zebras, giraffes and other animals was really cool. That was the best part of the zoo. The little train is a $4 rip off. The carosuel wasn't working. The building with the reptiles is still closed. Basically this zoo is a huge rip off because they have no animals and the ones they do have are sleeping and everything is closed/doesn't work. 

My 4 year old brother had a way better time at the Oakland Zoo. 

Don't waste your money until this place gets their act together.
author: Cheri M.

description: I just came back from the zoo today and absolutely loved it. Although it was a typical rainy SF day, the animals in there made the trip all worth it. The penguins, tigers and chimpanzees were very cute. Admission and parking might seem pricey, but it's a great experience!
author: Yi-Bing Z.

description: AWW i love the zoo! How can you go wrong when you go with your boyfriend?? I took so many pictures. I always feel bad for the animals there... encaged and miserable for our amusement. I remember the beautiful flamingoes very vividly and the big giraffes. It is definitely very fun, and you get some exercise too because it is quite a walk around the whole park!
author: Rachel T.

description: While I realize this review will cause my friends to laugh and continue with the happy bunnies and unicorns jokes I can't resist it. Spending a day with sea otters and penguins is pretty much a dream come true. Watching my boyfriend freak out as the mini-goats in the petting zoo tried to play with him was priceless. Why 4 stars and not 5?? I will always believe the zoo should have more space, other then that its a fun filled day in san francisco. If you can avoid getting your lunch stolen by a moody seagul, make sure you stop by the monkey cages for some classic entertainment :)
author: Jessica L.

description:
Okay, before I had children I was never a big fan of zoo's.  But my kids love it here.  It has beautiful gardens and some great exhibits.  I love the Children's zoo.  If you have children you have to make sure you go there when all of the animals are out.  Also my 4 year old gets a kick out of the farm section.  You can actually go in with the goats and the sheep's and feel like you are on a farm.  FUN!  My almost 2 year old was kinda scared, but I just hold her and she is ok.  
Also we love the train and the carousel.  If there isn't a line at the gate get your tickets there.  

We have been members now for 2 years.  I
author: Jackie K.

description: Oh dear. I see that I'm not the only one who thinks the zoo is so depressing. The past few times I've been here were on Free Wednesdays and partly due to a class assignment. All the animals look so sad here, and the fog and grey skies just adds on to it. I make eye contact sometimes and I feel like crying because I can't help them. The only animals I can think of that are worth seeing are the penguins. They're the only happy campers around here. I used to love this place as a kid when I didn't realize that animals had feelings too.
author: Zell C.

description: It may have been a lot more fun when you're a kid but as you grow older you can't help but feel sorry for these animals! Caged up for the rest of their animal lives as humans watch them, ooh and ahh, take pictures, and laugh. How sad.  I'm depressed.
author: Mel P.

description:
Are there animals here?  I never see many, and the ones I do look oh so depressed.  I guess I would too if I had to live in a *natural habitat* such as theirs.  It  just always looks overgrown and , oddly, at the same time, bare (how do they manage that combination??)   I do occasionally go for a change of scenery for the kiddies, but always leave disappointed. 
The kids like the petting zoo, but  even my 3year old won't brush the over-stuffed (to the point of near bursting) sheep-things because the filth is too much (but, they ARE animals, so I guess that's par for the course).  The sheep-things can be fairly aggressive when they sense you have a pile of kibble in your hand so very young children are often scared off.  Maybe they should rotate the sheep-things to regulate their diet and curtail their kibble-from-hand mania.  The roosters are pretty.   All the kids fight over turns on the tiny tractors.  There are two - and one is in disrepair. Parents watch the kids clamor for their turn with a greedy eye, checking their watch ("umm, it's little Jake's turn- your Emily has been on the tractor for 3.5 minutes already...")

The cafe is terribly over-priced and food is average-to below average for this type of venue.   AND - this really kills me,  the doors are too small to easily allow the double-stroller that they rent out.  Without fail I am at the mercy of some other mother or father who has been in the same boat as me.  You think they would realize the majority of patrons are parents with small children who rent these strollers- they should accommodate.  There is also a very very snotty guy who works the cafe... the zoo nazi... ready to pounce if he senses a particle of food has dropped from your kid's plate and now available for the swarming pigeons. "PLEASE DON'T FEED THE ANIMALS!!!"  he scolds. 
No lids/straws for drinks as they are choking hazards for animals.  Many-a-spilled-drink at the hands of little ones who haven't mastered the open top cup.

There is a train that takes you for a double loop around a portion of the  zoo.  My kids LOVE this and have a grand time waving at everybody as they chug-chug by.  They love that train so that alone makes my trips worth it.   

One thing there is a lot of are what appear to be divorced father's on *their weekend* with the kid/s... so you ladies in search of an insta-family - here's a good alternative to meeting men at a bar.

I must say, thought that this zoo is better than the Sacramento or Oakland zoos.
author: Meg W.

description: There's something about kids and zoos and the San Francisco Zoo is no exception. It's a great family outing. Sure, it's not as nice as it could be but improvements like the African Savanna are worth it. There are a lot of animals to see. Plus, there's Little Puffer the steam engine, a Merry Go Round, and plenty of other activities for kids. Check it out and have fun.
author: David D.

description:
A saddened Coach K here,

This was my first time at the SF Zoo and I must say it made me realize why I never go here. To be fair, the Zoo did have most of the animals a person would want to see, but just not in the conditions you want to see them in. I can recall going to zoo's when I was younger and thinking the animals were at least somewhat happy.  Before I get into my breakdown of a few select animals I would hate to forget mentioning the fact that the café was deplorable. The food was disgusting, and I believe being 75 pounds overweight with "super" nacho remnants dripping onto your shirt was a pre-requisite to sitting at the tables. If not, it was just a huge coincidence shared by everyone dining there. Moving along:

Gorilla's  - There were three total in the exhibit. Their habitat was far too small and the silver back looked like he wanted to commit suicide as he sadly looked at everyone take photographs of him. I wouldn't be surprised if he does in fact take his own life in the near future. 

Seal - Notice I didn't use the plural form. One of the good parts of the Zoo is the "interesting facts" posted on the outside of the exhibits. The interesting Seal fact was that they can dive up to 475 feet deep and hold their breaths underwater for 20 minutes. Well, this Seal was confined to what would be considered a small pool in someone's backyard, and the water depth was around three feet. The area surrounding the pool consisted of dirty and cracked concrete. The Seal appeared to be dead as it was lying lifeless in the left corner of this kiddie pool. We hoped for the best and moved on. On our way out of the Zoo we stopped by to check up on him and sure enough he had not moved a centimeter (two hours had passed). In an attempt to find out if this thing had in fact passed away I threw a quarter at it. After a delayed reaction the Seal took a lap around its bucket and settled back into his familiar position. It wasn't until the drive home that we noticed in the Zoo literature that throwing coins into the water exhibits is highly dangerous for the inhabitants (I think I did the thing a favor).

Chimpanzee's - A chimp was sitting on a stump in his tree house flipping through a magazine page by page. The magazine was oriented appropriately for reading and he spent about five seconds on each page. One of the more odd things I have seen in awhile.

I could go on and on, but this review is already to long. The fact is the Zoo needs some larger exhibits for the animals. The next time I go to the Zoo it will be because my future children make me. 

P.s. - the hippo on display actually was dead...
author: Coach K.

description: We took our son to the S.F. Zoo for his first birthday and he had a blast. He had a moment with a baby giraffe. He laughed and pointed to it, and it actually separated from the adults and walked over to him. Very cute! He also enjoyed the carousel so much that he gripped the pole and we had to pry his fingers open just to get him off! My daughter had a blast too. She particularly enjoyed the flamingoes and the children's zoo. She got a kick out of brushing and feeding the goats, and getting to pet a snake.
author: Yvonne C.

description:
where sad elephants go to die.

edit:  since writing this review i've learned a little bit about the elephants i saw there, and just want to point out that i don't think the zoo actually killed these elephants.  but i did feel strongly depressed and sad roaming through the sf zoo, and the elephants stuck in my head most strongly as being sad creatures in a place they didn't belong.  i've been to many many zoos over the course of my life, and none have seemed so upsetting as this one.  but apparently much has been renovated (or is being renovated) since my visit, which has been a couple years past.  so here's holding out hope for a brighter future!
author: Sharon M.

description:
I have nothing to complain about SF Zoo.
The zoo is organized and clean.
It's free every first Wednesday every month.
Otherwise $8 for SF resident, $9 for non-SF resident, $4.50 for child.
They provide free map at the entrance.
