They also have a GPS system - like computerized map - that you can rent for $9.50 so you will not get lost and show you direction.
Now they also have employees taking photos near the entrance which you can pay later at the booth if you decide to keep the photo.
I believe it's $12/photo but they also have Package A or Package B in case you want several prints and a key chain.
I know it's expensive but if you don't want then you can bring your own camera.
They also have variety of food in side the zoo like Asian food, burger and fries, cotton candy, sandwiches, Taqueria.
You can always bring your own food too.
You may think anything sold here is pricey but hey think that as supporting the zoo because it does cost a lot to feed and maintain all those animal in good condition.
The little penguin eats herring 1 lb/day and just think how much to feed all those penguins, let alone other animals.
I hope this review will help.
author: Oribel ..

description: Watching a pair of seagulls eat all the ducklings in the penguin playground while a crowd of horrified toddlers screamed in terror was perhaps the most authentic moment I ever experienced in a zoo. We tried to intercede and stop the carnage but those seagulls were efficient. Talk about a wild kingdom finish to our visit.  All in all this zoo has improved considerably since I've lived here but it has a long way to go.  I particularly like the gorilla exhibit and they have a very nice kangaroo area.  Another troubling sight, for me, was the bald eagle who seems to sit in his tree, practically at human shoulder level, without flying away.  Are his wings clipped?  Shouldn't he be gobbling up chihuahuas in the Marina?
author: Kevin S.

description: We had a good time here today, overall. We arrived a couple of hours after opening and there was still plenty of parking...and parking was easy! The price is really reasonable, and the zoo grounds are beautiful. There were several empty exhibits, which was disappointing, and the rainforest was definitely disappointing. Nevertheless, many of the exhibits were beautiful and well-maintained, and the animals were gorgeous. I'd definitely take another trip out here.
author: Katie W.

description: Zoo's blow by nature: depressed animals standing around in cages and pens; expensive food; too many crying babies. This one is even worse than that. A lot of empty exhibits. "Well, this is where the sealions TYPICALLY are..." Expensive school cafeteria food. Gorillas sitting around crying into their hands. Just stay at home and watch NOVA instead: at least you know the animals are having a good time.
author: Molly E.

description: This is a really nice zoo, clean and the animals are not too cramped ( considering they are not free) I took my granddaughter and son and we had a great day, well worth the visit, I even bought a membership so I can go all I want for a whole year
author: mitch r.

description: This is zoo is always extremely cold, foggy, windy, and depressing. Don't patronize it... donate your money to an organization that protects animals in their real habitats. I went here for free recently on a Tuesday and jogged around the Zoo.. It's pretty sad. :( Save the elephants!!! Oh yeah, I remember the cages that the lions and tigers are in.. And they throw huge slabs of meat in. It's just so cruel. It looks like some cage from the 1920s. At least the San Diego Zoo recreates their environment!
author: O K.

description: While some zoos have taken to the idea of rebuilding in order to recreate animals' natural habitats, it seems that the SF Zoo is sticking to their roots.  The living spaces are tiny, mostly cement, and clearly geared more towards easy viewing of the animals than animal comfort.  I'm not anti-zoo, but this is sort of pathetic for a city as progressive as SF.
author: Katie S.

description: Warning, one extra star for sentimental reasons. My parent used to bring me to San Francisco Zoo at least twice a year and I fell in love. Actually my love affair with San Francisco started here. Is that bestiality?
author: patrick g.

description:
Alright haters.  This is a zoo, not a five-star restaurant.  The animals are not here to serve you, or sing and dance on demand.  

The tigers and lions were awesome and only four feet away in the lion house.  The baby gorilla was really sweet too.  The grizzly was funny playing in the water as well.  

I'd probably rank this a four since it isn't as good as the San Diego Zoo, it's still a solid showing for NorCal.  Parking is a little high, but a total of fifty dollars isn't bad for four or five hours of interesting exhibits.

Take an afternoon off and go during the week.  It is so much nicer without the crowds.
author: Matt H.

description: The portions of the zoo that have been remodeled (e.g. giraffes) are good, but older portions are in desperate need of updates.  The puffer train in the back is a highlight of every trip.  It's an authentic steam train circling the park complete with a tunnel and a fearless peacock that always seems to be on the verge of getting run over.
author: Phat P.

description: Wow.  I went to check this out one Sunday, and really had some low expectations.  Every other zoo I've ever seen has been pretty sad.  I was quite surprised.  They've obviously spent some time and money fixing the place up.  There was a very large variety of animals, and it was certainly large enough to make a day out of it.  It was quite crowded on the weekend, but that's probably to be expected.  Might be easier to just shoot for the parking on Sloat and walk down to the entrance.  I think they give a discount for SF residents or something, too.
author: Ken B.

description:
I went their last year in the summer.  Hottest day of the year.  I had to pay too much for a bottle of water.  many of the areas were under construction..

On the positive note the bear exhibit was amazing...the two bears were playing around.  The gorilla exhibit is and always was awesome.  As well as the giraffe area.
author: Vesa S.

description: It's like the little zoo that commercialism forgot.  Unlike some other zoo's I've been to there aren't a bunch of Cocacola signs plastered everywhere.  It was just a kickin good time.  We went today on July 4th so the stroller brigade was in full force, but it was FREE since it was the first Wed. of the month.  We scored free parking in the neighborhood across from the zoo, SWEET!  It was pretty crowded, but everyone was pretty much on their good behavior.  The petting farm was cool and the polar bears were in full effect.  The lemur forrest, penguin island and prairie dog mound was hilarious.  I couldn't help but think that the animals didn't look too jazzed to be there, but it could have been the heat.  FREE NIMO..sorry wrong review....
author: Chris W J.

description:
All jokes about killer lions escaping their cages and attacking zoo patrons aside, I'm not a huge fan of the SF zoo for some pretty basic reasons.

1. It's way too cold out there by the ocean.  They have a bunch of African wild animals like giraffes, lions, and rhinos who are adapted through millenia to thrive in very hot African heat.  The time we were there, it was so freakin' cold that I couldn't even stay in the open very long.  The wind was howling through there, and I could only imagine how miserable those animals must be.

2. In the lion's den, they have a rock that is heated underneath and is placed strategically in front of the viewing window.  While this is a clever way of getting the lions to not avoid people-- which they would clearly rather do-- it's also sad that such animals are forced to live in such an unnaturally cold climate.

3. The zoo is quite spread out, being mostly outdoors.  The daily lion feedings are cool, though the place gets swamped by the unwashed masses of families and their screaming kids.  Must not be very relaxing for the caged lions and tigers.  Certainly wasn't for us.

4. Oakland zoo does everything the SF zoo does, and does it better.  We noticed that the confines of the Oakland zoo were in general much more generously sized than at SF.  This means that you may not always get a direct look at the hyenas, for example, but the animals are given a lot more space to be wild hyenas.
author: Dave N.

description: I have been going to the SF Zoo since I was a child.  It is a great place to visit and make memories.  The weather isn't always ideal and it closes too early... Other than that I can't complain!
author: Jodi M.

description:
I volunteered at the zoo for 4 years (Nature Trail). It was the best experience of my life!
I am a strong believer in animal rights however I think having a zoo in a big city like SF is necessary to educate people.
Most people cannot afford to go and visit animals in their natural habitat like say Africa.  If you have this privilege..consider yourself lucky.
The first Wednesday of every month is free which is a great opportunity for low income families and school field trips. 
5 stars for education!
author: Caroline G.

description: I love coming here. I bring my kids very often. We live close by and we have a year pass. The parking lot is expensive so we park on Sloat for free and walk to the zoo. My sons love the old reconditioned little steam train. If the train is a must for your family check ahead to see if the train is running that day. On more than one occasion the train wasn't running that day and it put a big wrench in my toddlers' "plans". We love the new hippo exhibit, his name is Brian Wilson! The hippo loves a crowd and can be a lot of fun to watch in action but when he is sleeping underwater there isn't much to see. We always make sure to visit the penguins as they are very active and fun for the little ones to watch. They have a really fun petting zoo, playground, and carousel. The zoo has one major cafe that serves lunch and snacks. There is another cafe near the back of the zoo but most often they are not open. I always grab a cup of coffee from the gift shop on my way in to boost me through chasing toddlers around the zoo. If you forget your stroller they have little jeeps you can rent for the day at the gift shop. If you get a membership here you also get a discount when you visit the Oakland zoo which is also a wonderful! Personally, I think when the weather is typical SF weather, foggy and a little cold the animals come out to play.
author: Cheryl T.

description: Went on Mother's Day with a friend and was pleasantly surprised they were NOT charging admission. I mention this because had I paid admission I would have left feeling cheated. My friend who is a very talented landscaper commented on the lack of attention and how unkempt it appeared overall. We were disappointed as well in the lack of information at each animal location and most of the animals seemed tired and in many locations absent. Additionally, a good number of the animal cages had signs indicating they were under renovation and there was no animal to see. Having been to the San Diego Zoo where the energy level is poppin,' it was like night and day. I've also been to the Riverbanks Zoo in Columbia, South Carolina and it is much better than our San Francisco zoo by a mile. A shame really. To me, it's a zoo that has much potential.
author: mark z.

description:
we actually just went here the other day with some friends.  i thought they fixed this place up?? wtf? everything looked pretty old and run down.  

it is a pretty big zoo...but they really need to do some landscaping and cleaning.  looks more like "escape from new york" than a zoo.  a lot of the animal exhibits make you really feel bad for the animals.  it's like they're in some sort of "ghetto zoo" or something.  i think i saw a peacock straight jack a little kid for their pink popcorn.
author: Craig I.

description:
Absolute crap in terms of space. The first time I visited this zoo in 2002 I *refused* to visit the pacyderms just after seeing the venerable warehouse they were stored in. Sure enough, a couple years later one dies in captivity for to apparent reason other than being a prisoner. Seriously, this zoo has enough space for an atrium for birds, maybe a few monkeys with red-asses, an ant farm, and that's it.

Fast-forward to July 2007 and my 2nd visit to this prison and I was seriously looking at the cat cage and thinking to myself, gee these guys can jump out anytime they want; I'm out. Well 'lo and behold...

Common sense must tell you that if you want big animals in captivity, then you need big space to keep 'em. Now I present Exhibit A: The NC Zoo in Ashboro. Hell, I recall as a kid, my ass required a quarter and a boost to the binoculars to view the big African elephants. Here's how one should view such animals in captivity: http://www.nczoo.org/tour/photo_ar_plains.cfm.

To hell with this prison. Free after 4pm or not, I'm done with the SF Zoo, and I suggest you are the same, regardless of the taunting thugs.

If you want something do do in that neck of the woods on the weekend, go to Stern Grove for free on Sundays, otherwise take your kids to the beach, maybe catch a glimpse of a whale in the wild, imagine that, wildlife, in the *wild*.
author: Charles S.

description:
Everyone---  see article on bottom from the Chronicle about the zoo now only allowing SF residents to attend the zoo for free the first Wednesday of the month, those not from the city, you are NOT ALLOWED...

Now how pathetic is THIS? I sent two emails to the zoo inquring about this, but none were answered. Twice before,I was a former member of the zoo for a year each time. Periodically, I receive renewal notices in the mail, asking us to rejoin. 

How does the zoo handle some people taunting the animals? Surely, the docents, and security people could handle some kids who are hyperactive (and remove them from the zoo if needed)  or in more serious cases, contact law enforcement.

But, let's discriminate against those who don't live in the city? From Daly City, Marin, East Bay, San Mateo, you have to pay. How does this even remotely deal with the problem of people taunting the animals? 

If you feel that "free day" causes issues then eliminate it across the board.

We certainly won't be returning as a member or as a paying guest. After the tragic incident with the tiger last year, I would think that they would try to effectively deal with the problem. Sadly, their way is to make absurd policies that don't accomplish anything, and ignore emails thinking that this will help their cause. 

Boycott the zoo, at it's best , it was a 2nd class zoo anyway. 
====================================================
From the San Francisco Chronicle:

The San Francisco Zoo will restrict its once-a-month free admission program to city residents only beginning in September, officials said Friday. 

Currently, anyone can visit the zoo for free on the first Wednesday of the month. The program is popular, attracting up to five times the average number of visitors.

Zoo officials said they were changing the free-day program because there has been a notable increase in visitors taunting, teasing and shouting at animals on those days, particularly since a tiger escaped Christmas Day and fatally mauled a San Jose teenager. 

The zoo will continue to provide free admission to a number of school groups, nonprofits and participants in other city programs. 

Residents will have to show proof of residency, such as a valid driver's license, state identification card or a bill with their home address on it.
author: G L.

description: need to be updated a bit ...do like the different animals
author: Inez M.

description: I don't like zoos. I don't like seeing animals caged up and trapped inside their small habitats. I'd rather see them out in the wild (hopefully not gobbling up human beings lol).
author: Michelle B.

description:
came here on friday dec 12, 08 for our bio240 field trip.

like many others have said, what a sad zoo. there arent many animals to see. lots of exhibits were closed. and all the animals were just sad looking. 


extra high barricades and fences made it difficult to take pictures, and there were no food vendors open. dont think ill ever come back to this zoo. good thing we got in for free, id be pretty upset if we had to pay the $15 general admission fee
author: David D.

description:
I've been a fan of the SF Zoo for a long time.  It may not be the most prime location for many of the animals (nearby Ocean Beach is nowhere near an African Savannah-like environment); But, I think it brings the city back to 'nature' as a constant reminder that just cuz you live in a big populous, urban environment, doesn't mean you can't appreciate wildlife!  It's become quite trendy and very crowded in the past years, especially since the renovation.  But still, I am always forced to slow down and appreciate the surroundings.  I think they've really got a great educational setting for city and peninsula kids, and a great program for teens, pre-teens to volunteer while learning about different animals of the world;  By extension, they promote conservation, land stewardship and generel awareness and appreciation of diversity.  That can't be a bad thing, right?  My favorite exhibit - Primates baby!  

The zoo has come a long way in creating exciting new events for old and young alike with lecture series, special member events and children-focused events, too.
author: Olma M.

description: This is a cute place to come with family or friends. I always find it amusing since I come every once in a long while. The animals are cute but I guess sometimes you feel bad for them cause they've been stuck in cages forever. The food in the cafeteria is a tad bit overpriced, so minus 1 star for that. But it's a cool little traditional place to stroll around, and it's free sometimes, too. That situation about the tigers was sad though, poor thing :(
author: M J.

description:
This place was really run down a few years ago.  It is really obvious that all of the work is not done, but it's starting to look good.
The African exhibit was the best.  Two baby giraffes, 3 adults, zebras, ostriches, cranes, and other safari animals all in one walkabout.  The layout really let us get close.
The gorillas are still there, funny as ever.  They also have three baby Tigers on display now.  
However, since the tragedy in the tiger area, it now resembles a prison rather than a zoo.  That area looks scary and I miss the old one.  It worked for so many years without problems!  Now there are also signs around the park reminding those stupid punks that animals are sensitive and have feelings too...
I might wait a few years to return based on all of the empty exhibits.  I did see a new grizzly bear exhibit, but it was empty.  The lemur exhibit was also new and pretty nice.  
The zoo is a nice way to spend a day in SF without a lot of cash.
author: Kerry K.

description: i love zoos no matter what. Even though i like the zoo in San Diego. Going to S.F. zoo was great. Getting up and close with a female lion was awesome. The farm animal area was great petting the farm animals. Also funny when they would go after you when you had food in your hand.
author: maria l.

description: My kids still get a kick out of this place, but every time I go there, the Zoo really grinds my gears! The amount of money they collect should be spend on the animals, not their opulent management and special interests that blatantly feed off this place. Animals housing is either outdated and cramped or built with no regards to the animals contained. The Oakland Zoo does a hell of a lot more for its animals with a lot less money - visit them instead.
author: Degustator J.

description:
WHA WHA WHA, the animals live in poo, they don't get fed, WHA WHA WHA! Shut up! The animals love the zoo. I love the zoo. dumb ass kids could have loved the zoo, but they were being dumb, that is a lesson for everyone... don't be dumb, it's horrible to have happened, but seriously, when dealing with things that can eat you, act smart. That is besides the point and only my opinion, but it is sad the have to constantly hear about it all day sunday. Ok that part of my rant is done.

HOLY HOP'N HIPPO'S BAT MAN I LOVE THE ZOO! Sunday parking was a cluster f**k. We arrived in time to see the little pinguines eat! It was neat! The otters were sleeping all cozy and cute. The grizzly bears got a new habitat! SWEET! They were all cute and cuddly and playing in the water! BEARS! THe polar bears came out too! TO POOP! Lions were lazy! tigers were playful. Koalas were... being themselves. Kids were annoying! Lets lock kids up in the zoo instead. I saw the zoo chuck full of zoo keepers, care takers, and volunteers more than happy to answer any question that could have come up. Even the dumb questions we asked... The animals get taken care of very well at the zoo, and if you pansy ass cry babies don't think so, why don't you try and volunteer at to zoo and see how well they are taken care of instead of just bitching about things you want to see differently but are too lazy to do anything about... The zoo has changed sooo much since I have been a little kid, and it has changed for the better. They are constantly making imporvements for the animals so you can better enjoy them. Instead of complaing about the zoo, and feeling bad, donate your time or money in order to get changes made. I LOVE THE ZOO. I especially like the birds of prey, I need to watch that show. Owls are neat. We got to see baby giraffes in side their own custom built barn! It was 4 months old and taller than me! I'm 6'2" Taller than ME!

Lemurs are amazing cool, and have like a whole jungle gym with jungle in it.

I really do love the ZOO.

ZOO!

they update the big cat habitat now, it's a shame it happened, but sure it should have been updated a long time ago I guess, but I have been going for 24 years and I've never had a problem. 

ZOO!
author: danny e.

description: I remember the zoo in the hey day, or maybe i  was just so little and it seemed like a hey day, but so much of the old architecture is closed. While they might have the savanna enclosure, the pachiderms house is closed and looks like a ghost town as with many of the enclosures for other animals and it's just....sad. I understand why and it is still a place to see animals but it makes you sad for the animals. I love the SF zoo and would go everyday of the week to see the animals if I could but I just wish the old vibrancy was there.
author: sophie p.

description:
Ya know, I expected much better. I was underwhelmed to the point of being just a little sad for SF residents. I'm originally from Memphis and there is not much about that town that is better,excluding BBQ. However, the zoo is one of those places. The exhibits were so clean they didn't even have animals in them! I didn't see anything that made me stop. The best part were the statues of animals on foamy stuff so you could climb on them. I would also like to know what's up with the bald eagle there. Are it's wings clipped? Does it just have an overwhelming ennui? I was able to walk within 5 ft. of an endangered species and our national bird and it just stared at me like, what?
I'm sure the kids will have fun but if you really want to go to a good zoo without travelling your screwed. I can't give it 1 star because after all it does have animals and I didn't get attacked, ohh wait that already happened...
author: Greg H.

description:
my boyfriend surprised me and took me here cause i've been begging to go .. so one friday we finally went.. i was super excited.. 

i loved all the monkeys. but very disappointed when i didnt get to see a rhino, elephant or hippo. & when we went all the tigers, lions and bears were sleeping :( 

i had a good time and surprisingly we walked around for 4 hours. good enough to work up an appetite. but i don't recommend eating here.. overpriced food. might as well bring your own snacks or eat somewhere else.
author: Jay C.

description:
While I agree with other visitors that this zoo is a bit of a let down, I have to say that through the eyes of a 3 year old, the zoo is the shiznit!  My DD loves to go there.  She often will wake up on a Saturday morning and say, "Mommy, Daddy, can we go to the zoo?  Please?  I want to see the bugs." 

The children's zoo area is a blast.  We rarely even make it to the other areas of the zoo because we hit the African Safari area, the gorillas and then head over to the children's zoo.  

The area by the penguins is really depressing so we don't go over there.  It's really an old school type display and just kind of gives me that yucky feeling.  The bear displays are also pretty damned depressing.

The zoo is small enough that if we don't get there until 1pm we have time to enjoy everything.  

I do like the farm animal area and my DD enjoys using the wheel barrows and the little brooms.

If my DD could rate it she'd give it a 5 stars.  I've been to the San Diego Zoo, so there is no way I could give this zoo 5 stars :)
author: Jazz E.

description: A nice zoo, good for a couple hours or killing time with visitors (most common reason to visit for us). There always seems to be animals missing or hiding though - it can get a tad tedious at times, especially if you've already been there before. But it's certainly worth checking out regardless. If you go on the weekend on a sunny day, parking will be hell in the afternoons.  Parking is usually pretty open if the weather isn't the best and in the mornings. Make sure you go way down to the southwest(ish) corner to see the big cats - if you're lucky they won't be sleeping or hiding. Saw a fishing cat "catch" and eat a fish. One time a snow leopard was sprinting back and forth in the cage - it was really cool to see, but pretty sad at the same time.  Remember to bring your fancy zoom lens or binoculars if you have them.
author: Jen D.

description: i thought this zoo was WAY BETTER than the LA zoo.....maybe they're feeding their animals coffee beans or something but some of the nocturnal animals (which usually are ALL asleep&inactive&not visible during normal zoo hrs) were actually awake&roaming around. so the visit here was surprisingly more fun than my other zoo visits in other cities. to me, a zoo visit is not a zoo visit if all you get to see are grazing prey animals eating grass in the sun. a zoo visit is seeing tigers&koalas&other COOL nocturnal animals. thank you.
author: Dth S.

description: Today my kids and I went to the San Francisco Zoo, we had a Fantastic time!!! I always look forward to Weekend's with my Girls, it's pure Joy!!!
author: Rod C.

description: had my 5-yr old son's birthday here and they did a fantastic job. highly recommend it... it was a huge hit
author: Matthew C.

description: I like visiting zoos very much, but for some reason this one always has a lot of empty exhibits.  The grounds are nice and well kept, but I'd like to see more animals.  Sorry for the low rating, but compared to others I've visited, San Francisco's version is pretty weak.
author: Sara A.

description: This was the last place my (ex)boyfriend took me before he left me for someone else. Good thing I'm better off or I would have been as depressed as half these animals here! A good experience, though, to walk around and see things we never get to see in good ole' SF.
author: haley d.

description: This review is for the Zoo's new Grizzly Gulch exhibit. While I'm not particularly a fan of zoos, I've learned the young bears that now call the SF Zoo home were saved from a worse fate. They were apparently to be euthanized in the upper midwest because they were exhibiting troublesome behavior in the wild, as in they were approaching homes in search of food. (Aren't we all glad our trip to the refrigerator doesn't end the same way.) So... it seems the SF Zoo's offer to take them in made all the difference in the outcome of this story.
author: a p.

description: The zoo is a great activity for a kinda cold sunday afternoon when you have nothing to do.  Buy a coffee and walk around and see the animals! It is a great way to catch up with your friends about the weekend and do something you haven't done since you were a kid.  Lions and tigers are no less interesting to look at 10 years later. And its only $9 with a SF address.
author: Bridget B.

description: Seems like a pretty nice zoo. It's been decades since I've been to one so I don't have a lot to compare it to. I always feel somewhat conflicted as the animals have such small, but nice areas. But then I think at least there safe from predators and all that. I don' t know much about Polar Bears but thought that they liked cold weather but they were out in the sun chillin. The Grizzly Gulch was cool. Is that an electric fence around them though?  It's funny how local animals  integrate themselves into all the enviornments. Ducks with Prarie Dogs, Ducks with Penguins, Ducks with Polar Bears! They get around :) And squirrels in with the monkeys!
author: Carolyn P.

description: I had a fabulous day at the SF Zoo. The animals looks healthy. Most were chowing on snacks or taking naps in the sun. I saw the new gorilla baby boy and even watched a gorilla playfully run around with a bucket on his head. A tall giraffe happily scratched its neck on a tall palm tree. Enjoyed the Puffer steam train. Snacked at the cafe and watched countless children have a ball. It as wonderful!
author: Christina G.

description:
SF Zoo needs to close.  I went there during one of those very rare warm days and it was packed with families and tourists.  I can only imagine what it's like on a Wed. when the only people there are school kids and seniors out for a walk in the bitter cold and fog.
Many of the main exhibits were closed and the ones that were open seemed poorly maintained.  The soil these poor creatures were walking on was dry as the Sahara Desert; lacking in both moisture and green vegetation.
I am a skeptic when it comes to zoos and I'll save those arguements for the PETA people.
One thing that tipped me off about the lack of attention this place gets is the signs by each animal, that was authored by a zoo attendant.  Many were hand written, which is fine, in 2005 and 2006.  Hello?
Also I like to learn a few things at a zoo so I look forward to reading the informational sign by each "cage".  It was definitely geared towards kids with short attention spans because they contained two or three sentences.  Let down!  (Oakland Zoo goes much more in depth)
Please close SF Zoo!  SF is not in the business of running a zoo.
author: David A.

description: I'm not much of a zoo person, so maybe I just won't be surprised no matter which I go to. They have tigers, bears, lions and all of that here though, and I'm guessing it contains more than most other zoos around the area. I have to see the koalas because they are super adorable!!! But unless I'm amazed, it'll stay at 3 stars anywhere.
author: Elaine H.

description: We were really looking forward to our first visit to the SF zoo, and we were completely dissapointed.  It's just soooooo glomy, and it's littered all around.  I will not go back.
author: Miriam S.

description: A mixed review-- 4 stars for the grounds (smart array of trees, some nice, newer tiling/stonework, ubiquitous child-friendly bathrooms ), but 2 stars for the depressing "exhibits" and buildings.  Cramped, outdated, sparsely-maintained cages made me pity the poor beasts (especially the lions), and the children's zoo was ho-hum at best.  The playground was a big hit with my kids (who doesn't like sand?), but that, too, was in need of some basic repair.  A highlight was the Little Puffer Train ride and the giraffes (sooo close to you).  Unfortunately, the Bronx Zoo has spoiled me...
author: siobhan s.

description: If   you're really into zoo's and animals pleeeze dont be surprised if you end up being disappointed such as me. The lack of character in this zoo is just amazing. Its as if they built a zoo on a bare minimum mentality. Seriously.....trash floods the sidewalks at certain areas of the park. Lack of animals is something too, and the animals they do have seem to have nothing to keep themselves entertained so basically you're going around and watching animals sleep. They seem sick, habitats seem damn small, pretty filthy looking.  Everything and I mean EVERYTHING needs to be touched up, modernized, and just all around needs attention.  Irwin, Hannah, and Corwin would probably puke. Its sad that a great, loving city such as san fran has settled for the bottom of the barrel when it comes to their zoo. As I said, they seem to have put the bare minimum in what it takes to have, run, and maintain a zoo. They even sell beer there which is funny. Who in the shit needs beer at a damn zoo ??? They need two things. A.)    A bailout or B.)  Start from scratch.  For San Francisco, the parking was pretty good. Just park on the outside and save ten bucks. I usually donate money to zoo's as well, and I was looking around and thinking to myself. "Well this zoo obviously shows that their donations are going into someones pocket rather than the animals and the parks well being."  I mean dont get me wrong, its a great way to spend a day and look at a FEW animals. But overall, very, very disappointing.
author: Lonnie G.

description: This place is okay-if you live in SF go on a free day. Otherwise, don't bother. The zoo beefed up their security and cages since that awful incident, so now you can feel safer.
author: Janae L.

description: The gorillas were awesome.  For sentimental reasons I think I prefer the Toledo Zoo, but this place is most definitely better than the Detroit Zoo.  It was pretty easy to see everything that was worth seeing in 3.5 hours or so (got there late in the day).
author: Dave M.

description: Had the "new" outdoor grilled food at the Zoo, and it was delicious!  I was happy to see sustainable and local items.  Also, my kids loved the tarantula exhibit, which has a month-long extension. And the live feeding of the Grizzly Bears was at its best!!!
author: Tanya M.

description: Sad, sad zoo...not because of the poor tiger that they had to shoot last year but because the animals look sad.  Not sure if it's because of the weather too, but I'd rather take my son to the Oakland Zoo.  The exhibits look run down and not well kept.
author: Nathalie C.

description: We had our wedding at the zoo.  Carol Mann, the Catering Sales Manager, was spectacular!  She was supportive and extremely attentive to detail.  The whole day was absolutely beautiful and fun!  Thank you to the zoo staff and especially to Carol!
author: Erin T.

description: This is a great place to visit especially on a sunny day. If you are a resident of SF, you could go there the first Wednesday of each month. it is free. Don't forget to bring the proof of residency.
author: Erica C.

description:
I also am a member mainly due the fact the my four year old loves to go to this place and see the animals and ride the train etc.. My wife has been taking him on a regular basis over the past six months. Today his school was closed and Mom had to work so Daddy got to take him to the zoo today. I was shocked at the changes since the last time I was there. The place looks really run down and I was shocked by some of the price changes. The Little Puffer train used to be $3 per person now it's $4. Parking on the inside lot used to be $6 now it's $8. In the childrens petting zoo the food for the goats used to be 25 cents now it's 50 cents and you get about 1/2 a handful of food. 
I guess the zoo is trying to raise revenue to pay for the lawsuit from the kid killed by the tiger last year. They certainly are not spending the money to improve any of the exibits or grounds. 
I got really pissed on the way out when I stopped to pay for parking and the automatic machine was broken and I'm waiting in a line 10 people deep to get my parking ticket and I'm listening to the two old hens behind the counter talk to each other about some Jazz festivale and moving like snails.
I think the zoo should be closed and fixed and cleaned up. As a homeowner in SF I would be more than happy to pay an extra parcel tax for a couple of years to raise the money to do this. I think we should have zoo that is on the same level as San Diego. I guess the leaders in this city are more concerned about who is getting married to who. 
My two cents. I would still go but bring your own lunch, park on the street and bring your own goat pellets.
author: Baron S.

description: I went back recently with the 2 lil ones and we all had a great time - maybe from my low expectations.  The highlight was really the brand new playground, which i would say is almost worth the admission itself.  We were also lucky to go on a slow day, 12/24.  We saw most of the animals we were looking for including the adorable koala, Austin.  The staff throughout were lovely, paying special attention to our 3 yr old, and helped enhance our experience with the animals.  I still cant go above 3 stars, though, because their food is so awful, and in a place like Sf, just inexcusable.  Stay away from those animal shaped bottle drinks.  Neither kid could drink this--weird and chemical.
author: Bonny C.

description: I was shocked to see that the zoo gets such low ratings.  We had a great time here on the last day of our honeymoon.  Yes, there were some displays that were under renovation, but that happens at any zoo.  And some days the animals were active, others they aren't.  I was happy since I got to see some kangaroos jump and the peacocks that were wandering around the grounds were pretty cool.  A great way to spend a lazy day, especially in the middle of the week when it isn't crowded!
author: Derek A.

description:
the only downfall of this Is the cost. its a bit pricey. but the experience is awesome. you definately need to plan your entire day there. its pretty big. make sure you bring walking shoes too. fun for all ages. I'd go again. as long as someone else pays.

oh and when it comes to parking, there's a lot across the street on the beach. park there and you save 8 bucks. admission alone is 15 per adult.
author: Samm V.

description: Where are the animals? This place is kinda depressing. Of course the damn animals are getting out because they don't want to be there either... Please someone do something with this place... make it beautiful again like when I was little!!!   ;(
author: Serina H.

description: I used to absolutely love going to the zoo when I was a little.  I loved looking at the animals.  My parents would take us on the first Wednesday of the month (it's free!).  Now, I take my nephew when I can.  We took him this past Saturday on the Zooparents day.  Sure, parts of the zoo are a little rundown, but they're slowly making improvements.  I mean, the area for the giraffes and zebras looks really nice now.  And it was the first time I've ever ridden on the little puffer steam train.  Wow, that thing goes fast!  I don't think it's worth $3 a person for a ride (good thing we got to go on for free), but it's something.  This place has nothing on the San Diego Zoo, but it's pretty good for SF.
author: Kris L.

description: Great zoo to beat the heat of the east bay in the summertime.  A lot of walking to get around, but the ocean breeze is divine.  The petting zoo is nice.
author: Matthew P.

description:
we came here today with the kids,and they had a great time.  i'm glad we went on a friday,'cause it wasn't that busy.  it's true some animals seemed sad, but than i think to myself that the zookeepers must be taking good care of them.  
i'm glad i came here with my kids.
author: Cutiepie B.

description:
So being a born and raised San Francisco child, I have fond memories of the Zoo-those special nights where I sat atop my daddy's shoulders and fed the giraffe's, watching their long tongues wrap around the twiggy leaf clutched in my hand...oh how I loved feeding those beauties. 
I recently went back to the zoo, and was a little sad. the animals didn't seem as happy, the cages seemed cagey...not like the habitats of the Bronx Zoo, for example. The Zoo honestly seemed a little rundown, although the new exhibits did look amazing, they did not counterbalance the old. However, the things exhibits and animals that make a smile come to my face because of the memories connected to them, are still there...so here is why I still love the SF Zoo in no particular order
1. the plastic zoo keys (shaped like animals and control the informational boxes...yes, I still have mine from when I was 4)
2. the carousel, the sea horse and unicorn ones are my favorite
3. penguins...need I say more? they are just adorable
4. flamingos ...I could spend hours watching them
5. giraffe's....even without feeding them, they are adorable
6. zebras....am I white with black stripes,or black with white stripes?
7. OTTERS!!! ok...yes, they are my favorite
8. the petting zoo....hey, you can pet them,brush them and feed them....and what about those baby chicks? how cute are they?
9. the climbing spider web.... I got myself tangled in that on more than one occasion
10. peacocks running around everywhere...*peacock was my first word, so I obviously love them
11. the train...gotta love the zoo train
12. insect display...oh those creepy crawlers get me everytime
13. groundhogs ...prairie dogs....CUTE
14. the gift shop...I can;t leave the zoo without buying some sort of animal related item....I'm a sucker, I know
15. hippos!!!
16. elephants
17. lions and tigers and bears, oh my!
17....ok, really, I could list forever, but the Zoo is still a place to make memories that you will treasure forever
author: Bianca L.

description:
what a sad spot...  there were more pigeons and seagulls than anything else...
can't go to any zoos anymore 
i've already been to the world's greatest zoo in singapore....
author: charlotte s.

description: I was in San Franciso for work and figured I'd see the zoo on a lazy Sunday. Warning don't go hungry- the only things that eat the food at the zoo are the sea gulls. With San Francisco being such a progressive city I assumed that the zoo would be a "must see" rather an avoid at all costs. At a zoo like this even the animals are depressed, hell I would be too if I was caged in that rat hole with the balls to still charge $8 for a drink and $15 dollars for admission, do me a favor take my money and buy a "closed" sign.
author: Nathan C.

description: First of all... bring your walking shoes. Better yet, go buy some inserts for your shoes so you'll be "gellin" all day. Parking is  horrible. The parking places to cars ratio is like 5%. You have to end up parking a mile away, up a hill, IF u are lucky. By the time u get there, u are exhausted. I took my kids here for one of their birthdays and it was a big let down. The giraffe exhibit was really neat but everything else pretty much sucked. Its a big area to walk around to see everything and its soooooo not worth the time, energy, money, etc. you be better off going to Marine World, or the Monterey Aquarium to see their animal exhibits.
author: Aarica C.

description: After watching Madagascar and Happy Feet, I don't think I can look at Zoo's the same anymore. It was kinda depressing seeing the animals on display in their fake habitats meanwhile people are staring and pointing taking pictures + whatnot. I haven't been to this zoo since I was in 6th grade but I remember a very different zoo back then. I think my 6th grade experience was a lot better because well...I was in 6th grade... but after growing up and becoming a lil more conscious about things I've had a bit of resentment to these sort of places. Not so much the protecting/caring that they do for the animals, but the commercial side of it leaves my mouth kinda bitter..
author: Adrian S.

description: First off let me say I am NOT a zoo person. Animals are eh, and most of em stink so that makes them ew. lol ...However, I have two small kids, and to them the Zoo is the shizz. We frequent the San Francisco Zoo a few times a year. Same old shizz different day right? Eh not so much. The location is awesome, and lately it seems as if we're timing it so new animals come or go. My favorite Zoo moment, um the rhino with the giant "happy to see you" body part hanging out. Try explaining that to a 7 year old...child:"Mommy what is that???"  Me: "Um huh?, what???...Let's go find your sister now." Phew, close call!
author: Erica A.

description: Recently, my family and I visited the San Francisco Zoo for the first time and had a great time. I'd heard that it wasn't that great and that the Oakland Zoo was better. Whatever the case, it was awesome. There were plenty of animals to see and the zoo exceeded my expectations. We would visit again.
author: R. G.

description:
The SF Zoo is pretty cool. They have a wide selection of animals. Some of favorite things to do is go to the petting zoo first, because I like to feed the goats, and sheep, then I like to check out the Insect Zoo. I love the insect zoo, because I used to raise a few insects myself growing up.

 Then I like to head over to the South American room. You have to go through a double door to conserve heat. When you go in if you have glasses, sometimes your glasses will start getting foggy. I love to check out the fishes like the pacu, and the arrowona. The cool thing is the arrowna is gold I think, They also added some live birds to the room, and my favorite the huge green anaconda.
author: Mike h.

description: I'm morally opposed to keeping animals in a zoo and it seems the tigers are too...
author: Quartknee K.

description:
I'll preface this by saying I came to this zoo all the time as a kid, and it's always been dear to my heart.  I'm only giving it 4 stars, because while it's still great, there is a lot of room for improvement.

Despite the bad points, the pros far outweigh them, and this zoo is still great. If I had kids I would take them there in a second.  And the more of us that do that, the more money they'll have to finish renovating and fixing the problem areas.

Oh and for people that complain about admission prices, it's 1/3 the cost of Great America, goes to a great cause, and helps make our world a better place.

First off the cool parts:
1.  The new African Savannah is awesome.  Having the Giraffes, Zebras, Ostriches and other animals together is great, and there's never a dull moment.  The young Giraffes are so much fun to watch.
2.  Children's petting zoo.  Always a crowd pleaser.
3.  The Penguins. OMG they're so much fun to watch.  The SF ZOO has one of the most vibrant penguin communities in captivity, and it's paid off.  Tons of young and active penguins zooming around and frolicking.  The penguin keepers seem to be more visibile and participatory with the public than in any other exhibit, you can tell they love their jobs.  Don't miss feeding time!
4.  The Primates.  Though it's starting to show it's age, the primate habitat is still great, with a large diversity of monkeys, gorillas, chimpanzees, squirrel monkeys, etc, all fairly active even on a cold day.
5.  Lemurs.  Seem to spend a lot of their time sleeping, but man are they adorable.  They sleep in clumps, where all you'll see are heads and tails poking out.
7. Avian Conservation Center.  It's near the children's zoo, and is a great opportunity to see large raptors up close and personal.
8. Praire Dogs and Meerkats.  It's like watching a town of speed addicts. Fun Times :)

Now the bad or in need of improvement:
1.  The ancient bear habitats.  The Grizzlies now have a new enclosure that is great, but the rest of the bears are still stuck in concrete enclosures from the 1940's.  They all seem to be alone and old.  I'm sure they still have their good days, but it just felt depressing.
2.  The lack of cats.  They still have tigers and snow leopards and lions.  But except for one forest river cat (who caught a fish for dinner!), all the small cats were gone, as a result of what seems to be a frivolous ADA lawsuit regarding the great habitat built for them in the '90s.
3.  Awful *AWFUL* food.  Last time I was at the Zoo, there was at least a semblance of decent, healthy food.  This time around, at least when we tried to get food (around 3), well just think luke-warm burgers and hot dogs.  Get food before or after the zoo.  They need to take a hint from the dining experience at the SF Academy of Sciences.
4.  Lack of visible keepers/docents.  Other than the penguin and raptor keepers, I don't believe I saw a single other docent or keeper interacting with the public.  A little interaction goes a long way in building support for animal conservation.  I know they still do a lot of school outreach programs, so kudos to them for that.
5.  Large parts of the zoo were fenced off.  Not sure what the deal with that was, they may just be renovating the area where the african animals used to be, but have no idea since there were no informative signs.
6.  Lack of information displays.  While many of the new or renovated habitats had great displays with information on the animals and their conservation status, there were a lot of animals that seemed to get little attention.  It felt tragic that here we'd have these animals in captivity, under the guise of conservation and education, but for their to be so little effort to educate the public about them.
7.  What's the deal with the tiny concrete pool for the Grey Seal?
author: Kevin O.

description:
Unfair parking charges - There is AMPLE parking in this area, and nothing else of significance to see in this part of the city. They should/could slightly increase membership rates to include free or deeply discounted parking, or offer a premium membership which includes free parking. This is just a rip-off, plain and simple. Given toddler's nap schedules and limited energy, it is not a good use of time to walk the extra distance to the street parking. I feel extorted every time, and wonder why the hell I have a membership anyway.

Not pedestrian friendly - The maps indicate lots of paths available which appear shorter, but I consistently encounter "authorized personnel only" signs. Why is so much of the zoo closed off? Again, since the zoo is primarily for families, who often have small children, it seems obvious that they should try to reduce the amount of wandering around that people have to do.  I can't describe how many times I got repeatedly frustrated going in circles trying to get somewhere, only to give up and find that I had to walk the long way due to poor signs or closed paths (ex: paths behind the Lion fountain).  The maps have color coded walking paths - why not paint special feet on the asphalt with the different animal footprints so that the real world actually matches the map? Another  suggestion: install one-way exit gates so that people can exit directly from the petting zoo areas or other parts of the zoo onto Sloat.  Again, maybe they don't want to do this because that would reduce the incentive to pay extra for parking.

Photos Lost - I got a photo taken on the train, which never showed up online. I searched all the images from that day and it's not there. I emailed for assistance and got no response. That block of pictures simply wasn't uploaded. What a disappointment that was!

Photo ID hassles - I am continuously frustrated when I have to show ID at the gate. It is impossible to carry a toddler, push a twin stroller, have everything in the diaper bag, and have to stop to dig out ID.  I don't want to carry my ID in my pocket for fear of it falling out and getting lost. Sometimes my pants don't even have pockets to make this an option (after all, I just had twins, so my pants options are limited).  What would be so difficult about putting a photo ON the membership card itself?  Or have a scanner so that the person at the kiosk can swipe/scan the card and have the family photo appear?  It just sends the wrong message, implying that I DON'T belong, and I am NOT valued.. I certainly don't feel welcomed when I have to dig out ID.

Poor food options - overpriced and terrible food, especially for toddlers. They need healthier options and some better vegetarian options would be nice too. The burrito place is horrifically slow and expensive.

The exhibits are run down and depressing, as others have said. The penguins really smell bad. 

To add insult to injury - I attempted to contact the membership office over a month ago with this feedback, and received ZERO response. Not even a form letter. They clearly have no interest in hearing feedback or making improvements. I wouldn't be sad if this zoo just closes one day - it's not worth our community support, at least not until their attitude changes.

Plusses: the playground, the petting farm though it's still unnecessarily indirect to walk there).
author: Lester N.

description: I took my family to the San Francisco Zoo 2 weeks ago and we had a GREAT time. The staff and vendors were very friendly and very helpful.
author: John W.

description:
i've never liked this zoo. but there's one reason why i'm giving two stars. 

High School school year - i don't exactly remember when, but i think it was my sophmore year where we had a class field trip to the Zoo for fun. I don't exactly know what was the reason to visit the zoo. at first i hated the fact that a High school class would visit the zoo as a field trip. i came to this place thinking it was some boring place. and in fact it was true. 

the gift shop cost a billion dollars and everything is like over 10 bucks. the food stand also has prices of baseball stadiums. the place was filled with animal smells. it definitely looks like one of those zoos where the government didn't give much budget for.  
 
the reason i gave it 2 stars  was because of childhood memories when i was a kid, way before high school. i still have a few pictures of my parents bringing me to the zoo when i was kid. props to that, otherwise i wouldn't bother going to the zoo ever again
author: Eric Y.

description: I really expected much much mucho.  I remember coming here when I was a wee girl and I wasn't too thrilled but I thought maybe it has changed......NO it hasn't.  My daughter seemed to like the train ride more than seeing the animals.  I was disappointed because they had no stinking elephants or lions.  I think the highlight for me was the cute mommy & baby giraffes and the peacocks running wild.  Luckily my friend is a member so we got in FREE...now you can't beat that with a bat.
author: Natacha M.

description: While it may not measure up to the World Famous San Diego Zoo,it's still worth paying a visit to the San Francisco Zoo. It's improved much since the late 1980s when all the animals were locked up in cages,now they're all visible through glass displays. Don't leave San Francisco without stopping here. Be sure to arrive early so you can be guaranteed to get a parking space.
author: Leo T.

description: Good price, free on Wednesdays, good for a couple or even a family.  Not much animals to see and it's tough in San Francisco weather.  Overall, I would recommend it since it is a good price, well worth it's try!
author: Brian Y.

description: Every word of my original review stands and I give the animals who live there 5 stars plus!  and most of the Keepers rock!   Everyone above Keepers get minus stars.  The management there is horrible.  Up until last month I was a three times a week visitor/member so I know all the players and all the games. ... Last month my Membership of many years was revoked.  Canceled and fee refunded, without reason.  I have requested the Director provide me with a reason in writing and a month later I have yet to receive that.  I have contacted a City Supervisor, two Zoo Board Members, a Prak and Rec Commissioner, and the Mayor, no one involved with the Zoo is professional enough to give a reason or investigate this crime.  Instead they let an injustice like this be committed against myself and a friend of mine, both of us who have been great friends to the Zoo.  If you would like more information about this San Francisco Zoo Crime,  please view my video and read my blog for details  watch - http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=37Q2IONIngA & read - http://sanfranciscozoocrime.blogspot.com/  ... via this blog you can also view my blogs and photosite where I share all my knowledge and photos of my beloved San Francisco Zoo Friends, the Animals who live there.
author: misskim f.

description: Although educational, I can't get past the depressing state of the confined animals. Watched a hawk start in on a bunny and haven't slept right since.
author: Rachel B.

description: I was very disappointed with SF Zoo.  I was trying to plan my son's 2nd birthday there and they said they will work with you in prices and details but yet when I was trying to talk to them about pricing they suddenly don't have an answer for me and was not willing to help.  I was very disappointed.
author: May A.

description: I LOVE the zoo! Sometimes not all the animals are there. When we eat in the cafe, I always get the yummy garlic fries. The food in there are a little pricey, but I guess they need to make money somehow. I still have my blue elephant key when I got it in elementary school. Hehehe. The zoo will never be the same for me now that I know a tiger escaped its grotto.

We visited the zoo on a Monday. There was plenty of parking available, way better than visiting on a free day due to the lack of parking spaces and large crowds. It has been around 2 years since our last visit and have noticed some improvements and changes here and there.  
The gift shop looks like it has been expanded and there is plenty of goodies to choose from, but most items were too expensive for my taste. 
The giraffe exhibit is by far the best. It's nice how they have a variety of animals in the exhibit instead of just one. The most depressing of the exhibits is the lion, tiger, rhino and bears.  They are too small, dirty looking, and looks more like a prison than a natural habitat.  The chimp exhibit looks more like a jungle gym for small children - terrible! The only bear that looks like it has it good is the grizzly bear because it has a whole new, humongous exhibit - which i feel is unfair for the other species of bears there. 

I thought polar bears came from the Arctic?!? Where is the ice???
author: Aber M.

description: Of all the organizations and museums of which I am a member, this is by far the most valuable. I have a 3 year old daughter who goes there at least once a week with her nanny. She gets so much out of it. She has taken toddler and preschooler classes there since she was 18 months old - the best classes you can get for the money. The new exhibits are fabulous and I love the improvements they are making on old ones. The Savanna, the Lemur Exhibit, the Grizzly Bears, and the Children's Zoo just to name a few are fantastic.
author: Amy M.

description: Sometimes it makes me sad to see African animals out in the cold since the zoo is next to the beach. The zoo is small enough to go through the whole thing in a few hours. The layout is alright and there are enough variety of zoo animals.
author: Retired B.

description: As a child, the zoo was a regular stop on the weekends. Dirty and cold, I think about it now, it wasn't very inviting. NOW - as an adult, WOW! They sure have made some major improvements! It's all pretty, and the animals look so happy. The food at the cafe place it awesome. The landscape is breathtaking - you have to experience it to believe it.....I love the zoo(sigh).
author: Jewel N.

description: Though it is embarrassing to our city, it's a great place for a 2nd or 3rd date for locals (who are SF Zoo virgins ;-). I took my partner there and we laughed and laughed (at how sad it was). And since you're a local (with proven ID) you get a discount w/ch makes it for a fun cheap date.
author: Chance K.

description: This place is perfect if you have kids. It has all of the essentials and a very intimate feel to it. I actually prefer this place over the SD zoo which is so huge and filled with millions of tourists.
author: Jaime G.

description: 3 stars for the penguins, sea otters, and the fact that the zoo was empty when i went=)
author: christy w.

description: I saw an elephant and maybe a horse, that's it. The SF zoo.
author: Kurosh H.

description: The giraffe/penguin exhibit was cool. I got to catch them at feeding time which was exciting. Many of the main exhibits were open, but many of the others were closed. I dont know why. The children's petting zoo was fun. Walking around you could see peacocks. The Zoo was okay, it wasnt as much as the San Diego zoo but it was good.
author: Ryan L.

description:
i hate to give any type of zoo or animal related place lower then 5 stars but...

i just recently moved to the city and the awesome family i nanny for have a zoo pass so i thought i would take advantage and take the beautiful baby to the zoo! well, i yelped it and that set my expectations low. well, they stayed that way. it was upsetting to see so many exhibits closed and/or covered up and the animals that had huge exhibits didn't need them or use them per se. the bears are in a cement area the size of a large studio apt but two pelicans (which i love since they are LA state bird!) have acres of pond and trees; it saddened me to see this. i am heavily involved in animal rescue in new orleans and have also been to many many zoos across the nation/world and for a city that is so environmentally "friendly" they sure dont know how to care for their animals. it was depressing to see and probably wont be going back. it was also weird to see all the donor's names by the entrance. all this money and who got to designate it? because obviously the bears saw nothing of this and neither did a lot of other animals there :(
author: Jenn A.

description: They changed the free first Wednesday of the month to include only San Francisco residents now, lame. When you have small children they only stay interested for an hour or so, and with the increase in prices I think they will scare a lot of people away.  $15 per adult?
author: Jon T.

description: Today was foggy, almost rainy.  A lot of animals were inside and not in view of the public. There's the preface. Here's the better part of my experience: the visiting children. They loved the place. At every exhibit, little kids were so excited to see the animals! If I had children, I'd bring them here.
author: Coco K.

description: I was amazed by how sparsely populated the zoo is.  And, by how small it is.  I expected a bit more.
author: Jeff P.

description: Sad sad sad.  I grew up in Sf and always loved the zoo.  I took my kids yesterday.  What a sad depressing mess.  The few new things were nice but its as if they let the rest of the zoo go to hell.  The landscaping is a mess and some of the animal enclosures are disgraceful.
author: Nicole P.

description:
Took my 1 year old son here for his first bday. Train was not running, big dissapointmrnt. Some animals looked depressed and lethargic. Grizzly Gulch was not all it was hyped up to be.

But I ended up paying for a family season pass anyway, which was definitly a bargain since I plan on coming back several times within the year. You get a 10% discount on food and gift shop. 2 free parking passes. 2 free tickets to give away. Unlimited children's entrance and parent entrance.

The chidlren's zoo, playground, and barn yard petting zoo me over, as these were all area's that my son enjoyed.
author: Ro F.

description: The SF Zoo is a fun family outing. We got the family membership.  It's an annual membership that gives free admission, ride, parking coupons.
author: Steve W.

description: Needs a TLC but it is a childhood to me. I love it and it has good intentions for the future. Great place for kids but i still enjoy learning. The docents are great.
author: Kristina H.

description: Maybe my memories of the Bronx Zoo are tainting my opinion of the SF Zoo, but most of it with the exception of the children's zoo and the exhibit at the right of the entrance with the giraffe, zebra.. seemed sort of sad. Didn't really enjoy it as much as I had hoped!
author: Jenny W.

description: What can you say? A zoo is a zoo right? This one just seemed really boring to both me and my son. We came here on April 1st this year. $15 for me and $9 for him. $8 for parking in their lot. We had planned to spend most of the day, but there just wasn't enough to do or see. So we ended up at Ocean Beach. I think it's time we check out Oakland Zoo again, haven't been there in years. But I remember it being more fun.
author: Jessica O.

description:
i thought i was in a mental institution for animals...
the warthog, anteater, polar bear and many other animals pace around the same patch of space in the small captivity space.  the other poor animals are either sleeping to escape their misery or are not even on display.
if i could give it negative stars, i would
T.T
author: Angela P.

description: If you had no stars that is what I would give.  I am a SF native who only now with a 4 year old grandchild decided to tackle the Zoo.  Absolutely terrible!!! 45% of the exhibits either look abandoned or say they are being renovated (so not just closed for the day)...Where are the seals, ELEPHANTS,hyppos,bison, monkey island, the petting zoo was just sheep & goats (although the goats are adorable), no rain forest (renovating)....the penguin feeding was a good, but the tigers playing/ feeding with dead bunnies was brutal...and because (my Grand Daughter's parent's are teachers, she handled better this better than most of us spectators). Basically I was so disappointed but my Grand Daughter said it all when I returned her home she said to her Parents...."I saw all the animals butts, when can we go back to the better zoo"  we asked her what better zoo..."Rain Forest Cafe"  sad very sad. We paid full price..TOURISTS TO SAN FRANCISCO DON'T BOTHER  The best deal $2.00 Carousel ride...the animals that are still there should be sent to better zoo's, since they can not be released.  This was awful!!!!! San Francisco should not be known for it's Zoo! SAD
author: Barbara M.

description: you call that a zoo.Half of the cages was empty and the ones with animal in it was sleeping. That wasn't the worst part the bathroom was disguisting
author: Nancy H.

description: not the best zoo in the world, but +1 star for being free on the first wednesday of every month. also, i had some good memories as a kid coming here on field trips bragging about having the blue elephant key and wondering what food to buy with the $10 in my pocket. they still have cool animals here and the petting zoo is always fun. those furry goats are hilarious. the sheep? not so much...
author: Andrew T.

description: allright - truth be told i pretty much grew up at the zoo. no, i wasn't raised by the gorillas...i just spent a chunk of my adolesence there. so, i will preface this by admitting that i am biased. i can say this, i have seen first hand how well the animals are cared for and truly loved and the education programs offerred by the zoo help to pass that care on to youth. yeah yeah, every zoo has an old exhibit or ten that need some work...but if the institution is treating its animals well and educating the public about conservation it has 5 stars in my book.
author: Jessa B.

description: ah, the zoo! what a wonderful way to spend a day gazing at animals.... the big cats and the monkeys are my favorite! i will admit though, the zoo in san diego is quite a bit better but i still like coming here.
author: Michelle I.

description: Although I don't really like the idea of keeping animals behind bars so we can have a look at them, the concept exists and we have to make the best of it.  That being said, I think the SF zoo is one of the best zoos I've ever visited, especially the renovated part (Africa trail and gorilla exhibit).  Special attention is provided to the vegetation and that shows, it's amazing.  Some other parts are still being renovated so they're a bit ugly at the moment.  I especially liked the fact that 'docents' were walking around and were prepared to give you some extra information, without being too 'pushy'.
author: Marijke D.

description: The zoo was larger than I thought. My 2 year old had a great time.  They need to keep the peacock confined to one area. Every where we went, we saw peacocks even in the pens of small animal. The peacocks were trying to eat the small animals which I did not like. Overall, if you have a few hours, take a stroll through the zoo. It's fun to see all the animals. The small petting area is great for kids.
author: Anonymous A.

description: those poor big cats, they hardly have room to stretch their legs.. this zoo is horribly depressing, if you care about the animals' quality of life this is not the place to go, the oakland zoo is more humane
author: sappho f.

description: Nice Zoo. Sucked because we went on a rainy day, all of the animals were hiding so we didnt get to see half of them.  The only thing that I didnt really like is they close at 5:00 and we went to the family petting zoo around 4:30 and they wouldnt let us in. was looking for more but overall it was an okay time.
author: joo l.

description: I was in one of those sentimental moods the other day looking at some pictures (you know the old school kind you put in photo albums, before the digital days) and I found a bunch of the kid at the zoo. This zoo used to really be a place my kid loved. We used to get a family annual pass which was only $60, so we went a lot.  We had our routine see the monkeys and then spend a good half hour in the petting zoo. Anyone who's been here knows those sheep get kinda frisky when they see you put a quarter in the feed vending machine. They had a great exhibit once, where for a couple of bucks they would give you a cup of nectar and set you into this great enclosure where all these parakeets would land on your arm to drink it.  It was always a great way to spend a nice day and eat a crappy overpriced hot dog. I miss those days. My heart goes out to everyone who was part of recent horrible tragedy. I miss you zoo and all the good times we had there.
author: Catherine D.

description: Before entering the human world I lived here and it wasn't bad. I will miss the peguines and the zebras but not the lions
author: Daisy S.

description: Our Zoo is pathetic. The Zoo in Philadelphia is like 100 times better. 2 stars for free day, close free parking , brown bear sisters, cheap prices(although maybe they should increase so more money will go to the animals habitats, food, etc.......). I have an obsession with Hippos, if you are every in New Jersey you must go to their Aquarium and you too may develop a love for them. The habitat they are provided with at the SF zoo is sickening, they have cement and a pool of dirty water. It is absolutely disgusting, and I vow that when I become rich I will sponsor their habitat. It is like a torture chamber and is a sorry excuse for a home, I challenge any employee at the zoo to live like that for a week. The pool is so small the hippo cant even swim, it can only emerge itself in the dirty water. Maybe I should have been a zoo keeper, or maybe i should be( note to self )............anyway..........the lone tiger in the first habitat by the bears looks extremely malnourished, I have never seen a tiger so skinny. The brown bear sisters are extremely cute though, they were play fighting in the water on their hind legs the last time I was there, it was adorable. They are trying, but not hard enough, this zoo is more like a jail, and it isn't right. I love to see animals, but not see them suffering, they all look sad. Hopefully one day I can make a difference........yay aspirations
author: Lorain C.

description: I remember when this zoo was owned by the city. It was better, because what kid doesn't like the zoo, but it was reasonably priced. There's no other game in town, really, but the prices are criminally outrageous. There's a discount for SF residents, but that makes it merely expensive.
author: David K.

description: don't bother.  go to San Diego.  the SF zoo is expensive and NOT people friendly.  we went at 10 AM Saturday.  Not only were many exhibits closed (tropical rain forest and too many others to list) but the lion house didn't open til 1 (nobody we asked was sure) and the animals were locked inside. we never saw snakes or elephants. the penguins had no water. there were many people working there riding around in their carts, but nobody was helpful.  the signage is non existent.  we wandered around trying to find the exit.  our granddaughter liked the playground best, until we came to the farm animals.  that was more like it. the animals were happy and friendly and being there saved the trip.
author: jill c.

description: two stars for the zoo, extra star because i got to go ice skating without an audience of tourists (like in union square). it's alright
author: kiki b.

description: Not the best zoo, but a decent place to take the kids. Can get pretty good discounts if you looki around (ie Entertainment Book, etc)
author: Michael S.

description:
I also like the Oakland zoo much better.....We went to the zoo yesterday and I noticed a spooky lack of zoo employees in certain regions.   Yes, it is true that here are some area's where there were very nice zoo volunteers/employees telling us about the birds or grizzly bears, but then when the train wasn't coming and we were trying to find somebody to ask about it, there was nobody in sight.  The guy working in the snack shack was pretending he didn't see us while refilling the french fries, though I'm sure he knows nothing about the train anyways....
    So about the train.  After watching "little puffer" the train  videos on you tube AND calling the zoo beforehand to make sure the train was running (i'm told it is), we arrive at the zoo and buy tickets for the the train.  We are told it opens at 11 or 11:30.  We wait....and wait.... and wait.... no employees, and the ones we find know nothing.   Finally we are told little puffer is not running, a mechanical problem.   Okay fine, these things happen.   Well, my 2 year old is basically at the zoo to go on little puffer and has been talking about it ALL DAY.  No apology, no sending somebody over to the train area to let people know it's not running... When I go to get a refund for my tickets on my way out, I am berated for not having the receipt... WHat?? I have the tickets.   You should be giving me free train tickets for sitting around waiting for little puffer for an hour and disappointing my son.   Shame on you SF ZOO.   I won't be back.
author: Lindsay P.

description: this place is cool! i always go here the first wednesday of the month to get in free! last time i went i FINALLY got to go to the petting zoo, which IMO is the best part of the zoo! they goats are terribly ugly, but they are fun to feed. also, the donkey was pretty friendly. in any case, well worth seeing if you're in the area, esp when it's the first wedsneday of the month!
author: Simon L.

description: I love animals - and I love going to the zoo - but it's the small exhibits or the exhibits with fewer visitors that make me feel bad. The Grizzly Gulch exhibit is cool - but why is 1/2 the exhibit sectioned off from the bears? It makes it look like they have all this room when really they don't at all. I always think to myself  - that's not natural for them, but then I remind myself most of these animals were abandoned or grew up in a zoo so they are probably better off than their prior situation. Anyway  - this being said the SF Zoo has some great areas.  There are also some areas that are hard to find.   It's not like this park is huge - but signage is not clear. Also - while I'm an adult - I think it's silly they charge you to get in the park and if you want to ride the train you have to pay again. Food - not so good - think cafeteria food from High School. All in all we had a great day - but the zoo does need work in some areas. Also - if your not from SF - may I suggest you bring a pair of jeans and a sweatshirt and not wear flip flops and shorts. SF does not get all that hot especially during the typical summer months- and this zoo is right by  Ocean Beach.  Once the fog rolls in - that's it... COLD - so be prepared (best weather months in SF are September-October). They have lockers at the zoo you can use to store your extras and if parking stinks - take the bus it drops you right in front of the park and only costs $1.50!
author: J S.

description: someone has to fix up the old fleishhacker pool building. this was a important place. could be great for a museum all about the zoo etc, maybe a resturant as well!!!!!!!!        ZOO LOOKS AND SMELLS ALOT BETTER NOW BUT IT IS EXPENSIVE TO GO NOW AND THEY STOPPED SELLING SOFT ICE CREAM CONES. USED TO BE CALLED SOFTIES! I THINK THEY ARE DOING A GOOD JOB FROM WHAT I CAN SEE BUT SOMETHING IS STILL NOT RIGHT WITH ME AND I CAN'T PUT A FINGER ON IT YET!!!!
author: RODGER B.

description:
This is kinda sad but I don't think that my family ever took me to the zoo when I was little. I heard it was the best back in the days.The first time I went I was probably 16 or maybe graduated from high school. Not too long ago.. prob 4-5 years since my first visit. Still it was pretty exciting for me but it wasn't what I expected. Prob cuz I wasn't a little kid. And we went on a free day which is when all the little children of the city come .. babies.. elementary kids... yeah. Pretty crowded. Kids running everywhere. Kids screaming trying to run for their lives away from the peacocks that were chasing them.... which is really really really funny to see/watch if you ask me. Almost more interesting than just viewing all the other animals [...such as the sad polar bears on the rocks or whatever sitting there in boredom ....and such as. haha]. Kids all up in my space when I wanted to go see an animal. 

There were also some closed exhibits which kinda sucked. But I actually don't know about how that is right now cuz... uhh the last time i went was more than a year and a half ago. =/

So yeah, if you decide to go here.. don't come on a free day. 
Bring a bag of food to eat or eat before because the prices of the food here are just too much and the food isn't even all that great.
Ooo... and you get a residents discount if you're from here and you show your I.D. .. or a student discount. I forget how much though.

If you find yourself bored after and have nothing at all to do .. walk the beach towards the cliff house!! =) teehee
author: Mila B.

description: I am from Southern Ca originally and this zoo has nothing on the LA zoo. It's small, not too many animals, the day we went there were no activities going on, and it's very expensive. But, they do have penguins, which is a plus.
author: Tricia B.

description: This zoo was blah to say the least.  One of the better things is that the zoo is easy to get to, and I didn't find parking to be a problem, plus it's only $5 to park in the lot.  One of the exhibits had tree branches with these dried up leaves and it was just obviously so old, while others had nice green ones.  There were also empty exhibit spaces with overgrown plants, and areas that were pretty dirty and unkept.  It was cute to see them peacocks walking around, though the staff should get people out there cleaning the walking grounds cuz them peacocks were eating dropped french fries and other foods they shouldn't have been eating.
