Take caution around the Lemur cafe, there are some seagulls outside the cafe that won't hesitate to literally get in your face.  Had it been Fall, I would've left the zoo early and headed to Ocean Beach across the street.  I probably would've had more fun there.
author: Rox M.

description: i don't mean to sound like an animal rights activists but let them go already all the animals look sad they either need some sex or to be replaced... i mean look a lion had to attack to get that out of its system.. it looks better now than it did 10 years ago but a lot of it is still no good.
author: T L.

description: I grew up in the Bay Area and the zoo was always one of my favorite places to go as a kid. I think money constraints must have hit it over the last few years. While they've been able to upgrade certain areas such as the primates, African exhibit, grizzly bear pair, a new baby giraffe, etc. they just don't seem to be able to upgrade the whole place overall.  From insects to large mammals to botanical treasures to most any thing you'd see at any zoo, you'll find it at the SF Zoo but I wouldn't rate it as my favorite zoo.  When my kids were little, we use to go on a specific day of the month when admission was free. Now that's a deal!
author: P G.

description: Why is it that both times I've been here, it appears that nearly 1/2 the exhibits are closed for renovation?  We dragged our small children around the whole place and they kept asking where the animals were.  Good question.  Also, paid to get into the new and much hyped bird exhibit in which you are given a food stick and parakeets are supposed to  land on you and feed.  Too bad none of the birds (hundreds) were hungry at all and we couldn't get even one to come near.   Did see lions having a quick shag, though, which was good for a laugh.  The Oakland zoo is better!
author: Ellen F.

description: excellent date spot! or maybe if you're bored and it happens to be the free day. otherwise, not much of a reason to go.
author: Jaei P.

description: honestly, i like zoos, but for some reason, i'm not a fan for this zoo too much. zoo is small, food is expensive, and theres not that much animals. weak!
author: Valerie N.

description:
I love this Zoo! I love zoos. Its one of the first spot I hit when I have to discover a new city. While it was hardly one of the first spots I hit , the zoo was well worth the anticipation. Perhaps the fact that the weather was seriously agreeable when I visited has a lot to do with my experience .
The facilities are  conveniently located. I think thats critical to a pleasant day out. Also there are plenty of maps etc, not that they would help me much if I were alone. I not so good with maps you see......I am working on it .For now I am a GPS kinda gal.
There is a nice gift store, very cute place . Its nice to be able to buy things for other people's kids till one has one's own. Also they have good programs for kids and campers , I mean in theoretically anyways, as I haven't tried either. When I do I shall yelp 
The Polar bears look so unhappy though. That was a downside. In general the experience has a melancholy undercurrent , 'cuz one is essentially visiting prisoners. I try not to dwell on it. 
I am going back there as soon as I can. There is much to be discovered. When you go there please give out a positive vibe the animals need it. I am positive it will help them.
Also  just to let you know the peacocks enjoy  free range  privilege  , they are super  cute !
author: M p.

description: My friend just had her wedding here at the zoo.  Having it at the zoo gave it a toally different and really fun atmosphere.  The wedding was outside, and so was the cocktail hour.  During the cocktail hour, the zoo had about 5 small animals out for the guests to pet and learn about.    Everything was beautiful and it was a great experience.  If I could copy her for my wedding I would.  I am taking a star away though since the "bridal" room was really a small conference room. I didn't feel really safe leaving my belongings in there.
author: suzanne f.

description: Just went to the zoo for the second time ever. First time was ok since it was new to me. This time around, half the exhibits seemed closed. Tough to find any animals to even look at. The place doesn't look like it's being maintained and I think we saw one zoo employee/volunteer the whole time we were there.
author: Pablo P.

description: I haven't been to the SF zoo in a long time and now I know why.  The bathrooms are filthy and they have only made cosmetic changes around the entrance to the zoo.  The old exhibits are still run down and the train for $4.00 is a rip-off.  There weren't that many animals out on display during the middle of the afternoon.  On a cold day like yesterday, you better dress warmly as all of the exhibits are outdoors and it was freezing.
author: Brian L.

description: Pretty lame place.  There are hardly much animals around.  I take my son there only during the once a month free day.  And of those animals around, they look so old and tired.  If you've checked out the San Diego Zoo, this place is sad in comparison.
author: Amy V.

description: I just think zoos are very sad places.  The vast majority of animals barely move.  They are living way outside their natural habitats and many have health and reproductive problems.  The San Francisco zoo is no different.  It's so funny to think about how much enjoyment the zoo brings as a child, but as you get older, you simply have no interest whatsoever in seeing animals locked up in small prisons.  As stupid as it sounds, one need only watch the old planet of the apes movie to see the absurdity of the modern zoo ideology.  We should be encouraging the restoration of natural animal habitat as a means of enjoying wild animals, not paying $10 to see a locked up tiger.  I know I probably sound like some crazy animal rights activist.  I'm not.  I just don't like seeing animals locked up in cages or small artificial cement pens.  Not my idea of the wild.  Don't get me wrong.  The SF zoo does have several more natural settings for the animals.  And I suspect most zoos are moving more in that direction.  Still, I think all zoos should be closed and the resources spent on other means of seeing animals in their wild habitat.
author: AMY Y.
